original: Suhadayoti sundaracitto hitacittako. Nudāti nīhara. Nivesananti lakkhiyā pana nivesanaṃ
analyzed: su hadayaḥ iti sundara cittaḥ hita cittakaḥ nuda ati nīhara nivesananti lakkhiyā pana nivesanam
translated: Suhadayo means one with a good heart, a kind heart. Nudāti means take away. Nivesana means a house built according to the rules.

original: bhava patiṭṭhā hohi. Sa lakkhīdhitisampannoti, mahārāja, kāsipati so puriso paññāya
analyzed: bhava patiṭṭhā hohi sa lakkhīdhiti sampanno ti mahā rāja kāsipati so puriso paññāya
translated: Be a support for existence. Sa lakkhīdhitisampanno means, great king, that man, the lord of Kāsi, was endowed with wisdom

original: ceva vīriyena ca sampanno. Mahaggatoti mahajjhāsayo corānaṃ paccayabhūte gaṇhanto
analyzed: ca iva vīriyena ca sampannaḥ mahaggataḥ ti mahajjhāsayaḥ corānam paccaya bhūte gaṇhanto
translated: and energy. Mahaggato means one with great desires. Taking the conditions of thieves,

original: amittānaṃ mūlaṃ core gaṇhanto amittānaṃ aggaṃ chindatīti vadati. Sakkoti indo. Bhūtapatīti
analyzed: amittānam mūlam core gaṇhantaḥ amittānam aggam chindati iti vadati sakkoti indo bhūta pati iti
translated: he says he cuts off the head of enemies by taking the root of thieves, the head of enemies. Sakkoti means he is able. Inda means Indra. Bhūtapatī means

original: rājānaṃ ālapati. Uṭṭhāneti uṭṭhānavīriye. Nappamajjatīti na pamajjati, sabbakiccāni
analyzed: rājānam ālapati uṭṭhāne iti uṭṭhāna vīriye na ppamajjati iti na pamajjati sabba kiccāni
translated: he addresses the king. Uṭṭhāneti means in the energy of rising up. Nappamajjatī means he does not neglect, he does all his duties.

original: karoti. Sa kalyāṇeti so devarājā uṭṭhānavīriye manaṃ karonto pāpakammaṃ akatvā kalyāṇe
analyzed: karoti sa kalyāṇe iti saḥ devarājā uṭṭhāna vīriye manam karonto pāpa kammam a katvā kalyāṇe
translated: Sa kalyāṇe means that god-king, making his mind in the energy of rising up, not doing evil deeds, making steadfastness in good

original: puññakammasmiññeva dhitiṃ katvā appamatto uṭṭhāne manaṃ karoti, tassa pana kalyāṇakamme
analyzed: puñña kammasmin ñeva dhitim katvā appamattaḥ uṭṭhāne manam karoti tassa pana kalyāṇa kamme
translated: deeds and merit alone, being heedful, makes his mind in rising up. In order to show the state of doing deeds of merit by him,

original: vīriyakaraṇabhāvadassanatthaṃ sarabhaṅgajātake dvīsu devalokesu devatāhi saddhiṃ
analyzed: vīriya karaṇa bhāva dassana attham sarabhaṅga jātake dvīsu deva lokesu devatāhi saddhiṃ
translated: in the Sarabhaṅga Jātaka, together with the gods in two god-realms,

original: kapiṭṭhārāmaṃ āgantvā pañhaṃ pucchitvā dhammassa sutabhāvo, mahākaṇhajātake attano
analyzed: kapiṭṭha ārāmam āgantvā pañham pucchitvā dhammassa suta bhāvaḥ mahākaṇha jātake attano
translated: and after going to the Piṭṭha Rāma Hermitage, he asked a question and heard the Dhamma, in the Mahākaṇha Jātaka he gave up his own🔽

original: ānubhāvena janaṃ tāsetvā osakkantassa sāsanassa pavattitabhāvo cāti evamādīni vatthūni kathetabbāni.
analyzed: ānubhāvena janam tāsetvā osakkantassa sāsanassa pavattita bhāvo ca ati evamādīni vatthūni kathetabbāni
translated: and the fact that he went to the Piṭṭhi River, asked a question, and found out that the Dhamma had been well-learned, and the fact that in the Mahākaṇha Jātaka he frightened the people with his own power and then made them enter the Dispensation.

original: Gandhabbāti cātumahārājikānaṃ heṭṭhā catuyonikā devā, catuyonikattāyeva kira te gandhabbā
analyzed: gandhabbā ati cātumahārājikānam heṭṭhā catu yonikāḥ devā catu yonika ttāya iva kira te gandhabbā
translated: Gandhabbas: gods of the four-fold generation below the Four Great Kings. They are called gandhabbas because they have four modes of generation.

original: nāma jātā. Pitaroti brahmāno. Devāti upapattidevavasena cha kāmāvacaradevā. Tādinoti
analyzed: nāma jātā pitaraḥ iti brahmānaḥ devā ati upapatti deva vasena cha kāmāvacara devā
translated: Pitaro: Brahmās. Devā: the six gods of the sense sphere, according to the method of rebirth. Tādino: of such a kind.

original: tathāvidhassa kusalābhiratassa rañño. Sājīvā hontīti samānajīvikā upajīvitabbā. Tādisā
analyzed: tathāvidhassa kusala abhiratassa raññaḥ sa ājīvāḥ honti iti samāna jīvikā upajīvitabbā tādisā
translated: Rājā: a king who delights in merit. Sājīvā hontīti: they have the same livelihood. They are to be supported.

original: hi rājāno dānādīni puññāni karontā devatānaṃ pattiṃ denti, tā taṃ pattiṃ anumoditvā
analyzed: hi rājānaḥ dāna ādīni puññāni karontāḥ devatānam pattim denti tāḥ tam pattim anumoditvā
translated: Such kings, when they perform meritorious deeds such as giving, give the merit to the gods. The gods rejoice in that merit and accept it.

original: sampaṭicchitvā dibbayasena vaḍḍhanti. Anutiṭṭhantīti tādisassa rañño vīriyaṃ karontassa
analyzed: sampaṭicchitvā dibba yasena vaḍḍhanti anutiṭṭhanti iti tādisassa raññaḥ vīriyam karontassa
translated: They increase in divine power. Anutiṭṭhantīti: when such a king exerts himself,

original: appamādaṃ āpajjantassa devatā anutiṭṭhanti anugacchanti, dhammikaṃ rakkhaṃ saṃvidahantīti attho.
analyzed: appamādam āpajjantassa devatāḥ anutiṭṭhanti anugacchanti dhammikam rakkham saṃvidahanti iti attho
translated: and the gods will attend on and follow him who is heedful, and will provide him with righteous protection.

original: Soti so tvaṃ. Vāyamassūti tāni raṭṭhakiccāni karonto tulanavasena tīraṇavasena paccakkhakammavasena
analyzed: saḥ iti saḥ tvam tāni raṭṭha kiccāni karontaḥ tulana vasena tīraṇa vasena paccakkha kamma vasena
translated: So: you. Strive: while doing those duties of the realm, you should strive with the means of weighing, with the means of examining, with the means of direct knowledge,

original: tesu tesu kiccesu vīriyaṃ karassu. Tattheva te vattapadāti, tāta, yaṃ maṃ tvaṃ kiṃsu
analyzed: tesu tesu kiccesu vīriyam karassu tattha iva te vatta padāti tāta yam mama tvam
translated: with the means of direct action, with the means of the various duties. There itself are the steps of the practice: dear sir, the duties that I asked you,

original: kiccaṃ kataṃ varanti pucchi, tattha tava pañheyeva ete mayā “paṭhameneva vitatha”ntiādayo
analyzed: kiccam katam pucchi tattha tava ete mayā paṭhamena iva vitatha nti ādayaḥ
translated: “What is the duty done that is best?” there, these very questions of yours were spoken by me with the words “The first is false,”

original: vuttā, ete vattapadā vattakoṭṭhāsā, evaṃ tattha vattassu. Esāti yā te mayā kathitā,
analyzed: vuttāḥ ete vatta padāḥ vatta koṭṭhāsāḥ evam tattha vattassu esā ati yā te mayā kathitā
translated: and so on. These are the steps of the practice, the sections of the practice, thus you should practice there. This: this very instruction that was spoken by me to you,

original: esāva tava anusāsanī. Alanti evaṃ vattamāno hi rājā attano mitte sukhāpetuṃ, amittānañca
analyzed: tava anusāsanī evam vattamānaḥ hi rājā attanaḥ mitte amittānam ca
translated: this is your instruction. Enough: for a king who acts thus is able to make his friends happy and his enemies

original: dukkhāya alaṃ pariyatto samatthoti.
analyzed: dukkhāya alam pariyatto samatthaḥ ti
translated: unhappy.

original: Evaṃ vessantarasakuṇena ekāya gāthāya rañño pamādaṃ codetvā ekādasahi gāthāhi dhamme
analyzed: evam vessantara sakuṇena ekāya gāthāya rañño pamādam codetvā ekādasahi gāthāhi dhamme
translated: Thus, having rebuked the king’s heedlessness with one verse, with eleven verses the bird Vessavana

original: kathite “buddhalīḷāya pañho kathito”ti mahājano acchariyabbhutacittajāto sādhukārasatāni
analyzed: kathite buddha līḷāya pañho kathito ti mahā janaḥ sādhukāra satāni
translated: When it was told, the great crowd, thinking that the question was asked in a manner befitting a Buddha, was filled with wonder and amazement, and they shouted out a hundred cries of “bravo!”

original: pavattesi. Rājā somanassappatto amacce āmantetvā pucchi – “bhonto! Amaccā mama puttena
analyzed: pavattesi rājā somanassappattaḥ amacce āmantetvā pucchi bhontaḥ amaccāḥ mama puttena
translated: The king was delighted, and he summoned his ministers and asked them, “Gentlemen, what should be done for my son,

original: vessantarena evaṃ kathentena kena kattabbaṃ kiccaṃ kata”nti. Mahāsenaguttena, devāti.
analyzed: vessantarena evam kathentena kena kattabbam kiccam katanti mahāsena guttena deva ati
translated: the merchant Vessantara, who has spoken thus?” “Your majesty, he should be given the rank of Mahāsenagutta.”

original: “Tena hissa mahāsenaguttaṭṭhānaṃ dammī”ti vessantaraṃ ṭhānantare ṭhapesi. So tato
analyzed: tena hi ssa mahāsena gutta ṭṭhānam dammi iti vessantaram ṭhāna antare ṭhapesi saḥ tatas
translated: “Then I give him the rank of Mahāsenagutta,” said the king, and he appointed Vessantara to a new office.

original: paṭṭhāya mahāsenaguttaṭṭhāne ṭhito pitu kammaṃ akāsīti.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya mahāsena gutta ṭṭhāne ṭhito pitu kammaṃ akāsi iti
translated: From that time on, while still holding the rank of Mahāsenagutta, he performed the duties of his father’s office.

original: Vessantarapañho niṭṭhito.
analyzed: vessantara pañhaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The question of Vessantara is concluded.

original: Puna rājā katipāhaccayena purimanayeneva kuṇḍaliniyā santikaṃ dūtaṃ pesetvā sattame
analyzed: punar rājā kati pāhaccayena purima nayena iva kuṇḍaliniyā santikam dūtam pesetvā sattame
translated: Again, after a few days, the king sent a messenger to Kuṇḍalī in the same manner as before, and on the seventh day

original: divase tattha gantvā paccāgantvā tattheva maṇḍapamajjhe nisīditvā kuṇḍaliniṃ āharāpetvā
analyzed: divase tattha gantvā paccāgantvā tattha iva maṇḍapa majjhe nisīditvā kuṇḍalinim āharāpetvā
translated: he went there, returned, and sat down in the middle of the pavilion as before. He had Kuṇḍalī brought to him,

original: suvaṇṇapīṭhe nisinnaṃ rājadhammaṃ pucchanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: suvaṇṇa pīṭhe nisinnam rājadhammam pucchantaḥ gātham āha
translated: and while she was sitting on a golden couch, he asked her about the duties of a king and spoke this verse:

original: “Sakkhisi tvaṃ kuṇḍalini, maññasi khattabandhuni;
analyzed: sakkhisi tvam kuṇḍalini maññasi khatta bandhuni
translated: “Can you, O Kundalini, think, O Khattabandhu’s daughter,

original: Rajjaṃ kāretukāmena, kiṃ su kiccaṃ kataṃ vara”nti.
analyzed: rajjam kāretu kāmena kim su kiccam katam varanti
translated: What deed was done by one who wishes to rule, O best of women?”

original: Tattha sakkhisīti mayā puṭṭhapañhaṃ kathetuṃ sakkhissasīti pucchati. Kuṇḍalinīti🔽tassā saliṅgato āgatanāmenālapati. Tassā kira dvīsu kaṇṇapiṭṭhesu kuṇḍalasaṇṭhānā🔽dve lekhā ahesuṃ, tenassā “kuṇḍalinī”ti nāmaṃ kāresi. Maññasīti jānissasi mayā puṭṭhapañhassa
analyzed: tattha sakkhisi iti mayā puṭṭha pañham kathetum sakkhissasi iti pucchati kuṇḍalinī iti  tassā sa liṅgataḥ āgata nāmena ālapati tassā kira dvīsu kaṇṇa piṭṭhesu kuṇḍala saṇṭhānā  dve lekhāḥ ahesum tena assā kuṇḍalinī iti nāmam kāresi maññasi iti jānissasi mayā puṭṭha pañhassa
translated: Herein, can you means can you tell the question asked by me. Kundalini means🔽she is addressed by her name which is derived from her sign. It is said that on the two sides of her ears there were two lines shaped like earrings,

original: atthanti. Khattabandhunīti khattassa mahāsenaguttassa bhaginibhāvena naṃ evaṃ ālapati.
analyzed: khatta bandhunī iti khattassa mahāsena guttassa bhagini bhāvena naṃ evam ālapati
translated: therefore her name was made “Kundalini.” Think means you will know the meaning of the question asked by me. Khattabandhu’s daughter means she is addressed as the sister of Khatta, the guardian of the great army.

original: Kasmā panesa vessantarasakuṇaṃ evaṃ apucchitvā imameva pucchatīti? Itthibhāvena.
analyzed: kasmā pana isa vessantara sakuṇam evam a pucchitvā imam eva pucchati iti itthi bhāvena
translated: But why did he ask the bird Vessantara in this way and ask her alone? Because of her being a woman.

original: Itthiyo hi parittapaññā, tasmā “sace sakkoti, pucchissāmi, no ce, na pucchissāmī”ti
analyzed: itthiyaḥ hi paritta paññā tasmā sace sakkoti pucchissāmi no ce na pucchissāmi iti
translated: For women are of little wisdom, therefore “if she can, I will ask, if not, I will not ask,”

original: vīmaṃsanavasena evaṃ pucchitvā taññeva pañhaṃ pucchi.
analyzed: vīmaṃsana vasena evam pucchitvā taññeva pañham pucchi
translated: after asking in this way for the sake of testing, he asked her the same question.

original: Sā evaṃ raññā rājadhamme pucchite, “tāta, tvaṃ maṃ ‘itthikā nāma kiṃ kathessatī’ti vīmaṃsasi maññe, sakalaṃ te rājadhammaṃ dvīsuyeva padesu pakkhipitvā kathessāmī”ti vatvā āha –
analyzed: sā evam raññā rājadhamme pucchite tāta tvam mama itthikā nāma kim kathessati iti vīmaṃsasi maññe sakalam te rājadhammam dvīsu yeva padesu pakkhipitvā kathessāmi iti vatvā āha
translated: When the king had thus questioned her about the duties of a king, she said, “Dear, I suppose you are testing me, thinking, ‘What can a woman know?’ I will include all the duties of a king in two sections and tell you.”🔽“There are two words, dear,

original: “Dveva tāta padakāni, yattha sabbaṃ patiṭṭhitaṃ;
analyzed: dve iva tāta padakāni yattha sabbam patiṭṭhitam
translated: In which everything is included:🔽The acquisition of what has not been acquired,

original: Aladdhassa ca yo lābho, laddhassa cānurakkhaṇā.
analyzed: a laddhassa ca yaḥ lābhaḥ laddhassa ca anurakkhaṇā
translated: And the protection of what has been acquired.🔽“Appoint as your ministers, dear,

original: “Amacce tāta jānāhi, dhīre atthassa kovide;
analyzed: amacce tāta jānāhi dhīre atthassa kovide
translated: Wise men who are skilled in business,🔽Who are not greedy, dear,

original: Anakkhākitave tāta, asoṇḍe avināsake.
analyzed: anakkhā kitave tāta a soṇḍe a vināsake
translated: And who are not corrupters.🔽“He who would protect you, dear,

original: “Yo ca taṃ tāta rakkheyya, dhanaṃ yañceva te siyā;
analyzed: yaḥ ca tam tāta rakkheyya dhanam yat ca iva te siyā
translated: And your wealth,🔽Should be appointed as your charioteer;

original: Sūtova rathaṃ saṅgaṇhe, so te kiccāni kāraye.
analyzed: sūtaḥ uva ratham saṅgaṇhe saḥ te kiccāni kāraye
translated: He should be your chief minister.🔽“He who has a well-disciplined retinue,

original: “Susaṅgahitantajano, sayaṃ vittaṃ avekkhiya;
analyzed: sayam vittam avekkhiya
translated: Who looks after his own wealth,🔽Who does not engage in hoarding and in debt,

original: Nidhiñca iṇadānañca, na kare parapattiyā.
analyzed: nidhim ca iṇa dānam ca na kare parapattiyā
translated: Should not be dismissed by you.🔽“He who knows his income and expenditure,

original: “Sayaṃ āyaṃ vayaṃ jaññā, sayaṃ jaññā katākataṃ;
analyzed: sayam āyam vayam jaññā sayam jaññā kata akatam
translated: Who knows what has been done and what has not been done,🔽Should restrain those who should be restrained,

original: Niggaṇhe niggahārahaṃ, paggaṇhe paggahārahaṃ.
analyzed: niggaṇhe niggaha araham paggaṇhe paggaha araham
translated: And encourage those who should be encouraged.

original: “Sayaṃ jānapadaṃ atthaṃ, anusāsa rathesabha;
analyzed: sayam jānapadam attham anusāsa rathesabha
translated: “He who knows the country, dear,

original: Mā te adhammikā yuttā, dhanaṃ raṭṭhañca nāsayuṃ.
analyzed: mā te adhammikāḥ yuttāḥ dhanam raṭṭham ca na āsayum
translated: Let not unrighteous wretches, who destroy wealth and kingdom, be your companions.

original: “Mā ca vegena kiccāni, karosi kārayesi vā;
analyzed: mā ca vegena kiccāni karosi kārayesi vā
translated: Do not do or cause to be done any business in haste.

original: Vegasā hi kataṃ kammaṃ, mando pacchānutappati.
analyzed: vegasā hi katam kammam mandaḥ pacchā anutappati
translated: For a deed done in haste is regretted afterwards.

original: “Mā te adhisare muñca, subāḷhamadhikopitaṃ;
analyzed: mā te adhisare muñca su bāḷham adhi kopitam
translated: Do not let those who are your superiors go free when they have offended you.

original: Kodhasā hi bahū phītā, kulā akulataṃ gatā.
analyzed: kodhasā hi bahū phītā kulā a kulatam gatā
translated: For it is through anger that many prosperous families have come to ruin.

original: “‘Mā tāta issaromhī’ti, anatthāya patārayi;
analyzed: mā tāta issaromhi iti anatthāya patārayi
translated: Do not, thinking ‘I am a king,’ bring about your own destruction.

original: Itthīnaṃ purisānañca, mā te āsi dukhudrayo.🔽“Apetalomahaṃsassa, rañño kāmānusārino;
analyzed: itthīnam purisānam ca mā te āsi  apeta lomahaṃsassa raññaḥ kāma anusārinaḥ
translated: Let not your anger be a source of sorrow to men and women.🔽For all the wealth of the king who follows his desires, like the king of the geese without a white breast, will perish.

original: Sabbe bhogā vinassanti, rañño taṃ vuccate aghaṃ.
analyzed: sabbe bhogāḥ vinassanti raññaḥ tat vuccate agham
translated: This is said to be the king’s crime.

original: “Tattheva te vattapadā, esāva anusāsanī;
analyzed: tattha iva te vatta padāḥ anusāsanī
translated: These are the rules of conduct right there, this is the instruction:

original: Dakkhassudāni puññakaro, asoṇḍo avināsako;
analyzed: dakkhassudāni puñña karaḥ a soṇḍaḥ a vināsakaḥ
translated: Now the righteous man who does good, the generous man who does not destroy,

original: Sīlavāssu mahārāja, dussīlo vinipātiko”ti.
analyzed: sīla vāssu mahā rāja dussīlaḥ vinipātikaḥ iti
translated: the virtuous man, great king, but the unvirtuous man is ruined.”

original: Tattha padakānīti kāraṇapadāni. Yatthāti yesu dvīsu padesu sabbaṃ atthajātaṃ hitasukhaṃ
analyzed: tattha padakāni iti kāraṇa padāni yattha ati yesu dvīsu padesu sabbam attha jātam hita sukham
translated: Herein, the reasons are the reasons for the two places where all profitable things are established, namely,

original: patiṭṭhitaṃ. Aladdhassāti yo ca pubbe aladdhassa lābhassa lābho, yā ca laddhassa
analyzed: patiṭṭhitam a laddhassa ati yaḥ ca pubbe a laddhassa lābhassa lābhaḥ yā ca laddhassa
translated: for the gain of what was not gained before and for the preservation of what was gained.

original: anurakkhaṇā. Tāta, anuppannassa hi lābhassa uppādanaṃ nāma na bhāro, uppannassa pana
analyzed: anurakkhaṇā tāta anuppannassa hi lābhassa uppādanam nāma na bhāraḥ uppannassa pana
translated: Protection. For it is not a burden to produce what has not been produced. But it is a burden

original: anurakkhaṇameva bhāro. Ekacco hi yasaṃ uppādetvāpi yase pamatto pamādaṃ uppādetvā
analyzed: anurakkhaṇam eva bhāraḥ ekaccaḥ hi yasam uppādetvā api yase pamattaḥ pamādam uppādetvā
translated: to protect what has been produced. For some people, though they have produced fame, are careless about it, and through carelessness

original: pāṇātipātādīni karoti, mahācoro hutvā raṭṭhaṃ vilumpamāno carati. Atha naṃ rājāno
analyzed: pāṇa atipāta ādīni karoti mahā coraḥ hutvā raṭṭham vilumpamāno carati atha nam rājāno
translated: they commit killing living beings, etc., and they become great thieves who go about robbing the country. Then the kings

original: gāhāpetvā mahāvināsaṃ pāpenti. Atha vā uppannarūpādīsu kāmaguṇesu pamatto ayoniso
analyzed: gāhāpetvā mahā vināsam pāpenti atha vā uppanna rūpa ādīsu kāma guṇesu pamattaḥ ayonisaḥ
translated: have them caught and destroy them in various ways. Or else, careless about the forms, etc., that have arisen as objects of sensual desire, they

original: dhanaṃ nāsento sabbasāpateyye khīṇe kapaṇo hutvā cīrakavasano kapālamādāya carati.🔽Pabbajito vā pana ganthadhurādivasena lābhasakkāraṃ nibbattetvā pamatto hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: dhanam na āsento sabba sāpateyye khīṇe kapaṇaḥ hutvā cīraka vasanaḥ kapālam ādāya carati  pabbajitaḥ vā pana gantha dhura ādi vasena lābha sakkāram nibbattetvā pamattaḥ hīnāya avattati
translated: squander their wealth, and when all their property is exhausted, they become paupers, wander about in rags with their hair disheveled, carrying their few belongings in their hands.🔽Or else, though they have produced gain and honor by means of the recitation of the scriptures, etc., they are careless and turn to the secular life.

original: Aparo paṭhamajhānādīni nibbattetvāpi muṭṭhassatitāya tathārūpe ārammaṇe bajjhitvā
analyzed: aparaḥ paṭhama jhāna ādīni nibbattetvā api muṭṭha ssati tāya tathārūpe ārammaṇe bajjhitvā
translated: Or else, though they have produced the first jhāna, etc., they are forgetful and, being obsessed with such ideas as “I am,”

original: jhānā parihāyati. Evaṃ uppannassa yasassa vā jhānādilābhassa vā rakkhaṇameva dukkaraṃ.
analyzed: evam uppannassa yasassa vā jhāna ādi lābhassa vā rakkhaṇam eva dukkaram
translated: they fall away from the jhāna. So it is hard to protect the fame that has been produced or the gain of jhāna, etc.

original: Tadatthadīpanatthaṃ pana devadattassa vatthu ca, mudulakkhaṇa- lomasakassapa- haritacajātaka-
analyzed: tad attha dīpana ttham pana devadattassa vatthu ca mudu lakkhaṇa lomasa kassapa
translated: In order to illustrate this, the story of Devadatta, the story of the monk with the soft hair, the story of the Hare-horn,

original: saṅkappajātakādīni ca kathetabbāni. Eko pana lābhasakkāraṃ uppādetvā appamāde ṭhatvā
analyzed: saṅkappa jātaka ādīni ca kathetabbāni ekaḥ pana lābha sakkāram uppādetvā appamāde ṭhatvā
translated: the story of the Thought, and so on, should be told. But one man, having produced gain and honour, stands firm in heedfulness,

original: kalyāṇakammaṃ karoti, tassa so yaso sukkapakkhe cando viya vaḍḍhati, tasmā tvaṃ,
analyzed: kalyāṇa kammam karoti tassa saḥ yasaḥ sukka pakkhe candaḥ viya vaḍḍhati tasmai tvam
translated: and does good deeds. His fame increases like the moon in the bright fortnight. Therefore,

original: mahārāja, appamatto payogasampattiyā ṭhatvā dhammena rajjaṃ kārento tava uppannaṃ
analyzed: mahā rāja appamattaḥ payoga sampattiyā ṭhatvā dhammena rajjam kārento tava uppannam
translated: great king, you, being heedful, standing firm in the perfection of application, ruling the kingdom righteously,

original: yasaṃ anurakkhāhīti.🔽Jānāhīti bhaṇḍāgārikakammādīnaṃ karaṇatthaṃ upadhārehi. Anakkhākitaveti anakkhe akitave
analyzed: yasam anurakkhāhi iti  jānāhi iti bhaṇḍāgārika kamma ādīnam karaṇa attham upadhārehi anakkha akitave ti anakkhe a kitave
translated: should protect the fame that has arisen to you.

original: ajutakare ceva akerāṭike ca. Asoṇḍeti pūvasurāgandhamālāsoṇḍabhāvarahite. Avināsaketi
analyzed: ca iva akerāṭike ca asoṇḍā iti pūva surā gandha mālā soṇḍa bhāva rahite avināsakā iti
translated: Know: in order to do the work of the treasurer and so on, you should consider. Not a gambler: not one who plays with dice. Not a drunkard: not one who is addicted to drinking liquor, perfume, and garlands. Not a wastrel:

original: tava santakānaṃ dhanadhaññādīnaṃ avināsake. Yoti yo amacco. Yañcevāti yañca te ghare
analyzed: tava santakānam dhana dhañña ādīnam avināsake yaḥ uti yaḥ amaccaḥ yat ca iva ati yat ca te ghare
translated: not one who squanders your wealth, grain, and so on. Whoever: whoever is a minister. And whatever: and whatever is in your house,

original: dhanaṃ siyā, taṃ rakkheyya. Sūtovāti rathasārathi viya. Yathā sārathi visamamagganivāraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: dhanam siyā tam rakkheyya sūtaḥ uvāti ratha sārathi viya yathā sārathi visama magga nivāraṇa attham
translated: He may be wealthy, but he should guard it. The learned: like a charioteer. Just as a charioteer controls the horses in order to avoid rough roads,

original: asse saṅgaṇhanto rathaṃ saṅgaṇheyya, evaṃ yo saha bhogehi taṃ rakkhituṃ sakkoti,
analyzed: asse saṅgaṇhantaḥ ratham saṅgaṇheyya evam yaḥ saha bhogehi tam rakkhitum sakkoti
translated: so he who can guard it together with the wealth,

original: so te amacco nāma tādisaṃ saṅgahetvā bhaṇḍāgārikādikiccāni kāraye.
analyzed: saḥ te amaccaḥ nāma tādisam saṅgahetvā bhaṇḍāgārika ādi kiccāni kāraye
translated: he is a minister. Having appointed such a one, he should have him do the duties of the treasurer and so on.

original: Susaṅgahitantajanoti, tāta, yassa hi rañño attano antojano attano valañjanakaparijano
analyzed: tāta yassa hi raññaḥ attanaḥ antojanaḥ attanaḥ valañjanaka parijanaḥ
translated: Well-guarded people: if a king’s own people, his own retinue,

original: ca dānādīhi asaṅgahito hoti, tassa antonivesane suvaṇṇahiraññādīni tesaṃ asaṅgahitamanussānaṃ
analyzed: ca dāna ādīhi asaṅgahitaḥ hoti tassa antar nivesane suvaṇṇa hirañña ādīni tesam asaṅgahita manussānam
translated: are not well-guarded by gifts and so on, then in his inner palace gold, silver, and so on are lost because of those unguarded people,

original: vasena nassanti, antojanā bahi gacchanti, tasmā tvaṃ suṭṭhusaṅgahitaantojano hutvā
analyzed: vasena nassanti antojanāḥ bahi gacchanti tasmai tvam suṭṭhu saṅgahita antojanaḥ hutvā
translated: and his inner people go outside. Therefore, being well-guarded yourself,

original: “ettakaṃ nāma me vitta”nti sayaṃ attano dhanaṃ avekkhitvā “asukaṭṭhāne nāma nidhiṃ
analyzed: ettakam nāma me vittanti sayam attanaḥ dhanam avekkhitvā asukaṭṭhāne nāma nidhim
translated: “I have this much wealth” and looking at your own wealth, “I will bury treasure in such and such a place,

original: nidhema, asukassa iṇaṃ demā”ti idaṃ ubhayampi na kare parapattiyā, parapattiyāpi
analyzed: nidhema asukassa iṇam dema ati idam ubhayam pi na kare parapattiyā parapattiyā api
translated: I will give a loan to such and such a person,” do not do both of these because of another’s gain, and because of another’s gain

original: tvaṃ mā kari, sabbaṃ attapaccakkhameva kareyyāsīti vadati.
analyzed: tvam mā kari sabbam atta paccakkham eva kareyyāsi iti vadati
translated: “You should not do that. You should do everything yourself.”

original: Āyaṃ vayanti tato uppajjanakaṃ āyañca tesaṃ tesaṃ dātabbaṃ vayañca sayameva jāneyyāsīti.
analyzed: āyam vayanti tatas uppajjanakam āyam ca tesam tesam dātabbam vayam ca sayam eva jāneyyāsi iti
translated: “You should know the income and the expenditure that arise from that.

original: Katākatanti saṅgāme vā navakamme vā aññesu vā kiccesu “iminā idaṃ nāma mayhaṃ kataṃ,
analyzed: kata akatam ti saṅgāme vā nava kamme vā aññesu vā kiccesu iminā idam nāma mayham katam
translated: “‘What has been done and what has not been done’: In battle, in building work, and in other activities, you should know for yourself ‘This has been done for me by this person,

original: iminā na kata”nti etampi sayameva jāneyyāsi, mā parapattiyo hohi. Niggaṇheti, tāta,🔽rājā nāma sandhicchedādikārakaṃ niggahārahaṃ ānetvā dassitaṃ upaparikkhitvā sodhetvā
analyzed: iminā na etam pi sayam eva jāneyyāsi mā para pattiyaḥ hohi niggaṇha iti tāta  rājā nāma sandhi cheda ādi kārakam niggaha araham ānetvā dassitam upaparikkhitvā sodhetvā
translated: this has not been done,’ and you should not be dependent on others.🔽“‘You should arrest’: Having arrested a person who deserves arrest, such as one who has breached a wall, etc., and having had him examined and punished in accordance with the offense,

original: porāṇakarājūhi ṭhapitadaṇḍaṃ oloketvā dosānurūpaṃ niggaṇheyya. Paggaṇheti yo pana
analyzed: porāṇaka rājūhi ṭhapita daṇḍam oloketvā dosa anurūpam niggaṇheyya paggaṇheti yaḥ pana
translated: the king should look at the punishment laid down by the ancient kings and arrest him in accordance with the offense.

original: paggahāraho hoti, abhinnassa vā parabalassa bhedetā, bhinnassa vā sakabalassa ārādhako,
analyzed: paggaha ārahaḥ hoti abhinnassa vā para balassa bhedetā bhinnassa vā saka balassa ārādhakaḥ
translated: “‘You should release’: But if someone deserves to be released, such as one who has split an unconquered army, or one who has united his own army after it has been split,

original: aladdhassa vā rajjassa āharako, laddhassa vā thāvarakārako, yena vā pana jīvitaṃ
analyzed: a laddhassa vā rajjassa āharakaḥ laddhassa vā thāvara kārakaḥ yena vā pana jīvitam
translated: or one who has brought about the acquisition of a kingdom that has not been acquired, or one who has stabilized a kingdom that has been acquired, or one who has saved his life

original: dinnaṃ hoti, evarūpaṃ paggahārahaṃ paggahetvā mahantaṃ sakkārasammānaṃ kareyya. Evaṃ
analyzed: dinnam hoti evarūpam paggaha araham paggahetvā mahantam sakkāra sammānam kareyya evam
translated: If he were to give it, they would honour and respect him greatly.

original: hissa kiccesu aññepi uraṃ datvā kattabbaṃ karissanti.
analyzed: aññe pi uram da tvā kattabbam karissanti
translated: And so they will do what is to be done for him, giving their breasts to his children.

original: Jānapadanti janapadavāsīnaṃ atthaṃ sayaṃ attapaccakkheneva anusāsa. Adhammikā yuttāti🔽adhammikā tattha tattha niyuttā āyuttakā lañjaṃ gahetvā vinicchayaṃ bhindantā tava
analyzed: jānapadam ti janapada vāsīnam attham sayam atta paccakkhena iva anusāsa adhammikā yuttā ati  adhammikā tattha tattha niyuttā āyuttakā lañjam gahetvā vinicchayam bhindantā tava
translated: “The country’s affairs”: advise the people of the country yourself, without relying on others.🔽“The unrighteous ones appointed”: the unrighteous officials, the tax-collectors, who, taking bribes, make decisions

original: dhanañca raṭṭhañca mā nāsayuṃ. Iminā kāraṇena appamatto hutvā sayameva anusāsa. Vegenāti
analyzed: dhanañca raṭṭhañca mā na asayum iminā kāraṇena appamattaḥ hutvā sayam eva anusāsa vegena ati
translated: and destroy your wealth and kingdom. For this reason, be heedful and advise yourself.🔽“In haste”: suddenly, without thinking or considering.

original: sahasā atuletvā atīretvā. Vegasāti atuletvā atīretvā chandādivasena sahasā kataṃ
analyzed: sahasā a tuletvā a tīretvā vegasāti a tuletvā a tīretvā chanda ādi vasena sahasā katam
translated: “Haste”: an action done suddenly, without thinking or considering, through desire, etc.,🔽is not good, not beautiful. Why? Because,

original: kammañhi na sādhu na sundaraṃ. Kiṃkāraṇā? Tādisañhi katvā mando pacchā vippaṭisāravasena
analyzed: kamman hi na sādhu na sundaram kiṃkāraṇā tādisam hi katvā pacchā vippaṭisāra vasena
translated: having done such a thing, a fool later, through remorse,🔽suffers misery in this world and is tormented in the next.

original: idha loke apāyadukkhaṃ anubhavanto paraloke ca anutappati. Ayaṃ panettha attho “isīnamantaraṃ
analyzed: idha loke apāya dukkham anubhavantaḥ para loke ca anutappati ayam pana ittha atthaḥ isīnam antaram
translated: The meaning here is this: “The wise, having considered and reflected,

original: katvā, bharurājāti me suta”nti bharujātakena dīpetabbo.🔽Mā te adhisare muñca, subāḷhamadhikopitanti, tāta, tava hadayaṃ kusalaṃ adhisaritvā
analyzed: katvā me sutanti bharu jātakena dīpetabbo  mā te adhisare muñca su bāḷham adhi kopitanti tāta tava hadayam kusalam adhisaritvā
translated: and he was called King Bharata.”🔽Do not let your heart be angered,

original: atikkamitvā pavatte paresaṃ akusalakamme suṭṭhu bāḷhaṃ adhikopitaṃ kujjhāpitaṃ hutvā
analyzed: atikkamitvā pavatte paresam akusala kamme suṭṭhu bāḷham adhikopitam kujjhāpitam hutvā
translated: Do not let your heart be angered, dear, by the evil deeds of others that are done and carried out in excess of your good heart.

original: mā muñca, mā patiṭṭhāyatūti attho. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – tāta, yadā te vinicchaye ṭhitassa
analyzed: mā muñca mā patiṭṭhāyatu iti attho idam vuttam hoti tāta yadā te vinicchaye ṭhitassa
translated: The meaning is: Do not let it be released, do not let it be established. This is what is said: Dear, when a man is standing in your judgment

original: iminā puriso vā hato sandhi vā chinnoti coraṃ dassenti, tadā te paresaṃ vacanehi
analyzed: iminā puriso vā hataḥ sandhi vā chinnoti coram dassenti tadā te paresam vacanehi
translated: and they show a thief, saying: “This man has killed or cut a limb,” then, even though your heart is well angered

original: suṭṭhu kopitampi hadayaṃ kodhavasena mā muñca, apariggahetvā mā daṇḍaṃ paṇehi. Kiṃkāraṇā?
analyzed: suṭṭhu kopitam pi hadayam kodha vasena mā muñca a pariggahetvā mā daṇḍam paṇehi kiṃkāraṇā
translated: by the words of others, do not let it be released through anger. Do not apply the punishment without taking into account. Why?

original: Acorampi hi “coro”ti gahetvā ānenti, tasmā akujjhitvā ubhinnaṃ attapaccatthikānaṃ
analyzed: a coram pi hi coraḥ uti gahetvā ānenti tasmai a kujjhitvā ubhinnam atta paccatthikānam
translated: For they bring one who is not a thief, saying: “He is a thief.” Therefore, without being angered, having listened to the statements of both parties,

original: kathaṃ sutvā suṭṭhu sodhetvā attapaccakkhena tassa corabhāvaṃ ñatvā paveṇiyā ṭhapitadaṇḍavasena
analyzed: katham sutvā suṭṭhu sodhetvā atta paccakkhena tassa cora bhāvam ñatvā paveṇiyā ṭhapita daṇḍa vasena
translated: having investigated well, having known the state of thief through your own knowledge, apply the punishment according to the offence.

original: kattabbaṃ karohi. Raññā hi uppannepi kodhe hadayaṃ sītalaṃ akatvā kammaṃ na kātabbaṃ.
analyzed: kattabbam karohi raññā hi uppanne pi kodhe hadayam sītalam a katvā kammam na kātabbam
translated: For when a king is angry, he should not act without first cooling his heart.

original: Yadā panassa hadayaṃ nibbutaṃ hoti mudukaṃ, tadā vinicchayakammaṃ kātabbaṃ. Pharuse
analyzed: yadā panassa hadayam nibbutam hoti mudukam tadā vinicchaya kammam kātabbam pharuse
translated: But when his heart is cooled and softened, then he should act on his decision.

original: hi citte pakkuthite udake mukhanimittaṃ viya kāraṇaṃ na paññāyati. Kodhasā hīti,
analyzed: hi citte pakkuthite udake mukha nimittam viya kāraṇam na paññāyati kodhasā hi iti
translated: For when the mind is rough and heated, the reason is not clear, like the reflection in heated water.

original: tāta, kodhena hi bahūni phītāni rājakulāni akulabhāvaṃ gatāni mahāvināsameva pattānīti.
analyzed: tāta kodhena hi bahūni phītāni rāja kulāni a kula bhāvam gatāni mahā vināsam eva pattāni iti
translated: “Because of anger, dear, many prosperous royal families have come to ruin and have met with destruction.”

original: Imassa panatthassa dīpanatthaṃ khantivādijātaka- nāḷikerarājavatthusahassabāhuajjunavatthuādīni kathetabbāni.
analyzed: imassa pana atthassa dīpana attham khanti vādi jātaka nāḷikera rāja vatthu sahassabāhu ajjuna vatthu ādīni kathetabbāni
translated: And in order to illustrate this meaning, the stories of the Khantivādi Jātaka, the Nāḷikerarāja Jātaka, the Sahassabāhu Jātaka, the Ajjuna Jātaka, and so on, should be told.🔽“Do not, dear, be a despot,

original: Mā, tāta, issaromhīti, anatthāya patārayīti, tāta, “ahaṃ pathavissaro”ti mā mahājanaṃ
analyzed: mā tāta issaromhi iti anatthāya patārayi iti tāta aham mā mahājanam
translated: Do not, dear, be a despot and lead the people to destruction and ruin, thinking ‘I am the lord of the earth.’

original: kāyaduccaritādianatthāya patārayi mā otārayi, yathā taṃ anatthaṃ samādāya vattati,
analyzed: kāya duccarita ādi anatthāya patārayi mā otārayi yathā tam anattham samādāya vattati
translated: Do not lead them to destruction and ruin by bodily misconduct, etc., as you would by taking up a weapon and leading them to destruction and ruin.

original: mā evamakāsīti attho. Mā te āsīti, tāta, tava vijite manussajātikānaṃ vā tiracchānajātikānaṃ
analyzed: mā evam akāsi iti atthaḥ mā te āsi iti tāta tava vijite manussa jātikānam vā tiracchāna jātikānam
translated: the meaning is, “Do not act like this.” “Let there not be” means, “Dear, let there not be in your realm

original: vā itthipurisānaṃ dukhudrayo dukkhuppatti mā āsi. Yathā hi adhammikarājūnaṃ vijite
analyzed: vā itthi purisānam dukkhudrayaḥ dukkhuppatti mā āsi yathā hi adhammika rājūnam vijite
translated: The meaning is, do not act thus. Do not let there be, dear, in your realm, among human beings or among animals, among women or men, a source of suffering, a source of pain. For just as in the realms of unrighteous kings

original: manussā kāyaduccaritādīni katvā niraye uppajjanti, tava raṭṭhavāsīnaṃ taṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: manussā kāya duccarita ādīni katvā niraye uppajjanti tava raṭṭha vāsīnam tat dukkham
translated: human beings, by committing bodily misconduct, etc., are reborn in hell, so too, dear, do what is necessary so that such suffering

original: yathā na hoti, tathā karohīti attho.
analyzed: yathā na hoti tathā karohi iti attho
translated: will not exist for the inhabitants of your realm.

original: Apetalomahaṃsassāti attānuvādādibhayehi nibbhayassa. Iminā imaṃ dasseti – tāta, yo
analyzed: apeta lomahaṃsassa ati attā anuvāda ādi bhayehi nibbhayassa iminā imam dassa iti tāta yaḥ
translated: Fearless like the haṃsa in the lotus pond: fearless because of the absence of self-reproach, etc. This shows that, dear,

original: rājā kismiñci āsaṅkaṃ akatvā attano kāmameva anussarati, chandavasena yaṃ yaṃ icchati,
analyzed: rājā kismiñci āsaṅkam a katvā kāmam eva anussarati chanda vasena yam yam icchati
translated: a king who, without any misgivings, remembers only his own desires, who does whatever he wishes according to his whims,

original: taṃ taṃ karoti, vissaṭṭhayaṭṭhi viya andho niraṅkuso viya ca caṇḍahatthī hoti, tassa
analyzed: tam tam karoti vissaṭṭha yaṭṭhi viya andhaḥ niraṅkusaḥ viya ca caṇḍa hatthī hoti tassa
translated: becomes like a broken-kneed man, like a wild elephant without a goad.

original: sabbe bhogā vinassanti, tassa taṃ bhogabyasanaṃ aghaṃ dukkhanti vuccati.
analyzed: sabbe bhogāḥ vinassanti tassa tat bhoga byasanam agham dukkhanti vuccati
translated: All his wealth is lost, and that loss of wealth is called his “evil.”

original: Tattheva te vattapadāti purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Dakkhassudānīti, tāta, tvaṃ imaṃ
analyzed: tattha iva te vatta padāti purima nayena iva yojetabbam dakkhassudāni iti tāta tvam imaṃ
translated: And there, too, the words “the duties of a wife” are to be construed as above.

original: anusāsaniṃ sutvā idāni dakkho analaso puññānaṃ karaṇena puññakaro surādipariharaṇena.
analyzed: anusāsanim sutvā idāni dakkhaḥ analaso puññānam karaṇena puñña karo surā ādi pariharaṇena
translated: “Now be clever” : “Now, dear, having heard this instruction, be clever, not lazy, in the performance of merit, and by refraining from liquor, etc., be a doer of merit.

original: Asoṇḍo diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikassa atthassa avināsanena avināsako bhaveyyāsīti.
analyzed: a soṇḍaḥ diṭṭhadhammika samparāyikassa atthassa avināsanena avināsakaḥ bhaveyyāsi iti
translated: And be not a destroyer by not destroying the good of this life and the next.”

original: Sīlavāssūti sīlavā ācārasampanno bhava, dasasu rājadhammesu patiṭṭhāya rajjaṃ kārehi.
analyzed: sīlavāssu iti sīlavā ācāra sampannaḥ bhava dasasu rājadhammesu patiṭṭhāya rajjam kārehi
translated: “Be virtuous” : “Be virtuous, endowed with good conduct, and rule your kingdom by establishing yourself in the ten royal virtues.

original: Dussīlo vinipātikoti dussīlo hi, mahārāja, attānaṃ niraye vinipātento vinipātiko nāma hotīti.
analyzed: dussīlaḥ vinipātikaḥ iti dussīlaḥ hi mahā rāja attānam niraye vinipātentaḥ vinipātikaḥ nāma hoti iti
translated: For the unvirtuous man, O king, is a destroyer, destroying himself in hell.”

original: Evaṃ kuṇḍalinīpi ekādasahi gāthāhi dhammaṃ desesi. Rājā tuṭṭho amacce āmantetvā pucchi
analyzed: evam ekādasahi gāthāhi dhammam desesi rājā tuṭṭhaḥ amacce āmantetvā pucchi
translated: Thus Kuṇḍalī also taught the Dhamma in eleven stanzas. The king was pleased. He summoned his ministers and asked them,

original: – “bhonto! Amaccā mama dhītāya kuṇḍaliniyā evaṃ kathayamānāya kena kattabbaṃ kiccaṃ
analyzed: bhontaḥ amaccāḥ mama dhītāya kuṇḍaliniyā evam kathayamānāya kena kattabbam kiccam
translated: “Gentlemen, what should be done for my daughter Kuṇḍalī, who has spoken thus?”

translated: “One who knows the analysis of ideas”: one who is skilled in the analysis of the ten profitable courses of action. “One who is not a shirker” is one who does the work at the time it should be done. “One who is not a procrastinator” is one who does this or that work at this or that time.

original: samannāgatassa, anāyatanabhūtameva dussīlapuggalaṃ sevantassa, kusalassa kammassa
analyzed: samannāgatassa anāyatana bhūtam eva dussīla puggalam sevantassa kusalassa kammassa
translated: “For him”: for that person the result of his action succeeds, comes to pass. “One whose virtue is not a mere opening” : bad conduct is called “a mere opening” because it is the cause of gain, fame, and pleasure. “For him” is for one who possesses that bad conduct. “One who consorts with a person whose virtue is a mere opening” is one who consorts with a person whose virtue is bad conduct.

original: karaṇakāle nibbindiyakārissa nibbinditvā ukkaṇṭhitvā karontassa evarūpassa, tāta,🔽puggalassa kammānaṃ attho sammā na vipaccati na sampajjati, tīṇi kulaggāni ca cha
analyzed: karaṇa kāle nibbindiya kārissa nibbinditvā ukkaṇṭhitvā karontassa evarūpassa tāta  puggalassa kammānam attho sammā na vipaccati na sampajjati tīṇi kulaggāni ca cha
translated: “When he is doing a profitable action” is when he is doing a profitable action. “One who is dissatisfied” is one who is dissatisfied and discontented. “One who is of such a kind” is one who is of such a kind, dear sir.

original: kāmasaggāni ca na upanetīti attho. Ajjhattañcāti attano niyakajjhattaṃ aniccabhāvanādivasena
analyzed: kāma saggāni ca na upaneti iti atthaḥ ajjhattam ca ati anicca bhāvanā ādi vasena
translated: “For him the meaning of the action does not succeed” : it does not come to pass, does not succeed. “He does not lead to the three kinds of families” : the meaning is that he does not lead to the three kinds of families and to the six sensual-sphere heavens. “His own” : his own internal .🔽“His own” : his own internal .

original: payuttassa. Tathāyatanasevinoti tatheva sīlavante puggale sevamānassa. Vipaccatīti
analyzed: payuttassa tathā āyatana sevino ti tathā iva sīlavante puggale sevamānassa vipaccati iti
translated: and to one who is suitable. “To one who serves the field of good men”: to one who serves good men in the same way. “It will ripen”:

original: sampajjati mahantaṃ yasaṃ deti.
analyzed: sampajjati mahantam yasam deti
translated: it will come to fruition and give great fame.

original: Yogappayogasaṅkhātanti yoge yuñjitabbayuttake kāraṇe payogakoṭṭhāsabhūtaṃ paññaṃ.
analyzed: yoga ppayoga saṅkhātanti yoge yuñjitabba yuttake kāraṇe payoga koṭṭhāsa bhūtam paññam
translated: “The means of guarding wealth”: wisdom which is the means of guarding wealth, which is a part of the means of application.

original: Sambhatassāti rāsikatassa dhanassa anurakkhaṇaṃ. Tāni tvanti etāni ca dve purimāni
analyzed: sambhatassa ati rāsikatassa dhanassa anurakkhaṇam tāni etāni ca dve purimāni
translated: “The means of protecting”: the protection of the wealth which has been accumulated. “These two”: these two and the other two

original: ca mayā vuttakāraṇāni sabbāni, tāta, tvaṃ sevassu, mayā vuttaṃ ovādaṃ hadaye katvā
analyzed: ca mayā vutta kāraṇāni sabbāni tāta tvam sevassu mayā vuttam ovādam hadaye katvā
translated: which I have mentioned. “You should serve all these”: you should serve all these four which I have mentioned, keeping my advice in mind.

original: attano ghare dhanaṃ rakkha. Mā akammāya randhayīti ayuttena akāraṇena mā randhayi,
analyzed: attanaḥ ghare dhanam rakkha mā akammāya randhayi iti ayuttena akāraṇena mā randhayi
translated: “Protect your wealth in your own home”: do not waste it for no reason.

original: taṃ dhanaṃ mā jhāpayi mā nāsayi. Kiṃkāraṇā? Akammunā hīti ayuttakammakaraṇena dummedho
analyzed: tam dhanam mā jhāpayi mā na asayi kiṃkāraṇā akammunā hi iti ayutta kamma karaṇena dummedhaḥ
translated: Do not burn it up, do not destroy it. Why? “For a fool who acts for no reason”: a foolish person who acts for no reason

original: puggalo sakaṃ dhanaṃ nāsetvā pacchā duggato. Naḷāgāraṃva sīdatīti yathā naḷāgāraṃ
analyzed: puggalaḥ sakam dhanam na āsetvā pacchā duggataḥ naḷāgāram va sīdati iti yathā naḷāgāram
translated: destroys his own wealth and later becomes destitute. “Like a house of reeds”:

original: mūlato paṭṭhāya jīramānaṃ appatiṭṭhaṃ patati, evaṃ akāraṇena dhanaṃ nāsetvā apāyesu nibbattatīti.
analyzed: mūlataḥ paṭṭhāya jīramānam appatiṭṭham patati evam akāraṇena dhanam na āsetvā apāyesu nibbattati iti
translated: and as it falls away from the root it falls down without support. So, too, the man who squanders his wealth without cause is reborn in the states of woe.

original: Evampi bodhisatto ettakena ṭhānena pañca balāni vaṇṇetvā paññābalaṃ ukkhipitvā candamaṇḍalaṃ nīharanto viya kathetvā idāni dasahi gāthāhi rañño ovādaṃ dento āha –
analyzed: evam pi bodhisatto ettakena ṭhānena pañca balāni vaṇṇetvā paññā balam ukkhipitvā canda maṇḍalam nīharantaḥ viya kathetvā idāni dasahi gāthāhi raññaḥ ovādam dentaḥ āha
translated: Thus the Bodhisatta, having extolled the five powers in this way, raised up the power of wisdom, and spoke as if he were drawing out the orb of the moon. Having thus spoken the admonition to the king in ten verses, he said:

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, mātāpitūsu khattiya;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja mātā pitūsu khattiya
translated: “O king, live righteously towards your parents, O prince;

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having lived righteously here, O king, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, puttadāresu khattiya;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja putta dāresu khattiya
translated: “O king, live righteously towards your wife and children, O prince;

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having lived righteously here, O king, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, mittāmaccesu khattiya;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja mittāmaccesu khattiya
translated: “O king, live righteously towards your friends and companions, O prince;

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having lived righteously here, O king, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, vāhanesu balesu ca;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja vāhanesu balesu ca
translated: “O king, live righteously towards your vehicles and your beasts of burden;

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having lived righteously here, O king, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, gāmesu nigamesu ca;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja gāmesu nigamesu ca
translated: “O king, live righteously towards your villages and towns,

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having practiced Dhamma here, O King, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, raṭṭhe janapadesu ca;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja raṭṭhe janapadesu ca
translated: Practice Dhamma, great king, in the kingdom and in the countryside;

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having practiced Dhamma here, O King, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, samaṇe brāhmaṇesu ca;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja samaṇe brāhmaṇesu ca
translated: Practice Dhamma, great king, with ascetics and brahmins;

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having practiced Dhamma here, O King, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, migapakkhīsu khattiya;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja miga pakkhīsu khattiya
translated: Practice Dhamma, great king, with animals and birds, O Warrior;

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having practiced Dhamma here, O King, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, dhammo ciṇṇo sukhāvaho;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja dhammaḥ ciṇṇaḥ sukha āvahaḥ
translated: Practice Dhamma, great king, for Dhamma, when practiced well,

original: Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, rāja saggaṃ gamissasi.
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna rāja saggam gamissasi
translated: Having practiced Dhamma here, O King, you will go to heaven.

original: “Dhammaṃ cara mahārāja, saindā devā sabrahmakā;
analyzed: dhammam cara mahā rāja saindā devā sa brahmakā
translated: Practice Dhamma, great king, with the gods together with Indra and Brahma;

original: Suciṇṇena divaṃ pattā, mā dhammaṃ rāja pāmado”ti.
analyzed: su ciṇṇena divam pattāḥ mā dhammam rāja pāmada uti
translated: Having practiced well, they attained heaven, O King, do not be negligent in Dhamma.

original: Tattha paṭhamagāthāya tāva idha dhammanti mātāpitupaṭṭhānadhammaṃ. Taṃ kālasseva
analyzed: tattha paṭhama gāthāya tāva idha mātā pitu paṭṭhāna dhammam tam kālassa iva
translated: Here, in the first verse, practice Dhamma here means the duty of supporting one's parents. That should be done from an early age

original: vuṭṭhāya mātāpitūnaṃ mukhodakadantakaṭṭhadānamādiṃ katvā sabbasarīrakiccapariharaṇaṃ
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya mātā pitūnam mukha udaka danta kaṭṭha dānam ādim katvā sabba sarīra kicca pariharaṇam
translated: by getting up before them and giving them mouth water, tooth cleaners, etc., and by refraining from all bodily misconduct.

original: karontova pūrehīti vadati. Puttadāresūti puttadhītaro tāva pāpā nivāretvā kalyāṇe
analyzed: karontaḥ uva pūrehi iti vadati putta dāresu iti putta dhītaro tāva pāpā nivāretvā kalyāṇe
translated: “You should do it” means he speaks thus: “You should do it.” As regards wife and children: he behaves rightly as regards his children by preventing them from doing evil and establishing them in good,

original: nivesento sippaṃ uggaṇhāpento vayappattakāle patirūpakulavaṃsena āvāhavivāhaṃ karonto
analyzed: nivesentaḥ sippam uggaṇhāpentaḥ vaya patta kāle pati rūpa kula vaṃsena āvāha vivāham karontaḥ
translated: by having them learn a craft, by giving them in marriage at the right time to a suitable family of the same social class,

original: samaye dhanaṃ dento puttesu dhammaṃ carati nāma, bhariyaṃ sammānento anavamānento
analyzed: samaye dhanam dentaḥ puttesu dhammam carati nāma bhariyam sammānentaḥ an avamānento
translated: by giving them wealth at the right time, and by behaving rightly as regards his wife by honouring her, not despising her,

original: anaticaranto issariyaṃ vossajjento alaṅkāraṃ anuppadento dāresu dhammaṃ carati nāma.
analyzed: an aticarantaḥ issariyam vossajjentaḥ alaṅkāram an uppadentaḥ dāresu dhammam carati nāma
translated: not being unfaithful to her, not usurping her authority, and by providing her with ornaments.

original: Mittāmaccesūti mittāmacce catūhi saṅgahavatthūhi saṅgaṇhanto avisaṃvādento etesu🔽dhammaṃ carati nāma. Vāhanesu balesu cāti hatthiassādīnaṃ vāhanānaṃ balakāyassa ca
analyzed: mitta amaccesu iti mitta amacce catūhi saṅgaha vatthūhi saṅgaṇhantaḥ a visaṃvādentaḥ etesu  dhammam carati nāma vāhanesu balesu ca ati hatthi assa ādīnam vāhanānam balakāyassa ca
translated: As regards friends and companions: he behaves rightly as regards friends and companions by associating with them through the four means of social intercourse and by not deceiving them.

original: dātabbayuttakaṃ dento sakkāraṃ karonto hatthiassādayo mahallakakāle kammesu ayojento🔽tesu dhammaṃ carati nāma.
analyzed: dātabba yuttakam dentaḥ sakkāram karontaḥ hatthi assa ādayaḥ mahallaka kāle kammesu a yojentaḥ  tesu dhammaṃ carati nāma
translated: As regards vehicles and building sites: he behaves rightly as regards vehicles and building sites by giving them what is suitable and by honouring them. As regards elephants, horses, etc., he behaves rightly as regards them by not employing them beyond their capacity and by looking after them when they are old.

original: Gāmesu nigamesu cāti gāmanigamavāsino daṇḍabalīhi apīḷentova tesu dhammaṃ carati
analyzed: gāmesu nigamesu ca ati gāma nigama vāsinaḥ daṇḍa balīhi a pīḷentaḥ uva tesu dhammam carati
translated: As regards villages and towns: he behaves rightly as regards the inhabitants of villages and towns by not oppressing them with fines and taxes.

original: nāma. Raṭṭhe janapadesu cāti raṭṭhañca janapadañca akāraṇena kilamento hitacittaṃ🔽apaccupaṭṭhapento tattha adhammaṃ carati nāma, apīḷento pana hitacittena pharanto🔽tattha dhammaṃ carati nāma. Samaṇe brāhmaṇesu cāti tesaṃ cattāro paccaye dentova🔽tesu dhammaṃ carati nāma. Migapakkhīsūti sabbacatuppadasakuṇānaṃ abhayaṃ dento tesu🔽dhammaṃ carati nāma. Dhammo ciṇṇoti sucaritadhammo ciṇṇo. Sukhāvahoti tīsu kulasampadāsu🔽chasu kāmasaggesu sukhaṃ āvahati. Suciṇṇenāti idha ciṇṇena kāyasucaritādinā suciṇṇena.
analyzed: nāma raṭṭhe janapadesu ca ati raṭṭham ca janapadam ca akāraṇena kilamentaḥ hita cittam  a paccupaṭṭhapentaḥ tattha adhammam carati nāma a pīḷentaḥ pana hita cittena pharantaḥ  tattha dhammam carati nāma samaṇe brāhmaṇesu ca ati tesam cattāro paccaye dentaḥ iva  tesu dhammam carati nāma miga pakkhīsu iti sabba catuppada sakuṇānam abhayam dentaḥ tesu  dhammam carati nāma dhammo ciṇṇoti su carita dhammo ciṇṇaḥ sukha āvahaḥ ti tīsu kula sampadāsu  chasu kāma saggesu sukham āvahati su ciṇṇena ati idha ciṇṇena kāya su carita ādinā su ciṇṇena
translated: In the country and in the provinces: he is said to “practice what is contrary to the Dhamma” in the country and in the provinces when he oppresses them without reason, not attending to their welfare. But when he oppresses them with a mind of loving-kindness, attending to their welfare, he is said to “practice the Dhamma” there. In the case of ascetics and brahmins: when he gives them the four requisites, he is said to “practice the Dhamma” there. In the case of animals: when he grants safety to all four-footed animals, he is said to “practice the Dhamma” there. The Dhamma is practiced: good conduct is practiced. It leads to happiness: it leads to happiness in the three kinds of success and in the six divine abodes of the sense sphere. By one who practices well: by one who practices well through good bodily conduct, etc.

original: Divaṃ pattāti devalokabrahmalokasaṅkhātaṃ divaṃ gatā, tattha dibbasampattilābhino🔽jātā. Mā dhammaṃ rāja pāmadoti tasmā tvaṃ, mahārāja, jīvitaṃ jahantopi dhammaṃ mā pamajjīti.
analyzed: divam pattā ati devaloka brahmaloka saṅkhātam divam gatā tattha dibba sampatti lābhinaḥ 🔽jātā mā dhammam rāja pāmada uti tasmai tvam mahā rāja jīvitam jahantaḥ api dhammam mā pamajji iti
translated: In the country and the provinces: he is said to “practice the Dhamma” in the country and the provinces when he is not oppressing them without cause, when he is not acting with a mind of ill will. But when he is oppressing them, when he is acting with a mind of ill will, he is said to “practice the Dhamma” in the country and the provinces. In the ascetics and the brahmins: when he is giving the four requisites to them, he is said to “practice the Dhamma” in the ascetics and the brahmins. In the deer and the birds: when he is giving protection to all four-footed animals and birds, he is said to “practice the Dhamma” in the deer and the birds. The Dhamma is practiced: the Dhamma of good conduct is practiced. It brings happiness: it brings happiness in the three kinds of success and in the six divine abodes. By the well-practiced: by the well-practiced bodily good conduct, etc. They have gone to heaven: they have gone to heaven called the world of the gods and the world of the Brahmas; they have been reborn there, having attained divine excellence. O king, do not neglect the Dhamma: therefore, great king, even at the cost of your life, do not neglect the Dhamma.

original: Evaṃ dasa dhammacariyagāthāyo vatvā uttaripi ovadanto osānagāthamāha –
analyzed: evam dasa dhamma cariya gāthāyaḥ vatvā ovadantaḥ osāna gātham āha
translated: Having thus recited the ten stanzas on the practice of the Dhamma, the Master continued his exhortation with the following concluding stanza:

original: “Tattheva te vattapadā, esāva anusāsanī;
analyzed: tattha iva te vatta padāḥ anusāsanī
translated: “Therein are the steps of practice, this is the instruction;

original: Sappaññasevī kalyāṇī, samattaṃ sāma taṃ vidū”ti.🔽Tattha tattheva te vattapadāti idaṃ purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Sappaññasevī kalyāṇī,
analyzed: sappañña sevī kalyāṇī sa mattam sāma tam  tattha tattha iva te vatta padāti idam purima nayena iva yojetabbam sappañña sevī kalyāṇī
translated: The wise man should follow the good, and then he will know the truth of it.”

original: samattaṃ sāma taṃ vidūti, mahārāja, taṃ mayā vuttaṃ ovādaṃ tvaṃ niccakālaṃ sappaññapuggalasevī
analyzed: sa mattam sāma tam vidūti mahā rāja tam mayā vuttam ovādam tvam nicca kālam sappañña puggala sevī
translated: Therein are the steps of practice, this is the instruction. The wise man should follow the good, and then he will know the truth of it. Great king, the instruction which I have given you, you should follow it at all times, associating with wise men,

original: kalyāṇaguṇasamannāgato hutvā samattaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ sāmaṃ vidū attapaccakkhatova jānitvā
analyzed: kalyāṇa guṇa samannāgataḥ hutvā samattam paripuṇṇam sāmam vidū atta paccakkhatā uva jānitvā
translated: and being endowed with good qualities. Then you will know the truth of it, that it is complete and perfect, by yourself, by your own insight,

original: yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjāti.🔽Evaṃ mahāsatto ākāsagaṅgaṃ otārento viya buddhalīḷāya dhammaṃ desesi. Mahājano mahāsakkāraṃ
analyzed: yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjāti  evam mahāsattaḥ ākāsagaṅgam otārentaḥ viya buddha līḷāya dhammam desesi mahā janaḥ mahā sakkāram
translated: and you will practice according to the instruction.

original: akāsi, sādhukārasahassāni adāsi. Rājā tuṭṭho amacce āmantetvā pucchi – “bhonto! Amaccā
analyzed: akāsi sādhukāra sahassāni adāsi rājā tuṭṭhaḥ amacce āmantetvā pucchi bhontaḥ amaccā
translated: Thus the Great Being, as if plunging into the celestial Ganges, taught the Dhamma with the play of a Buddha. The multitude paid great honor to him, and gave a thousand shouts of “Bravo!” The king, pleased, summoned his ministers and asked them, “Sirs,🔽what is the name of the ascetic?”

original: mama puttena taruṇajambuphalasamānatuṇḍena jambukapaṇḍitena evaṃ kathentena kena🔽kattabbaṃ kiccaṃ kata”nti. Senāpatinā, devāti. “Tena hissa senāpatiṭṭhānaṃ dammī”ti
analyzed: mama puttena taruṇa jambu phala samāna tuṇḍena jambuka paṇḍitena evam kathentena kena  kattabbam kiccam katanti senāpatinā deva ati tena hi ssa senāpati ṭṭhānam dammi iti
translated: “By my son, the wise Jambukolā, who has a beak like a young rose-apple fruit, what should be done has been done.” “Then, my good man, I give him the rank of general.”

original: jambukaṃ ṭhānantare ṭhapesi. So tato paṭṭhāya senāpatiṭṭhāne ṭhatvā pitu kammāni🔽akāsi. Tiṇṇaṃ sakuṇānaṃ mahanto sakkāro ahosi. Tayopi janā rañño atthañca dhammañca
analyzed: jambukam ṭhāna antare ṭhapesi saḥ tatas paṭṭhāya senāpati ṭṭhāne ṭhatvā pitu kammāni  akāsi tiṇṇam sakuṇānam mahantaḥ sakkāraḥ ahosi tayo pi janāḥ raññaḥ atthañca dhammañca
translated: And he appointed Jambukolā to that office. From that time forth he, as general, performed the duties of his father.🔽The three birds received great honor. And the three men advised the king as to his duties and his welfare.

original: anusāsiṃsu. Mahāsattassovāde ṭhatvā rājā dānādīni puññāni katvā saggaparāyaṇo ahosi.🔽Amaccā rañño sarīrakiccaṃ katvā sakuṇānaṃ ārocetvā “sāmi, jambukasakuṇa rājā tumhākaṃ
analyzed: anusāsiṃsu mahāsattassa uvāde ṭhatvā rājā dāna ādīni puññāni katvā sagga parāyaṇaḥ ahosi  amaccāḥ rañño sarīra kiccam katvā sakuṇānaṃ ārocetvā sāmi jambuka sakuṇa rājā tumhākam
translated: The king, following the advice of the Great Being, gave gifts and performed other meritorious deeds, and at death was reborn in heaven.

original: chattaṃ ussāpetabbaṃ akāsī”ti vadiṃsu. Mahāsatto “na mayhaṃ rajjenattho, tumhe appamattā
analyzed: chattam ussāpetabbam akāsi iti vadiṃsu mahāsattaḥ na mayham tumhe appamattā
translated: The ministers, having performed the funeral rites for the king, informed the birds, saying, “Master, the king has ordered that the royal parasol be raised for the bird Jambukolā.” The Great Being replied, “I have no desire for kingship. You must rule the kingdom diligently.

original: rajjaṃ kārethā”ti mahājanaṃ sīlesu patiṭṭhāpetvā “evaṃ vinicchayaṃ pavatteyyāthā”ti
analyzed: rajjam kāretha ati mahājanam sīlesu patiṭṭhāpetvā evam vinicchayam pavatteyyātha ati
translated: ” And he established the people in the moral precepts, saying, “You must conduct the government in this way.”

original: vinicchayadhammaṃ suvaṇṇapaṭṭe likhāpetvā araññaṃ pāvisi. Tassovādo cattālīsa vassasahassāni pavattati.
analyzed: vinicchaya dhammam suvaṇṇa paṭṭe likhāpetvā araññam pāvisi tassa uvādo cattālīsa vassa sahassāni pavattati
translated: He had the Vinaya written on a golden plate, and then he entered the forest. His teaching continued for forty thousand years.

original: Satthā rañño ovādavasena imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ desetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi “tadā rājā ānando ahosi, kuṇḍalinī uppalavaṇṇā, vessantaro sāriputto, jambukasakuṇo pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Tesakuṇajātakavaṇṇanā paṭhamā.
analyzed: satthā rañño ovāda vasena imam dhamma desanam desetvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā rājā ānandaḥ ahosi kuṇḍalinī uppala vaṇṇā vessantaro sāriputto jambuka sakuṇaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti  tesakuṇa jātaka vaṇṇanā paṭhamā
translated: When the Teacher had concluded this religious instruction, he identified the Birth Stories: “At that time the king was Ānanda, the female serpent was Uppalavaṇṇā, the merchant was Sāriputta, and I myself was the mynah bird.”🔽The Story of the Mynah Bird.

original: [522] 2. Sarabhaṅgajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of Sarabhanga

original: Alaṅkatā kuṇḍalino suvatthāti idaṃ satthā veḷuvane viharanto mahāmoggallānattherassa
analyzed: alaṅkatā kuṇḍalino idam satthā veḷuvane viharantaḥ mahāmoggallāna therassa
translated: “Adorned with earrings, wearing fine garments” — this story the Teacher told while living at Veḷuvana, about the Elder Moggallāna.

original: parinibbānaṃ ārabbha kathesi. Sāriputtatthero tathāgataṃ jetavane viharantaṃ attano
analyzed: parinibbānam ārabbha kathesi sāriputta theraḥ tathāgatam jetavane viharantam attano
translated: When the Elder Sāriputta was living at Jetavana, he asked the permission of the Tathāgata to pass into Nibbāna.

original: parinibbānaṃ anujānāpetvā gantvā nāḷakagāmake jātovarake parinibbāyi. Tassa parinibbutabhāvaṃ
analyzed: parinibbānam anujānāpetvā gantvā nāḷakagāmake jāta uvarake parinibbāyi tassa parinibbuta bhāvam
translated: He went to the village of Nāḷakagāma, and there he passed into Nibbāna in a potter’s shed.

original: sutvā satthā rājagahaṃ gantvā veḷuvane vihāsi. Tadā mahāmoggallānatthero isigilipasse
analyzed: sutvā satthā rājagaham gantvā veḷuvane vihāsi tadā mahāmoggallāna theraḥ isigili passe
translated: When the Teacher heard that the Elder had passed into Nibbāna, he went to Rājagaha and took up his residence at Veḷuvana.🔽At that time the Elder Moggallāna was living on the side of Mount Isigili.

original: kāḷasilāyaṃ viharati. So pana iddhibalena koṭippattabhāvena devalokacārikañca ussadanirayacārikañca
analyzed: kāḷasilāyam viharati saḥ pana iddhi balena koṭippatta bhāvena deva loka cārikam ca ussada niraya cārikam ca
translated: and he was staying at the Black Rock. He, by means of his psychic power and by the power of his attainment, went to the world of the gods and to the hells of the uprising,

original: gacchati. Devaloke buddhasāvakānaṃ mahantaṃ issariyaṃ disvā ussadanirayesu ca titthiyasāvakānaṃ
analyzed: gacchati deva loke buddha sāvakānam mahantam issariyam disvā ussada nirayesu ca titthiya sāvakānam
translated: and after seeing the great power of the Buddha’s disciples in the world of the gods and after seeing the great suffering of the disciples of the sectarians

original: mahantaṃ dukkhaṃ disvā manussalokaṃ āgantvā “asuko upāsako asukā ca upāsikā asukasmiṃ
analyzed: mahantam dukkham disvā manussa lokam āgantvā asukaḥ upāsakaḥ asukā ca upāsikā asukasmin
translated: in the hells of the uprising, he went to the world of men and said: “This lay follower and this lay follower’s wife, after being reborn

original: nāma devaloke nibbattitvā mahāsampattiṃ anubhavanti, titthiyasāvakesu asuko ca asukā
analyzed: nāma deva loke nibbattitvā mahā sampattim anubhavanti titthiya sāvakesu asukaḥ ca asukā
translated: in such and such a god realm, are experiencing great good fortune, and among the sectarians’ disciples such and such a one and such and such a one

original: ca nirayādīsu asukaapāye nāma nibbattā”ti manussānaṃ kathesi. Manussā sāsane pasīdanti,
analyzed: ca niraya ādīsu asuka apāye nāma nibbattā ati manussānam kathesi manussā sāsane pasīdanti
translated: have been reborn in such and such an unhappy destination, in the hells.” People had faith in the Dispensation,

original: titthiye parivajjenti. Buddhasāvakānaṃ sakkāro mahanto ahosi, titthiyānaṃ parihāyati.
analyzed: titthiye parivajjenti buddha sāvakānam sakkāraḥ mahantaḥ ahosi titthiyānam parihāyati
translated: and they avoided the sectarians. The respect for the Buddha’s disciples was great, but that for the sectarians declined.

original: Te there āghātaṃ bandhitvā “imasmiṃ jīvante amhākaṃ upaṭṭhākā bhijjanti, sakkāro
analyzed: te there āghātam bandhitvā imasmin jīvante amhākam upaṭṭhākāḥ bhijjanti sakkāro
translated: They, after harbouring hatred for the Elders, said: “As long as he lives our supporters will break away, and our respect

original: ca parihāyati, mārāpessāma na”nti therassa māraṇatthaṃ samaṇaguttakassa nāma corassa
analyzed: ca parihāyati mārāpessāma nanti therassa māraṇa attham samaṇaguttakassa nāma corassa
translated: and he is wasting away. We will kill him.” For the purpose of killing the Elder, they gave a thousand kahāpaṇa coins to a robber named Samaṇagutta.

original: sahassaṃ adaṃsu. So “theraṃ māressāmī”ti mahantena parivārena saddhiṃ kāḷasilaṃ agamāsi.🔽Thero taṃ āgacchantaṃ disvāva iddhiyā uppatitvā pakkāmi. Coro taṃ divasaṃ theraṃ
analyzed: sahassam saḥ theram māressāmi iti mahantena parivārena saddhim kāḷasilam agamāsi  theraḥ tam āgacchantam disvā avaḥ iddhiyā uppatitvā pakkāmi coraḥ tam divasam theram
translated: He went to Kāḷasilā with a large retinue, thinking, “I will kill the Elder.”🔽The Elder saw him coming and flew up into the air by means of his psychic power. The robber,🔽not seeing the Elder that day, turned back and went again the next day. The Elder did the same thing.

original: adisvā nivattitvā punadivasepīti cha divase agamāsi. Theropi tatheva iddhiyā pakkāmi.
analyzed: a disvā nivattitvā puna divase pi iti divase agamāsi theraḥ pi tathā iva iddhiyā pakkāmi
translated: In this way he went for six days.

original: Sattame pana divase therassa pubbe kataṃ aparāpariyavedanīyakammaṃ okāsaṃ labhi.
analyzed: sattame pana divase therassa pubbe katam apara apariya vedanīya kammam okāsam labhi
translated: But on the seventh day, the Elder’s previous kamma, which was to be experienced in a subsequent birth, found an opportunity.

analyzed: so kira pubbe bhariyāya vacanam gahetvā mātā pitaraḥ māretu kāmo yānakena araññam netvā

original: corānaṃ uṭṭhitākāraṃ katvā mātāpitaro pothesi pahari. Te cakkhudubbalatāya rūpadassanarahitā
analyzed: uṭṭhita ākāram katvā mātā pitaro pothesi pahari te cakkhu dubbala tāya rūpa dassana rahitā
translated: He had made a show of rising up as if to kill them, and had struck his parents. Because they were blind and had no eyes to see,🔽they did not recognize him as their son, but thought, “These are robbers.”

original: taṃ attano puttaṃ asañjānantā “corā eva ete”ti saññāya, “tāta, asukā nāma corā no
analyzed: tam attano puttam a sañjānantā corāḥ eva ete iti saññāya tāta asukāḥ nāma corāḥ no
translated: “Dear, these are the robbers who are going to kill us.

original: ghātenti, tvaṃ paṭikkamāhī”ti tassevatthāya parideviṃsu. So cintesi – “ime mayā pothiyamānāpi🔽mayhaṃ yevatthāya paridevanti, ayuttaṃ kammaṃ karomī”ti. Atha ne assāsetvā corānaṃ🔽palāyanākāraṃ dassetvā tesaṃ hatthapāde sambāhitvā “amma, tātā, mā bhāyittha, corā🔽palātā”ti vatvā puna attano gehameva ānesi. Taṃ kammaṃ ettakaṃ kālaṃ okāsaṃ alabhitvā
analyzed: tvam paṭikkamāhi iti tassa iva atthāya parideviṃsu saḥ cintesi ime mayā pothiyamānā api  mayham yevatthāya paridevanti ayuttam kammam karomi iti atha ne assāsetvā corānaṃ  palāyana ākāram dassetvā tesam hattha pāde sambāhitvā amma tātā mā bhāyittha corā  palātā ati vatvā puna attanaḥ geham eva ānesi tam kammam ettakam kālam okāsam a labhitvā
translated: and they wept and lamented for him. He thought, “They weep and lament for me even though I am being killed. I am doing a wrong deed.” Then he comforted them, and he showed them how the thieves had fled. He rubbed their hands and feet, and he said, “Don’t be afraid, mother and father. The thieves have fled.” And he brought them back to their own house. That deed did not find an opportunity for forty-eight years.

original: bhasmapaṭicchanno aṅgārarāsi viya ṭhatvā imaṃ antimasarīraṃ upadhāvitvā gaṇhi. Yathā🔽hi pana sunakhaluddakena migaṃ disvā sunakho vissajjito migaṃ anubandhitvā yasmiṃ🔽ṭhāne pāpuṇāti, tasmiṃyeva gaṇhāti, evaṃ idaṃ kammaṃ yasmiṃ ṭhāne okāsaṃ labhati,
analyzed: bhasma paṭicchannaḥ imam antima sarīram upadhāvitvā gaṇhi yathā  hi pana su nakha luddakena migam disvā su nakhaḥ vissajjitaḥ migam anubandhitvā yasmin  ṭhāne pāpuṇāti tasmin yeva gaṇhāti evam idam kammam yasmin ṭhāne okāsam labhati
translated: They cried and lamented for the sake of their own wealth. He thought, “They are crying and lamenting for their own sake even though I am being killed. I am doing a wrong thing.” Then he comforted them, and he showed the thieves a way of escape. He rubbed their hands and feet and said, “Mother, father, do not be afraid. The thieves have escaped.” And he brought them back to their own house. That kamma did not find an opportunity for all that time, but remained like a heap of embers covered with ashes. It ran after this last body and seized it.

original: tasmiṃ vipākaṃ deti, tena mutto nāma natthi.
analyzed: tasmin vipākam deti tena muttaḥ nāma natthi
translated: For just as when a hunter has seen a deer, he lets loose a dog, and the dog follows the deer and seizes it wherever it may be, so too, this kamma gives its fruit wherever it finds an opportunity to do so. Therefore there is no such thing as being free from kamma.

original: Thero attanā katakammassa ākaḍḍhitabhāvaṃ ñatvā na apagacchi. Thero tassa nissandena
analyzed: thero attanā kata kammassa ākaḍḍhita bhāvam ñatvā na apagacchi thero tassa nissandena
translated: The Elder, knowing that he was being drawn on by the deed he had done, did not go away. As a result of that deed

original: ākāse uppatituṃ nāsakkhi. Nandopanandadamanasamatthavejayantakampanasamatthāpissa
analyzed: ākāse uppatitum nā asakkhi nanda upananda damana samattha vejayanta kampana samatthā api ssa
translated: he was unable to rise up into the air. His power of Iddhi, which was able to subdue Nandopananda and to shake the Vejayanta Palace,

original: iddhi kammabalena dubbalataṃ pattā. Coro theraṃ gahetvā therassa aṭṭhīni taṇḍulakaṇamattāni🔽karonto bhinditvā sañcuṇṇetvā palālapiṭṭhikakaraṇaṃ nāma katvā “mato”ti saññāya ekasmiṃ
analyzed: id hi kamma balena dubbala tam pattā coraḥ theram gahetvā therassa aṭṭhīni taṇḍula kaṇa mattāni  karontaḥ bhinditvā sañcuṇṇetvā palālapiṭṭhika karaṇam nāma katvā mato ti saññāyaḥ ekasmin
translated: had become weak through the power of the deed. The robber seized the Elder, crushed his bones to the size of a grain of rice,🔽broke them to pieces, and made a kind of dust of them. Thinking that he was dead, he threw him on the back of a certain

original: gumbapiṭṭhe khipitvā saparivāro pakkāmi. Thero satiṃ paṭilabhitvā “satthāraṃ passitvā🔽parinibbāyissāmī”ti cintetvā sarīraṃ jhānaveṭhanena veṭhetvā thiraṃ katvā ākāsaṃ
analyzed: gumba piṭṭhe khipitvā sa parivāraḥ pakkāmi thero satim paṭilabhitvā satthāram passitvā  parinibbāyissāmi iti cintetvā sarīram jhāna veṭhanena veṭhetvā thiram katvā ākāsam
translated: heap of rubbish, and went away with his retinue. The Elder recovered consciousness, and thinking, “I will see the Teacher🔽and then attain Nibbāna,” he wrapped his body in the robe, made it firm, rose up into the air,

original: uppatitvā ākāsena satthu santikaṃ gantvā satthāraṃ vanditvā “bhante, āyusaṅkhāro
analyzed: uppatitvā ākāsena satthu santikam gantvā satthāram vanditvā bhante āyu saṅkhāraḥ
translated: went through the air to the Teacher, saluted the Teacher, and said, “Reverend Sir, my span of years is at an end; I will attain Nibbāna.”🔽“You will attain Nibbāna, Moggallāna?”

analyzed: me ossaṭṭhaḥ parinibbāyissāmi iti āha parinibbāyissasi moggallāna āti āma bhante iti
translated: “Yes, Reverend Sir.”

analyzed: kattha gantvā parinibbāyissasi iti kāḷasilā paṭṭe bhante iti tena hi moggallāna  dhammam mayham kathetvā yāhi tādisassa sāvakassa idāni dassanam natthi iti saḥ evam
translated: “Where will you attain Nibbāna?” “At the Black Rock, Reverend Sir.” “Well then, Moggallāna,

original: karissāmi, bhante”ti satthāraṃ vanditvā tālappamāṇaṃ ākāse uppatitvā parinibbānadivase
analyzed: karissāmi bhante iti satthāram vanditvā tāla ppamāṇam ākāse uppatitvā parinibbāna divase
translated: preach the Law to me and then go.” “Very well, Reverend Sir,” he replied, and after paying obeisance to the Teacher, he rose into the air to the height of a palm-tree, and on the day of his attainment of Nibbāna,

original: sāriputtatthero viya nānappakārā iddhiyo katvā dhammaṃ kathetvā satthāraṃ vanditvā
analyzed: sāriputta theraḥ viya nānappakārāḥ iddhiyaḥ katvā dhammam kathetvā satthāram vanditvā
translated: like the Elder Sāriputta, he performed various miracles and preached the Law. After paying obeisance to the Teacher,

analyzed: kāḷasilāyam aṭaviyam parinibbāyi
translated: he attained Nibbāna at the Black Rock in the forest.

analyzed: taṅkhaṇaññeva cha deva lokāḥ eka kolāhalāḥ ahesum amhākam kira ācariyo parinibbuto ti
translated: At that moment there arose a great uproar in the six divine worlds, “Our teacher has attained Nibbāna.”

original: dibbagandhamālāvāsadhūmacandanacuṇṇāni ceva nānādārūni ca gahetvā āgamiṃsu, ekūnasataratanacandanacitakā
analyzed: dibba gandha mālā vāsadhūma candana cuṇṇāni ca iva nānā dārūni ca gahetvā āgamiṃsu ekūna sata ratana candana citakā
translated: Taking celestial garlands, perfumes, and incense, and various kinds of wood, they came to the place where the body of the Elder lay. A funeral pyre was constructed of celestial sandalwood,

original: ahosi. Satthā therassa santike ṭhatvā sarīranikkhepaṃ kāresi. Āḷāhanassa samantato
analyzed: ahosi satthā therassa santike ṭhatvā sarīra nikkhepam kāresi āḷāhanassa samantataḥ
translated: and the Teacher, standing near the body of the Elder, caused the body to be placed thereon. The funeral pyre of Āḷāra

analyzed: yojana matte padese puppha vassam vassi devānam antare manussāḥ manussānam antare
translated: and a rain of flowers fell over an area a league in extent. Among the gods were men,

analyzed: devāḥ ahesum yathākkamena devānam antare yakkhāḥ tiṭṭhanti yakkhānam antare gandhabbāḥ

analyzed: tiṭṭhanti gandhabbānam antare nāgā tiṭṭhanti nāgānam antare venateyyā tiṭṭhanti

analyzed: venateyyānam antare kinnarā tiṭṭhanti kinnarānam antare chattā tiṭṭhanti chattānam  antare suvaṇṇa cāmarā tiṭṭhanti tesam antare dhajāḥ tiṭṭhanti tesam antare paṭākā
translated: among the Venateyyas were Kinnaras, among the Kinnaras were Chattas, among the Chattas

original: tiṭṭhanti. Satta divasāni sādhukīḷaṃ kīḷiṃsu. Satthā therassa dhātuṃ gāhāpetvā veḷuvanadvārakoṭṭhake
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti satta divasāni sādhu kīḷam kīḷiṃsu satthā therassa dhātum gāhāpetvā veḷuvana dvāra koṭṭhake
translated: were Suvaṇṇacāmaras, among them were banners, and among them were flags. For seven days they played games in a most delightful manner. The Teacher, having caused the Elder’s relics to be taken, caused a shrine to be erected at the gate of the Bamboo Grove.

original: cetiyaṃ kārāpesi. Tadā bhikkhū dhammasabhāyaṃ kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ “āvuso, sāriputtatthero
analyzed: cetiyam kārāpesi tadā bhikkhū dhamma sabhāyam katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso sāriputta thero
translated: At that time the monks began a discussion in the Hall of Truth, saying, “Brethren, the Elder Sāriputta

original: tathāgatassa santike aparinibbutattā buddhānaṃ santikā mahantaṃ sammānaṃ na labhi,
analyzed: tathāgatassa santike a parinibbuta ttā buddhānam santikā mahantam sammānam na labhi
translated: did not receive the great honor which is paid to the Buddhas, because he did not attain extinction in the presence of the Tathāgata.

original: moggallānatthero pana buddhānaṃ samīpe parinibbutattā mahāsammānaṃ labhī”ti. Satthā
analyzed: moggallāna theraḥ pana buddhānam samīpe parinibbuta ttā mahā sammānam labhi iti satthā
translated: But the Elder Moggallāna, because he had attained Nibbāna in the presence of the Buddhas, received the highest honors.”

original: āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā “imāya nāmā”ti
analyzed: āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya nāma ati
translated: The Teacher came in and asked, “Monks, what are you sitting here now talking about?” When they told him,

analyzed: vutte na bhikkhave idānā iva moggallānaḥ mama santikā sammānam labhati pubbe pi labhiyā iva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: he said, “Monks, Moggallāna did not receive honor from me only now, but in a previous state of existence also he received honor from me.” So saying, he told a story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto purohitassa brāhmaṇiyā kucchimhi🔽paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhitvā dasamāsaccayena paccūsasamaye mātukucchito nikkhami. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto purohitassa brāhmaṇiyā kucchimhi  paṭisandhim gaṇhitvā dasa māsa cayena paccūsa samaye mātukucchitaḥ nikkhami tasmin
translated: Once upon a time when Brahmadatta reigned in Benares, the Bodhisatta took his rebirth in the womb of the king’s chaplain.

original: khaṇe dvādasayojanike bārāṇasinagare sabbāvudhāni pajjaliṃsu. Purohito puttassa jātakkhaṇe
analyzed: khaṇe dvādasa yojanike bārāṇasi nagare sabbāvudhāni pajjaliṃsu purohitaḥ puttassa jāta kkhaṇe
translated: After ten lunar months he was born, and at that moment all the weapons in the city of Benares, twelve leagues in extent, blazed up. The chaplain, on the very day his son was born,

analyzed: bahi nikkhamitvā ākāsam olokentaḥ nakkhatta yogam disvā iminā nakkhattena jāta ttā
