original: anekasahassā isayo tattheva gantvā pañcasu ṭhānesu maṇḍapañca kāretvā anekasahassā🔽isigaṇā kisavacchassa tāpasassa candanacitakaṃ katvā sarīraṃ jhāpesuṃ. Āḷāhanassa
analyzed: aneka sahassāḥ isayaḥ tattha iva gantvā pañcasu ṭhānesu maṇḍapañca kāretvā aneka sahassā  isi gaṇā kisavacchassa tāpasassa candana citakam katvā sarīram jhāpesuṃ āḷāhanassa
translated: and in five places they made five mounds, and many thousands of ascetics🔽made a funeral pyre of sandalwood for the young ascetic Kisā. The ascetics cremated his body. In all directions, within a distance of half a yojana,

original: samantā aḍḍhayojanamatte ṭhāne dibbakusumavassaṃ vassi. Mahāsatto tassa sarīranikkhepaṃ
analyzed: samantā aḍḍha yojana matte ṭhāne dibba kusuma vassam vassi mahāsatto tassa sarīra nikkhepaṃ
translated: a rain of divine flowers fell. The Great Being had his funeral rites performed,

original: kārāpetvā assamaṃ pavisitvā tehi isigaṇehi parivuto nisīdi. Tesampi rājūnaṃ nadītīraṃ
analyzed: kārāpetvā assamam pavisitvā tehi isi gaṇehi parivutaḥ nisīdi tesam pi rājūnam nadī tīram
translated: and after entering his hermitage, he sat surrounded by those groups of ascetics. Those three kings also reached the bank of the river,

original: āgatakāle mahāsenāvāhanatūriyasaddo ahosi. Mahāsatto taṃ sutvā anusissaṃ tāpasaṃ🔽āmantetvā “tāta, tvaṃ gantvā tāva jānāhi, kiṃ saddo nāmeso”ti āha. So pānīyaghaṭaṃ
analyzed: āgata kāle mahā senāvāhana tūriya saddaḥ ahosi mahāsatto tam sutvā anusissam tāpasam  āmantetvā tāta tvam gantvā tāva jānāhi kim saddo nāma iso ti āha saḥ pānīya ghaṭam
translated: When they arrived, there was a great noise of the royal troops and the music of the royal drums. The Great Being, hearing this, sent the ascetic to find out what it was.

original: ādāya tattha gantvā te rājāno disvā pucchanavasena paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: ādāya gantvā te rājānaḥ disvā pucchana vasena paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: He took a water-pot and went to the place where the noise was. When he saw the kings, he asked them, and in so doing he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Alaṅkatā kuṇḍalino suvatthā, veḷuriyamuttātharukhaggabandhā;
analyzed: alaṅkatā kuṇḍalinaḥ su vatthā
translated: “Adorned with earrings, well-dressed, with swords and daggers in their girdles,

original: Rathesabhā tiṭṭhatha ke nu tumhe, kathaṃ vo jānanti manussaloke”ti.
analyzed: rathesabhā tiṭṭhatha ke nu tumhe katham vaḥ jānanti manussa loke iti
translated: Standing in their chariots, who are you? How are you known in the world of men?”

original: Tattha veḷuriyamuttātharukhaggabandhāti veḷuriyamaṇīhi ceva muttālambakehi ca alaṅkatatharūhi
analyzed: tattha veḷuriya muttā tharu khagga bandhā ti veḷuriya maṇīhi ca iva muttā ālambakehi ca alaṅkata tharūhi
translated: Here “with swords and daggers in their girdles” means that they were adorned with swords and daggers made of the precious gem called “cat’s-eye.”

original: khaggaratanehi samannāgatā. Tiṭṭhathāti ekasmiṃ rathe tiṭṭhatha. Ke nūti ke nāma
analyzed: khagga ratanehi samannāgatāḥ tiṭṭhatha ati ekasmin rathe tiṭṭhatha ke nu uti ke nāma
translated: “Standing in their chariots” means that they were standing in one chariot. “Who are you?” means “What are you?”

original: tumhe, kathaṃ vo sañjānantīti?
analyzed: tumhe katham vaḥ sañjānanti iti
translated: “How are you known?” means “How are you recognized?”

original: Te tassa vacanaṃ sutvā rathā otaritvā vanditvā aṭṭhaṃsu. Tesu aṭṭhakarājā tena saddhiṃ sallapanto dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: te tassa vacanam sutvā rathāḥ otaritvā vanditvā aṭṭhaṃsu tesu aṭṭhaka rājā tena saddhim sallapantaḥ dutiyam gātham āha
translated: When they heard his words, they got down from their chariots, saluted him, and stood before him. The King of Aṭṭha, in conversation with him, spoke the second stanza:

original: “Ahamaṭṭhako bhīmaratho panāyaṃ, kāliṅgarājā pana uggatoyaṃ;
analyzed: aham aṭṭhakaḥ bhīmaratho pana ayam kāliṅga rājā pana
translated: And this is Kāliṅgara, and this is Uggattha;🔽We have come to see the well-controlled seers,

original: Susaññatānaṃ isīnaṃ dassanāya, idhāgatā pucchitāyemha pañhe”ti.🔽Tattha uggatoti cando viya sūriyo viya ca pākaṭo paññāto. Susaññatānaṃ isīnanti,🔽bhante, na mayaṃ vanakīḷādīnaṃ atthāya āgatā, atha kho kāyādīhi susaññatānaṃ sīlasampannānaṃ
analyzed: su saññatānam isīnam dassanāya idha āgatā pucchitāya imha pañhā iti  tattha uggataḥ ti candaḥ viya sūriyaḥ viya ca pākaṭaḥ paññātaḥ su saññatānam isīnam ti  bhante na mayam vana kīḷa ādīnam atthāya āgatāḥ atha kho kāya ādīhi su saññatānam sīla sampannānam
translated: And we have asked them these questions.”🔽Herein, Uggattha means as well known and famous as the moon or the sun. Well-controlled seers : “Venerable sirs, we have not come for the sake of playing in the forest, etc., but rather to see seers who are well-controlled in body, etc.,

original: isīnaṃ dassanatthāya idhāgatā. Pucchitāyemha pañheti sarabhaṅgasatthāraṃ pañhe pucchituṃ
analyzed: isīnam dassana tthāya idha āgatā pucchitāya imha pañhā iti sarabhaṅga satthāram pañhe pucchitum
translated: who are endowed with virtue. We have asked them these questions : we have come to ask the teacher Sarabhagga questions.

original: emha, āgatāmhāti attho. Ya-kāro byañjanasandhikaroti veditabbo.
analyzed: āgata amhā ati atthaḥ yakāraḥ byañjana sandhi karoti veditabbo
translated: The word emha is to be understood as having the function of a ligature consonant.

original: Atha ne tāpaso “sādhu mahārājā, āgantabbaṭṭhānaññeva āgatāttha, tena hi nhatvā vissamitvā
analyzed: atha ne tāpasaḥ sādhu mahā rājā āgantabba ṭṭhānaññā iva āgatā attha tena hi nhatvā vissamitvā
translated: Then the ascetic said to them, “Very well, great kings, you have come to the place where you should come. So bathe, and after you have eaten and rested,

original: assamapadaṃ pavisitvā isigaṇaṃ vanditvā sarabhaṅgasatthārameva pañhaṃ pucchathā”ti
analyzed: assama padam pavisitvā isi gaṇam vanditvā sarabhaṅga satthāram eva pañham pucchatha ati
translated: enter the hermitage, pay homage to the company of seers, and ask the teacher Sarabhagga your questions.”

original: tehi saddhiṃ paṭisanthāraṃ katvā pānīyaghaṭaṃ ukkhipitvā udakatheve puñchanto ākāsaṃ
analyzed: tehi saddhim paṭisanthāram katvā pānīya ghaṭam ukkhipitvā udaka theve puñchantaḥ ākāsam
translated: After exchanging greetings with them, he lifted up the water-pot and, while sprinkling water on the ground, he looked up into the sky.

original: olokento sakkaṃ devarājānaṃ devagaṇaparivutaṃ erāvaṇakkhandhavaragataṃ otarantaṃ
analyzed: olokentaḥ sakkam devarājānam deva gaṇa parivutam erāvaṇa khandha vara gatam otarantam
translated: He saw Sakka, the King of the Gods, descending from the sky surrounded by a group of gods and riding on the back of the excellent elephant Eravana.

original: disvā tena saddhiṃ sallapanto tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: disvā tena saddhim sat lapantaḥ tatiyam gātham āha
translated: After seeing him, he spoke to him and uttered the third stanza:🔽“You stand in the sky, in the air,

original: “Vehāyasaṃ tiṭṭhasi antalikkhe, pathaddhuno pannaraseva cando;
analyzed: vehāyasam tiṭṭhasi antalikkhe pathaddhuno pannarasā iva cando
translated: like the moon on the fifteenth day.

original: Pucchāmi taṃ yakkha mahānubhāva, kataṃ taṃ jānanti manussaloke”ti.
analyzed: pucchāmi tam yakkha mahā anubhāva katam tam jānanti manussa loke iti
translated: I ask you, O mighty Yakkha, what is it that men in the world know you to be?”

original: Tattha vehāyasanti abbhuggantvā antalikkhe ākāse tiṭṭhasi. Pathaddhunoti pathaddhagato, addhapathe gaganamajjhe ṭhitoti attho.
analyzed: tattha vehāyasanti abbhut gantvā antalikkhe ākāse tiṭṭhasi pathaddhunoti addha pathe gagana majjhe ṭhito ti attho
translated: Herein, in the air means after rising up into the air, in the sky, you stand. On the fifteenth day means having gone half-way, in the middle of the sky, you stand.

original: Taṃ sutvā sakko catutthaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā sakko catuttham gātham āha
translated: After hearing this, Sakka uttered the fourth stanza:

original: “Yamāhu devesu ‘sujampatī’ti, ‘maghavā’ti taṃ āhu manussaloke;
analyzed: yam āhu devesu su jampati iti maghavā ati tam āhu manussa loke
translated: “They call me ‘Suja’s husband’ among the gods, and ‘Magha’ in the world of men.

original: Sa devarājā idamajja patto, susaññatānaṃ isīnaṃ dassanāyā”ti.
analyzed: sa devarājā idam ajja pattaḥ su saññatānam isīnam dassanāya ati
translated: That King of the Gods has now come here to see the well-disciplined seers.”

original: Tattha sa devarājāti so ahaṃ sakko devarājā. Idamajja pattoti idaṃ ṭhānaṃ ajja āgato. Dassanāyāti dassanatthāya vandanatthāya sarabhaṅgasatthārañca pañhaṃ pucchanatthāyāti āha.
analyzed: tattha sa devarājā iti saḥ aham sakkaḥ devarājā idam ajja patto ti idam ṭhānam ajja āgataḥ dassanāya ati dassana tthāya vandana tthāya sarabhaṅga satthāram ca pañham pucchana tthāya ati āha
translated: There, I, the king of the gods, have come today to see the seer, to pay homage to him, and to ask him a question.

original: Atha naṃ anusisso “sādhu, mahārāja, tumhe pacchā āgacchathā”ti vatvā pānīyaghaṭaṃ
analyzed: atha nam anusissaḥ sādhu mahā rāja tumhe pacchā āgacchatha ati vatvā pānīya ghaṭaṃ
translated: Then Anusissa, saying, “Very well, great king, you may come later,” took a pitcher of water,

original: ādāya assamapadaṃ pavisitvā pānīyaghaṭaṃ paṭisāmetvā tiṇṇaṃ rājūnaṃ devarājassa ca
analyzed: ādāya assama padam pavisitvā pānīya ghaṭam paṭisāmetvā tiṇṇam rājūnam devarājassa ca
translated: entered the hermitage, set down the pitcher of water, and informed the Great Being that the three kings and the king of the gods

original: pañhapucchanatthāya āgatabhāvaṃ mahāsattassa ārocesi. So isigaṇaparivuto mahāvisālamāḷake
analyzed: pañha pucchana tthāya āgata bhāvam mahāsattassa ārocesi saḥ isi gaṇa parivutaḥ mahā visāla māḷake
translated: had come to ask questions. The Great Being, surrounded by a group of seers, sat down in the great and wide hall.

original: nisīdi. Tayo rājāno āgantvā isigaṇaṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Sakkopi otaritvā
analyzed: tayo rājānaḥ āgantvā isi gaṇam vanditvā ekamantam nisīdiṃsu sakko api otaritvā
translated: The three kings came, paid homage to the group of seers, and sat to one side. Sakka also descended,

original: isigaṇaṃ upasaṅkamitvā añjaliṃ paggayha ṭhito isigaṇaṃ vaṇṇetvā vandamāno pañcamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: isi gaṇam upasaṅkamitvā añjalim paggayha ṭhitaḥ isi gaṇam vaṇṇetvā vandamānaḥ pañcamam gātham āha
translated: approached the group of seers, stood with palms joined in reverence, praised the group of seers, and spoke the fifth verse:

original: “Dūre sutā no isayo samāgatā, mahiddhikā iddhiguṇūpapannā;
analyzed: dūre sutāḥ no isayaḥ samāgatāḥ mahiddhikāḥ iddhi guṇa upapannā
translated: “We have heard from afar that the seers have gathered, possessing great power and endowed with spiritual qualities;

original: Vandāmi te ayire pasannacitto, ye jīvalokettha manussaseṭṭhā”ti.
analyzed: vandāmi te pasanna cittaḥ ye jīva lokā ittha manussa seṭṭhā ti
translated: I praise you, O Ayas, with a serene heart, you who are the best of men in this world of life.”

original: Tattha dūre sutā noti, bhante, amhehi tumhe dūre devaloke ṭhitehiyeva sutāti mamāyanto
analyzed: tattha dūre sutā no ti bhante amhehi tumhe dūre deva loke sutā ati
translated: Therein, “Heard afar” : “Venerable Sir, we are standing in the deva-world far away from you, and we have heard you.”

original: evamāha. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ime idha samāgatā amhākaṃ isayo dūre sutā yāva brahmalokā
analyzed: evam āha idam vuttam hoti ime idha samāgatāḥ amhākam isayaḥ dūre sutāḥ yāva brahma lokā
translated: Thus he says. This is what is meant: “These seers who have assembled here are heard afar by us, up to the world of Brahma,

original: vissutā pākaṭāti. Mahiddhikāti mahānubhāvā. Iddhiguṇūpapannāti pañcavidhena iddhiguṇena
analyzed: vissutā pākaṭā ati mahiddhikā ati mahā anubhāvā iddhi guṇa upapannā ati pañcavidhena iddhi guṇena
translated: they are well-known. “Greatly powerful” : of great influence. “Endowed with the qualities of psychic power” : endowed with the five kinds of psychic power.

original: samannāgatā. Ayireti, ayye. Yeti ye tumhe imasmiṃ jīvaloke manussesu seṭṭhāti.
analyzed: samannāgatāḥ ayire iti ayye ye iti ye tumhe imasmin jīva loke manussesu seṭṭhā ti
translated: “Ayas” : Ayas. “You who are the best of men in this world of life.”

original: Evaṃ isigaṇaṃ vaṇṇetvā sakko cha nisajjadose pariharanto ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Atha naṃ isīnaṃ adhovāte nisinnaṃ disvā anusisso chaṭṭhaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam isi gaṇam vaṇṇetvā sakko nisajja dose pariharantaḥ ekamantam nisīdi atha nam isīnam adhovāte nisinnam disvā anusissaḥ chaṭṭham gātham āha
translated: Having thus praised the assembly of seers, Sakka, avoiding the six faults of sitting, sat down at one side. Then, seeing him sitting downwind from the seers, Anusissa, spoke the sixth stanza:

original: “Gandho isīnaṃ ciradikkhitānaṃ, kāyā cuto gacchati mālutena;
analyzed: gandhaḥ isīnam cira dikkhitānam kāyā cutaḥ gacchati mālutena
translated: “The scent of the seers, long-perceived, goes forth from their bodies, O Māluṅkyaputta;

original: Ito paṭikkamma sahassanetta, gandho isīnaṃ asuci devarājā”ti.
analyzed: itas paṭikkamma sahassa netta gandhaḥ isīnam asuci deva rājā ati
translated: Turn back from here, O thousand-eyed one, the scent of the seers is impure, O king of the devas.”

original: Tattha ciradikkhitānanti cirapabbajitānaṃ. Paṭikkammāti paṭikkama apehi. Sahassanettāti🔽ālapanametaṃ. Sakko hi amaccasahassehi cintitaṃ atthaṃ ekakova passati, tasmā “sahassanetto”ti
analyzed: tattha cira dikkhitānam ti cira pabbajitānam paṭikkamma ati paṭikkama apehi sahassa nettā ti  ālapanam etam sakkaḥ hi amacca sahassehi cintitam attham ekakaḥ uva passati tasmā sahassanetto ti
translated: Herein, those who have gone forth long ago are those who have gone forth for a long time. Go back: go away. Thousand-eyed:🔽this is an address. For Sakka sees a matter that is thought of by a thousand ministers all by himself, and so he is called “thousand-eyed.”🔽

original: vuccati. Atha vā sahassanettānaṃ pana devānaṃ dassanūpacārātikkamanasamatthoti sahassanettā.
analyzed: vuccati atha vā sahassa nettānam pana devānam dassana upacāra atikkamana samatthaḥ ti sahassa nettā
translated: Herein, those who have gone forth long ago are called “those who have gone forth long ago.” “Go away” means “go away, depart.” “Thousand-eyed” is an address. For Sakka sees a matter that is thought out by a thousand ministers all by himself, and so he is called “thousand-eyed.” Or alternatively, he is “thousand-eyed” because he is able to look at a thousand gods at one time.

original: Asucīti sedamalādīhi paribhāvitattā duggandho, tumhe ca sucikāmā, tena vo esa gandho bādhatīti.
analyzed: asuci iti sā idam mala ādīhi duggandhaḥ tumhe ca suci kāmā tena vaḥ esa gandhaḥ bādhati iti
translated: “Filthy” means stinking, because it is defiled by sweat, etc., and you are fond of what is clean, so that smell annoys you.”

original: Taṃ sutvā sakko itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā sakkaḥ itaram gātham āha
translated: When he heard that, Sakka spoke the second stanza:

original: “Gandho isīnaṃ ciradikkhitānaṃ, kāyā cuto gacchatu mālutena;
analyzed: gandhaḥ isīnam cira dikkhitānam kāyā cutaḥ gacchatu mālutena
translated: “The smell of seers who have gone forth long ago, Let it go away with the wind,

original: Vicittapupphaṃ surabhiṃva mālaṃ, gandhañca etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhāma bhante;
analyzed: vicitta puppham surabhim iva mālam gandham ca etam pāṭikaṅkhāma bhante
translated: Like a garland of variegated flowers, fragrant, We desire the smell, good sir,

original: Na hettha devā paṭikkūlasaññino”ti.
analyzed: na ha ittha devā paṭikkūla saññinaḥ ti
translated: For the gods here are not disgusted with it.”

original: Tattha gacchatūti yathāsukhaṃ pavattatu, nāsapuṭaṃ no paharatūti attho. Pāṭikaṅkhāmāti
analyzed: tattha gacchatu uti yathāsukham pavattatu nāsa puṭam no paharatu iti
translated: Herein, “Let it go away” means “let it go away as it likes,” the meaning is, “let it not strike our nostrils.” “We desire” means

original: icchāma patthema. Etthāti etasmiṃ gandhe devā jigucchasaññino na honti. Dussīleyeva
analyzed: icchāma patthema etthā ati etasmin gandhe devāḥ jiguccha saññinaḥ na honti dussīleya iva
translated: We wish to lie down. ‘ There’ they are not disgusted with the smell.

original: hi devā jigucchanti, na sīlavanteti.
analyzed: hi devāḥ jigucchanti na sīlavantā iti
translated: For gods are disgusted only with the unvirtuous, not with the virtuous.

original: Evañca pana vatvā “bhante, anusissa ahaṃ mahantena ussāhena pañhaṃ pucchituṃ āgato,
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā bhante anusissa aham mahantena ussāhena pañham pucchitum āgataḥ
translated: And after saying this, he said: ‘Venerable sir, I have come to ask a question with great effort,

original: okāsaṃ me karohī”ti āha. So tassa vacanaṃ sutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā isigaṇaṃ okāsaṃ karonto gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: okāsam me karohi iti āha saḥ tassa vacanam sutvā uṭṭhāya āsanā isi gaṇam okāsam karontaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: make a space for me.’ On hearing his words, the seer rose from his seat and, making a space for him, he spoke two stanzas:🔽‘The lord of the earth, the lord of beings, the glorious,

original: “Purindado bhūtapatī yasassī, devānamindo sakko maghavā sujampati;
analyzed: purindadaḥ bhūta patī yasassī devānam indo sakkaḥ maghavā su jampati
translated: Sakka, the lord of the gods, Magha’s lord, Suja’s lord,🔽That king of gods, the one who delights the hosts of asuras,

original: Sa devarājā asuragaṇappamaddano, okāsamākaṅkhati pañha pucchituṃ.
analyzed: sa devarājā asura gaṇa pamaddanaḥ okāsam ākaṅkhati pañha pucchitum
translated: wants a space to ask a question.🔽‘Who here among the wise will answer

original: “Ko nevimesaṃ idha paṇḍitānaṃ, pañhe puṭṭho nipuṇe byākarissati;
analyzed: kaḥ idha paṇḍitānam pañhe puṭṭhaḥ nipuṇe byākarissati
translated: when asked a subtle question,🔽among the grass, the kings, the lords of men,

original: Tiṇañca raññaṃ manujādhipānaṃ, devānamindassa ca vāsavassā”ti.
analyzed: tiṇam ca raññam manuja adhipānam devānam indassa ca vāsavassa ati
translated: and the lord of the gods, Vāsava?’

original: Tattha “purindado”tiādīni sakkasseva guṇanāmāni. So hi pure dānaṃ dinnattā purindado,
analyzed: tattha purindadaḥ ti ādīni sakkassa iva guṇa nāmāni saḥ hi pure dānam dinnattā purindadaḥ
translated: Herein, ‘The lord of the earth’ and so on are names for Sakka’s special qualities. For he is ‘the lord of the earth’ because he gives gifts,

original: bhūtesu jeṭṭhakattā bhūtapati, parivārasampadāya yasassī, paramissaratāya devānamindo,
analyzed: bhūtesu jeṭṭha kattā bhūta pati parivāra sampadāya yasassī devānam indo
translated: He is the Lord of Spirits because he is the chief of all spirits. He is the Glorious One because of the excellence of his retinue. He is the Lord of the Devas because of his sovereignty.

original: sattannaṃ vattapadānaṃ suṭṭhu katattā sakko, purimajātivasena maghavā, sujāya asurakaññāya
analyzed: sattannam vatta padānam suṭṭhu kata ttā sakko purima jāti vasena maghavā sujāya asura kaññāya
translated: He is Sakka because he has well performed the seven duties of a king. He is Maghavana because of his former birth. He is Suja because he is the husband of Suja, the Asura maiden.

original: patibhāvena sujampati, devānaṃ rañjanatāya devarājā. Ko nevāti ko nu eva. Nipuṇeti🔽saṇhasukhume pañhe. Raññanti rājūnaṃ. original: vacanena sakkena pucchitapañhakathanāya okāsaṃ kārehī”ti. So “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā

translated: Having said this, the group of seers said to Anusissa: “Dear sir, you yourself pay homage to the Teacher and ask him for a chance to state the questions that the group of seers wants to ask Sakka.” He agreed, saying, “Very well,”

original: satthāraṃ vanditvā okāsaṃ kārento anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: satthāram vanditvā okāsam kārentaḥ anantaram gātham āha
translated: paid homage to the Teacher, and asked for a chance to state the questions. He then spoke the following verse:

original: “Koṇḍañña pañhāni viyākarohi, yācanti taṃ isayo sādhurūpā;
analyzed: koṇḍañña pañhāni viyākarohi yācanti tam isayo sādhu rūpā
translated: “Koṇḍañña, answer the questions, The seers, good sir, are asking you.

original: Koṇḍañña eso manujesu dhammo, yaṃ vuddhamāgacchati esa bhāro”ti.
analyzed: koṇḍaññaḥ esaḥ manujesu dhammaḥ yam vuddham āgacchati esa bhāraḥ ti
translated: This is the way of men, Koṇḍañña: The burden falls on the one who is here.”

original: Tattha koṇḍaññāti taṃ gottenālapati. Dhammoti sabhāvo. Yaṃ vuddhanti yaṃ paññāya
analyzed: tattha koṇḍaññā iti tam gottena ālapati dhammo ti sabhāvaḥ yam vuddhanti yam paññāya
translated: Herein, Koṇḍañña is a designation of the clan. Dhamma is nature.

original: vuddhaṃ purisaṃ esa pañhānaṃ vissajjanabhāro nāma āgacchati, eso manujesu sabhāvo,
analyzed: vuddham purisam esa pañhānam vissajjana bhāraḥ nāma āgacchati esaḥ manujesu sabhāvaḥ
translated: What is called “grown in wisdom” is a man who has this burden of answering questions. This is the nature of men.

original: tasmā candimasūriyasahassaṃ uṭṭhāpento viya pākaṭaṃ katvā devarañño pañhe kathehīti.
analyzed: tasmā candima sūriya sahassam uṭṭhāpentaḥ viya pākaṭam katvā deva rañño pañhe kathehi iti
translated: Therefore, like one who causes a thousand suns and moons to rise, make it clear and answer the questions of the King of the Devas.”

original: Tato mahāpuriso okāsaṃ karonto anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas mahā purisaḥ okāsam karontaḥ anantaram gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Man, making an opportunity, spoke the next verse:

original: “Katāvakāsā pucchantu bhonto, yaṃ kiñci pañhaṃ manasābhipatthitaṃ;
analyzed: kata avakāsā pucchantu bhontaḥ yam kiñci pañham manasā abhipatthitam
translated: “Having made an opportunity, let the venerable ones ask whatever question they desire in their minds;

original: Ahañhi taṃ taṃ vo viyākarissaṃ, ñatvā sayaṃ lokamimaṃ parañcā”ti.
analyzed: ahan hi tam tam vaḥ viyākarissam ñatvā sayam lokam imam param ca ati
translated: For I will answer each and every one of your questions, having known this world and the world beyond.”

original: Tattha yaṃ kiñcīti na kevalaṃ tumhākaṃyeva, atha kho sadevakassapi lokassa yaṃ manasābhipatthitaṃ,
analyzed: tattha yam kiñci iti na kevalam tumhākam yeva atha kho sa devakassa api lokassa yam manasā abhipatthitam
translated: Herein, whatever means not only yours, but also of the world with its gods, whatever is desired in the mind,

original: taṃ maṃ bhavanto pucchantu. Ahañhi vo idhalokanissitaṃ vā paralokanissitaṃ vā sabbaṃ
analyzed: tam mama bhavantaḥ pucchantu aham hi vaḥ idha loka nissitam vā para loka nissitam vā sabbam
translated: let the venerable ones ask me. For I will answer all of you

original: pañhaṃ imañca parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ paññāya sacchikatvā kathessāmīti sabbaññupavāraṇaṃ sampavāresi.
analyzed: pañham iman ca paran ca lokam sayam paññāya sacchikatvā kathessāmi iti sabbaññu pavāraṇam sampavāresi
translated: I will answer your question and all other questions, having realized this world and the world beyond by my own super-knowledge.”

original: Evaṃ tena okāse kate sakko attanā abhisaṅkhataṃ pañhaṃ pucchi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: evam tena okāse kate sakkaḥ attanā abhisaṅkhatam pañham pucchi tam attham pakāsento satthā āha
translated: When the Exalted One had thus given his consent, Sakka asked him the question he had prepared. Expounding that matter, the Master said:

original: “Tato ca maghavā sakko, atthadassī purindado;
analyzed: tato ca maghavā sakkaḥ attha dassī purindadaḥ
translated: “Then Maghavā, Sakka, the Seer, the Giver of Wealth,

original: Apucchi paṭhamaṃ pañhaṃ, yañcāsi abhipatthitaṃ.
analyzed: apucchi paṭhamam pañham yat ca asi abhipatthitam
translated: Asked the first question, which was the one he had in mind.

original: “Kiṃ sū vadhitvā na kadāci socati, kissappahānaṃ isayo vaṇṇayanti;
analyzed: kim su vadhitvā na kadāci socati isayaḥ vaṇṇayanti
translated: “What is it that, when slain, one never grieves? What is it whose abandonment the seers praise?

original: Kassīdha vuttaṃ pharusaṃ khametha, akkhāhi me koṇḍañña etamattha”nti.
analyzed: kassi idha vuttam pharusam khametha akkhāhi me koṇḍañña etam attham ti
translated: What is it that, here, is said to be harsh? Forgive me, Koṇḍañña, but tell me this.”

original: Tattha yañcāsīti yaṃ tassa manasā abhipatthitaṃ āsi, taṃ pucchīti attho. Etanti etaṃ mayā pucchitamatthaṃ akkhāhi meti ekagāthāya tayo pañhe pucchi.
analyzed: tattha yat ca asi iti yam tassa manasā abhipatthitam āsi tam pucchi iti attho etat ti etam mayā pucchitam attham akkhāhi mā iti eka gāthāya tayo pañhe pucchi
translated: Herein, which was the one he had in mind means which was the one he had in mind mentally. He asked three questions in one stanza: “What is it that …?” “What is it whose …?” and “What is it that …?”

original: Tato paraṃ byākaronto āha –
analyzed: tatas param byākarontaḥ āha
translated: Thereafter, in order to answer them, he said:

original: “Kodhaṃ vadhitvā na kadāci socati, makkhappahānaṃ isayo vaṇṇayanti;
analyzed: kodham vadhitvā na kadāci socati makkha ppahānam isayaḥ vaṇṇayanti
translated: “Anger, when slain, one never grieves. The abandonment of conceit the seers praise.

original: Sabbesaṃ vuttaṃ pharusaṃ khametha, etaṃ khantiṃ uttamamāhu santo”ti.
analyzed: sabbesam vuttam pharusam khametha etam khantim uttamam āhu santaḥ ti
translated: All harsh words, forgive them, for the good declare that this is the highest patience.

original: Tattha kodhaṃ vadhitvāti kodhaṃ māretvā chaḍḍetvā. Socanto hi paṭighacitteneva socati,🔽kodhābhāvā kuto soko. Tena vuttaṃ “na kadāci socatī”ti. Makkhappahānanti parehi attano
analyzed: tattha kodham vadhitvā ati kodham māretvā chaḍḍetvā socantaḥ hi paṭigha cittena iva socati  kodha abhāvā kutas sokaḥ tena vuttam na kadāci socati iti makkha ppahānam ti parehi attanaḥ
translated: Herein, having slain anger: having killed anger, having discarded it. For one who grieves grieves with resentment.

original: kataguṇamakkhanalakkhaṇassa akataññubhāvasaṅkhātassa makkhassa pahānaṃ isayo vaṇṇayanti.
analyzed: kataguṇa makkhana lakkhaṇassa akataññu bhāva saṅkhātassa makkhassa pahānam isayaḥ vaṇṇayanti
translated: And since there is no anger, how can there be grief? Hence it was said: “He never grieves.” The sages praise the abandoning of contempt: the sages praise the abandoning of contempt called ingratitude, which is characterized by the contempt of others for one’s own good qualities.

original: Sabbesanti hīnamajjhimukkaṭṭhānaṃ sabbesampi pharusaṃ vacanaṃ khametha. Santoti porāṇakā
analyzed: sabbesam ti hīna majjhima ukka ṭṭhānam sabbesam pi pharusam vacanam khametha santo ti porāṇakā
translated: All: all of low, medium, and superior status. Harsh words: words that are rough. Forgive them: endure them. For the good declare: the ancient sages declare.

original: paṇḍitā evaṃ kathenti.
analyzed: paṇḍitāḥ evam kathenti
translated: Thus: in this way.

original: Sakko āha –
analyzed: sakkaḥ āha
translated: Sakka said:

original: “Sakkā ubhinnaṃ vacanaṃ titikkhituṃ, sadisassa vā seṭṭhatarassa vāpi;
analyzed: sakkā ubhinnam vacanam titikkhitum sadisassa vā seṭṭhatarassa vā api
translated: “One can endure the words of one’s equal or of one superior,

original: Kathaṃ nu hīnassa vaco khametha, akkhāhi me koṇḍañña etamattha”nti.
analyzed: katham nu hīnassa vacaḥ khametha akkhāhi me koṇḍañña etamattham ti
translated: But how can one endure the words of one inferior? Tell me this, Koṇḍañña.”

original: Sarabhaṅgo āha –
analyzed: sarabhaṅgaḥ āha
translated: Sarabhanga said:

original: “Bhayā hi seṭṭhassa vaco khametha, sārambhahetū pana sādisassa;
analyzed: bhayā hi seṭṭhassa vacaḥ khametha sa ārambha hetū pana sādisassa
translated: “One endures the words of a superior out of fear, And the words of an equal out of a desire for his friendship,

original: Yo cīdha hīnassa vaco khametha, etaṃ khantiṃ uttamamāhu santo”ti. –
analyzed: yaḥ ci idha hīnassa vacaḥ khametha etam khantim uttamam āhu santaḥ iti
translated: And if you bear with speech of one who’s low, That patience, they declare, is best of all.

original: Evamādīnaṃ gāthānaṃ vacanappaṭivacanavasena sambandho veditabbo.
analyzed: evamādīnam gāthānam vacana paṭivacana vasena sambandhaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The connection of the verses should be understood as follows.

original: Tattha akkhāhi meti, bhante koṇḍañña, tumhehi dve pañhā sukathitā, eko me cittaṃ
analyzed: tattha akkhāhi mā iti bhante koṇḍañña tumhehi dve pañhā su kathitā ekaḥ me cittam
translated: Herein, he said: “Tell me, sir, two questions have been well asked by you, but one does not take hold of my mind.

original: na gaṇhāti, kathaṃ sakkā attano hīnatarassa vacanaṃ adhivāsetuṃ, taṃ mama akkhāhīti
analyzed: na gaṇhāti katham sakkā attanaḥ hīnatarassa vacanam adhivāsetum tam mama akkhāhi iti
translated: How can one bear with the speech of one who is lower than oneself? Tell me that.”

original: pucchanto evamāha. Etaṃ khantinti yadetaṃ jātigottādihīnassa vacanaṃ khamanaṃ, etaṃ
analyzed: pucchantaḥ evam āha etam khantin ti yat etam jāti gotta ādi hīnassa vacanam khamanam etam
translated: He said this asking. That patience, they declare, is best of all: the patience in bearing with the speech of one who is low in birth, family, etc.,

original: khantiṃ uttamanti porāṇakapaṇḍitā vadanti. Yaṃ panetaṃ jātiādīhi seṭṭhassa bhayena,
analyzed: khantim uttamanti porāṇaka paṇḍitāḥ vadanti yam pana itam jāti ādīhi seṭṭhassa bhayena
translated: is the best, say the ancient sages. But that patience in bearing with the speech of one who is higher than oneself in birth, etc., out of fear,

original: sadisassa karaṇuttariyalakkhaṇe sārambhe ādīnavadassanena khamanaṃ, nesā adhivāsanakhanti nāmāti attho.
analyzed: sadisassa karaṇa uttariya lakkhaṇe sa ārambhe ādīnava dassanena khamanam na isā adhivāsanakhanti nāma ati attho
translated: and that patience in bearing with the speech of one who is equal to oneself in birth, etc., out of the desire to do what is proper, and that patience in bearing with the speech of one who is equal to oneself in birth, etc., out of the desire to see the danger in the act of retaliation, is not called the patience of endurance. This is the meaning.

original: Evaṃ vutte sakko mahāsattaṃ āha – “bhante, paṭhamaṃ tumhe ‘sabbesaṃ vuttaṃ pharusaṃ
analyzed: evam vutte sakkaḥ mahāsattam āha bhante paṭhamam tumhe sabbesam vuttam pharusam
translated: When this was said, Sakka said to the Great Being: “Venerable sir, first you said: ‘All that is said by all is harsh to one who is not devoid of lust.

original: khametha, etaṃ khantiṃ uttamamāhu santo’ti vatvā idāni ‘yo cīdha hīnassa vaco khametha,
analyzed: khametha etam khantim uttamam āhu santo ti vatvā idāni yaḥ ci idha hīnassa vacaḥ khametha
translated: “Forgive the speech of one who is low, this is the highest forgiveness, say the good.” Now, you say, “Forgive the speech of one who is low,

original: etaṃ khantiṃ uttamamāhu santo’ti vadatha, na vo purimena pacchimaṃ sametī”ti. Atha
analyzed: etam khantim uttamam āhu santaḥ iti vadatha na vaḥ purimena pacchimam sameti iti atha
translated: this is the highest forgiveness, say the good,” but the latter does not agree with the former.” Then

original: naṃ mahāsatto, “sakka, pacchimaṃ mayā ‘ayaṃ hīno’ti ñatvā pharusavacanaṃ adhivāsentassa
analyzed: nam mahāsatto sakka pacchimam mayā ayam hīnaḥ iti ñatvā pharusa vacanam adhivāsentassa
translated: the Great Being said, “Sakka, the latter was said by me, knowing that he was low, to bear with the harsh speech

original: vasena vuttaṃ, yasmā pana na sakkā rūpadassanamattena sattānaṃ seṭṭhādibhāvo ñātuṃ,
analyzed: vasena vuttam yasmā pana na sakkā rūpa dassana mattena sattānam seṭṭha ādi bhāvaḥ ñātum
translated: uttered by him. But since it is not possible to know the best, etc., of beings by merely seeing their form,

original: tasmā purimaṃ vutta”nti vatvā sattānaṃ aññatra saṃvāsā rūpadassanamattena seṭṭhādibhāvassa
analyzed: tasmā purimam vutta nti vatvā sattānam aññatra saṃvāsāḥ rūpa dassana mattena seṭṭha ādi bhāvassa
translated: therefore the former was said.” So saying, in order to show that the best, etc., of beings is difficult to know

original: duviññeyyataṃ pakāsento gāthamāha –
analyzed: duviññeyya tam pakāsentaḥ gātham āha
translated: apart from association with them, he spoke the stanza:

original: “Kathaṃ vijaññā catupattharūpaṃ, seṭṭhaṃ sarikkhaṃ athavāpi hīnaṃ;
analyzed: katham vijaññā catu pattha rūpam seṭṭham sa rikkham athavā api hīnam
translated: “How can one know the best, the equal, or the low, by the fourfold form?

original: Virūparūpena caranti santo, tasmā hi sabbesaṃ vaco khamethā”ti.
analyzed: virūpa rūpena caranti santaḥ tasmā hi sabbesam vacaḥ khametha ati
translated: The good go about in a different form, therefore one should forgive the speech of all.”

original: Tattha catupattharūpanti catūhi iriyāpathehi paṭicchannasabhāvaṃ. Virūparūpenāti
analyzed: tattha catu pattha rūpam ti catūhi iriyāpathehi paṭicchanna sabhāvam virūpa rūpena ati
translated: Herein, by the fourfold form means by the four postures, which conceal the true nature. In a different form means

original: virūpānaṃ lāmakapuggalānaṃ rūpena uttamaguṇā santopi vicaranti. Imasmiṃ panatthe
analyzed: virūpānam lāmaka puggalānam rūpena uttama guṇā santaḥ api vicaranti imasmin pana atthe
translated: and though they are of the highest beauty, they go about with ugly, unsightly people. But in this case🔽

original: majjhantikattherassa vatthu kathetabbaṃ.
analyzed: majjhantika therassa vatthu kathetabbam
translated: though they be ugly and repulsive, they go about their business with the highest degree of self-confidence. In this connection the story of the Elder Majjhima should be told.

original: Taṃ sutvā sakko nikkaṅkho hutvā, “bhante, etāya no khantiyā ānisaṃsaṃ kathehī”ti yāci. Athassa mahāsatto gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā sakkaḥ nikkaṅkhaḥ hutvā bhante etāya naḥ khantiyai ānisaṃsam kathehi iti yāci athassa mahāsatto gātham āha
translated: When Sakka heard this, he became convinced, and said, “Reverend Sir, tell me the reward that comes from such patience.” Then the Great Being spoke the first stanza,

original: “Na hetamatthaṃ mahatīpi senā, sarājikā yujjhamānā labhetha;
analyzed: na mahatī ipi senā sa rājikā yujjhamānā labhetha
translated: “No great army, with king at its head, in battle joined,🔽Can win the victory that a patient, virtuous man can win;🔽For by the power of patience, by the power of self-control,

original: Yaṃ khantimā sappuriso labhetha, khantībalassūpasamanti verā”ti.
analyzed: yam khantimā sappurisaḥ labhetha khantī balassu upasamanti
translated: The angry are appeased.”

original: Tattha etamatthanti etaṃ veravūpasamanippaṭighasabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ atthaṃ.🔽Evaṃ mahāsattena khantiguṇe kathite te rājāno cintayiṃsu – “sakko attanova pañhe
analyzed: tattha etam attham ti etam vera vūpa sama nippaṭigha sabhāva saṅkhātam attham  evam mahāsattena khanti guṇe kathite te rājānaḥ cintayiṃsu sakko attanā uva pañhe
translated: Herein, the victory is the victory of the destruction of anger, the victory of the destruction of hatred, the victory of the destruction of the underlying tendency to anger, the victory of the destruction of the underlying tendency to hatred.

original: pucchati, amhākaṃ pucchanokāsaṃ na dassatī”ti. Atha nesaṃ ajjhāsayaṃ viditvā sakko
analyzed: pucchati amhākam pucchana ukāsam na dassati iti atha na isam ajjhāsayam viditvā sakkaḥ

translated: the hell of the pot-maker. “The hell of the sharp knives” means the hell of sharp knives. Having been reborn in such a hell, he is cooked

original: antare paccati. Vitthārato pana kalāburañño vatthu khantivādijātake kathitameva.
analyzed: antare paccati vitthārato pana kalāburañño vatthu khanti vādi jātake kathitam eva
translated: between six nets. But the story of King Kalābu is told in detail in the Khantivādi-jātaka.

original: Aññāni pāpiṭṭhatarāni cetthāti etehi nirayehi pāpiṭṭhatarāni ca aññāni nirayāni sutvā.
analyzed: aññāni pāpiṭṭhatarāni ca itthā ati etehi nirayehi pāpiṭṭhatarāni ca aññāni nirayāni sutvā
translated: “And other hells more terrible than these” means having heard of other hells more terrible than these hells,

original: Dhammaṃ careti, sakka devarāja, paṇḍito kulaputto na kevalaṃ eteyeva cattāro nirayā,
analyzed: dhammam careti sakka devarāja paṇḍito kula putto na kevalam cattāro nirayā
translated: “One should live by the Dhamma” means, Sakka, the wise, the good man, not only these four hells,

original: eteyeva ca rājāno nerayikā, atha kho aññepi nirayā, aññepi ca rājāno nirayesu uppannāti
analyzed: ete iya iva ca rājānaḥ nerayikāḥ atha kho aññe pi nirayāḥ aññe api ca rājānaḥ nirayesu uppannā ati
translated: but also these kings are hellish, and there are other hells and other kings who have arisen in the hells.

original: viditvā catupaccayadānadhammikārakkhāvaraṇasaṃvidhānasaṅkhātaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇesu dhammaṃ careyyāti.
analyzed: viditvā catu paccaya dāna dhammika ārakkha āvaraṇa saṃvidhāna saṅkhātam samaṇa brāhmaṇesu dhammam careyya ati
translated: and that he should behave towards recluses and brahmans in accordance with the Dhamma, by giving them the four requisites and by protecting and sheltering them according to the Dhamma.”

original: Evaṃ mahāsattena catunnaṃ rājūnaṃ nibbattaṭṭhāne dassite tayo rājāno nikkaṅkhā ahesuṃ. Tato sakko avasese cattāro pañhe pucchanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam mahāsattena catunnam rājūnam nibbatta ṭṭhāne dassite tayo rājāno nikkaṅkhāḥ ahesuṃ tatas sakkaḥ avasese cattāro pañhe pucchantaḥ gātham āha
translated: Thus the Great Being removed the doubts of the three kings who had been shown the places of birth of the four kings. Then Sakka asked the remaining four questions, saying:🔽“I approve of your good words,

original: “Subhāsitaṃ te anumodiyāna, aññaṃ taṃ pucchāmi tadiṅgha brūhi;
analyzed: su bhāsitam te anumodiyāna aññam tam pucchāmi tat iṅgha brūhi
translated: and now I ask you this:

original: Kathaṃvidhaṃ sīlavantaṃ vadanti, kathaṃvidhaṃ paññavantaṃ vadanti;
analyzed: kathaṃvidham sīlavantam vadanti kathaṃvidham paññavantam vadanti
translated: What kind of person is called virtuous? What kind is called wise?

original: Kathaṃvidhaṃ sappurisaṃ vadanti, kathaṃvidhaṃ no siri no jahātī”ti.
analyzed: kathaṃvidham sappurisam vadanti kathaṃvidham no siri no jahāti iti
translated: What kind is called a good man? What kind does not lose his glory?”

original: Tattha kathaṃvidhaṃ no siri no jahātīti kathaṃvidhaṃ nu purisaṃ paṭiladdhasirī na jahātīti.
analyzed: tattha kathaṃvidham no siri no jahāti iti kathaṃvidham nu purisam paṭiladdha sirī na jahāti iti
translated: Here, what kind does not lose his glory? What kind of man does not lose the glory he has gained?

original: Athassa vissajjento mahāsatto catasso gāthāyo abhāsi –
analyzed: athassa vissajjentaḥ mahāsatto catassaḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsi
translated: Then the Great Being, in reply, spoke four verses:

original: “Kāyena vācāya ca yodha saññato, manasā ca kiñci na karoti pāpaṃ;
analyzed: kāyena vācāya ca yodha saññataḥ manasā ca kiñci na karoti pāpam
translated: “He who is restrained in deed, word, and thought, and does no evil with his mind,

original: Na attahetū alikaṃ bhaṇeti, tathāvidhaṃ sīlavantaṃ vadanti.
analyzed: na atta hetū alikam bhaṇa iti tathāvidham sīlavantam vadanti
translated: He does not speak falsely for the sake of self, such a one is called virtuous.

original: “Gambhīrapañhaṃ manasābhicintayaṃ, nāccāhitaṃ kamma karoti luddaṃ;
analyzed: gambhīra pañham manasā abhicintayan na accāhitam kamma karoti luddam
translated: He thinks with his mind on a deep question, he does not do a cruel deed out of haste,

original: Kālāgataṃ atthapadaṃ na riñcati, tathāvidhaṃ paññavantaṃ vadanti.
analyzed: kālāgatam attha padam na riñcati tathāvidham paññavantam vadanti
translated: he does not neglect a word of truth when it comes in time, such a one is called wise.

original: “Yo ve kataññū katavedi dhīro, kalyāṇamitto daḷhabhatti ca hoti;
analyzed: yaḥ ve kataññū kata vedi dhīro kalyāṇa mittaḥ daḷha bhatti ca hoti
translated: He who is grateful and thankful, the wise one, who has a good friend and is a firm ally,

original: Dukhitassa sakkacca karoti kiccaṃ, tathāvidhaṃ sappurisaṃ vadanti.
analyzed: dukhitassa sakkacca karoti kiccam tathāvidham sappurisam vadanti
translated: who does a task well for one who is suffering, such a one is called a good man.

original: “Etehi sabbehi guṇehupeto, saddho mudū saṃvibhāgī vadaññū;
analyzed: etehi sabbehi guṇehi upetaḥ saddhaḥ mudū saṃvibhāgī vadaññū
translated: Endowed with all these virtues, he is faithful, gentle, generous, and charitable,

original: Saṅgāhakaṃ sakhilaṃ saṇhavācaṃ, tathāvidhaṃ no siri no jahātī”ti.
analyzed: saṅgāhakam sa khilam saṇha vācam tathāvidham no siri no jahāti iti
translated: he is a gatherer, friendly, and soft-spoken, such a one does not abandon glory.”

original: Tattha “kāyenā”tiādīni padāni tividhasucaritadvāravasena vuttāni. Na attahetūti desanāsīsamevetaṃ,
analyzed: tattha kāyena ati ādīni padāni tividha sucarita dvāra vasena vuttāni na atta hetū ti desanā sīsam eva etam
translated: Herein, the words “with the body” and so on are spoken in terms of the door of the threefold good conduct. “He does not speak falsely for the sake of self”: this is the climax of the teaching.

original: attahetu vā parahetu vā yasahetu vā dhanahetu vā lābhahetu vā āmisakiñcikkhahetu
analyzed: atta hetu vā para hetu vā yasa hetu vā dhana hetu vā lābha hetu vā āmisa kiñcikkha hetu
translated: For the sake of self, for the sake of another, for the sake of fame, for the sake of wealth, for the sake of gain, for the sake of some material advantage,

original: vā alikaṃ na kathetīti attho. Kāmañcesa attho “vācāya saññato”ti imināva siddho,
analyzed: vā alikam na katheti iti attho kāmañca isa attho vācāya saññato ti iminā ava siddho
translated: the meaning is, he does not speak falsehood. Though this meaning is established by the words “controlled in speech,”

original: musāvādino pana akattabbaṃ pāpaṃ nāma natthīti garubhāvadīpanatthaṃ puna evamāhāti
analyzed: musāvādinaḥ pana akattabbam pāpam nāma natthi iti garu bhāva dīpana tham puna evam āha ati
translated: nevertheless he says this again in order to show the seriousness of the evil that should not be done by one who speaks falsehood.

original: veditabbo. Taṃ puggalaṃ sīlavantaṃ vadanti.🔽Gambhīrapañhanti atthato ca pāḷito ca gambhīraṃ guḷhaṃ paṭicchannaṃ sattubhastajātaka-
analyzed: veditabbaḥ tam puggalam sīlavantam vadanti  gambhīra pañhanti atthato ca pāḷito ca gambhīram guḷham paṭicchannam
translated: That person is called virtuous.🔽A deep question: a question that is deep in meaning and in phrasing, like the questions in the Sutta on the Wise and the Foolish , the Sutta on the Origin of Milk , and the Great Forty .

original: sambhavajātaka- mahāumaṅgajātakesu āgatasadisaṃ pañhaṃ. Manasābhicintayanti manasā
analyzed: sambhava jātaka mahāumaṅga jātakesu āgata sadisam pañham manasā abhicintayanti manasā
translated: Thinking it over in his mind: thinking it over in his mind,

original: abhicintento atthaṃ paṭivijjhitvā candasahassaṃ sūriyasahassaṃ uṭṭhāpento viya pākaṭaṃ🔽katvā yo kathetuṃ sakkotīti attho. Nāccāhitanti na atiahitaṃ, hitātikkantaṃ luddaṃ
analyzed: abhicintentaḥ attham paṭivijjhitvā canda sahassam sūriya sahassam uṭṭhāpentaḥ viya pākaṭam  katvā yaḥ kathetum sakkoti iti atthaḥ na accāhitam ti na ati ahitam hita atikkantam luddam
translated: having penetrated the meaning, he is able to explain it clearly, as if he were raising a thousand moons and a thousand suns. The meaning is: he is able to explain it after making it clear.

original: pharusaṃ sāhasikakammañca yo na karotīti attho. Imassa panatthassa āvibhāvatthaṃ –
analyzed: pharusam sāhasika kammam ca yaḥ na karoti iti atthaḥ imassa pana atthassa āvi bhāva attham
translated: Not harmful: not very harmful, not wicked, not rough, not rash action. The meaning is: he does not do what is not beneficial, what exceeds the bounds of what is beneficial. In order to make the meaning of this clear,

original: “Na paṇḍitā attasukhassa hetu, pāpāni kammāni samācaranti;
analyzed: na paṇḍitāḥ atta sukhassa hetu pāpāni kammāni samācaranti
translated: The wise do not perform evil deeds for the sake of their own happiness,

original: Dukkhena phuṭṭhā piḷitāpi santā, chandā dosā ca na jahanti dhamma”nti. –
analyzed: dukkhena phuṭṭhā piḍitā api santā chandā dosā ca na jahanti dhammanti
translated: Though touched by pain, though sore beset, They still the Dhamma do not slight.

original: Bhūripañho kathetabbo.🔽Kālāgatanti ettha dānaṃ dātabbakāle, sīlaṃ rakkhaṇakāle, uposathaṃ upavāsakāle, saraṇesu
analyzed: bhūri pañhaḥ kathetabbo  kālāgatam ti ettha dānam dātabba kāle sīlam rakkhaṇa kāle uposatham upavāsa kāle saraṇesu
translated: The question of the many is to be told.

original: patiṭṭhānakāle, pabbajitakāle, samaṇadhammakaraṇakāle, vipassanācārasmiṃ yuñjanakāle
analyzed: patiṭṭhāna kāle pabbajita kāle samaṇa dhamma karaṇa kāle vipassanā ācārasmim yuñjana kāle
translated: In time: here, giving is to be given at the time of giving, virtue is to be guarded at the time of guarding, the Uposatha is to be undertaken at the time of undertaking it, the Refuges are to be established at the time of establishing them, going forth is to be gone at the time of going forth, the monk’s duties are to be done at the time of doing them, and the practice of insight is to be undertaken at the time of undertaking it.

original: cāti imāni dānādīni sampādento kālāgataṃ atthapadaṃ na riñcati na hāpeti na gaḷāpeti
analyzed: ca ati imāni dāna ādīni sampādento kālāgatam attha padam na riñcati na hāpeti na gaḷāpeti
translated: So one who accomplishes these things beginning with giving does not neglect, does not fail, does not neglect the word of meaning in time.

original: nāma. Tathāvidhanti sakka sabbaññubuddhā ca paccekabuddhā ca bodhisattā ca paññavantaṃ🔽kathentā evarūpaṃ puggalaṃ kathenti.🔽“Yo ve”ti gāthāya parena attano kataguṇaṃ jānātīti kataññū. Evaṃ ñatvā pana yenassa
analyzed: nāma tathāvidhanti sakka sabbaññu buddhā ca paccekabuddhā ca bodhisattā ca paññavantam  kathentāḥ evarūpam puggalam kathenti  yaḥ vā iti gāthāya parena attano kataguṇam jānāti iti kataññuḥ evam ñatvā pana yenassa
translated: Such a one: Sakka, all-knowing Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and wise Bodhisattas speak of such a person.

original: guṇo kato, tassa guṇaṃ paṭikaronto katavedī nāma. Dukhitassāti attano sahāyassa dukkhappattassa
analyzed: guṇo kato tassa guṇam paṭikaronto katavedī nāma dukhitassa ati attanaḥ sahāyassa dukkha ppattassa
translated: In the verse beginning “Yo ve” , he who knows what another has done for him is grateful. But having known thus, he who repays the other for his virtue is called grateful. To the afflicted: to his friend who has come to grief,

original: dukkhaṃ attani āropetvā yo tassa uppannakiccaṃ sahatthena sakkaccaṃ karoti, buddhādayo
analyzed: dukkham attani āropetvā yaḥ tassa uppanna kiccam sahatthena sakkaccam karoti buddha ādayo
translated: and who, having laid the suffering on himself, does it with his own hands and with care, are🔽called good men by the Buddhas, etc.,

original: evarūpaṃ sappurisaṃ nāma kathenti. Apica sappurisā nāma kataññū katavedino hontīti
analyzed: evarūpam sappurisam nāma kathenti apica sappurisāḥ nāma kataññū kata vedinaḥ honti iti
translated: Moreover, good men are grateful and thankful.🔽The Satapatta, Cullahaṃsa, Mahāhaṃsa, and other jātakas should be told.

original: satapattajātaka- cūḷahaṃsajātaka- mahāhaṃsajātakādīni kathetabbāni. Etehi sabbehīti
analyzed: satapattajātaka cūḷahaṃsajātaka mahāhaṃsajātaka ādīni kathetabbāni etehi sabbehi iti
translated: By all these:

original: sakka yo etehi heṭṭhā vuttehi sīlādīhi sabbehipi guṇehi upeto. Saddhoti okappanasaddhāya
analyzed: sakka yaḥ etehi heṭṭhā vuttehi sīla ādīhi sabbehi pi guṇehi upetaḥ saddhaḥ ti okappana saddhāya
translated: he who is endowed with all these virtues beginning with virtue, mentioned above.🔽Faithful: endowed with the faith of conviction.🔽Gentle: a pleasant speaker.🔽A sharer: one who delights in sharing virtue, sharing gifts,

original: samannāgato. Mudūti piyabhāṇī. Saṃvibhāgīti sīlasaṃvibhāgadānasaṃvibhāgābhiratattā
analyzed: samannāgataḥ piya bhāṇī saṃvibhāgī iti sīla saṃvibhāga dāna saṃvibhāga abhirata ttā
translated: and sharing fearlessness.🔽A giver: one who gives in accordance with the words of those who ask.

original: saṃvibhāgī. Yācakānaṃ vacanaṃ ñatvā dānavasena vadaññū. Catūhi saṅgahavatthūhi tesaṃ
analyzed: saṃvibhāgī yācakānam vacanam ñatvā dāna vasena vadaññū catūhi saṅgaha vatthūhi tesam
translated: A gatherer: one who gathers them by means of the four bases of gathering.🔽A friendly man: one who is friendly in speech.

original: tesaṃ saṅgaṇhanato saṅgāhakaṃ, madhuravacanatāya sakhilaṃ, maṭṭhavacanatāya saṇhavācaṃ
analyzed: tesam saṅgaṇhanataḥ saṅgāhakam madhura vacana tāya sa khilam maṭṭha vacana tāya saṇha vācam
translated: A soft-spoken man: one who is soft in speech.

original: tathāvidhaṃ nu puggalaṃ adhigatayasasobhaggasaṅkhātā sirī no jahāti, nāssa sirī vinassatīti.
analyzed: tathāvidham nu puggalam adhigata yasa sobhagga saṅkhātā sirī no jahāti na assa sirī vinassati iti
translated: Such a person is not abandoned by glory, which is called fame and beauty. His glory does not perish.

original: Evaṃ mahāsatto gaganatale puṇṇacandaṃ uṭṭhāpento viya cattāro pañhe vissajjesi. Tato paraṃ sesapañhānaṃ pucchā ca vissajjanañca hoti –
analyzed: evam mahāsatto gagana tale puṇṇa candam uṭṭhāpentaḥ viya cattāro pañhe vissajjesi tato param sesa pañhānam pucchā ca vissajjanam ca hoti
translated: Thus did the Great Being answer the four questions, as if he were raising the full moon out of the ocean. The rest of the questions and answers are as follows:

original: “Subhāsitaṃ te anumodiyāna, aññaṃ taṃ pucchāmi tadiṅgha brūhi;
analyzed: su bhāsitam te anumodiyāna aññam tam pucchāmi tat iṅgha brūhi
translated: “I approve of your good words, and ask you another question:

original: Sīlaṃ siriñcāpi satañca dhammaṃ, paññañca kaṃ seṭṭhataraṃ vadanti.
analyzed: sīlam sirim ca api satam ca dhammam paññam ca kam seṭṭhataram vadanti
translated: Which do they call the best, virtue, glory, truth, or wisdom?

original: “Paññā hi seṭṭhā kusalā vadanti, nakkhattarājāriva tārakānaṃ;
analyzed: paññā hi seṭṭhā kusalā vadanti tārakānaṃ
translated: “Wisdom, they say, is the best, the most skillful, like the moon among the stars;

original: Sīlaṃ sirī cāpi satañca dhammo, anvāyikā paññavato bhavanti.
analyzed: sīlam sirī ca api dhammaḥ anvāyikā paññavataḥ bhavanti
translated: Virtue, glory, truth, and wisdom are the followers of the wise man.

original: “Subhāsitaṃ te anumodiyāna, aññaṃ taṃ pucchāmi tadiṅgha brūhi;🔽Kathaṃkaro kintikaro kimācaraṃ, kiṃ sevamāno labhatīdha paññaṃ;🔽Paññāya dānippaṭipadaṃ vadehi, kathaṃkaro paññavā hoti macco.
analyzed: su bhāsitam te anumodiyāna aññam tam pucchāmi tat iṅgha brūhi  kathaṃkaro kintikaro kimācaram kim sevamānaḥ labhati idha paññam  paññāya dānippaṭipadam vadehi kathaṃkaro paññavā hoti macco
translated: “I approve of your good words, and ask you another question:🔽How does a man act, what does he do, what does he practice, what does he follow, that he may gain wisdom here?🔽Now tell me the way to wisdom: how does a man become wise and live long?

original: “Sevetha vuddhe nipuṇe bahussute, uggāhako ca paripucchako siyā;
analyzed: sevetha vuddhe nipuṇe bahu ssute uggāhako ca paripucchako siyā
translated: Let him serve the wise, the skillful, the learned; let him be eager to learn and ask questions;

original: Suṇeyya sakkacca subhāsitāni, evaṃkaro paññavā hoti macco.
analyzed: suṇeyya sakkacca su bhāsitāni evaṃkaraḥ paññavā hoti macco
translated: He should listen to the well-spoken with respect: Thus does the mortal man become wise.

original: “Sa paññavā kāmaguṇe avekkhati, aniccato dukkhato rogato ca;
analyzed: sa paññavā kāma guṇe avekkhati aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ rogataḥ ca
translated: “The wise one considers the strands of sensual pleasure As impermanent, as suffering, as a disease,

original: Evaṃ vipassī pajahāti chandaṃ, dukkhesu kāmesu mahabbhayesu.🔽“Sa vītarāgo pavineyya dosaṃ, mettaṃ cittaṃ bhāvaye appamāṇaṃ;
analyzed: evam vipassī pajahāti chandam dukkhesu kāmesu mahabbhayesu  sa vīta rāgaḥ pavineyya dosam mettam cittam bhāvaye appamāṇam
translated: Thus, seeing, he abandons desire For sensual pleasures, a great danger.

original: Sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍaṃ, anindito brahmamupeti ṭhāna”nti.
analyzed: sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍam aninditaḥ brahmam upeti
translated: “Free from desire, he should banish hatred, Develop the measureless mind of loving-kindness, Laying aside the rod against all beings: The blameless one goes to the realm of Brahma.”

original: Tattha sīlanti ācārasīlaṃ. Sirinti issariyasiriṃ. Satañca dhammanti sappurisadhammaṃ.
analyzed: tattha sīlanti ācāra sīlam sirinti issariya sirim satam ca dhammanti sappurisa dhammam
translated: Herein, virtue is virtue of conduct. Glory is glory of sovereignty. The good men’s state is the good men’s Dhamma.

original: Paññanti supaññaṃ. Evaṃ imesaṃ catunnaṃ dhammānaṃ kataraṃ dhammaṃ seṭṭhataraṃ vadantīti
analyzed: evam imesam catunnam dhammānam kataram dhammam seṭṭhataram vadanti iti
translated: Wisdom is good wisdom. Which of these four things do they declare to be the best?

original: pucchati. Paññā hīti, sakka, etesu catūsu dhammesu yā esā paññā nāma, sāva seṭṭhā,
analyzed: pucchati paññā hi iti sakkaḥ etesu catūsu dhammesu yā esā paññā nāma sā ava seṭṭhā
translated: He asks this. Sakka, of these four things, this wisdom is the best,🔽so the wise declare, just as the moon among the stars,

original: iti buddhādayo kusalā vadanti. Yathā hi tārakagaṇā candaṃ parivārenti, candova tesaṃ
analyzed: iti buddha ādayaḥ kusalāḥ vadanti yathā hi tāraka gaṇā candam candaḥ uva tesam
translated: just as the ocean among the waters,

original: uttamo. Evaṃ sīlañca sirī cāpi satañca dhammoti ete tayopi anvāyikā paññavato bhavanti🔽paññavantameva anugacchanti, paññāya eva parivārā hontīti attho.🔽“Kathaṃkaro”tiādīni aññamaññavevacanāneva. Kathaṃkaroti kiṃ nāma kammaṃ karonto kiṃ🔽ācaranto kiṃ sevamāno bhajamāno payirupāsamāno idhaloke paññaṃ labhati, paññāyameva
analyzed: evam sīlam ca sirī ca api satam ca dhammo ti ete tayo pi anvāyikā paññavataḥ bhavanti  paññavantam eva anugacchanti paññāya eva parivārāḥ honti iti attho  kathaṃkaroti ādīni aññamañña vevacanāni eva kathaṃkaroti kim nāma kammam karonto kim  ācarantaḥ kim sevamānaḥ bhajamānaḥ payirupāsamānaḥ idha loke paññam labhati paññāyam eva
translated: They follow only the wise man; they are the wise man’s retinue, is the meaning.

original: paṭipadaṃ vadehi, jānitukāmomhi, kathaṃkaro macco paññavā nāma hotīti pucchati. Vuddheti🔽paññāvuddhippatte paṇḍite. Nipuṇeti sukhumakāraṇajānanasamatthe. Evaṃkaroti yo puggalo🔽evaṃ vuttappakāre puggale sevati bhajati payirupāsati, pāḷiṃ uggaṇhāti, punappunaṃ

original: Evaṃ mahāsatte kāmānaṃ dosaṃ kathenteyeva tesaṃ tiṇṇampi rājūnaṃ sabalakāyānaṃ tadaṅgappahānena pañcakāmaguṇarāgo pahīno. Taṃ ñatvā mahāsatto tesaṃ pahaṃsanavasena gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam mahāsatte kāmānam dosam kathentā iya iva tesam tiṇṇam pi rājūnam sa balakāyānam tad aṅga ppahānena pañca kāmaguṇa rāgaḥ pahīnaḥ tam ñatvā mahāsatto tesam pahaṃsana vasena gātham āha
translated: While the Great Being was thus speaking of the faults of sensual pleasures, the lust for the five strands of sense pleasures together with its underlying tendencies was abandoned in the three kings and their armies. Understanding this, the Great Being spoke this verse in order to praise them:

original: “Mahatthiyaṃ āgamanaṃ ahosi, tavamaṭṭhakā bhīmarathassa cāpi;

original: Taṃ sutvā rājāno mahāsattassa thutiṃ karontā gāthamāhaṃsu –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājānaḥ mahāsattassa thutim karontā gātham āhaṃsu

translated: “So it is, one who knows the minds of others; all of our lust for sensual pleasures has been abandoned;

original: Karohi okāsamanuggahāya, yathā gatiṃ te abhisambhavemā”ti.
analyzed: karohi okāsam anuggahāya yathā gatim te abhisambhavema ati

original: Tattha anuggahāyāti pabbajjatthāya okāsaṃ no karohi. Yathā mayaṃ pabbajitvā tava gatiṃ nipphattiṃ abhisambhavema pāpuṇeyyāma, tayā paṭividdhaguṇaṃ paṭivijjheyyāmāti vadiṃsu.
analyzed: tattha anuggahāya ati pabbajja atthāya okāsam no karohi yathā mayam pabbajitvā tava gatim nipphattim abhisambhavema pāpuṇeyyāma tayā paṭividdha guṇam paṭivijjheyyāma ati vadiṃsu
translated: Herein, “for the sake of the opportunity” means: “Do thou grant us the opportunity to go forth.” “That we may attain to thy state” means: “That we may attain to the state of the fruit of the path which thou hast attained.”

original: Atha nesaṃ okāsaṃ karonto mahāsatto itaraṃ gāthamāha –

original: Taṃ sutvā te sampaṭicchantā gāthamāhaṃsu –

analyzed: jhāne ratāḥ hotha sadā samāhitāḥ esā ratī pabbajitassa seṭṭhā ti

translated: “These verses are meaningful and well-phrased, well-spoken by the Sage,

analyzed: pubbāpariyam visesam a dassanam maccu rājassa gaccha iti  tattha paramattha saṃhitā ti anicca ādi dīpanena nibbāna nissitā gāthā imā ti idam satthā

analyzed: paramattha nissitā su byañjanā ati parisuddha byañjanā su bhāsitā ati su kathitā aṭṭhika tvā ati  attanaḥ atthika bhāvam katvā atthikaḥ hutvā sakkaccam suṇeyya pubba apariyanti paṭhamajjhānam
translated: by way of leading to Nibbāna. The words “well-phrased” refer to the pure phrasing. The words “well-spoken” refer to the well-said words. The words “having listened” refer to

analyzed: a dassananti pariyosāne apara visesam arahattam labhitvā nibbānam pāpuṇeyya nibbāna ppatto

translated: For a person who has attained Nibbāna is said to have gone to a place where the King of Death cannot see him.

original: Pabbato anuruddho ca, kaccāyano ca devalo;

analyzed: anusissaḥ ca ānandaḥ kisavacchaḥ ca kolitaḥ
translated: the Elder Ānanda the pupil of the god, the Elder Kolita the young Kisā,

translated: the Elder Udāyī the god Nārada, the assembly the assembly of Buddhas,

analyzed: sarabhaṅgaḥ loka nāthaḥ evam dhāretha jātakanti 🔽sarabhaṅga jātaka vaṇṇanā dutiyā 🔽

analyzed: atha bravīti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ purāṇa dutiyikā apalobhanam ārabbha kathesi  vatthu indriya jātake vitthāritam eva satthā pana tam bhikkhum saccam kira tvam
translated: The story is told at length in the Jataka of the Five Senses.🔽The Master asked the monk, “Is it true, monk, that you are discontented?”

original: bhikkhu, ukkaṇṭhitosī”ti pucchitvā “saccaṃ, bhante”ti vutte “kena ukkaṇṭhāpitosī”ti
analyzed: bhikkhu ukkaṇṭhitaḥ asi iti pucchitvā saccam bhante iti vutte kena ukkaṇṭhāpitaḥ asi iti
translated: “It is true, Reverend Sir.”🔽“By whom were you made discontented?”🔽“By my old mistress.”

original: vatvā “purāṇadutiyikāyā”ti vutte “bhikkhu esā itthī tuyhaṃ anatthakārikā, tvaṃ etaṃ🔽nissāya jhānaṃ nāsetvā tīṇi saṃvaccharāni mūḷho visaññī nipajjitvā uppannāya saññāya
analyzed: vatvā purāṇadutiyikāya iti vutte bhikkhu esā itthī tuyham anattha kārikā tvam etam  nissāya jhānam nāsetvā tīṇi saṃvaccharāni mūḷhaḥ visaññī nipajjitvā uppannāya saññāya
translated: “Monk, this woman has been your misfortune.

original: mahāparidevaṃ paridevī”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: mahā paridevam paridevī iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: Through her you have lost your meditation, and for three years have lain senseless and bewildered, and when you have recovered your senses, you have indulged in great lamentation.”🔽And with this he told a story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto kāsiraṭṭhe brāhmaṇakule nibbattitvā
