original: “Pallaṅkaṃ pahiṇī khippaṃ, sovaṇṇaṃ sopavāhanaṃ;
analyzed: pallaṅkam pahiṇī khippam sovaṇṇam sa upavāhanam
translated: “quickly sent a golden couch, with a footstool,

original: Sauttaracchadapaññāsaṃ, sahassapaṭiyatthataṃ.
analyzed: sa uttaracchada paññāsam
translated: with a canopy of fifty (pieces of cloth), and a pillow.

original: “Tamenaṃ tattha dhāresi, ure katvāna sobhanā;
analyzed: tam enam tattha dhāresi ure katvāna sobhanā
translated: “She, the beautiful one, having placed it on her chest, there she held it,

original: Yathā ekamuhuttaṃva, tīṇi vassāni dhārayi.
analyzed: yathā eka muhuttam iva tīṇi vassāni
translated: as if it was only a moment, she held it for three years.

original: “Vimado tīhi vassehi, pabujjhitvāna brāhmaṇo;
analyzed: vimadaḥ tīhi vassehi pabujjhitvāna brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: “After three years, the one without passion, having awakened, the brāhmaṇa,

original: Addasāsi haritarukkhe, samantā aggiyāyanaṃ.
analyzed: addasāsi harita rukkhe samantā aggiyāyanam
translated: saw the green trees, and the sacrificial fire all around.

original: “Navapattavanaṃ phullaṃ, kokilaggaṇaghositaṃ;
analyzed: nava patta vanam phullam kokila ggaṇa ghositam
translated: “The grove was in full bloom, and was resounding with the calls of the cuckoo,

original: Samantā paviloketvā, rudaṃ assūni vattayi.
analyzed: samantā paviloketvā rudam assūni
translated: having looked all around, he wept, and shed tears.

original: “Na juhe na jape mante, aggihuttaṃ pahāpitaṃ;
analyzed: na juhe na jape mante aggi huttam pahāpitam
translated: “He did not offer sacrifice, nor did he recite the mantras, the sacrificial fire was abandoned,

original: Ko nu me pāricariyāya, pubbe cittaṃ palobhayi.
analyzed: kaḥ nu me pāricariyāya pubbe cittam palobhayi
translated: Who, in attendance on me, has formerly tempted my mind?

original: “Araññe me viharato, yo me tejā ha sambhutaṃ;
analyzed: araññe me viharataḥ yaḥ me ha
translated: “While I was living in the forest, he who has taken away

original: Nānāratanaparipūraṃ, nāvaṃva gaṇhi aṇṇave”ti.🔽Tattha ajjhappattoti sampatto. Tamudāvatta kalyāṇīti taṃ kese parāmasitvā ṭhitaṃ
analyzed: nānā ratana paripūram gaṇhi  tattha ajjhappattaḥ ti sampattaḥ tam udāvatta kalyāṇī iti tam kese parāmasitvā ṭhitam
translated: the fire that was generated in me, like a boat in the ocean taking away a treasure filled with various jewels.”🔽Here, “has come” means “has arrived.” “She turned back, having turned away from him” means that she turned back, having touched his hair and stood there.

original: isiṃ udāvattitvā nivattitvā kalyāṇadassanā sā suṭṭhu sobhanā. Palissajīti āliṅgi.🔽Cavitamhi brahmacariyā, yathā taṃ atha tositāti, bhikkhave, tassa isino tāvadeva
analyzed: isim udāvattitvā nivattitvā kalyāṇa dassanā sā suṭṭhu sobhanā palissajī iti āliṅgi  cavitamhi brahmacariyā yathā taṃ atha bhikkhave tassa isino tāvat eva
translated: “She turned back, having turned away from him, and then turned back again” means that she turned back, having turned away from him, and then turned back again. “She was well-adorned” means that she was well-adorned with a beautiful appearance. “She embraced him” means that she embraced him.🔽“My celibacy was broken, just as he had wished” means that, monks, his jhāna disappeared right then and there.

original: jhānaṃ antaradhāyi. Tasmiṃ tamhā jhānā brahmacariyā cavite yathā taṃ sakkena patthitaṃ,🔽tatheva ahosi. Atha sakkassa patthanāya samiddhabhāvaṃ viditvā sā devakaññā tositā,
analyzed: jhānam antaradhāyi tasmin tamhā jhānā brahmacariyā cavite yathā tam sakkena patthitam  tathā iva ahosi atha sakkassa patthanāya samiddha bhāvam viditvā sā deva kaññā tositā
translated: When his celibacy was broken, just as Sakka had wished,🔽then that goddess, knowing that Sakka’s wish had been fulfilled, was satisfied.

original: tassa tena brahmacariyavināsena sañjanitapītipāmojjāti attho.
analyzed: tassa tena brahmacariya vināsena sañjanita pīti pāmojjā ati attho
translated: The meaning is that she was satisfied with the joy and delight that arose in her because of the destruction of his celibacy.

original: Manasā agamāti sā taṃ āliṅgitvā ṭhitā “aho vata sakko pallaṅkaṃ me peseyyā”ti evaṃ
analyzed: manasā agamā ati sā tam āliṅgitvā ṭhitā aho vata sakko pallaṅkam me peseyya ati evam
translated: “She went with her mind” means that she stood there, embracing him, thinking, “Oh, may Sakka send me a couch.”

original: pavattena manasā indaṃ agamā. Nandane vaneti nandijananasamatthatāya nandanavanasaṅkhāte
analyzed: pavattena manasā indam agamā nandane vane iti nandi janana samattha tāya nandana vana saṅkhāte
translated: With a mind that was intent, he went to Indra. In the Nandana Grove: because it is able to cause delight, it is called the Nandana Grove.

original: tāvatiṃsabhavane vasantaṃ. Devakuñjaroti devaseṭṭho. Pahiṇīti pesesi. “Pāhiṇī”tipi
analyzed: tāvatiṃsa bhavane vasantam deva kuñjaro ti deva seṭṭhaḥ pahiṇī iti pesesi
translated: Dwelling in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven. The lord of the gods: the best of the gods. He sent: he dispatched. The reading is also “he sent” (pahiṇī).

original: pāṭho. Sopavāhananti saparivāraṃ. Sauttaracchadapaññāsanti paññāsāya uttaracchadehi🔽paṭicchāditaṃ. Sahassapaṭiyatthatanti sahassadibbakojavatthataṃ. Tamenaṃ tatthāti🔽taṃ isisiṅgaṃ tattha dibbapallaṅke nisinnā sā ure katvā dhāresi. Tīṇi vassānīti ekamuhuttaṃ
analyzed: sa upavāhananti sa parivāram sa uttaracchada paññāsanti paññāsāyaḥ uttaracchadehi  paṭicchāditam sahassa paṭiyatthatanti sahassa dibba kojava tthatam tam enam tattha ati  tam isisiṅgam tattha dibba pallaṅke nisinnā sā ure katvā dhāresi tīṇi vassāni iti eka muhuttam
translated: With a retinue: with a following. With a canopy of fifty: covered with fifty canopies.

original: viya manussagaṇanāya tīṇi vassāni taṃ ure nipajjāpetvā tattha nisinnā dhāresi.
analyzed: viya manussa gaṇanāya tīṇi vassāni tam tattha nisinnā dhāresi
translated: With a thousand: spread with a thousand divine cloths. They held him there: they held that Isisiṅga, placing him on their breasts, sitting there. For three years: for three years according to human reckoning,🔽sitting there, they held him, as if it were a moment.

original: Vimadoti nimmado vigatasaññabhāvo. So hi tīṇi saṃvaccharāni visañño sayitvā pacchā
analyzed: vimado ti nimmadaḥ vigata sañña bhāvo so hi tīṇi saṃvaccharāni visaññaḥ sayitvā pacchā
translated: Senseless: unconscious, devoid of perception. For he lay unconscious for three years, and then

original: paṭiladdhasañño pabujjhi. Tasmiṃ pabujjhamāne hatthādiphandanaṃ disvāva alambusā
analyzed: paṭiladdha saññaḥ tasmin pabujjhamāne hattha ādi phandanam alambusā
translated: he awoke, having regained his perception. As he awoke, seeing the waving of hands and so on, he was alarmed,🔽and he looked around.

original: tassa pabujjhanabhāvaṃ ñatvā pallaṅkaṃ antaradhāpetvā sayampi antarahitā aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: tassa pabujjhana bhāvam ñatvā pallaṅkam antaradhāpetvā sayam pi antarahitā aṭṭhāsi
translated: Knowing that he was waking up, she caused the couch to disappear and stood there invisible.

original: Addasāsīti so assamapadaṃ olokento “kena nu khomhi sīlavināsaṃ pāpito”ti cintetvā
analyzed: addasāsi iti saḥ assama padam olokento kena nu kho mhi sīla vināsam pāpito ti cintetvā
translated: “He saw”: looking at the hermitage, he thought, “By whom have I been caused to fall from virtue?”

original: mahantena saddena paridevamāno addasāsi. Haritarukkheti aggiyāyanasaṅkhātaṃ aggisālaṃ🔽samantā parivāretvā ṭhite haritapattarukkhe. Navapattavananti taruṇehi navapattehi
analyzed: mahantena saddena paridevamānaḥ addasāsi harita rukkha iti aggiyāyana saṅkhātam aggi sālam  samantā parivāretvā ṭhite harita patta rukkhe taruṇehi nava pattehi
translated: and he wept with a loud voice. “Green trees”: the fire-sanctuary called the “fire-grove”

original: sañchannaṃ vanaṃ. Rudanti paridevanto.
analyzed: sañchannam vanam rudanti paridevantaḥ
translated: surrounded by trees with green leaves. “A grove with fresh leaves”: a grove covered with young fresh leaves. “Weeping”: lamenting.

original: Na juhe na jape manteti ayamassa paridevanagāthā. Pahāpitanti hāpitaṃ, pa-kāro upasaggamattaṃ.
analyzed: na juhe na jape mantā iti ayam assa paridevana gāthā pahāpitam ti hāpitam pakāraḥ upasagga mattam
translated: “I neither offer oblations nor recite mantras”: this is his lament. “Abandoned”: hāpitaṃ, the pa- is merely a prefix.

original: Pāricariyāyāti ko nu kilesapāricariyāya ito pubbe mama cittaṃ palobhayīti paridevati.
analyzed: pāricariyāya ati kaḥ nu kilesa pāricariyāya itas pubbe mama cittam palobhayi iti paridevati
translated: “To attend upon”: “Who has previously seduced my mind to attend upon defilements?” Thus he laments.

original: Yo me tejā ha sambhutanti ha-kāro nipātamattaṃ. Yo mama samaṇatejena sambhūtaṃ jhānaguṇaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ me hakāraḥ nipāta mattam yaḥ mama samaṇa tejena sambhūtam jhāna guṇam
translated: “That which was produced by my energy, O Sambhūta”: the ha is merely a particle. “That which was produced by my energy, O Sambhūta, my virtue,

original: nānāratanaparipuṇṇaṃ mahantaṃ mahaṇṇave nāvaṃ viya gaṇhi, vināsaṃ pāpesi, ko nāmesoti paridevatīti.
analyzed: nānā ratana paripuṇṇam mahantam nāvam viya gaṇhi vināsam pāpesi kaḥ nāma isaḥ iti paridevati iti
translated: as if he had seized a great ship filled with various precious stones in the great ocean and had wrecked it. Who is it that has brought me to this pass?”

original: Taṃ sutvā alambusā cintesi – “sacāhaṃ na kathessāmi, ayaṃ me abhisapissati, handassa kathessāmī”ti. Sā dissamānena kāyena ṭhatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā alambusā cintesi sacā aham na kathessāmi ayam me abhisapissati handassa kathessāmi iti sā dissamānena kāyena ṭhatvā gātham āha
translated: When she heard this, Alambusā thought to herself, “If I do not tell him, he will curse me. I had better tell him.” So she stood there, displaying her body, and addressed the prince in verse:

original: “Ahaṃ te pāricariyāya, devarājena pesitā;
analyzed: aham te pāricariyāya devarājena pesitā
translated: “I was sent to you, O prince, to wait upon you, by the king of the gods.

original: Avadhiṃ cittaṃ cittena, pamādo tvaṃ na bujjhasī”ti.
analyzed: avadhim cittam cittena pamādaḥ tvam na bujjhasi iti
translated: I have won your heart by my heart, but you are heedless and do not know it.”

original: So tassā kathaṃ sutvā pitarā dinnaovādaṃ saritvā “pitu vacanaṃ akatvā mahāvināsaṃ pattomhī”ti paridevanto catasso gāthāyo abhāsi –
analyzed: saḥ tassā katham sutvā pitarā dinnaovādam saritvā pitu vacanam a katvā mahā vināsam patto mhi iti paridevantaḥ catassaḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsi
translated: When he heard her speak thus, he remembered the advice given him by his father, and said to himself, “It is because I did not do as my father told me to do that I have come to this pass.” And lamenting, he recited four verses:

original: “Imāni kira maṃ tāto, kassapo anusāsati;
analyzed: imāni kira mama tātaḥ kassapaḥ anusāsati
translated: “These things, it seems, my father Kassapa advised me to do:

original: Kamalāsadisitthiyo, tāyo bujjhesi māṇava.🔽“Uregaṇḍāyo bujjhesi, tāyo bujjhesi māṇava;
analyzed: kamalā sadisā itthiyaḥ tāyaḥ bujjhesi māṇava  uregaṇḍāyaḥ bujjhesi tāyaḥ bujjhesi māṇava
translated: ‘Beware of women like lotuses.’🔽“‘Beware of women with prominent breasts,’ my father advised me to do:

original: Iccānusāsi maṃ tāto, yathā maṃ anukampako.
analyzed: mam tātaḥ yathā mam anukampakaḥ
translated: ‘Beware of women,’ thus did my father advise me, out of pity for me.

original: “Tassāhaṃ vacanaṃ nākaṃ, pitu vuddhassa sāsanaṃ;
analyzed: tassa aham vacanam nākam pitu vuddhassa sāsanam
translated: “But I did not obey the words of my father, the aged one,

original: Araññe nimmanussamhi, svajja jhāyāmi ekako.
analyzed: araññe nimmanussamhi svajja jhāyāmi ekakaḥ
translated: Alone I meditate today In forest that is void of men.

original: “Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi, dhiratthu jīvitena me;
analyzed: sā uham tathā karissāmi jīvitena me
translated: “So I will do as you advise; fie on my life!

original: Puna vā tādiso hessaṃ, maraṇaṃ me bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: puna vā tādisaḥ hessam maraṇam me bhavissati iti
translated: Or else I’ll be like this again, and death will be my fate.”

original: Tattha imānīti imāni vacanāni. Kamalāsadisitthiyoti kamalā vuccati nāripupphalatā,
analyzed: tattha imāni iti imāni vacanāni kamalā sadisa itthiyaḥ ti kamalā vuccati nāri puppha latā
translated: Herein, these are the words: “A woman like a jasmine flower” : a creeper bearing jasmine flowers is called a “jasmine flower” ,

original: tāsaṃ pupphasadisā itthiyo. Tāyo bujjhesi māṇavāti māṇava tvaṃ tāyo jāneyyāsi, ñatvā
analyzed: tāsam puppha sadisāḥ itthiyaḥ tāyaḥ bujjhesi māṇava ati māṇava tvam tāyaḥ jāneyyāsi ñatvā
translated: and women are like its flowers. “You should know these, young man” : young man, you should know these. “Having known them,

original: dassanapathaṃ agantvā palāpeyyāsīti yāni evarūpāni vacanāni tadā maṃ tāto anusāsati,🔽imāni kira tānīti. Uregaṇḍāyoti uramhi dvīhi gaṇḍehi samannāgatā. Tāyo bujjhesi,🔽māṇavāti, māṇava, tāyo attano vasaṃ gate vināsaṃ pāpentīti tvaṃ jāneyyāsi. Nākanti
analyzed: dassana patham a gantvā palāpeyyāsi iti yāni evarūpāni vacanāni tadā mama tātaḥ anusāsati  imāni kira tāni iti uregaṇḍāya iti uramhi dvīhi gaṇḍehi samannāgatā tāyaḥ bujjhesi  māṇava ati māṇava vasam gate vināsam pāpenti iti tvam jāneyyāsi nākanti
translated: without going into their presence, you should flee” : these are the words my father advised me with then.

original: nākariṃ. Jhāyāmīti pajjhāyāmi paridevāmi. Dhiratthu jīvitena meti dhiratthu garahitaṃ
analyzed: na akarim jhāyāmi iti pajjhāyāmi paridevāmi dhiratthu jīvitena mā iti dhiratthu garahitam
translated: “These, it seems, are them” . “With two swellings on her chest” : she has two swellings on her chest. “You should know these, young man” : young man, you should know that these women, when they come into your power, will bring about your destruction. “I did not” : I did not do it. “I meditate” : I meditate, I lament. “Fie on my life” : fie on my despised life!

original: mama jīvitaṃ, jīvitena me ko attho. Puna vāti tathā karissāmi, yathā puna vā tādiso
analyzed: mama jīvitam jīvitena me kaḥ atthaḥ puna vā ati tathā karissāmi yathā puna vā tādisaḥ
translated: my life, what have I to do with life? Again I will do as I did before,🔽

original: bhavissāmi, naṭṭhaṃ jhānaṃ uppādetvā vītarāgo bhavissāmi, maraṇaṃ vā me bhavissatīti.
analyzed: bhavissāmi naṭṭham jhānam uppādetvā vīta rāgaḥ bhavissāmi maraṇam vā me bhavissati iti
translated: “What have I to do with life? What have I to do with life? I will so act that I may never again be born into this world. I will so act that I may again attain the ecstatic meditations. I will so act that I may become free from the passions. I will so act that I may die.”

original: So kāmarāgaṃ pahāya puna jhānaṃ uppādesi. Athassa samaṇatejaṃ disvā jhānassa ca uppāditabhāvaṃ ñatvā alambusā bhītā khamāpesi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā dve gāthāyo abhāsi –
analyzed: saḥ kāma rāgam pahāya puna jhānam uppādesi athassa samaṇa tejam disvā jhānassa ca uppādita bhāvam ñatvā alambusā bhītā khamāpesi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā dve gāthāyaḥ abhāsi
translated: Abandoning his passion, he again attained the ecstatic meditations. Then, seeing the power of the monk’s virtue and knowing that he had again attained the ecstatic meditations, Alambusā, terrified, craved his pardon. Expounding this matter, the Teacher pronounced the following Stanza,

original: “Tassa tejaṃ vīriyañca, dhitiṃ ñatvā avaṭṭhitaṃ;
analyzed: tassa tejam vīriyam ca dhitim ñatvā avaṭṭhitam
translated: “Seeing his power, his energy, his steadfastness,

original: Sirasā aggahī pāde, isisiṅgaṃ alambusā.
analyzed: sirasā aggahī pāde isisiṅgam alambusā
translated: Alambusā, bowing her head, craved the pardon of the Seer.

original: “Mā me kujjha mahāvīra, mā me kujjha mahāise;
analyzed: mā me kujjha mahāvīra mā me kujjha mahāise
translated: “Be not angry with me, O mighty hero, be not angry with me, O mighty Seer!

original: Mahā attho mayā ciṇṇo, tidasānaṃ yasassinaṃ;
analyzed: mahā atthaḥ mayā ciṇṇaḥ tidasānam yasassinam
translated: Great profit have I gained, I who have seen the glory of the Thirty-three!

original: Tayā pakampitaṃ āsi, sabbaṃ devapuraṃ tadā”ti.
analyzed: tayā pakampitam āsi sabbam deva puram tadā ati
translated: By you was all the city of the gods made to tremble.”

original: Atha naṃ so “khamāmi te, bhadde, yathāsukhaṃ gacchā”ti vissajjento gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam saḥ khamāmi te bhadde yathāsukham gacchāti vissajjentaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then the monk said to her, “I pardon you, my dear. Go in peace.” And pronouncing the following Stanza, he dismissed her,

original: “Tāvatiṃsā ca ye devā, tidasānañca vāsavo;
analyzed: ca ye devā vāsavau
translated: “The Thirty-three, and Vāsava, the lord of the Thirty-three,

original: Tvañca bhadde sukhī hohi, gaccha kaññe yathāsukha”nti.
analyzed: tvañca bhadde sukhī hohi gaccha kaññe yathāsukhanti
translated: “And you, my dear, be happy, and go to another as you please.”

original: Sā taṃ vanditvā teneva suvaṇṇapallaṅkena devapuraṃ gatā. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā tisso gāthāyo abhāsi –
analyzed: sā tam vanditvā tena iva suvaṇṇa pallaṅkena deva puram gatā tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā tissaḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsi
translated: She paid her respects to him, and returned to the city of the gods on the very same golden couch. Expounding this matter, the Master uttered three stanzas:

original: “Tassa pāde gahetvāna, katvā ca naṃ padakkhiṇaṃ;
analyzed: tassa pāde gahetvāna katvā ca nam padakkhiṇam
translated: “She took his feet, and then she walked around him, keeping him on her right;

original: Añjaliṃ paggahetvāna, tamhā ṭhānā apakkami.
analyzed: añjalim paggahetvāna tamhā ṭhānā apakkami
translated: And then she raised her joined hands in salutation, and left that place.

original: “Yo ca tassāsi pallaṅko, sovaṇṇo sopavāhano;
analyzed: yaḥ ca tassa asi pallaṅkaḥ sovaṇṇo sa upavāhano
translated: “The couch on which she sat, of gold, with footstool,

original: Sauttaracchadapaññāso, sahassapaṭiyatthato;
analyzed: sa uttaracchada paññāsaḥ
translated: With canopy above, and a thousand cushions,

original: Tameva pallaṅkamāruyha, agā devāna santike.
analyzed: tam eva pallaṅkam āruyha agāḥ devān santike
translated: On that same couch she mounted, and went to the presence of the gods.

original: “Tamokkamiva āyantiṃ, jalantiṃ vijjutaṃ yathā;
analyzed: tamokkam iva āyantim jalantim vijjutam yathā
translated: “As she came, she seemed to be coming down from the sky, and shining like a flash of lightning;

original: Patīto sumano vitto, devindo adadā vara”nti.
analyzed: patītaḥ sumanaḥ vittaḥ devindaḥ adadāḥ varanti
translated: Delighted, pleased, and satisfied, the Lord of the gods gave her a boon.”

original: Tattha okkamivāti dīpakaṃ viya. “Patīto”tiādīhi tuṭṭhākārova dassito adadā varanti āgantvā vanditvā ṭhitāya tuṭṭho varaṃ adāsi.
analyzed: tattha okkamiva ati dīpakam viya patīto ti ādīhi tuṭṭhā kāraḥ uva dassitaḥ adadā varanti āgantvā vanditvā ṭhitāya tuṭṭhaḥ varam adāsi
translated: Here “okkamivā” means “like a lamp.” “Delighted,” etc., show the manner in which he was pleased. “He gave her a boon” means that he gave her a boon, being pleased, after she had come and paid him homage and stood there.

original: Sā tassa santike varaṃ gaṇhantī osānagāthamāha –
analyzed: sā tassa santike varam gaṇhantī osāna gātham āha
translated: She, accepting the boon from him, spoke the last stanza:

original: “Varañce me ado sakka, sabbabhūtānamissara;
analyzed: varañce me ado sakka
translated: “If thou wilt grant me a boon, O Sakka, lord of all beings,

original: Nisippalobhikā gacche, etaṃ sakka varaṃ vare”ti.
analyzed: nisippalobhikā gacche etam sakka varam vara iti
translated: I will not go to tempt the Seer: this boon I ask of thee, O Sakka.”

original: Tassattho – “sakka devarāja, sace me tvaṃ varaṃ ado, puna isipalobhikāya na gaccheyyaṃ, mā maṃ etadatthāya pahiṇeyyāsi, etaṃ varaṃ vare yācāmī”ti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ sakka devarāja sace me tvam varam ado punar isipalobhikāya na gaccheyyam mā mama etad atthāya pahiṇeyyāsi etam varam vare yācāmi iti
translated: The meaning is: “O Sakka, king of the gods, if thou wilt grant me a boon, I will not go to tempt the Seer; do not send me for that purpose; this boon I ask of thee.”

original: Satthā tassa bhikkhuno imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi,
analyzed: satthā tassa bhikkhuno imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi
translated: The Teacher, having related this story, explained the Truths, and identified the Birth by saying, “At that time the old wife was Alambusā, the monk who was tempted was the Seer Siṅga, and I myself was the Great Seer.”

original: saccapariyosāne so bhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. Tadā alambusā purāṇadutiyikā
analyzed: sacca pariyosāne so bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi tadā alambusā purāṇadutiyikā
translated: At the conclusion of the Truths, the monk was established in the Fruit of Conversion.

original: ahosi, isisiṅgo ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu, pitā mahāisi pana ahameva ahosinti.
analyzed: ahosi isisiṅgaḥ ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu pitā mahā aisi pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: At that time Alambusā was the old wife, the monk who was tempted was Siṅga, and the Great Seer was myself.

original: Alambusājātakavaṇṇanā tatiyā.
analyzed: alambusā jātaka vaṇṇanā tatiyā
translated: The story of Alambusā is ended.

original: [524] 4. Saṅkhapālajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The story of Saṅkhapāla

original: Ariyāvakāsosīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto uposathakammaṃ ārabbha kathesi. Tadā
analyzed: ariya avakāso asi iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ uposatha kammam ārabbha kathesi tadā
translated: “The opening of the noble path,” etc.—this story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, about the Uposatha observance.

original: hi satthā uposathike upāsake sampahaṃsetvā “porāṇakapaṇḍitā mahatiṃ nāgasampattiṃ
analyzed: hi satthā uposathike upāsake sampahaṃsetvā porāṇaka paṇḍitāḥ mahatim nāga sampattim
translated: The Teacher, after gladdening the lay disciples who were observing the Uposatha, said, “The wise men of old, after renouncing the great glory of the Nāgas,

original: pahāya uposathavāsaṃ upavasiṃsuyevā”ti vatvā tehi yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: pahāya uposatha vāsam vatvā tehi yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: observed the Uposatha fast.” And when they asked him to tell the story of the past, he did so.

original: Atīte rājagahe magadharājā nāma rajjaṃ kāresi. Tadā bodhisatto tassa rañño aggamahesiyā
analyzed: atīte rājagahe magadharājā nāma rajjam kāresi tadā bodhisatto tassa rañño aggamahesiyā
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was conceived in the womb of the king’s chief consort,

original: kucchimhi nibbatti, “duyyodhano”tissa nāmaṃ kariṃsu. So vayappatto takkasilāyaṃ sabbasippāni
analyzed: kucchimhi nibbatti duyyodhanotissa nāmam kariṃsu saḥ vaya patto takkasilāyam sabba sippāni
translated: and when he was born, they gave him the name of Duryodhana. When he grew up, he learned all the arts in Takkasilā,

original: uggaṇhitvā āgantvā pitu sippaṃ dassesi. Atha naṃ pitā rajje abhisiñcitvā isipabbajjaṃ
analyzed: uggaṇhitvā āgantvā pitu sippam dassesi atha nam pitā rajje abhisiñcitvā isipabbajjam
translated: and when he returned, he showed his skill to his father. Then his father anointed him king, and he himself retired from the world,

original: pabbajitvā uyyāne vasi. Bodhisatto divasassa tikkhattuṃ pitu santikaṃ agamāsi. Tassa
analyzed: pabbajitvā uyyāne vasi bodhisatto divasassa tikkhattum pitu santikam agamāsi tassa
translated: and lived in a garden. The Bodhisatta went to his father three times a day,

original: mahālābhasakkāro udapādi. So teneva palibodhena kasiṇaparikammamattampi kātuṃ asakkonto
analyzed: mahā lābha sakkāraḥ udapādi saḥ tena iva palibodhena kasiṇa parikamma mattam pi kātum a sakkonto
translated: and he received great gifts and honors. He was unable to perform even the preliminary meditation for the kasiṇas,

original: cintesi – “mahā me lābhasakkāro, na sakkā mayā idha vasantena imaṃ jaṭaṃ chindituṃ,
analyzed: cintesi mahā me lābha sakkāraḥ na sakkā mayā idha vasantena imam jaṭam chinditum
translated: because of the hindrance of his great gifts and honors. He thought, “I have great gifts and honors. I cannot cut this knot while I live here.

original: puttassa me anārocetvāva aññattha gamissāmī”ti. So kañci ajānāpetvā uyyānā nikkhamitvā
analyzed: puttassa me an ārocetvā ava aññattha gamissāmi iti saḥ kañci a jānāpetvā uyyānā nikkhamitvā
translated: “I will go away somewhere without telling my son.” He left the park without telling anyone.

original: magadharaṭṭhaṃ atikkamitvā mahisakaraṭṭhe saṅkhapāladahato nāma nikkhantāya kaṇṇaveṇṇāya🔽nadiyā nivattane candakapabbataṃ upanissāya paṇṇasālaṃ katvā tattha vasanto kasiṇaparikammaṃ🔽katvā jhānābhiññā nibbattetvā uñchācariyāya yāpesi. Tamenaṃ saṅkhapālo nāma nāgarājā
analyzed: magadha raṭṭham atikkamitvā mahisaka raṭṭhe saṅkhapāladahataḥ nāma nikkhantāya kaṇṇa veṇṇāya  nadiyāḥ nivattane candakapabbatam upanissāya paṇṇa sālam katvā tattha vasanto kasiṇa parikammaṃ  katvā jhāna abhiññāḥ nibbattetvā uñchā cariyāya yāpesi tam enam saṅkhapālaḥ nāma nāga rājā
translated: He crossed the Magadha country, and in the Mahiṃsa country, on the bank of the river Kaṇṇamuṇḍī, which flows from the Saṅkhapāladaha,🔽he built a leaf-hut on the Candaka mountain and lived there. He developed the meditation subject of kasiṇa and attained the jhānas and the superknowledges. He lived on alms food. A nāga king named Saṅkhapāla

original: mahantena parivārena kaṇṇaveṇṇanadito nikkhamitvā antarantarā upasaṅkamati. So tassa🔽dhammaṃ desesi. Athassa putto pitaraṃ daṭṭhukāmo gataṭṭhānaṃ ajānanto anuvicārāpetvā
analyzed: mahantena parivārena kaṇṇa veṇṇa naditaḥ nikkhamitvā antar antarā upasaṅkamati saḥ tassa  dhammaṃ desesi athassa puttaḥ pitaram daṭṭhu kāmo gata ṭṭhānam a jānantaḥ anuvicārāpetvā
translated: came to him with a great retinue from the river Kaṇṇamuṇḍī and visited him from time to time. He taught the Dhamma to the nāga king.🔽Then the son, who wanted to see his father, not knowing where he had gone, had inquiries made.

original: “asukaṭṭhāne nāma vasatī”ti ñatvā tassa dassanatthāya mahantena parivārena tattha
analyzed: asuka ṭṭhāne nāma vasati iti ñatvā tassa dassana tthāya mahantena parivārena tattha
translated: He found out that he was living in such and such a place. He went there with a great retinue to see his father.

original: gantvā ekamante khandhavāraṃ nivāsetvā katipayehi amaccehi saddhiṃ assamapadābhimukho pāyāsi.
analyzed: gantvā ekamante khandhavāram nivāsetvā katipayehi amaccehi saddhim assama pada abhimukhaḥ pāyāsi
translated: He halted his army on one side, and with a few ministers he went to the hermitage.

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe saṅkhapālo mahantena parivārena dhammaṃ suṇanto nisīdi. So taṃ rājānaṃ
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe saṅkhapālaḥ mahantena parivārena dhammam suṇantaḥ nisīdi saḥ tam rājānam
translated: At that moment Saṅkhapāla was sitting listening to the Law, surrounded by a great retinue. He saw the king coming,

original: āgacchantaṃ disvā isiṃ vanditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi. Rājā pitaraṃ vanditvā paṭisanthāraṃ
analyzed: āgacchantam disvā isim vanditvā uṭṭhāya āsanā pakkāmi rājā pitaram vanditvā paṭisanthāram
translated: and after paying obeisance to the seer, he rose up from his seat and departed. The king paid obeisance to his father, and after exchanging greetings,

original: katvā nisīditvā pucchi – “bhante, katararājā nāmesa tumhākaṃ santikaṃ āgato”ti. Tāta,
analyzed: katvā nisīditvā pucchi bhante katara rājā nāma isa tumhākam santikam āgataḥ iti tāta
translated: sat down and asked, “Father, what king is it that has come to you?” “Dear,

original: saṅkhapālanāgarājā nāmesoti. So tassa sampattiṃ nissāya nāgabhavane lobhaṃ katvā🔽katipāhaṃ vasitvā pitu bhikkhāhāraṃ nibaddhaṃ dāpetvā attano nagarameva gantvā catūsu
analyzed: saṅkhapāla nāga rājā nāma iso ti saḥ tassa sampattim nissāya nāga bhavane lobham katvā  katipāham vasitvā bhikkhāhāram nibaddham dāpetvā attanaḥ nagaram eva gantvā catūsu
translated: it is the king of the nāgas, Saṅkhapāla.” He became envious of his prosperity,

original: dvāresu dānasālāyo kāretvā sakalajambudīpaṃ saṅkhobhento dānaṃ datvā sīlaṃ rakkhitvā
analyzed: dvāresu dāna sālāyaḥ kāretvā sakala jambudīpam saṅkhobhentaḥ dānam datvā sīlam rakkhitvā
translated: and after remaining there for several days, he had his father’s alms-food regularly given to him, and then he went back to his own city. He had alms-halls built at the four gates,

original: uposathakammaṃ katvā nāgabhavanaṃ patthetvā āyupariyosāne nāgabhavane nibbattitvā
analyzed: uposatha kammam katvā nāga bhavanam patthetvā āyu pariyosāne nāga bhavane nibbattitvā
translated: and after giving alms and keeping the precepts and performing the Uposatha ceremonies, he aspired to be reborn in the nāga world. At the end of his life he was reborn in the nāga world,

original: saṅkhapālanāgarājā ahosi. So gacchante kāle tāya sampattiyā vippaṭisārī hutvā tato
analyzed: saṅkhapāla nāga rājā ahosi saḥ gacchante kāle tāya sampattiyā vippaṭisārī hutvā tatas
translated: and became the nāga king Saṅkhapāla. As time went on, he became remorseful for his prosperity, and then

original: paṭṭhāya manussayoniṃ patthento uposathavāsaṃ vasi. Athassa nāgabhavane vasantassa
analyzed: paṭṭhāya manussa yonim patthento uposatha vāsam vasi athassa nāga bhavane vasantassa
translated: and he observed the Uposatha. But while he was living in the nāga’s abode

original: uposathavāso na sampajjati, sīlavināsaṃ pāpuṇāti. So tato paṭṭhāya nāgabhavanā nikkhamitvā
analyzed: uposatha vāsaḥ na sampajjati sīla vināsam pāpuṇāti so tatas paṭṭhāya nāga bhavanā nikkhamitvā
translated: he was unable to observe the Uposatha, and he lost his virtue. So he left the nāga’s abode

original: kaṇṇaveṇṇāya nadiyā avidūre mahāmaggassa ca ekapadikamaggassa ca antare ekaṃ vammikaṃ🔽parikkhipitvā uposathaṃ adhiṭṭhāya samādinnasīlo “mama cammamaṃsādīhi atthikā cammamaṃsādīni
analyzed: kaṇṇaveṇṇāya nadiyāḥ avidūre mahā maggassa ca ekapadika maggassa ca antare ekam vammikam  parikkhipitvā uposatham adhiṭṭhāya samādinna sīlaḥ mama camma maṃsa ādīhi atthikā camma maṃsa ādīni
translated: and built a termite-mound near the river Kaṇṇamuṇḍī, between the main road and a side road.

original: harantū”ti attānaṃ dānamukhe vissajjetvā vammikamatthake nipanno samaṇadhammaṃ karonto
analyzed: harantu uti attānam dāna mukhe vissajjetvā vammika matthake nipanno samaṇa dhammam karonto
translated: He surrounded the termite-mound, observed the Uposatha, and undertook the precepts. Then he gave himself away at the gate of giving, thinking, “Let those who need my skin, flesh, etc., take my skin, flesh, etc.” He lay down on top of the termite-mound, practiced the ascetic’s duties,

original: cātuddase pannarase vasitvā pāṭipade nāgabhavanaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: cātuddase pannarase vasitvā pāṭipade nāgabhavanam gacchati
translated: and lived there on the fourteenth and fifteenth days of the half-month. On the sixteenth day he went to the nāga’s abode.

original: Tasmiṃ ekadivasaṃ evaṃ sīlaṃ samādiyitvā nipanne paccantagāmavāsino soḷasa janā “maṃsaṃ
analyzed: tasmin eka divasam evam sīlam samādiyitvā nipanne paccanta gāma vāsinaḥ soḷasa janāḥ maṃsam
translated: One day, after he had undertaken the precepts in this way and lay down, sixteen men from a village in the border region, who were wandering in the forest with weapons in their hands, thinking, “We will get some meat,”

original: āharissāmā”ti āvudhahatthā araññe vicarantā kiñci alabhitvā nikkhantā taṃ vammikamatthake
analyzed: āharissāma ati āvudha hatthā araññe vicarantā kiñci a labhitvā nikkhantā tam vammika matthake
translated: got nothing and left. They saw the nāga on top of the termite-mound.

original: nipannaṃ disvā “mayaṃ ajja godhāpotakampi na labhimhā, imaṃ nāgarājānaṃ vadhitvā
analyzed: nipannam disvā mayam ajja godhā potakam pi na labhimha imam nāga rājānam vadhitvā
translated: Seeing him lying there, they thought, “We have not been able to get even a young goat to-day. We will kill this king of the nāgas

original: khādissāmā”ti cintetvā “mahā kho panesa gayhamāno palāyeyya, yathānipannameva taṃ
analyzed: khādissāma ati cintetvā mahā kho pana isa gayhamānaḥ palāyeyya yathā nipannam eva tam
translated: and eat him.” But they thought again, “He is a very large nāga. If we catch him, he will perhaps escape from us. We will therefore pierce him with our spears

original: bhogesu sūlehi vijjhitvā dubbalaṃ katvā gaṇhissāmā”ti sūlāni ādāya upasaṅkamiṃsu.
analyzed: bhogesu sūlehi vijjhitvā dubbalam katvā gaṇhissāma ati sūlāni ādāya upasaṅkamiṃsu
translated: while he is lying down, and so make him weak and helpless, and then we will catch him.” So saying, they took their spears and went up to him.

original: Bodhisattassa sarīraṃ mahantaṃ ekadoṇikanāvappamāṇaṃ vaṭṭetvā ṭhapitasumanapupphadāmaṃ
analyzed: bodhisattassa sarīram mahantam eka doṇika nāva ppamāṇam vaṭṭetvā ṭhapita sumana puppha dāmam
translated: The body of the Bodhisatta was very large, being as big as a boat with a single outrigger. It was lying there like a garland of sumana flowers placed in a straight line,

original: viya jiñjukaphalasannibhehi akkhīhi jayasumanapupphasadisena ca sīsena samannāgataṃ
analyzed: viya jiñjuka phala sannibhehi akkhīhi jayasumana puppha sadisena ca sīsena samannāgatam
translated: and was very beautiful, having eyes like the jīṇjūka fruit and a head like the jasmine flower.

original: ativiya sobhati. So tesaṃ soḷasannaṃ janānaṃ padasaddena bhogantarato sīsaṃ nīharitvā🔽rattakkhīni ummīletvā te sūlahatthe āgacchante disvā cintesi – “ajja mayhaṃ manoratho
analyzed: ativiya sobhati saḥ tesam soḷasannam janānam pada saddena bhogantarataḥ sīsam nīharitvā  ratta kkhīni ummīletvā te sūlahatthe āgacchante disvā cintesi ajja mayham manorathaḥ
translated: The Bodhisatta, hearing the sound of the men’s footsteps, drew his head from between his coils,

original: matthakaṃ pāpuṇissati, ahaṃ attānaṃ dānamukhe niyyādetvā vīriyaṃ adhiṭṭhahitvā nipanno,
analyzed: matthakam pāpuṇissati aham attānam dāna mukhe niyyādetvā vīriyam adhiṭṭhahitvā nipannaḥ
translated: opened his red eyes, and seeing the men coming with their spears, thought to himself, “To-day my desire will be fulfilled. I have been lying here, making a vow to give myself as an offering, and exerting myself to the utmost.

original: ime mama sarīraṃ sattīhi koṭṭetvā chiddāvachiddaṃ karonte kodhavasena akkhīni ummīletvā
analyzed: ime mama sarīram sattīhi koṭṭetvā chidda avachiddam karonte kodha vasena akkhīni ummīletvā
translated: “As they are piercing my body with spears and mangling it, I will not open my eyes in anger and look at them.”

original: na olokessāmī”ti attano sīlabhedabhayena daḷhaṃ adhiṭṭhāya sīsaṃ bhogantareyeva pavesetvā🔽nipajji. Atha naṃ te upagantvā naṅguṭṭhe gahetvā kaḍḍhantā bhūmiyaṃ pothetvā tikhiṇasūlehi
analyzed: na olokessāmi iti attano sīlabheda bhayena daḷham adhiṭṭhāya sīsam bhogantareya iva pavesetvā  nipajji atha nam te upagantvā naṅguṭṭhe gahetvā kaḍḍhantā bhūmiyam pothetvā tikhiṇa sūlehi
translated: And through fear of breaking his virtue he made a firm resolve, and thrusting his head between his shoulders,🔽he lay down. Then they came up to him, and seizing him by the legs, they dragged him along, and rolling him on the ground, they pierced him in eight places with sharp stakes,

original: aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu vijjhitvā sakaṇṭakakāḷavettayaṭṭhiyo pahāramukhehi pavesetvā aṭṭhasu
analyzed: aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu vijjhitvā pahāra mukhehi pavesetvā aṭṭhasu
translated: and thrusting into his mouth the bones of a black snake with its fangs, they bound him to eight stakes in eight places,

original: ṭhānesu kājenādāya mahāmaggaṃ paṭipajjiṃsu, mahāsatto sūlehi vijjhanato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: ṭhānesu kājena ādāya mahā maggam paṭipajjiṃsu mahāsatto sūlehi vijjhanataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: and set out on the high road. From the time he was pierced with the stakes,

original: ekaṭṭhānepi kodhavasena akkhīni ummīletvā te na olokesi. Tassa aṭṭhahi kājehi ādāya
analyzed: eka ṭṭhāne pi kodha vasena akkhīni ummīletvā te na olokesi tassa aṭṭhahi kājehi ādāya
translated: he did not open his eyes in anger and look at them even for a moment. As he was being carried away on the eight litters,

original: nīyamānassa sīsaṃ olambetvā bhūmiyaṃ pahari. Atha naṃ “sīsamassa olambatī”ti mahāmagge
analyzed: nīyamānassa sīsam olambetvā bhūmiyam atha nam sīsam assa olambati iti mahā magge
translated: his head hung down and struck the ground. Then they laid him down on the high road, saying, “His head hangs down.”🔽They pierced his nostrils with a young shoot, and drawing him along by a rope, they lifted up his head,

original: nipajjāpetvā taruṇasūlena nāsāpuṭaṃ vijjhitvā rajjukaṃ pavesetvā sīsaṃ ukkhipitvā
analyzed: nipajjāpetvā taruṇa sūlena nāsā puṭam vijjhitvā rajjukam pavesetvā sīsam ukkhipitvā
translated: and

original: kājakoṭiyaṃ laggitvā punapi ukkhipitvā maggaṃ paṭipajjiṃsu.
analyzed: kājakoṭiyam laggitvā puna api ukkhipitvā maggam paṭipajjiṃsu
translated: and then they lifted him up again and went on their way.

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe videharaṭṭhe mithilanagaravāsī āḷāro nāma kuṭumbiko pañca sakaṭasatāni
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe videha raṭṭhe mithila nagara vāsī āḷāraḥ nāma kuṭumbiko pañca sakaṭa satāni
translated: At that moment a merchant of Mithilā, in the kingdom of Videha, named Āḷāra, was going along in a comfortable carriage,

original: ādāya sukhayānake nisīditvā gacchanto te bhojaputte bodhisattaṃ tathā gaṇhitvā gacchante
analyzed: ādāya sukha yānake nisīditvā gacchantaḥ te bhojaputte bodhisattam tathā gaṇhitvā gacchante
translated: accompanied by five hundred carts, when he saw the sons of Bhoja carrying the Bodhisatta in this way.

original: disvā tesaṃ soḷasannampi soḷasahi vāhagoṇehi saddhiṃ pasataṃ pasataṃ suvaṇṇamāsake
analyzed: disvā tesam soḷasannam api soḷasahi vāha goṇehi saddhim pasatam pasatam suvaṇṇa māsake
translated: He gave to each of them a hundred pieces of gold, together with sixteen oxen,

original: sabbesaṃ nivāsanapārupanāni bhariyānampi nesaṃ vatthābharaṇāni datvā vissajjāpesi.
analyzed: sabbesam nivāsana pārupanāni bhariyānam pi nesam vattha ābharaṇāni da tvā vissajjāpesi
translated: and he gave to their wives clothes and ornaments, and then he sent them away.

original: Atha so nāgabhavanaṃ gantvā tattha papañcaṃ akatvā mahantena parivārena nikkhamitvā
analyzed: atha saḥ nāga bhavanam gantvā tattha papañcam a katvā mahantena parivārena nikkhamitvā
translated: Then he went to the Nāga’s abode, and without making any fuss there, he came out with a great retinue,

original: āḷāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā nāgabhavanassa vaṇṇaṃ kathetvā taṃ ādāya nāgabhavanaṃ gantvā
analyzed: āḷāram upasaṅkamitvā nāga bhavanassa vaṇṇam kathetvā tam ādāya nāga bhavanam gantvā
translated: and he approached Āḷāra, and after telling him of the beauty of the Nāga’s abode, he took him there,

original: tīhi nāgakaññāsatehi saddhiṃ mahantamassa yasaṃ datvā dibbehi kāmehi santappesi.
analyzed: tīhi nāga kaññā satehi saddhim mahantam assa yasam da tvā dibbehi kāmehi santappesi
translated: and he gave him great honour, together with three hundred Nāga maidens, and he entertained him with heavenly pleasures.

original: Āḷāro nāgabhavane ekavassaṃ vasitvā dibbakāme paribhuñjitvā “icchāmahaṃ, samma, pabbajitu”nti
analyzed: āḷāraḥ nāga bhavane eka vassam vasitvā dibba kāme paribhuñjitvā icchāmaham samma pabbajitunti
translated: Āḷāra, having lived in the nāga’s abode for one year, having enjoyed divine pleasures, after telling the nāga king: “Friend, I wish to go forth,”

original: nāgarājassa kathetvā pabbajitaparikkhāre gahetvā nāgabhavanato himavantappadesaṃ
analyzed: nāga rājassa kathetvā pabbajita parikkhāre gahetvā nāga bhavanataḥ himavanta ppadesam
translated: having taken the requisites for going forth, having gone from the nāga’s abode to the Himālaya region,

original: gantvā pabbajitvā tattha ciraṃ vasitvā aparabhāge cārikaṃ caranto bārāṇasiṃ patvā
analyzed: gantvā pabbajitvā tattha ciram vasitvā aparabhāge cārikam carantaḥ bārāṇasim patvā
translated: having gone forth there, having lived there for a long time, in the latter part of his life, while wandering on a journey, he arrived at Bārāṇasī,

original: rājuyyāne vasitvā punadivase bhikkhāya nagaraṃ pavisitvā rājadvāraṃ agamāsi. Atha
analyzed: rāja uyyāne vasitvā puna divase bhikkhāya nagaram pavisitvā rājadvāram agamāsi atha
translated: and lived in the King’s Pleasure Garden. On the following day, after entering the city for alms, he went to the King’s door. Then

original: naṃ bārāṇasirājā disvā iriyāpathe pasīditvā pakkosāpetvā paññattāsane nisīdāpetvā
analyzed: nam bārāṇasi rājā disvā iriyāpathe pasīditvā pakkosāpetvā paññatta āsane nisīdāpetvā
translated: the King of Bārāṇasī, after seeing him, being pleased with his deportment, after inviting him, having him sit on a prepared seat,

original: nānaggarasabhojanaṃ bhojetvā aññatarasmiṃ nīce āsane nisinno vanditvā tena saddhiṃ
analyzed: nānagga rasa bhojanam bhojetvā aññatarasmin nīce āsane nisinnaḥ vanditvā tena saddhim
translated: after feeding him with various kinds of flavoured food, sitting on a low seat, after worshipping him, while conversing with him,

original: sallapanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: he spoke this verse:

original: “Ariyāvakāsosi pasannanetto, maññe bhavaṃ pabbajito kulamhā;
analyzed: ariya avakāso asi pasanna nettaḥ maññe bhavam pabbajitaḥ kulamhā
translated: “You are a noble one, your eyes are clear, I think you have gone forth, good Sir, from the home life;

original: Kathaṃ nu vittāni pahāya bhoge, pabbaji nikkhamma gharā sapaññā”ti.
analyzed: katham nu vittāni pahāya bhoge pabbaji nikkhamma gharā sa paññā ati
translated: How is it, after giving up your wealth and possessions, you have gone forth, wise one, after leaving the home life?”

original: Tattha ariyāvakāsosīti niddosasundarasarīrāvakāsosi, abhirūposīti attho. Pasannanettoti
analyzed: tattha ariya avakāso asi iti niddosa sundara sarīra avakāso asi abhirūpaḥ usi iti attho pasanna netto ti
translated: Herein, a noble opening is a noble, beautiful opening of the body, is what is said. His eyes are clear:

original: pañcahi pasādehi yuttanetto. Kulamhāti khattiyakulā vā brāhmaṇakulā vā seṭṭhikulā🔽vā pabbajitosīti maññāmi. Kathaṃ nūti kena kāraṇena kiṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā dhanañca
analyzed: pañcahi pasādehi kulamhā ati khattiya kulā vā brāhmaṇa kulā vā seṭṭhi kulā  vā pabbajito asi iti maññāmi katham nu iti kena kāraṇena kim ārammaṇam katvā dhanam ca
translated: his eyes are endowed with the five kinds of eye-clear ness. You are a clansman: I think you are gone forth from a khattiya clan or a brahmin clan or a wealthy merchant clan.

original: upabhoge ca pahāya gharā nikkhamitvā pabbajitosi sapañña paṇḍitapurisāti pucchati.
analyzed: upabhoge ca pahāya gharā nikkhamitvā pabbajitaḥ asi sa pañña paṇḍita purisa ati pucchati
translated: How is it that you, wise man, have gone forth, abandoning wealth and sensual pleasures? He asks: “How is it that you, wise man, have gone forth, abandoning wealth and sensual pleasures?”

original: Tato paraṃ tāpasassa ca rañño ca vacanappaṭivacanavasena gāthānaṃ sambandho veditabbo –
analyzed: tato param tāpasassa ca rañño ca vacana paṭivacana vasena gāthānam sambandhaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The connection of the verses should be understood by way of the ascetic’s reply and the king’s question.

original: “Sayaṃ vimānaṃ naradeva disvā, mahānubhāvassa mahoragassa;
analyzed: sayam vimānam naradeva disvā mahā anubhāvassa mahā uragassa
translated: “Having seen the deva’s self-made mansion, the great power of the great nāga,

original: Disvāna puññāna mahāvipākaṃ, saddhāyahaṃ pabbajitomhi rāja.
analyzed: disvāna puññāna mahā vipākam saddhā ayam aham pabbajitaḥ amhi rāja
translated: And having seen the great result of merit, I went forth from home, O king, out of faith.

original: “Na kāmakāmā na bhayā na dosā, vācaṃ musā pabbajitā bhaṇanti;
analyzed: na kāma kāmāḥ na bhayāḥ na dosāḥ vācam musā pabbajitāḥ bhaṇanti
translated: “Those who have gone forth do not speak falsehoods, not for the sake of sensual pleasures, not out of fear, not out of hatred.

original: Akkhāhi me pucchito etamatthaṃ, sutvāna me jāyihitippasādo.
analyzed: akkhāhi me pucchitaḥ etam attham sutvāna me
translated: Answer me this question, O ascetic, and having heard your answer, I will have confidence.”

original: “Vāṇijja raṭṭhādhipa gacchamāno, pathe addasāsimhi bhojaputte;
analyzed: vāṇijja raṭṭha adhipa gacchamāno pathe addasā asimhi bhoja putte
translated: “As I was going along, O King, on business, I saw on the road two sons of Bhoja

original: Pavaḍḍhakāyaṃ uragaṃ mahantaṃ, ādāya gacchante pamodamāne.
analyzed: pavaḍḍha kāyam uragam mahantam ādāya gacchante pamodamāne
translated: Carrying a great big snake, a boa constrictor, and going along delighted.

original: “Sohaṃ samāgamma janinda tehi, pahaṭṭhalomo avacamhi bhīto;
analyzed: saḥ aham samāgamma janinda tehi pahaṭṭha lomaḥ bhīto
translated: “I approached them, O King, and, my hair standing on end, I said in fear:

original: Kuhiṃ ayaṃ nīyati bhīmakāyo, nāgena kiṃ kāhatha bhojaputtā.
analyzed: kuhim ayam bhīma kāyaḥ nāgena kim bhoja puttā
translated: ‘Where is this fearful body being taken? What do you say, O sons of Bhoja?’

original: “Nāgo ayaṃ nīyati bhojanatthā, pavaḍḍhakāyo urago mahanto;
analyzed: nāgaḥ ayam nīyati bhojanatthā pavaḍḍha kāyaḥ uragaḥ mahanto
translated: “‘This snake is being taken for food, a great big snake, a boa constrictor.

original: Sāduñca thūlañca muduñca maṃsaṃ, na tvaṃ rasaññāsi videhaputta.
analyzed: sādum ca thūlam ca mudum ca maṃsam na tvam rasaññā asi videha putta
translated: The flesh is good, fat, and tender, O Prince of Videha, you do not know the taste.’

original: “Ito mayaṃ gantvā sakaṃ niketaṃ, ādāya satthāni vikopayitvā;
analyzed: itas mayam gantvā sakam niketam ādāya satthāni vikopayitvā
translated: “‘Having gone from here to our abode, having taken our weapons and made ready,

original: Maṃsāni bhokkhāma pamodamānā, mayañhi ve sattavo pannagānaṃ.
analyzed: maṃsāni bhokkhāma pamodamānāḥ mayan hi ve sattavaḥ pannagānam
translated: we will enjoy the flesh, delighted, for we are, indeed, eaters of snakes.’

original: “Sace ayaṃ nīyati bhojanatthā, pavaḍḍhakāyo urago mahanto;
analyzed: sace ayam nīyati bhojanatthā pavaḍḍha kāyaḥ uragaḥ mahanto
translated: “‘If this is being taken for food, a great big snake, a boa constrictor,

original: Dadāmi vo balibaddāni soḷasa, nāgaṃ imaṃ muñcatha bandhanasmā.
analyzed: dadāmi vaḥ balibaddāni soḷasa nāgam imam muñcatha bandhanasmā
translated: I will give you sixteen sacrificial animals; release this snake from his bonds.’

original: “Addhā hi no bhakkho ayaṃ manāpo, bahū ca no uragā bhuttapubbā;
analyzed: addhā hi naḥ bhakkhaḥ ayam manāpaḥ bahū ca naḥ uragāḥ bhutta pubbā
translated: “‘Surely this is a delightful food for us, and many snakes have been eaten by us.

original: Karoma te taṃ vacanaṃ aḷāra, mittañca no hohi videhaputta.
analyzed: karoma te tam vacanam aḷāra mittam ca naḥ hohi videha putta
translated: We will do as you say, Alara, and be your friends, Prince of Videha.

original: “Tadāssu te bandhanā mocayiṃsu, yaṃ natthuto paṭimokkassa pāse;
analyzed: te bandhanā mocayiṃsu yam natthu tassa paṭimokkassa pāse
translated: “Then they released him from his bonds, from the noose of the one without pity;

original: Mutto ca so bandhanā nāgarājā, pakkāmi pācīnamukho muhuttaṃ.
analyzed: mutto ca saḥ bandhanā nāga rājā pakkāmi pācīnamukhaḥ muhuttam
translated: And the king of the nāgas, released from his bonds, went off to the east for a moment.

original: “Gantvāna pācīnamukho muhuttaṃ, puṇṇehi nettehi palokayī maṃ;
analyzed: gantvāna pācīna mukhaḥ muhuttam puṇṇehi nettehi palokayī mam
translated: “Having gone off to the east for a moment, he looked back with his full eyes at me;

original: Tadāssahaṃ piṭṭhito anvagacchiṃ, dasaṅguliṃ añjaliṃ paggahetvā.
analyzed: piṭṭhitaḥ anvagacchim dasa aṅgulim añjalim paggahetvā
translated: And I followed him, holding out my ten finger-nails in reverence.

original: “Gaccheva kho tvaṃ taramānarūpo, mā taṃ amittā punaraggahesuṃ;
analyzed: gaccha iva khalu tvam taramāna rūpaḥ mā tam amittāḥ punar aggahesum
translated: “Go on, go on, you who are going quickly, let not your enemies seize you again;

original: Dukkho hi luddehi punā samāgamo, adassanaṃ bhojaputtāna gaccha.
analyzed: dukkhaḥ hi luddehi punā samāgamaḥ adassanam bhoja puttāna gaccha
translated: For it is painful to meet with enemies again, go to the unseen state, son of Bhoja.

original: “Agamāsi so rahadaṃ vippasannaṃ, nīlobhāsaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ sutitthaṃ;
analyzed: agamāsi saḥ rahadam vippasannam nīla ubhāsam ramaṇīyam su tittham
translated: “He went to a delightful, clear, blue-hued pool with a good ford;

original: Samotataṃ jambuhi vetasāhi, pāvekkhi nittiṇṇabhayo patīto.
analyzed: samotatam jambuhi vetasāhi nittiṇṇa bhayaḥ patītaḥ
translated: He looked around, free from fear and confident, with the trees and vines all around.

original: “So taṃ pavissa nacirassa nāgo, dibbena me pāturahū janinda;
analyzed: saḥ tam pavissa nacirassa nāgaḥ dibbena me pāturahū janinda
translated: “Not long after the nāga entered there, he appeared to me, Lord of the People, in a vision;

original: Upaṭṭhahī maṃ pitaraṃva putto, hadayaṅgamaṃ kaṇṇasukhaṃ bhaṇanto.
analyzed: upaṭṭhahī mam pitaram va puttaḥ hadayaṅgamam kaṇṇa sukham bhaṇantaḥ
translated: He attended on me like a son on his father, speaking what was pleasing to the heart and delightful to the ear.

original: “Tvaṃ mesi mātā ca pitā aḷāra, abbhantaro pāṇadado sahāyo;
analyzed: tvam mā isi mātā ca pitā aḷāraḥ abbhantaraḥ pāṇadadaḥ sahāyaḥ
translated: “You are my mother and my father, Aḷāra, my friend who gives me life within.

original: Sakañca iddhiṃ paṭilābhakosmi, aḷāra passa me nivesanāni;
analyzed: sakañca iddhim paṭilābhakaḥ asmi aḷāra passa me nivesanāni
translated: I have attained my own psychic power; see my abodes, Aḷāra,

original: Pahūtabhakkhaṃ bahuannapānaṃ, masakkasāraṃ viya vāsavassā”ti.
analyzed: pahūta bhakkham bahu anna pānam masakka sāram viya vāsavassa ati
translated: With plenty of food, much food and drink, like the abode of Vāsava.”

original: Tattha vimānanti saṅkhapālanāgarañño anekasatanāṭakasampattisampannaṃ kañcanamaṇivimānaṃ.
analyzed: tattha vimānam ti saṅkhapāla nāga raññaḥ aneka sata nāṭaka sampatti sampannam kañcana maṇi vimānam
translated: Herein, the mansion is the golden-paved mansion of the Saṅkhapāla nāga king, endowed with the many hundreds of requisites of a nāga king.

original: Puññānanti tena katapuññānaṃ mahantaṃ vipākaṃ disvā kammañca phalañca paralokañca
analyzed: puññānam ti tena kata puññānam mahantam vipākam disvā kammañca phalañca para lokañca
translated: By merit: having seen the great result of the merit he had made, he had faith in kamma, its result, and the world beyond.

original: saddahitvā pavattāya saddhāya ahaṃ pabbajito. Na kāmakāmāti na vatthukāmenapi bhayenapi
analyzed: saddahitvā pavattāya saddhāya aham pabbajitaḥ na kāma kāma ati na vatthu kāmena api bhayena api
translated: Because of that faith, I went forth. Not for the sake of sensual pleasures: not for the sake of sensual pleasures, not out of fear,

original: dosenapi musā bhaṇanti. Jāyihitīti, bhante, tumhākaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā mayhampi pasādo
analyzed: dosena api musā bhaṇanti bhante tumhākam vacanam sutvā mayhampi pasādaḥ
translated: not out of hatred, not out of delusion, do I tell a lie. “Delight will arise”: “Venerable sir, having heard your words, delight and joy will arise in me.

original: somanassaṃ jāyissati. Vāṇijjanti vāṇijjakammaṃ karissāmīti gacchanto. Pathe addasāsimhīti
analyzed: somanassam jāyissati vāṇijjanti vāṇijja kammam karissāmi iti gacchantaḥ pathe addasāsimhi iti
translated: “Trade”: “I will go and do trade.” “On the way I saw”:

original: pañcannaṃ sakaṭasatānaṃ purato sukhayānake nisīditvā gacchanto mahāmagge janapadamanusse🔽addasaṃ. Pavaḍḍhakāyanti vaḍḍhitakāyaṃ. Ādāyāti aṭṭhahi kājehi gahetvā. Avacamhīti
analyzed: pañcannam sakaṭa satānam puratas sukha yānake nisīditvā gacchantaḥ mahā magge janapada manusse  addasam pavaḍḍhakāyanti vaḍḍhita kāyam ādāya ati aṭṭhahi kājehi gahetvā avacamhi iti
translated: and was going along in a comfortable carriage in front of five hundred carts, I saw on the highway some people of the country

original: abhāsiṃ. Bhīmakāyoti bhayajanakakāyo. Bhojaputtāti luddaputtake piyasamudācārenālapati.
analyzed: abhāsim bhīma kāyaḥ ti bhaya janaka kāyaḥ bhojaputta ati ludda puttake piya samudācārena alapati
translated: who had a great many oxen. ‘Having taken’ means having taken with eight loads. ‘I said’ means I spoke. ‘A fearful body’ means a body that causes fear. ‘Sons of Bhoja’ means he spoke affectionately to the hunters.

original: Videhaputtāti videharaṭṭhavāsitāya āḷāraṃ ālapiṃsu. Vikopayitvāti chinditvā. Mayañhi🔽vo sattavoti mayaṃ pana nāgānaṃ verino nāma. Bhojanatthāti bhojanatthāya. Mittañca
analyzed: videha puttā ati videha raṭṭha vāsitāya āḷāram vikopayitvā iti chinditvā mayan hi  vaḥ sattavaḥ ti mayam pana nāgānam verinaḥ nāma bhojanatthā ati bhojanatthāya mittam ca
translated: ‘Sons of Videha’ means they spoke to Āḷāra because he lived in the country of Videha. ‘Having killed’ means having cut up. ‘For we are’

original: no hohīti tvaṃ amhākaṃ mitto hohi, kataguṇaṃ jāna.
analyzed: no hohi iti tvam amhākam mittaḥ hohi kata guṇam jāna
translated: means we are the enemies of the nāgas. ‘For food’ means for the sake of food. ‘And be our friend’ means you be our friend, and know the favour we have done.

original: Tadāssu teti, mahārāja, tehi bhojaputtehi evaṃ vutte ahaṃ tesaṃ soḷasa vāhagoṇe nivāsanapārupanāni
analyzed: tadā assu te iti mahā rāja tehi bhoja puttehi evam vutte aham tesam soḷasa vāha goṇe nivāsana pārupanāni
translated: ‘Then to them’ means, great king, when those sons of Bhoja spoke thus, I gave them sixteen draught oxen with their harness,

original: pasataṃ pasataṃ suvaṇṇamāsake bhariyānañca nesaṃ vatthālaṅkāraṃ adāsiṃ, atha te saṅkhapālanāgarājānaṃ
analyzed: pasatam pasatam suvaṇṇa māsake bhariyānam ca nesam vattha alaṅkāram adāsim atha te saṅkhapāla nāga rājānam
translated: and a hundred pieces of money for each, and to their wives I gave clothes and ornaments, and then they said to the nāga king Saṅkhapāla:🔽‘Great king, we have done what you asked us to do,

original: bhūmiyaṃ nipajjāpetvā attano kakkhaḷatāya sakaṇṭakakāḷavettalatāya koṭiyaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: bhūmiyam nipajjāpetvā attanaḥ kakkhaḷa tāya sa kaṇṭaka kāḷa vetta latāya koṭiyam gahetvā
translated: and made him lie down on the ground. Then they seized him by the neck with a prickly black-thorn creeper, and

original: ākaḍḍhituṃ ārabhiṃsu. Athāhaṃ nāgarājānaṃ kilamantaṃ disvā akilamentova asinā tā🔽latā chinditvā dārakānaṃ kaṇṇavedhato vaṭṭinīharaṇaniyāmena adukkhāpento saṇikaṃ
analyzed: ākaḍḍhitum ārabhiṃsu atha aham nāga rājānam kilamantam disvā a kilamenta uva asinā  latā chinditvā dārakānam kaṇṇa vedhataḥ vaṭṭinī haraṇa niyāmena a dukkhāpentaḥ saṇikam
translated: began to drag him along. Then, seeing the king of the nāgas struggling, I, without struggling, cut that creeper with my sword,

original: nīhariṃ, tasmiṃ kāle te bhojaputtā yaṃ bandhanaṃ assa natthuto pavesetvā pāse paṭimokkaṃ,
analyzed: nīharim tasmin kāle te bhoja puttāḥ yam bandhanam pavesetvā pāse paṭimokkam
translated: and, as if removing the thread from the ear of a child after piercing the ear, I gently removed the creeper, without causing pain. At that time, those sons of the brāhmaṇa, having put the rope into the mouth of the nāga, and having untied the noose,

original: tasmā bandhanā taṃ uragaṃ mocayiṃsu. Tassa nāsato saha pāsena taṃ rajjukaṃ nīhariṃsūti
analyzed: tasmai bandhanā tam uragam mocayiṃsu tassa nāsataḥ saha pāsena tam rajjukam nīhariṃsu iti
translated: released the serpent from the bonds. They removed the rope with the noose from his nose.

original: dīpeti. Iti te uragaṃ vissajjetvā thokaṃ gantvā “ayaṃ urago dubbalo, matakāle naṃ
analyzed: dīpeti iti te uragam vissajjetvā thokam gantvā ayam uragaḥ dubbalaḥ mata kāle
translated: Thus he shows. In this way, having released the serpent, they went a little way, thinking, This serpent is weak, at the time of death we

original: gahetvā gamissāmā”ti nilīyiṃsu.
analyzed: gahetvā gamissāma ati nilīyiṃsu
translated: will seize him and go.

original: Puṇṇehīti sopi muhuttaṃ pācīnābhimukho gantvā assupuṇṇehi nettehi maṃ palokayi. Tadāssahanti
analyzed: puṇṇehi iti saḥ api muhuttam pācīna abhimukhaḥ gantvā assu puṇṇehi nettehi mama
translated: With full eyes: He too, having gone a little way facing east, looked at me with eyes full of tears. At that time, with that

original: tadā assa ahaṃ. Gacchevāti evaṃ taṃ avacanti vadati. Rahadanti kaṇṇaveṇṇadahaṃ. Samotatanti
analyzed: tadā assa aham gaccheva iti evam tam avacanti vadati kaṇṇa veṇṇa daham samotatanti
translated: ‘Pool’: a pool of water.🔽‘Overgrown’: overgrown with trees on both banks.

original: ubhayatīresu jamburukkhavetasarukkhehi otataṃ vitataṃ. Nittiṇṇabhayo patītoti so
analyzed: ubhaya tīresu jambu rukkha vetasa rukkhehi otatam vitatam nittiṇṇa bhayaḥ patītaḥ iti so
translated: ‘Fearless’: he was fearless, confident,

original: kira taṃ dahaṃ pavisanto āḷārassa nipaccakāraṃ dassetvā yāva naṅguṭṭhā otari, udake
analyzed: kira tam daham pavisantaḥ āḷārassa nipaccakāram dassetvā yāva naṅguṭṭhāḥ udake
translated: when he had entered the pool, having shown Āḷāra his humility, and had descended as far as his navel.

original: paviṭṭhaṭṭhānamevassa nibbhayaṃ ahosi, tasmā nittiṇṇabhayo patīto haṭṭhatuṭṭho pāvekkhīti.🔽Pavissāti pavisitvā. Dibbena meti nāgabhavane pamādaṃ anāpajjitvā mayi kaṇṇaveṇṇatīraṃ

translated: The place where he had entered the water was fearless for him.🔽‘I entered’: having entered.🔽‘Divine’: without falling into negligence in the nāga world, the divine retinue appeared before me on the bank of the pool🔽before I had even reached the bank.

analyzed: ghanasāratāya ca sineru pabbata rājā ayam tattha māpitam tāvatiṃsa bhavanam sandhāya ivam āha

analyzed: na avakulā upari ukkula vikula bhāva rahitā vā sama saṇṭhitā

analyzed: pokkharaṇī iti attho catuddisanti tassā pokkharaṇiyā catūsu disāsu pakkā ca ati tasmin  amba vane amba rukkhā pakka phalā ca aḍḍha pakka phalā ca taruṇa phalā ca phullitāya iva ati

analyzed: saḥ saṅkhapālaḥ iti mahā rāja aham evam tasmin nāga bhavanam vaṇṇente tam daṭṭhu kāmo  ahosim atha mam tattha netvā saḥ saṅkha pālaḥ hatthe gahetvā taramānaḥ veḷuriya thambhehi

analyzed: upaṭṭhahiṃsu bhattu manaḥ viditvā ati attanaḥ patino cittam jānitvā tato

translated: Having approached in this way, he spoke this verse:

analyzed: pana sumajjhā iti pāṭho padumuttarābhā ati padumavaṇṇā auttarābhā  attho paricārayassu iti tāḥ attano pāda paricārikā karohi iti vatvā tīhi itthi satehi saddhiṃ

original: So āha –

translated: “Having enjoyed divine food for a year, then I spoke to the most excellent one in the middle,

translated: I ask you, O Nāga, this question: How did you come to this excellent mansion?”

original: Tattha dibbarasānubhutvāti dibbe kāmaguṇarase anubhavitvā. Tadāssuhanti tadā assu
analyzed: tattha dibba rasa anubhutvā iti dibbe kāma guṇa rase anubhavitvā tadā

analyzed: aham bhadramukhassa saṅkhapāla nāga rājassa idam sampatti jātam kinti
translated: I asked the good-faced Saṅkhapāla, king of the nāgas, “What is this prosperity that has arisen to you?

translated: Through my own good deeds, through my own good deeds, this mansion was obtained by me.
