analyzed: tālā ca mūlā ca phalā ca mā ittha vaṇṇena gandhena upeta rūpam
translated: “Here are palm trees, roots, and fruits, beautiful in color and smell,

original: Taṃ bhūmibhāgehi upetarūpaṃ, aho bhavaṃ assamaṃ mayhaṃ passe.
analyzed: tam bhūmi bhāgehi upeta rūpam aho bhavam assamam mayham passe
translated: It is supplied with various kinds of ground, Ah, my lord’s hermitage is lovely to behold.

original: “Phalā ca mūlā ca pahūtamettha, vaṇṇena gandhena rasenupetā;
analyzed: ca mūlā ca pahūtam ettha vaṇṇena gandhena rasena upetā
translated: Here there are abundant fruits and roots, Of various colours, scents, and tastes;

original: Āyanti ca luddakā taṃ padesaṃ, mā me tato mūlaphalaṃ ahāsu”nti.🔽Tattha uttarāyanti uttarāya. Khemāti evaṃnāmikā nadī. Himavatā pabhāvīti himavantato🔽pavattati. Ahoti patthanatthe nipāto. Uddālakāti vātaghātakā. Kimpurisābhigītanti🔽samantato parivāretvā madhurasaddena gāyantehi kimpurisehi abhigītaṃ. Tālā ca mūlā🔽ca phalā ca metthāti ettha mama assame pāsādikā tālarukkhā ca tesaññeva vaṇṇagandhādisampannā
analyzed: āyanti ca tam padesam mā me tatas mūla phalam  tattha uttarāyanti uttarāya khemā ati evaṃnāmikā nadī himavatā pabhāvī iti himavantataḥ  pavattati aho ti patthana atthe nipātaḥ uddālakā ati vātaghātakā kimpurisa abhigītam ti  samantataḥ madhura saddena gāyantehi kimpurisehi abhigītam tālā ca mūlā  ca phalā ca metthā ati ettha mama assame pāsādikā tālarukkhā ca tesaññeva vaṇṇa gandha ādi sampannā
translated: And hunters are coming to that place, Do not take away my roots and fruits.

original: kandasaṅkhātā mūlā ca phalā ca. Pahūtametthāti nānārukkhaphalā ca rukkhavallimūlā🔽ca pahūtā ettha. Mā me tatoti taṃ mama assamapadaṃ sambahulā luddakā āgacchanti,
analyzed: kanda saṅkhātā mūlā ca phalā ca pahūtam ettha ati nānā rukkha phalā ca rukkha valli mūlā 🔽ca pahūtāḥ ettha mā me tatoti tam mama assama padam sambahulāḥ luddakāḥ āgacchanti
translated: Herein, uttarāya means in the north. Khemā is the name of a river. Himavantapabbhāvī means flowing from the Himalayas. Ah is an exclamation of desire. Uddālaka means wind-breakers. Kimpurisābhigītā means surrounded all round and sung by Kimpurisa-demons with sweet voices. Tāla and mūlā and phalā ca metthāti means here in my hermitage there are beautiful tāla trees and roots called tubers which are of various colours, scents, and tastes, and fruits. Pahūtametthāti means here there are abundant various kinds of tree fruits and tree creeper roots. Mā me tato means many hunters are coming to that place of mine,

original: mayā cettha āharitvā ṭhapitaṃ bahu madhurasamūlaphalāphalaṃ atthi, te mayi cirāyante🔽mūlaphalāphalaṃ hareyyuṃ. Te tato mama mūlaphalāphalaṃ mā hariṃsu, tasmā sacepi mayā
analyzed: mayā ca itthā āharitvā ṭhapitam bahu madhu rasa mūla phala aphalam atthi te mayi cirāyante  mūla phala aphalam hareyyum te tatas mama mūla phala aphalam mā hariṃsu tasmai sacepi mayā
translated: “There is much sweet-tasting root, fruit and flower which I have gathered and laid aside here. If I delay, they will take my root, fruit and flower.🔽So that they may not take my root, fruit and flower, I will go quickly.”

original: saddhiṃ āgantukāmo, ehi, no ce, ahaṃ gamissāmīti āha.
analyzed: saddhim āgantu kāmaḥ ehi no ce aham gamissāmi iti āha
translated: “There is much sweet-tasting root and fruit and other things which I have gathered and laid by. If I delay, they will take them away. Let them not take them away. Therefore, if you wish to go with me, come; if not, I will go by myself.”

original: Taṃ sutvā tāpaso yāva pitu āgamanā adhivāsāpetuṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā tāpasaḥ gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the ascetic said this verse in order to get her to wait until his father came:

original: “Pitā mamaṃ mūlaphalesanaṃ gato, idāni āgacchati sāyakāle;
analyzed: pitā mamam mūla phala isanam gataḥ idāni āgacchati sāya kāle
translated: “My father has gone to seek roots and fruit, and he will return at the time of the evening meal.

original: Ubhova gacchāmase assamaṃ taṃ, yāva pitā mūlaphalato etū”ti.
analyzed: ubhā uva gacchāmase assamam tam yāva pitā mūla phalataḥ etu uti
translated: Let us both go to our hermitage, until my father returns with roots and fruit.”

original: Tattha ubhova gacchāmaseti mama pitu ārocetvā ubhova gamissāma.
analyzed: tattha ubhau uva gacchāmasa iti mama pitu ārocetvā ubhau uva gamissāma
translated: Here, “let us both go” means “let us both go after I have informed my father.”

original: Tato sā cintesi – “ayaṃ tāva araññeva vaḍḍhitabhāvena mama itthibhāvaṃ na jānāti,
analyzed: tatas sā cintesi ayam tāva araññā iva vaḍḍhita bhāvena mama itthi bhāvam na jānāti
translated: Then she thought, “This man, being brought up in the forest, does not know that I am a woman.

original: pitā panassa maṃ disvāva jānitvā ‘tvaṃ idha kiṃ karosī’ti kājakoṭiyā paharitvā sīsampi
analyzed: pitā panassa mam disvā ava jānitvā tvam idha kim karosi iti kāja koṭiyā paharitvā sīsam pi
translated: But his father, seeing me, will know it at once, and will strike me on the head with his axe, saying, ‘What are you doing here?’”

original: me bhindeyya, tasmiṃ anāgateyeva mayā gantuṃ vaṭṭati, āgamanakammampi me niṭṭhita”nti.
analyzed: me bhindeyya tasmin anāgateya iva mayā gantum vaṭṭati āgamana kammam pi me niṭṭhitan ti
translated: “If he should break in, it is proper for me to go before he comes; and I have finished the work of coming.”

original: Sā tassa āgamanūpāyaṃ ācikkhantī itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: sā tassa āgamana upāyam ācikkhantī itaram gātham āha
translated: And she spoke the second stanza:

original: “Aññe bahū isayo sādhurūpā, rājīsayo anumagge vasanti;
analyzed: aññe bahū isayo sādhu rūpāḥ rājīsayo anumagge vasanti
translated: “There are many other sages good to look on, Rājis and Brāhmaṇis on the high road dwelling;

analyzed: teyeva pucchesi mamassamam tam te tam nayissanti mamam sakāsā iti
translated: Ask them, and they will show you where I am, And they will lead you to my presence.”

analyzed: tattha rājīsayo ti samma mayā na sakkā cirāyitum aññe pana sādhu sabhāvāḥ
translated: Herein, Rājis means, my dear, I cannot stay long, but there are other Rājis and Brāhmaṇis of good character

analyzed: ca brāhmaṇi sayo ca anumagge mama assama magga passe vasanti aham tesam ācikkhitvā
translated: dwelling on the high road, on the side of my hermitage path. I shall tell them and go.

original: gamissāmi, tvaṃ te puccheyyāsi, te taṃ mama santikaṃ nayissantīti.🔽Evaṃ sā attano palāyanūpāyaṃ katvā paṇṇasālato nikkhamitvā taṃ olokentameva “tvaṃ
analyzed: gamissāmi tvam te puccheyyāsi te tam mama santikam nayissanti iti  evam sā attano palāyana upāyam katvā paṇṇa sālataḥ nikkhamitvā tam olokentam eva tvam
translated: You can ask them, and they will lead you to me.

original: nivattā”ti vatvā āgamanamaggeneva amaccānaṃ santikaṃ agamāsi. Te taṃ gahetvā khandhāvāraṃ
analyzed: nivattā ati vatvā āgamana maggena iva amaccānam santikam agamāsi te tam gahetvā khandhāvāram

analyzed: devam tatas subhikkham janapadam ahosi isisiṅga tāpasassa api tāya pakkanta mattāya
translated: and the country became prosperous. As soon as the ascetic Isi-Singa had left,

analyzed: eva kāye ḍāhaḥ uppajji saḥ kampantaḥ paṇṇa sālam pavisitvā vāka cīram pārupitvā socantaḥ

analyzed: nipajji bodhisatto sāyam āgantvā puttam a passanto kaham nu kho gataḥ iti kājam otāretvā

analyzed: paṇṇasālam pavisitvā tam nipannakam disvā tāta kim karosi iti piṭṭhim parimajjantaḥ

translated: “The wood is not chopped, the water not brought,

analyzed: bhinnāni kaṭṭhāni hutaḥ ca aggi tapanīpi te samitā brahmacārī

analyzed: tattha bhinnāni iti araññataḥ uddhaṭāni na hāpito ti na jalitaḥ bhinnāni iti pubbe tayā
translated: Herein, split means cut. Not boiled means not heated. Split means that previously,

analyzed: hoti brahma bhūto ti tuvam pi itas puratthā seṭṭha bhūto imasmin assame abhiramasi abhinna kaṭṭhaḥ asi iti
translated: It would have been prepared. Brahma-like means you, too, would have been delighted in this hermitage, being the best here before this. Your firewood is unsplit means

analyzed: saḥ dāni ajja anuddhaṭa kaṭṭhaḥ asi na te kiñci amhākam kanda mūlam vā
translated: today it is unsplit. Your food uncooked means we have no roots or fruits

analyzed: paṇṇam vā seditam mamajja ati mama putta ajja na me tvam ālapasi naṭṭham nu kinti

analyzed: saḥ pitu vacanam sutvā tam kāraṇam kathentaḥ āha
translated: Hearing his father’s words, he told him the reason:

analyzed: idha āgamā jaṭilaḥ brahmacārī sudassaneyyaḥ su tanū vinā iti  na iva ati dīghaḥ na pana ati rassaḥ su kaṇha kaṇha chadanehi bhoto
translated: ‘Here came a holy man, a brahmacārī, who was very handsome, with a lovely complexion, and who was well-controlled.🔽He was neither too tall nor too short, and his hair was dark brown.

original: “Amassujāto apurāṇavaṇṇī, ādhārarūpañca panassa kaṇṭhe;
analyzed: a massu jātaḥ a purāṇa vaṇṇī ādhāra rūpam ca panassa kaṇṭhe
translated: He was not born of a womb, and his complexion was not that of an old man. On his neck was a mark,

analyzed: dve yamā gaṇḍā ure su jātā suvaṇṇa tinduka nibhā pabhassarā

analyzed: mukham ca tassa bhusa dassaneyyam kaṇṇesu lambanti ca kuñcitaggā

original: Te jotare carato māṇavassa, suttañca yaṃ saṃyamanaṃ jaṭānaṃ.
analyzed: te jotare carataḥ māṇavassa suttam ca yam saṃyamanam

original: “Aññā ca tassa saṃyamāni catasso, nīlā pītā lohitikā ca setā;
analyzed: aññā ca tassa saṃyamāni catassaḥ nīlā pītā lohitikā ca setā

analyzed: tā piṃsare carataḥ māṇavassa pāvusamhi
translated: which shone as the young man walked along, like a peacock’s tail in a rain cloud.

original: “Na mikhalaṃ muñjamayaṃ dhāreti, na santhare no pana pabbajassa;
analyzed: na mikhalam muñja mayam dhāreti na santhare no pana pabbajassa
translated: “He does not wear a girdle of muñja grass, nor a patched cloak, nor is he a wanderer;

original: Tā jotare jaghanantare vilaggā, sateratā vijjurivantalikkhe.

translated: But his testicles hang down, his buttocks are protruding, like lightning flashes in the sky.

original: “Akhīlakāni ca avaṇṭakāni, heṭṭhā nabhyā kaṭisamohitāni;
analyzed: a khīlakāni ca a vaṇṭakāni heṭṭhā kaṭi samohitāni
translated: “His testicles are smooth, without a crack, below the navel, hidden in the loins;

analyzed: a ghaṭṭitāḥ nicca kīḷam karonti ham tāta kiṃrukkha phalāni tāni
translated: Unstruck, they always play a tune, my dear, what kind of fruit are they?

original: “Jaṭā ca tassa bhusadassaneyyā, parosataṃ vellitaggā sugandhā;
analyzed: jaṭā ca tassa bhusa dassaneyyā velli taggā sugandhā
translated: “His matted hair is very beautiful, more than a hundred coils, fragrant,

original: Dvedhā siro sādhu vibhattarūpo, aho nu kho mayha tathā jaṭāssu.
analyzed: dvedhā sādhu aho nu tathā
translated: The head is well divided into two parts, oh, may I have such matted hair!

original: “Yadā ca so pakirati tā jaṭāyo, vaṇṇena gandhena upetarūpā;
analyzed: yadā ca saḥ pakirati tā jaṭāyo vaṇṇena gandhena upeta rūpā
translated: “And when he shakes his matted hair, fragrant with color and scent,

original: Nīluppalaṃ vātasameritaṃva, tatheva saṃvāti panassamo ayaṃ.
analyzed: nīluppalam vāta sameritam va tathā iva saṃvāti panassamaḥ ayam
translated: It smells just like a blue lotus stirred by the wind.

original: “Paṅko ca tassa bhusadassaneyyo, netādiso yādiso mayhaṃ kāye;
analyzed: paṅko ca tassa bhusa dassaneyyaḥ netādisaḥ yādisaḥ mayham kāye
translated: “And his mud is very beautiful, not like the one on my body;

original: So vāyati erito mālutena, vanaṃ yathā aggagimhe suphullaṃ.
analyzed: saḥ vāyati eritaḥ mālutena vanam yathā aggagimhe su phullam
translated: It smells like a forest in full bloom in the first summer month.

original: “Nihanti so rukkhaphalaṃ pathabyā, sucittarūpaṃ ruciraṃ dassaneyyaṃ;
analyzed: nihanti saḥ rukkha phalam pathabyā su citta rūpam ruciram dassaneyyam
translated: “He throws down a fruit from a tree, well-formed, lovely, beautiful to behold;

original: Khittañca tassa punarehi hatthaṃ, haṃ tāta kiṃrukkhaphalaṃ nu kho taṃ.
analyzed: khittam ca tassa punar ehi hattham ham tāta kiṃrukkha phalam nu kho tam
translated: And he cut off his hand, saying, “What kind of fruit is it, dear father?”

original: “Dantā ca tassa bhusadassaneyyā, suddhā samā saṅkhavarūpapannā;
analyzed: dantā ca tassa bhusa dassaneyyā suddhā samā saṅkha vara upapannā
translated: “His teeth were very beautiful, pure, and like a conch-shell;

original: Mano pasādenti vivariyamānā, na hi nūna so sākamakhādi tehi.
analyzed: manaḥ pasādenti vivariyamānāḥ na hi nūna saḥ sākamakhādi tehi
translated: They delighted the mind when opened, he certainly did not eat grass with them.🔽“His speech was not harsh, not rough, but soft,

analyzed: a kakkasam aggaḷitam muhum mudum ujum an uddhatam a capalam assa bhāsitam
translated: Straight, not haughty, not fickle,🔽His cry was gentle, like the cry of a karavīka bird,

original: Rudaṃ manuññaṃ karavīkasussaraṃ, hadayaṅgamaṃ rañjayateva me mano.
analyzed: rudam manuññam karavīka sussaram hadayaṅgamam rañjayatā iva me manaḥ
translated: It delighted my mind, going to the heart.

original: “Bindussaro nātivisaṭṭhavākyo, na nūna sajjhāyamatippayutto;
analyzed: bindussaraḥ na ati visaṭṭha vākyaḥ na nūna sajjhāya mati ppayuttaḥ
translated: “His voice was not stammering, not slurred, he was not too devoted to study;

original: Icchāmi bho taṃ punadeva daṭṭhuṃ, mitto hi me māṇavohu puratthā.
analyzed: icchāmi bho tam punadeva daṭṭhum mittaḥ hi me puratthā
translated: I wish, sir, to see him again, for he was my friend in the past, young man.

original: “Susandhi sabbattha vimaṭṭhimaṃ vaṇaṃ, puthū sujātaṃ kharapattasannibhaṃ;
analyzed: su sandhi sabbattha su jātam khara patta sannibham
translated: “His wound was well-joined, well-healed everywhere, well-formed, like a fine leaf;

original: Teneva maṃ uttariyāna māṇavo, vivaritaṃ ūruṃ jaghanena piḷayi.
analyzed: tena iva mam uttariyāna māṇavaḥ ūrum jaghanena piḷayi
translated: By that very thing the young man, going further, rubbed his open thigh with his buttock.🔽“They shine, they glow, they shine forth,

original: “Tapanti ābhanti virocare ca, sateratā vijjurivantalikkhe;
analyzed: tapanti ābhanti virocare ca
translated: Like lightning in the sky at night,

original: Bāhā mudū añjanalomasādisā, vicitravaṭṭaṅgulikāssa sobhare.
analyzed: bāhā mudū sobhare
translated: His arms are soft, like cotton wool or flax, and his fingers are webbed, and beautiful.

original: “Akakkasaṅgo na ca dīghalomo, nakhāssa dīghā api lohitaggā;
analyzed: a kakkasaṅgaḥ na ca dīgha lomaḥ nakhā assa dīghāḥ api lohitaggā
translated: His body is not rough, nor is his hair long, his nails are long and red,

original: Mudūhi bāhāhi palissajanto, kalyāṇarūpo ramayaṃ upaṭṭhahi.
analyzed: mudūhi bāhāhi palissajantaḥ kalyāṇa rūpaḥ ramayan upaṭṭhahi
translated: and he is well-formed, and he attends to me, delighting me with his soft arms.

original: “Dumassa tūlūpanibhā pabhassarā, suvaṇṇakambutalavaṭṭasucchavi;
analyzed: dumassa tūlūpa nibhā pabhassarā suvaṇṇa kambu tala vaṭṭa su chavi
translated: His hands are soft, like cotton wool or flax, and his fingers are webbed, and beautiful.

original: Hatthā mudū tehi maṃ samphusitvā, ito gato tena maṃ dahanti tāta.🔽“Na nūna so khārividhaṃ ahāsi, na nūna so kaṭṭhāni sayaṃ abhañji;
analyzed: hatthāḥ mudū tehi mam samphusitvā itas gataḥ tena mam dahanti tāta  na nūna saḥ khārividham ahāsi na nūna saḥ kaṭṭhāni sayam abhañji
translated: He touches me with his soft hands, and then he leaves, and it burns me, dear.🔽He certainly did not carry a load, he certainly did not break up wood himself,

original: Na nūna so hanti dume kuṭhāriyā, na hissa hatthesu khilāni atthi.
analyzed: na nūna saḥ hanti dume kuṭhāriyā na hissa hatthesu khilāni atthi
translated: he certainly did not cut down a tree with an axe, there are no callouses on his hands.

original: “Accho ca kho tassa vaṇaṃ akāsi, so maṃbravi ‘sukhitaṃ maṃ karohi’;
analyzed: acchas ca kho tassa vaṇam akāsi saḥ maṃbravi sukhitam mama karohi
translated: He certainly made a wound in the water, he said to me: ‘Make me happy.’

original: Tāhaṃ kariṃ tena mamāsi sokhyaṃ, so cabravi ‘sukhitosmī’ti brahme.
analyzed: tā aham tena mama asi sokhyam saḥ sukhitaḥ asmi iti
translated: I did it for him, and he was happy with me, and he said to me: ‘I am happy,’ Brahman.

original: “Ayañca te māluvapaṇṇasanthatā, vikiṇṇarūpāva mayā ca tena ca;
analyzed: ayam ca te māluva paṇṇa santhatā mayā ca tena ca
translated: This bed of yours is spread with Maluva leaves, and it is scattered with me and him,

original: Kilantarūpā udake ramitvā, punappunaṃ paṇṇakuṭiṃ vajāma.
analyzed: kilanta rūpāḥ udake ramitvā punappunam paṇṇa kuṭim vajāma
translated: and we are tired out from playing in the water, let us go to the leaf-hut again and again.

original: “Na majja mantā paṭibhanti tāta, na aggihuttaṃ napi yaññatantaṃ;
analyzed: na majja mantā paṭibhanti tāta na aggi huttam
translated: “No, dear, the words of the Vedas do not appeal to me, nor the fire-sacrifice, nor the sacrifice of the Veda,

original: Na cāpi te mūlaphalāni bhuñje, yāva na passāmi taṃ brahmacāriṃ.
analyzed: na ca api te mūla phalāni bhuñje yāva na passāmi tam brahmacāriṃ
translated: Nor do I eat roots and fruits, until I see that holy man.

original: “Addhā pajānāsi tuvampi tāta, yassaṃ disaṃ vasate brahmacārī;
analyzed: addhā pajānāsi tuvam pi tāta yassam disam vasate brahmacārī
translated: “Surely, dear, you also know in which direction the holy man lives,

original: Taṃ maṃ disaṃ pāpaya tāta khippaṃ, mā te ahaṃ amarimassamamhi.
analyzed: tam mama disam pāpaya tāta khippam mā te aham
translated: So lead me quickly to that direction, dear, lest I die right here.”

original: “Vicitraphullañhi vanaṃ sutaṃ mayā, dijābhighuṭṭhaṃ dijasaṅghasevitaṃ;
analyzed: vicitra phullam hi vanam sutam mayā dija abhighuṭṭham dija saṅgha sevitam
translated: “For I have heard that the forest is in full bloom, frequented by flocks of birds,

original: Taṃ maṃ vanaṃ pāpaya tāta khippaṃ, purā te pāṇaṃ vijahāmi assame”ti.
analyzed: tam mama vanam pāpaya tāta khippam purā te pāṇam vijahāmi
translated: So lead me quickly to that forest, dear, lest I give up the life right here in the hermitage.”

original: Tattha idhāgamāti, tāta, imaṃ assamapadaṃ āgato. Sudassaneyyoti suṭṭhu dassaneyyo.
analyzed: tattha idha agamā ti tāta imam assama padam āgato su dassaneyyaḥ ti suṭṭhu dassaneyyaḥ
translated: Here, having come here means: having come to this hermitage. Very beautiful to behold means: very beautiful to see.

original: Sutanūti suṭṭhu tanuko nātikiso nātithūlo. Vinetīti attano sarīrappabhāya assamapadaṃ
analyzed: su tanū ti suṭṭhu tanukaḥ na ati kisaḥ na ati thūlaḥ vineti iti attano sarīra ppabhāya assama padam
translated: Well-proportioned means: very slender, neither too thin nor too stout. He adorns means: with the radiance of his own body

original: ekobhāsaṃ viya vineti pūreti. Sukaṇhakaṇhacchadanehi bhototi, tāta, tassa bhoto sukaṇhehi
analyzed: ekobhāsam viya vineti pūreti su kaṇha kaṇha chadanehi bhoto ti tāta tassa bhoto su kaṇhehi
translated: he adorns, he fills, as it were, with a single light, this hermitage. With his very dark, very black, very glossy hair means: dear, with his very dark, very black, very glossy hair.

original: kaṇhacchadanehi bhamaravaṇṇehi kesehi sukaṇhasīsaṃ sumajjitamaṇimayaṃ viya khāyati.
analyzed: kaṇha chadanehi bhamara vaṇṇehi kesehi su kaṇha sīsam su majjita maṇi mayam viya khāyati
translated: His head is dark, with hair the colour of bees, and it looks as if it were polished black crystal.

original: Amassūjātoti na tāvassa massu jāyati, taruṇoyeva. Apurāṇavaṇṇīti acirapabbajito.
analyzed: a massūjātaḥ ti na tāva assa massu jāyati taruṇaḥ yā iva a purāṇa vaṇṇī ti acira pabbajitaḥ
translated: His beard is not yet grown: it is not yet grown, he is still young. His skin is not yet broken: he has not long gone forth.

original: Ādhārarūpañca panassa kaṇṭheti kaṇṭhe ca panassa amhākaṃ bhikkhābhājanaṭṭhapanaṃ
analyzed: ādhāra rūpam ca panassa kaṇṭhe iti kaṇṭhe ca panassa amhākam bhikkhā bhājana ṭṭhapanam
translated: And the shape of his throat: on his throat there is a collar like the base of our alms bowl,

original: pattādhārasadisaṃ piḷandhanaṃ atthīti muttāhāraṃ sandhāya vadati. Gaṇḍāti thane sandhāyāha.
analyzed: patta ādhāra sadisam piḷandhanam atthi iti mutta āhāram sandhāya vadati thane sandhāya āha
translated: he says, referring to a pearl necklace. His Adam’s apple: he says, referring to his throat.🔽His chest is well formed: well formed on his chest. The reading is also “urato.” His shoulders are well rounded: well rounded with shoulders.

original: Ure sujātāti uramhi sujātā. “Urato”tipi pāṭho. Pabhassarāti pabhāsampannā. “Pabhāsare”tipi
analyzed: ure su jātā ati uramhi su jātā urataḥ iti pāṭhaḥ pabhassarā ati pabhā sampannā pabhāsarā iti pi
translated: His arms are long and beautiful: his arms are long and beautiful. His fingers are rounded: his fingers are rounded.🔽His hands and feet are soft and tender: his hands and feet are soft and tender. His hands and feet are net-like: his hands and feet are net-like.🔽His heels are long: his heels are long. His ankles are rounded: his ankles are rounded.🔽His legs are like the antelope’s: his legs are like the antelope’s. His male organ is enclosed in a sheath: his male organ is enclosed in a sheath.🔽His skin is golden coloured: his skin is golden coloured. His skin is smooth: his skin is smooth.🔽His body hairs grow singly: his body hairs grow singly. His body hairs are turned upwards: his body hairs are turned upwards.🔽His body hairs are black: his body hairs are black. His body hairs are glossy: his body hairs are glossy.🔽His body is well rounded: his body is well rounded. His body is well proportioned: his body is well proportioned.

original: pāṭho, obhāsantīti attho.🔽Bhusadassaneyyanti ativiya dassanīyaṃ. Kuñcitaggāti sīhakuṇḍalaṃ sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ attho  bhusa dassaneyyanti ativiya dassanīyam kuñcita ggā ati sīha kuṇḍalam sandhāya vadati
translated: His bust is like the lion’s: he says, referring to his curls.

original: Suttañcāti yaṃ tassa jaṭābandhanasuttaṃ, tampi jotati pabhaṃ muñcati. “Saṃyamāni
analyzed: suttam ca ati yam tassa jaṭā bandhana suttam tam pi jotati pabham muñcati saṃyamāni
translated: And his topknot: the topknot with which his matted hair is bound, that also shines, gives off a glow.

original: catasso”ti iminā maṇisuvaṇṇapavāḷarajatamayāni cattāri piḷandhanāni dasseti. Tā piṃsareti
analyzed: catasso ti iminā maṇi suvaṇṇa pavāḷa rajata mayāni cattāri piḷandhanāni dasseti tā
translated: They jingle :

original: tāni piḷandhanāni pāvusamhi pavuṭṭhe deve tiriṭisaṅghā viya viravanti. Mikhalanti🔽mekhalaṃ, ayameva vā pāṭho. Idaṃ nivatthakañcanacīrakaṃ sandhāyāha. Na santhareti
analyzed: tāni piḷandhanāni pāvusamhi pavuṭṭhe deve tiriṭi saṅghāḥ viya viravanti mikhalanti  ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ idam sandhāya āha na santharā iti
translated: they jingle like a group of three hundred bhikkhus when it rains in the rainy season.🔽Girdle :🔽this is the reading. He says this referring to the golden skin that he wears.🔽No cloak :

original: na vāke. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – tāta, yathā mayaṃ tiṇamayaṃ vā vākamayaṃ vā cīrakaṃ dhārema,
analyzed: na vāke idam vuttam hoti tāta yathā mayam tiṇa mayam vā vāka mayam vā cīrakam dhārema
translated: no cloak. This is what is meant: “Dear, we wear a cloak made of grass or made of bark,🔽but he does not do so; he wears a golden cloak.”🔽Unbroken :🔽uncut.

original: na tathā so, so pana suvaṇṇacīrakaṃ dhāretīti. Akhīlakānīti atacāni nippaṇṇāni. Kaṭisamohitānīti
analyzed: na tathā saḥ saḥ pana suvaṇṇa cīrakam dhāreti iti a khīlakāni iti a tacāni nippaṇṇāni kaṭi samohitāni iti
translated: Tied round the hips :🔽bound to the hips.

original: kaṭiyaṃ baddhāni. Niccakīḷaṃ karontīti aghaṭṭitānipi niccakālaṃ kīḷāyanti. Haṃ, tātāti🔽hambho, tāta. Kiṃ rukkhaphalāni tānīti tāni tassa māṇavassa suttāruḷhāni kaṭiyaṃ
analyzed: kaṭiyam baddhāni nicca kīḷam karonti iti a ghaṭṭitāni api nicca kālam kīḷāyanti haṃ tāta ati  hambho tāta kim rukkha phalāni tāni iti tāni tassa māṇavassa sutta āruḷhāni kaṭiyam
translated: They jingle all the time : they jingle all the time even when not struck.🔽Hey, dear :🔽hey, dear.

original: baddhāni katararukkhaphalāni nāmāti maṇisaṅghāṭiṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: baddhāni katara rukkha phalāni nāma ati maṇi saṅghāṭim sandhāya āha
translated: What are those fruits of trees? : he asks, referring to the gem-studded cloak that is bound to the young man’s hips and is suspended from his shoulders, “What are those fruits of trees called?”

original: Jaṭāti jaṭāmaṇḍalākārena baddharatanamissakakesavaṭṭiyo sandhāyāha. Vellitaggāti🔽kuñcitaggā. Dvedhāsiroti tassa sīsaṃ dvedhā katvā baddhānaṃ jaṭānaṃ vasena suṭṭhu
analyzed: jaṭā iti jaṭā maṇḍala ākārena sandhāya āha velli taggā iti  kuñcita aggā tassa sīsam dvedhā katvā baddhānam jaṭānam vasena suṭṭhu
translated: “Plaits” : he says this referring to the plaits of hair bound with jewels in the form of a circle. “Curled tips” :

original: vibhattarūpaṃ. Tathāti yathā tassa māṇavassa jaṭā, tathā tumhehi mama na baddhā,
analyzed: vibhatta rūpam tathā ati yathā tassa māṇavassa jaṭā tathā tumhehi mama na baddhā
translated: curled ends. “Two-edged” : the plaits of hair bound on his head were so well divided that they looked as if they were two-edged. “Just like that” : just as the youth’s plaits were bound, so they were not bound on me.

original: aho vata mamapi tathā assūti patthento āha. Upetarūpāti upetasabhāvā. Vātasameritaṃvāti
analyzed: aho vata mama api tathā patthentaḥ āha upeta rūpā ati upeta sabhāvā
translated: “Oh, that they were bound on me in the same way!” wishing for this, he says, “I long for plaits like that.” “Like a blue lotus swayed by the wind” :

original: yathā nāma nīluppalaṃ vātena samīritaṃ, tatheva ayaṃ imasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe assamo saṃvāti.🔽Netādisoti, tāta, yādiso mama kāye paṅko, netādiso tassa sarīre. So hi dassanīyo
analyzed: yathā nāma nīluppalam vātena samīritam tathā iva ayam imasmin vana saṇḍe assamaḥ saṃvāti  netādiso ti tāta yādisaḥ mama kāye paṅkaḥ netādiso tassa sarīre saḥ hi dassanīyaḥ
translated: just as a blue lotus is swayed by the wind, so this hermitage in the forest is swaying.

original: ceva sugandho ca. Aggagimheti vasantasamaye.
analyzed: ca iva sugandho ca aggagimha iti vasanta samaye
translated: “Not like that” : dear, not like the mud on my body is there any such thing on his body. For he is beautiful and fragrant. “In the height of summer” : in the hot season.

original: Nihantīti paharati. Kiṃ rukkhaphalaṃ nu kho tanti katararukkhassa nu kho taṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: nihanti iti paharati kim rukkha phalam nu kho tat ti katara rukkhassa nu kho tat phalam
translated: “Striking” : hitting. “What fruit is it? Whose fruit is it?”

original: Saṅkhavarūpapannāti sudhotasaṅkhapaṭibhāgā. Na hi nūna so sākamakhādi tehīti na nūna🔽so māṇavo mayaṃ viya tehi dantehi rukkhapaṇṇāni ceva mūlaphalāphalāni ca khādi. Amhākañhi
analyzed: sudhā uta saṅkha paṭibhāgā na hi nūna saḥ na nūna  saḥ māṇavaḥ mayam viya tehi dantehi rukkha paṇṇāni ca iva mūla phala aphalāni ca amhākam hi
translated: “With teeth like shells”: like well-polished shells. “He must not have eaten any grass” :🔽he must not have eaten leaves, roots, fruits, etc., with those teeth, as we do.

original: tāni khādantānaṃ sabalā paṇṇavaṇṇā dantāti dīpeti.
analyzed: tāni khādantānam sa balā paṇṇa vaṇṇā dīpeti
translated: ‘With tusks like a white conch’: like a well-polished white conch. ‘He did not eat grass with them’: he did not eat leaves, roots, fruits, and so on, with those tusks, as we do. For when we eat them, our tusks become stained with the colour of the leaves, etc.

original: Akakkasanti, tāta, tassa bhāsitaṃ apharusaṃ agaḷitaṃ, punappunaṃ vadantassāpi madhuratāya
analyzed: akakkasanti tāta tassa bhāsitam a pharusam a gaḷitam punappunam vadantassa api madhura tāya
translated: ‘He did not bray’: his speech was not harsh, not grating, but sweet,

original: muhuṃ muduṃ, apamussatāya ujuṃ, avikkhittatāya anuddhaṭaṃ, patiṭṭhitatāya acapalaṃ.
analyzed: muhum mudum apamussa tāya ujum a vikkhitta tāya an uddhaṭam patiṭṭhita tāya a capalam
translated: repeatedly soft, straight, not crooked, not twisted, not confused, not unsteady.

original: Rudanti bhāsamānassa sarasaṅkhātaṃ rudampi manoharaṃ karavīkassa viya sussaraṃ sumadhuraṃ.🔽Rañjayatevāti mama mano rañjatiyeva. Bindussaroti piṇḍitassaro. Māṇavohūti so hi
analyzed: rudanti bhāsamānassa sara saṅkhātam manoharam karavīkassa viya sussaram su madhuram  rañjayatā iva ati mama manaḥ so hi
translated: ‘When he spoke, his voice was lovely, like the sweet, lovely, charming cry of a karavīka bird.

original: māṇavo puratthā mama mitto ahu.
analyzed: māṇavaḥ puratthā mama mittaḥ ahu
translated: It delighted my mind’: it delighted my mind. ‘With a voice like a drum’: with a voice like a drum. ‘The young brahmin’: that young brahmin was my friend in the past.

original: Susandhi sabbattha vimaṭṭhimaṃ vaṇanti tāta tassa māṇavassa ūrūnaṃ antare ekaṃ vaṇaṃ
analyzed: su sandhi sabbattha vaṇanti tāta tassa māṇavassa ūrūnam antare ekam vaṇam
translated: ‘His thighs were well-shaped, smooth, and without a scar’: between his thighs there was one scar,

original: atthi, taṃ susandhi suphusitaṃ sippipuṭamukhasadisaṃ, sabbattha vimaṭṭhaṃ samantato
analyzed: atthi tam su sandhi su phusitam sippi puṭa mukha sadisam sabbattha vimaṭṭham samantataḥ
translated: there is a place where it is well-joined, well-healed, like the mouth of a flute, rubbed all over, rubbed all around.

original: maṭṭhaṃ. Puthūti mahantaṃ. Sujātanti susaṇṭhitaṃ. Kharapattasannibhanti supupphitapadumamakuḷasannibhaṃ.🔽Uttariyānāti uttaritvā avattharitvā. Piḷayīti pīḷesi. Tapantīti tassa māṇavassa sarīrato
analyzed: maṭṭham mahantam su jātanti su saṇṭhitam khara patta sannibham su pupphita paduma makuḷa sannibham  uttariyānā ati uttaritvā avattharitvā piḷayi iti pīḷesi tapanti iti tassa māṇavassa sarīrataḥ
translated: ‘Extensive’: large. ‘Well-formed’: well-shaped. ‘Like a myrobalan fruit’: like a fully-blossomed lotus bud.

original: niccharantā suvaṇṇavaṇṇaraṃsiyo jalanti obhāsanti virocanti ca. Bāhāti bāhāpissa🔽mudū. Añjanalomasādisāti añjanasadisehi lomehi samannāgatā. Vicitravaṭṭaṅgulikāssa
analyzed: niccharantā suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa raṃsiyaḥ jalanti obhāsanti virocanti ca bāhā ati bāhāpissa  mudū añjana loma sādisā ati añjana sadisehi lomehi samannāgatāḥ
translated: ‘Having crossed over’: having crossed over, having descended. ‘He pressed’: he pressed down. ‘Shining’: the golden-coloured rays issuing from that young man’s body were burning, shining, and glowing. ‘His arms’: his arms🔽were soft. ‘Like a peacock’s neck’: he was endowed with feathers like those of a peacock. ‘His fingers and toes were webbed’: his hands and feet

original: sobhareti hatthāpissa varalakkhaṇavicitrāhi pavālaṅkurasadisāhi vaṭṭaṅgulīhi samannāgatā sobhanti.
analyzed: sobharā iti hatthāpissa vara lakkhaṇa vicitrāhi pavā alaṅkura sadisāhi vaṭṭa aṅgulīhi samannāgatā sobhanti
translated: were endowed with fingers and toes that were webbed, and they were beautiful.

original: Akakkasaṅgoti kacchupīḷakādirahitaaṅgapaccaṅgo. Ramayaṃ upaṭṭhahīti maṃ ramayanto
analyzed: a kakkasaṅgo iti kacchu pīḷaka ādi rahita aṅga paccaṅgo ramayan upaṭṭhahi iti mamam ramayantaḥ
translated: ‘His limbs were without hollows’: his limbs and secondary limbs were without hollows, pimples, and so on. ‘Delightful’: delighting me,

original: upaṭṭhahi paricari. Tūlūpanibhāti mudubhāvassa upamā. Suvaṇṇakambutalavaṭṭasucchavīti
analyzed: upaṭṭhahi mudu bhāvassa upamā suvaṇṇa kambu tala vaṭṭa su chavi iti
translated: and served him. The simile of softness is: ‘like cotton-wool’.🔽The simile of smoothness is: ‘smooth as a polished shell’.

original: suvaṇṇamayaṃ ādāsatalaṃ viya vaṭṭā ca succhavi ca, parimaṇḍalatalā ceva sundaracchavi
analyzed: suvaṇṇa mayam ādāsa talam viya vaṭṭā ca succhavi ca parimaṇḍalatalā ca iva sundara chavi
translated: The meaning is: it is round and smooth like the surface of a polished golden mirror.

original: cāti attho. Samphusitvāti suṭṭhu phusitvā attano hatthasamphassaṃ mama sarīre pharāpetvā.🔽Ito gatoti mama olokentasseva ito gato. Tena maṃ dahantīti tena tassa hatthasamphassena
analyzed: ca ati attho samphusitvā ti suṭṭhu phusitvā attanaḥ hattha samphassam mama sarīre pharāpetvā  itas gataḥ ti mama olokentassa iva itas gataḥ tena mama dahanti iti tena tassa hattha samphassena
translated: ‘Having touched’: having touched well, having spread the touch of his hand over my body.🔽‘Gone from here’: gone from here even as I was looking at him. ‘Burning me’:

original: idāni maṃ dahanti. Tathā hi tassa gatakālato paṭṭhāya mama sarīre ḍāho uṭṭhito, tenamhi
analyzed: idāni mam dahanti tathā hi tassa gata kālataḥ paṭṭhāya mama sarīre ḍāhaḥ uṭṭhito tena amhi

analyzed: virūpa rūpena ati vividha rūpena idam vuttam hoti tāta manussa lokasmin hi etāni yakkhini saṅkhātāni

analyzed: isisiṅgaḥ ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu pitā pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: The Brother who was dissatisfied was the seer Sivi, and I myself was the father.🔽The story of the she-monkey.

analyzed: niḷinikā jātaka vaṇṇanā paṭhamā         nivesanam kassanudam sunanda iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhum
translated: The story of Ummādantī.🔽“The house that is well-built and well-guarded,” etc. This story the Master told, while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a Brother who was dissatisfied.

original: ārabbha kathesi. So kirekadivasaṃ sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caranto ekaṃ alaṅkatapaṭiyattaṃ
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi saḥ kira eka divasam sāvatthiyam piṇḍāya carantaḥ ekam alaṅkata paṭiyattam
translated: This Brother, it seems, one day, while wandering for alms in Sāvatthi, saw a woman of the highest beauty, adorned with ornaments,

analyzed: uttama rūpa dharam itthim oloketvā paṭibaddha cittaḥ hutvā cittam nivattetum a sakkonto
translated: and his heart became attached to her. He was unable to turn his thoughts away from her,

original: vihārameva āgantvā tato paṭṭhāya sallaviddho viya rāgāturo bhantamigapaṭibhāgo kiso
analyzed: vihāram eva āgantvā tatas paṭṭhāya salla viddhaḥ viya rāga āturaḥ kiso

analyzed: dhamanī santhata gattaḥ uppaṇḍu paṇḍuka jātaḥ an abhirataḥ e kiriyā pathe pi citta ssādam a labhantaḥ

analyzed: pubbe tvam āvuso santindriyaḥ vippasanna mukha vaṇṇo idāni no tathā kim nu kho
translated: The monks who were his friends asked him, “Previously, friend, your faculties were clear, your complexion was pure. Now they are not. What is the reason?

original: kāraṇa”nti puṭṭho, “āvuso, anabhiratomhī”ti āha. Atha naṃ te “abhiramāvuso, sāsane,
analyzed: kāraṇam iti puṭṭhaḥ āvuso an abhirataḥ asmi iti āha atha nam te abhirama āvuso sāsane

original: buddhuppādo nāma dullabho, tathā saddhammassavanaṃ manussapaṭilābho ca, so tvaṃ manussapaṭilābhaṃ🔽paṭilabhitvā dukkhassantakiriyaṃ patthayamāno assumukhaṃ ñātijanaṃ pahāya saddhāya🔽pabbajitvā kiṃkāraṇā kilesavasaṃ yāsi, kilesā nāmete gaṇḍuppādakapāṇakaṃ upādāya

translated: The arising of a Buddha is rare. So too is it rare to hear the true Teaching. It is rare to obtain human birth. You have obtained human birth.🔽You have gone forth out of faith, abandoning your tearful relatives.🔽Why do you go under the sway of defilements? Defilements are shared by all foolish people, beginning with those who are born as worms.

original: sabbabālajanasādhāraṇā, ye tesaṃ vatthubhūtā, tepi appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā,

analyzed: attano sarīrataḥ apanetvā parassa sarīre khipati parassa vā sukhena attano sukham  dahati parassa sukham gahetvā attani pakkhipati attanaḥ dukkham harissāmi iti param

translated: “You are worthy of offerings, great king,” means “You are worthy of my offerings, respect, and honor.” “You are the supporter, the provider,

analyzed: casi kāma pālaḥ iti tvam mama deva dhāraṇataḥ dhātā issariya sukhassa vidahanataḥ vidhātā  icchita patthitānam kāmānam pālanataḥ kāmapālo tayī hutā ati tuyham dinnā kāmena mā iti
translated: and the protector of desires” means “You are the supporter because you bear up, you are the provider because you provide the happiness of sovereignty,

analyzed: addhā hi iti gātham āha tattha kattu puttā ati pitā api ssa kattā ava tena nam evam ālapati  idam vuttam hoti addhā tvam itas pubbe mayham sabba dhammam acari hitam eva vuḍḍhim eva  akāsi idāni pana paṭipakkhaḥ hutvā bahum kathesi mā evam vippalapasi aññaḥ nu te  dvipadaḥ naraḥ kaḥ idha jīva loke sace hi aham viya aññaḥ rājā  tava bhariyāya paṭibaddha cittaḥ abhavissa tava sīsam chindāpetvā tam
translated: and spoke the first stanza, “Surely, son of Kattu.” Herein, son of Kattu means his father was a Kattu too, and so he addressed him thus.

original: attano ghare kareyya, ahaṃ pana akusalabhayeneva na karomi, tuṇhī hohi, na me etāya

If any other king were as attached to your wife as I am, he would have your head cut off at dawn and would take your wife to his own house. But I do not do so because I am afraid of demerit. Be silent. I have no use for you.”

original: attho”ti taṃ santajjesi.
analyzed: attha uti tam santajjesi

translated: On hearing this, the king, unable to say anything more, spoke this verse in praise of the king:

analyzed: tvam vinicchaya dhamma paveṇi dhamma su carita dhammānam gopāyanena dhamma gutto tesam  viditattā dhamma vidū tvam sumedho saḥ tvam yam dhammam gopesi tena iva guttaḥ cīram
translated: You are a righteous king because you protect the law of judgment, the tradition of the Dhamma, and the good conduct of the Dhamma.

original: jīva, dhammañca me desehi dhammapālaka, dhammagopaka, rājavarāti.
analyzed: jīva dhammañca me desehi dhamma pālaka dhamma gopaka
translated: Because of your knowledge of these, you are wise in the Dhamma. Therefore, protected by that Dhamma, you should live. original: Atha rājā dhammaṃ desento “tadiṅghā”tiādimāha. Tattha iṅghāti codanatthe nipāto,

translated: being appointed to the king’s court, became extortioners, and made the owner of an animal the owner of another’s animal, and another’s animal the owner’s animal.

original: Athekadivasaṃ eko puriso kūṭaṭṭaparājito mahāsattaṃ bhikkhāya carantaṃ rājagehaṃ
analyzed: atha eka divasam ekaḥ purisaḥ kūṭaṭṭa parājitaḥ mahāsattam bhikkhāya carantam rājageham
translated: One day a man who had been defeated by a trick, saw the Great Being going on his alms-round and entering the king’s palace.

original: pavisantaṃ disvā vanditvā, “bhante, tumhe rājagehe bhuñjamānā vinicchayāmacce lañjaṃ🔽gahetvā lokaṃ vināsente kasmā ajjhupekkhatha, idāni pañcahi amaccehi kūṭaṭṭakārakassa
analyzed: pavisantam disvā vanditvā bhante tumhe rāja gehe bhuñjamānāḥ lañjam  gahetvā lokam vināsente kasmai ajjhupekkhatha idāni pañcahi amaccehi kūṭaṭṭa kārakassa
translated: He saluted him, and said: “Reverend Sir, while you are eating in the king’s palace, the ministers of justice, taking bribes,

analyzed: hatthataḥ lañjam gahetvā sāmikaḥ uva samānaḥ a sāmikaḥ kato ti so tasmin kāruñña vasena
translated: are destroying the world. Why do you look on? Now five ministers have taken a bribe from a cheat, and have made a man who is the owner of an animal, not the owner of it.” And he lamented. The Great Being, out of compassion for him,

original: vinicchayaṃ gantvā dhammena vinicchinitvā sāmikaññeva sāmikaṃ akāsi. Mahājano ekappahāreneva
analyzed: vinicchayam gantvā dhammena vinicchinitvā sāmikam ñeva sāmikam akāsi mahā janaḥ eka ppahārena iva
translated: went to the court, and judged according to justice, and made the owner of an animal the owner of it. The people, with one accord,

analyzed: mahā saddena sādhukāram adāsi rājā tam saddam sutvā kiṃsaddaḥ nāmāyanti pucchitvā
translated: gave a great shout of applause. The king, hearing that shout, asked: “What is the meaning of that shout?”

original: tamatthaṃ sutvā katabhattakiccaṃ mahāsattaṃ upanisīditvā pucchi – “bhante, ajja kira

translated: The king, hearing the news, went to the Great Being after he had eaten, and asked him, saying, “Reverend Sir, I hear that to-day you have decided a case.”

original: vo aṭṭo vinicchito”ti. “Āma, mahārājā”ti. “Bhante, tumhesu vinicchinantesu mahājanassa🔽vuḍḍhi bhavissati, ito paṭṭhāya tumheva vinicchinathā”ti. “Mahārāja, mayaṃ pabbajitā
analyzed: vaḥ aṭṭaḥ vinicchito ti āma mahā rāja ati bhante tumhesu vinicchinantesu mahājanassa  vuḍḍhi bhavissati itas paṭṭhāya tumhā iva vinicchinatha ati mahā rāja mayam pabbajitā
translated: “Yes, great king.” “Reverend Sir, if you decide cases, the people will be greatly benefited. From this time forth you must decide cases.”🔽“Great king, we are ascetics; it is not proper for us to decide cases.”

analyzed: nāma na itam kammam amhākam kammanti bhante mahājane kāruññena kātum vaṭṭati  tumhe sakala divasam mā vinicchinatha uyyānataḥ pana idha āgacchantā vinicchaya ṭṭhānam
translated: “Reverend Sir, it is proper for you to do so out of compassion for the people.

original: gantvā pātova cattāro aṭṭe vinicchinatha, bhutvā uyyānaṃ gacchantā cattāro, evaṃ
analyzed: gantvā cattāraḥ aṭṭe vinicchinatha bhutvā uyyānam gacchantā cattāraḥ evam
translated: Do not decide cases all day long, but when you come from the garden to the palace, go to the place where cases are decided, and decide four cases in the morning, and four after you have eaten, before you go to the garden.🔽In this way the people will be greatly benefited.”

original: mahājanassa vuḍḍhi bhavissatī”ti. So tena punappunaṃ yāciyamāno “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā
analyzed: mahājanassa vuḍḍhi bhavissati iti saḥ tena punappunam yāciyamānaḥ sādhu uti sampaṭicchitvā

original: tato paṭṭhāya tathā akāsi.
analyzed: tato paṭṭhāya tathā akāsi
translated: From that time forth he did as he had promised.

original: Kūṭaṭṭakārakā okāsaṃ na labhiṃsu. Tepi amaccā lañjaṃ alabhantā duggatā hutvā cintayiṃsu
analyzed: kūṭaṭṭa kārakāḥ okāsam na labhiṃsu te pi amaccāḥ lañjam a labhantāḥ duggatāḥ hutvā cintayiṃsu
translated: The builders of the palace could not get on with their work. The ministers, not getting the bribes they expected, became discontented, and said,

original: – “bodhiparibbājakassa vinicchinanakālato paṭṭhāya mayaṃ kiñci na labhāma, handa
analyzed: bodhiparibbājakassa vinicchinana kālataḥ paṭṭhāya mayam kiñci na labhāma handa
translated: “Since the time that the Wanderer Bodhi began to pass judgment, we have received nothing. Well then,

analyzed: nam rājaverikā iti vatvā raññaḥ antare paribhinditvā mārāpessāma iti te rājānam upasaṅkamitvā
translated: let us accuse him of being an enemy of the king, slander him in the king’s presence, and have him put to death.” So they went to the king and said,

analyzed: mahā rāja bodhi paribbājakaḥ tumhākam anattha kāmaḥ ti vatvā asaddahantena raññā sīlavā  esa ñāṇa sampannaḥ na evam karissati iti vutte mahā rāja tena sakala nagara vāsinaḥ  attanaḥ hatthe katvā kevalam pañca jane kātum na sakkā sace amhākam vacanam
translated: “Your majesty, the Wanderer Bodhi is your enemy.” But the king did not believe them. “He is virtuous,🔽and he is learned in the scriptures. He would not do such a thing.” “Your majesty,” they replied, “he has brought the whole city into his power. He is able to do anything except make us five men his slaves. If you do not believe our word,

original: na saddahatha, tassa idhāgamanakāle parisaṃ olokethā”ti āhaṃsu. Rājā “sādhū”ti sīhapañjare
analyzed: na saddahatha tassa idha āgamana kāle parisam oloketha ati āhaṃsu rājā sādhu iti sīhapañjare
translated: look at the crowd that will gather when he comes here.” The king said, “Very well,” and standing in a window,

analyzed: ṭhito tam āgacchantam olokento parivāram disvā attanaḥ aññāṇena aṭṭa kāraka manusse

analyzed: tassa parivārā ati maññamānaḥ bhijjitvā te amacce pakkosāpetvā kinti karoma ati pucchi
translated: Thinking, “They are his supporters,” he split up and summoned those ministers and asked them, “What shall we do?”

original: “Gaṇhāpetha naṃ, devā”ti. “Oḷārikaṃ aparādhaṃ apassantā kathaṃ gaṇhāmā”ti. “Tena
analyzed: gaṇhāpetha nam deva ati oḷārikam aparādham a passantā katham gaṇhāma iti tena
translated: “Arrest him, sire.” “Not seeing any gross offense, how can we arrest him?” “Then,

translated: great king, deprive him of his privileges. When he is deprived of his privileges, the wise wanderer will

analyzed: kassaci an ārocetvā sayam eva palāyissati iti  rājā sādhu uti vatvā anupubbena tassa parihāram parihāpesi paṭhama divasam tāva naṃ
translated: see that he is being deprived of them. Without informing anyone, he will run away of his own accord.”

analyzed: so tuccha pallaṅkam disvā ava rañño paribhinna bhāvam  ñatvā sayam eva uyyānam gantvā tam divasam eva pakkamitu kāmaḥ hutvā api ekantena ñatvā
translated: The king said, “Good,” and gradually deprived him of his privileges. On the first day they made him sit on an empty seat. When he saw the empty seat, he knew that the king had split with him.

original: pakkamissāmī”ti na pakkāmi. Athassa punadivase tucchapallaṅke nisinnassa raññopakatibhattañca
analyzed: pakkamissāmi iti na pakkāmi athassa puna divase tuccha pallaṅke nisinnassa raññā upakati bhattam ca

translated: and on the third day they gave him a mixed meal and placed it on the steps of the staircase.🔽He took it and went to the park and ate his meal.

analyzed: gantvā bhatta kiccam akāsi rājā amacce pucchi bodhi paribbājakaḥ sakkāre parihāpite pi
translated: The king asked his ministers, “Although the ascetic Bodhi has been deprived of his honors,

analyzed: na pakkamati kinti nam karoma ati deva na saḥ bhatta tthāya carati chatta tthāya

analyzed: pana carati sace bhattatthāya careyya paṭhama divasaṃyā iva palāyeyya ati idāni kim  karoma ati sve nam mahā rāja ati saḥ sādhu iti tesaññeva hatthe khagge
translated: If he were to go about for the sake of food, he would have run away on the first day.” “What shall we do now?”

original: ṭhapetvā “sve antaradvāre ṭhatvā pavisantassevassa sīsaṃ chinditvā khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ

original: Rājāpi sāyaṃ bhuttabhojano sirisayane nipajjitvā mahāsattassa guṇe anussari. Athassa🔽tāvadeva soko uppajji, sarīrato sedā mucciṃsu, sayane assāsaṃ alabhanto aparāparaṃ
analyzed: rājā api sāyam bhutta bhojanaḥ siri sayane nipajjitvā mahāsattassa guṇe  tāvat eva sokaḥ uppajji sarīrataḥ sedāḥ mucciṃsu sayane assāsam a labhantaḥ apara aparam
translated: The king, after eating his evening meal, lay down on his splendid couch and recollected the virtues of the Great Being.

translated: Then and there sorrow arose within him, sweat broke out on his body, and he tossed about on his couch, unable to find comfort. His chief consort lay down by his side, but he paid no attention to her, not even to the extent of holding conversation with her.

original: Atha naṃ sā “kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, sallāpamattampi na karotha, api nu kho me koci

translated: Then she said to him, “Why, your majesty, do you not even hold conversation with me? Have I done you any wrong?”

original: aparādho atthī”ti pucchi. “Natthi devi, apica kho bodhiparibbājako kira amhākaṃ paccatthiko
analyzed: aparādhaḥ atthi iti pucchi natthi devi apica kho bodhi paribbājakaḥ kira amhākam paccatthikaḥ

analyzed: kātabbaḥ uva mā socittha ati assāsesi saḥ tassā vacanena paṭiladdha ssāsaḥ niddam okkami  tasmin khaṇe koleyyakaḥ piṅgalasunakhaḥ tam katham sutvā sve mayā balenassa

analyzed: ummāre sīsam katvā mahāsattassa āgamana maggaṃ olokento iva nipajji te pi amaccā pātova

translated: Go away quickly.” The Bodhisatta, who knew all languages, having understood the meaning of that (barking),

translated: and will be ready to set out on his expedition. If he does not, he will take his own belongings and

analyzed: parikkhāre ādāya gamissāmi iti paṇṇa sālataḥ nikkhantam caṅkamana koṭiyam disvā ava vanditvā
translated: be ready to go. I will know what he is going to do.” So he went to the park, and when he saw the Great Being coming out of the leaf-hut, taking his own belongings, and saying, “I will go,” he saw him walking up and down on the terrace, and after saluting him,

original: ekamantaṃ ṭhito paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: eka mantam paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: he stood at one side and spoke the first stanza:

original: “Kiṃ nu daṇḍaṃ kimajinaṃ, kiṃ chattaṃ kimupāhanaṃ;
analyzed: kim nu daṇḍam kim ajinam kim chattam kim upāhanam
translated: “What is the staff? What the antelope skin? What the sunshade? What the sandals?

original: Kimaṅkusañca pattañca, saṅghāṭiñcāpi brāhmaṇa;
analyzed: kim aṅkusam ca pattam ca saṅghāṭiñca api brāhmaṇa
translated: What the goad? What the bowl? What the outer robe? What the patched garment, Brahman?

original: Taramānarūpohāsi, kiṃ nu patthayase disa”nti.
analyzed: taramāna rūpa ūhā asi kim nu patthayase disanti
translated: You are going away in haste. What is it you seek in every quarter?”

original: Tassattho – bhante, pubbe tvaṃ amhākaṃ gharaṃ āgacchanto daṇḍādīni na gaṇhāsi, ajja
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ bhante pubbe tvam amhākam gharam āgacchantaḥ daṇḍa ādīni na gaṇhāsi ajja
translated: The meaning is this: “Reverend Sir, when you came to our house before, you did not take a staff, etc. But now

original: pana kena kāraṇena daṇḍañca ajinañca chattūpāhanañca mattikapasibbakolambanaaṅkusañca
analyzed: pana kena kāraṇena daṇḍañca ajinañca chattu upāhanañca mattika pasibba kolambana aṅkusañca
translated: why is it that you take a staff, an antelope skin, a sunshade, sandals, a clay water-pot with a strap, a goad,

original: mattikapattañca saṅghāṭiñcāti sabbepime parikkhāre taramānarūpo gaṇhāsi, kataraṃ
analyzed: mattika pattam ca saṅghāṭiñca ati sabbe pi ime parikkhāre taramāna rūpaḥ gaṇhāsi kataram
translated: a clay bowl, and an outer robe? You take all these belongings in haste. What is it you seek in every quarter?

original: nu disaṃ patthesi, kattha gantukāmosīti pucchi.
analyzed: nu disam patthesi kattha gantu kāmo asi iti pucchi
translated: “In what direction do you wish to go? Where do you wish to go?”

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto “ayaṃ attanā katakammaṃ na jānātīti maññati, jānāpessāmi na”nti dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsattaḥ ayam attanā kata kammam na jānāti iti maññati jānāpessāmi na nti dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having heard that, the Great Being thought, “This one thinks that he does not know the deed that he has done, I will make him know,” and spoke two verses:

original: “Dvādasetāni vassāni, vusitāni tavantike;
analyzed: dvādasa itāni vassāni vusitāni tava antike
translated: “These twelve years have been spent in your presence;

original: Nābhijānāmi soṇena, piṅgalenābhikūjitaṃ.
analyzed: na abhijānāmi soṇena piṅgalena abhikūjitam
translated: I do not know that I have been barked at by a dog,

original: “Svāyaṃ dittova nadati, sukkadāṭhaṃ vidaṃsayaṃ;
analyzed: su āyam dittaḥ uva nadati vidaṃsayan
translated: “This one, as if intoxicated, barks, breaking his dry teeth;

original: Tava sutvā sabhariyassa, vītasaddhassa maṃ patī”ti.
analyzed: tava sutvā sabhariyassa vīta saddhassa mam pati iti
translated: Having heard of your wife’s husband, I am without faith in you, my lord.”

original: Tattha abhikūjitanti etena tava sunakhena evaṃ mahāviravena viravitaṃ na jānāmi.
analyzed: tattha etena tava sunakhena evam mahā viravena viravitam na jānāmi
translated: Herein, barked at means I do not know that I have been barked at by your dog, by this great bird.

original: Ditto vāti dappito viya. Sabhariyassāti tava sabhariyassa mama māraṇatthāya pañcannaṃ
analyzed: dittaḥ vā ati dappitaḥ viya sabhariyassa ati tava sabhariyassa mama māraṇa tthāya
translated: As if intoxicated means as if intoxicated. Having heard of your wife’s husband means having heard of the fact that you have been ordered by the five ministers to kill me, your wife.

original: amaccānaṃ āṇattabhāvaṃ kathentassa sutvā “kiṃ tvaṃ aññattha bhikkhaṃ na labhasi,
analyzed: amaccānam āṇatta bhāvam kathentassa sutvā kim tvam aññattha bhikkham na labhasi
translated: “Why do you not get alms elsewhere?

original: raññā te vadho āṇatto, idha māgacchī”ti dittova nadati. Vītasaddhassa maṃ patīti
analyzed: raññā te vadhaḥ āṇattaḥ idha mā āgacchi iti dittā uva nadati vīta saddhassa mam pati iti
translated: You have been ordered to be killed by the King, come here.” As if intoxicated, he barks. I am without faith in you, my lord.

original: mamantare vigatasaddhassa tava vacanaṃ sutvā eva nadatīti āha.
analyzed: mamantare vigata saddhassa tava vacanam sutvā eva nadati iti āha
translated: and that it was only after hearing his words that he had begun to beat the drum.

original: Tato rājā attano dosaṃ sampaṭicchitvā taṃ khamāpento catutthaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas rājā attanaḥ dosam sampaṭicchitvā tam khamāpentaḥ catuttham gātham āha
translated: Then the king, acknowledging his own fault, asked the Bodhisatta’s pardon, and spoke the fourth stanza:—

original: “Ahu esa kato doso, yathā bhāsasi brāhmaṇa;
analyzed: ahu esa kataḥ dosaḥ yathā bhāsasi brāhmaṇa
translated: “The fault was mine, O Brahman, as thou hast said;

original: Esa bhiyyo pasīdāmi, vasa brāhmaṇa māgamā”ti.
analyzed: esa bhiyyas pasīdāmi vasa brāhmaṇa mā āgama ati
translated: I have still greater confidence in thee: stay here, O Brahman, go not hence.”

original: Tattha bhiyyoti saccaṃ mayā evaṃ āṇattaṃ, ayaṃ me doso, esa panāhaṃ idāni adhikataraṃ tayi pasīdāmi, idheva vasa, mā aññattha gamīti.
analyzed: tattha bhiyyo ti saccam mayā evam āṇattam ayam me doso esa pana aham idāni adhikataram tayi pasīdāmi idhā iva vasa mā aññattha gami iti
translated: “Greater confidence,” he said, “I have now in thee than ever I had before. Stay here, and go not hence.”

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto, “mahārāja, paṇḍitā nāma tādisena parapattiyena apaccakkhakārinā saddhiṃ na vasantī”ti vatvā tassa anācāraṃ pakāsento āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsattaḥ mahā rāja paṇḍitāḥ nāma tādisena parapattiyena apaccakkhakārinā saddhim na vasanti iti vatvā tassa anācāram pakāsentaḥ āha
translated: When the Great Being heard this, he said, “Great king, the wise do not live with such as thou art, who art so ready to take offence.” And in order to make known his own conduct, he spoke the following stanzas:—

original: “Sabbaseto pure āsi, tatopi sabalo ahu;
analyzed: sabbaseto pure āsi tatas pi sabalaḥ ahu
translated: “I was all white before, and then all black;

original: Sabbalohitako dāni, kālo pakkamituṃ mama.
analyzed: sabbalohitakaḥ dāni kālaḥ pakkamitum mama
translated: Now I am all red: it is time for me to go.

original: “Abbhantaraṃ pure āsi, tato majjhe tato bahi;
analyzed: abbhantaram pure āsi tatas majjhe tatas bahi
translated: “I was within before, then in the middle, then without;

original: Purā niddhamanā hoti, sayameva vajāmahaṃ.
analyzed: purā sayam eva vajāmaham
translated: Before the water overflows, I will go of myself.”

original: “Vītasaddhaṃ na seveyya, upadānaṃvanodakaṃ;
analyzed: vīta saddham na seveyyaḥ upadānaṃvana udakam
translated: “One should not associate with the faithless, who are like a well without a rope;

original: Sacepi naṃ anukhaṇe, vāri kaddamagandhikaṃ.
analyzed: sace pi naṃ anukhaṇe vāri kaddama gandhikam
translated: Even if there is water, it cannot be drawn.

original: “Pasannameva seveyya, appasannaṃ vivajjaye;
analyzed: pasannam eva seveyya appasannam vivajjaye
translated: “One should associate with the faithful, avoid the faithless;

original: Pasannaṃ payirupāseyya, rahadaṃvudakatthiko.
analyzed: pasannam rahat aṃvuda katthikaḥ
translated: One should attend on the faithful, like one who needs water, a well.

original: “Bhaje bhajantaṃ purisaṃ, abhajantaṃ na bhajjaye;
analyzed: bhaje bhajantam purisam a bhajantam na bhajjaye
translated: “One should associate with the associating person, not with the non-associating person;

original: Asappurisadhammo so, yo bhajantaṃ na bhajjati.
analyzed: a sappurisa dhammaḥ saḥ yaḥ bhajantam na bhajjati
translated: That is the way of the bad person, who does not associate with the associating person.

original: “Yo bhajantaṃ na bhajati, sevamānaṃ na sevati;
analyzed: yaḥ bhajantam na bhajati sevamānam na sevati
translated: “He who does not associate with the associating person, who does not attend on the attending person,

original: Sa ve manussapāpiṭṭho, migo sākhassito yathā.
analyzed: sa ve manussa pāpiṭṭhaḥ migaḥ sākhassitaḥ yathā
translated: He is a human cur, like a deer caught in a snare.

original: “Accābhikkhaṇasaṃsaggā, asamosaraṇena ca;
analyzed: acca abhikkhaṇa saṃsaggāḥ a samosaraṇena ca
translated: “Through excessive begging, through not sharing,

original: Etena mittā jīranti, akāle yācanāya ca.
analyzed: etena mittāḥ jīranti akāle yācanāya ca
translated: Through that friends deteriorate, and through begging at the wrong time.

original: “Tasmā nābhikkhaṇaṃ gacche, na ca gacche cirāciraṃ;
analyzed: tasmai na abhikkhaṇam gacche na ca gacche cirāciram
translated: “Therefore one should not go begging excessively, nor should one go begging too often;

original: Kālena yācaṃ yāceyya, evaṃ mittā na jīyare.
analyzed: kālena yācam yāceyyaḥ evam mittāḥ na jīyare
translated: One should beg at the right time, in this way friends do not deteriorate.

original: “Aticiraṃ nivāsena, piyo bhavati appiyo;
analyzed: aticiram nivāsena piyaḥ bhavati appiyaḥ
translated: “Through living too long together, the dear one becomes an enemy;

original: Āmanta kho taṃ gacchāma, purā te homa appiyā”ti.
analyzed: āmanta kho tam gacchāma purā te homa appiya ati
translated: ‘I will go, friend, before you come to hate me.’“

original: Tattha sabbasetoti, mahārāja, paṭhamameva tava nivesane mama odano sabbaseto ahosi,🔽yaṃ tvaṃ bhuñjasi, tameva dāpesīti attho. Tatoti tato pacchā paribhedakānaṃ vacanaṃ🔽gahetvā tava mayi virattakāle sabalo missakodano jāto. Dānīti idāni sabbalohitako
analyzed: tattha sabbaseto ti mahā rāja paṭhamam eva tava nivesane mama odanaḥ sabba seto ahosi  yam tvam bhuñjasi tam eva dāpesi iti tato ti tato pacchā paribhedakānam vacanam  gahetvā tava mayi viratta kāle sabalaḥ missaka udanaḥ jātaḥ dāni iti idāni sabba lohitakaḥ
translated: Herein, ‘all-white’ means, sire, that in your own house my rice was all-white at the very first,

original: jāto. Kāloti aguṇaññussa tava santikā idāni mama pakkamituṃ kālo. Abbhantaranti paṭhamaṃ🔽mama abbhantaraṃ āsanaṃ āsi, alaṅkatamahātalamhi ussitasetacchatte rājapallaṅkeyeva
analyzed: jātaḥ kālaḥ ti aguṇaññussa tava santikā idāni mama pakkamitum kālaḥ abbhantaranti paṭhamam  mama abbhantaram āsanam āsi alaṅkata mahā talamhi ussita seta chatte
translated: and you gave me only that which you yourself ate. ‘Then’ means after that, after accepting the words of the slanderers. ‘Now’ means now that you have turned against me, it has become mixed rice with all the husks on. ‘The time’ means the time for me to leave you, who are devoid of virtue. ‘Formerly’ means🔽formerly my seat was in the inner quarters, and they made me sit on the royal couch, which was set on a high dais, with a white canopy spread above it,

original: maṃ nisīdāpesuṃ. Majjheti sopānamatthake. Purā niddhamanā hotīti yāva gīvāyaṃ gahetvā🔽nikkaḍḍhanā na hoti.🔽Anukhaṇeti sacepi anudakaṃ udapānaṃ patto puriso udakaṃ apassanto kalalaṃ viyūhitvā
analyzed: mam nisīda apesum majjhe ti sopāna matthake purā niddhamanā hoti iti gahetvā  nikkaḍḍhanā na hoti  anukhaṇeti sace pi anudakam udapānam pattaḥ purisaḥ udakam a passanto kalalam viyūhitvā
translated: just like the king’s. ‘Now’ means now that I am outside, on the steps. ‘Before’ means before they seize me by the neck and drag me out.🔽‘If a man’ means if a man who has gone to a well without water and who does not see any water should break up the mud

original: anukhaṇeyya, tathāpi taṃ vāri kaddamagandhikaṃ bhaveyya, amanuññatāya na piveyya,
analyzed: anukhaṇeyya tathā api tam vāri kaddama gandhikam bhaveyya amanuñña tāya na piveyya
translated: and dig down, still the water would be muddy and smelly, and he would not drink it because it was not good.

original: tatheva vītasaddhaṃ payirupāsantena laddhapaccayāpi parittā ceva lūkhā ca, amanuññā
analyzed: tathā iva vīta saddham laddha paccayā api parittā ca iva lūkhā ca amanuññā
translated: Even though he has the requisites, he is limited and poor, and he is not worthy of being used.🔽The meaning is: he is not worthy of being enjoyed.🔽One who has confidence: one whose faith is settled.

original: aparibhogārahāti attho. Pasannanti patiṭṭhitasaddhaṃ. Rahadanti gambhīraṃ mahārahadaṃ.
analyzed: a paribhoga arahā ati pasannam ti patiṭṭhita saddham rahadanti gambhīram mahā rahadam
translated: A pool: a deep, large pool.

original: Bhajantanti attānaṃ bhajantameva bhajeyya. Abhajantanti paccatthikaṃ. Na bhajjayeti
analyzed: bhajantanti attānam bhajantam eva bhajeyya a bhajantanti paccatthikam na bhajjayeti
translated: One should associate with one who associates with oneself: one should associate only with one who associates with oneself.🔽One should not associate with one who does not associate with oneself: one should not associate with one who does not associate with oneself.

original: na bhajeyya. Na bhajjatīti yo puriso attānaṃ bhajantaṃ hitacittaṃ puggalaṃ na bhajati,
analyzed: na bhajeyya na bhajjati iti yaḥ purisaḥ attānam bhajantam hita cittam puggalam na bhajati
translated: One who does not associate with one who associates with oneself: a person who does not associate with a person who associates with oneself with a helpful mind,🔽he is called a person who is not a true man.

original: so asappurisadhammo nāmāti. Manussapāpiṭṭhoti manussalāmako patikuṭṭho sabbapacchimako.
analyzed: so asappurisadhammaḥ nāma ati manussa pāpiṭṭho ti manussa lāmakaḥ patikuṭṭho sabbapacchimako
translated: The worst of men: the most contemptible, the most despised, the most inferior of men.

original: Sākhassitoti makkaṭo.
analyzed: sākhassitaḥ iti makkaṭaḥ
translated: A monkey: a monkey.🔽Too much association: through too much association.

original: Accābhikkhaṇasaṃsaggāti ativiya abhiṇhasaṃsaggena. Akāleti ayuttappattakāle parassa
analyzed: acca abhikkhaṇa saṃsaggā ti ativiya abhiṇha saṃsaggena akāle ayutta patta kāle parassa
translated: At the wrong time: at a time that is not suitable, when it is not the right time,

original: piyabhaṇḍaṃ yācanāya mittā jīranti nāma, tvampi aticiraṃ nivāsena mayi mittiṃ bhindi.
analyzed: piya bhaṇḍam yācanāya mittāḥ jīranti nāma tvam pi ati ciram nivāsena mayi mittim bhindi
translated: friends are lost through begging for a dear friend’s goods. You too have broken our friendship through living with me too long.

original: Tasmāti yasmā accābhikkhaṇasaṃsaggena asamosaraṇena ca mittā jīranti, tasmā. Cirāciranti
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmai acca abhikkhaṇa saṃsaggena a samosaraṇena ca mittāḥ jīranti tasmai cirā āciranti
translated: Therefore, since friends decay through too frequent visits and through not visiting,🔽after a long time has passed, do not go too often, do not visit too often.

original: cirakālaṃ vītināmetvā ciraṃ na gacche na upasaṅkameyya. Yācanti yācitabbaṃ bhaṇḍakaṃ
analyzed: cira kālam vītināmetvā ciram na gacche na upasaṅkameyya yācanti yācitabbam bhaṇḍakam
translated: When they ask, when they request, when they beckon,🔽at the right time you should ask. In this way friends do not decay.

original: yuttakāle yāceyya. Na jīyareti evaṃ mittā na jīranti. Purā te homa appiyāti yāva
analyzed: yutta kāle yāceyya na evam mittāḥ na jīranti purā te homa appiyā ati yāva
translated: Before you become displeasing,

original: tava appiyā na homa, tāva āmantetvāva taṃ gacchāmāti.
analyzed: tava appiyāḥ na homa tāva āmantetvā ava tam gacchāma iti
translated: before you become displeasing to us, first invite us, and then go.”

original: Rājā āha –
analyzed: rājā āha
translated: The king said:🔽“If you do not understand the folded hands

original: “Evaṃ ce yācamānānaṃ, añjaliṃ nāvabujjhasi;
analyzed: evam ce yācamānānam añjalim na avabujjhasi
translated: of those who are asking in this way,

original: Paricārakānaṃ sataṃ, vacanaṃ na karosi no;
analyzed: paricārakānam satam vacanam na karosi no
translated: and do not do what the many servants say,

original: Evaṃ taṃ abhiyācāma, puna kayirāsi pariyāya”nti.
analyzed: evam tam abhiyācāma punar kayirāsi pariyāyanti
translated: we ask you to do this again, to make a way.”

original: Tattha nāvabujjhasīti sace, bhante, evaṃ yācantena mayā kataṃ añjaliṃ na jānāsi, na paṭiggaṇhasīti attho. Pariyāyanti puna idhāgamanāya ekavāraṃ kareyyāsīti yācati.
analyzed: tattha na avabujjhasi iti sace bhante evam yācantena mayā katam añjalim na jānāsi na paṭiggaṇhasi iti attho pariyāyanti puna idha āgamanāya eka vāram kareyyāsi iti yācati
translated: Here, “do not understand” means “if you do not know, if you do not accept the folded hands done by me who am asking in this way, the meaning is that.” “Way” means “make a way to come here again.”

original: Bodhisatto āha –
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ āha
translated: The Buddha-to-be said:

original: “Evaṃ ce no viharataṃ, antarāyo na hessati;
analyzed: evam ce naḥ viharatam antarāyaḥ na hessati
translated: “If, while we are living in this way, there will be no obstacle,

original: Tuyhaṃ vāpi mahārāja, mayhaṃ vā raṭṭhavaddhana;
analyzed: tuyham vā api mahā rāja mayham vā raṭṭha vat hana
translated: “If, O king, you or I, or the wealth of the realm,

original: Appeva nāma passema, ahorattānamaccaye”ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma passema ahorattānam accayā iti
translated: Should pass away, then perhaps we might see each other again, day by day and night by night.”

original: Tattha evaṃ ce noti sace, mahārāja, evaṃ nānā hutvā viharantānaṃ amhākaṃ antarāyo na hessati, tuyhaṃ vā mayhaṃ vā jīvitaṃ pavattissatīti dīpeti. Passemāti api nāma passeyyāma.
analyzed: tattha evam ce no ti sace mahā rāja evam nānā hutvā viharantānam amhākam antarāyaḥ na hessati tuyham vā mayham vā jīvitam pavattissati iti dīpeti passema ati api nāma passeyyāma
translated: Herein, if thus means if, O king, there will be no obstacle to us who are living thus in different places, and if your life or my life will continue. We might see means we might perhaps see.

original: Evaṃ vatvā mahāsatto rañño dhammaṃ desetvā “appamatto hohi, mahārājā”ti vatvā uyyānā
analyzed: evam vatvā mahāsattaḥ raññaḥ dhammam desetvā appamattaḥ hohi mahā rāja iti vatvā uyyānā
translated: Having thus spoken, the Great Being taught the king the Dhamma, saying: “Be heedful, O great king.” After he had left the pleasure garden,

original: nikkhamitvā ekasmiṃ sabhāgaṭṭhāne bhikkhāya caritvā bārāṇasito nikkhamma anupubbena🔽himavantokāsameva gantvā kiñci kālaṃ vasitvā puna otaritvā ekaṃ paccantagāmaṃ nissāya
analyzed: nikkhamitvā ekasmim sabhāgaṭṭhāne bhikkhāya caritvā bārāṇasitaḥ nikkhamma anupubbena  himavant okāsam eva gantvā kiñci kālam vasitvā punar otaritvā ekam paccanta gāmam nissāya
translated: he went on his alms-round in a suitable place. After he had left Bārāṇasī, he went on step by step🔽to the Himalayas. After he had stayed there for some time, he came down again and lived in a forest near a border village.

original: araññe vasi. Tassa pana gatakālato paṭṭhāya te amaccā puna vinicchaye nisīditvā vilopaṃ
analyzed: araññe vasi tassa pana gata kālataḥ paṭṭhāya te amaccā puna vinicchaye nisīditvā vilopam
translated: From the time he had left, those ministers sat down again to settle the lawsuits and to take bribes.

original: karontā cintayiṃsu – “sace mahābodhiparibbājako punāgamissati, jīvitaṃ no natthi,
analyzed: karontā cintayiṃsu sace mahābodhi paribbājakaḥ puna āgamissati jīvitam no natthi
translated: They thought: “If the Great Ascetic should come back, there is no life for us.

original: kiṃ nu khvassa anāgamanakāraṇaṃ kareyyāmā”ti. Atha nesaṃ etadahosi – “ime sattā paṭibaddhaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: kim nu khvassa an āgamana kāraṇam kareyyāma ati atha na īsam etat ahosi ime sattā paṭibaddha ṭṭhānam
translated: “What can we do to make him not come?” Then they thought, “These people cannot leave a place to which they are attached.

original: nāma jahituṃ na sakkonti, kiṃ nu khvassa idha paṭibaddhaṭṭhāna”nti. Tato “rañño aggamahesī”ti
analyzed: nāma jahitum na sakkonti kim nu khvassa idha paṭibaddha ṭṭhānan ti tatas raññaḥ aggamahesī iti

original: Tattha tādisoti, mahārāja, yādisā ete pañca diṭṭhigatikā, tādiso puriso sayampi pāpaṃ🔽kareyya. Yvāssa vacanaṃ suṇāti, taṃ aññampi kāraye. Dukkhantoti evarūpehi asappurisehi🔽saddhiṃ saṃsaggo idhalokepi paralokepi dukkhanto kaṭukudrayova hoti. Imassa panatthassa🔽pakāsanatthaṃ “yāni kānici, bhikkhave, bhayāni uppajjanti, sabbāni tāni bālato”ti
analyzed: tattha tādisaḥ ti mahā rāja yādisāḥ ete pañca diṭṭhi gatikā tādisaḥ puriso sayam pi pāpam  kareyya yvā assa vacanam suṇāti tam aññam pi kāraye dukkhanto ti evarūpehi a sappurisehi  saddhim saṃsaggaḥ idha loke pi para loke pi dukkhantaḥ hoti imassa pana atthassa  pakāsana attham yāni kānici bhikkhave bhayāni uppajjanti sabbāni tāni bālato ti
translated: Herein, “Such a one” is a person like these five who have gone into the wilderness. He himself would do evil and he would make others do it too. “The end of suffering” is that association with such bad people is the end of suffering, it is bitter and harsh in this world and the next. In order to demonstrate this meaning, “Whatever fears arise, all of them arise from the fool.”🔽🔽

original: suttaṃ āharitabbaṃ. Godhajātaka- sañjīvajātaka- akittijātakādīhi cāyamattho dīpetabbo.
analyzed: suttam āharitabbam godha jātaka sañjīva jātaka akitti jātaka ādīhi ca ayam atthaḥ dīpetabbaḥ
translated: Herein, “Such a one” means, sire, that a person like these five who hold views would himself do evil and would also cause another to do it who would listen to his words. “The end of suffering” means that association with such bad people is the end of suffering, it is bitter and hard in this world and in the world beyond. In order to make this meaning clear, the sutta “Whatever fears arise, they all arise from the fool” should be quoted. And this meaning should be illustrated by the Godha Jātaka, the Sañjīva Jātaka, the Akitti Jātaka, etc.
