translated: It perishes: it becomes empty, people abandon the villages and towns and go to the border districts and the uneven places of the mountains,

original: sabbāni āyamukhāni pacchijjanti. Sabbosadhīhīti sabbehi mūlatacapattapupphaphalādīhi🔽ceva sappinavanītādīhi ca osadhehi virujjhati, tāni na sampajjanti. Adhammikarañño🔽hi pathavī nirojā hoti, tassā nirojatāya osadhānaṃ ojā na hoti, tāni rogañca vūpasametuṃ
analyzed: sabbāni āya mukhāni pacchijjanti sabba osadhīhi iti sabbehi mūla taca patta puppha phala ādīhi  ca iva sappi navanīta ādīhi ca osadhehi virujjhati tāni na sampajjanti adhammika rañño  hi pathavī nirojā hoti tassāḥ niroja tāya osadhānam ojā na hoti tāni rogañca vūpasametum
translated: all the sources of income are destroyed. All the medicines: all the roots, tree-barks, leaves, flowers, fruits, etc.,

original: na sakkonti. Iti so tehi viruddho nāma hoti.
analyzed: na sakkonti iti saḥ tehi viruddhaḥ nāma hoti
translated: and the medicines such as ghee, fresh butter, etc., are destroyed, they do not succeed. For in the country of an unrighteous king the earth is without essence, and because of its lack of essence the medicines have no essence, and they are unable to cure disease. Thus he is said to be opposed to them.

original: Negameti nigamavāsikuṭumbike. Hiṃsanti hiṃsanto pīḷento. Ye yuttāti ye kayavikkaye
analyzed: negama iti nigama vāsi kuṭumbike hiṃsanti hiṃsantaḥ pīḷentaḥ ye yuttā ati ye kaya vikkaye
translated: The townsmen: the householders of the town. They harm: he harms, oppresses. Those engaged in: those engaged in buying and selling,

original: yuttā āyānaṃ mukhā thalajalapathavāṇijā, te ca hiṃsanto. Ojadānabalīkāreti tato tato
analyzed: yuttāḥ thala jala patha vāṇijā te ca hiṃsantaḥ oja dāna balīkāra iti tatas tatas
translated: the sources of income, the land, water and earth trade, and he harms them. The taxes and the tribute:

original: bhaṇḍāharaṇasuṅkadānavasena ojadānañceva chabhāgadasabhāgādibhedaṃ baliñca karonte.
analyzed: bhaṇḍa āharaṇa suṅka dāna vasena oja dānam ca iva chabhāga dasabhāga ādi bhedam balim ca karonte
translated: and by taking away goods and by giving away corpses, he makes gifts of the kind called “gifts of violence” and he makes offerings of the kind classed as “not shared in common” and so on.

original: Sa kosenāti so ete hiṃsanto adhammikarājā dhanadhaññehi parihāyanto kosena virujjhati
analyzed: sa kosena ati saḥ ete hiṃsantaḥ adhammika rājā dhana dhaññehi parihāyantaḥ kosena virujjhati
translated: He is at variance with his treasury: the unrighteous king who harms these is deprived of wealth and corn and so is at variance with his treasury.

original: nāma. Pahāravarakhettaññūti “imasmiṃ ṭhāne vijjhituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti evaṃ pahāravarānaṃ🔽khettaṃ jānante dhanuggahe. Saṅgāme katanissameti yuddhe sukatakamme mahāyodhe. Ussiteti
analyzed: nāma imasmin ṭhāne vijjhitum vaṭṭati iti evam  khettam jānante dhanuggahe saṅgāme kata nissame ti yuddhe su kata kamme mahā yodhe ussita iti
translated: He is at variance with the field: he is at variance with the field of the best archers, who know the field for the best shot, thinking “It is allowable to shoot from this place.”🔽He is at variance with the battle: he is at variance with the great warriors who have done their duty in battle.

original: uggate paññāte mahāmatte. Hi sayanti evarūpe sayaṃ vā hiṃsanto parehi vā hiṃsāpento.
analyzed: uggate paññāte mahāmatte hi sayanti evarūpe sayam vā hiṃsantaḥ parehi vā
translated: He is at variance with the wise: he is at variance with the wise, the great councillors, who are advanced in years and renowned.

original: Balenāti balakāyena. Tathāvidhañhi rājānaṃ “ayaṃ bahukāre attano rajjadāyakepi hiṃsati,
analyzed: balena ati balakāyena tathāvidhan hi rājānam ayam bahu kāre rajja dāyake api hiṃsati
translated: He is at variance with the army: he is at variance with the army, for other warriors also abandon him, thinking “This man harms even his own regents who have done so much for him,

original: kimaṅgaṃ pana amhe”ti avasesāpi yodhā vijahantiyeva. Iti so balena viruddho nāma hoti.
analyzed: kim aṅgam pana amheti avasesāḥ api yodhāḥ iti saḥ balena viruddhaḥ nāma hoti
translated: what to say of us?” So he is at variance with the army.🔽The seers are at variance with him as are the town-dwellers, etc.,

original: Tatheva isayo hiṃsanti yathā ca negamādayo, tatheva esitaguṇe pabbajite akkosanapaharaṇādīhi
analyzed: tathā iva isayaḥ hiṃsanti yathā ca negama ādayaḥ tathā iva esita guṇe pabbajite akkosana paharaṇa ādīhi
translated: and so too the ascetics with their special qualities are at variance with him by abusing and robbing them, etc.

original: hiṃsanto adhammacārī rājā kāyassa bhedā apāyameva upeti, sagge nibbattituṃ na sakkotīti
analyzed: hiṃsantaḥ adhamma cārī rājā kāyassa bhedā apāyam eva upeti sagge nibbattitum na sakkoti iti
translated: a king who is violent and unrighteous, after the dissolution of the body, goes to a state of suffering, and is not able to be reborn in heaven.

original: saggena viruddho nāma hoti. Bhariyaṃ hanti adūsikanti attano bāhucchāyāya vaḍḍhitaṃ🔽puttadhītāhi saṃvaḍḍhaṃ sīlavatiṃ bhariyaṃ mittapatirūpakānaṃ corānaṃ vacanaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: saggena viruddhaḥ nāma hoti bhariyam hanti a dūsikanti attanaḥ bāhu chāyāya vaḍḍhitam  putta dhītāhi saṃvaḍḍham sīlavatim bhariyam mitta pati rūpakānam corānam vacanam gahetvā
translated: He is called one who is opposed to heaven. He kills his wife, though she is innocent.🔽He kills his virtuous wife, who has been brought up in the shadow of his own arm,🔽and who has been brought up with his children, on the word of thieves who are like friends.

original: māreti. Luddhaṃ pasavate ṭhānanti so attano nirayūpapattiṃ pasavati nipphādeti. Puttehi
analyzed: māreti luddham pasavate ṭhānan ti saḥ attanaḥ niraya upapattim pasavati nipphādeti puttehi
translated: He produces a murderer. He is opposed to his children.

original: cāti imasmiññeva attabhāve attano puttehi saddhiṃ virujjhatīti.
analyzed: ca ati imasmin ñeva atta bhāve attano puttehi saddhim virujjhati iti
translated: In this very existence he is opposed to his own children.

original: Evamassa so tesaṃ pañcannaṃ janānaṃ kathaṃ gahetvā deviyā māritabhāvañca puttānaṃ
analyzed: evam assa saḥ tesam pañcannam janānam katham gahetvā deviyāḥ mārita bhāvam ca puttānam
translated: Thus, having taken the side of these five men, he told the story of the queen’s murder and the opposition of the princes

original: viruddhabhāvañca sandhimukhe coraṃ cūḷāyaṃ gaṇhanto viya kathesi. Mahāsatto hi tesaṃ
analyzed: viruddha bhāvam ca sandhi mukhe coram cūḍāyam gaṇhantaḥ viya kathesi mahāsattaḥ hi tesam
translated: like a thief caught in the act, in the presence of the king. For the great being🔽had the ministers arrested and preached the Dhamma, and in order to reveal the queen’s murder by them

original: amaccānaṃ niggaṇhanañca dhammadesanañca deviyā tehi māritabhāvassa āvikaraṇatthañca
analyzed: amaccānam niggaṇhanam ca dhamma desanam ca deviyā tehi mārita bhāvassa āvikaraṇa attham ca
translated: and

original: tattha anupubbena kathaṃ āharitvā okāsaṃ katvā etamatthaṃ kathesi. Rājā tassa vacanaṃ
analyzed: tattha anupubbena katham āharitvā okāsam katvā etam attham kathesi rājā tassa vacanaṃ
translated: and after he had gradually introduced the subject, he made an opportunity and related this matter. The king,🔽having heard his words,

original: sutvā attano aparādhaṃ jāni. Atha naṃ mahāsatto “ito paṭṭhāya, mahārāja, evarūpānaṃ
analyzed: sutvā attanaḥ aparādham atha nam mahāsatto itas paṭṭhāya mahā rāja
translated: knew his own offence. Then the Great Being, saying: “From this day forth, great king, having taken to heart such

original: pāpānaṃ kathaṃ gahetvā mā puna evamakāsī”ti vatvā ovadanto “dhammaṃ care”tiādimāha.
analyzed: pāpānam katham gahetvā mā punar evam akāsi iti vatvā ovadantaḥ dhammam cara itiādim āha
translated: evil deeds, do not act thus again,” and instructing him, said: “Dhammaṃ care” etc.

original: Tattha dhammaṃ careti, mahārāja, rājā nāma janapadaṃ adhammikena balinā apīḷento
analyzed: tattha dhammam cara iti mahā rāja rājā nāma janapadam adhammikena balinā a pīḍentaḥ
translated: Herein, dhammaṃ care means, great king, a king, oppressing the country with unrighteous might,

original: janapade dhammaṃ careyya, sāmike asāmike akaronto negamesu dhammaṃ careyya, aṭṭhāne🔽akilamento balesu dhammaṃ careyya. Vadhabandhaakkosaparibhāse pariharanto paccaye🔽ca nesaṃ dadanto isayo na vihiṃseyya, dhītaro yuttaṭṭhāne patiṭṭhāpento putte ca
analyzed: janapade dhammam careyya sāmike a sāmike a karontaḥ negamesu dhammam careyya aṭṭhāne  a kilamentaḥ balesu dhammam careyya vadha bandha akkosa paribhāse pariharantaḥ paccaye  ca nesam dadantaḥ isayaḥ na vihiṃseyya dhītaraḥ yutta ṭṭhāne patiṭṭhāpento putte ca
translated: should act righteously in the country, not making a master of one who is not a master, he should act righteously in the villages, not troubling one who is not in the wrong,🔽he should act righteously in the army, avoiding killing, binding, reviling, and threatening, and giving them their requisites,🔽he should not harm the ascetics, and establishing his daughters in a suitable place, and training his sons in the crafts, and rightly supporting them, he should not oppress his wife,

original: sippāni sikkhāpetvā sammā pariharanto bhariyaṃ issariyavossaggaalaṅkāradānasammānanādīhi
analyzed: sippāni sikkhāpetvā sammā pariharantaḥ bhariyam issariya vossagga alaṅkāra dāna sammānana ādīhi
translated: by giving her authority, ornaments, respect, etc.

original: anuggaṇhanto puttadāre samaṃ careyya. Sa tādisoti so tādiso rājā paveṇiṃ abhinditvā
analyzed: anuggaṇhantaḥ putta dāre samam careyya sa tādisaḥ iti saḥ tādisaḥ rājā paveṇim a bhinditvā
translated: and should treat his wife and children impartially.

original: dhammena samena rajjaṃ kārento rājāṇāya rājatejena sapatte sampakampeti tāseti cāleti.
analyzed: dhammena samena rajjam kārentaḥ rājāṇāya rāja tejena sa patte sampakampeti tāseti cāleti
translated: He is such a king, and he is a king who shines with the glory of kingship, and he terrifies and frightens his enemies, by ruling righteously and impartially.

original: “Indovā”ti idaṃ upamatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Yathā asure jetvā abhibhavitvā ṭhitakālato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: indovāti idam upamattham vuttam yathā asure jetvā abhibhavitvā ṭhita kālataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: “Indra-like” – this is the meaning of the simile. Just as Indra, after conquering and subduing the Asuras,

original: asurādhipoti saṅkhyaṃ gato indo attano sapattabhūte asure kampesi, tathā kampetīti.
analyzed: asura adhipaḥ iti saṅkhyam gataḥ indo sapatta bhūte asure kampesi tathā kampeti iti
translated: became known as the “Lord of the Asuras,” and shook the Asuras, his enemies, so he shakes them.

original: Evaṃ mahāsatto rañño dhammaṃ desetvā cattāropi kumāre pakkosāpetvā ovaditvā rañño
analyzed: evam mahāsattaḥ raññaḥ dhammam desetvā cattāro api kumāre pakkosāpetvā ovaditvā raññaḥ
translated: Thus the Great Being, having taught the king the Dhamma, summoned the four princes, instructed them, and revealed the king’s deed.

original: katakammaṃ pakāsetvā rājānaṃ khamāpetvā “mahārāja, ito paṭṭhāya atuletvā paribhedakānaṃ
analyzed: kata kammam pakāsetvā rājānam khamāpetvā mahā rāja itas paṭṭhāya a tuletvā paribhedakānam
translated: He asked the king for forgiveness, saying: “Great king, from now on, without thinking,

original: kathaṃ gahetvā mā evarūpaṃ sāhasikakammaṃ akāsi, tumhepi kumārā mā rañño dubbhitthā”ti
analyzed: katham gahetvā mā evarūpam sāhasika kammam akāsi tumhe api kumārāḥ mā raññaḥ dubbhittha ati
translated: without taking the words of those who cause dissension, do not do such rash deeds. You princes, do not offend the king.”

original: sabbesaṃ ovādaṃ adāsi. Atha naṃ rājā āha – “ahaṃ, bhante, tumhesu ca deviyā ca aparajjhanto
analyzed: sabbesam ovādam adāsi atha nam rājā āha aham bhante tumhesu ca deviyā ca aparajjhantaḥ
translated: He gave advice to all. Then the king said: “Venerable Sir, I have offended you and the queen,🔽and I have offended my sons, and I have offended my subjects. I have done many evil deeds.

original: ime nissāya etesaṃ kathaṃ gahetvā etaṃ pāpakammaṃ kariṃ, ime pañcapi māremī”ti. Na
analyzed: ime nissāya etesam katham gahetvā etam pāpa kammam kariṃ ime pañca api māremi iti na
translated: “I will kill them, too, and make an end of them.”

original: labbhā, mahārāja, evaṃ kātunti. Tena hi tesaṃ hatthapāde chedāpemīti. Idampi na labbhā
analyzed: labbhā mahā rāja evam kātun ti tena hi tesam hattha pāde chedāpemi iti idam pi na labbhā
translated: “That cannot be done, sire.” “Well then, I will have their hands and feet cut off.”

original: kātunti. Rājā “sādhu, bhante”ti sampaṭicchitvā te sabbasaṃharaṇe katvā pañcacūḷākaraṇagaddūlabandhanagomayāsiñcanehi
analyzed: rājā sādhu bhante iti sampaṭicchitvā te sabba saṃharaṇe katvā pañcacūḷākaraṇa gaddūla bandhana gomaya āsiñcanehi
translated: “That cannot be done, sire.” The king assented, and had them all seized and bound with fivefold cords, and then insulted and abused them with the vilest epithets, and banished them from the kingdom.

original: avamānetvā raṭṭhā pabbājesi. Bodhisatto tattha katipāhaṃ vasitvā “appamatto hohī”ti
analyzed: avamānetvā raṭṭhā pabbājesi bodhisatto tattha katipāham vasitvā appamattaḥ hohi iti
translated: The Bodhisatta remained there a few days, and then, admonishing the king to be diligent,

original: rājānaṃ ovaditvā himavantaṃyeva gantvā jhānābhiññā nibbattetvā yāvajīvaṃ brahmavihāre
analyzed: rājānam ovaditvā himavantam yā iva gantvā jhāna abhiññāḥ nibbattetvā yāvajīvam brahmavihāre
translated: returned to the Himalayas, and there attained the Attainments of Meditation and the Supernatural Faculties. And for the rest of his life he cultivated the Divine States,

original: bhāvetvā brahmalokūpago ahosi.
analyzed: bhāvetvā brahma loka upagaḥ ahosi
translated: and was finally reborn in the Brahma-world.

original: Satthā imaṃ desanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi tathāgato paññavāyeva
analyzed: satthā imam desanam āharitvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi tathāgato
translated: When the Teacher had finished this lesson, he said, “Monks, the Tathāgata was not only wise in this present life, but in a previous state of existence also he was wise.

original: parappavādappamaddanoyevā”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi “tadā pañca diṭṭhigatikā pūraṇakassapamakkhaligosālapakudhakaccānaajitakesakambalanigaṇṭhanāṭaputtā
analyzed: para pavāda ppamaddanoyā iva ati vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā pañca diṭṭhigatikā pūraṇa kassapa makkhali gosāla pakudha kaccāna ajitakesa kambala nigaṇṭha nāṭa puttā
translated: and the discussion of other doctrines was just a pretext.” Then he identified the Birth Story: “At that time the five heretical teachers were Pūraṇa Kassapa, Makkhali Gosāla, Pakudha Kaccāyana, Ajita Kesakambala, and Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta.

original: ahesuṃ, piṅgalasunakho ānando, mahābodhiparibbājako pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Mahābodhijātakavaṇṇanā tatiyā.
analyzed: ahesum piṅgalasunakhaḥ ānandaḥ mahābodhi paribbājakaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti  mahābodhijātakavaṇṇanā tatiyā
translated: and the rest were only concerned with the refutation of other doctrines.” So saying, he identified the Birth: “At that time the five heretical teachers were Pūraṇa Kassapa, Makkhali Gosāla, Ajita Kesakambala, Pakudha Kaccāyana, and Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta; the tawny-hued Sunakha was Ānanda; but I myself was the great Wanderer.”🔽The Mahābodhi Jātaka is ended.

original: Jātakuddānaṃ –🔽Saniḷīnikamavhayano paṭhamo, dutiyo pana saummadantivaro;🔽Tatiyo pana bodhisirīvhayano, kathitā pana tīṇi jinena subhāti.
analyzed: jātakuddānam  paṭhamaḥ dutiyaḥ pana saummadantivaro  kathitā pana tīṇi jinena
translated: Here ends the third chapter.

original: Paṇṇāsanipātavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṇṇāsa nipāta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Jātaka Commentary is finished.

original: 19. Saṭṭhinipāto
analyzed: saṭṭhi nipātaḥ
translated: The Sixty Birth-Stories

original: [529] 1. Soṇakajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Soṇa Birth-Story

original: Kassa sutvā sataṃ dammīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto nekkhammapāramiṃ ārabbha
analyzed: kassa sutvā satam dammi iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ nekkhamma pāramiṃ ārabbha
translated: “Having heard what, will I give a hundred?” The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, about the perfection of renunciation.

original: kathesi. Tadā hi bhagavā dhammasabhāyaṃ nekkhammapāramiṃ vaṇṇayantānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: kathesi tadā hi bhagavā dhammasabhāyam nekkhamma pāramim vaṇṇayantānam bhikkhūnam
translated: For the monks were extolling the perfection of renunciation,

original: majjhe nisīditvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi tathāgato mahābhinikkhamanaṃ nikkhantoyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: majjhe nisīditvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi tathāgataḥ mahā abhinikkhamanam nikkhantaḥ yeva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: and sitting down in the middle of the assembly, he said, “Monks, this is not the first time the Tathāgata has gone forth in great pomp; in a previous state of existence also he did so.” And with this he told a story of the past.

original: Atīte rājagahe magadharājā nāma rajjaṃ kāresi. Bodhisatto tassa aggamahesiyā kucchismiṃ
analyzed: atīte rājagahe magadharājā nāma rajjam kāresi bodhisatto tassa aggamahesiyā kucchismiṃ
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta came to life as his chief queen’s son,

original: nibbatti, nāmaggahaṇadivase cassa “arindamakumāro”ti nāmaṃ kariṃsu. Tassa jātadivaseyeva
analyzed: nibbatti nāma ggahaṇa divase cassa arindama kumāraḥ ti nāmam kariṃsu tassa jāta divaseya iva
translated: and on the day of his naming he was called Prince Arindama. On the day of his birth

original: purohitassapi putto jāyi, “soṇakakumāro”tissa nāmaṃ kariṃsu. Te ubhopi ekatova vaḍḍhitvā
analyzed: purohitassa api putto soṇaka kumāra ūtissa nāmam kariṃsu te ubho pi ekatas va
translated: the chaplain’s son was also born, and he was called Prince Soṇaka. The two boys grew up together,

original: vayappattā uttamarūpadharā rūpena nibbisesā hutvā takkasilaṃ gantvā uggahitasippā
analyzed: vaya pattāḥ uttama rūpa dharāḥ rūpena nibbisesāḥ hutvā takkasilam gantvā uggahita sippā
translated: and when they were old enough, being of noble presence, they went to Takkasilā, where they learned all the arts,

original: tato nikkhamitvā “sabbasamayasippañca desacārittañca jānissāmā”ti anupubbena cārikaṃ
analyzed: tatas nikkhamitvā sabba samaya sippam ca desa cārittañca jānissāma ati anupubbena cārikam
translated: and then left Takkasilā, saying, “We will learn all the rules of propriety and good conduct.” So they wandered about,🔽and at last they came to Benares, and stayed in the royal park. The next day they entered the city,

original: carantā bārāṇasiṃ patvā rājuyyāne vasitvā punadivase nagaraṃ pavisiṃsu. Taṃ divasañca
analyzed: carantā bārāṇasim patvā rājuyyāne vasitvā punar divase nagaram tam divasam ca
translated: and on that day

original: ekacce manussā “brāhmaṇavācanakaṃ karissāmā”ti pāyāsaṃ paṭiyādetvā āsanāni paññāpetvā
analyzed: ekacce manussāḥ brāhmaṇa vācanakam karissāma ati pāyāsam paṭiyādetvā āsanāni paññāpetvā
translated: Some people, thinking, “We will make a proclamation of the Brāhmaṇas,” prepared rice-milk, and prepared seats.

original: āgacchante te kumāre disvā gharaṃ pavesetvā paññattāsane nisīdāpesuṃ. Tattha bodhisattassa
analyzed: āgacchante te kumāre disvā gharam pavesetvā paññatta āsane nisīdāpesum tattha bodhisattassa

analyzed: tena vutta gāthāya pana ayam atthaḥ mahā rāja yam tvam sutvā ārocentassa satam dammi iti
translated: and

original: vadasi, tampi mameva dehi, yaṃ “disvā ārocentassa sahassaṃ dammī”ti vadasi, tampi
analyzed: vadasi tam pi mama eva dehi yam disvā ārocentassa sahassam dammi iti vadasi tam pi
translated: “You say, ‘If anyone can point out to me where he is, I will give him a thousand pieces of money.’ Give me that thousand pieces of money.

original: mayhameva dehi, ahaṃ te piyasahāyaṃ idāneva paccakkhatova “ayaṃ soṇako”ti ācikkhissanti.
analyzed: mayham eva dehi aham te piya sahāyam idānā iva paccakkhataḥ uva ayam soṇako ti ācikkhissanti
translated: I will point out to you your dear friend. I will point out to you right now, right before your eyes, that this is Soṇaka.”

original: Ito paraṃ suviññeyyā sambuddhagāthā pāḷinayeneva veditabbā –
analyzed: itas param su viññeyyā sambuddha gāthā pāḷi nayena iva veditabbā
translated: From here on, the verses of the Buddha can be understood by the method of the Pali text itself.

original: “Katamasmiṃ so janapade, raṭṭhesu nigamesu ca;
analyzed: katamasmin saḥ janapade raṭṭhesu nigamesu ca
translated: “In which country, in which state, in which town,

original: Kattha soṇakamaddakkhi, taṃ me akkhāhi pucchito.
analyzed: kattha soṇakam addakkhi tam me akkhāhi pucchitaḥ
translated: where did you see Soṇaka? Tell me that, when asked.”

original: “Taveva deva vijite, tavevuyyānabhūmiyaṃ;
analyzed: tava iva deva vijite
translated: “In your own kingdom, on your own pleasure ground,

original: Ujuvaṃsā mahāsālā, nīlobhāsā manoramā.
analyzed: uju vaṃsā mahā sālā nīla ubhāsā manoramā
translated: the great straight-stemmed trees, blue-shining, delightful.

original: “Tiṭṭhanti meghasamānā, rammā aññoññanissitā;
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti megha samānāḥ rammāḥ aññoñña nissitā
translated: “They stand like clouds, beautiful, supporting each other;

original: Tesaṃ mūlamhi soṇako, jhāyatī anupādano;
analyzed: tesam mūlamhi soṇakaḥ jhāyati anupādanaḥ
translated: at the foot of those trees, Soṇaka

analyzed: upādānesu lokesu ḍayhamānesu nibbutaḥ
translated: meditates, without clinging, while the world, with its clinging, burns.

analyzed: ca rājā senāya caturaṅgiyā  kārāpetvā samam maggam agamā yena soṇako
translated: “Then the king went out with his fourfold army;🔽having had a level road made, he went to where Soṇaka was.

original: “Uyyānabhūmiṃ gantvāna, vicaranto brahāvane;
analyzed: uyyāna bhūmim gantvāna vicarantaḥ brahā vane
translated: Having gone to the pleasure ground, wandering in the great forest,

original: Āsīnaṃ soṇakaṃ dakkhi, ḍayhamānesu nibbuta”nti.
analyzed: āsīnam soṇakam dakkhi ḍayhamānesu nibbutanti
translated: Extinguished, while the world burns.”

original: Tattha ujuvaṃsāti ujukkhandhā. Mahāsālāti mahārukkhā. Meghasamānāti nīlameghasadisā.
analyzed: tattha uju vaṃsā ati uju khandhā mahāsālā ati mahā rukkhā megha samānā ati nīla megha sadisā
translated: Herein, straight-trunked means having straight trunks. Great trees means big trees. Like rainclouds means like dark rainclouds.

analyzed: rammā ati ramaṇīyā aññoñña nissitā ati sākhāhi sākham mūlena mūlam saṃsibbitvā ṭhitā
translated: Delightful means lovely. Supporting each other means standing supporting each other’s branches, roots, and so on.

original: Tesanti tesaṃ evarūpānaṃ tava uyyānavane sālānaṃ heṭṭhā. Jhāyatīti lakkhaṇūpanijjhānaārammaṇūpanijjhānasaṅkhātehi
analyzed: tesanti tesam evarūpānam tava uyyāna vane sālānam heṭṭhā jhāyati iti lakkhaṇa upanijjhāna ārammaṇa upanijjhāna saṅkhātehi
translated: Under such trees as these means under such trees as these in your park. He meditates means he meditates with the meditation called “contemplation of characteristics” and the meditation called “contemplation of object.”

original: jhānehi jhāyati. Anupādanoti kāmupādānādivirahito. Ḍayhamānesūti ekādasahi aggīhi🔽ḍayhamānesu sattesu. Nibbutoti te aggī nibbāpetvā sītalena hadayena jhāyamāno tava
analyzed: jhānehi jhāyati kāma upādāna ādi virahitaḥ ḍayhamāneṣu iti ekādasahi aggīhi  ḍayhamānesu sattesu nibbutaḥ ti te aggī nibbāpetvā sītalena hadayena jhāyamānaḥ tava
translated: Free from grasping means free from the grasping of sensual desire, etc. While the world burns means while beings burn with the eleven fires.🔽Extinguished means he sits on a slab at the foot of a lucky sal-tree in your park, extinguished, with a cool heart, after extinguishing those fires.

original: uyyāne maṅgalasālarukkhamūle silāpaṭṭe nisinno esa te sahāyo kañcanapaṭimā viya sobhamāno
analyzed: uyyāne maṅgala sāla rukkha mūle silā paṭṭe nisinno esa te sahāyaḥ kañcana paṭimā viya sobhamāno
translated: This friend of yours shines like a golden image🔽and is waiting for you.”

original: paṭimānetīti. Tato cāti, bhikkhave, tato so arindamo rājā tassa vacanaṃ sutvāva “soṇakapaccekabuddhaṃ
analyzed: paṭimāneti iti tato ca ati bhikkhave tatas saḥ arindamaḥ rājā tassa vacanam sutvā va soṇaka paccekabuddham
translated: Then, bhikkhus, after listening to his words, King Arindama said:

original: passissāmī”ti caturaṅginiyā senāya pāyāsi nikkhami. Vicarantoti ujukameva agantvā
analyzed: passissāmi iti caturaṅginiyā senāya pāyāsi nikkhami vicarantaḥ iti ujukam eva a gantvā
translated: I will see him.” And he set out with his fourfold army.

original: tasmiṃ mahante vanasaṇḍe vicaranto tassa santikaṃ gantvā taṃ āsīnaṃ addakkhi.
analyzed: tasmin mahante vana saṇḍe vicarantaḥ tassa santikam gantvā tam āsīnam addakkhi
translated: As he was wandering about, he went to the place where the Elder was and saw him sitting there.

original: So taṃ avanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīditvā attano kilesābhiratattā taṃ “kapaṇo”ti maññamāno imaṃ gāthamāha –

translated: Without paying homage to him, he sat down to one side and, thinking that the Elder was a wretched man because of his own delight in the defilements, he uttered this verse:

analyzed: kapaṇaḥ vatayam bhikkhu muṇḍaḥ saṅghāṭi pārutaḥ
translated: “Wretched indeed is this monk, shaven-headed, wearing the outer robe,

analyzed: amātikaḥ apitikaḥ rukkha mūlasmi jhāyati iti
translated: Without wife, without child, he meditates at the foot of a tree.”

original: Tattha jhāyatīti nimmātiko nippitiko kāruññappatto jhāyati.
analyzed: tattha jhāyati iti nimmātikaḥ nippitikaḥ kāruñña ppatto jhāyati
translated: Here “he meditates” means that he is without wife, without child, and has attained compassion.

original: “Imaṃ vākyaṃ nisāmetvā, soṇako etadabravi;
analyzed: imam vākyam soṇakaḥ etat abravi
translated: Having listened to this statement, Soṇaka said this:

analyzed: na rāja kapaṇaḥ hoti dhammam kāyena phassayaṃ
translated: “O King, one is not wretched because of that; one should experience the Dhamma with the body.

original: “Yo ca dhammaṃ niraṃkatvā, adhammamanuvattati;
analyzed: yaḥ ca dhammam niraṃkatvā adhammam anuvattati
translated: “One who, having rejected the Dhamma, follows the non-Dhamma,

analyzed: sa rāja kapaṇaḥ hoti pāpaḥ pāpa parāyaṇaḥ iti
translated: O King, he is wretched, evil, and given to evil.”

original: Tattha imanti tassa kilesābhiratassa pabbajjaṃ arocentassa imaṃ pabbajjāgarahavacanaṃ
analyzed: tattha iman ti tassa kilesa abhiratassa pabbajjam a rocentassa imam pabbajja agaraha vacanam
translated: Here “this” refers to the statement about the worthiness of the going forth of one who delights in the defilements and invites him to go forth.

original: sutvā. Etadabravīti pabbajjāya guṇaṃ pakāsento etaṃ abravi. Phassayanti phassayanto
analyzed: sutvā etat abravīti pabbajjāya guṇam pakāsentaḥ etam abravi phassayanti phassayantaḥ
translated: Having heard, he said this: showing the virtue of going forth, he said this. Having touched: having touched

analyzed: niraṃkatvā ati atta bhāvataḥ nīharitvā sayam pāpānam karaṇena
translated: Having removed: having taken out from his own person. Evil, given to evil: himself being evil by doing evil,

analyzed: aññesam pi karontānam patiṭṭhā bhāvena pāpa parāyaṇaḥ ti

original: Evaṃ so bodhisattaṃ garahi. So attano garahitabhāvaṃ ajānanto viya hutvā nāmagottaṃ kathetvā tena saddhiṃ paṭisanthāraṃ karonto gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam saḥ bodhisattam garahi saḥ attanaḥ garahita bhāvam a jānantaḥ viya hutvā nāma gottam kathetvā tena saddhim paṭisanthāram karontaḥ gātham āha

translated: “The monk who is a true Bhadra, who is not a householder,

analyzed: catuttham pi bhadram adhanassa anāgārassa bhikkhuno
translated: “The monk who is a true Bhadra, who is not a householder,

analyzed: muttassa raṭṭhe carataḥ saṅgaḥ yassa na vijjati
translated: Who wanders from state to state, has no attachment whatever.

analyzed: pañcamam pi bhadram adhanassa anāgārassa bhikkhuno
translated: “The monk who is a true Bhadra, who is not a householder,

translated: When the city is burning, has nothing that is burned.

analyzed: chaṭṭham pi bhadram adhanassa anāgārassa bhikkhuno
translated: “For the sixth time, too, the good fortune of the penniless monk who has gone forth,

translated: While the country is being plundered, he has no fear of anything.

original: “Sattamampi bhadramadhanassa, anāgārassa bhikkhuno;
analyzed: sattamam pi bhadram adhanassa anāgārassa bhikkhuno
translated: “For the seventh time, too, the good fortune of the penniless monk who has gone forth,

original: Corehi rakkhitaṃ maggaṃ, ye caññe paripanthikā;
analyzed: corehi rakkhitam maggam ye caññe paripanthikā
translated: The path guarded by thieves and other highwaymen,

original: Pattacīvaramādāya, sotthiṃ gacchati subbato.
analyzed: patta cīvaram ādāya sotthim gacchati subbataḥ
translated: Taking his bowl and robe, he goes in safety, well-supported.

original: “Aṭṭhamampi bhadramadhanassa, anāgārassa bhikkhuno;
analyzed: aṭṭhamam pi bhadram adhanassa anāgārassa bhikkhuno
translated: “For the eighth time, too, the good fortune of the penniless monk who has gone forth,

analyzed: yam yam disam pakkamati anapekkhaḥ uva gacchati iti
translated: Wherever he goes, he goes without concern.”

analyzed: akiñcanassa bhikkhuno sabbakālam bhadram eva na tesanti mahā rāja tesam adhanānam
translated: who has nothing, whose good fortune is always good. “They don’t” means, great king, that for those penniless monks

analyzed: bhikkhūnam na koṭṭhāgāre dhana dhaññāni openti na kumbhiyam na pacchiyam te pana
translated: grain and wealth are not stored in granaries, in jars, or in baskets, but

analyzed: subbatā para niṭṭhitam paresam ghare pakkam āhāram saṅghāṭim pārupitvā kapālam ādāya
translated: those who are well-supported, having put on their outer robes, taking their bowls,

analyzed: pāṭikulyānam vasena paccavekkhitvā paribhuñjitvā jīvita vuttim yāpenti  anavajja piṇḍaḥ bhottabbaḥ ti vejja kamma ādikāya an esanāya vā kuhanā lapanā nemittika tā  nippesika tā lābhena lābham nijigīsana tā ati evarūpena micchājīvena vā uppāditā cattāro
translated: after reflecting on it as repulsive in nine aspects.🔽The blameless alms food to be eaten: the four requisites produced by wrong livelihood such as medical practice, by scheming, hypocrisy, hinting, belittling, pursuing gain with gain,

original: paccayā, dhammena uppāditāpi apaccavekkhitvā paribhuttā sāvajjapiṇḍo nāma. Anesanaṃ🔽pana pahāya micchājīvaṃ vajjetvā dhammena samena uppāditā “paṭisaṅkhā yoniso cīvaraṃ
analyzed: paccayā dhammena uppāditā api a paccavekkhitvā paribhuttā sāvajjapiṇḍaḥ nāma anesanam  pana pahāya micchājīvam vajjetvā dhammena samena uppāditā paṭisaṅkhā yonisas cīvaram
translated: are called “blameworthy alms food.” The four requisites produced by right livelihood but eaten without reflection are also called “blameworthy alms food.”🔽But when a bhikkhu abandons scheming for gains, avoids wrong livelihood, and produces the requisites by right means, and then eats them after reflecting in the way described as “I use the robe after reviewing it,”

original: paṭisevāmī”ti vuttanayeneva paccavekkhitvā paribhuttā anavajjapiṇḍo nāma. Yena evarūpo
analyzed: paṭisevāmi iti vutta nayena iva paccavekkhitvā paribhuttā anavajja piṇḍaḥ nāma yena evarūpaḥ
translated: that is called “blameless alms food.”

original: anavajjapiṇḍo bhottabbo paribhuñjitabbo, yañca evarūpaṃ anavajjaṃ piṇḍaṃ bhuñjamānānaṃ
analyzed: anavajja piṇḍaḥ bhottabbaḥ paribhuñjitabbaḥ yat ca evarūpam anavajjam piṇḍam bhuñjamānānam
translated: The blameless alms food to be eaten is to be eaten by one who eats it after reviewing it in this way. And when bhikkhus are eating such blameless alms food,

analyzed: paccaye nissāya koci appamattakaḥ api kilesaḥ na uparodhati na pīḍeti tassa dutiyam pi
translated: No defilement, however slight, oppresses or torments him, depending on conditions.

original: bhadraṃ adhanassa anāgārassa bhikkhuno.🔽Nibbutoti puthujjanabhikkhuno dhammena uppannapiṇḍopi paccavekkhitvā paribhuñjiyamāno
analyzed: bhadram adhanassa anāgārassa bhikkhuno  nibbutaḥ ti puthujjana bhikkhuno dhammena uppanna piṇḍaḥ api paccavekkhitvā paribhuñjiyamāno
translated: This is the second blessing for a poor, penniless bhikkhu.

original: nibbutapiṇḍo nāma, ekantato pana khīṇāsavassa piṇḍova nibbutapiṇḍo nāma. Kiṃkāraṇā?
analyzed: nibbuta piṇḍaḥ nāma ekantato pana khīṇāsavassa piṇḍaḥ uva nibbuta piṇḍaḥ nāma kiṃkāraṇā
translated: “Nibbāna-food”: when a bhikkhu of the worldling class eats alms food that has arisen lawfully, it is called “nibbāna-food.” But the alms food of one whose cankers are destroyed is called “nibbāna-food” in the absolute sense. Why?

original: So hi theyyaparibhogo, iṇaparibhogo, dāyajjaparibhogo, sāmiparibhogoti imesu catūsu
analyzed: saḥ hi theyya paribhogaḥ iṇa paribhogaḥ dāyajja paribhogo sāmi paribhogaḥ iti imesu catūsu
translated: Because he eats it as one who is master, among the four kinds of consumers.

original: paribhogesu sāmiparibhogavasena taṃ bhuñjati, taṇhādāsabyaṃ atīto sāmī hutvā paribhuñjati,
analyzed: paribhogesu sāmi paribhoga vasena tam bhuñjati taṇhā dāsabyam sāmī hutvā paribhuñjati
translated: He eats it as one who is master, having gone beyond the slavery of craving.

original: na taṃ tappaccayā koci appamattakopi kileso uparodhati.🔽Muttassa raṭṭhe caratoti upaṭṭhākakulādīsu alaggamānasassa chinnavalāhakassa viya
analyzed: na tam tad paccayā koci appamattakaḥ api kilesaḥ uparodhati  muttassa raṭṭhe carato ti upaṭṭhāka kula ādīsu alagga mānasassa chinna valāhakassa viya
translated: No defilement, however slight, oppresses him on that account.🔽“Free, wandering in the realm”: he who is not attached to families that give him service, etc., like a cloud that has been dispersed by the wind,

original: rāhumukhā pamuttassa vimalacandamaṇḍalassa viya ca yassa gāmanigamādīsu carantassa
analyzed: rāhu mukhā ca yassa gāma nigama ādīsu carantassa
translated: and who wanders from village to village, town to town,

original: rāgasaṅgādīsu ekopi saṅgo natthi. Ekacco hi kulehi saṃsaṭṭho viharati sahasokī sahanandī,
analyzed: rāga saṅga ādīsu ekaḥ api saṅgaḥ na atthi ekaccaḥ hi kulehi saṃsaṭṭhaḥ viharati saha sokī saha nandī
translated: For one person lives in close association with families, sharing their grief and joy,

original: ekacco mātāpitūsupi alaggamānaso vicarati korunagaragāmavāsī daharo viya, evarūpassa
analyzed: ekaccaḥ a lagga mānasaḥ vicarati koru nagara gāma vāsī daharaḥ evarūpassa
translated: while another goes about his business with his mind unattached even to his parents, like the young man who lived in a village of weavers.

original: puthujjanassapi bhadrameva.🔽Nāssa kiñcīti yo hi bahuparikkhāro hoti, so “mā me corā parikkhāre hariṃsū”ti atirekāni🔽ca cīvarādīni antonagare upaṭṭhākakule nikkhipati, atha nagaramhi ḍayhamāne “asukakule
analyzed: puthujjanaḥ sa pi bhadram eva  na assa kiñci iti yaḥ hi bahu parikkhāraḥ hoti saḥ mā me corā parikkhāre hariṃsu iti atirekāni  ca cīvara ādīni antonagare upaṭṭhāka kule nikkhipati atha nagaramhi ḍayhamāne asuka kule
translated: Such a person is good, even though he be an ordinary man.🔽He has nothing that can be burned. One who has many requisites thinks, “Let not thieves carry off my requisites,” and he stores extra robes, etc., in a house belonging to a family in the village.🔽Then when the village is burning, he is distressed and worried, thinking, “A fire has broken out in the house of the family where I have stored my requisites.

original: nāma aggi uṭṭhito”ti sutvā socati kilamati, evarūpassa bhadraṃ nāma natthi. Yo pana,
analyzed: nāma aggi uṭṭhitaḥ iti sutvā socati kilamati evarūpassa bhadram nāma natthi yaḥ pana
translated: ” Such a person is not good. But one who,

original: mahārāja, sakuṇavattaṃ pūreti, kāyapaṭibaddhaparikkhārova hoti, tassa tādisassa na
analyzed: mahā rāja sakuṇavattam pūreti kāya paṭibaddha parikkhāraḥ uva hoti tassa tādisassa na
translated: great king, fulfills the duties of a bird, who has only the requisites that he carries with him, has nothing that can be burned.

original: kiñci aḍayhatha, tenassa pañcamampi bhadrameva.
analyzed: kiñci tenassa pañcamam pi bhadram eva
translated: Therefore he is good in the fifth way too.

original: Vilumpamānamhīti viluppamānamhi, ayameva vā pāṭho. Ahīrathāti yathā pabbatagahanādīhi
analyzed: vilumpamānamhi iti viluppamānamhi ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ yathā pabbata gahana ādīhi
translated: While being plundered: the reading is doubtful.

original: nikkhamitvā raṭṭhaṃ vilumpamānesu coresu bahuparikkhārassa antogāme ṭhapitaṃ vilumpati
analyzed: nikkhamitvā raṭṭham vilumpamānesu coresu bahu parikkhārassa antogāme ṭhapitam vilumpati
translated: When thieves come out and plunder the country, he plunders what is stored in the village,

original: harati, tathā yassa adhanassa kāyapaṭibaddhaparikkhārassa na kiñci ahīratha tassa
analyzed: harati tathā yassa adhanassa kāya paṭibaddha parikkhārassa na kiñci tassa
translated: and he takes what is stored in the house of a poor man who has nothing else to lose.

original: chaṭṭhampi bhadrameva.
analyzed: bhadram eva
translated: The sixth is also good.

original: Ye caññe paripanthikāti ye ca aññepi tesu tesu ṭhānesu suṅkagahaṇatthāya ṭhapitā🔽paripanthikā, tehi ca rakkhitaṃ. Pattacīvaranti corānaṃ anupakāraṃ suṅkikānaṃ asuṅkārahaṃ🔽mattikāpattañceva katadaḷhīkammaparibhaṇḍaṃ paṃsukūlacīvarañca appagghāni kāyabandhanaparissāvanasūcivāsipattatthavikāni
analyzed: ye ca aññe ye ca aññe pi tesu tesu ṭhānesu suṅka gahaṇa tthāya ṭhapitā  paripanthikā tehi ca rakkhitam patta cīvaranti corānam anupakāram suṅkikānam a suṅkāraham  mattikā pattam ca iva kata daḷhīkamma paribhaṇḍam paṃsukūla cīvarañca appagghāni kāya bandhana parissāvana sūci vāsi patta thavikāni
translated: And other robbers: those who are placed here and there to seize travelers’ goods,🔽and what is guarded by them. The bowl and robes: the bowl is not useful to thieves, and the robes are not worth carrying off by robbers.

original: cāti sabbepi aṭṭha parikkhāre kāyapaṭibaddhe katvā maggappaṭipanno kenaci aviheṭhiyamāno
analyzed: ca ati sabbe pi aṭṭha parikkhāre kāya paṭibaddhe katvā magga ppaṭipanno kenaci a viheṭhiyamāno
translated: The bowl is a clay bowl, and the robes are a set of three rag-robes. The eight requisites are of little value, and they are bound to the body. He goes along the road unmolested by anyone,

original: sotthiṃ gacchati. Subbatoti lobhanīyāni hi cīvarādīni disvā corā haranti, suṅkikāpi
analyzed: sotthim gacchati subbato ti lobhanīyāni hi cīvara ādīni disvā corāḥ haranti
translated: and he goes in safety. The one who is virtuous: thieves and robbers carry off what is attractive, such as robes, etc.,

original: “kiṃ nu kho etassa hatthe”ti pattatthavikādīni sodhenti, subbato pana sallahukavutti
analyzed: kim nu kho etassa hatthe ti patta tthavika ādīni sodhenti subbataḥ pana
translated: “What has he got in his hand?” They searched his bowl, his water-strainer, etc.,

original: tesaṃ passantānaññeva sotthiṃ gacchati, tenassa sattamampi bhadrameva.
analyzed: tesam passantānam na eva sotthim gacchati tena assa sattamam pi bhadram eva
translated: but the alms-food was safe. The king was easy-going, and so the alms-food was safe even while they were looking at it. That was the seventh good fortune.

original: Anapekkhova gacchatīti kāyapaṭibaddhato atirekassa vihāre paṭisāmitassa kassaci parikkhārassa🔽abhāvā vasanaṭṭhānaṃ nivattitvāpi na oloketi. Yaṃ yaṃ disaṃ gantukāmo hoti, taṃ taṃ
analyzed: anapekkhaḥ uva gacchati iti kāya paṭibaddhataḥ atirekassa vihāre paṭisāmitassa kassaci parikkhārassa  abhāvā vasana ṭṭhānam nivattitvā api na oloketi yam yam disam gantu kāmo hoti tam tam
translated: He went away without looking back: because he had no extra requisites, such as a dwelling, to which he was attached,

original: gacchanto anapekkhova gacchati anurādhapurā nikkhamitvā thūpārāme pabbajitānaṃ dvinnaṃ🔽kulaputtānaṃ vuḍḍhataro viya.🔽Iti soṇakapaccekabuddho aṭṭha samaṇabhadrakāni kathesi. Tato uttariṃ pana satampi
analyzed: gacchantaḥ anapekkhaḥ uva gacchati anurādha purā nikkhamitvā thūpa ārāme pabbajitānam dvinnam  kula puttānam vuḍḍhataraḥ viya  iti soṇaka paccekabuddhaḥ aṭṭha samaṇa bhadrakāni kathesi tatas uttarim pana satam pi
translated: he did not turn his head to look at his dwelling even when he had left it. He went away without looking back, just as the two clansmen who went forth in the Thūpārāma did when they left Anurādhapura.

original: sahassampi aparimāṇāni samaṇabhadrakāni esa kathetuṃ samatthoyeva. Rājā pana kāmābhiratattā
analyzed: sahassam pi aparimāṇāni samaṇa bhadrakāni esa kathetum samatthaḥ yā iva rājā pana
translated: So the Private Buddha Soṇa told of eight good fortunes of an ascetic. But he could have told of a thousand, a hundred thousand, indeed of countless good fortunes of an ascetic. But the king was devoted to sensual pleasures,🔽and so he did not understand the good fortunes of an ascetic.

original: tassa kathaṃ pacchinditvā “mayhaṃ samaṇabhadrakehi attho natthī”ti attano kāmādhimuttataṃ pakāsento āha –
analyzed: tassa katham pacchinditvā mayham samaṇa bhadrakehi atthaḥ natthi iti attanaḥ kāma adhimutta tam pakāsentaḥ āha
translated: After breaking in upon his talk, he declared his own infatuation for sensual desires, saying:🔽“The many good recluses,

original: “Bahūni samaṇabhadrāni, ye tvaṃ bhikkhu pasaṃsasi;
analyzed: bahūni samaṇa bhadrāni ye tvam bhikkhu pasaṃsasi
translated: You praise, O monk, but I am greedy for sensual desires,

original: Ahañca giddho kāmesu, kathaṃ kāhāmi soṇaka.
analyzed: aham ca giddhaḥ kāmesu katham soṇaka
translated: What shall I do, O Son of the Sakyans?🔽“I love human sensual desires,

original: “Piyā me mānusā kāmā, atho dibyāpi me piyā;
analyzed: piyāḥ me mānusāḥ kāmāḥ atha u dibyā api me piyā
translated: And also the sensual desires of the gods,🔽But by what means shall we both

original: Atha kena nu vaṇṇena, ubho loke labhāmase”ti.
analyzed: atha kena nu vaṇṇena ubhau loke labhāmasa iti
translated: Obtain the two worlds?”

original: Tattha vaṇṇenāti kāraṇena.
analyzed: tattha vaṇṇena ati kāraṇena
translated: Herein, by what means means by what reason.

original: Atha naṃ paccekabuddho āha –
analyzed: atha nam paccekabuddhaḥ āha
translated: Then the Private Buddha said:

original: “Kāme giddhā kāmaratā, kāmesu adhimuccitā;
analyzed: kāme giddhā kāma ratā kāmesu adhimuccitā
translated: “Those who are greedy for sensual desires, who delight in sensual desires,🔽Who are infatuated with sensual desires,🔽Men who have done evil deeds,

original: Narā pāpāni katvāna, upapajjanti duggatiṃ.
analyzed: narā pāpāni katvānaḥ upapajjanti duggatim
translated: Are reborn in an evil state.🔽“But those who have given up sensual desires,

original: “Ye ca kāme pahantvāna, nikkhantā akutobhayā;
analyzed: ye ca kāme pahantvāna nikkhantāḥ akutobhayā
translated: Who have gone forth, free from fear,🔽Who have attained to one-pointedness of mind,

original: Ekodibhāvādhigatā, na te gacchanti duggatiṃ.
analyzed: ekodi bhāva adhigatāḥ na te gacchanti duggatim
translated: Do not go to an evil state.🔽“I will make a simile for you,

original: “Upamaṃ te karissāmi, taṃ suṇohi arindama;
analyzed: upamam te karissāmi tam suṇohi arindama
translated: Listen to it, O subduer of foes;

original: Upamāya midhekacce, atthaṃ jānanti paṇḍitā.
analyzed: upamāya midhā ekacce attham jānanti paṇḍitā
translated: By means of a simile some wise men understand the meaning.🔽“Seeing a corpse in the Ganges,

original: “Gaṅgāya kuṇapaṃ disvā, vuyhamānaṃ mahaṇṇave;
analyzed: gaṅgāya kuṇapam disvā vuyhamānam mahaṇṇave
translated: Being carried along in the great ocean,🔽The bird thought: ‘It is light,’

original: Vāyaso samacintesi, appapañño acetaso.
analyzed: vāyasaḥ samacintesi appapaññaḥ acetasaḥ
translated: Being without wisdom and without thought.

original: “Yānañca vatidaṃ laddhaṃ, bhakkho cāyaṃ anappako;
analyzed: yānam ca vatidam laddham bhakkho ca ayam anappako
translated: “You have obtained a vehicle, and this food is not small;

original: Tattha rattiṃ tattha divā, tattheva nirato mano.
analyzed: tattha rattim tattha divā tattha iva nirataḥ mano
translated: There at night, there by day, the mind is attached just there.

original: “Khādaṃ nāgassa maṃsāni, pivaṃ bhāgīrathodakaṃ;
analyzed: khādam nāgassa maṃsāni pivam bhāgīratha udakam
translated: “Eat the elephant’s flesh, drink the water of the Ganges;

original: Sampassaṃ vanacetyāni, na palettha vihaṅgamo.
analyzed: sampassam vana cetyāni na palettha vihaṅgamaḥ
translated: Seeing the forest trees, you will not fly away.

original: “Tañca otaraṇī gaṅgā, pamattaṃ kuṇape rataṃ;
analyzed: tat ca otaraṇī gaṅgā pamattam kuṇape ratam
translated: “And the Ganges is fordable, the careless one is attached to the corpse;

original: Samuddaṃ ajjhagāhāsi, agatī yattha pakkhinaṃ.
analyzed: samuddam ajjhagāhāsi agatī yattha pakkhinam
translated: It has entered the ocean, where there is no way for a bird.

original: “So ca bhakkhaparikkhīṇo, udapatvā vihaṅgamo;
analyzed: so ca bhakkha parikkhīṇaḥ uda patvā vihaṅgamaḥ
translated: “And he, having eaten the food, having drunk water, the bird;

original: Na pacchato na purato, nuttaraṃ nopi dakkhiṇaṃ.
analyzed: na pacchatas na puratas na uttaram na upi dakkhiṇam
translated: Not behind, not in front, not to the north, nor to the south.

original: “Dīpaṃ so najjhagāgañchi, agatī yattha pakkhinaṃ;
analyzed: dīpam saḥ agatī yattha pakkhinam
translated: “And he did not reach the island, where there is no way for a bird;

original: So ca tattheva pāpattha, yathā dubbalako tathā.
analyzed: saḥ ca tattha iva yathā dubbalakaḥ tathā
translated: And he fell down just there, as weak as he was.

original: “Tañca sāmuddikā macchā, kumbhīlā makarā susū;
analyzed: tat ca sāmuddikāḥ macchāḥ kumbhīlāḥ makarāḥ
translated: “And the sea-fish, the porpoises, the sharks, the stingrays;

original: Pasayhakārā khādiṃsu, phandamānaṃ vipakkhakaṃ.
analyzed: pasayhakārā khādiṃsu phandamānam vipakkhakam
translated: The saw-fish ate him, trembling, with his wings broken.

original: “Evameva tuvaṃ rāja, ye caññe kāmabhogino;
analyzed: evam eva tuvam rāja ye caññe kāma bhogino
translated: “Even so, you, King, and others who enjoy sensual pleasures;

original: Giddhā ce na vamissanti, kākapaññāva te vidū.
analyzed: giddhā ce na vamissanti kākapaññā ava te vidū
translated: If the greedy ones do not vomit, they are wise like the crow.

original: “Esā te upamā rāja, atthasandassanī katā;
analyzed: esā te upamā rāja attha sandassanī katā
translated: “This is the simile, O king, that I have made for you,

original: Tvañca paññāyase tena, yadi kāhasi vā na vā”ti.
analyzed: tvañca paññāyase tena yadi vā na vāti
translated: And by it you may know whether you will do or not.”

original: Tattha pāpānīti, mahārāja, tvaṃ kāmagiddho, narā ca kāme nissāya kāyaduccaritādīni
analyzed: tattha pāpāni iti mahā rāja tvam kāma giddhaḥ narā ca kāme nissāya kāya duccarita ādīni
translated: Herein, “Evil” means that you, O king, are infatuated with sensual desires, and men, having done evil deeds, such as bodily misconduct, etc.,🔽through their dependence on sensual desires, are reborn in an unhappy destiny,

original: pāpāni katvā yattha supinantepi dibbā ca mānusikā ca kāmā na labbhanti, taṃ duggatiṃ
analyzed: pāpāni katvā dibbāḥ ca mānusikā ca kāmāḥ na labbhanti tam duggatim
translated: where even in dreams celestial and human sensual desires are not to be had.

original: upapajjantīti attho. Pahantvānāti kheḷapiṇḍaṃ viya pahāya. Akutobhayāti rāgādīsu
analyzed: upapajjanti iti rāga ādīsu
translated: “Having abandoned” means having abandoned as if it were a lump of spittle. “Fearless from anywhere” means fearless from any of the fears of lust, etc.

original: kutoci anāgatabhayā. Ekodibhāvādhigatāti ekodibhāvaṃ ekavihārikataṃ adhigatā. Na
analyzed: anāgata bhayā eka udi bhāva adhigatā ati eka udi bhāvam adhigatā na
translated: “Having attained to singleness of intent” means having attained to singleness of mind, to living alone.

original: teti te evarūpā pabbajitā duggatiṃ na gacchanti.🔽Upamaṃ teti, mahārāja, dibbamānusake kāme patthentassa hatthikuṇape paṭibaddhakākasadisassa
analyzed: te iti te evarūpāḥ pabbajitāḥ duggatim na gacchanti  upamam te iti mahā rāja dibba mānusake kāme patthentassa hatthi kuṇape paṭibaddha kāka sadisassa
translated: “They do not go” means that such monks do not go to an unhappy destiny.🔽“A simile for you” means that I will make a simile for you who are like a crow tied to a skeleton of an elephant, who are longing for celestial and human sensual desires.

original: tava ekaṃ upamaṃ karissāmi, taṃ suṇohīti attho. Kuṇapanti hatthikaḷevaraṃ. Mahaṇṇaveti
analyzed: tava ekam upamam karissāmi tam suṇohi iti kuṇapanti hatthi kaḷevaram
translated: Listen to it. “Skeleton” means the skeleton of an elephant. “In the ocean” means in the great ocean.

original: gambhīraputhule udake. Eko kira mahāvāraṇo gaṅgātīre caranto gaṅgāyaṃ patitvā uttarituṃ
analyzed: gambhīra puthule udake ekaḥ kira mahā vāraṇaḥ gaṅgā tīre carantaḥ gaṅgā ayam patitvā uttaritum
translated: In the deep and wide water. It seems that a great tusker, wandering on the bank of the Ganges, fell into the Ganges and,

original: asakkento tattheva mato gaṅgāya vuyhi, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Vāyasoti ākāsena gacchanto
analyzed: a sakkentaḥ tattha iva mataḥ gaṅgāya vuyhi tam sandhāya itam vuttam vāyaso ti ākāsena gacchantaḥ
translated: being unable to get out, died there and was carried away by the Ganges. This is what is meant. “A bird” means a crow flying through the air.

original: eko kāko. Yānañca vatidanti so evaṃ cintetvā tattha nilīyitvā “idaṃ mayā hatthiyānaṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ kākaḥ yānam ca vatidanti saḥ evam cintetvā tattha nilīyitvā idam mayā hatthi yānam
translated: “And a vehicle” means that after thinking thus, he settled there, thinking, “This elephant vehicle has been obtained by me.

original: laddhaṃ, ettha nilīno sukhaṃ carissāmi, ayameva ca me anappako bhakkho bhavissati,
analyzed: laddham ettha nilīnaḥ sukham carissāmi ayam eva ca me anappakaḥ bhakkhaḥ bhavissati
translated: Sitting here, I will move about happily. This alone will be my abundant food.

original: idāni mayā aññattha gantuṃ na vaṭṭatī”ti sanniṭṭhānamakāsi. Tattha rattinti tattha
analyzed: idāni mayā aññattha gantum na vaṭṭati iti sanniṭṭhānam akāsi tattha tattha
translated: Now it is not proper for me to go elsewhere.” He made up his mind thus. There

original: rattiñca divā ca tattheva mano abhirato ahosi. Na paletthāti na uppatitvā pakkāmi.🔽Otaraṇīti samuddābhimukhī otaramānā. “Ohāriṇī”tipi pāṭho, sā samuddābhimukhī avahāriṇīti
analyzed: rattiñca divā ca tattha iva manaḥ abhirataḥ ahosi na palettha ati na uppatitvā pakkāmi  samudda abhimukhī otaramānā ohāriṇī iti pi sā samudda abhimukhī avahāriṇī iti
translated: he was delighted in mind, day and night, right there. “He did not fly away” means he did not fly up and leave.🔽“A river” means a river flowing towards the ocean. “A descending river” means a river flowing towards the ocean. The reading is also “a descending river.” The meaning is a river flowing towards the ocean.

original: attho. Agatī yatthāti samuddamajjhaṃ sandhāyāha. Bhakkhaparikkhīṇoti parikkhīṇabhakkho.
analyzed: atthaḥ agatī yattha iti samudda majjham sandhāya āha bhakkha parikkhīṇaḥ ti parikkhīṇa bhakkhaḥ
translated: “A place to go” means the middle of the ocean. “When the food is exhausted” means when the food is finished.

original: Udapatvāti khīṇe camme ca maṃse ca aṭṭhisaṅghāto ūmivegena bhinno udake nimujji.
analyzed: uda patvā ati khīṇe camme ca maṃse ca aṭṭhi saṅghātaḥ ūmi vegena bhinnaḥ udake
translated: Without reaching the end: when the skin and flesh were exhausted, the skeleton was broken by the force of the water and sank.

original: Atha so kāko udake patiṭṭhātuṃ asakkonto uppati, evaṃ uppatitvāti attho. Agatī yattha
analyzed: atha saḥ kākaḥ udake patiṭṭhātum a sakkontaḥ uppati evam uppatitvā iti atthaḥ agatī
translated: Then the crow, unable to stay in the water, rose up, the meaning is, he rose up in this way. He had no way to go

original: pakkhinanti yasmiṃ samuddamajjhe pakkhīnaṃ agati, tattha so evaṃ uppatito pacchimaṃ
analyzed: pakkhinanti yasmim samudda majjhe pakkhīnam tattha saḥ evam uppatitaḥ pacchimam
translated: where there was no way for birds: in the middle of the ocean where there was no way for birds, having risen up in this way,

original: disaṃ gantvā tattha patiṭṭhaṃ alabhitvā puratthimaṃ, tato uttaraṃ, tato dakkhiṇanti
analyzed: disam gantvā tattha patiṭṭham a labhitvā puratthimam tatas uttaram tatas dakkhiṇanti
translated: he went to the western direction, and not finding a footing there, to the eastern, then to the northern, then to the southern.

original: catassopi disā gantvā attano patiṭṭhānaṃ na ajjhagā nāgañchīti attho. Atha vā vāyaso
analyzed: catasso api disāḥ gantvā attanaḥ patiṭṭhānam na ajjhagāḥ na agañchi iti attho atha vā vāyasaḥ
translated: Having gone to all four directions, he did not find a footing, the meaning is, he did not go. Or alternatively,

original: evaṃ uppatitvā pacchimādīsu ekekaṃ disaṃ āgañchi, dīpaṃ pana najjhāgamāti evamettha🔽attho daṭṭhabbo. Pāpatthāti papatito. Yathā dubbalakoti yathā dubbalako pateyya,
analyzed: evam uppatitvā pacchima ādīsu ekekam disam āgañchi dīpam pana najjhāgamā ti evam ettha  atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo pāpa tthā ati papatitaḥ yathā dubbalako iti yathā dubbalakaḥ pateyya
translated: the bird rose up in this way and went to each of the western and other directions, but he did not reach an island, this is how the meaning🔽should be seen here. He fell: he fell down. As a weak one: just as a weak one would fall,

original: tatheva patito. Susūti susunāmakā caṇḍamacchā. Pasayhakārāti anicchamānakaṃyeva balakkārena.
analyzed: tathā iva susūti susunāmakā balakkārena
translated: in the same way he fell. Susu: and the fish called susu. By force: by force unwillingly.

original: Vipakkhakanti viddhastapakkhakaṃ.
analyzed: vipakkhakam ti viddha sta pakkhakam
translated: ‘The opposite’ means the opposite of what is desired.

original: Giddhā ce na vamissantīti yadi giddhā hutvā kāme na vamissanti, na chaḍḍessanti.
analyzed: giddhā ced na vamissanti iti yadi giddhā hutvā kāme na vamissanti na chaḍḍessanti
translated: ‘If the greedy do not vomit up’ means if the greedy do not vomit up, do not give up, sensual desires.

original: Kākapaññāva teti kākassa samānapaññā iti te buddhādayo paṇḍitā vidū vidanti, jānantīti
analyzed: kāka paññā va te iti kākassa samāna paññāḥ iti te buddha ādayaḥ paṇḍitāḥ vidū vidanti jānanti iti
translated: ‘They are known as wise as crows’ means the wise, the learned, the Buddhas and so on, know them as having the wisdom of a crow.

original: attho. Atthasandassanīti atthappakāsikā. Tvañca paññāyaseti tvañca paññāyissasi.
analyzed: atthaḥ attha sandassanī iti attha ppakāsikā tvam ca paññāyase iti tvam ca paññāyissasi
translated: The meaning is that they know them. ‘They are known as showing the meaning’ means they are known as revealing the meaning. ‘And you will be known’ means you will be known.

original: Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – mahārāja, mayā hitakāmena tava ovādo dinno, taṃ pana tvaṃ yadi
analyzed: idam vuttam hoti mahā rāja mayā hita kāmena tava ovādaḥ dinnaḥ tam pana tvam yadi
translated: This is what is said: ‘Great king, advice has been given to you by me who wishes for your welfare, but if you

original: kāhasi, devaloke nibbattissasi, yadi na kāhasi, kāmapaṅke nimuggo jīvitapariyosāne
analyzed: kā ahasi deva loke nibbattissasi yadi na kāma paṅke nimuggaḥ jīvita pariyosāne
translated: do it, you will be reborn in the heavenly world, if you do not do it, you will be drowned in the mud of sensual desires and at the end of your life

original: niraye nibbattissasīti evaṃ tvameva tena kāraṇena vā akāraṇena vā sagge vā niraye
analyzed: niraye nibbattissasi iti evam tvam eva tena kāraṇena vā akāraṇena vā sagge vā niraye
translated: you will be reborn in hell. Thus you will be known for that reason or for no reason in heaven or in hell.

original: vā paññāyissasi. Ahaṃ pana sabbabhavehi mutto appaṭisandhikoti.
analyzed: vā paññāyissasi aham pana sabba bhavehi muttaḥ appaṭisandhikaḥ ti
translated: But I am free from all existences and am not subject to rebirth.’🔽While giving this advice, the Independent Buddha pointed out a river, and the elephant’s corpse

original: Imaṃ pana ovādaṃ dentena paccekabuddhena nadī dassitā, tāya vuyhamānaṃ hatthikuṇapaṃ
analyzed: imam pana ovādam dentena paccekabuddhena nadī dassitā tāya vuyhamānam hatthi kuṇapam
translated: being carried away by it,

original: dassitaṃ, kuṇapakhādako kāko dassito, tassa kuṇapaṃ khāditvā pānīyapivanakālo dassito,🔽ramaṇīyavanasaṇḍadassanakālo dassito, kuṇapassa nadiyā vuyhamānassa samuddapaveso🔽dassito, samuddamajjhe kākassa hatthikuṇape patiṭṭhaṃ alabhitvā vināsaṃ pattakālo
analyzed: dassitam kuṇapa khādakaḥ kākaḥ dassitaḥ tassa kuṇapam khāditvā pānīya pivana kālaḥ dassitaḥ  ramaṇīya vana saṇḍa dassana kālaḥ dassitaḥ kuṇapassa nadiyā vuyhamānassa samudda paveso  dassitaḥ samudda majjhe kākassa hatthi kuṇape patiṭṭham a labhitvā vināsam patta kālaḥ
translated: The crow who ate the corpse is shown, the time when he ate the corpse and drank water is shown,🔽the time when he saw the delightful forest grove is shown, the time when the corpse was carried away by the river and entered the ocean is shown,

original: dassito. Tattha nadī viya anamataggo saṃsāro daṭṭhabbo, nadiyā vuyhamānaṃ hatthikuṇapaṃ🔽viya saṃsāre pañca kāmaguṇā, kāko viya bālaputhujjano, kākassa kuṇapaṃ khāditvā pānīyapivanakālo
analyzed: dassitaḥ tattha nadī viya anamataggaḥ saṃsāro daṭṭhabbo nadiyā vuyhamānam hatthi kuṇapam  viya saṃsāre pañca kāma guṇā kākaḥ viya bāla puthujjanaḥ kākassa kuṇapam khāditvā pānīya pivana kālaḥ
translated: the time when the crow, not finding a foothold in the middle of the ocean, was destroyed is shown. There, the endless cycle of rebirths should be seen like the river,🔽the five sense pleasures in the cycle of rebirths like the elephant's corpse being carried away by the river,🔽the foolish worldling like the crow, the time when the worldling, after enjoying the sense pleasures, is happy

original: viya puthujjanassa kāmaguṇe paribhuñjitvā somanassikakālo, kākassa kuṇape laggasseva
analyzed: viya puthujjanassa kāma guṇe paribhuñjitvā somanassika kālo kākassa kuṇape laggassa iva
translated: like the crow's eating the corpse and drinking water,

original: ramaṇīyavanasaṇḍadassanaṃ viya puthujjanassa kāmaguṇesu laggasseva savanavasena aṭṭhatiṃsārammaṇadassanaṃ,
analyzed: ramaṇīya vana saṇḍa dassanam viya puthujjanassa kāma guṇesu laggassa iva savana vasena aṭṭhatiṃsa ārammaṇa dassanam
translated: the worldling's seeing the thirty-eight objects of perception through hearing, while still attached to the sense pleasures, like the crow's seeing the delightful forest grove while still attached to the corpse,

original: kuṇape samuddaṃ paviṭṭhe kākassa patiṭṭhaṃ labhituṃ asakkontassa vināsaṃ pattakālo
analyzed: kuṇape samuddam paviṭṭhe kākassa patiṭṭham labhitum a sakkontassa vināsam patta kālaḥ
translated: As when a corpse is thrown into the ocean, the crow cannot find a footing and is lost,

original: viya bālaputhujjanassa kāmaguṇagiddhassa pāpaparāyaṇassa kusaladhamme patiṭṭhaṃ labhituṃ
analyzed: viya bāla puthujjanassa kāma guṇa giddhassa pāpa parāyaṇassa kusala dhamme patiṭṭham labhitum
translated: so it should be seen that when the fool and the prthagjana, greedy for the strands of sensual pleasure, devoted to evil, cannot find a footing in wholesome states,

original: asakkontassa mahāniraye mahāvināsapatti daṭṭhabbāti.
analyzed: a sakkontassa mahāniraye mahā vināsa patti daṭṭhabbā ati
translated: he is lost in the great hell with a great destruction.

original: Evamassa so imāya upamāya ovādaṃ datvā idāni tameva ovādaṃ thiraṃ katvā patiṭṭhapetuṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam assa saḥ imāya upamāya ovādam da tvā idāni tam eva ovādam thiram katvā patiṭṭhapetum gātham āha
translated: Thus, having given him this simile as advice, he now spoke this verse in order to make that very advice firm and to establish it:

original: “Ekavācampi dvivācaṃ, bhaṇeyya anukampako;
analyzed: eka vācam pi dvi vācam bhaṇeyya anukampakaḥ
translated: “Even one word or two, the compassionate one should speak;

original: Tatuttariṃ na bhāseyya, dāsovayyassa santike”ti.
analyzed: tatuttarim na bhāseyya dāsa uvayyassa santikā iti
translated: Beyond that he should not speak, in the presence of the slave-like one.”

original: Tattha na bhāseyyāti vacanaṃ aggaṇhantassa hi tato uttariṃ bhāsamāno sāmikassa santike
analyzed: tattha na bhāseyya ati vacanam aggaṇhantassa hi tatas uttarim bhāsamānaḥ sāmikassa santike
translated: Herein, he should not speak: for when the other does not understand the speech, speaking beyond that, in the presence of the master,

analyzed: dāsaḥ viya hoti dāsaḥ hi sāmike katham gaṇhante api aggaṇhante api tena vuttam
translated: he becomes like a slave. For the slave speaks whether the master understands or not. Therefore it was said:

original: “tatuttariṃ na bhāseyyā”ti.
analyzed: tatuttarim na bhāseyya ati
translated: “Beyond that he should not speak.”

original: “Idaṃ vatvāna pakkāmi, soṇako amitabuddhimā;
analyzed: idam vatvāna soṇakaḥ amita buddhimā
translated: “Having spoken this, the wise one of immeasurable wisdom, Soṇaka,

original: Vehāse antalikkhasmiṃ, anusāsitvāna khattiya”nti. –
analyzed: vehāse antalikkhasmiṃ anusāsitvāna khattiyanti
translated: And, after giving this advice to the prince, he went away through the air.”

original: Ayaṃ abhisambuddhagāthā.🔽Tattha idaṃ vatvānāti, bhikkhave, so paccekabuddho amitāya lokuttarabuddhiyā amitabuddhimā
analyzed: ayam abhisambuddha gāthā  tattha idam bhikkhave so paccekabuddhaḥ amitāya lokuttara buddhiyā amita buddhimā
translated: This is the story of the verse.🔽“Having said this,” etc.

original: idaṃ vatvā iddhiyā uppatitvā “sace pabbajissasi, taveva, no ce pabbajissasi, taveva,
analyzed: idam vatvā iddhiyā uppatitvā sace pabbajissasi tava iva no ce pabbajissasi tava iva
translated: Having said this, the Private Buddha rose up into the air and said, “If you will go forth, it will be yours; if you will not go forth, it will be yours.

original: dinno te mayā ovādo, appamatto hohī”ti evaṃ anusāsitvāna khattiyaṃ pakkāmi.
analyzed: dinnaḥ te mayā ovādaḥ appamattaḥ hohi iti evam anusāsitvāna khattiyam pakkāmi
translated: I have given you advice; be heedful.” After giving this advice to the prince, he departed.

original: Bodhisattopi taṃ ākāsena gacchantaṃ yāva dassanapathā olokento ṭhatvā tasmiṃ cakkhupathe
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ api tam ākāsena gacchantam yāva dassana pathāḥ olokentaḥ ṭhatvā tasmin cakkhu pathe
translated: The Bodhisatta watched him as he went through the air until he was out of sight, and then he stood still.

original: atikkante saṃvegaṃ paṭilabhitvā cintesi – “ayaṃ brāhmaṇo hīnajacco samāno asambhinne
analyzed: atikkante saṃvegam paṭilabhitvā cintesi ayam brāhmaṇaḥ hīnajaccaḥ samānaḥ asambhinne
translated: When he was out of sight, the Bodhisatta was deeply moved, and he thought to himself, “This brāhman, though of low birth,

original: khattiyavaṃse jātassa mama matthake attano pādarajaṃ okiranto ākāsaṃ uppatitvā gato,
analyzed: khattiya vaṃse jātassa mama matthake attanaḥ pāda rajam okirantaḥ ākāsam uppatitvā gataḥ
translated: has come and sprinkled his foot-dust on my head, and then has gone away through the air.

original: mayāpi ajjeva nikkhamitvā pabbajituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti. So rajjaṃ niyyādetvā pabbajitukāmo gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: mayā api ajja iva nikkhamitvā pabbajitum vaṭṭati iti saḥ rajjam niyyādetvā pabbajitu kāmaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: I too ought to go forth this very day.” So he gave up his kingdom and went forth into the houseless state, and he uttered two stanzas:

original: “Ko nume rājakattāro, suddā veyyattamāgatā;
analyzed: kaḥ nu me rāja kattāraḥ suddāḥ veyyattam āgatā
translated: these pure ones who have come to me?

original: Rajjaṃ niyyādayissāmi, nāhaṃ rajjena matthiko.
analyzed: rajjam niyyādayissāmi na aham rajjena matthikaḥ
translated: I will give up the kingship; I am not greedy for the kingship.

original: “Ajjeva pabbajissāmi, ko jaññā maraṇaṃ suve;
analyzed: ajjā iva pabbajissāmi kaḥ jaññā maraṇam suve
translated: Today I will go forth; who knows whether I will live until tomorrow?

original: Māhaṃ kākova dummedho, kāmānaṃ vasamanvaga”nti.
analyzed: mā aham kākaḥ iva dummedhaḥ kāmānam vasam anvaganti
translated: May I not, like a foolish crow, come under the sway of sensual pleasures.”

original: Tattha ko numeti kuhiṃ nu ime. Rājakattāroti ye rājārahaṃ abhisiñcitvā rājānaṃ karonti.
analyzed: tattha kaḥ numā iti kuhim nu ime rāja kattāraḥ ti ye rāja araham abhisiñcitvā rājānam karonti
translated: Here, “who are these?” means “where are these?” “Royal officers” are those who anoint a king and make him king.

original: Suddā veyyattamāgatāti suddā ca ye ca aññe byattabhāvaṃ āgatā mukhamaṅgalikā. Rajjena🔽matthikoti rajjena atthiko. Ko jaññā maraṇaṃ suveti maraṇaṃ ajja vā suve vāti idaṃ
analyzed: suddā veyyattam āgatā ati suddā ca ye ca aññe byatta bhāvam āgatāḥ mukha maṅgalikāḥ rajjena  matthiko iti rajjena atthiko kaḥ jaññā maraṇam suva iti maraṇam ajja vā suve vā iti idam
translated: “Pure ones who have come to me” are the pure ones and others who have come to me for the sake of good fortune.🔽“I am not greedy for the kingship” means “I am not greedy for the kingship.” “Who knows whether I will live until tomorrow?” means

original: ko jānituṃ samattho.
analyzed: kaḥ jānitum samatthaḥ
translated: “who is able to know whether I will die today or tomorrow?”

analyzed: evam rajjam niyyādentassa sutvā amaccāḥ āhaṃsu

analyzed: tam rajje abhisiñcassu saḥ naḥ rājā bhavissati iti

translated: Having seen him, the king spoke to his dear only son:

translated: “There are sixty thousand villages, completely full.
