analyzed: soḷa sitthi sahassāni sabba alaṅkāra bhūsitā
translated: “Sixteen thousand women, all adorned with ornaments,

original: Vicitravatthābharaṇā, āmuttamaṇikuṇḍalā;
analyzed: vicitra vattha ābharaṇā āmutta maṇi kuṇḍalā
translated: With various garments and jewelry, with fine gem earrings,

original: Tā putta paṭipajjassu, rajjaṃ niyyādayāmi te.
analyzed: tā putta paṭipajjassu rajjam niyyādayāmi te
translated: Serve you, my son. I give you the kingdom.

original: “Ajjeva pabbajissāmi, ko jaññā maraṇaṃ suve;
analyzed: ajjā iva pabbajissāmi kaḥ jaññā maraṇam suve
translated: “Today I will go forth, who knows if I will live until tomorrow?

original: Māhaṃ kākova dummedho, kāmānaṃ vasamanvagaṃ.
analyzed: mā aham kākaḥ iva dummedhaḥ kāmānam vasam anvagam
translated: May I not be like a foolish crow, under the control of sensual pleasures.”

original: “Daharasseva me tāta, mātā matāti me sutaṃ;
analyzed: daharassa iva me tāta mātā matā ati me sutam
translated: “Father, I have heard that my mother died when I was young.

original: Tayā vinā ahaṃ tāta, jīvitumpi na ussahe.
analyzed: tayā vinā aham tāta jīvitum pi na ussahe
translated: Without you, father, I cannot bear to live.”

original: “Yathā āraññakaṃ nāgaṃ, poto anveti pacchato;
analyzed: yathā āraññakam nāgam poto anveti pacchatas
translated: “Just as a young elephant follows the forest elephant,

original: Jessantaṃ giriduggesu, samesu visamesu ca.
analyzed: jessantam giri duggesu samesu visamesu ca
translated: Roaming in the mountains and valleys, on level and uneven ground,

original: “Evaṃ taṃ anugacchāmi, pattamādāya pacchato;
analyzed: evam tam anugacchāmi pattam ādāya pacchatas
translated: “So I will follow you, carrying your bowl behind you.

original: Subharo te bhavissāmi, na te hessāmi dubbharo.
analyzed: subharaḥ te bhavissāmi na te hessāmi dubbharaḥ
translated: I will be easy for you to support, I will not be difficult to support.”

original: “Yathā sāmuddikaṃ nāvaṃ, vāṇijānaṃ dhanesinaṃ;
analyzed: yathā sāmuddikam nāvam vāṇijānam dhanesinam
translated: “Just as a seafaring ship, of merchants seeking wealth,

original: Vohāro tattha gaṇheyya, vāṇijā byasanī siyā.🔽“Evamevāyaṃ puttakali, antarāyakaro mama;
analyzed: vohāro tattha gaṇheyya vāṇijā byasanī siyā  evam eva ayam putta kali antarāya karaḥ mama
translated: If it sinks, the merchants will be lost.🔽“So too, this wicked son of mine is an obstacle for me.

original: Imaṃ kumāraṃ pāpetha, pāsādaṃ rativaḍḍhanaṃ.
analyzed: imam kumāram pāpetha pāsādam rati vaḍḍhanam
translated: Send this prince to the pleasure palace, the increase of joy.”

original: “Tattha kambusahatthāyo, yathā sakkaṃva accharā;
analyzed: yathā sakkaṃva accharā
translated: “There the handmaids, like the Sakka’s nymphs, will delight him as they can,

original: Tā naṃ tattha ramessanti, tāhi ceso ramissati.
analyzed: tāḥ nam tattha ramessanti tāhi ca iso ramissati
translated: and he will delight in them.”

original: “Tato kumāraṃ pāpesuṃ, pāsādaṃ rativaḍḍhanaṃ;
analyzed: tatas kumāram pāpesum pāsādam rati vaḍḍhanam
translated: “Then they brought the prince to the palace that increased delight,

original: Taṃ disvā avacuṃ kaññā, dīghāvuṃ raṭṭhavaḍḍhanaṃ.
analyzed: tam disvā avacum kaññā dīghāvum raṭṭhavaḍḍhanam
translated: and the maidens, having seen Dīghāvu, the increaser of the realm, said:

original: “Devatānusi gandhabbo, adu sakko purindado;
analyzed: gandhabbaḥ adu sakkaḥ purindadaḥ
translated: “You are not a god or a gandhabba, nor are you Sakka, the giver of treasures.

original: Ko vā tvaṃ kassa vā putto, kathaṃ jānemu taṃ mayaṃ.
analyzed: kaḥ vā tvam kassa vā putto katham jānemu tam mayam
translated: Who are you? Whose son are you? How can we know you?”

original: “Namhi devo na gandhabbo, nāpi sakko purindado;
analyzed: devaḥ na gandhabbaḥ na api sakkaḥ purindadaḥ
translated: “I am not a god or a gandhabba, nor am I Sakka, the giver of treasures.

original: Kāsirañño ahaṃ putto, dīghāvu raṭṭhavaḍḍhano;
analyzed: kāsiraññaḥ aham puttaḥ dīghāvu raṭṭhavaḍḍhano
translated: I am the son of the king of Kāsi, Dīghāvu, the increaser of the realm.

original: Mamaṃ bharatha bhaddaṃ vo, ahaṃ bhattā bhavāmi vo.
analyzed: bharatha bhaddam vaḥ aham bhattā bhavāmi vaḥ
translated: Support me, good ladies, I am your supporter.”

original: “Taṃ tattha avacuṃ kaññā, dīghāvuṃ raṭṭhavaḍḍhanaṃ;
analyzed: tam tattha avacum kaññāḥ dīghāvum raṭṭhavaḍḍhanam
translated: “There the maidens said to Dīghāvu, the increaser of the realm:

original: Kuhiṃ rājā anuppatto, ito rājā kuhiṃ gato.
analyzed: kuhim rājā anuppattaḥ itas rājā kuhim gataḥ
translated: “Where did the king come from? Where did the king go from here?”

original: “Paṅkaṃ rājā atikkanto, thale rājā patiṭṭhito;
analyzed: paṅkam rājā atikkantaḥ thale rājā patiṭṭhitaḥ
translated: “The king has crossed the mire, the king has come to dry land,

original: Akaṇḍakaṃ agahanaṃ, paṭipanno mahāpathaṃ.
analyzed: a kaṇḍakam a gahanam paṭipannaḥ mahāpatham
translated: he has entered the great path, which is free from stumps and clear.

original: “Ahañca paṭipannosmi, maggaṃ duggatigāminaṃ;
analyzed: aham ca paṭipannaḥ asmi maggam duggati gāminam
translated: “I too am going along the path that leads to a bad destination,

original: Sakaṇṭakaṃ sagahanaṃ, yena gacchanti duggatiṃ.
analyzed: sa kaṇṭakam sa gahanam yena gacchanti duggatim
translated: By which they go to states of woe.

original: “Tassa te svāgataṃ rāja, sīhasseva giribbajaṃ;
analyzed: tassa te svāgatam rāja sīhassa iva giribbajam
translated: “Welcome to you, O King, like a lion in a mountain cave;

original: Anusāsa mahārāja, tvaṃ no sabbāsamissaro”ti.
analyzed: anusāsa mahā rāja tvam no
translated: Instruct us, O great King, for you are our sole lord.”

original: Tattha khippanti tena hi naṃ sīghaṃ ānetha. Ālapīti “saṭṭhi gāmasahassānī”tiādīni
analyzed: tattha khippanti tena hi nam sīgham ānetha ālapīti saṭṭhi gāma sahassāni itiādīni
translated: Herein, quickly is what is meant. Bring him quickly. He spoke is what is said.

original: vadanto ālapi. Sabbālaṅkārabhūsitāti te nāgā sabbehi sīsūpagādīhi alaṅkārehi bhūsitā.
analyzed: vadantaḥ sabba alaṅkāra bhūsitā ati te nāgā sabbehi sīsūpaga ādīhi alaṅkārehi bhūsitā
translated: Adorned with all adornments: the elephants were adorned with all adornments beginning with head-ornaments.🔽Covered with golden cloth: their bodies were covered with cloth woven with gold thread.

original: Hemakappanavāsasāti suvaṇṇakhacitena kappanena paṭicchannasarīrā. Gāmaṇīyebhīti hatthācariyehi.
analyzed: hema kappana vāsasā ati suvaṇṇa khacitena kappanena paṭicchanna sarīrā gāmaṇīyebhi iti hatthācariyehi
translated: By their leaders: by their mahouts.🔽They knew what was to be done and what was not to be done: they knew what was to be done and what was not to be done.

original: Ājānīyāvāti kāraṇākāraṇavijānanakā va. Jātiyāti sindhavajātiyā sindhuraṭṭhe sindhunadītīre🔽jātā. Gāmaṇīyebhīti assācariyehi. Illiyā cāpadhāribhīti illiyāvudhañca cāpāvudhañca
analyzed: ājānīyāvā ati sindhava jātiyā sindhu raṭṭhe sindhu nadī tīre  jātāḥ gāmaṇīyebhiḥ iti assācariyehi illiyā cāpa dhāribhiḥ iti illiyāvudham ca cāpāvudham ca
translated: Of the Sindhu breed: born in the Sindhu country on the banks of the Sindhu River.🔽By their leaders: by their charioteers.🔽With quivers and bows: with quivers and bows as their weapons.

original: dhārentehi. Dīpā athopi veyyagghāti dīpicammabyagghacammaparivārā. Gāmaṇīyebhīti
analyzed: dhārentehi dīpāḥ veyyagghā ati dīpi camma byaggha camma parivārāḥ gāmaṇīyebhi iti
translated: With shields and tiger skins: with shields made of elephant hide and tiger skins. By their leaders:

original: rathikehi. Vammibhīti sannaddhavammehi. Rohaññāti rattavaṇṇā. Puṅgavūsabhāti usabhasaṅkhātena
analyzed: rathikehi vammibhiḥ iti sannaddha vammehi rohaññā iti ratta vaṇṇā puṅgava usabhā iti usabha saṅkhātena
translated: with chariots. With troops of soldiers armed with pikes. Rohaṇa is red-coloured. Puṅgavūsabha means endowed with the best bull.

original: jeṭṭhakapuṅgavena samannāgatā.
analyzed: jeṭṭhaka puṅgavena samannāgatā
translated: Endowed with the best bull.

original: Daharasseva me, tātāti atha naṃ kumāro, tāta, mama daharasseva sato mātā matā iti
analyzed: daharassa iva me tāta ati atha nam kumāraḥ tāta mama daharassa iva sataḥ mātā matā iti
translated: My father, I have heard that my mother died when I was a young boy,

original: mayā sutaṃ, sohaṃ tayā vinā jīvituṃ na sakkhissāmīti āha. Pototi taruṇapotako. Jessantanti
analyzed: mayā sutam saḥ ham tayā vinā jīvitum na sakkhissāmi iti āha poto ti taruṇa potakaḥ
translated: so I cannot live without you. Poto means a young one. Jessanta means

original: vicarantaṃ. Sāmuddikanti samudde vicarantaṃ. Dhanesinanti dhanaṃ pariyesantānaṃ.
analyzed: vicarantam sāmuddikam ti samudde vicarantam dhanesinam ti dhanam pariyesantānam
translated: wandering. Sāmuddika means wandering in the ocean. Dhanesin means seeking wealth.

original: Vohāroti vicitravohāro heṭṭhākaḍḍhanako vāḷamaccho vā udakarakkhaso vā āvaṭṭo vā.
analyzed: vohāro ti vicitra vohāraḥ heṭṭhākaḍḍhanakaḥ vāḷamacchaḥ vā udakarakkhasaḥ vā āvaṭṭaḥ vā
translated: Vohāra means a variety of vocalisations, a fish that drags down from below, a water demon, or a whirlpool.

original: Tatthāti tasmiṃ samudde. Vāṇijā byasanī siyāti atha te vāṇijā byasanappattā bhaveyyuṃ.
analyzed: tattha ati tasmin samudde vāṇijāḥ byasanī siyāti atha te vāṇijāḥ byasana pattāḥ bhaveyyuṃ
translated: There means in that ocean. The merchants would be in danger means then those merchants would be in danger.

original: “Siyyunti”pi pāṭho. Puttakalīti puttalāmako puttakāḷakaṇṇī. Kumāro puna kiñci vattuṃ
analyzed: pāṭho kumāro puna kiñci vattum
translated: The reading “siyyunti” is also found. Puttakalī means a young fish, a small black fish. The prince again said something.

original: na visahi. Atha rājā amacce āṇāpento “ima”ntiādimāha. Tattha kambusahatthāyoti kambusaṃ
analyzed: na atha rājā amacce āṇāpentaḥ imanti ādim āha tattha kambu sa hatthāya iti kambu saṃ
translated: could not bear it. Then the king, giving orders to his ministers, said, “Let them be brought.”🔽Herein, “with hands adorned with bracelets” means with hands adorned with golden ornaments.

original: vuccati suvaṇṇaṃ, suvaṇṇābharaṇabhūsitahatthāyoti attho. Yathāti yathā icchanti, tathā karonti.
analyzed: vuccati suvaṇṇam suvaṇṇa ābharaṇa bhūsita hatthāyaḥ ti atthaḥ yathā iti yathā icchanti tathā karonti
translated: “As they desire” means as they wish, so they do.

original: Evaṃ vatvā mahāsatto tattheva taṃ abhisiñcāpetvā nagaraṃ pāhesi. Sayaṃ pana ekakova
analyzed: evam vatvā mahāsatto tattha iva tam abhisiñca apetvā nagaram sayam pana ekakaḥ iva
translated: Having said this, the Great Being had him anointed right there, and sent him to the city. But he himself, alone,

original: uyyānā nikkhamitvā himavantaṃ pavisitvā ramaṇīye bhūmibhāge paṇṇasālaṃ māpetvā isipabbajjaṃ
analyzed: uyyānā nikkhamitvā himavantam pavisitvā ramaṇīye bhūmi bhāge paṇṇa sālam māpetvā isipabbajjam
translated: left the garden, entered the Himalayas, and had a leaf-hut built in a delightful place. He went forth into homelessness

original: pabbajitvā vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpesi. Mahājanopi kumāraṃ bārāṇasiṃ pavesesi. So nagaraṃ
analyzed: pabbajitvā vana mūla phala āhāraḥ yāpesi mahā janaḥ api kumāram bārāṇasim pavesesi saḥ nagaram
translated: as an ascetic, and lived on forest roots and fruits. The people brought the prince to Bārāṇasī. He circumambulated the city

original: padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pāsādaṃ abhiruhi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā “tato”tiādimāha. Taṃ🔽disvā avacuṃ kaññāti taṃ mahantena parivārena sirisobhaggena āgataṃ disvā “asuko
analyzed: padakkhiṇam katvā pāsādam abhiruhi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā tatas iti ādim āha tam  disvā avacum kaññāti tam mahantena parivārena siri sobhaggena āgatam disvā asukaḥ
translated: and ascended the palace. Explaining this, the Teacher said, “Then,” and so on.🔽Seeing him, they said, “Take me.” Seeing him come with a great retinue, resplendent with glory, not knowing his name,

original: nāmeso”ti ajānantiyova tā nāṭakitthiyo gantvā avocuṃ. Mamaṃ bharathāti mamaṃ icchatha.
analyzed: nāma isaḥ iti a jānantiyaḥ uva tāḥ nāṭakitthiyaḥ gantvā avocuḥ mamam bharatha ati mamam icchatha
translated: those dancing-girl women went and said, “Take me.”

original: Paṅkanti rāgādikilesapaṅkaṃ. Thaleti pabbajjāya. Akaṇṭakanti rāgakaṇṭakādivirahitaṃ.
analyzed: paṅkam ti rāga ādi kilesa paṅkam thaleti pabbajjāya akaṇṭakam ti rāga kaṇṭaka ādi virahitam
translated: The mud: the mud of the defilements such as lust, etc. The dry land: the going forth. The thornless: free from the thorns of lust, etc.

original: Teheva gahanehi agahanaṃ. Mahāpathanti saggamokkhagāminaṃ mahāmaggaṃ paṭipanno. Yenāti
analyzed: tehi iva gahanehi agahanam mahāpathanti saggamokkha gāminam mahā maggam paṭipannaḥ yena ati
translated: The unfrequented: free from the thickets of the defilements. The great highway: the great path leading to heaven and liberation. By which:

original: yena micchāmaggena duggatiṃ gacchanti, taṃ ahaṃ paṭipannoti vadati. Tato tā cintesuṃ
analyzed: yena micchāmaggena duggatim gacchanti tam aham paṭipanno ti vadati tā cintesuṃ
translated: by which wrong path they go to the unhappy destinies, I am going by that, I say. Then they thought:

original: – “rājā tāva amhe pahāya pabbajito, ayampi kāmesu virattacittarūpo, sace naṃ nābhiramessāma,
analyzed: rājā tāva amhe pahāya pabbajitaḥ ayam pi kāmesu viratta citta rūpo sace nam na abhiramessāma
translated: “The king has gone forth, leaving us behind. This one, too, has a mind detached from sensual pleasures. If we do not please him,

original: nikkhamitvā pabbajeyya, abhiramanākāramassa karissāmā”ti. Atha naṃ abhinandantiyo
analyzed: nikkhamitvā pabbajeyya abhiramana ākāram assa karissāma ati atha nam abhinandantiyaḥ
translated: he will leave us and go forth. We will act in such a way as to please him.” Then, in order to please him,🔽they spoke the following verse of praise:

original: osānagāthamāhaṃsu. Tattha giribbajanti sīhapotakānaṃ vasanaṭṭhānaṃ kañcanaguhaṃ kesarasīhassa
analyzed: osāna gātham āhaṃsu tattha giribbajanti sīha potakānam vasana ṭṭhānam kañcana guham kesarasīhassa
translated: Giribbaja: the golden cave, the dwelling place of lion cubs, as if it were the arrival of a lion.

original: āgataṃ viya tassa tava āgataṃ suāgataṃ. Tvaṃ noti tvaṃ sabbāsampi amhākaṃ issaro, sāmīti.
analyzed: āgatam viya tassa tava āgatam su āgatam tvam no ti tvam sabbāsam pi amhākam issaraḥ sāmi iti
translated: Your arrival is a good arrival. You: you are the lord and master of all of us.

original: Evañca pana vatvā sabbā tūriyāni paggaṇhiṃsu, nānappakārāni naccagītāni pavattiṃsu.
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā sabbā tūriyāni paggaṇhiṃsu nānappakārāni nacca gītāni pavattiṃsu
translated: Having spoken thus, they all played musical instruments and performed various kinds of dances and songs.

original: Yaso mahā ahosi, so yasamadamatto pitaraṃ na sari, dhammena rajjaṃ kāretvā yathākammaṃ
analyzed: yasaḥ mahā ahosi saḥ yasa mada mattaḥ pitaram na sari dhammena rajjam kāretvā yathākammam
translated: He became very famous, and being intoxicated with this fame, he did not honor his father. Having ruled righteously, he went to his destiny.

original: gato. Bodhisattopi jhānābhiññā nibbattetvā āyupariyosāne brahmalokūpago ahosi.
analyzed: gataḥ bodhisattaḥ api jhāna abhiññāḥ nibbattetvā āyu pariyosāne brahma loka upagaḥ ahosi
translated: The Bodhisatta, having attained the Attainments of Meditation and the Supernatural Faculties, passed away at the end of his life and was reborn in the Brahma-world.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi tathāgato mahābhinikkhamanaṃ
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi tathāgataḥ mahā abhinikkhamanam
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he said, “Monks, this is not the first time the Tathāgata has gone forth into homelessness;

original: nikkhantoyevā”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā paccekabuddho parinibbāyi, putto
analyzed: nikkhantaḥ yā iva ati vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā paccekabuddhaḥ parinibbāyi putto
translated: in a previous state of existence he went forth into homelessness.” And so saying, he joined the connection, and preaching the Law, he pronounced the following Stanza,🔽“In the days of yore, in the city of Bārāṇasī, the king named Arindama went forth into homelessness.🔽The Private Buddha passed into Nibbāna, the son

original: rāhulakumāro ahosi, sesaparisā buddhaparisā, arindamarājā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: rāhula kumāraḥ ahosi sesa parisā buddha parisā arindama rājā pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: was Rāhula, the rest of the company was the company of the Buddha, and I myself was the king Arindama.”🔽The story of Saṇkha.

original: Soṇakajātakavaṇṇanā paṭhamā.🔽[530] 2. Saṃkiccajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Disvā nisinnaṃ rājānanti idaṃ satthā jīvakambavane viharanto ajātasattussa pitughātakammaṃ
analyzed: soṇaka jātaka vaṇṇanā paṭhamā         disvā nisinnam rājānanti idam satthā jīvakambavane viharantaḥ ajātasattussa pitu ghāta kammaṃ
translated: The story of Saṃkicca.🔽“Seeing the king seated,” etc. This story the Teacher told while sojourning at Jīvaka’s Mango-grove, concerning Ajātasattu’s patricide.

original: ārabbha kathesi. So hi devadattaṃ nissāya tassa vacanena pitaraṃ ghātāpetvā devadattassa
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi saḥ hi devadattam nissāya tassa vacanena pitaram ghātāpetvā devadattassa
translated: For Ajātasattu, incited by Devadatta, at his word slew his father.

original: saṅghabhedāvasāne bhinnaparisassa roge uppanne “tathāgataṃ khamāpessāmī”ti mañcasivikāya
analyzed: saṅgha bheda avasāne bhinna parisassa roge uppanne tathāgatam khamāpessāmi iti mañca sivikāya
translated: At the end of the schism, when the disease of the schismatic assembly arose, he thought, “I will ask for the forgiveness of the Tathāgata.”🔽While going to Sāvatthi on a palanquin, he heard that at the gate of Jetavana he had entered the earth.

original: sāvatthiṃ gacchantassa jetavanadvāre pathaviṃ paviṭṭhabhāvaṃ sutvā “devadatto sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: sāvatthim gacchantassa jetavana dvāre pathavim paviṭṭha bhāvam sutvā devadatto sammāsambuddhassa
translated: “Devadatta, having become an adversary of the Perfectly Awakened One,

original: paṭipakkho hutvā pathaviṃ pavisitvā avīciparāyaṇo jāto, mayāpi taṃ nissāya pitā dhammiko
analyzed: paṭipakkhaḥ hutvā pathavim pavisitvā avīci parāyaṇaḥ jātaḥ mayā api tam nissāya pitā dhammiko
translated: having entered the earth, has gone to the Avīci hell. I too, having relied on him, have had my righteous father,

original: dhammarājā ghātito, ahampi nu kho pathaviṃ pavisissāmī”ti bhīto rajjasiriyā cittassādaṃ
analyzed: dhamma rājā ghātitaḥ aham pi nu kho pathavim pavisissāmi iti bhītaḥ rajja siriyā
translated: a righteous king, killed. Shall I too enter the earth?” Frightened, he did not get any satisfaction in the glory of kingship,

original: na labhi, “thokaṃ niddāyissāmī”ti niddaṃ upagatamattova navayojanabahalāyaṃ ayamahāpathaviyaṃ

analyzed: tatas ti bhikkhave saḥ rājā tassa vacanam sutvā tatas tassa vacanataḥ anantaram eva  nikkhippa ti nikkhipitvā tassa kira uyyāna dvāram patvā ava etat ahosi pabbajitā nāma

translated: between two iron mountains, thus it is the Crushing Hell. It is said that the beings in this hell are placed on an iron surface that is heated,🔽and made motionless. Then an iron mountain that is burning, blazing, and glowing,

analyzed: sattāḥ mahā viravam viravanti iti dve pi roruvāti vuttā jālānam vā

original: catūhi iriyāpathehi paccantānaṃ sattānaṃ pamāṇaṃ natthi, na ca aññamaññaṃ byābādhenti,🔽sakaṭṭhāneyeva paccanti. Evamettha sattānaṃ vīci nāma natthi. Yathā pana jivhagge
analyzed: catūhi iriyāpathehi paccantānam sattānam pamāṇam natthi na ca aññam aññam byābādhenti  saka ṭṭhāneya iva paccanti evam ettha sattānam vīci nāma natthi yathā pana jivhagge
translated: They do not obstruct each other,🔽but they roast in their own individual space. Thus there is no interval of space between the beings there.🔽But just as seven drops of water on a lotus leaf do not spread because of the absence of moisture in the leaf,

original: cha madhubindūni sattamassa tambalohabinduno anudahanabalavatāya abbohārikāni honti,
analyzed: cha madhu bindūni sattamassa tamba loha binduno anudahana balavatāya abbohārikāni honti

original: tathā tattha anudahanabalavatāya sesā cha akusalavipākupekkhā abbohārikā honti, dukkhameva
analyzed: tathā tattha anudahana balavatāya sesā cha akusala vipāka upekkhāḥ abbohārikāḥ honti dukkham eva
translated: Likewise, because of the absence of the power of buoyancy there, the other six kinds of unprofitable resultant equanimity that occur there are not buoyant. Pain only

original: nirantaraṃ paññāyati. Evamettha dukkhassa vīci nāma natthi. Svāyaṃ saha bhittīhi
analyzed: nirantaram paññāyati evam ettha dukkhassa vīci nāma natthi saha bhittīhi
translated: is evident there without interruption. So there is no “wave” of pleasure there. This hell is

original: vikkhambhato aṭṭhārasādhikatiyojanasato, āvaṭṭato pana catupaṇṇāsādhikanavayojanasato,
analyzed: vikkhambhataḥ aṭṭhārasa adhikati yojana sataḥ āvaṭṭataḥ pana catu paṇṇāsa adhika nava yojana sataḥ
translated: 18,000 leagues in extent with the walls, but it is 45,000 leagues in perimeter,

original: saha ussadehi dasa yojanasahassāni. Evamassa mahantatā veditabbā.
analyzed: saha ussadehi dasa yojana sahassāni evam assa mahanta tā veditabbā
translated: and with the mounds it is 10,000 leagues. This is how it should be understood to be extensive.

original: Niccale satte tapatīti tāpano. Ativiya tāpetīti patāpano. Tattha tāpanasmiṃ tāva
analyzed: niccale satte tapati iti tāpanaḥ ativiya tāpeti iti patāpanaḥ tattha tāpanasmim tāva
translated: It burns those beings that are still , thus it is Saṃjīva ; it burns them excessively, thus it is Saṃjīva . Herein, in the first place,

original: satte tālakkhandhappamāṇe jalitaayasūle nisīdāpenti. Tato heṭṭhā pathavī jalati,
analyzed: satte tāla khandha ppamāṇe jalita ayasūle nisīdāpenti tatas heṭṭhā pathavī jalati
translated: as regards Saṃjīva , they make beings sit down on red-hot iron spikes the size of spears and then drive them on to sit on other such spikes below them. Then the earth below them is heated,

original: sūlāni jalanti, sattā jalanti. Evaṃ so nirayo niccale satte tapati. Itarasmiṃ pana
analyzed: sūlāni jalanti sattāḥ jalanti evam saḥ nirayaḥ niccale satte tapati itarasmin pana

original: nibbattasatte jalantehi āvudhehi paharitvā jalitaṃ ayapabbataṃ āropenti. Tesaṃ pabbatamatthake
analyzed: nibbatta satte jalantehi āvudhehi paharitvā jalitam aya pabbatam āropenti tesam pabbata matthake
translated: after striking the beings that are born there with weapons, they make them climb a red-hot iron mountain. On the peak of that mountain

original: ṭhitakāle kammapaccayo vāto paharati. Te tattha saṇṭhātuṃ asakkontā uddhaṃpādā adhosirā🔽patanti. Atha heṭṭhā ayapathavito jalitāni ayasūlāni uṭṭhahanti. Te tāni matthakeneva
analyzed: ṭhita kāle kamma paccayaḥ vātaḥ paharati te tattha saṇṭhātum a sakkontāḥ uddhaṃpādāḥ adhas sirāḥ  patanti atha heṭṭhā aya pathavitaḥ jalitāni aya sūlāni uṭṭhahanti te tāni matthakena iva
translated: When they stand up, the wind blows them down again. Unable to stand, they fall down with their heads downwards and feet upwards.

original: paharitvā tesu vinividdhasarīrā jalantā paccanti. Evamesa ativiya tāpetīti.
analyzed: paharitvā tesu vinividdha sarīrāḥ jalantā paccanti evam esa ativiya tāpeti iti
translated: Then from the iron surface below, blazing iron spikes rise up. They fall upon the spikes and their bodies are pierced. Burning, they are roasted. Thus this hell is exceedingly hot.

original: Bodhisatto pana ete niraye dassento paṭhamaṃ sañjīvaṃ dassetvā tattha paccante nerayikasatte🔽disvā mahājanassa mahābhaye uppanne taṃ antaradhāpetvā puna pathaviṃ dvidhā katvā
analyzed: bodhisatto pana ete niraye dassento paṭhamam sañjīvam dassetvā tattha paccante nerayika satte  disvā mahā janassa mahā bhaye uppanne tam antaradhāpetvā puna pathavim dvidhā katvā
translated: But the Bodhisatta, showing these hells, first showed the Sañjīva hell. There he saw the denizens of the hell

original: kāḷasuttaṃ dassesi, tatthapi paccamāne satte disvā mahājanassa mahābhaye uppanne
analyzed: kāḷa suttam dassesi tattha api paccamāne satte disvā mahājanassa mahā bhaye uppanne
translated: and, when great fear arose in the multitude, he caused it to disappear. Then he cleft the earth in two and showed the Kāḷasutta hell. There also he saw the denizens being roasted. When great fear arose in the multitude,

original: tampi antaradhāpesīti evaṃ paṭipāṭiyā dassesi. Tato rājānaṃ āmantetvā, “mahārāja,
analyzed: tam pi antaradhāpesi iti evam paṭipāṭiyā dassesi tatas rājānam āmantetvā mahā rāja
translated: he caused that also to disappear. Thus he showed them in turn. Then he addressed the king: “Great king,

original: tayā imesu aṭṭhasu mahānirayesu paccamāne satte disvā appamādaṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti
analyzed: tayā imesu aṭṭhasu mahānirayesu paccamāne satte disvā appamādam kātum vaṭṭati iti
translated: having seen the denizens of these eight great hells being roasted, you should be heedful.”

original: vatvā puna tesaññeva mahānirayānaṃ kiccaṃ kathetuṃ “iccete”tiādimāha. Tattha akkhātāti
analyzed: vatvā puna tesan eva mahānirayānam kiccam kathetum tattha akkhātā ti
translated: Herein, they are called “declared”🔽by me and by the Ancients. They are “full” of them.

original: mayā ca tuyhaṃ kathitā, porāṇakehi ca kathitāyeva. Ākiṇṇāti paripuṇṇā. Paccekā soḷasussadāti
analyzed: mayā ca tuyham kathitā porāṇakehi ca kathitāya iva ākiṇṇā ati paripuṇṇā paccekā soḷasussadā ati
translated: Each has sixteen subsidiary hells.

original: etesaṃ nirayānaṃ ekekassa catūsu dvāresu ekekasmiṃ cattāro cattāro katvā soḷasa soḷasa
analyzed: etesam nirayānam ekekassa catūsu dvāresu ekekasmin cattāraḥ cattāraḥ katvā soḷasa soḷasa
translated: In each of these hells there are four in each of the four directions, making sixteen subsidiary hells for each of them.

original: ussadanirayāti sabbepi sataṃ aṭṭhavīsati ca ussadanirayā aṭṭha ca mahānirayāti chattiṃsanirayasataṃ.
analyzed: ussada nirayā ti sabbe pi satam aṭṭhavīsati ca ussada nirayāḥ aṭṭha ca mahānirayā ti chattiṃsa niraya satam
translated: All these are subsidiary hells. The eight great hells and the sixteen subsidiary hells make one hundred and eight hells.🔽They are “tortures for the miserly” because they are torments for the miserly. They are “terrible” because of the great suffering.

original: Kadariyatāpanāti sabbete kadariyānaṃ tāpanā. Balavadukkhatāya ghorā. Kammanibbattānaṃ🔽accīnaṃ atthitāya accimanto. Bhayassa mahantatāya mahabbhayā. Diṭṭhamattā vā sutamattā
analyzed: kadariya tāpanā ati sabbe ete kadariyānam tāpanāḥ balava dukkha tāya ghorāḥ kamma nibbattānam  accīnam atthitāya accimantaḥ bhayassa mahantatāya mahabbhayāḥ diṭṭha mattā vā suta mattā
translated: Because of the presence of flames produced by kamma, they are “flaming.”🔽Because of the greatness of the fear, they are “greatly feared.” They make the hair stand on end just to see or hear about them, so they are “horrible.”

original: vā lomāni haṃsantīti lomahaṃsanarūpā ca. Bhīsanatāya bhesmā. Bhayajananatāya paṭibhayā.
analyzed: vā lomāni haṃsanti iti loma haṃsana rūpā ca bhīsa natāya bhesmā bhaya janana tāya paṭibhayā
translated: Because of their frightfulness, they are “frightful.” Because they generate fear, they are “fearful.”

original: Sukhābhāvena dukhā. Catukkaṇṇāti sabbepi caturassamañjūsasadisā. Vibhattāti catudvāravasena🔽vibhattā. Bhāgaso mitāti dvāravīthīnaṃ vasena koṭṭhāse ṭhapetvā mitā. translated: “Painful by the absence of pleasure” : painful because of the absence of pleasure. “Four-cornered” : all are like a four-sided mansion. “Divided” : divided by way of the four doors.🔽“Measured out by parts” : measured out by way of the doors and the streets. “Covered with iron” : all are covered with an iron roof nine leagues in extent.🔽“Standing touching each other” : all extend over that much space and stand touching each other.

original: Uddhaṃpādā avaṃsirāti evaṃ tesu tesu nirayesu samparivattitvā punappunaṃ patamāne🔽sandhāyāha. Ativattāroti pharusavācāhi atikkamitvā vattāro. Mahānirayesu kira yebhuyyena🔽dhammikasamaṇabrāhmaṇesu katāparādhāva paccanti, tasmā evamāha. Te bhūnahunoti te🔽isīnaṃ ativattāro attano vuḍḍhiyā hatattā bhūnahuno koṭṭhāsakatā macchā viya paccanti.

original: Asaṅkheyyeti gaṇetuṃ asakkuṇeyye. Kibbisakārinoti dāruṇakammakārino. Nikkhamanesinoti
analyzed: asaṅkheyye iti gaṇetum a sakkuṇeyye kibbisa kārinaḥ ti dāruṇa kamma kārinaḥ nikkhamanesinaḥ ti
translated: Asaṅkheyyanti = “incalculable.” Kibbisakārino = “having done evil deeds.” Nikkhamanesino = “seeking to get out.”

original: nirayā nikkhamanaṃ esantāpi gavesantāpi nikkhamanadvāraṃ nādhigacchanti. Puratthimenāti
analyzed: nirayāḥ nikkhamanam esantā api gavesantā api nikkhamana dvāram na adhigacchanti puratthimena ati
translated: Even though they seek and search for an exit from hell, they do not find a door to get out. Puratthimenāti = “in the east.”

original: yadā taṃ dvāraṃ apārutaṃ hoti, atha tadabhimukhā dhāvanti, tesaṃ tattha chaviādīni🔽jhāyanti. Dvārasamīpaṃ pattānañca tesaṃ taṃ pidhīyati, pacchimadvāraṃ apārutaṃ viya
analyzed: yadā tam dvāram a pārutam hoti atha tad abhimukhāḥ dhāvanti tesam tattha chavi ādīni  jhāyanti dvāra samīpam pattānam ca tesam tam pidhīyati pacchima dvāram a pārutam viya
translated: When that door is opened, they run towards it, and their skin and so on are torn off.

original: khāyati. Esa nayo sabbattha. Na sādhurūpeti vuttappakāraṃ sappaṃ viya sādhurūpe isayo
analyzed: khāyati esa nayo sabbattha na sādhu rūpā iti vutta ppakāram sappam viya sādhu rūpe
translated: When they reach the vicinity of the door, it appears to them as if it were closed, as if it were shut. The same applies to all the other directions. Na sādhurūpeti = “it is not good.” Just as a snake of the kind described is not good, so also the ascetics are not good.

original: na āsīde, na pharusavacanena kāyakammena vā ghaṭṭento upagaccheyya. Kiṃkāraṇā? Saññatānaṃ
analyzed: na āsīde na pharusa vacanena kāya kammena vā ghaṭṭentaḥ upagaccheyya kiṃkāraṇā saññatānam
translated: They should not approach the king with harsh words or with bodily action. Why? Because they have been insulted by the king,

original: tapassīnaṃ āsāditattā aṭṭhasu mahānirayesu mahādukkhassa anubhavitabbattā.
analyzed: tapassīnam āsādita ttā aṭṭhasu mahānirayesu mahā dukkhassa anubhavitabba ttā
translated: and because they will have to experience great suffering in the eight great hells.

original: Idāni ye rājāno tathārūpe āsādetvā taṃ dukkhaṃ pattā, te dassetuṃ “atikāyo”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni ye rājānaḥ tathārūpe āsādetvā tam dukkham pattā te dassetuṃ atikāya iti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show those kings who, having insulted the ascetics in that way, have experienced that suffering, the following is said: “Atikāyo,” etc.

original: Tattha atikāyoti balasampanno mahākāyo. Mahissāsoti mahādhanuggaho. Kekakādhipoti🔽kekakaraṭṭhādhipati. Sahassabāhūti pañcahi dhanuggahasatehi bāhusahassena āropetabbaṃ🔽dhanuṃ āropanasamatthatāya sahassabāhu. Vibhavaṅgatoti vināsaṃ patto. Vatthūni pana🔽sarabhaṅgajātake vitthāritāni. Upahacca mananti attano cittaṃ padūsetvā. Mātaṅgasminti
analyzed: tattha atikāyaḥ ti bala sampannaḥ mahā kāyaḥ mahissāsaḥ ti mahā dhanuggaho kekaka adhipo ti  kekakaraṭṭha adhipati sahassabāhu uti pañcahi dhanuggaha satehi bāhu sahassena āropetabbam  dhanum āropana samattha tāya sahassa bāhu vibha vaṅgato ti vināsam pattaḥ vatthūni pana  sarabhaṅga jātake vitthāritāni upahacca mananti attanaḥ cittam padūsetvā mātaṅgasmin ti
translated: Herein, atikā means one with a large body, endowed with strength. Mahissāsa means a great archer. Kekakādhipati means lord of the Kekakas. Sahassabāhu means one with a thousand arms, because he is able to draw a bow that can be drawn by five hundred archers. Vibhavaṅgata means he has come to destruction. The stories are related in detail in the Sarabhaṅga Jātaka. Upahacca mananti having defiled his own mind. Mātaṅgasminti

original: mātaṅgapaṇḍite. Vatthu mātaṅgajātake vaṇṇitaṃ. Kaṇhadīpāyanāsajjāti kaṇhadīpāyanaṃ🔽āsajja. Yamasādhananti nirayapālakarañño āṇāpavattaṭṭhānaṃ. Vatthu ghaṭapaṇḍitajātake🔽vitthāritaṃ. Isināti kapilatāpasena. Pāvekkhīti paviṭṭho. Ceccoti cetiyarājā. Hīnattoti🔽parihīnattabhāvo antarahitaiddhi. Pattapariyāyanti pariyāyaṃ maraṇakālaṃ patvā. Vatthu
analyzed: mātaṅga paṇḍite vatthu mātaṅga jātake vaṇṇitam kaṇhadīpāyana asajjāti kaṇhadīpāyanam 🔽āsajja yama sādhanam ti niraya pāla karaññaḥ āṇāpa vatta ṭṭhānam vatthu ghaṭa paṇḍita jātake 🔽vitthāritam isinā ati kapila tāpasena pāvekkhi iti paviṭṭhaḥ cecco ti cetiya rājā 🔽parihīna atta bhāvaḥ pariyāyam maraṇa kālam patvā vatthu
translated: Herein, atikā means one with a large body, endowed with strength. Mahissāsa means a great archer. Kekakādhipati means the lord of the Kekakas. Sahassabāhu means one with a thousand arms, capable of stringing a bow that can be strung by five hundred archers. Vibhavaṅgata means fallen into destruction. The stories are related in the Sarabhaṅga Jātaka. Upahacca mananti having defiled his own mind. Mātaṅgasmin means in the case of the wise Mātaṅga. The story is related in the Mātaṅga Jātaka. Kaṇhadīpāyanāsajjā means having attacked Kaṇhadīpāyaṇa. Yamasādhana means the place where the king of the hells issues his commands. The story is related in the Ghaṭapaṇḍita Jātaka. Isinā means by Kapila the ascetic. Pāvekkhī means entered. Cecco means the king of the Cetis. Hīnatto means one whose personal existence has declined, whose psychic power has disappeared. Pattapariyāya means having reached the time of death. The story is related in the

original: cetiyajātake kathitaṃ.
analyzed: cetiya jātake kathitam
translated: This is told in the Cetiyajātaka.

original: Tasmā hīti yasmā cittavasiko hutvā isīsu aparajjhitvā aṭṭhasu mahānirayesu paccati,🔽tasmā hi. Chandāgamananti chandādicatubbidhampi agatigamanaṃ. Paduṭṭhenāti kuddhena.
analyzed: tasmai hi iti yasmai cittavasikaḥ hutvā isīsu aparajjhitvā aṭṭhasu mahānirayesu paccati  tasmā hi chanda āgamanam ti chanda ādi catubbidham pi agati gamanam paduṭṭhena ati kuddhena
translated: Therefore, since he has become a mental case and has not been able to get out of the seers, he is cooked in the eight great hells.🔽Therefore, he has gone by the way of desire, etc., which is the fourfold wrong way.

original: Gantā so nirayaṃ adhoti so tena adhogamaniyena kammena adhonirayameva gacchati. Pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: gantā saḥ nirayam adha iti saḥ tena adhogamaniyena kammena adhas nirayam eva gacchati pāḷiyam
translated: He who is angry goes to hell below. He who goes by that way of going down goes to hell below.

original: pana “nirayussada”nti likhitaṃ, tassa ussadanirayaṃ gacchatīti attho. Vuḍḍheti vayovuḍḍhe
analyzed: pana niraya ussadanti likhitam tassa ussada nirayam gacchati iti atthaḥ vuḍḍhā iti vayaḥ vuḍḍhe
translated: But in the text it is written “nirayussada,” which means he goes to the hell of the upper strata.

original: ca guṇavuḍḍhe ca. Anapaccāti bhavantarepi apaccaṃ vā dāyādaṃ vā na labhantīti attho.
analyzed: ca guṇa vuḍḍhe ca bhavantare pi apaccam vā dāyādam vā na labhanti iti attho
translated: He who is old in years and old in virtue does not get a son or a grandson even in the next world.

original: Tālavatthūti diṭṭhadhammepi chinnamūlatālo viya mahāvināsaṃ patvā niraye nibbattanti.
analyzed: tāla vatthu uti diṭṭhadhamme pi chinna mūla tālaḥ viya mahā vināsam patvā niraye nibbattanti
translated: They are born in hell, having suffered a great loss, like a palm tree that has had its crown cut off.

original: Yo ca pabbajitaṃ hantīti yo bālajano samaṇaṃ hanati. Cirarattāyāti ciraṃ kālaṃ.
analyzed: yaḥ ca pabbajitam hanti iti yaḥ bāla janaḥ samaṇam hanati cira rattāya ati ciram kālam
translated: He who kills a monk, a foolish person, kills an ascetic. For a long time.

original: Evaṃ mahāsatto isiviheṭhakānaṃ paccananiraye dassetvā upari adhammikarājūnaṃ paccananiraye
analyzed: evam mahāsattaḥ isi viheṭhakānam paccana niraye dassetvā upari adhammika rājūnam paccana niraye
translated: Having thus shown the hell of the adversaries of the seers, the Great Being now, in order to show the hell of the adversaries of unrighteous kings,

translated: He said “yā ca” , etc., showing the place of rebirth for those who do not fulfil the duties.

original: vuttaṃ sāmikavattaṃ akarontī atikkamitvā maññati. Jeṭṭhaṃ vāti sāmikassa jeṭṭhabhātaraṃ.🔽Nanandaranti sāmikassa bhaginiṃ. Etesampi hi aññatarassa hatthapādapiṭṭhiparikammanhāpanabhojanādibhedaṃ
analyzed: vuttam sāmika vattam a karontī atikkamitvā maññati jeṭṭham vāti sāmikassa jeṭṭha bhātaram  sāmikassa bhaginim etesam pi hi aññatarassa hattha pāda piṭṭhi parikamma nhāpana bhojana ādi bhedam
translated: Herein, she treats with contempt is she who, not doing the duties to her husband as stated in the BhiSajJ, transgresses and thinks herself superior.🔽The elder brother is the husband’s elder brother.

original: vattaṃ apūrentī tesu hirottappaṃ anupaṭṭhapentī te atimaññati nāma, sāpi niraye nibbatti.🔽Vaṅkenāti tassā sāmikavattādīnaṃ aparipūrikāya sāmikādayo akkositvā paribhāsitvā
analyzed: vattam a pūrentī tesu hirottappam anupaṭṭhapentī te atimaññati nāma sā api niraye nibbatti  vaṅkena ati tassā sāmika vatta ādīnam a paripūrikāya sāmika ādayaḥ akkositvā paribhāsitvā
translated: The sister-in-law is the husband’s sister. For if she does not fulfil the duties to them, which are of the kind beginning with massaging their hands and feet, bathing them, and feeding them, and if she does not show them respect, she treats them with contempt, and she is reborn in hell.

original: niraye nibbattāya lohapathaviyaṃ nipajjāpetvā ayasaṅkunā mukhaṃ vivaritvā balisena
analyzed: niraye nibbattāya loha pathaviyam nipajjāpetvā aya saṅkunā mukham vivaritvā balisena
translated: She is impaled on a stake is she who, by not fulfilling the duties to her husband, etc., is reviled and abused by her husband, etc., and is reborn in hell. She is made to lie on an iron surface, her mouth is opened with an iron spike, and a red-hot iron ball is thrust into her mouth.

original: jivhaggaṃ nibbahanti, rajjubandhanena sabandhanaṃ kaḍḍhanti. Kiminanti kimibharitaṃ.
analyzed: jivhaggam nibbahanti rajju bandhanena sa bandhanam kaḍḍhanti kiminanti kimi bharitam
translated: She is pulled out by the hair is she who is pulled out by the hair, which is bound with a rope, because of her not fulfilling the duties to her husband, etc.

original: Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – mahārāja, so nerayikasatto evaṃ nikkaḍḍhitaṃ attano byāmena byāmamattaṃ
analyzed: idam vuttam hoti mahā rāja saḥ nerayika sattaḥ evam nikkaḍḍhitam attanaḥ byāmena byāma mattam
translated: What is meant is this: the hell-being sees his own tongue, which is a league long, being pulled out by the warders of hell,

original: jivhaṃ āvudhehi koṭṭitakoṭṭitaṭṭhāne sañjātehi mahādoṇippamāṇehi kimīhi bharitaṃ
analyzed: jivham āvudhehi koṭṭita koṭṭita ṭṭhāne sañjātehi mahā doṇi ppamāṇehi kimīhi bharitam
translated: and it is covered with worms as big as water-buffalo calves, which appear in the places where it has been cut by the weapons.

original: passati. Viññāpetuṃ na sakkotīti nirayapāle yācitukāmopi kiñci vattuṃ na sakkoti.
analyzed: passati viññāpetum na sakkoti iti niraya pāle yācitu kāmaḥ api kiñci vattum na sakkoti
translated: He is unable to make his plea: even though he wants to ask for something, he is unable to say anything.

original: Tāpaneti evaṃ sā tattha bahūni vassasahassāni paccitvā puna tāpanamahāniraye paccati.
analyzed: tāpana iti evam sā tattha bahūni vassa sahassāni paccitvā puna tāpana mahāniraye paccati
translated: In the Burning: having been thus burnt there for many thousands of years, he is burnt again in the Great Hell of Burning.

original: Evaṃ mahāsatto sāmikavattasassusasuravattādīni apūrentīnaṃ paccananirayaṃ dassetvā🔽idāni sūkarikādīnaṃ paccananiraye dassento “orabbhikā”tiādimāha. Tattha avaṇṇe vaṇṇakārakāti🔽pesuññakārakā. Khāranadinti ete orabbhikādayo etehi sattiādīhi haññamānā vetaraṇiṃ
analyzed: evam mahāsattaḥ sāmikavatta sassusasuravatta ādīni a pūrentīnam paccana nirayam dassetvā  idāni sūkarikā ādīnam paccana niraye dassentaḥ orabbhikā iti ādim āha tattha avaṇṇe vaṇṇa kārakā ti  ete orabbhika ādayaḥ etehi satti ādīhi haññamānāḥ vetaraṇim
translated: Having thus shown the subsidiary hell for those who do not fulfil the duties of a wife and husband, a good friend, etc.,🔽the Great Being now said “Butchers of sheep” in order to show the subsidiary hells for pigs, etc. Herein, those who speak in dispraise of those worthy of praise

original: nadiṃ patantīti attho. Sesāni orabbhikādīnaṃ paccanaṭṭhānāni nimijātake āvi bhavissanti.
analyzed: nadim patanti iti attho sesāni orabbhika ādīnam paccana ṭṭhānāni nimi jātake āvi bhavissanti
translated: are slanderers. In the River of Burning Lye: the meaning is that these butchers of sheep, etc., falling into the river of burning lye are being killed by the knives, etc. The other places of burning for the butchers of sheep, etc., will be given in the Nimijataka .

original: Kuṭakārīti kūṭavinicchayassa ceva tulākūṭādīnañca kārake sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: kuṭa kārī iti kūṭa vinicchayassa ca iva tulā kūṭa ādīnam ca kārake sandhāya itam vuttam tattha
translated: “One who cheats with weights and measures” is one who makes a living by fraudulent transactions and by cheating with weights and measures, etc. Herein,

original: kūṭavinicchayakūṭaṭṭakārakakūṭaagghāpanikānaṃ paccananirayā nimijātake āvi bhavissanti.
analyzed: kūṭa vinicchaya kūṭa aṭṭa kāraka kūṭa agghāpanikānam paccana nirayāḥ nimi jātake bhavissanti
translated: the hell named Paccanika, where the punishment for fraudulent transactions and for cheating with weights and measures, etc., is inflicted, will be dealt with in the description of the Hell of Crushing.

original: Vantanti vamitakaṃ. Durattānanti duggatattabhāvānaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – mahārāja,🔽te durattabhāvā sattā ayakūṭehi matthake bhijjamāne vamanti, tato taṃ vantaṃ jalitaayakapallehi
analyzed: vantanti vamitakam durattānam ti duggata tta bhāvānam idam vuttam hoti mahā rāja  te duratta bhāvā sattāḥ ayakūṭehi matthake bhijjamāne vamanti tatas tam vantam jalita ayaka pallehi
translated: “Vomiting” is what is vomited. “The wretched” are those who have become wretched. This is what is meant:

original: tesu ekaccānaṃ mukhe khipanti, iti te paresaṃ vantaṃ bhuñjanti nāma. Bheraṇḍakāti
analyzed: tesu ekaccānam mukhe khipanti iti te paresam vantam bhuñjanti nāma bheraṇḍakā ati
translated: when their heads are being smashed by the iron hammers, they vomit, and then they are made to eat what they have vomited by having it thrown into their mouths with the iron balls that are burning, flaming, and ablaze. Thus they are said to “eat the vomiting of others.” “Jackals”

original: siṅgālā. Vipphandamānanti adhomukhaṃ nipajjāpitaṃ nikkaḍḍhitajivhaṃ ito cito ca vipphandamānaṃ.
analyzed: siṅgālāḥ vipphandamānanti adhomukham nipajjāpitam nikkaḍḍhita jivham itas ca itas ca vipphandamānam
translated: are dogs. “Struggling” is struggling here and there with the tongue hanging out and the face turned down because of being dragged along.

original: Migenāti okacārakamigena. Pakkhināti tathārūpeneva. Gantā teti gantāro te. Nirayussadanti
analyzed: migena ati oka cāraka migena pakkhinā ati tathārūpena iva gantā te iti gantāraḥ te nirayuḥ sadanti
translated: “Deer” are wild deer. “Birds” are of the same kind. “Their devourers” are their consumers. “The hell named”

original: ussadanirayaṃ. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “nirayaṃ adho”ti likhitaṃ. Ayaṃ pana nirayo nimijātake āvi bhavissatīti.
analyzed: ussada nirayam pāḷiyam pana nirayam adhoti likhitam ayam pana nirayaḥ nimi jātake bhavissati iti
translated: and the Hell of Compression. But in the text it is written “Nirayaṃ adho” . This Hell will be described in the Nimijātaka.

original: Iti mahāsatto ettake niraye dassetvā idāni devalokavivaraṇaṃ katvā rañño devaloke dassento āha –
analyzed: iti mahāsattaḥ ettake niraye dassetvā idāni deva loka vivaraṇam katvā raññaḥ deva loke dassentaḥ āha
translated: Thus the Great Being, having shown him so many hells, now, describing the world of the gods, said to the king:

original: “Santo ca uddhaṃ gacchanti, suciṇṇenidha kammunā;
analyzed: santaḥ ca uddham gacchanti su ciṇṇenidha kammunā
translated: “The good go up, by the power of their good deeds;

original: Suciṇṇassa phalaṃ passa, saindā devā sabrahmakā.
analyzed: su ciṇṇassa phalam passa saindā devā sa brahmakā
translated: See the fruit of good deeds, with the gods, with Sakka, with Brahmā.

original: “Taṃ taṃ brūmi mahārāja, dhammaṃ raṭṭhapatī cara;
analyzed: tam tam brūmi mahā rāja dhammam raṭṭhapatī cara
translated: “I say to you, great king, follow the Dhamma as ruler of the land;

original: Tathā rāja carāhi dhammaṃ, yathā taṃ suciṇṇaṃ nānutappeyya pacchā”ti.🔽Tattha santoti kāyādīhi upasantā. Uddhanti devalokaṃ. Saindāti tattha tattha indehi🔽saddhiṃ. Mahāsatto hissa cātumahārājādike deve dassento, “mahārāja, cātumahārājike
analyzed: tathā rāja carāhi dhammam yathā tam su ciṇṇam na anutappeyya pacchā ati  tattha santo ti kāya ādīhi upasantā uddhanti deva lokam sainda ati tattha tattha indehi  saddhim mahāsattaḥ hissa cātumahārājādike deve dassentaḥ mahārāja cātumahārājike
translated: Rule the land in such a way that you will not repent later.”

original: deve passa, cattāro mahārājāno passa, tāvatiṃse passa, sakkaṃ passā”ti evaṃ sabbepi
analyzed: deve passa cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ passa tāvatiṃse passa sakkam passa ati evam sabbe pi
translated: Herein, good means tranquil in body, etc. Up means to the world of the gods. With Sakka means together with the Sakkas here and there. For the Great Being, describing the gods of the Four Great Kings, etc., said: “Great king, see the gods of the Four Great Kings; see the Four Great Kings; see the Tāvatiṃsa gods; see Sakka.” Thus he showed all the gods of the Four Great Kings, etc.,

original: saindake sabrahmake ca deve dassento “idampi suciṇṇassa phalaṃ idampi phala”nti dassesi.
analyzed: saindake sabrahmake ca deve dassentaḥ idam pi su ciṇṇassa phalam idam pi phalanti dassesi
translated: and the gods of the Thirty-three, and the gods of the Heaven of the Thirty-three with their king, and he showed him that this was the fruit of his good deeds, and that this was the fruit of his bad deeds.

original: Taṃ taṃ brūmīti tasmā taṃ bhaṇāmi. Dhammanti ito paṭṭhāya pāṇātipātādīni pañca verāni🔽pahāya dānādīni puññāni karohīti. Yathā taṃ suciṇṇaṃ nānutappeyyāti yathā taṃ dānādipuññakammaṃ
analyzed: tam tam brūmi iti tasmai tam bhaṇāmi ito paṭṭhāya pāṇātipāta ādīni pañca verāni  pahāya dāna ādīni puññāni karohi iti yathā tam su ciṇṇam na anutappeyya ati yathā tam dāna ādi puñña kammam
translated: I say to you, therefore, is what I say to you. Do good is what I say to you, beginning with the five precepts,

original: suciṇṇaṃ pitughātakammapaccayaṃ vippaṭisāraṃ paṭicchādetuṃ samatthatāya taṃ nānutappeyya,
analyzed: su ciṇṇam pitu ghāta kamma paccayam vippaṭisāram paṭicchādetum samattha tāya tam na anutappeyya
translated: and do good works, such as charity, and so on. Do not grieve for what you have well done is what I say to you. Do not grieve for what you have well done, because you are able to conceal the remorse which is the consequence of your patricide.

original: tathā taṃ suciṇṇaṃ cara, bahuṃ puññaṃ karohīti attho.
analyzed: tathā tam su ciṇṇam cara bahum puññam karohi iti attho
translated: Do not grieve for what you have well done, but do what you have well done, and do much good.

original: So mahāsattassa dhammakathaṃ sutvā tato paṭṭhāya assāsaṃ paṭilabhi. Bodhisatto pana kiñci kālaṃ tattha vasitvā attano vasanaṭṭhānaññeva gato.
analyzed: so mahāsattassa dhamma katham sutvā tatas paṭṭhāya assāsam paṭilabhi bodhisatto pana kiñci kālam tattha vasitvā attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhānaññā iva gato
translated: Having heard the Great Being’s discourse on the Law, he obtained relief from that time forth. The Bodhisatta, however, after remaining there for some time, went to his own abode.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepesa mayā assāsitoyevā”ti
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā na bhikkhave idānā iva mayā assāsito yeva ati
translated: The Teacher, having related this Jātaka, said, “Monks, not now only, but formerly also I gave relief to this man.”

original: vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi “tadā rājā ajātasattu ahosi, isigaṇo buddhaparisā, saṃkiccapaṇḍito
analyzed: vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā rājā ajātasattu ahosi isi gaṇaḥ buddha parisā saṃkicca paṇḍito
translated: and explaining the Jātaka, identified the Birth by saying, “At that time the King was Ajātasattu, the band of seers was the company of the Buddha, and I myself was the wise Saṃkicca.”🔽

original: pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: pana aham eva
translated: and explaining the Jātaka, identified the Birth, saying, “Then the king was Ajātasattu, the company of seers was the company of the Buddha, and I myself was the wise Saṃkicca.”

original: Saṃkiccajātakavaṇṇanā dutiyā.
analyzed: saṃkicca jātaka vaṇṇanā dutiyā
translated: The Jātaka of Saṃkicca is ended.🔽The Jātaka Commentary is finished.

original: Jātakuddānaṃ –
analyzed: jātakuddānam
translated: The Jātaka Collection

original: Atha saṭṭhinipātamhi, suṇātha mama bhāsitaṃ;
analyzed: atha saṭṭhi nipātamhi suṇātha mama bhāsitam
translated: Listen as I tell you

original: Jātakasavhayano pavaro, soṇakaarindamasavhayano;
analyzed: jātaka savhayanaḥ pavaraḥ soṇaka arindama savhayanaḥ
translated: The Jātaka Collection, the best of all, the lion among books,

original: Tathā vuttarathesabhakiccavaroti.
analyzed: tathā
translated: And the duties of a charioteer, as told by the Buddha.

original: Saṭṭhinipātavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: saṭṭhi nipāta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sixty-Nipāta is finished.

original: 20. Sattatinipāto
analyzed: sattati nipātaḥ
translated: The Seventy-Nipāta

original: [531] 1. Kusajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Kusajātaka

original: Idaṃ te raṭṭhanti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhuṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: idam te raṭṭhanti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhum ārabbha kathesi
translated: “This kingdom of yours,” etc. — this story the Master told, while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a monk who was discontented.

original: Eko kira sāvatthivāsī kulaputto sāsane uraṃ datvā pabbajito ekadivasaṃ sāvatthiyaṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ kira sāvatthi vāsī kula putto sāsane uram da tvā pabbajitaḥ eka divasam sāvatthiyam
translated: A certain young man of good family, it seems, who was living at Sāvatthi, gave his adhesion to the Faith, and became a monk. One day, as he was going his rounds for alms in Sāvatthi,

original: piṇḍāya caranto ekaṃ alaṅkataitthiṃ disvā subhanimittaggāhavasena oloketvā kilesābhibhūto
analyzed: piṇḍāya carantaḥ ekam alaṅkataitthim disvā subha nimitta ggāha vasena oloketvā kilesa abhibhūtaḥ
translated: he saw a certain well-dressed woman, and looking at her with a view to seizing on the sign of her beauty, he was overcome by passion,🔽and

original: anabhirato vihāsi dīghakesanakho kiliṭṭhacīvaro uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajāto dhamanīsanthatagatto.🔽Yathā hi devalokā cavanadhammānaṃ devaputtānaṃ pañca pubbanimittāni paññāyanti, mālā
analyzed: an abhirataḥ vihāsi dīgha kesa nakhaḥ kiliṭṭha cīvaraḥ uppaṇḍu paṇḍuka jātaḥ dhamanī santhata gatto  yathā hi deva lokā cavana dhammānam deva puttānam pañca pubba nimittāni paññāyanti mālā
translated: and he lived dissatisfied, with long hair and beard, dirty, his robes covered with dust and dirt, his body a mass of sores, his limbs covered with scabs, scratching himself all over.

original: milāyanti, vatthāni kilissanti, sarīre dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkamati, ubhohi kacchehi sedā🔽muccanti, devo devāsane nābhiramati, evameva sāsanā cavanadhammānaṃ ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: milāyanti vatthāni kilissanti sarīre dubbaṇṇiyam okkamati ubhohi kacchehi sedā  muccanti devaḥ devāsane na abhiramati evam eva sāsanā cavana dhammānam ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhūnam
translated: Just as, when a god is about to pass away from the world of the gods, five omens appear: his garlands wither, sweat breaks out on his armpits, his eyes water, his clothes smell bad, and he no longer enjoys his seat;

original: pañca pubbanimittāni paññāyanti, saddhāpupphāni milāyanti, sīlavatthāni kilissanti,🔽sarīre maṅkutāya ceva ayasavasena ca dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkamati, kilesasedā muccanti, araññarukkhamūlasuññāgāresu
analyzed: pañca pubba nimittāni paññāyanti saddhā pupphāni milāyanti sīlavatthāni kilissanti  sarīre maṅkutāya ca iva ayasa vasena ca dubbaṇṇiyam okkamati kilesa sedāḥ muccanti arañña rukkha mūla suññāgāresu
translated: in the same way, when a monk is about to pass away from the spiritual path, five omens appear: his faith withers, his virtue smells bad,

original: nābhiramanti. Tassapi tāni paññāyiṃsu. Atha naṃ bhikkhū satthu santikaṃ netvā “ayaṃ,
analyzed: na abhiramanti tassa api tāni paññāyiṃsu atha nam bhikkhū satthu santikam netvā ayam
translated: his shame and compunction disappear, his defilements sweat, and he no longer enjoys his lodging in the forest, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty place. These five omens appeared to him. Then the monks took him to the Teacher and said, “Reverend Sir,

original: bhante, ukkaṇṭhito”ti dassesuṃ. Satthā “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, bhikkhu, ukkaṇṭhitosī”ti
analyzed: bhante ukkaṇṭhitaḥ iti dassesuṃ satthā saccam kira tvam bhikkhu ukkaṇṭhitaḥ asi iti
translated: and showed him to the Teacher. The Teacher asked him, “Is it true, monk, that you are discontented?”🔽The monk replied, “It is true, Reverend Sir.” The Teacher asked him, “Monk, why are you discontented?”

original: taṃ pucchitvā “saccaṃ, bhante”ti vutte “mā, bhikkhu, kilesavasiko hohi, mātugāmo🔽nāmesa pāpo, tasmiṃ paṭibaddhacittataṃ vinodehi, sāsane abhirama, mātugāme paṭibaddhacittatāya
analyzed: tam pucchitvā saccam bhante ti vutte mā bhikkhu kilesa vasikaḥ hohi mātu gāmaḥ  nāma īsa tasmin paṭibaddha citta tam vinodehi sāsane abhirama mātugāme paṭibaddha citta tāya
translated: The monk replied, “Reverend Sir, I am discontented because I am in love with a woman.”

original: hi tejavantopi porāṇakapaṇḍitā nittejā hutvā anayabyasanaṃ pāpuṇiṃsū”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: hi tejavantaḥ api porāṇaka paṇḍitāḥ nittejāḥ hutvā anaya byasanam vatvā atītam āhari
translated: The Teacher said to him, “Monk, do not be a slave to the passions. Women are evil. Cast out the thought of love that has taken possession of your mind. Delight yourself in the Dispensation of the Buddha. original: Atīte mallaraṭṭhe kusāvatīrājadhāniyaṃ okkāko nāma rājā dhammena samena rajjaṃ kāresi.
analyzed: atīte mallaraṭṭhe kusāvatī rājadhāniyam okkākaḥ nāma rājā dhammena samena rajjam kāresi
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, said he, there was a king named Okkāka, who ruled righteously in the city of Kusāvatī in the kingdom of the Mallas.

original: Tassa soḷasannaṃ itthisahassānaṃ jeṭṭhikā sīlavatī nāma aggamahesī ahosi, sā neva🔽puttaṃ, na dhītaraṃ labhi. Athassa nāgarā ceva raṭṭhavāsino ca rājanivesanadvāre
analyzed: tassa soḷasannam itthi sahassānam jeṭṭhikā sīlavatī nāma aggamahesī ahosi sā na iva  puttam na dhītaram athassa nāgarā ca iva raṭṭha vāsino ca rāja nivesana dvāre
translated: His chief queen was a virtuous woman named Sīlavatī, who was the chief of sixteen thousand women. But she had neither🔽son nor daughter. Then the citizens and the inhabitants of the kingdom assembled at the palace gate and cried out, “The kingdom is lost, the kingdom is lost.” The king, hearing the tumult,

original: sannipatitvā “raṭṭhaṃ nassissati, raṭṭhaṃ nassissatī”ti upakkosiṃsu. Rājā sīhapañjaraṃ
analyzed: sannipatitvā raṭṭham nassissati raṭṭham nassissati iti upakkosiṃsu rājā sīhapañjaram
translated: had the door of the palace opened and looked out.

translated: And in all the land of Jambudīpa, whoever the king may be that desires a daughter, we will bring him and make him your chief queen.

original: “kumārassa imaṃ pavattiṃ ārocetvā cittaṃ jānāhī”ti ekaṃ paricārikaṃ pesesi. Sā gantvā
analyzed: kumārassa imam pavattim ārocetvā cittam jānāhi iti ekam paricārikam pesesi sā gantvā
translated: Consider your own heart, and tell us which royal maiden you prefer.” She consented, saying, “Very well,” and sent a maid with her, saying, “Go and tell the prince this, and find out what he thinks.”

original: tassa taṃ pavattiṃ ārocesi. Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto cintesi – “ahaṃ na rūpavā, rūpasampannā
analyzed: tassa tam pavattim ārocesi tam sutvā mahāsatto cintesi aham na rūpavā rūpa sampannā
translated: The maid went and told him. When he heard it, the Great Being thought to himself, “I am not handsome.

original: rājadhītā ānītāpi maṃ disvā ‘kiṃ me iminā virūpenā’ti palāyissati iti no lajjitabbakaṃ
analyzed: rāja dhītā ānītā api mama disvā kim me iminā virūpena ati palāyissati iti no lajjitabbakam
translated: If a royal maiden, endowed with beauty, were brought to me, she would see me and run away, saying, ‘What have I to do with this ugly man?’ and would bring disgrace upon me.

original: bhavissati, kiṃ me gharāvāsena, dharamāne mātāpitaro upaṭṭhahitvā tesaṃ accayena
analyzed: bhavissati kim me ghara āvāsena dharamāne mātā pitaraḥ upaṭṭhahitvā tesam accayena
translated: What have I to do with the household life? While my parents are alive I will wait on them, and after their death I will go forth into the homeless state.

original: nikkhamitvā pabbajissāmī”ti. So “mayhaṃ neva rajjenattho, na nāṭakehi, ahaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ
analyzed: nikkhamitvā pabbajissāmi iti saḥ mayham na iva rajjena atthaḥ na nāṭakehi aham mātā pitūnam
translated: I have no desire for the kingdom, nor for dancing-girls.

original: accayena pabbajissāmī”ti āha. Sā gantvā tassa kathaṃ deviyā ārocesi, devīpi rañño
analyzed: accayena pabbajissāmi iti āha sā gantvā tassa katham deviyā ārocesi devī pi rañño
translated: “When the time comes, I will go forth.” She went and told the queen, and the queen told the king.

original: ārocesi. Rājā anattamano hutvā puna katipāhaccayena sāsanaṃ pesesi. Sopi paṭibāhatiyeva.🔽Evaṃ yāvatatiyaṃ paṭibāhitvā catutthavāre cintesi – “mātāpitūhi saddhiṃ ekantena
analyzed: ārocesi rājā anattamanaḥ hutvā puna kati pāhaccayena sāsanam pesesi saḥ api paṭibāhatiyā iva  evam yāvatatiyam paṭibāhitvā catuttha vāre cintesi mātā pitūhi saddhim ekantena

original: paṭipakkhabhāvo nāma na yutto, ekaṃ upāyaṃ karissāmī”ti.
analyzed: paṭipakkha bhāvaḥ nāma na yuttaḥ ekam upāyam karissāmi iti
translated: In this way he refused three times. But on the fourth occasion he thought to himself, “It is not proper for me to be entirely on the side of my enemies, my parents. I will adopt some expedient.”

original: So kammārajeṭṭhakaṃ pakkosāpetvā bahuṃ suvaṇṇaṃ datvā “ekaṃ itthirūpakaṃ karohī”ti
analyzed: saḥ kammāra jeṭṭhakam pakkosāpetvā bahum suvaṇṇam datvā ekam itthi rūpakam karohi iti
translated: So he summoned the chief of the smiths, gave him much gold, and sent him away, saying, “Make a woman’s figure.”

original: uyyojetvā tasmiṃ pakkante aññaṃ suvaṇṇaṃ gahetvā sayampi itthirūpakaṃ akāsi. Bodhisattānañhi
analyzed: uyyojetvā tasmin pakkante aññam suvaṇṇam gahetvā sayam pi itthi rūpakam akāsi bodhisattānam hi
translated: When the smith had gone, the Great Being took another piece of gold and made a woman’s figure himself. For the purpose of Bodhisattas is accomplished.

original: adhippāyo nāma samijjhati. Taṃ suvaṇṇarūpakaṃ jivhāya avaṇṇanīyasobhaṃ ahosi. Atha
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ nāma samijjhati tam suvaṇṇa rūpakam jivhāya a vaṇṇanīya sobham ahosi atha

analyzed: disvā tam gara hitvā gaccha amhākam sirigabbhe ṭhapita rūpakam āharāti āha saḥ sirigabbham

analyzed: paviṭṭhaḥ tam disvā kumārena saddhim abhiramitum ekā deva charā āgatā bhavissati iti

translated: and being unable to stretch out his hand, he went out and said, “Your majesty, in the treasure-house there is a lady all alone; I am unable to approach her.”

analyzed: na sakkomi iti āha tāta gaccha suvaṇṇa rūpakam etam āhara ati punar pesitaḥ āhari
translated: “Go, my good man,” said the king, “it is only a golden image; bring it.” He was sent again, and brought it.

analyzed: kumāraḥ kammārena katam rūpakam suvaṇṇa gabbhe nikkhipāpetvā attanā katam alaṅkārāpetvā

analyzed: rathe evarūpam labhantaḥ gaṇhāmi iti mātu santikam
translated: and having it placed in a chariot, sent it to his mother, saying, “I will take one like this.”

analyzed: sā amacce pakkosāpetvā tātā mayham puttaḥ mahāpuññaḥ sakkadattiyaḥ anucchavikam kumārikam

analyzed: kathā savana attham eka mante tiṭṭhanti mahā janaḥ tam oloketvā suvaṇṇa rūpakanti saññam  a katvā ayam manussitthī samānā api deva chara paṭibhāgā sobhati kim nu kho

translated: When the ministers heard this, they said, “If there were such a girl in this country, people would say, ‘She is like the king’s daughter, she is like the minister’s daughter.’ But there is no such girl in this country.” So they took the money and went to another city.

translated: Wandering about from place to place, they at last reached the city of Sāgala in the kingdom of Madhurā. There were eight daughters of the king of Madhurā, all of them of surpassing beauty, the equals of celestial nymphs. The eldest of them was named Pabhāvatī.

analyzed: pahāram adāsim ayam mama dhītu santike kevalam me hatthaḥ dukkhāpitaḥ ti āha  atha nam rāja dūtāḥ tvam mama dhītā itas vadantī kam nāma

translated: They entered and saluted the king, and said, “Great king, our king inquires after your welfare.”🔽When they had been duly honored and entertained,🔽they were asked what their errand was. analyzed: ekāham pi avasitvā palāyissati upāyam karissāmi iti sā madda rājānam āmantetvā mahā rāja

analyzed: amhākam vaṃse yāva ekassa gabbhassa patiṭṭhānam hoti tāva divā sāmikam passitum  na labhati sace esā tathā karissati nessāmi nanti rājā kim amma sakkhissasi

translated: “Wait until you get a son.” But he asked again and again. Then

analyzed: sampaṭicchitvā hatthi sālam agamāsi athassa mātā hatthi sālam alaṅkārāpetvā pabhāvatim

translated: Seeing the axe and the bowl, she wept in the King’s presence in the capital city.”

original: Tattha udaṭṭhāsīti āsanā uṭṭhāya rañño santikaṃ gantvā aṭṭhāsi. Disvā asiñca sūnañcāti
analyzed: tattha udaṭṭhāsi iti āsanā uṭṭhāya rañño santikam gantvā aṭṭhāsi disvā asiñca sūnañca ati
translated: Herein, she rose up means that she rose up from her seat and went to the King’s presence and stood there. Seeing the axe and the bowl means

original: antepuramhi alaṅkatamahātale rañño purato nikkhittaṃ pharasuñca gaṇḍikañca disvā
analyzed: antepuramhi alaṅkata mahā tale rañño puratas nikkhittam pharasuñca gaṇḍikañca disvā
translated: that, seeing the axe and the bowl placed in front of the King on the decorated floor of the palace,

original: vilapantī gāthamāha –

original: “Iminā nūna asinā, susaññaṃ tanumajjhimaṃ;
analyzed: iminā nūna asinā su saññam tanu majjhimam
translated: “With this axe, surely, having killed my slender-waisted, lovely daughter,

translated: you will make the Khattiyas your slaves, O King Maddava.”

original: Tattha asināti pharasuṃ sandhāyāha. So hi imasmiṃ ṭhāne asi nāma jāto. Susaññaṃ tanumajjhimanti suṭṭhu saññātaṃ tanumajjhimaṃ.
analyzed: tattha asinā iti pharasum sandhāya āha saḥ hi imasmim ṭhāne asi nāma jātaḥ su saññam tanu majjhimam ti suṭṭhu saññātam tanu majjhimam
translated: Herein, axe means the axe. For in this context the axe has become known as axe. Slender-waisted, lovely means well-known, slender-waisted, lovely.

analyzed: atha nam rājā saññāpentaḥ āha devi kim kathesi tava dhītā sakala jambudīpe agga rājānam

original: ‘virūpo’ti chaḍḍetvā gatamagge padavalañje avinaṭṭheyeva maccuṃ nalāṭenādāya āgatā,
analyzed: virūpā iti chaḍḍetvā gata magge pada valañje maccum nalāṭena ādāya āgatā
translated: “Virūpa” means “disfigured.” She has come back with the corpse on her hip, the footprints on the road still fresh.

translated: “Thus a man comes to ruin and goes to a bad bourne

translated: Who does not do the bidding of those who see what is for his good.

translated: “If you had today taken the boy, so fair to look upon,

original: “Yatthassu bherī nadati, kuñjaro ca nikūjati;
analyzed: bherī nadati ca nikūjati
translated: “Where the drum resounds and the elephant trumpets,

analyzed: khattiyānam kule bhadde kinnu sukhataram tatas
translated: O blessed one, what is more delightful than that in the family of Khattiyas?

original: “Asso ca sisati dvāre, kumāro uparodati;
analyzed: assaḥ ca sisati dvāre kumāraḥ uparodati
translated: “Where the horse neighs at the gate and the prince cries within,

original: Khattiyānaṃ kule bhadde, kinnu sukhataraṃ tato.
analyzed: khattiyānam kule bhadde kinnu sukhataram tatas
translated: O blessed one, what is more delightful than that in the family of Khattiyas?”

original: “Mayūrakoñcābhirude, kokilābhinikūjite;
analyzed: mayūra koñca abhirude kokila abhinikūjite
translated: and cuckoos are cooing,

analyzed: khattiyānam kule bhadde kinnu sukhataram tatas ti
translated: in a noble family, O blessed one, what is more delightful than that?”

analyzed: tattha puttika iti tam ālapati idam vuttam hoti amma idha kim karissasi sāmikassa
translated: There, “putti” is an address. This is what is said: “Mother, what will you do here? Go to your husband’s

analyzed: santikam gaccha mā rūpa madena majji iti evam yācantiyā api me vacanam na sā tvam
translated: presence. Do not be intoxicated with the pride of beauty.” Even though I spoke thus, you did not do what I said. Today,

original: ajja lohitasañchannā gacchasi yamasādhanaṃ, maccurājassa bhavanaṃ gamissasīti. Pāpiyañcāti
analyzed: ajja lohita sañchannā gacchasi yama sādhanam maccu rājassa bhavanam gamissasi iti pāpiyam ca ati

original: ito pāpatarañca nigacchati. Sace ca ajja dhāresīti, amma, sace tvaṃ cittassa vasaṃ🔽agantvā kusanarindaṃ paṭicca laddhaṃ attano rūpena sadisaṃ cārudassanaṃ kumāraṃ ajja
analyzed: itas pāpataram ca nigacchati sace ca ajja dhāresi iti amma sace tvam cittassa vasam  a gantvā kusa narindam paṭicca laddham attanaḥ rūpena sadisam cārudassanam kumāram ajja
translated: means that you are going to a place worse than this. “And if you would keep him today” means: “Mother, if you🔽would not come under the sway of your mind, and would keep this prince who is like you in beauty and good looks,

translated: Herein, of great wisdom means of great wisdom.

original: Tato pabhāvatī “mama mātu kusassa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇantiyā mukhaṃ nappahoti, ācikkhissāmi tāvassā tassa idheva āḷārikakammaṃ katvā vasanabhāva”nti cintetvā gāthamāha –

translated: Thereupon Pabhāvatī thought to herself, “My mother is unable to speak the praises of my husband to the king’s satisfaction; I will tell him that he is living here, having performed the ceremony of investiture.” Accordingly she spoke the following Stanza,

original: “Idheva so sattumaddano, pararaṭṭhappamaddano;
analyzed: idhā iva saḥ sattu maddanaḥ para raṭṭha ppamaddanaḥ

analyzed: kusaḥ soḷāra paññāṇaḥ yaḥ te sabbe vadhissati iti
translated: This is the wise Kusā, who will slay all of you.”

original: Athassā mātā “ayaṃ maraṇabhayabhītā vippalapatī”ti cintetvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha sā mātā ayam maraṇa bhaya bhītā vippalapati iti cintetvā gātham āha
translated: Thereupon her mother thought to herself, “She is speaking thus through fear of death.” Accordingly she spoke the following Stanza,

original: “Ummattikā nu bhaṇasi, andhabālā pabhāsasi;
analyzed: ummattikā nu bhaṇasi andha bālā pabhāsasi
translated: “Are you mad? Are you blind? Are you a fool to speak thus?

original: Kuso ce āgato assa, kiṃ na jānemu taṃ maya”nti.
analyzed: kuso ce āgataḥ assa kim na jānemu tam mayanti
translated: If Kusā has come, why do we not know it?”

original: Tattha andhabālāti sammūḷhā aññāṇā hutvā. Kiṃ na jānemūti kena kāraṇena taṃ na jāneyyāma.🔽So hi antarāmagge ṭhitova amhākaṃ sāsanaṃ peseyya, samussitaddhajā caturaṅginīsenā
analyzed: tattha andha bālā ati sammūḍhāḥ aññāṇāḥ hutvā kim na jānemu iti kena kāraṇena tam na jāneyyāma  saḥ hi antarāmagge ṭhitaḥ uva amhākam sāsanam peseyya samussita ddhajā caturaṅginī senā
translated: Herein, “blind” means “deluded,” “ignorant.” “Why do we not know it?” means “For what reason should we not know it?”

original: paññāyetha, tvaṃ pana maraṇabhayena kathesīti.
analyzed: paññāyetha tvam pana maraṇa bhayena kathesi iti
translated: For he would have sent us word while yet he was on the way, and then we should have known that a four-membered army with banners hoisted was approaching. But you speak thus through fear of death.

original: Sā evaṃ vutte “na me mātā saddahati, tassa idhāgantvā satta māse vasanabhāvaṃ na
analyzed: sā evam vutte na me mātā saddahati tassa idha āgantvā satta māse vasana bhāvam na
translated: When she had so spoken, she thought, “My mother does not believe me. She does not know that he has been living here for seven months.

original: jānāti, dassessāmi na”nti cintetvā mātaraṃ hatthe gahetvā sīhapañjaraṃ vivaritvā
analyzed: jānāti dassessāmi cintetvā mātaram hatthe gahetvā sīha pañjaram
translated: I will show her.” So she took her mother by the hand, opened the lion-door,

original: hatthaṃ pasāretvā dassentī gāthamāha –
analyzed: hattham pasāretvā dassentī gātham āha
translated: and stretching out her hand, pointed him out, saying,

original: “Eso āḷāriko poso, kumārīpuramantare;
analyzed: esaḥ āḷārikaḥ posaḥ kumārīpuram antare
translated: “There is that man of Āḷāra, within the maidens’ quarters;

original: Daḷhaṃ katvāna saṃvelliṃ, kumbhiṃ dhovati oṇato”ti.
analyzed: daḷham katvāna saṃvellim kumbhim dhovati
translated: Binding his cloth about him tightly, he is washing a water-pot, stooping.”

original: Tattha kumārīpuramantareti vātapāne ṭhitā tava dhītānaṃ kumārīnaṃ vasanaṭṭhānantare naṃ olokehi. Saṃvellinti kacchaṃ bandhitvā kumbhiṃ dhovati.
analyzed: tattha kumārīpuram antareti vāta pāne ṭhitā tava dhītānam kumārīnam vasana ṭṭhāna antare naṃ olokehi saṃvellinti kaccham bandhitvā kumbhim dhovati
translated: Within the maidens’ quarters, looking at your daughters, the maidens, standing at the window. Binding his cloth about him, he is washing a water-pot.

original: So kira tadā “ajja me manoratho matthakaṃ pāpuṇissati, addhā maraṇabhayatajjitā,
analyzed: saḥ kira tadā ajja me manorathaḥ matthakam pāpuṇissati addhā maraṇa bhaya tajjitā
translated: It is said that on that occasion he thought, “To-day my desire will be fulfilled. Surely, terrified by the fear of death,

original: pabhāvatī, mama āgatabhāvaṃ kathessati, bhājanāni dhovitvā paṭisāmessāmī”ti udakaṃ
analyzed: pabhāvatī mama āgata bhāvam kathessati bhājanāni dhovitvā paṭisāmessāmi iti udakam
translated: Pabhāvatī will tell me that she has come to me. I will wash the dishes and put them away.” So he brought water

original: āharitvā bhājanāni dhovituṃ ārabhi. Atha naṃ mātā paribhāsantī gāthamāha –
analyzed: āharitvā bhājanāni dhovitum ārabhi atha nam mātā paribhāsantī gātham āha
translated: and began to wash the dishes. Then his mother, reproaching him, spoke this verse:

original: “Veṇī tvamasi caṇḍālī, adūsi kulagandhinī;
analyzed: veṇī tvam asi caṇḍālī kula gandhinī
translated: “You are a braid-haired woman, a Caṇḍāla woman, a defiler of families, a perfume-seller;

analyzed: katham mad da kule jātā dāsam kayirāsi kāmukanti
translated: How is it that you, born in a good family, should make a lover your slave?”

original: Tattha veṇīti tacchikā. Adūsi kulagandhinīti udāhu tvaṃ kuladūsikā. Kāmukanti kathaṃ nāma tvaṃ evarūpe kule jātā attano sāmikaṃ dāsaṃ kareyyāsīti.
analyzed: tattha veṇī iti tad śikā adūsi kulagandhinī iti udāhu tvam kula dūsikā kāmukanti katham nāma tvam evarūpe kule jātā sāmikam dāsam kareyyāsi iti
translated: Herein, a braid-haired woman is a grass-plaiter. A defiler of families is a woman who defiles families by her conduct. A perfume-seller is a woman who sells perfumes. A lover is a paramour. How is it that you, born in such a good family, should make your own husband a slave?

original: Tato pabhāvatī “mama mātā imassa maṃ nissāya evaṃ vasanabhāvaṃ na jānāti maññe”ti cintetvā itaraṃ gāthamāha –

translated: Then Pabhāvatī thought “My mother does not know, I suppose, that I am living here in this way” and she spoke the next verse:

original: “Namhi veṇī na caṇḍālī, na camhi kulagandhinī;
analyzed: veṇī na caṇḍālī na kula gandhinī
translated: “I am no braid-haired woman, no Caṇḍāla woman, no defiler of families, no perfume-seller;

analyzed: okkāka putto bhaddante tvam nu dāso ti maññasi iti
translated: The son of Okkāka, good sir, you think is a slave.”

original: Tattha okkākaputtoti, amma, esa okkākaputto, tvaṃ pana “dāso”ti maññasi, kasmā naṃ ahaṃ “dāso”ti kathessāmīti.
analyzed: tattha okkākaputtoti amme esaḥ okkākaputto tvam pana dāso ti maññasi kasmai nam aham dāso ti kathessāmi iti
translated: Herein, the son of Okkāka is the son of Okkāka, good sir, but you think he is a slave. Why should I call him a slave?

original: Idānissa yasaṃ vaṇṇentī āha –
analyzed: yasam vaṇṇentī āha
translated: Now, extolling his fame, she spoke the next verse:

analyzed: yaḥ brāhmaṇa sahassāni sadā bhojeti vīsatim
translated: “He who always entertains twenty thousand brahmans,

translated: “He who has twenty thousand horses,

translated: O Blessed One, do you think that I am a slave?”

original: “Yassa rathasahassāni, sadā yojenti vīsatiṃ;
analyzed: yassa ratha sahassāni sadā yojenti vīsatim
translated: “He who has twenty thousand chariots,

original: Okkākaputto bhaddante, tvaṃ nu dāsoti maññasi;
analyzed: okkāka puttaḥ bhaddante tvam nu dāso ti maññasi
translated: O Blessed One, do you think that I am a slave?”

original: Yassa usabhasahassāni, sadā yojenti vīsatiṃ;
analyzed: yassa usabha sahassāni sadā yojenti vīsatim
translated: “He who has twenty thousand bulls,

original: Okkākaputto bhaddante, tvaṃ nu dāsoti maññasi.
analyzed: okkāka puttaḥ bhaddante tvam nu dāso ti maññasi
translated: O Blessed One, do you think that I am a slave?”

original: “Yassa dhenusahassāni, sadā duhanti vīsatiṃ;
analyzed: yassa dhenu sahassāni sadā duhanti vīsatim
translated: “He who has twenty thousand cows,
