analyzed: okkāka putto bhaddante tvam nu dāso ti maññasi iti
translated: O Blessed One, do you think that I am a slave?”

original: Evaṃ tāya pañcahi gāthāhi mahāsattassa yaso vaṇṇito. Athassā mātā “ayaṃ asambhitā
analyzed: evam tāya pañcahi gāthāhi mahā sattassa yasaḥ vaṇṇitaḥ athassā mātā ayam asambhitā
translated: Thus her fame was extolled by her with five stanzas. Then her mother thought, “This girl is inexperienced.

original: kathaṃ katheti, addhā evameta”nti saddahitvā rañño santikaṃ gantvā tamatthaṃ ārocesi.
analyzed: katham kathā iti addhā evam etat ti saddahitvā rañño santikam gantvā tam attham ārocesi
translated: How can she speak thus? Surely it must be so.” Having thus believed her, she went to the king and informed him of the matter.

original: So vegena pabhāvatiyā santikaṃ gantvā “saccaṃ kira, amma, kusarājā idhāgato”ti. “Āma🔽tāta, ajjassa satta māsā atikkantā tava dhītānaṃ āḷārikattaṃ karontassā”ti. So tassā
analyzed: saḥ vegena pabhāvatiyāḥ santikam gantvā saccam kira amma kusa rājā idha āgataḥ iti  tāta ajjassa satta māsāḥ atikkantā tava dhītānam āḷārika ttam karontassa ati saḥ tassa
translated: He went quickly to Pabhāvatī and said, “Is it true, my dear, that King Kuśa has come here?” “Yes, my dear, seven months have passed since your daughter was given to him in marriage.” He said, “My dear, I have been deceived by you. I will go and kill him.”🔽“Do not do so, my dear. He is a king’s son, and he is my husband. He is a man of great power. He will not be killed by you.🔽

original: asaddahanto khujjaṃ pucchitvā yathābhūtaṃ sutvā dhītaraṃ garahanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: asaddahantaḥ khujjam pucchitvā yathābhūtam sutvā dhītaram garahantaḥ gātham āha
translated: He went quickly to his mother and asked, “Is it true, mother, that King Kusa has come here?” “Yes, my son,” she replied. “Seven months have passed since your daughter made King Kusa her husband.” He did not believe her, so he asked the hunchback, and when he told him the truth he scolded his daughter and spoke this verse:

original: “Taggha te dukkaṭaṃ bāle, yaṃ khattiyaṃ mahabbalaṃ;
analyzed: tat ha te dukkaṭam bāle yam khattiyam mahat balam
translated: “Indeed, you have done wrong, foolish girl, in that you have taken a mighty king

original: Nāgaṃ maṇḍūkavaṇṇena, na taṃ akkhāsidhāgata”nti.
analyzed: nāgam maṇḍūka vaṇṇena na tam
translated: As your husband, a nāga in the guise of a frog, and have not told me.”

original: Tattha tagghāti ekaṃseneva.
analyzed: ekaṃsena iva
translated: Here, indeed means in every way.

original: So dhītaraṃ garahitvā vegena tassa santikaṃ gantvā katapaṭisanthāro añjaliṃ paggayha attano accayaṃ dassento gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ dhītaram garahitvā vegena tassa santikam gantvā kata paṭisanthāraḥ añjalim paggayha attanaḥ accayam dassentaḥ gātham āha
translated: After scolding his daughter, he went quickly to the king, and after exchanging greetings, he held out his joined hands in reverential salutation and spoke this verse, showing his own fault:

original: “Aparādhaṃ mahārāja, tvaṃ no khama rathesabha;
analyzed: aparādham mahā rāja tvam na u khama rathesabha
translated: “Great king, forgive us, lord of chariots,

original: Yaṃ taṃ aññātavesena, nāññāsimhā idhāgata”nti.
analyzed: yam tam aññāta vesena na aññāsimha idha āgatanti
translated: For we did not know that you had come here in disguise.”

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto “sacāhaṃ pharusaṃ vakkhāmi, idhevassa hadayaṃ phalissati, assāsessāmi na”nti cintetvā bhājanantare ṭhitova itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsatto sacā aham pharusam vakkhāmi idha iva assa hadayam phalissati assāsessāmi nanti cintetvā bhāja nantare ṭhitaḥ uva itaram gātham āha
translated: The great being thought to himself, “If I speak harshly, his heart will burst. I will comfort him.” So standing in the trough, he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Mādisassa na taṃ channaṃ, yohaṃ āḷāriko bhave;
analyzed: mādisassa na tam channam āḷārikaḥ bhave
translated: “It is not fitting for one like me, who am a prince, to do what you have done.

original: Tvaññeva me pasīdassu, natthi te deva dukkaṭa”nti.
analyzed: tvañc eva me pasīdassu natthi te deva dukkaṭanti
translated: Be comforted, O King, there is no offense in what you have done.”

original: Rājā tassa santikā paṭisanthāraṃ labhitvā pāsādaṃ abhiruhitvā pabhāvatiṃ pakkosāpetvā khamāpanatthāya pesetuṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: rājā tassa santikā paṭisanthāram labhitvā pāsādam abhiruhitvā pabhāvatim pakkosāpetvā khamāpana thāya pesetum gātham āha
translated: The king, having received comfort from the great being, ascended to the palace and sent for Pabhāvatī, in order that she might be comforted. He spoke the third stanza:

original: “Gaccha bāle khamāpehi, kusarājaṃ mahabbalaṃ;
analyzed: gaccha bāle khamāpehi kusa rājam mahat balam
translated: “Go, foolish girl, and ask forgiveness of the mighty King Kuśa.

original: Khamāpito kuso rājā, so te dassati jīvita”nti.
analyzed: khamāpitaḥ kusaḥ rājā so te dassati jīvitanti
translated: The King Kuśa has been appeased, and he will give you your life.”

original: Sā pitu vacanaṃ sutvā bhaginīhi ceva paricārikāhi ca parivutā tassa santikaṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: sā pitu vacanam sutvā bhaginīhi ca iva paricārikāhi ca parivutā tassa santikam agamāsi
translated: When she heard her father’s words, she went to the great being, surrounded by her sisters and her attendants.

original: Sopi kammakāravesena ṭhitova tassā attano santikaṃ āgamanaṃ ñatvā “ajja pabhāvatiyā
analyzed: saḥ api kammakāra vesena ṭhitaḥ uva tassāḥ attano santikam āgamanam ñatvā ajja pabhāvatiyā
translated: The great being, standing in the trough, knew that she had come to him. “To-day,” thought he, “Pabhāvatī will see my manliness.”

original: mānaṃ bhinditvā pādamūle naṃ kalale nipajjāpessāmī”ti sabbaṃ attanā ābhataṃ udakaṃ
analyzed: mānam bhinditvā pāda mūle nam kalale nipajjāpessāmi iti sabbam attanā ābhatam udakam
translated: “I will break his pride and make him lie down in the mud at my feet.” So saying, she threw away all the water she had brought,

original: chaḍḍetvā khalamaṇḍalamattaṃ ṭhānaṃ madditvā ekakalalaṃ akāsi. Sā tassa santikaṃ
analyzed: chaḍḍetvā khala maṇḍala mattam ṭhānam madditvā eka kalalam akāsi sā tassa santikaṃ

original: gantvā tassa pādesu nipatitvā kalalapiṭṭhe nipannā taṃ khamāpesi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: gantvā tassa pādesu nipatitvā kalala piṭṭhe nipannā tam khamāpesi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: fell at his feet, and lying down in the mud, craved his pardon. Expounding this incident, the Master said:

original: “Pitussa vacanaṃ sutvā, devavaṇṇī pabhāvatī;
analyzed: pituḥ sa vacanam sutvā devavaṇṇī pabhāvatī
translated: “Having heard the words of her father, Devavanna’s daughter, Pabhavati,

original: Sirasā aggahī pāde, kusarājaṃ mahabbala”nti.
analyzed: sirasā aggahī pāde kusa rājam mahabbalanti
translated: Fell at the feet of Kusaraja, the mighty king, and craved his pardon.”

original: Tattha sirasāti sirasā nipatitvā kusarājānaṃ pāde aggahesīti.
analyzed: tattha sirasā ti sirasā nipatitvā kusa rājānam pāde aggahesi iti
translated: Here “fell at the feet” means that she fell at his feet and took hold of them.

original: Gahetvā ca pana naṃ khamāpentī tisso gāthāyo abhāsi –
analyzed: gahetvā ca pana nam khamāpentī tissaḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsi
translated: And having taken hold of them, she craved his pardon, and spoke three stanzas:

original: “Yāmā ratyo atikkantā, tāmā deva tayā vinā;
analyzed: yāmā ratyaḥ atikkantā tāmā deva tayā vinā
translated: “The joys of heaven are past, and now I am without thee, O god!

original: Vande te sirasā pāde, mā me kujjha rathesabha.
analyzed: vande te sirasā pāde mā me kujjha rathesabha
translated: I fall at thy feet, I bow my head to thee, be not angry with me, O lord of chariots.

original: “Sabbaṃ te paṭijānāmi, mahārāja suṇohi me;
analyzed: sabbam te paṭijānāmi mahā rāja suṇohi me
translated: “I confess all, O great king, hear me!

original: Na cāpi appiyaṃ tuyhaṃ, kareyyāmi ahaṃ puna.
analyzed: na ca api appiyam tuyham kareyyāmi aham puna
translated: I will never again do thee wrong.

original: “Evaṃ ce yācamānāya, vacanaṃ me na kāhasi;
analyzed: evam ce yācamānāya vacanam me na kā ahasi
translated: “If thou wilt not do as I ask,

analyzed: mahā rāja ettakam kālam mayā tava appiyam eva katam idam te aham sabbam paṭijānāmi
translated: Great king, for this length of time I have done only what is displeasing to you. I confess all this to you.

analyzed: aparam pi suṇohi me itas paṭṭhāya aham puna tuyham appiyam na karissāmi evam ca iti sace
translated: Listen to me further. From now on I will not do what is displeasing to you. If you do not do what I ask,

analyzed: evam yācamānāya mama tvam vacanam na karissasi iti
translated: if you do not act on the words of me who am asking thus.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “sacāhaṃ ‘imaṃ tvañceva jānissasī’ti vakkhāmi, hadayamassā phalissati, assāsessāmi na”nti cintetvā āha –

translated: “What shall I not do for you,

original: Na cāpi appiyaṃ tuyhaṃ, kareyyāmi ahaṃ puna.

translated: I will not do what is displeasing to you again.

translated: “I’ll do whatever you say, dear Sussondi, I’ll endure much suffering,

translated: Having slain the many of the Maddas’ clan, I’ll lead you away, O Pabhāvati.”

original: Bahuṃ maddakulaṃ hantvā nayituṃ tanti bahumaddarājakulaṃ hanitvā balakkārena taṃ netuṃ samatthoti.🔽Atha so sakkassa devarañño paricārikaṃ viya taṃ attano paricārikaṃ disvā khattiyamānaṃ
analyzed: bahum madda kulam hantvā nayitum tanti bahu madda rāja kulam hanitvā balakkārena tam netum samattha uti  atha saḥ sakkassa deva raññaḥ paricārikam viya tam attano paricārikam disvā khattiyamānam
translated: Having slain the many of the Maddas’ clan: having slain the many of the Maddas’ royal clan. I’ll lead you away: I am able to lead you away by force.

analyzed: senāya parivutaḥ pācīna dvārena nikkhamitvā para senam oloketvā aham kusa rājā jīvitatthikā

translated: frightened at the sound of Kusa, cut one another down.

original: “Tasmiṃ saṅgāmasīsasmiṃ, passitvā haṭṭhamānaso;
analyzed: tasmim saṅgāma sīsasmim passitvā haṭṭha mānasaḥ

original: gaṇhanto panesa sattannaṃ saṃvaccharānaṃ upari sattadivasādhikehi sattamāsehi gaṇhi.
analyzed: gaṇhantaḥ pana esa upari satta divasa adhikehi satta māsehi

analyzed: saḥ ekeka rājadhānitaḥ nānappakāram khajja bhojanam āharāpetvā eka sata rājānaḥ gahetvā
translated: He had various kinds of food and drink brought from each capital city, and taking the one hundred kings,

original: tehi saddhiṃ sattāhaṃ mahāpānaṃ pivi.
analyzed: tehi saddhim sattāham mahā pānam pivi
translated: he drank with them for seven days.

original: Nandapaṇḍito “yāva rājā sattāhaṃ issariyasukhaṃ anubhoti, tāvassa attānaṃ na dassessāmī”ti
analyzed: nanda paṇḍitaḥ yāva rājā sattāham issariya sukham anubhoti tāva assa attānam na dassessāmi iti
translated: The wise Nanda thought, “As long as the king enjoys the pleasures of sovereignty, I will not show myself to him.”

analyzed: uttarakurumhi piṇḍāya caritvā himavante kañcana guhā dvāre sattāham
translated: So he wandered for alms in Uttarakuru and stayed for seven days at the door of the Golden Cave in the Himalayas. Manojā, too,

analyzed: sattame divase mahantam siri vibhavam oloketvā ayam yasaḥ na mayham

analyzed: na aññehi dinnaḥ nanda tāpasam nissāya uppanno tam kho pana me a passantassa ajja
translated: nor of any other person. It is the result of my having served the ascetic Nanda. But it is now seven days since I have seen him.

original: sattamo divaso, kahaṃ nu kho me yasadāyako”ti nandapaṇḍitaṃ sari. So tassa anussaraṇabhāvaṃ🔽ñatvā āgantvā purato ākāse aṭṭhāsi. Rājā taṃ disvā cintesi – “ahaṃ imassa tāpasassa
analyzed: sattamaḥ divasaḥ kaham nu kho me nanda paṇḍitam saḥ tassa anussaraṇa bhāvam  ñatvā āgantvā puratas ākāse aṭṭhāsi rājā tam disvā cintesi aham imassa tāpasassa
translated: Where is he, the giver of my glory?” And he remembered the wise Nanda.

original: etasseva dassāmi. Atha devo, sakkāramassa karissāmī”ti. So taṃ vīmaṃsanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –

translated: Here, “shining like” means shining like. “Arranged” means the meaning is “whose musical instruments come in front.”🔽“Delighting” means pleasing. “With a golden cloth” means, “Dear, whose forehead is surrounded by a golden cloth with the color of lightning?”🔽“Youth” means young. “Covered with cloth” means

original: sannaddhasaratūṇīro. Ukkāmukhapahaṭṭhaṃ vāti kammārānaṃ uddhane pahaṭṭhaṃ suvaṇṇaṃ🔽viya. Khadiraṅgārasannibhanti vītaccitakhadiraṅgāravaṇṇaṃ. Ādiccaraṃsāvaraṇantiādiccaraṃsīnaṃ
analyzed: sannaddha sara tūṇīraḥ ukkā mukha pahaṭṭham vāti uddhane pahaṭṭham suvaṇṇam 🔽viya khadiḥ aṅgāra sannibhanti vīta cita khadira aṅgāra vaṇṇam
translated: covered with armor. “Like gold beaten by the mouth of a furnace” means like gold beaten in the mouth of a blacksmith’s furnace.🔽“Like acacia charcoal” means the color of acacia charcoal without consciousness. “The sun’s rays” means

original: āvaraṇaṃ. Aṅgaṃ pariggayhāti aṅgaṃ pariggahetvā, sarīraṃ parikkhipitvāti attho. Vālabījanimuttamanti🔽vālabījaniṃ uttamaṃ. Carantīti sañcaranti. Chattānīti ājānīyapiṭṭhe nisinnānaṃ dhāritachattāni.🔽Parikīrentīti tassa samantā sabbadisābhāgesu parikīrayanti. Caturaṅginīti etehi hatthiādīhi
analyzed: āvaraṇam aṅgam pariggayha ati aṅgam pariggahetvā sarīram parikkhipitvā iti atthaḥ vāla bīja nimuttamanti  vālabījanim uttamam caranti iti sañcaranti chattāni iti ājānīya piṭṭhe dhārita chattāni  parikīrenti iti tassa samantā sabba disā bhāgesu parikīrayanti caturaṅginī iti etehi hatthi ādīhi
translated: is a hindrance. Having taken up the limbs: having taken up the limbs, having surrounded the body, is the meaning. The best of the cow-pen:🔽the best of the cow-pen. Wandering: they wander. Umbrellas: umbrellas carried by those sitting on the backs of thoroughbreds.

original: catūhi aṅgehi samannāgatā. Akkhobhaṇīti khobhetuṃ na sakkā. Sāgarassevāti sāgarassa
analyzed: catūhi aṅgehi samannāgatā akkhobhaṇī iti khobhetum na sakkā sāgarassa iva ati sāgarassa
translated: They spread out: they spread out in all directions around him. Four-fold: endowed with these four limbs beginning with elephants. Not to be shaken: not able to be shaken. Like the ocean: like the waves of the ocean.

original: ūmiyo viya apariyantā. Rājābhirājāti ekasatarājūnaṃ pūjito, tesaṃ vā adhiko rājāti
analyzed: rājā abhirājā ati eka sata rājūnam pūjitaḥ tesam vai adhikaḥ rājā ati
translated: Unbounded. King of kings: worshipped by a hundred kings, or a king above them.

original: rājābhirājā. Jayataṃ patīti jayappattānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ jeṭṭhako. Ajjhāvaranti mamaṃ
analyzed: rājā abhirājā jayatam patī iti jaya ppattānam tāvatiṃsānam jeṭṭhakaḥ
translated: King of kings. Lord of the victorious: the chief of the victorious Thirty-Three. To me:

original: khamāpanatthāya nandassa parisabhāvaṃ upagantvā eti.
analyzed: khamāpana atthāya nandassa parisa bhāvam upagantvā eti
translated: he comes to me in order to ask for forgiveness, having gone to the assembly of Nandana.

original: Satthā āha –
analyzed: satthā āha
translated: The Teacher said:

original: “Anulittā candanena, kāsikuttamadhārino;
analyzed: anulittāḥ candanena kāsi kuttama dhārino
translated: “Not anointed with sandalwood, wearing the finest Kāsi cloth,

original: Sabbe pañjalikā hutvā, isīnaṃ ajjhupāgamu”nti.
analyzed: sabbe pañjalikāḥ hutvā isīnam ajjhupāgamunti
translated: all of them with hands raised in reverence, they have come to the seers.”

original: Tattha isīnaṃ ajjhupāgamunti, bhikkhave, sabbepi te rājāno surabhicandanena anulittā uttamakāsikavatthadhārino sirasi patiṭṭhāpitaañjalī hutvā isīnaṃ santikaṃ upagatā.
analyzed: tattha isīnam ajjhupāgamunti bhikkhave sabbe api te rājānaḥ surabhi candanena anulittāḥ uttama kāsika vattha dhārino sirasi patiṭṭhāpita añjalī hutvā isīnam santikam upagatāḥ
translated: Herein, they approached the seers: all those kings, anointed with the perfume of surabhi sandalwood, wearing the best of Kāsi cloth, with hands raised in reverential salutation at their heads, approached the seers.

original: Tato manojo rājā taṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisinno paṭisanthāraṃ karonto gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: tatas manojaḥ rājā tam vanditvā ekamantam nisinnaḥ paṭisanthāram karontaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: Then King Manoja, having worshipped them, sat down on one side and, in the act of hospitality, spoke this verse:

original: “Kacci nu bhoto kusalaṃ, kacci bhoto anāmayaṃ;
analyzed: kacci nu bhotaḥ kusalam kacci bhotaḥ anāmayam
translated: “I trust you are well, sir, I trust you are healthy,

original: Kacci uñchena yāpetha, kacci mūlaphalā bahū.
analyzed: kacci uñchena yāpetha kacci mūla phalā
translated: I trust you live on alms, I trust fruits and roots are plentiful.

original: “Kacci ḍaṃsā makasā ca, appameva sarīsapā;
analyzed: kacci ḍaṃsā makasā ca appamā iva sarīsapā
translated: “I trust there are few snakes and scorpions, I trust there are few reptiles,

original: Vane vāḷamigākiṇṇe, kacci hiṃsā na vijjatī”ti.
analyzed: vane kacci hiṃsā na vijjati iti
translated: I trust there is no danger in the forest, I trust there is no violence.”

original: Tato paraṃ ubhinnaṃ tesaṃ vacanapaṭivacanavasena kathitagāthā honti –
analyzed: tatas param ubhinnam tesam vacana paṭivacana vasena kathita gāthāḥ honti
translated: Then the verses spoken by them both, in reply to each other, are:

original: “Kusalañceva no rāja, atho rāja anāmayaṃ;
analyzed: kusalam ca iva naḥ rāja atha u rāja anāmayam
translated: “We are well, O King, and we are healthy,

original: Atho uñchena yāpema, atho mūlaphalā bahū.🔽“Atho ḍaṃsā makasā ca, appameva sarīsapā;
analyzed: atha u uñchena yāpema atha u mūla phalā  atho ḍaṃsā makasā ca appamā iva sarīsapā
translated: and we live on alms, and fruits and roots are plentiful.🔽“And there are few snakes and scorpions, and there are few reptiles,

original: Vane vāḷamigākiṇṇe, hiṃsā mayhaṃ na vijjati.
analyzed: vane vāḷamiga ākiṇṇe hiṃsā mayham na vijjati
translated: and there is no danger in the forest, and there is no violence for me.

original: “Bahūni vassapūgāni, assame sammataṃ idha;
analyzed: bahūni vassa pūgāni assame sammatam idha
translated: “For many years, in this hermitage,

original: Nābhijānāmi uppannaṃ, ābādhaṃ amanoramaṃ.
analyzed: na abhijānāmi uppannam ābādham amanoramam
translated: I do not recall any illness, unpleasant or otherwise.

original: “Svāgataṃ te mahārāja, atho te adurāgataṃ;
analyzed: svāgatam te mahā rāja atho te adurāgatam
translated: “Welcome to you, great king, and your arrival is timely;

original: Issarosi anuppatto, yaṃ idhatthi pavedaya.
analyzed: issarā asi an uppattaḥ yam idha atthi pavedaya
translated: You are the lord who has come, so tell me what you want.🔽“There are tinduka fruits, piyal fruits,

original: “Tindukāni piyālāni, madhuke kāsumāriyo;
analyzed: tindukāni piyālāni madhuke
translated: madhuka fruits, and kāsumāri fruits;

original: Phalāni khuddakappāni, bhuñja rāja varaṃ varaṃ.
analyzed: phalāni khudda kappāni bhuñja rāja varam varam
translated: Eat the small fruits, great king, the best of the best.🔽“This is cool water brought

original: “Idampi pānīyaṃ sītaṃ, ābhataṃ girigabbharā;
analyzed: idam pi pānīyam giri gabbharā
translated: from the slopes of the mountains;

original: Tato piva mahārāja, sace tvaṃ abhikaṅkhasi.
analyzed: tatas piva mahā rāja sace tvam abhikaṅkhasi
translated: Drink it, great king, if you wish.”

original: “Paṭiggahitaṃ yaṃ dinnaṃ, sabbassa agghiyaṃ kataṃ;
analyzed: paṭiggahitam yam dinnam sabbassa agghiyam katam
translated: “What was given to me, I have accepted; all of it has been made into the highest offering.

original: Nandassāpi nisāmetha, vacanaṃ so pavakkhati.
analyzed: nandassa api nisāmetha vacanam so pavakkhati
translated: Listen to Nandā’s words, she is speaking.”

original: “Ajjhāvaramhā nandassa, bhoto santikamāgatā;
analyzed: nandassa bhoto santikam āgatā
translated: “We have come from Nandā’s presence, to your presence, sir;

original: Suṇātu bhavaṃ vacanaṃ, nandassa parisāya cā”ti.
analyzed: suṇātu bhavam vacanam nandassa parisāya ca ati
translated: May you listen to Nandā’s words, and to the words of the assembly.”

original: Imā yebhuyyena pākaṭasambandhāyeva, yaṃ panettha apākaṭaṃ, tadeva vakkhāma. Pavedayāti
analyzed: imāḥ yebhuyyena pākaṭa sambandhāya iva yam pana ittha apākaṭam tat eva vakkhāma pavedayāti
translated: Most of these are obvious, but we will explain what is not obvious here. “Tell me what you want” means:

original: yaṃ imasmiṃ ṭhāne tava abhirucitaṃ atthi, taṃ no kathehīti vadati. Khuddakappānīti
analyzed: yam imasmin ṭhāne tava abhirucitam atthi tam no kathehi iti vadati khudda kappāni iti
translated: “What you like best in this place, tell us that.”🔽“These small fruits,” etc.

original: etāni nānārukkhaphalāni khuddakamadhupaṭibhāgāni madhurāni. Varaṃ varanti ito uttamuttamaṃ🔽gahetvā bhuñja. Girigabbharāti anotattato. Sabbassa agghiyanti yena mayaṃ āpucchitā,
analyzed: etāni nānā rukkha phalāni khuddaka madhu paṭibhāgāni madhurāni varam varanti itas uttamuttamam  gahetvā bhuñja giri gabbha rāti sabbassa agghiyanti yena mayam āpucchitā
translated: “Take and eat the best of all,” etc.

original: taṃ amhehi paṭiggahitaṃ nāma tumhehi ca dinnameva nāma, ettāvatā imassa janassa sabbassa🔽agghiyaṃ tumhehi kataṃ. Nandassāpīti amhākaṃ tāva sabbaṃ kataṃ, idāni pana nandapaṇḍito🔽kiñci vattukāmo, tassapi tāva vacanaṃ suṇātha. Ajjhāvaramhāti mayañhi na aññena kammena
analyzed: tam amhehi paṭiggahitam nāma tumhehi ca dinnam eva nāma ettāvatā imassa janassa sabbassa  agghiyam tumhehi katam nandassa api iti amhākam tāva sabbam katam idāni pana nanda paṇḍito  kiñci vattu kāmo tassa api tāva vacanam suṇātha mayan hi na aññena kammena
translated: “What we have accepted from you is what you have given us. In this way you have done the best for all of us. Now let Nandapandita,” etc.🔽“We have done all that is to be done. Now let Nandapandita, who is desirous of saying something, speak.”🔽“We have not come here,” etc.

original: āgatā, nandassa pana parisā hutvā tumhākaṃ khamāpanatthāya āgatāti vadati. Bhavanti
analyzed: āgatā nandassa pana parisā hutvā tumhākam khamāpana atthāya āgatā ati vadati bhavanti
translated: “We have not come here for any other business. We have come to make you forgive Nandapandita.”

original: bhavaṃ soṇapaṇḍito suṇātu.
analyzed: bhavam soṇa paṇḍitaḥ suṇātu
translated: “Let Bhavan Soṇapaṇḍita listen.”

original: Evaṃ vutte nandapaṇḍito uṭṭhāyāsanā mātāpitaro ca bhātarañca vanditvā sakaparisāya saddhiṃ sallapanto āha –
analyzed: evam vutte nanda paṇḍitaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā mātā pitaro ca bhātaram ca vanditvā saka parisāya saddhim sallapantaḥ āha
translated: When this had been said, the wise Nanda rose from his seat, and after worshipping his parents and his brother, he spoke to his own retinue, saying:

original: “Parosataṃ jānapadā, mahāsālā ca brāhmaṇā;
analyzed: parosatam jānapadā mahā sālā ca brāhmaṇā
translated: “More than a hundred people from the provinces, and great brahmins of wealth,

original: Ime ca khattiyā sabbe, abhijātā yasassino;
analyzed: ime ca khattiyā sabbe abhijātāḥ yasassinaḥ
translated: And all these nobles, of high birth and renowned,

original: Bhavañca rājā manojo, anumaññantu me vaco.
analyzed: bhavañca rājā manojaḥ anumaññantu me vacaḥ
translated: And you, King Manoja, give your consent to my words.

original: “Ye ca santi samītāro, yakkhāni idha massame;
analyzed: ye ca santi samītāraḥ yakkhāni idha massame
translated: “And those who are assembled here, Yakkhas and spirits,

original: Araññe bhūtabhabyāni, suṇantu vacanaṃ mama.
analyzed: araññe bhūta bhabyāni suṇantu vacanam mama
translated: And those who are in the forest, Bhutas and Bhabyas, listen to my words.

original: “Namo katvāna bhūtānaṃ, isiṃ vakkhāmi subbataṃ;
analyzed: namaḥ katvāna bhūtānam isim vakkhāmi subbatam
translated: “After paying homage to the spirits, I will speak of the sage Subbata,

original: So tyāhaṃ dakkhiṇā bāhu, tava kosiya sammato.
analyzed: so tyā aham dakkhiṇā bāhu tava kosiya sammato
translated: And I, your right hand, Kosiya, am approved by him.

original: “Pitaraṃ me janettiñca, bhattukāmassa me sato;
analyzed: pitaram me janettim ca bhattu kāmassa me sataḥ
translated: “To my father and mother, while I am desirous of merit,

original: Vīra puññamidaṃ ṭhānaṃ, mā maṃ kosiya vāraya.
analyzed: vīra puññam idam ṭhānam mā mama kosiya vāraya
translated: This is the place, O hero, do not hinder me, Kosiya.

original: “Sabbhi hetaṃ upaññātaṃ, mametaṃ upanissaja;
analyzed: sabbhi ha etam upaññātam mama etam upanissaja
translated: “This is known to all, I rely on this,

original: Uṭṭhānapāricariyāya, dīgharattaṃ tayā kataṃ;
analyzed: uṭṭhāna pāricariyāya dīgharattam tayā katam
translated: Through rising and service, for a long time you have done it;

original: Dhātāpitūsu puññāni, mama lokadado bhava.
analyzed: dhātā pitūsu puññāni mama loka dadaḥ bhava
translated: In the support of father and mother, give me a world, O giver of the world.

original: “Tatheva santi manujā, dhamme dhammapadaṃ vidū;
analyzed: tathā iva santi manujāḥ dhamme dhamma padam vidū
translated: “And so there are men, who know the word of Dhamma, the word of Dhamma,

original: Maggo saggassa lokassa, yathā jānāsi tvaṃ ise.
analyzed: maggaḥ saggassa lokassa yathā jānāsi tvam ise
translated: The path to the world of heaven, As you know, O king.

original: “Uṭṭhānapāricariyāya, mātāpitusukhāvahaṃ;
analyzed: uṭṭhāna pāricariyāya mātā pitu sukha āvaham
translated: “By rising early and serving my parents,

original: Taṃ maṃ puññā nivāreti, ariyamaggāvaro naro”ti.🔽Tattha anumaññantūti anubujjhantu, sādhukaṃ sutvā paccakkhaṃ karontūti attho. Samītāroti🔽samāgatā. Araññe bhūtabhabyānīti asmiṃ himavantāraññe yāni bhūtāni ceva vuḍḍhimariyādappattāni
analyzed: tam mama puññā nivāreti ariya magga avaraḥ  tattha anumaññantu uti anubujjhantu sādhukam sutvā paccakkham karontu iti attho samītāro ti  samāgatā araññe bhūta bhabyāni iti asmin himavanta araññe yāni bhūtāni ca iva vuḍḍhi mariyāda pattāni
translated: Merit restrains me, a man of low birth, from the Noble Path.”

original: bhabyāni ca taruṇadevatāni, tānipi sabbāni mama vacanaṃ suṇantūti attho. “Namo katvānā”ti
analyzed: ca taruṇa devatāni tāni api sabbāni mama vacanam suṇantu iti attho
translated: Herein, let them approve is let them understand; the meaning is, let them make it manifest by listening well. Assembled is gathered together. The beings and the would-be beings in the wood is the meaning of the words bhūtabhabyāni araññe. The beings are the deities who have already been reborn in this Himalayan wood; the would-be beings are the young deities who are about to be reborn there. Let all of them listen to my words. Having made obeisance is having paid homage.

original: idaṃ so parisāya saññaṃ datvā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe nibbattadevatānaṃ namakkāraṃ katvā🔽āha. Tassattho – ajja bahūhi devatāhi mama bhātikassa dhammakathāsavanatthaṃ āgatāhi
analyzed: idam saḥ parisāya saññam da tvā tasmim vana saṇḍe nibbatta devatānam namakkāram katvā  āha tassa atthaḥ ajja bahūhi devatāhi mama bhātikassa dhamma kathā savana ttham āgatāhi
translated: This is said by him after he has given notice to the assembly and paid homage to the deities reborn in that wood.

original: bhavitabbaṃ, ahaṃ vo namakkāro, tumhepi mayhaṃ sahāyā hothāti. So devatānaṃ añjaliṃ
analyzed: bhavitabbam aham vaḥ namakkāro tumhe pi mayham sahāyāḥ hotha ati saḥ devatānam añjalim
translated: The meaning is this. Today there must be many deities who have come to listen to my brother’s Dhamma teaching. I pay homage to you. You too be my helpers. He raised his clasped hands in reverential salutation to the deities.

original: paggahetvā parisaṃ jānāpetvā “isiṃ vakkhāmī”tiādimāha. Tattha isinti soṇapaṇḍitaṃ🔽sandhāya vadati. Sammatoti bhātaro nāma aṅgasamā honti, tasmā so te ahaṃ dakkhiṇā
analyzed: paggahetvā parisam jānāpetvā isim vakkhāmi itiādim āha tattha isim ti soṇa paṇḍitam  sandhāya vadati sammatoti bhātaraḥ nāma aṅga samāḥ honti tasmā so te aham dakkhiṇā
translated: and having taken it up, he had the assembly informed, and he said, “I will speak of the sage.” Herein, he said this referring to the wise Soṇa.

original: bāhūti sammato. Tena me khamituṃ arahathāti dīpeti.🔽Vīrāti vīriyavanta mahāparakkama. Puññamidaṃ ṭhānanti idaṃ mātāpituupaṭṭhānaṃ nāma
analyzed: tena me khamitum arahatha ati dīpa iti  vīra ati vīriyavanta mahā parakkama puññam idam ṭhānam ti idam mātā pitu upaṭṭhānam nāma
translated: “Agreed”: brothers are equal in limbs, therefore he is agreed by me as a right hand. He shows that he is worthy of my forgiveness.

original: puññaṃ saggasaṃvattanikakāraṇaṃ, taṃ karontaṃ maṃ mā vārayāti vadati. Sabbhi hetanti
analyzed: puññam sagga saṃvattanika kāraṇam tam karontam mam mā vāraya ati vadati sabbhi hetanti
translated: “Hero”: he is endowed with energy, he has great valor. “This is the place for merit”: this attendance on mother and father is a cause that leads to merit, to heaven. He says: “Do not prevent me who is doing this.”

original: etañhi mātāpituupaṭṭhānaṃ nāma paṇḍitehi upaññātaṃ upagantvā ñātañceva vaṇṇitañca.
analyzed: etat hi mātā pitu upaṭṭhānam nāma paṇḍitehi upaññātam upagantvā ñātam ca iva vaṇṇitam ca
translated: “By all”: for this attendance on mother and father is known and praised by the wise who have undertaken it.

original: Mametaṃ upanissajāti idaṃ tvaṃ mayhaṃ nissaja vissajjehi dehi. Uṭṭhānapāricariyāyāti
analyzed: mama etam upanissajāti idam tvam mayham nissaja vissajjehi dehi uṭṭhāna pāricariyāya ati
translated: “Entrust to me”: this you should give to me, you should hand over to me. “By rising and service”:

original: uṭṭhānena ca pāricariyāya ca. Katanti dīgharattaṃ tayā kusalaṃ kataṃ. Puññānīti idāni
analyzed: uṭṭhānena ca pāricariyāya ca katanti dīgharattam tayā kusalam katam puññāni iti idāni
translated: by rising and by service. “What has been done”: for a long time you have done what is wholesome. “By merits”: now

original: ahaṃ mātāpitūsu puññāni kattukāmo. Mama lokadadoti tassa mama tvaṃ saggalokadado
analyzed: aham mātā pitūsu puññāni kattu kāmaḥ mama loka dado ti tassa mama tvam sagga loka dado
translated: I want to make merit with my mother and father. Be my giver of the world of the gods.

original: hoti, ahañhi tesaṃ vattaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ katvā devaloke aparimāṇaṃ yasaṃ labhissāmi,
analyzed: hoti aham hi tesam vattam upaṭṭhānam katvā deva loke aparimāṇam yasam labhissāmi
translated: For I shall receive immeasurable fame in the world of the gods by attending to their needs.

original: tassa me tvaṃ dāyako hohīti vadati.
analyzed: tassa me tvam dāyakaḥ hohi iti vadati
translated: Be my giver of that.”

translated: directing his mind to Nāḷāgiri, sent forth a flood of loving-kindness and uttered a sweet and gentle Brahma-voice, saying, “Come, Nāḷāgiri!

original: Dhammaṃ desesi.

translated: And he preached the Law.

analyzed: caturāsīti pāṇa sahassāni amatam satthā dhanapālakam pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhāpesi  saḥ soṇḍāya bhagavataḥ pāde paṃsūni gahetvā upari muddhani ākiritvā paṭikuṭitaḥ iva paṭikkamitvā
translated: eighty-four thousand living beings drank of the deathless draught. The Teacher established Dhanapāla in the Five Precepts.🔽With his trunk he gathered up the dust from the feet of the Teacher and scattered it over his own head. Then he turned about and went back to the elephant stable.

analyzed: dassana upacāre ṭhitaḥ dasabalam vanditvā nivattitvā hatthi sālam pāvisi tatas paṭṭhāya  dantasudantaḥ hutvā na kañci viheṭheti satthā nipphanna manorathaḥ yehi yam dhanam

analyzed: khittam tesañca eva tam hotu uti adhiṭṭhāya ajja mayā mahantam pāṭihāriyam katam
translated: he was no longer a maneater, but harmed no one. The Teacher, having accomplished his purpose, thought to himself, “Let the wealth which these men have thrown away be theirs again.” Having thus resolved, he said, “To-day I have performed a great miracle.

analyzed: imasmin nagare piṇḍāya caraṇam appaṭirūpanti titthiye madditvā bhikkhu saṅgha parivutaḥ
translated: It is not fitting that I should go about the city for alms.” Having thus rebuked the sectarians, he went about the city for alms surrounded by the Congregation of Monks.

analyzed: anna pāna khādanīyam ādāya vihāram gantvā mahādānam pavattayiṃsu  tam divasam sāyanha samaye dhamma sabham pūretvā sannisinnāḥ bhikkhū katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ
translated: and like a king who has won a victory, he left the city and went to the Bamboo Grove. The citizens, taking with them much food and drink and other provisions, went to the monastery and made a great distribution of alms.

analyzed: āvuso āyasmatā ānandena tathāgatassa atthāya attanaḥ jīvitam pariccajantena dukkaram
translated: On that day, in the evening, the monks filled the Hall of Truth and sat down. They began a discussion, saying, “Brethren, the venerable Ānanda has done a difficult thing, in that he has offered his own life for the sake of the Tathāgata.

original: kataṃ, nāḷāgiriṃ disvā satthārā tikkhattuṃ paṭibāhiyamānopi nāpagato, aho dukkarakārako,

original: pucchitvā “imāya nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi ānando tiracchānayoniyaṃ
analyzed: pucchitvā imāya nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi ānandaḥ tiracchānayoniyam
translated: When they told him, he said, “Monks, this is not the first time he has done this. Formerly also he did the same thing, and that, too, in the world of brutes.

original: nibbattopi mamatthāya jīvitaṃ pariccajiyevā”ti vatvā tehi yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: nibbattaḥ api mamatthāya jīvitam pariccajiya iva ati vatvā tehi yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: “Even when reborn as a bird, he gave up his life for my sake.” When they asked him to tell them the story, he related the following:

original: Atīte mahiṃsakaraṭṭhe sāgalanagare sāgalo nāma rājā dhammena rajjaṃ kāresi. Tadā
analyzed: atīte mahiṃsakaraṭṭhe sāgala nagare sāgalaḥ nāma rājā dhammena rajjam kāresi tadā
translated: In the past, in the country of Mahiṃsa, in the city of Sāgala, a king named Sāgala ruled righteously.

original: nagarato avidūre ekasmiṃ nesādagāmake aññataro nesādo pāsehi sakuṇe bandhitvā nagare
analyzed: nagarataḥ avidūre ekasmin nesāda gāmake aññataraḥ nesādaḥ pāsehi sakuṇe bandhitvā nagare
translated: Not far from the city, in a village of fowlers, a certain fowler made his living by catching birds in nets and selling them in the city.

original: vikkiṇanto jīvikaṃ kappesi. Nagarato ca avidūre āvaṭṭato dvādasayojano mānusiyo nāma
analyzed: vikkiṇantaḥ jīvikam kappesi nagarataḥ ca avidūre āvaṭṭataḥ dvādasa yojanaḥ mānusiyaḥ nāma
translated: Not far from the city, twelve leagues in circumference, was a lotus lake named Mānusiya,

original: padumasaro ahosi pañcavaṇṇapadumasañchanno. Tattha nānappakāro sakuṇasaṅgho otari.
analyzed: paduma saraḥ ahosi pañca vaṇṇa paduma sañchanno tattha nānappakāro sakuṇa saṅgho otari
translated: covered with lotuses of five colors. There a multitude of various birds alighted.

original: So nesādo tattha aniyāmena pāse oḍḍesi. Tasmiṃ kāle dhataraṭṭho haṃsarājā channavutihaṃsasahassaparivāro
analyzed: saḥ nesādaḥ tattha aniyāmena pāse oḍḍesi tasmin kāle dhataraṭṭhaḥ haṃsa rājā channavuti haṃsa sahassa parivāro
translated: That fowler set his nets there without regularity. At that time, the king of the swans, named Dhataraṭṭha, with an entourage of ninety-six thousand swans,

original: cittakūṭapabbate suvaṇṇaguhāyaṃ vasati, sumukho nāmassa senāpati ahosi. Athekadivasaṃ
analyzed: cittakūṭa pabbate suvaṇṇaguhāyam vasati sumukhaḥ nāmassa senāpati ahosi atha eka divasam
translated: lived in a golden cave on Cittakūṭa mountain. His general was named Sumukha. One day,🔽some of the swans from that flock went to the Mānusiya lake, and after feeding on the abundant food there,

original: tato haṃsayūthā katipayā suvaṇṇahaṃsā mānusiyaṃ saraṃ gantvā pahūtagocare tasmiṃ
analyzed: tatas haṃsa yūthā katipayā suvaṇṇa haṃsā mānusiyam saram gantvā pahūta gocare tasmin
translated: they returned to the mountain.

original: yathāsukhaṃ vicaritvā suhitā cittakūṭaṃ āgantvā dhataraṭṭhassa ārocesuṃ – “mahārāja,
analyzed: yathāsukham vicaritvā su hitā cittakūṭam āgantvā dhataraṭṭhassa ārocesuṃ mahā rāja
translated: and after they had roamed about as much as they wished, they returned to Cittakūṭa and reported to Dhataraṭṭha, saying, “Your majesty,

original: manussapathe mānusiyo nāma padumasaro sampannagocaro, tattha gocaraṃ gaṇhituṃ gacchāmā”ti.🔽So “manussapatho nāma sāsaṅko sappaṭibhayo, mā vo ruccitthā”ti paṭikkhipitvāpi tehi
analyzed: manussapathe mānusiyaḥ nāma paduma saraḥ sampanna gocaraḥ tattha gocaram gaṇhitum gacchāma ati  saḥ manussapathaḥ nāma sa āsaṅkaḥ sa paṭibhayaḥ mā vaḥ ruccittha ati paṭikkhipitvā api tehi
translated: on the road of men there is a lotus-lake named Paduma, which is well supplied with food. Let us go and get food there.”🔽“The road of men is full of danger and fear. I do not like it,” said he, and refused to go. But they urged him again and again, saying, “If it pleases you, let us go.”

original: punappunaṃ vuccamāno “sace tumhākaṃ ruccati, gacchāmā”ti saparivāro taṃ saraṃ agamāsi.🔽So ākāsā otaranto pādaṃ pāse pavesentoyeva otari. Athassa pāso pādaṃ ayapaṭṭakena
analyzed: punappunam vuccamānaḥ sace tumhākam ruccati gacchāma ati sa parivāraḥ tam saram agamāsi  saḥ ākāsā otarantaḥ pādam pāse pavesentaḥ yā iva otari athassa pāsaḥ pādam
translated: So he went to the lake with his retinue.🔽As he descended from the air, he put his foot into the noose and descended. Then the noose, as if it were a strap of iron,

original: kaḍḍhanto viya ābandhitvā gaṇhi. Athassa “chindissāmi na”nti ākaḍḍhantassa paṭhamavāre
analyzed: kaḍḍhantaḥ viya ābandhitvā gaṇhi athassa chindissāmi nanti ākaḍḍhantassa paṭhama vāre
translated: bound his foot and held him fast. Then he thought, “I will cut it off,” and as he pulled, in the first watch

original: cammaṃ chijji, dutiyavāre maṃsaṃ chijji, tatiyavāre nhāru chijji, pāso aṭṭhiṃ āhacca
analyzed: cammam chijji dutiya vāre maṃsam chijji tatiya vāre nhāru chijji pāsaḥ aṭṭhim āhacca
translated: the skin was cut, in the second watch the flesh was cut, in the third watch the sinews were cut, and the noose remained fastened to the bone.

original: aṭṭhāsi, lohitaṃ pagghari, balavavedanā pavattiṃsu.
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi lohitam pagghari balava vedanā pavattiṃsu
translated: Blood flowed and violent pains arose.

original: So cintesi – “sacāhaṃ baddharavaṃ ravissāmi, ñātakā me utrastā hutvā gocaraṃ aggaṇhitvā
analyzed: saḥ cintesi sacā aham baddha ravam ravissāmi ñātakāḥ me utrastāḥ hutvā gocaram aggaṇhitvā
translated: He thought to himself, “If I utter my cry of distress, my relatives, terrified, will not be able to find their food,

original: chātajjhattāva palāyantā dubbalatāya mahāsamudde patissantī”ti. So vedanaṃ adhivāsetvā
analyzed: chāta ajjhattā ava palāyantāḥ dubbala tāya mahā samudde patissanti iti saḥ vedanam adhivāsetvā
translated: and, being faint, will fall into the great ocean.” So he endured the pain,

original: ñātīnaṃ yāvadatthaṃ caritvā haṃsānaṃ kīḷanakāle mahantena saddena baddharavaṃ ravi.
analyzed: ñātīnam yāvadattham caritvā haṃsānam kīḍana kāle mahantena saddena baddha ravam ravi
translated: and, after his relatives had fed to their satisfaction, he uttered his cry of distress with a loud voice, at the time when the swans were disporting themselves.

original: Taṃ sutvā te haṃsā maraṇabhayatajjitā vaggavaggā hutvā cittakūṭābhimukhā pakkamiṃsu.
analyzed: tam sutvā te haṃsāḥ maraṇa bhaya tajjitāḥ vagga vaggāḥ hutvā cittakūṭa abhimukhāḥ pakkamiṃsu
translated: Hearing this cry, the swans, terrified at the thought of death, flew away in flocks, in the direction of Cittakūṭa.

original: Tesu pakkantesu sumukho haṃsasenāpati “kacci nu kho idaṃ bhayaṃ mahārājassa uppannaṃ,
analyzed: tesu pakkantesu sumukhaḥ haṃsa senāpati kacci nu kho idam bhayam mahā rājassa uppannaṃ
translated: When they had flown away, Sumukha, the leader of the swans, thought, “I wonder if this danger has befallen the king;

original: jānissāmi na”nti vegena pakkhanditvā purato gacchantassa haṃsagaṇassa antare mahāsattaṃ
analyzed: jānissāmi nanti vegena pakkhanditvā puratas gacchantassa haṃsa gaṇassa antare mahāsattam
translated: I will find out.” So he flew swiftly and entered the midst of the flock of swans flying in front.🔽He did not see the Great Being there, and so he searched the middle flock, and there also he did not see him.

original: adisvā majjhimahaṃsagaṇaṃ vicini, tatthapi adisvā pacchimahaṃsagaṇaṃ vicini, tatthapi
analyzed: a disvā majjhima haṃsa gaṇam vicini a disvā pacchima haṃsa gaṇam vicini tatthapi
translated: Then he searched the rear flock, and there also he did not see him.

original: adisvā “nissaṃsayaṃ tassevedaṃ bhayaṃ uppanna”nti nivattitvā āgacchanto mahāsattaṃ
analyzed: a disvā nissaṃsayam tassa iva idam bhayam uppannanti nivattitvā āgacchantaḥ mahāsattam
translated: Then he thought, “Without doubt, this danger has befallen him.” So he turned back and came to the Great Being.

original: pāse baddhaṃ lohitamakkhitaṃ dukkhāturaṃ paṅkapiṭṭhe nipannaṃ disvā “mā bhāyi, mahārāja,
analyzed: pāse baddham lohita makkhitam dukkha āturam paṅka piṭṭhe nipannam disvā mā bhāyi mahā rāja
translated: and saw the king bound in the net, covered with blood, and lying on his back in the mud, suffering great pain. Seeing him, he said, “Do not fear, great king.

original: ahaṃ mama jīvitaṃ pariccajitvā tumhe pāsato mocessāmī”ti vadanto otaritvā mahāsattaṃ
analyzed: aham mama jīvitam pariccajitvā tumhe pāsataḥ mocessāmi iti vadantaḥ otaritvā mahāsattam
translated: I will give up my life and set you free from the net.” Saying this, he descended and sat down on the mud,

original: assāsentova paṅkapiṭṭhe nisīdi. Atha naṃ vīmaṃsanto mahāsatto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: assāsentaḥ iva paṅka piṭṭhe nisīdi atha nam vīmaṃsantaḥ mahāsatto paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: and comforted the Great Being. Then the Great Being, testing him, spoke the first stanza:

original: “Sumukha anupacinantā, pakkamanti vihaṅgamā;
analyzed: su mukha an upacinantā pakkamanti vihaṅgamā
translated: “The birds fly away, O Susima, without a backward glance;

original: Gaccha tuvampi mā kaṅkhi, natthi baddhe sahāyatā”ti.🔽Tattha anupacinantāti sinehena ālayavasena anolokentā. Pakkamantīti ete channavuti🔽haṃsasahassā ñātivihaṅgamā maṃ chaḍḍetvā gacchanti, tvampi gaccha, mā idha vāsaṃ🔽ākaṅkhi, evañhi pāsena baddhe mayi sahāyatā nāma natthi, na hi te ahaṃ idāni kiñci
analyzed: gaccha tuvam pi mā kaṅkhi natthi baddhe sahāya tā ati  tattha anupacinantā ati sinehena ālaya vasena anolokentā pakkamanti iti ete channavuti  haṃsa sahassāḥ ñāti vihaṅgamāḥ mam chaḍḍetvā gacchanti tvam pi gaccha mā idha vāsam  ākaṅkhi evañhi pāsena baddhe mayi sahāya tā nāma natthi na hi te aham idāni kiñci
translated: Go thou also, and do not tarry, for there is no friendship with the bound.”

original: sahāyakiccaṃ kātuṃ sakkhissāmi, kiṃ te mayā nirūpakārena, papañcaṃ akatvā gacchevāti vadati.
analyzed: sahāya kiccam kātum sakkhissāmi kim te mayā nirūpakārena a katvā gaccha iva iti vadati
translated: Herein, without a backward glance means without looking back out of affection. They fly away means these eighty-four thousand geese, my kinsmen and my companions, have abandoned me and flown away. You also go, do not wish to stay here. For there is no friendship with me who am bound in the net. I shall not be able to do anything for you now as a friend. What use is it to you that I should remain here? Do not make a fuss. Go away.

original: Ito paraṃ –
analyzed: i taḥ param
translated: From here on:

original: “Gacche vāhaṃ na vā gacche, na tena amaro siyaṃ;
analyzed: gacche vā aham na vā gacche na tena amaraḥ siyam
translated: “Whether I go or whether I do not go, I will not become immortal thereby.

original: Sukhitaṃ taṃ upāsitvā, dukkhitaṃ taṃ kathaṃ jahe.
analyzed: sukhitam tam upāsitvā dukkhitam tam katham jahe
translated: Having served you when you are happy, how can I abandon you when you are unhappy?

original: “Maraṇaṃ vā tayā saddhiṃ, jīvitaṃ vā tayā vinā;
analyzed: maraṇam vā tayā saddhim jīvitam vā tayā vinā
translated: “Whether I die with you or live without you,

original: Tadeva maraṇaṃ seyyo, yañce jīve tayā vinā.
analyzed: tat eva maraṇam seyyaḥ yat ce jīve tayā vinā
translated: That very death is better for me than that I should live without you.

original: “Nesa dhammo mahārāja, yaṃ taṃ evaṃ gataṃ jahe;
analyzed: na isa dhammaḥ mahā rāja yam tam evam gatam jahe
translated: “This is not the way, great king, that you should abandon him who has come to you thus.

original: Yā gati tuyhaṃ sā mayhaṃ, ruccate vihagādhipa.
analyzed: yā tuyham sā mayham ruccate vihaga adhipa
translated: Whatever your fate, lord of birds, that is acceptable to me.”

original: “Kā nu pāsena baddhassa, gati aññā mahānasā;
analyzed: kā nu pāsena baddhassa gati aññā mahānasā
translated: “What other course is there for one bound with a snare, great king,

original: Sā kathaṃ cetayānassa, muttassa tava ruccati.
analyzed: sā katham cetayānassa muttassa tava ruccati
translated: Than that which is acceptable to you, who are free, when you reflect?”

original: “Kaṃ vā tvaṃ passase atthaṃ, mama tuyhañca pakkhima;
analyzed: kam vā tvam passase attham mama tuyham ca pakkhima
translated: “What benefit do you see for me and for you, bird,

original: Ñātīnaṃ vāvasiṭṭhānaṃ, ubhinnaṃ jīvitakkhaye.
analyzed: ñātīnam ubhinnam jīvita khaye
translated: Or for the remaining kinsmen, when the lives of both are destroyed?”🔽“What purpose does it serve to light a lamp

original: “Yaṃ na kañcanadepiñcha, andhena tamasā gataṃ;
analyzed: yam na kañcana depiñcha andhena tamasā gatam
translated: When the blind have gone in the darkness?🔽In such a case, when life is destroyed,

original: Tādise sañcajaṃ pāṇaṃ, kamatthamabhijotaye.
analyzed: tādise sañcajam pāṇam kamattham abhijotaye
translated: what is the use of lighting a lamp?”

original: “Kathaṃ nu patataṃ seṭṭha, dhamme atthaṃ na bujjhasi;
analyzed: katham nu patatam seṭṭha dhamme attham na bujjhasi
translated: “How is it, best of fliers, that you do not understand the benefit in the Dhamma

original: Dhammo apacito santo, atthaṃ dasseti pāṇinaṃ.
analyzed: dhammaḥ apacitaḥ santaḥ attham dasseti pāṇinam
translated: When the Dhamma is honoured, it shows the benefit to living beings.

original: “Sohaṃ dhammaṃ apekkhāno, dhammā catthaṃ samuṭṭhitaṃ;
analyzed: so ham dhammam apekkhānaḥ dhammā cattham samuṭṭhitam
translated: “I, looking to the Dhamma, the Dhamma that has arisen in you,

original: Bhattiñca tayi sampassaṃ, nāvakaṅkhāmi jīvitaṃ.
analyzed: bhattiñca tayi sampassam na avakaṅkhāmi jīvitaṃ
translated: and seeing your devotion to me, do not despair of life.

original: 10. “Addhā eso sataṃ dhammo, yo mitto mittamāpade.
analyzed: addhā esaḥ satam dhammaḥ yaḥ mittaḥ mitta āpade
translated: “Surely this is the true Dhamma, that a friend should help a friend.

original: Na caje jīvitassāpi, hetudhammamanussaraṃ.
analyzed: na caje jīvitassa api hetu dhammam anussaram
translated: I will not abandon you, remembering the reason for the Dhamma.

original: “Svāyaṃ dhammo ca te ciṇṇo, bhatti ca viditā mayi;
analyzed: svāyam dhammaḥ ca te ciṇṇaḥ ca viditā mayi
translated: “This Dhamma has been practiced by you, and your devotion to me is known.

original: Kāmaṃ karassu mayhetaṃ, gacchevānumato mayā.
analyzed: kāmam karassu mayha etam gaccha iva anumataḥ mayā
translated: Do what you want with me, go, I give my consent.”

original: “Api tvevaṃ gate kāle, yaṃ khaṇḍaṃ ñātinaṃ mayā;
analyzed: api tu evam gate kāle yam khaṇḍam ñātinam mayā
translated: “But if you go at this time, whatever is left of me among my relatives

original: Tayā taṃ buddhisampannaṃ, assa paramasaṃvutaṃ.
analyzed: tayā tam buddhi sampannam assa parama saṃvutam
translated: will be yours, you who are endowed with wisdom, you who are most restrained.”

original: “Iccevaṃ mantayantānaṃ, ariyānaṃ ariyavuttinaṃ;
analyzed: icca ivam mantayantānam ariyānam ariya vuttinam
translated: “Thus as the noble ones were consulting, those of noble conduct,

original: Paccadissatha nesādo, āturānamivantako.
analyzed: paccadissatha nesādaḥ ātura ānamivantako
translated: a hunter was seen by them, like a disease to the afflicted.

original: “Te sattumabhisañcikkha, dīgharattaṃ hitā dijā;
analyzed: te sattum abhisañcikkha dīgharattam hitāḥ dijā
translated: “He considered the bird, for the sake of the long-lived birds.

original: Tuṇhīmāsittha ubhayo, na sañcalesumāsanā.
analyzed: ubhayaḥ na
translated: Both of them sat in silence, they did not move from their seats.

original: “Dhataraṭṭhe ca disvāna, samuḍḍente tato tato;
analyzed: dhataraṭṭhe ca disvāna samuḍḍente tatas tatas
translated: “And having seen Dhataraṭṭha, they scattered in all directions.

original: Abhikkhamatha vegena, dijasattu dijādhipe.
analyzed: vegena dijasattu dija adhipe
translated: The bird-enemy advanced quickly, the lord of the birds.

original: “So ca vegenabhikkamma, āsajja parame dije;
analyzed: saḥ ca āsajja parame dije
translated: “And he, having advanced quickly, having attacked the supreme bird,

original: Paccakamittha nesādo, baddhā iti vicintayaṃ.
analyzed: paccakam ittha nesādaḥ baddhāḥ iti
translated: The fowler thought: “I have caught the bird, and he is thinking: ‘I have caught the fowler.’

original: “Ekaṃva baddhamāsīnaṃ, abaddhañca punāparaṃ;
analyzed: ekam iva baddham āsīnam a baddham ca punar aparam
translated: “One is bound, sitting down; another is free, but sitting down.

original: Āsajja baddhamāsīnaṃ, pekkhamānamadīnavaṃ.
analyzed: āsajja baddham āsīnam pekkhamānam adīnavam
translated: The bound one is sitting down, looking at the free one, with fear.

original: “Tato so vimatoyeva, paṇḍare ajjhabhāsatha;
analyzed: tatas saḥ vimatoyā iva paṇḍare ajjhabhāsatha
translated: “Then the white bird, full of doubt, spoke to the one sitting with his body extended:

original: Pavaḍḍhakāye āsīne, dijasaṅghagaṇādhipe.
analyzed: pavaḍḍha kāye āsīne dija saṅgha gaṇa adhipe
translated: ‘You are the king of the flock of birds, the lord of the flock of birds.’

original: “Yaṃ nu pāsena mahatā, baddho na kurute disaṃ;
analyzed: yam nu pāsena mahatā baddhaḥ na kurute disam
translated: “‘Why is it that one bound by a great snare does not go in any direction,

original: Atha kasmā abaddho tvaṃ, balī pakkhi na gacchasi.
analyzed: atha kasmai a baddhaḥ tvam balī pakkhi na gacchasi
translated: but you, free, do not go, though you are strong, bird?’

original: “Kiṃ nu tyāyaṃ dijo hoti, mutto baddhaṃ upāsasi;
analyzed: kim nu tyāyam dijaḥ muttaḥ baddham upāsasi
translated: “‘Why is it that you, a bird, are free, and attend on the bound one?

original: Ohāya sakuṇā yanti, kiṃ eko avahīyasi.
analyzed: ohāya sakuṇāḥ yanti kim ekaḥ avahīyasi
translated: The birds fly away; why do you alone not fly away?’

original: “Rājā me so dijāmitta, sakhā pāṇasamo ca me;
analyzed: rājā me saḥ dija amitta sakhā pāṇa samaḥ ca me
translated: “‘He is my king, my friend, my companion, dear as life to me,

original: Neva naṃ vijahissāmi, yāva kālassa pariyāyaṃ.
analyzed: na iva nam vijahissāmi yāva kālassa pariyāyam
translated: I will not abandon him until the time comes.’

original: “Kathaṃ panāyaṃ vihaṅgo, nāddasa pāsamoḍḍitaṃ;
analyzed: katham pana ayam vihaṅgaḥ na āddasa pāsam oḍḍitam
translated: “‘But how is it that this bird did not see the snare stretched out?

original: Padañhetaṃ mahantānaṃ, boddhumarahanti āpadaṃ.
analyzed: padam ha etam mahantānam boddhum arahanti āpadam
translated: This is the way of the great: they are able to understand a danger.

original: “Yadā parābhavo hoti, poso jīvitasaṅkhaye;
analyzed: yadā parābhavaḥ posaḥ jīvita saṅkhaye
translated: “‘When a man is in misfortune, when his life is coming to an end,

original: Atha jālañca pāsañca, āsajjāpi na bujjhati.
analyzed: atha jālam ca pāsañca āsajja api na bujjhati
translated: then he does not even notice the net and the snare when he enters them.’

original: “Api tveva mahāpañña, pāsā bahuvidhā tatā;
analyzed: api tu eva mahāpañña pāsā bahuvidhā tatā
translated: “But if, O you of great wisdom, the snares are many and various,

original: Guyhamāsajja bajjhanti, athevaṃ jīvitakkhaye”ti. –
analyzed: guyham āsajja bajjhanti atha evam jīvitakkhayā iti
translated: They catch one who has gone too far, and then at life’s end.”

original: Imāsaṃ gāthānaṃ sambandho pāḷinayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: imāsam gāthānam sambandhaḥ pāḷi nayena iva veditabbo
translated: The connection of these verses should be understood according to the method of the text.

original: Tattha gacche vāti, mahārāja, ahaṃ ito gaccheyyaṃ vā na vā, nāhaṃ tena gamanena vā
analyzed: tattha gacche vāti mahā rāja aham itas gaccheyyam vā na vā na aham tena gamanena vā
translated: Herein, “I would go,” etc., means: “Great king, whether I go from here or not, I will not become immortal by that going or

translated: Thus, by means of this conversation, he made the king’s heart soft and, asking for the life of the Great Being, he spoke this verse:

translated: “Is it not the case that he lived happily with you,

translated: Thus, with a heart that had become soft like cotton wool that has been sprinkled with water, the king, having made over his kingdom to the Great Being, said:

analyzed: ajjhabhāsatha vakkaṅgam vācam kaṇṇa sukham bhaṇanti
translated: addressed the hunter, speaking words that were sweet as honey.”

original: Atha mahāsatto rañño dhammaṃ desesi. So tassa dhammakathaṃ sutvā tuṭṭhahadayo “dhammakathikassa sakkāraṃ karissāmī”ti setacchattaṃ datvā rajjaṃ paṭicchāpento āha –
analyzed: atha mahāsattaḥ raññaḥ dhammam desesi saḥ tassa dhamma katham sutvā tuṭṭha hadayaḥ dhamma kathikassa sakkāram karissāmi iti seta chattam datvā rajjam paṭicchāpentaḥ āha
translated: Then the Great Being preached the Law to the king. The king, having listened to his discourse on the Law, was filled with joy and said, “I will show honor to the preacher of the Law,” and having given him a white parasol, he abdicated the throne in his favor, saying,

original: “Yaṃ khalu dhammamādhīnaṃ, vaso vattati kiñcanaṃ;
analyzed: yam khalu dhammam ādhīnam vaso vattati kiñcanam
translated: “Whatever Law there is that is dependent on me, let it be yours.”

original: Sabbatthissariyaṃ bhavataṃ, pasāsatha yadicchatha.
analyzed: sabbatthissariyam bhavatam pasāsatha yat icchatha
translated: “All sovereignty is yours; be pleased to do whatever you desire.”

original: “Dānatthaṃ upabhottuṃ vā, yaṃ caññaṃ upakappati;
analyzed: dāna attham upabhottum vā yam caññam upakappati
translated: “For the sake of charity or for enjoyment, or whatever else you may require,

original: Etaṃ dadāmi vo vittaṃ, issariyaṃ vissajāmi vo”ti.
analyzed: etam dadāmi vaḥ vittam issariyam vissajāmi vaḥ ti
translated: I give you this wealth; I surrender to you all sovereignty.”

original: Tattha vaso vattatīti yattha mama vaso vattati. Kiñcananti taṃ appamattakampi. Sabbatthissariyanti
analyzed: tattha vasaḥ vattati iti yattha mama vasaḥ vattati kiñcana nti tam appamattakam pi
translated: “Where my sovereignty extends,” said the king, “I give you all that is there, even though it be but little.

original: sabbaṃ bhavataṃyeva issariyaṃ atthu. Yaṃ caññaṃ upakappatīti puññakāmatāya dānatthaṃ
analyzed: sabbam bhavataṃyeva issariyam atthu yam caññam upakappati iti puñña kāmatāya dāna attham
translated: All sovereignty is yours. For the sake of charity,

original: vā chattaṃ ussāpetvā rajjameva upabhottuṃ vā yaṃ vā aññaṃ tumhākaṃ ruccati, taṃ karotha,
analyzed: vā chattam ussāpetvā rajjam eva upabhottum vā yam vā aññam tumhākam ruccati tam karotha
translated: or for enjoyment, or whatever else you may require, do you perform it.

original: etaṃ dadāmi vo vittaṃ, saddhiṃyeva setacchattena mama santakaṃ issariyaṃ vissajjāmi voti.🔽Atha mahāsatto raññā dinnaṃ setacchattaṃ puna tasseva adāsi. Rājāpi cintesi – “haṃsarañño
analyzed: etam dadāmi vaḥ vittam saddhiṃyā iva seta chattena mama santakam issariyam vissajjāmi vā uti  atha mahāsattaḥ raññā dinnam seta chattam puna tassa iva adāsi rājā api cintesi haṃsa rañño
translated: I give you this wealth, together with the white parasol; I surrender to you all sovereignty that is mine.”

original: tāva me dhammakathā sutā, luddaputtena pana ‘ayaṃ sumukho mudhurakatho’ti ativiya
analyzed: tāva me dhamma kathā sutā ludda puttena pana ayam sumukhaḥ mudhura kathā iti ativiya
translated: Then the Great Being gave back to the king the white parasol which the king had given to him. The king thought to himself, “From the king of the swans I have heard a discourse on righteousness, but from the son of the fowler I have heard nothing.🔽“Sumukha is a sweet talker,” said the king to himself, “but he is a fool.”

original: vaṇṇito, imassapi dhammakathaṃ sossāmī”ti. So tena saddhiṃ sallapanto anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: vaṇṇitaḥ imassa api dhamma katham sossāmi iti saḥ tena saddhim sallapantaḥ anantaram gātham āha
translated: “He is praised. I will listen to his Dhamma talk.” As he was conversing with him, he spoke the next verse:

original: “Yathā ca myāyaṃ sumukho, ajjhabhāseyya paṇḍito;
analyzed: yathā ca myā ayam su mukhaḥ paṇḍitaḥ
translated: “And if this Sumukha, wise,

original: Kāmasā buddhisampanno, taṃ myāssa paramappiya”nti.
analyzed: buddhi sampannaḥ tam
translated: Skilled in speech, were to address me, that would be most dear to me.”

original: Tattha yathāti yadi. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yadi ca me ayaṃ sumukho paṇḍito buddhisampanno kāmasā attano ruciyā ajjhabhāseyya, taṃ me paramappiyaṃ assāti.
analyzed: tattha yathā iti yadi idam vuttam hoti yadi ca me ayam sumukhaḥ paṇḍitaḥ buddhi sampannaḥ kāmasā attanaḥ ruciyā ajjhabhāseyya tam me param appiyam assa ati
translated: Here, “if” means “if this Sumukha, wise, skilled in speech, were to address me of his own accord, that would be most dear to me.”

original: Tato sumukho āha –
analyzed: tatas sumukhaḥ āha
translated: Then Sumukha said:

original: “Ahaṃ khalu mahārāja, nāgarājārivantaraṃ;
analyzed: aham khalu mahā rāja nāga rājā arivantaram
translated: “I, sire, am a nāga king’s enemy;

original: Paṭivattuṃ na sakkomi, na me so vinayo siyā.
analyzed: paṭivattum na sakkomi na me saḥ vinayaḥ siyā
translated: I cannot turn back, that would not be my way.

original: “Amhākañceva so seṭṭho, tvañca uttamasattavo;
analyzed: amhākam ca iva so seṭṭhaḥ tvam ca uttama sattavaḥ
translated: “He is best for us, and you are the best of beings;

original: Bhūmipālo manussindo, pūjā bahūhi hetubhi.
analyzed: bhūmipālaḥ manussindo pūjā bahūhi
translated: You are the lord of the earth, the ruler of men, to be worshipped for many reasons.

original: “Tesaṃ ubhinnaṃ bhaṇataṃ, vattamāne vinicchaye;
analyzed: tesam ubhinnam bhaṇatam vattamāne vinicchaye
translated: “While they were speaking thus, the matter being decided,

original: Nantaraṃ pativattabbaṃ, pessena manujādhipā”ti.
analyzed: nantaram pativattabbam pessena manuja adhipā ti
translated: The messenger should turn back, lord of men.”

original: Tattha nāgarājārivantaranti peḷāya abbhantaraṃ paviṭṭho nāgarājā viya. Paṭivattunti🔽tumhākaṃ dvinnaṃ antare vattuṃ na sakkomi. Na me soti sace vadeyyaṃ, na me so vinayo
analyzed: tattha peḷāya abbhantaram paviṭṭhaḥ nāga rājā viya paṭivattunti  tumhākam dvinnam antare vattum na sakkomi na me saḥ uti sace vadeyyam na me so vinayo
translated: “As a king of the nāgas is hidden in the interior of a tree trunk,”—that is, as a king of the nāgas is hidden in the interior of a tree trunk. “I cannot speak between you two,”—

original: bhaveyya. Amhākañcevāti channavutiyā haṃsasahassānaṃ. Uttamasattavoti uttamasatto.
analyzed: bhaveyya amhākam ca eva ati channavutiyā haṃsa sahassānam uttama sattavā ti uttama satto
translated: “If I were to say, ‘It is not the rule,’ it would not be the rule for me. And for us,”—that is, for the ninety-six thousand geese. “The best of beings,”—the best of creatures.

original: Pūjāti ubho tumhe mayhaṃ bahūhi kāraṇehi pūjārahā ceva pasaṃsārahā ca. Pessenāti
analyzed: ubho tumhe mayham bahūhi kāraṇehi pūjā rahā ca iva pasaṃsā rahā ca pessena ati
translated: “Worship,”—both of you are worthy of worship and praise for many reasons by me. “A servant,”—

original: veyyāvaccakarena sevakena.
analyzed: veyyāvaccakarena sevakena
translated: a servant who is a messenger.

original: Rājā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā tuṭṭhahadayo “nesādaputto taṃ vaṇṇeti, na aññena tumhādisena madhuradhammakathikena nāma bhavitabba”nti vatvā āha –
analyzed: rājā tassa vacanam sutvā tuṭṭha hadayaḥ nesāda putto tam vaṇṇeti na aññena tumha ādisena madhura dhamma kathikena nāma bhavitabbanti vatvā āha
translated: Having heard his words, the king, with a delighted heart, “The son of the hunter praises him, not by another like you, a sweet-voiced speaker,” saying so, he said:

original: “Dhammena kira nesādo, paṇḍito aṇḍajo iti;
analyzed: dhammena kira nesādaḥ paṇḍitaḥ aṇḍajaḥ iti
translated: “By the rule, it seems, the hunter, the wise one, is born from an egg;

original: Naheva akatattassa, nayo etādiso siyā.
analyzed: nahā iva a katattassa nayaḥ etādisaḥ siyā
translated: Not only for one who has not done, such a rule could be.

original: “Evaṃ aggapakatimā, evaṃ uttamasattavo;
analyzed: evam agga pakatimāḥ evam uttama sattavaḥ
translated: “Thus having the best of virtues, thus the best of beings,

original: Yāvatatthi mayā diṭṭhā, nāññaṃ passāmi edisaṃ.
analyzed: yāvatatthi mayā diṭṭhā na aññam passāmi edisam
translated: As far as I have seen, I do not see anyone like this.

original: “Tuṭṭhosmi vo pakatiyā, vākyena madhurena ca;
analyzed: tuṭṭhaḥ asmi vaḥ pakatiyā vākyena madhurena ca
translated: “I am pleased with you, both of you, by your natural disposition and by your sweet words;

original: Eso cāpi mamacchando, ciraṃ passeyya vo ubho”ti.
analyzed: eso ca api mamacchandaḥ ciram passeyya vaḥ ubho ti
translated: And this is my desire: I would like to see you both for a long time.”

original: Tattha dhammenāti sabhāvena kāraṇena. Akatattassāti asampāditaattabhāvassa mittadubbhissa.
analyzed: tattha dhammena ati sabhāvena kāraṇena a katattassa ati a sampādita atta bhāvassa mitta dubbhissa
translated: Herein, by the natural disposition means by the nature of the reason. Not yet fulfilled means not yet completed in the body.

original: Nayoti paññā. Aggapakatimāti aggasabhāvo. Uttamasattavoti uttamasatto. Yāvatatthīti
analyzed: paññā agga pakatimā ati agga sabhāvaḥ uttama sattavaḥ iti uttama sattaḥ yāvatatthi iti
translated: Wisdom means understanding. The highest state means the highest nature. The best being means the best creature. As far as there is means

original: yāvatā mayā diṭṭhā nāma atthi. Nāññanti tasmiṃ mayā diṭṭhaṭṭhāne aññaṃ evarūpaṃ na🔽passāmi. Tuṭṭhosmi vo pakatiyāti samma haṃsarāja ahaṃ pakatiyā paṭhamameva tumhākaṃ
analyzed: yāvatā mayā diṭṭhā nāma atthi na aññanti tasmin mayā diṭṭha ṭṭhāne aññam evarūpam na  passāmi tuṭṭhaḥ asmi vaḥ pakatiyā ati samma haṃsa rāja aham pakatiyā paṭhamam eva tumhākam
translated: as far as there is a name for me seeing. I do not see any other means

original: dassanena tuṭṭho. Vākyenāti idāni pana vo madhuravacanena tuṭṭhosmi. Ciraṃ passeyya
analyzed: dassanena tuṭṭhaḥ vākyena ati idāni pana vaḥ madhura vacanena tuṭṭhaḥ asmi ciram passeyya
translated: I do not see any other such in the place I have seen. I am pleased with you, both of you, by your natural disposition means, “Good king of geese, I am pleased with you both by my natural disposition, by seeing you for the first time.” By your sweet words means “Now I am pleased with you by your sweet words.” I would like to see you both for a long time means

original: voti idheva vasāpetvā muhuttampi avippavāsanto ciraṃ tumhe passeyyanti esa me chandoti vadati.
analyzed: vo ti idha iva vasāpetvā muhuttam pi a vippavāsanto ciram tumhe passeyyanti esa me chandaḥ ti vadati
translated: “Having settled you here, not being separated from you even for a moment, I would like to see you both for a long time.” This is my desire, he says.

original: Tato mahāsatto rājānaṃ pasaṃsanto āha –
analyzed: tatas mahāsattaḥ rājānam pasaṃsantaḥ āha
translated: Then the Great Being, praising the king, said:

original: “Yaṃ kiccaṃ parame mitte, katamasmāsu taṃ tayā;
analyzed: yam kiccam parame mitte katamasmāsu tam tayā
translated: “Whatever service to you, friend, should be done by us, that you have done to us;

original: Pattā nissaṃsayaṃ tyāmhā, bhattirasmāsu yā tava.
analyzed: pattā nissaṃsayam bhattiḥ asmāsu yā tava
translated: We have attained you without doubt, you are our benefactress.”

original: “Aduñca nūna sumahā, ñātisaṅghassa mantaraṃ;
analyzed: aduñca nūna su mahā ñāti saṅghassa mantaram
translated: “Surely it is a great loss to the great assembly of kinsmen,

original: Adassanena asmākaṃ, dukkhaṃ bahūsu pakkhisu.
analyzed: a dassanena asmākam dukkham bahūsu pakkhisu
translated: That we are not seen by them, there are many birds here.”

original: “Tesaṃ sokavighātāya, tayā anumatā mayaṃ;
analyzed: tesam soka vighātāya tayā anumatāḥ mayam
translated: “For the dispelling of their sorrow, we are approved by you;

original: Taṃ padakkhiṇato katvā, ñātiṃ passemurindama.
analyzed: tam padakkhiṇatas katvā ñātim passemuḥ indama
translated: Having done homage to that kinsman, we will see the lord of birds.”

original: “Addhāhaṃ vipulaṃ pītiṃ, bhavataṃ vindāmi dassanā;
analyzed: addhā aham vipulam pītim bhavatam vindāmi dassanā
translated: “Surely I find great joy in seeing you,

original: Eso cāpi mahā attho, ñātivissāsanā siyā”ti.🔽Tattha katamasmāsūti kataṃ amhesu. Pattā nissaṃsayaṃ tyāmhāti mayaṃ nissaṃsayena
analyzed: eso ca api mahā attho ñāti vissāsanā siyāti  tattha katam asmāsu iti katam amhesu pattā nissaṃsayam mayam nissaṃsayena
translated: And this great matter may be the release of the kinsmen.”

original: tayā pattāyeva. Bhattirasmāsu yā tavāti yā tava amhesu bhatti, tāya bhattiyā mayaṃ
analyzed: tayā pattāya iva bhattiḥ asmāsu yā tava ati yā tava amhesu bhatti tāya bhattiyā mayam
translated: Herein, katamasmāsū means done by us. Pattā nissaṃsayaṃ tyāmhāti we have attained you without doubt. Bhattirasmāsu yā tavāti the benefaction that you have to us, by that benefaction we are not

original: tayā asaṃsayena pattāyeva, na ca vippayuttā, vippavuṭṭhāpi sahavāsinoyeva nāma mayanti
analyzed: tayā asaṃsayena pattāya iva na ca vippayuttā vippavuṭṭhā api sahavāsino yā iva nāma
translated: without doubt attained by you, and we are not disjoined, we are called co-dwellers even though we are separated.

original: dīpeti. Aduñca nūna sumahāti etañca ekaṃseneva sumahantaṃ. Ñātisaṅghassa mantaranti🔽amhehi dvīhi janehi virahitassa mama ñātisaṅghassa antaraṃ chiddaṃ. Asmākanti amhākaṃ🔽dvinnaṃ adassanena bahūsu pakkhīsu dukkhaṃ uppannaṃ. Passemurindamāti passeyyāma
analyzed: dīpeti etañca ekaṃsena iva su mahantam ñāti saṅghassa mantaranti  amhehi dvīhi janehi virahitassa mama ñāti saṅghassa antaram chiddam asmākan ti amhākam  dvinnam a dassanena bahūsu pakkhīsu dukkham uppannam passemuḥ indama ati passeyyāma
translated: and the great grief of the multitude of kinsmen.🔽The multitude of kinsmen, deprived of us two, will be rent in twain.

original: arindama. Bhavatanti bhoto dassanena. Eso cāpi mahā atthoti yā esā ñātisaṅghasaṅkhātā
analyzed: arindama bhavatanti bhotaḥ dassanena esaḥ ca api mahā atthaḥ ti yā esā ñāti saṅgha saṅkhātā
translated: On account of our absence, great grief will arise among the many birds.🔽We will behold the king of the birds.🔽By beholding you, O king,

original: ñātivissāsanā siyā, eso cāpi mahanto atthopi.
analyzed: ñāti vissāsanā siyā eso ca api mahantaḥ attho pi
translated: this great benefit will accrue.🔽This great benefit will accrue to the multitude of kinsmen, who will be freed from their anxiety.🔽When this had been said, the king gave his consent to their departure.

original: Evaṃ vutte rājā tesaṃ gamanaṃ anujāni. Mahāsattopi rañño pañcavidhe dussīlye ādīnavaṃ,🔽sīle ca ānisaṃsaṃ kathetvā “imaṃ sīlaṃ rakkha, dhammena rajjaṃ kārehi, catūhi saṅgahavatthūhi🔽janaṃ saṅgaṇhāhī”ti ovaditvā cittakūṭaṃ agamāsi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: evam vutte rājā tesam gamanam anujāni mahāsattaḥ api rañño pañcavidhe dussīlye ādīnavam  sīle ca ānisaṃsam kathetvā imam sīlam rakkha dhammena rajjam kārehi catūhi saṅgaha vatthūhi  janam saṅgaṇhāhi iti ovaditvā cittakūṭam agamāsi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: The Great Being, after pointing out to the king the danger in the five kinds of unrighteousness,🔽and the advantage of righteousness, admonished him, saying, “Keep this righteousness, rule your kingdom righteously, and gather men about you by means of the four means of gathering a retinue.”

original: “Idaṃ vatvā dhataraṭṭho, haṃsarājā narādhipaṃ;
analyzed: idam vatvā dhataraṭṭhaḥ haṃsa rājā narādhipam
translated: Having thus admonished him, he went to Citrakūṭa. Expounding this matter, the Teacher said:

original: Uttamaṃ javamanvāya, ñātisaṅghaṃ upāgamuṃ.
analyzed: uttamam javam anvāya ñāti saṅgham upāgamum
translated: And, having gone with utmost speed, we came to our kinsmen’s flock.

original: “Te aroge anuppatte, disvāna parame dije;
analyzed: te aroge anuppatte disvāna parame dije
translated: “When they saw that we had come back safe and sound,

original: Kekāti makaruṃ haṃsā, puthusaddo ajāyatha.
analyzed: makarum haṃsā ajāyatha
translated: the geese cried out ‘Kek!’ and a general sound arose.

original: “Te patītā pamuttena, bhattunā bhattugāravā;
analyzed: te patītā pamuttena bhattunā bhattu gāravā
translated: “When we had alighted, out of respect for our host,

original: Samantā parikiriṃsu, aṇḍajā laddhapaccayā”ti.🔽Tattha upāgamunti aruṇuggamanavelāyameva lājamadhuphāṇitādīni paribhuñjitvā raññā
analyzed: samantā parikiriṃsu aṇḍajāḥ laddha paccayā ati  tattha upāgamunti lāja madhu phāṇita ādīni paribhuñjitvā raññā
translated: we surrounded him on all sides, we egg-born ones who had gained our ends.”

original: ca deviyā ca dvīhi suvaṇṇatālavaṇṭehi ukkhipitvā gandhamālādīhi katasakkārā tālavaṇṭehi🔽otaritvā rājānaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā vehāsaṃ uppatitvā raññā añjaliṃ paggayha “gacchatha
analyzed: ca deviyā ca dvīhi suvaṇṇa tāla vaṇṭehi ukkhipitvā gandha mālā ādīhi kata sakkārā tāla vaṇṭehi  otaritvā rājānam padakkhiṇam katvā vehāsam uppatitvā raññā añjalim paggayha gacchatha
translated: Herein, we came means that at the time of dawn they ate flour, honey, molasses, and so on, and then the king and the queen lifted them up with two golden poles, and they were honoured with perfumes, garlands, and so on.🔽After descending from the poles, they circumambulated the king clockwise, rose up into the air, raised their joined palms to the king, and said, “Go, lords,

original: sāmino”ti vutte sīhapañjarena nikkhantā uttamena javena gantvā ñātigaṇaṃ upāgamiṃsu.
analyzed: sāminā iti vutte sīha pañjarena nikkhantāḥ uttamena javena gantvā ñāti gaṇam upāgamiṃsu
translated: and when the king said, “Go and see your kinsmen,” they went out through the lion-door and, going with utmost speed, came to their kinsmen’s flock.

original: Parameti uttame. Kekāti attano sabhāvena “kekā”ti saddamakaṃsu. Bhattugāravāti bhattari
analyzed: paramā iti uttame kekā ati attano sabhāvena kekā ati bhattari
translated: Utmost means best. They cried out “Kek!” means they made a sound of “Kek!” according to their own nature. Out of respect for our host means out of respect for our host, the king.

original: sagāravā. Parikiriṃsūti bhattuno muttabhāvena tuṭṭhā taṃ bhattāraṃ samantā parivārayiṃsu.
analyzed: sa gāravā bhattunaḥ mutta bhāvena tuṭṭhā tam bhattāram samantā parivārayiṃsu
translated: and with great respect. They surrounded him, means that being pleased with the freedom of their master, they surrounded him on all sides.

original: Laddhapaccayāti laddhapatiṭṭhā.
analyzed: laddha paccayā ati laddha patiṭṭhā
translated: Having obtained the conditions, means having obtained a footing.

original: Evaṃ parivāretvā pana te haṃsā “kathaṃ muttosi, mahārājā”ti pucchiṃsu. Mahāsatto
analyzed: evam parivāretvā pana te haṃsā katham muttaḥ asi mahā rāja iti pucchiṃsu mahāsatto
translated: Having surrounded him in this way, the geese asked, “How were you freed, great king?” The Great Being

original: sumukhaṃ nissāya muttabhāvaṃ, sāgalarājaluddaputtehi katakammañca kathesi. Taṃ sutvā
analyzed: sumukham nissāya mutta bhāvam sāgala rājaludda puttehi kata kammam ca kathesi tam sutvā
translated: told them how he was freed through Sumukha, and how the son of the hunter, the king of Sāgala, had acted. Having heard this,

original: tuṭṭho haṃsagaṇo “sumukhasenāpati ca rājā ca luddaputto ca sukhitā niddukkhā ciraṃ
analyzed: tuṭṭhaḥ haṃsa gaṇaḥ sumukha senāpati ca rājā ca ludda putto ca sukhitā niddukkhā ciram
translated: the geese were pleased, and they made this eulogy: “May the general Sumukha, the king, and the hunter’s son live long,

original: jīvantū”ti thutimakāsi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā osānagāthamāha –
analyzed: jīvantu iti thutim akāsi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā osāna gātham āha
translated: happy and free from suffering.” In order to make this clear, the Teacher spoke the following verse:

original: “Evaṃ mittavataṃ atthā, sabbe honti padakkhiṇā;
analyzed: evam mittavatam atthā sabbe honti padakkhiṇā
translated: “Thus all are grateful to those who are good friends;

analyzed: dhataraṭṭhā kalyāṇa mitta sampannā yathā ñāti saṅgham upāgamum ñāti saṅgha upagamana saṅkhātaḥ

analyzed: na isam atthaḥ padakkhiṇaḥ jātaḥ evam aññesam pi mittavatam atthāḥ padakkhiṇāḥ honti iti  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbepānandaḥ mamatthāya
translated: The meaning of the expression “went to the company of their kinsmen” is that they were fortunate in their aims. So it is with others who have friends.🔽The Teacher, having related this story, said, “Monks, not now only, but formerly also Ānanda sacrificed his life for my sake.

translated: In the days of yore the hunter was Channa, the king was Sāriputta,

analyzed: cūḷahaṃsajātakavaṇṇanā paṭhamā 🔽

translated: This story the Master told, while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, concerning the Elder Ānanda’s renunciation of life. The story is the same as the one told above, only here the Master related the following incident of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ saṃyamassa nāma bārāṇasirañño khemā nāma aggamahesī ahosi. Tadā

analyzed: bodhisattaḥ navuti haṃsa sahassa parivutaḥ cittakūṭe vihāsi atha eka divasam khemā devī  paccūsa samaye supinam addasa suvaṇṇa vaṇṇāḥ haṃsāḥ āgantvā rāja pallaṅke nisīditvā madhurassarena
translated: The Bodhisatta, surrounded by a retinue of ninety thousand geese, dwelt on Citta Peak. One day, at dawn, Queen Khema🔽dreamed a dream. Geese, golden in hue, came and sat down on the royal couch and preached the Law in sweet voices.

original: Sā vegenuṭṭhāya “palāyamāne haṃse gaṇhatha gaṇhathā”ti vatvā hatthaṃ pasārentīyeva
analyzed: sā vegena uṭṭhāya palāyamāne haṃse gaṇhatha gaṇhatha iti vatvā hattham pasārentīya iva

translated: and woke up. Her attendants, hearing her talk, laughed a little, saying: “Where are the geese?” At that moment

analyzed: vatvā nirussukkaḥ bhavissati dohaḷaḥ ti vutte pana yena kenaci upāyena pariyesissati

But if I say: ‘I want a dohaḷa,’ he will seek them by any means.

original: evaṃ me manoratho samijjhissatī”ti. Sā gilānālayaṃ dassetvā paricārikānaṃ saññaṃ datvā nipajji.
analyzed: evam me manorathaḥ samijjhissati iti sā gilāna ālayam dassetvā paricārikānam saññam datvā nipajji

analyzed: rājā rāja āsane nisinnaḥ tassāḥ dassana velāya tam a disvā kaham khemā devī iti pucchitvā

analyzed: gilānā ati sutvā tassā santikam gantvā sayana ekadese nisīditvā piṭṭhim parimajjanto

analyzed: tena hi bhaṇa devi yam icchasi tam sīgham te upanāmessāmi iti mahā rāja aham ekassa
translated: “Well then, tell me, Queen, what you desire, and I will quickly bring it to you.” “Your Majesty, I desire

analyzed: katvā sādhukāram dadamānā dhamma katham sotum icchāmi sace labhāmi icca itam kusalam
translated: and listen to a sermon. If I can do this, it will be good for me,

analyzed: no ce jīvitam me natthi iti atha nam rājā sace manussa loke atthi labhissasi mā

analyzed: cintayi iti assāsetvā sirigabbhataḥ nikkhamma amaccehi saddhim mantesi ambho khemā  devī suvaṇṇahaṃsassa dhamma katham sotum labhantī jīvissāmi a labhantiyāḥ me jīvitam
translated: don’t worry,” left the women’s quarters and consulted with his ministers, saying, “Gentlemen, Queen Khemā

analyzed: natthi iti vadati atthi nu kho suvaṇṇa vaṇṇā haṃsa ati deva amhehi na iva diṭṭha pubbā

analyzed: na suta pubbā ati ke pana jāneyyunti brāhmaṇāḥ devā ati rājā brāhmaṇe pakkosāpetvā
translated: “No, sire, we have never seen them.” “Who then, might have seen them?” “Brahmans, sire.” The king summoned the brahman householders,

analyzed: sakkāram katvā pucchi honti nu kho ācariyā suvaṇṇa vaṇṇā haṃsā ti āma mahā rāja  amhākam kakkaṭakā kacchapāḥ migāḥ morāḥ haṃsāḥ ati cha ete tiracchāna gatā
translated: honoured them with gifts and asked them, “Have you ever seen golden-hued geese, teachers?” “Yes, sire,🔽in our sacred books it is written that there are six kinds of animals that are golden-hued: crocodiles, tortoises, deer, peacocks, geese and swans.

original: suvaṇṇavaṇṇā hontīti āgatā, tattha dhataraṭṭhakulahaṃsā nāma paṇḍitā ñāṇasampannā,

translated: “We do not know, sire.” “Who then, might know?” “The hunters, sire.”

analyzed: nāma kaham vasanti iti atha ikaḥ luddaḥ himavante kira deva cittakūṭa pabbata iti no

analyzed: kula paramparāya kathenti iti āha jānāsi pana na jānāmi deva iti  ke pana jānissanti iti brāhmaṇa ati saḥ brāhmaṇa paṇḍite pakkosāpetvā cittakūṭa pabbate
translated: “Do you know a way to catch them?” “I do not know, Your Majesty.”🔽“But who else would know?” “Brahmins, Your Majesty.” So the king summoned wise brahmins and told them about the golden-hued geese on the Citta Peak.

analyzed: pucchi mahā rāja kim tehi gantvā gahitehi upāyena te nagara samīpam ānetvā gahessāma ati
translated: “Your Majesty, what is the point of catching them? We will bring them to the vicinity of the city by means of a trick and then catch them.”

original: “Ko pana upāyo”ti? “Mahārāja, nagarato avidūre uttarena tigāvutamatte tigāvutappamāṇaṃ
analyzed: kaḥ pana mahā rāja nagarataḥ avidūre uttarena tigāvuta matte tigāvuta ppamāṇam
translated: “But what is the trick?” “Your Majesty, one league to the north of the city, at a distance of less than two leagues,

analyzed: khemam nāma saram kārāpetvā udakassa pūretvā nānā dhaññāni ropetvā pañca vaṇṇa paduma sañchannam
translated: have a lake called Khema made, fill it with water, plant various grains, and have it covered with lotuses of five colors.

original: kārāpetvā ekaṃ paṇḍitaṃ nesādaṃ paṭicchāpetvā manussānaṃ upagantuṃ adatvā catūsu
analyzed: kārāpetvā ekam paṇḍitam nesādam paṭicchāpetvā manussānam upagantum a datvā catūsu
translated: Have a wise hunter disguise himself and not allow people to approach it.

original: kaṇṇesu ṭhitehi abhayaṃ ghosāpetha, taṃ sutvā nānāsakuṇā dasa disā otarissanti, tepi
analyzed: kaṇṇesu ṭhitehi abhayam ghosāpetha tam sutvā nānā sakuṇāḥ dasa disāḥ otarissanti te pi
translated: and proclaim in the four quarters that there is safety there. When they hear that, various birds will come from the ten quarters and settle there.

analyzed: haṃsā paramparāya tassa sarassa khema bhāvam sutvā āgacchissanti atha ne vāla pāsehi
translated: The geese, hearing by the grapevine that the lake is safe, will come there. Then you can have them caught in nets

original: bandhāpetvā gaṇhāpeyyāthā”ti.
analyzed: bandhāpetvā gaṇhāpeyyātha ati
translated: and taken prisoner.”

analyzed: tam sutvā rājā tehi vutta padese vutta ppakāram saram kārāpetvā chekam nesādam pakkosāpetvā
translated: When the king heard this, he had a lake of the kind described built in the place indicated, and he summoned a certain fowler,
