analyzed: tassa sahassam dāpetvā tvam itas paṭṭhāya attano kammam mā kari putta dāram te aham  posessāmi tvam appamattaḥ khemam saram rakkhantaḥ manusse paṭikkamāpetvā catūsu kaṇṇesu  abhayam ghosāpetvā āgata āgate sakuṇe mama ācikkheyyāsi suvaṇṇa haṃsesu āgatesu mahantam
translated: gave him a thousand pieces of money, and said to him, “Henceforth do not work at your own trade. I will support your wife and children.

analyzed: sakkāram labhissasi iti tam assāsetvā khemam saram paṭicchāpesi so tatas paṭṭhāya raññā

analyzed: vutta nayena iva tattha paṭipajji khemam saram rakkhati iti ca ssa  nāmam udapādi tatas paṭṭhāya ca nānappakārā sakuṇāḥ otariṃsu khemam nibbhayam saranti

original: lohitamakkhito pāsayaṭṭhiyaṃ olambantoyeva tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: lohita makkhito pāsa yaṭṭhiyam olambanto yeva tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: while hanging from the snare, covered with blood, he uttered three stanzas:

original: “Ete haṃsā pakkamanti, vakkaṅgā bhayameritā;
analyzed: ete haṃsā pakkamanti vakkaṅgāḥ bhayam eritā
translated: “These geese are flying away, the Vakkas and the Gingers, too;

original: Harittaca hemavaṇṇa, kāmaṃ sumukha pakkama.
analyzed: harittaca hema vaṇṇa kāmam su mukha pakkama
translated: The Golden One with the yellow beak, Sumukha, fly away if you wish.

original: “Ohāya maṃ ñātigaṇā, ekaṃ pāsavasaṃ gataṃ;
analyzed: ohāya mam ñāti gaṇāḥ ekam pāsavasam gatam
translated: “Abandoning me, a kinsman, who am caught in a snare,

original: Anapekkhamānā gacchanti, kiṃ eko avahīyasi.
analyzed: an apekkhamānāḥ gacchanti kim ekaḥ avahīyasi
translated: They go without a care; why should you abandon me alone?

original: “Pateva patataṃ seṭṭha, natthi baddhe sahāyatā;
analyzed: pata iva patatam seṭṭha natthi baddhe sahāya tā
translated: “Fly away, fly away, O best of birds; there is no friendship with a captive.

original: Mā anīghāya hāpesi, kāmaṃ sumukha pakkamā”ti.
analyzed: mā anīghāya hāpesi kāmam su mukha pakkamāti
translated: Do not let the hunter kill you, too, O Sumukha, fly away if you wish.”

original: Tattha bhayameritāti bhayena eritā bhayaṭṭitā bhayacalitā. Tatiyapade “harī”tipi
analyzed: tattha bhayam eritā iti bhayena eritā bhaya ṭṭitā bhaya calitā tatiya pade
translated: Herein, bhayameritā means frightened, terrified, scared. In the third line, “harī” is also

original: “hema”ntipi suvaṇṇasseva nāmaṃ. So ca harittacatāya hemavaṇṇo, tena taṃ evaṃ ālapati.
analyzed: suvaṇṇassa iva nāmam saḥ ca harittacatāya hema vaṇṇaḥ tena tam evam ālapati
translated: the name of gold. And he was golden-hued because of his yellow beak, so he addresses him thus.

original: Sumukhāti sundaramukha. Anapekkhamānāti tava ñātakā maṃ anolokentā nirālayā hutvā.
analyzed: sumukhā ati sundaramukha an apekkhamānā ati tava ñātakāḥ mam nirālayāḥ hutvā
translated: Sumukha means beautiful-faced. Without regard for me means without looking back at me, without any attachment.

original: Patevāti uppatāhiyeva. Mā anīghāyāti ito gantvā pattabbāya nidukkhabhāvāya vīriyaṃ mā hāpesi.
analyzed: pateva āti uppata ahiyā iva mā anīghāya ati itas gantvā pattabbāya nidukkha bhāvāya vīriyam mā hāpesi
translated: Fly away means fly away. Do not slacken your effort means do not slacken your effort for the sake of the happiness that is to be attained by going from here.

original: Taṃ sutvā sumukho “ayaṃ haṃsarājā mama piyamittabhāvaṃ na jānāti, anuppiyabhāṇī mittoti maṃ sallakkheti, sinehabhāvamassa dassessāmī”ti cintetvā catasso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā su mukhaḥ ayam haṃsa rājā mama piya mitta bhāvam na jānāti anuppiya bhāṇī mittaḥ ti mam sallakkha iti sineha bhāvam assa dassessāmi iti cintetvā catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Having heard that, Sumukha thought, “This king of geese does not know my friendship, he thinks I am a disagreeable speaker, I will show him the state of affection.” And he spoke four verses:

original: “Nāhaṃ dukkhaparetopi, dhataraṭṭha tuvaṃ jahe;
analyzed: na aham dukkha paretaḥ api dhataraṭṭha tuvam jahe
translated: “I will not abandon you, Dhataraṭṭha, even if it is for my own suffering.

original: Jīvitaṃ maraṇaṃ vā me, tayā saddhiṃ bhavissati.
analyzed: jīvitam maraṇam vā me tayā saddhim bhavissati
translated: My life or death will be with you.”

original: “Nāhaṃ dukkhaparetopi, dhataraṭṭha tuvaṃ jahe;
analyzed: na aham dukkha paretaḥ api dhataraṭṭha tuvam jahe
translated: “I will not abandon you, Dhataraṭṭha, even if it is for my own suffering.

original: Na maṃ anariyasaṃyutte, kamme yojetumarahasi.
analyzed: na mam an ariya saṃyutte kamme yojetum arahasi
translated: You are not able to employ me in a deed connected with the unrighteous.”

original: “Sakumāro sakhātyasmi, sacitte casmi te ṭhito;
analyzed: sa kumāraḥ sakhā atyasmi sa citte ca asmi te ṭhitaḥ
translated: “I am your friend from childhood, and I am established in your mind.

original: Ñāto senāpatī tyāhaṃ, haṃsānaṃ pavaruttama.
analyzed: senāpatī tya aham haṃsānam pavar uttama
translated: I am known as your general, the most excellent of geese.”

original: “Kathaṃ ahaṃ vikattissaṃ, ñātimajjhe ito gato;
analyzed: katham aham vikattissam ñāti majjhe itas gataḥ
translated: “How can I go from here to the midst of my relatives without doing anything?

original: Taṃ hitvā patataṃ seṭṭha, kiṃ te vakkhāmito gato;
analyzed: tam hitvā patatam seṭṭha kim te gato
translated: Having left him, O best of swans, what will you say to me when you have gone?

original: Idha pāṇaṃ cajissāmi, nānariyaṃ kattumussahe”ti.
analyzed: idha pāṇam cajissāmi na anariyam kattum ussaheti
translated: Here I will give up my life; I cannot do what is unmanly.”

original: Tattha nāhanti ahaṃ, mahārāja, kāyikacetasikena dukkhena phuṭṭhopi taṃ na jahāmi.🔽Anariyasaṃyutteti mittadubbhīhi ahirikehi kattabbatāya anariyabhāvena saṃyutte. Kammeti🔽taṃ jahitvā pakkamanakamme. Sakumāroti samānakumāro, ekadivaseneva paṭisandhiṃ gahetvā🔽ekadivase aṇḍakosaṃ padāletvā ekato vaḍḍhitakumāroti attho. Sakhātyasmīti ahaṃ te🔽dakkhiṇakkhisamo piyasahāyo. Sacitteti tava sake citte ahaṃ ṭhito tava vase vattāmi,
analyzed: tattha aham mahā rāja kāyika cetasikena dukkhena phuṭṭhaḥ api tam na jahāmi  anariya saṃyuttā iti mitta dubbhīhi ahirikehi kattabba tāya anariya bhāvena saṃyutte kamme iti  tam jahitvā pakkamana kamme sa kumāraḥ ti samāna kumāraḥ eka divasena iva paṭisandhim gahetvā  eka divase aṇḍa kosam padāletvā ekatas sakhāti asmi iti aham te  piya sahāyaḥ sa citta iti tava sake citte aham ṭhitaḥ tava vase vattāmi
translated: Herein, I will not leave him, O great king, even though I am touched by bodily and mental suffering.

original: tayi jīvante jīvāmi, na jīvante na jīvāmīti attho. “Saṃcitte”tipi pāṭho, tava citte🔽ahaṃ saṇṭhito suṭṭhu ṭhitoti attho. Ñātoti sabbahaṃsānaṃ antare paññāto. Vikattissanti
analyzed: tayi jīvante jīvāmi na jīvante na jīvāmi iti attho tava citte 🔽aham saṇṭhitaḥ suṭṭhu ṭhitaḥ ti atthaḥ ñāto ti sabba haṃsānam antare paññātaḥ vikattissanti
translated: In what is unmanly: in what is connected with unmanliness because it is to be done by those who are faithless to friends. In the act: in the act of leaving him and flying away. As a young one: as a young one of the same age, the meaning is, as a young one hatched out of the egg on the same day as oneself and brought up together. I am your friend: I am your dear friend, equal to your right eye. In your mind: I am established in your mind, I am under your control, I am obedient to you, is the meaning. I live while you live: I live while you live, I do not live when you do not live. The reading is also saṃcitte. I am well established in your mind, is the meaning. Known: known among all the geese. I will not desert: I will not abandon you.

original: “kuhiṃ haṃsarājā”ti pucchito ahaṃ kinti kathessāmi. Kiṃ te vakkhāmīti te tava pavattiṃ
analyzed: kuhim haṃsa rājā ati pucchitaḥ aham kinti kathessāmi kim te vakkhāmi iti te tava pavattim
translated: “Where is the King of Geese?” If I am asked this, what shall I say? What shall I tell them?🔽When the flock of geese asks me about your whereabouts,

original: pucchante haṃsagaṇe kiṃ vakkhāmi.
analyzed: pucchante haṃsa gaṇe kim vakkhāmi
translated: what shall I say?

original: Evaṃ sumukhena catūhi gāthāhi sīhanāde nadite tassa guṇaṃ pakāsento mahāsatto āha –
analyzed: evam sumukhena catūhi gāthāhi sīha nāde nadite tassa guṇam pakāsentaḥ mahāsattaḥ āha
translated: When Sumukha had thus roared his lion’s roar with four verses, the Great Being, revealing his own virtue, said:

original: “Eso hi dhammo sumukha, yaṃ tvaṃ ariyapathe ṭhito;
analyzed: esaḥ hi dhammaḥ su mukha yam tvam ariya pathe ṭhitaḥ
translated: “This is the way, Sumukha, that you, standing on the noble path,

original: Yo bhattāraṃ sakhāraṃ maṃ, na pariccattumussahe.
analyzed: yaḥ bhattāram sakhāram mam na pariccattum ussahe
translated: could not abandon me, your master and friend.

original: “Tañhi me pekkhamānassa, bhayaṃ na tveva jāyati;
analyzed: tat hi me pekkhamānassa bhayam na tu eva jāyati
translated: “For, looking at you, fear does not arise in me;

original: Adhigacchasi tvaṃ mayhaṃ, evaṃbhūtassa jīvita”nti.🔽Tattha eso dhammoti esa porāṇakapaṇḍitānaṃ sabhāvo. Bhattāraṃ sakhāraṃ manti sāmikañca
analyzed: adhigacchasi tvam mayham evaṃbhūtassa jīvitanti  tattha esaḥ dhammaḥ ti esa porāṇaka paṇḍitānam sabhāvaḥ bhattāram sakhāram sāmikam ca
translated: you will attain the life of one like me.”

original: sahāyañca maṃ. Bhayanti cittutrāso mayhaṃ na jāyati, cittakūṭapabbate haṃsagaṇamajjhe
analyzed: sahāyam ca mam bhayanti cittu trāsaḥ mayham na jāyati citta kūṭa pabbate haṃsa gaṇa majjhe
translated: Herein, this is the way, etc.: this is the nature of the ancient wise men. Your master and friend, etc.: you could not abandon me, your master and friend. Fear: fear of the mind does not arise in me. Standing in the midst of the flock of geese on the Cittakūṭa Peak,

original: ṭhito viya homi. Mayhanti mama jīvitaṃ tvaṃ labhāpessasi.
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ viya homi mama jīvitam tvam
translated: I am as if standing in the midst of the flock of geese on Cittakūṭa Peak. Of one like me: you will attain my life.

original: Evaṃ tesaṃ kathentānaññeva luddaputto sarapariyante ṭhito haṃse tīhi khandhehi palāyante
analyzed: evam tesam kathentānam aññā iva ludda putto sara pariyante ṭhitaḥ haṃse tīhi khandhehi palāyante
translated: While they were thus conversing, the hunter’s son, who was standing at the edge of the water, saw the geese fly away in three directions.

original: disvā “kiṃ nu kho”ti pāsaṭṭhānaṃ olokento bodhisattaṃ pāsayaṭṭhiyaṃ olambantaṃ disvā
analyzed: disvā kim nu kha iti pāsa ṭṭhānam olokentaḥ bodhisattam pāsa yaṭṭhiyam olambantam disvā
translated: “What can this mean?” thought he, and looking in the direction of the snare, he saw the Bodhisatta hanging by his neck in the noose of the snare.

original: sañjātasomanasso kacchaṃ daḷhaṃ bandhitvā muggaraṃ gahetvā kappuṭṭhānaggi viya avattharamāno
analyzed: sañjāta somanassaḥ kaccham daḷham bandhitvā muggaram gahetvā viya avattharamānaḥ
translated: Filled with joy, he bound the tortoise fast, took his hatchet in his hand, and with a speed that resembled the speed of a flash of lightning,

original: paṇhiyā akkantakalale uparisīsena gantvā purato patante vegena upasaṅkami. Tamatthaṃ
analyzed: paṇhiyāḥ akkanta kalale upari sīsena gantvā puratas patante vegena upasaṅkami tam attham
translated: he went down into the water, and with a bound sprang out upon the bank, and ran swiftly forward.

original: pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: Expounding this matter, the Master said:

original: “Iccevaṃ mantayantānaṃ, ariyānaṃ ariyavuttinaṃ;
analyzed: icca ivam mantayantānam ariyānam ariya vuttinam
translated: “Thus as the noble geese, of noble conduct, were holding counsel together,

original: Daṇḍamādāya nesādo, āpatī turito bhusaṃ.
analyzed: daṇḍam ādāya nesādaḥ āpatī turitaḥ bhusam
translated: The hunter, taking his hatchet, came swiftly and suddenly.

original: “Tamāpatantaṃ disvāna, sumukho atibrūhayi;
analyzed: tam āpatantam disvāna su mukhaḥ atibrūhayi
translated: “Seeing him coming, Sumukha addressed the king,

original: Aṭṭhāsi purato rañño, haṃso vissāsayaṃ byathaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi puratas raññaḥ haṃsaḥ vissāsayam byatham
translated: ‘The goose is standing before the king, in confidence and at his ease.’

original: “Mā bhāyi patataṃ seṭṭha, na hi bhāyanti tādisā;
analyzed: mā bhāyi patatam seṭṭha na hi bhāyanti tādisā
translated: “‘Fear not, O best of birds; such as thou art, thou hast no cause for fear.

original: Ahaṃ yogaṃ payuñjissaṃ, yuttaṃ dhammūpasañhitaṃ;
analyzed: aham yogam payuñjissam yuttam dhamma upasañhitam
translated: I will employ a stratagem, a stratagem that is in accordance with righteousness;

original: Tena pariyāpadānena, khippaṃ pāsā pamokkhasī”ti.
analyzed: tena pariyāpadānena khippam pāsā pamokkhasi iti
translated: By this means you will soon be free from the snare.

original: Tattha ariyavuttinanti ariyācāre vattamānānaṃ. Bhusanti daḷhaṃ balavaṃ. Atibrūhayīti
analyzed: tattha ariya vuttinam ti ariya ācāre vattamānānam bhusanti daḷham balavam
translated: Herein, of noble conduct means of noble practice. Firmly means firmly, strongly. You have encouraged me means

original: anantaragāthāya āgataṃ “mā bhāyī”ti vacanaṃ vadanto atibrūhesi mahāsaddaṃ nicchāresi.
analyzed: anantara gāthāya āgatam mā bhāyi iti vacanam vadantaḥ mahā saddam nicchāresi
translated: you have encouraged me, have made a great noise, have shouted out, by saying Do not fear, which is found in the next verse.

original: Aṭṭhāsīti sace nesādo rājānaṃ paharissati, ahaṃ pahāraṃ sampaṭicchissāmīti jīvitaṃ🔽pariccajitvā purato aṭṭhāsi. Vissāsayanti vissāsento assāsento. Byathanti byathitaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi iti sace nesādaḥ rājānam paharissati aham pahāram sampaṭicchissāmi iti jīvitaṃ  pariccajitvā puratas aṭṭhāsi vissāsayanti vissāsentaḥ assāsentaḥ byathanti byathitam
translated: I stood there means I stood in front of him, having given up my life, thinking If the fowler strikes the king, I will take the blow.

original: bhītaṃ rājānaṃ “mā bhāyī”ti iminā vacanena vissāsento. Tādisāti tumhādisā ñāṇavīriyasampannā.
analyzed: bhītam rājānam mā bhāyi iti iminā vacanena vissāsento tādisā ati tumhādisā ñāṇa vīriya sampannā
translated: Reassuring means reassuring him, encouraging him. Frightened means frightened, terrified. Do not fear means by this word Do not fear he reassured the frightened king. Such as you means such as you, endowed with knowledge and energy.

original: Yoganti ñāṇavīriyayogaṃ. Yuttanti anucchavikaṃ. Dhammūpasañhitanti kāraṇanissitaṃ.
analyzed: yogam ti ñāṇa vīriya yogam yuttam ti anucchavikam dhamma upasañhitam ti kāraṇa nissitam
translated: Yoga means the yoga of knowledge and energy. Yuttā means suitable. Dhammūpasañhitā means having a reason.

original: Tena pariyāpadānenāti tena mayā payuttena yogena parisuddhena. Pamokkhasīti muccissasi.
analyzed: tena pariyāpadānena ati tena mayā payuttena yogena parisuddhena pamokkhasi iti muccissasi
translated: By this means you will soon be free from the snare means by this means, by this yoga, by this purity of mine. You will soon be free from the snare means you will be released.

original: Evaṃ sumukho mahāsattaṃ assāsetvā luddaputtassa santikaṃ gantvā madhuraṃ mānusiṃ🔽vācaṃ nicchārento, “samma, tvaṃ konāmosī”ti pucchitvā “suvaṇṇavaṇṇahaṃsarāja, ahaṃ🔽khemako nāmā”ti vutte, “samma khemaka, ‘tayā oḍḍitavālapāse yo vā so vā haṃso baddho’ti🔽saññaṃ mā kari, navutiyā haṃsasahassānaṃ pavaro dhataraṭṭhahaṃsarājā te pāse baddho,
analyzed: evam sumukhaḥ mahāsattam assāsetvā ludda puttassa santikam gantvā madhuram mānusim  vācam samma tvam konāmā asi iti pucchitvā suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa haṃsa rāja aham  khemakaḥ nāma ati vutte samma khemaka tayā oḍḍita vāla pāse yaḥ vā saḥ vā haṃsaḥ baddhaḥ ti  saññam mā kari navutiyā haṃsa sahassānam pavaraḥ dhataraṭṭha haṃsa rājā te pāse baddhaḥ
translated: Having thus comforted the Great Being, Sumukha went to the hunter’s son, and, desirous of speaking to him in a sweet human voice, asked him, “What is your name, my good man?”🔽“I am the king of the golden-hued geese, and my name is Khema.”🔽“My good Khema, do not think that the goose caught in your net is just any goose. The most excellent king of the geese, Dhataraṭṭha, is caught in your net.🔽“

original: ñāṇasīlācārasampanno saṅgāhakapakkhe ṭhito, na taṃ māretuṃ yutto, ahaṃ tava iminā🔽kattabbakiccaṃ karissāmi, ayampi suvaṇṇavaṇṇo, ahampi tatheva, ahaṃ etassatthāya🔽attano jīvitaṃ pariccajissāmi, sace tvaṃ etassa pattāni gaṇhitukāmosi, mama pattāni🔽gaṇha, athopi cammamaṃsanhāruaṭṭhīnamaññataraṃ gaṇhitukāmosi, mameva sarīrato gaṇha,
analyzed: ñāṇa sīla ācāra sampanno saṅgāhaka pakkhe ṭhitaḥ na tam māretum yuttaḥ aham tava iminā 🔽kattabba kiccam karissāmi ayam pi suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ aham pi tathā iva aham etassa atthāya 🔽attanaḥ jīvitam pariccajissāmi sace tvam etassa pattāni gaṇhitu kāmo asi mama pattāni 🔽gaṇha atho pi camma maṃsa nhāru aṭṭhīnam aññataram gaṇhitu kāmo asi mama eva sarīrataḥ gaṇha
translated: Having thus comforted the Great Being, Sumukha went to the hunter’s son, and, desirous of speaking to him in a human voice, asked him, “Good man, who are you?” “Golden-hued king of geese, I am Khemaka.” “Good Khemaka, do not think that the goose caught in your net is just any goose. The king of geese, Dhataraṭṭha, the most excellent of ninety thousand geese, is caught in your net. He is endowed with knowledge, virtue, and conduct, and he is on the side of the Sangha. It is not right to kill him. I will do for you what should be done with him. This one is golden-hued, and so am I. I will give up my life for his sake. If you wish to take his feathers, take mine. If you wish to take his skin, flesh, sinews, or bones, take them from me.

original: atha naṃ kīḷāhaṃsaṃ kātukāmosi, maññeva kara, jīvantameva vikkiṇitvā sace dhanaṃ🔽uppādetukāmosi, maṃ jīvantameva vikkiṇitvā dhanaṃ uppādehi, mā etaṃ ñāṇādiguṇasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: atha nam kīḷā haṃsam kātu kāmo asi maññā iva kara jīvantam eva vikkiṇitvā sace dhanam  uppādetu kāmaḥ asi mam jīvantam eva vikkiṇitvā dhanam uppādehi mā etam ñāṇa ādi guṇa saṃyuttam
translated: “If you want to make a plaything of him, then make him so. If you want to make money, then make money by selling him alive.

original: haṃsarājānaṃ avadhi, sace hi naṃ vadhissasi, nirayādīhi na muccissasī”ti taṃ nirayādibhayena🔽santajjetvā attano madhurakathaṃ gaṇhāpetvā puna bodhisattassa santikaṃ gantvā taṃ🔽assāsento aṭṭhāsi. Nesādo tassa kathaṃ sutvā “ayaṃ tiracchānagato samāno manussehipi
analyzed: haṃsa rājānam sace hi nam vadhissasi niraya ādīhi na muccissasi iti tam niraya ādi bhayena  santajjetvā attanaḥ madhura katham gaṇhāpetvā puna bodhisattassa santikam gantvā tam  assāsentaḥ aṭṭhāsi nesādaḥ tassa katham sutvā ayam tiracchāna gataḥ samānaḥ manussehi pi
translated: Do not kill this king of swans, who is endowed with the qualities of knowledge and so on. For if you kill him, you will not escape from hell and the other states of suffering.” Thus he frightened him with the terrors of hell and the other states of suffering,

original: kātuṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ evarūpaṃ mittadhammaṃ karoti, manussāpi evaṃ mittadhamme ṭhātuṃ
analyzed: kātum a sakkuṇeyyam evarūpam mittadhammam karoti manussā api evam mittadhamme ṭhātum
translated: and made him accept his own sweet words. Then he went back to the Bodhisatta and stood there comforting him. When the fowler heard his words, he thought, “This animal, though an animal, does this kind of friendship which men cannot do. Men cannot keep to such friendship.

original: na sakkonti, aho esa ñāṇasampanno madhurakatho dhammiko”ti sakalasarīraṃ pītisomanassaparipuṇṇaṃ
analyzed: na sakkonti aho esa ñāṇa sampannaḥ madhura kathaḥ dhammikaḥ ti sakala sarīram pīti somanassa paripuṇṇam

translated: to one who is in the midst of his desire,🔽who is surrounded by a multitude of relatives,

Yadyāyanti, samma khemaka, yadi🔽ayaṃ amhākaṃ pokkharaṇī navutihaṃsasahassehi puṇṇā tiṭṭhati. Kathaṃ rucimajjhagatanti🔽evaṃ sante tvaṃ tesaṃ rucīnaṃ piyadassanānaṃ haṃsānaṃ majjhagataṃ etaṃ ñātisaṅghehi🔽okiṇṇaṃ. Nimmajjhimanti neva majjhimaṃ neva kaniṭṭhaṃ uttamaṃ haṃsarājānaṃ kathaṃ
analyzed: okiṇṇam ñāti saṅghehi nimmajjhimam katham gahi iti  tattha pasannattanti pasanna bhāvam somanassa ppattam yadi āyanti samma khemaka yadi  ayam amhākam pokkharaṇī navuti haṃsa sahassehi puṇṇā tiṭṭhati katham  evam sante tvam tesam rucīnam piya dassanānam haṃsānam majjha gatam etam ñāti saṅghehi  okiṇṇam nimmajjhimanti na iva majjhimam na iva kaniṭṭham uttamam haṃsa rājānam katham
translated: who is neither middle-aged nor young, the king of geese?

original: pāsahattho upāgami kathaṃ gaṇhīti.
analyzed: pāsa hatthaḥ upāgami katham gaṇhi iti
translated: Herein, ‘because of his faith’ means because of his state of faith, because of his having attained joy. ‘If this, my friend’ means if this our lotus-pond is filled with nine hundred thousand geese. ‘How did you come, with a noose in your hand, to one who is in the midst of his desire’ means if it is so, then you came to one who is in the midst of his desire, who is in the midst of his beloved geese, who is surrounded by a multitude of relatives, who is neither middle-aged nor young, the king of geese. ‘How did you come, with a noose in your hand, to one who is neither middle-aged nor young, the king of geese?’ means how did you come, with a noose in your hand, to one who is neither middle-aged nor young, the king of geese?

original: So tassa kathento āha –
analyzed: saḥ tassa kathentaḥ āha
translated: Then, as he was telling him, he said:

original: “Ajja me sattamā ratti, adanāni upāsato;🔽Padametassa anvesaṃ, appamatto ghaṭassito.
analyzed: ajja me sattamā ratti adanāni upāsataḥ  padam etassa anvesam appamattaḥ ghaṭa ssitaḥ
translated: Today is the seventh night, since I have been seeking for the one who has taken my food,🔽I have been seeking for his footsteps, heedful and diligent.

original: “Athassa padamaddakkhiṃ, carato adanesanaṃ;
analyzed: athassa carataḥ adana isanam
translated: Then I saw his footsteps, as he was going about seeking for food,

original: Tatthāhaṃ odahiṃ pāsaṃ, evaṃ taṃ dijamaggahi”nti.
analyzed: tattha aham odahim pāsam evam tam
translated: I set a snare there, and so I caught the bird.”

original: Tattha adanānīti ādānāni, gocaraggahaṇaṭṭhānānīti attho, ayameva vā pāṭho. Upāsatoti
analyzed: tattha adanāni iti ādānāni gocara ggahaṇa ṭṭhānāni iti atthaḥ ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ upāsato ti
translated: Herein, snares are means of catching, places for catching, is the meaning; or the reading may be adanāni, and the meaning would be “I set a snare there.”🔽Approaching: approaching the place.

original: upagacchantassa. Padanti gocarabhūmiyaṃ akkantapadaṃ. Ghaṭassitoti cāṭipañjare nissito
analyzed: upagacchantassa padanti gocara bhūmiyam akkanta padam ghaṭassito ti cāṭi pañjare nissitaḥ
translated: Footprint: the place where the bird had stepped.🔽I saw: I saw it after burning.🔽Then: then on the sixth day.

original: hutvā. Athassāti atha chaṭṭhe divase etassa adanesanaṃ carantassa padaṃ addakkhiṃ.
analyzed: hutvā athassa ati atha chaṭṭhe divase etassa adanesanam carantassa padam
translated: I saw: I saw his footprint while I was searching for the snare.

original: Evaṃ tanti evaṃ taṃ dijaṃ aggahinti sabbaṃ gahitopāyaṃ ācikkhi.
analyzed: evam tam ti evam tam dijam aggahinti sabbam gahita upāyam ācikkhi
translated: So I caught the bird: so I caught the bird by all the means of catching.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “ayaṃ dvāre ṭhatvā paṭivedentopi dhataraṭṭhassevāgamanaṃ paṭivedesi, idānipi etaṃ ekameva gaṇhinti vadati, kiṃ nu kho ettha kāraṇa”nti cintetvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā ayam dvāre ṭhatvā paṭivedentaḥ api dhataraṭṭhassa iva āgamanam paṭivedesi etam ekam eva gaṇhinti vadati kim nu kho ettha kāraṇam iti cintetvā gātham āha
translated: On hearing this, the king thought, “Although he announced his arrival by standing at the door and announcing himself as Dhataraṭṭha, he now says that he caught only him. What can be the reason for this?” So he spoke this verse:🔽“Hunter, you say there are two birds,

original: “Ludda dve ime sakuṇā, atha ekoti bhāsasi;
analyzed: ludda dve ime sakuṇā atha ekoti bhāsasi
translated: But you speak of only one.🔽Is your mind confused?

original: Cittaṃ nu te vipariyattaṃ, adu kiṃ nu jigīsasī”ti.
analyzed: cittam nu te vipariyattam adu kim nu jigīsasi iti
translated: What is it you want to catch?”

original: Tattha vipariyattanti vipallatthaṃ. Adu kiṃ nu jigīsasīti udāhu kiṃ nu cintesi, kiṃ itaraṃ gahetvā aññassa dātukāmo hutvā cintesīti pucchati.
analyzed: tattha vipariyattanti vipallattham adu kim nu jigīsasi iti udāhu kim nu cintesi kim itaram gahetvā aññassa dātu kāmaḥ hutvā cintesi iti pucchati
translated: Herein, perverted is turned upside down. What is it you wanted to do? is what he said; or else, what did you think, what did you think of giving the other in exchange for the other?

original: Tato luddo “na me, deva, cittaṃ vipallatthaṃ, nāpi ahaṃ itaraṃ aññassa dātukāmo, apica kho pana mayā ohite pāse ekova baddho”ti āvi karonto āha –
analyzed: tatas luddaḥ na me deva cittam vipallattham na api aham itaram aññassa dātu kāmo apica kho pana mayā ohite pāse ekaḥ iva baddhaḥ iti āvi karontaḥ āha
translated: Then the fowler, ‘Your Majesty, my mind was not perverted, nor did I want to give the other in exchange for the other, but rather one was caught in the net I had set’, making this clear, he said:🔽Whose red-tinged eyes

original: “Yassa lohitakā tālā, tapanīyanibhā subhā;
analyzed: yassa lohitakā tālā tapanīya nibhā subhā
translated: Are lovely like the colour of brass,🔽Standing pressing his chest,

original: Uraṃ saṃhacca tiṭṭhanti, so me bandhaṃ upāgami.
analyzed: uram saṃhat ca tiṭṭhanti saḥ me bandham upāgami
translated: He came to me, caught in the net.🔽Then this bird, the Bhassara,

original: “Athāyaṃ bhassaro pakkhī, abaddho baddhamāturaṃ;
analyzed: atha ayam bhassaraḥ pakkhī a baddhaḥ baddham āturam
translated: Uncaught, stood by the caught one,🔽Speaking noble speech,

original: Ariyaṃ bruvāno aṭṭhāsi, cajanto mānusiṃ gira”nti.
analyzed: ariyam bruvānaḥ aṭṭhāsi cajantaḥ mānusim giranti
translated: And uttered human speech.

original: Tattha lohitakāti rattavaṇṇā. Lātāti rājiyo. Uraṃ saṃhaccāti uraṃ āhacca. Idaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: tattha lohitakā ati ratta vaṇṇā lātā ati rājiyaḥ uram saṃhacca ati uram āhacca idam vuttam
translated: Herein, red-tinged is red-coloured. Brass is copper. Standing pressing his chest: this is said:

original: hoti – mahārāja, yassetā rattasuvaṇṇasappaṭibhāgā tisso lohitakā rājiyo gīvaṃ parikkhipitvā
analyzed: hoti mahā rāja yassa etāḥ ratta suvaṇṇa sappaṭibhāgāḥ tissaḥ lohitakāḥ rājiyaḥ gīvam parikkhipitvā
translated: Your Majesty, those three red-tinged copper lines, which are like fine gold, encircle his neck

original: uraṃ āhacca tiṭṭhanti, so ekova mama pāse bandhaṃ upāgatoti. Bhassaroti parisuddho
analyzed: uram āhacca tiṭṭhanti saḥ ekaḥ iva mama pāse bandham upāgato ti bhassaroti parisuddhaḥ
translated: and they stand pressing against my breast. He alone has come within my power.’🔽‘Bhasara’ means pure,

original: pabhāsampanno. Āturanti gilānaṃ dukkhitaṃ aṭṭhāsīti.
analyzed: pabhā sampannaḥ āturanti gilānam dukkhitam aṭṭhāsi iti
translated: ‘Aturā’ means sick, afflicted. ‘Stood’ means stood there.

original: Atha dhataraṭṭhassa baddhabhāvaṃ ñatvā nivattitvā etaṃ samassāsetvā mamāgamanakāle🔽ca paccuggamanaṃ katvā ākāseyeva mayā saddhiṃ madhurapaṭisanthāraṃ katvā manussabhāsāya
analyzed: atha dhataraṭṭhassa baddha bhāvam ñatvā nivattitvā etam samassāsetvā mama āgamana kāle  ca paccuggamanam katvā ākāseya iva mayā saddhim madhura paṭisanthāram katvā manussa bhāsāya
translated: Then, knowing that Dhataraṭṭha was caught, he turned back, and after comforting him,🔽and after going out to meet me when I came, he stood there in the sky, and after conversing pleasantly with me,

original: dhataraṭṭhassa guṇaṃ kathento aṭṭhāsi, mama hadayaṃ mudukaṃ katvā puna etasseva purato
analyzed: dhataraṭṭhassa guṇam kathentaḥ aṭṭhāsi mama hadayam mudukam katvā punar etassa iva puratas
translated: he stood there praising Dhataraṭṭha’s virtues in human speech, and after softening my heart, he stood there again in front of him.

original: aṭṭhāsi. Athāhaṃ, deva, sumukhassa subhāsitaṃ sutvā pasannacitto dhataraṭṭhaṃ vissajjesiṃ,
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi atha aham deva sumukhassa su bhāsitam sutvā pasanna cittaḥ dhataraṭṭham vissajjesiṃ
translated: Then, God-King, after hearing Sumukha’s good speech, with a contented mind I released Dhataraṭṭha,

original: iti dhataraṭṭhassa pāsato mokkho, ime haṃse ādāya mama idhāgamanañca sumukheneva
analyzed: iti dhataraṭṭhassa pāsatas mokkhaḥ ime haṃse ādāya mama idha āgamanam ca su mukhena iva
translated: and so Dhataraṭṭha was freed from the snare, and after taking these geese, I came here, and it was through Sumukha

original: katanti. Evaṃ so sumukhassa guṇakathaṃ kathesi. Taṃ sutvā rājā sumukhassa dhammakathaṃ
analyzed: katam ti evam saḥ sumukhassa guṇa katham kathesi tam sutvā rājā sumukhassa dhamma katham
translated: that I came here.’ Thus he told the story of Sumukha’s virtues. After hearing it, the King, thinking: ‘Sumukha’s Dhamma-talk

original: sotukāmo ahosi. Luddaputtassa sakkāraṃ karontasseva sūriyo atthaṅgato, dīpā pajjalitā,
analyzed: sotu kāmo ahosi ludda puttassa sakkāram karontassa iva sūriyaḥ atthaṅgataḥ dīpā pajjalitā
translated: and he was eager to hear it. While he was paying homage to the son of the brāhman, the sun set, the lamps were lit,

original: bahū khattiyādayo sannipatitā, khemā devīpi vividhanāṭakaparivārā rañño dakkhiṇapasse
analyzed: bahū khattiya ādayo sannipatitā khemā devī pi vividha nāṭaka parivārā raññaḥ dakkhiṇa passe
translated: and many nobles and others assembled. Queen Khemā, surrounded by a troupe of various actors, sat to the king’s right.

original: nisīdi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe rājā sumukhaṃ kathāpetukāmo gāthamāha –
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe rājā su mukham kathā petu kāmaḥ gātham āha
translated: At that moment the king, wishing to have Sumukha questioned, spoke this verse:

original: “Atha kiṃ dāni sumukha, hanuṃ saṃhacca tiṭṭhasi;
analyzed: atha kim dāni su mukha hanum saṃhacca tiṭṭhasi
translated: “Why then, Sumukha, do you stand with your jaw clenched?

original: Adu me parisaṃ patto, bhayā bhīto na bhāsasī”ti.
analyzed: adu me parisam pattaḥ bhayā bhītaḥ na bhāsasi iti
translated: Have you come into my presence? Out of fear you do not speak.”

original: Tattha hanuṃ saṃhaccāti madhurakatho kira tvaṃ, atha kasmā idāni mukhaṃ pidhāya tiṭṭhasi. Adūti kacci. Bhayā bhītoti parisasārajjabhayena bhīto hutvā.
analyzed: tattha hanum madhura katho kira tvam atha kasmai idāni mukham pidhāya tiṭṭhasi kacci bhayā bhītā iti parisasāra ja bhayena bhītaḥ hutvā
translated: Here, “with your jaw clenched” means: it is said that you are a sweet-voiced speaker, why then do you stand now with your mouth closed? “Have you come” means: have you come into my presence? “Out of fear” means: out of fear of being ashamed in the assembly.

original: Taṃ sutvā sumukho abhītabhāvaṃ dassento gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā su mukhaḥ abhīta bhāvam dassentaḥ gātham āha
translated: Having heard that, Sumukha, showing his fearless state, spoke this verse:

original: “Nāhaṃ kāsipati bhīto, ogayha parisaṃ tava;
analyzed: na aham bhītaḥ ogayha parisam tava
translated: “I am not afraid, O lord of Kāsi, having come into your presence;

original: Nāhaṃ bhayā na bhāsissaṃ, vākyaṃ atthasmiṃ tādise”ti.
analyzed: na aham bhayā na bhāsissam vākyam atthasmin tādisā iti
translated: Out of fear I will not speak, a statement in such a matter.”

original: Tattha tādiseti apica kho pana tathārūpe atthe uppanne vākyaṃ bhāsissāmīti vacanokāsaṃ olokento nisinnomhīti attho.
analyzed: tattha tādisā iti apica kho pana tathārūpe atthe uppanne vākyam bhāsissāmi iti vacana ukāsam olokentaḥ nisinnaḥ mhi iti attho
translated: Herein, in such a case means the meaning is that I was sitting looking out for an opportunity to speak, thinking, “When such a matter arises, I will speak.”

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā tassa kathaṃ vaḍḍhetukāmatāya parihāsaṃ karonto āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā tassa katham vaḍḍhetu kāma tāya parihāsam karontaḥ āha
translated: After hearing that, the king, out of a desire to increase his talk, said, making fun of him:

original: “Na te abhisaraṃ passe, na rathe napi pattike;
analyzed: na te abhisaram passe na rathe na pi pattike
translated: “I do not see your army, nor your chariot, nor your infantry;

original: Nāssa cammaṃva kīṭaṃ vā, vammite ca dhanuggahe.
analyzed: na assa cammam iva kīṭam vā vammite ca dhanuggahe
translated: Nor your skin, nor your worm, nor your dung, nor your bowman.

original: “Na hiraññaṃ suvaṇṇaṃ vā, nagaraṃ vā sumāpitaṃ;
analyzed: na hiraññam suvaṇṇam vā nagaram vā su māpitam
translated: “Not gold or silver, nor a well-built city,

original: Okiṇṇaparikhaṃ duggaṃ, daḷhamaṭṭālakoṭṭhakaṃ;
analyzed: okiṇṇa parikham duggam daḷham aṭṭāla koṭṭhakam
translated: A fortress crowded with a moat, and strong with towers and ramparts;

original: Yattha paviṭṭho sumukha, bhāyitabbaṃ na bhāyasī”ti.🔽Tattha abhisaranti rakkhaṇatthāya parivāretvā ṭhitaṃ āvudhahatthaṃ parisaṃ te na🔽passāmi. Nāssāti ettha assāti nipātamattaṃ. Cammanti saraparittāṇacammaṃ. Kīṭanti
analyzed: yattha paviṭṭhaḥ su mukha bhāyitabbam na bhāyasi iti  tattha abhisaranti rakkhaṇa atthāya parivāretvā ṭhitam āvudha hattham parisam te na  passāmi na assa ati ettha assa ati nipāta mattam cammanti sara parittāṇa cammam kīṭanti
translated: Where, O fair-faced one, having entered, you would not fear to be afraid.”

original: kīṭaṃ cāṭikapālādi vuccati. Cāṭikapālahatthāpi te santike natthīti dīpeti. Vammiteti
analyzed: kīṭam cāṭi kapāla ādi vuccati cāṭi kapāla hatthā api te santike natthi iti dīpeti vammitā iti
translated: Herein, I do not see your army means I do not see the assembly standing around for protection with weapons in their hands. Nor your skin means the skin of a deer for protection. Worm means a worm is called a potsherd, etc. It shows that you have no potsherds in your hand. Dung means

original: cammasannaddhe. Na hiraññanti yaṃ nissāya na bhāyasi, taṃ hiraññampi te na passāmi.
analyzed: camma sannaddhe na hiraññanti yam nissāya na bhāyasi tam hiraññam pi te na passāmi
translated: and I am clad in skin. As for gold, I do not see any gold in you, that is, anything on the basis of which you would not be afraid.

original: Evaṃ raññā “kiṃ te abhāyanakāraṇa”nti vutte taṃ kathento āha –
analyzed: evam raññā kim te abhāyana kāraṇanti vutte tam kathentaḥ āha
translated: When the king asked him, “What is it that you are not afraid of? “ he told him:

original: “Na me abhisarenattho, nagarena dhanena vā;
analyzed: na me abhisarena atthaḥ nagarena dhanena vā
translated: “I have no need of a city, or of wealth,

original: Apathena pathaṃ yāma, antalikkhecarā mayaṃ.
analyzed: apathena patham yāma antalikkhe carāḥ mayam
translated: I go by the sky-path, not by the road.

original: “Sutā ca paṇḍitā tyamhā, nipuṇā catthacintakā;
analyzed: sutā ca paṇḍitā nipuṇā cattha cintakā
translated: “We have heard that you are wise, skilled in thinking about things;

original: Bhāsematthavatiṃ vācaṃ, sacce cassa patiṭṭhito.
analyzed: bhāsematthavatim vācam sacce ca assa patiṭṭhitaḥ
translated: Speak words that are meaningful, and stand firm in truth.

original: “Kiñca tuyhaṃ asaccassa, anariyassa karissati;
analyzed: kiñca tuyham asaccassa anariyassa karissati
translated: “And what will you do with your untruth, your unrighteousness?

original: Musāvādissa luddassa, bhaṇitampi subhāsita”nti.
analyzed: musāvādissa luddassa bhaṇitam pi su bhāsitanti
translated: For even what is well-spoken is mere prattle for one who is a liar and a thief.”

original: Tattha abhisarenāti ārakkhaparivārena. Atthoti etena mama kiccaṃ natthi. Kasmā? Yasmā
analyzed: tattha abhisarena āti ārakkha parivārena etena mama kiccam natthi kasmai yasmai
translated: Herein, of a city means of a city with a protective wall. As for wealth, I have no need of it. Why not? Because

original: apathena tumhādisānaṃ amaggena pathaṃ māpetvā yāma, ākāsacārino mayanti. Paṇḍitā
analyzed: apathena amaggena patham māpetvā yāme ākāsa cārinaḥ paṇḍitā
translated: we go by the sky-path, not by the road, for we travel through the sky. We have heard that you are wise, skilled in thinking about things;

original: tyamhāti paṇḍitāti tayā sutāmhā, teneva kāraṇena amhākaṃ santikā dhammaṃ sotukāmo
analyzed: paṇḍitā ati tayā sutā amhā tena iva kāraṇena amhākam santikā dhammam sotu kāmo
translated: we have heard that you are wise, therefore you are desirous of hearing the Dhamma from us.

original: kira no gāhāpesi. Sacce cassāti sace pana tvaṃ sacce patiṭṭhito assa, atthavatiṃ
analyzed: kira naḥ gāhāpesi sacce sacce cassa ati sace pana tvam sacce patiṭṭhitaḥ assa atthavatim
translated: “If you are established in truth, then you will be able to take it.”

original: kāraṇanissitaṃ vācaṃ bhāseyyāma. Asaccassāti vacīsaccarahitassa tava subhāsitaṃ muṇḍassa🔽dantasūci viya kiṃ karissati.
analyzed: kāraṇa nissitam vācam bhāseyyāma asaccassa ati vacī sacca rahitassa tava su bhāsitam muṇḍassa  dantasūci viya kim karissati
translated: “If you are established in truth, then we will speak words that are meaningful and have a reason. If you are without truth, then what good is it to speak well to you, who are like a tooth-stick for a toothless one?

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “kasmā maṃ musāvādī anariyoti vadasi, kiṃ mayā kata”nti āha. Atha naṃ sumukho “tena hi, mahārāja, suṇāhī”ti vatvā āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā kasmai mam musā vādī vadasi kim mayā āha atha nam sumukhaḥ tena hi mahā rāja suṇāhi iti vatvā āha
translated: ” Having heard that, the king said, “Why do you call me a liar and a bad person? What have I done?” Then Sumukha said, “Well then, great king, listen!” and spoke this verse:

original: “Taṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ vacanā, imaṃ khemamakārayi;
analyzed: tam brāhmaṇānam vacanā imam khemam akārayi
translated: “By the words of the brahmins, you made this safe place;

original: Abhayañca tayā ghuṭṭhaṃ, imāyo dasadhā disā.
analyzed: abhayam ca tayā ghuṭṭham dasadhā disā
translated: And you gave protection, in these ten directions.

original: “Ogayha te pokkharaṇiṃ, vippasannodakaṃ suciṃ;
analyzed: ogayha te pokkharaṇim vippasanna udakam sucim
translated: “Having descended into the lotus pond, with clear and pure water;

original: Pahūtaṃ cādanaṃ tattha, ahiṃsā cettha pakkhinaṃ.
analyzed: pahūtam ca adanam tattha ahiṃsā ca ittha pakkhinam
translated: There is abundant food, and here there is no harm to the birds.

original: “Idaṃ sutvāna nigghosaṃ, āgatamha tavantike;
analyzed: idam sutvāna nigghosam āgatamha tava antike
translated: “Having heard this sound, we have come into your presence;

original: Te te baddhasma pāsena, etaṃ te bhāsitaṃ musā.
analyzed: te te pāsena etam te bhāsitam musā
translated: We are bound by your snare, and this speech of yours is false.

original: “Musāvādaṃ purakkhatvā, icchālobhañca pāpakaṃ;

original: Mama paṭhamaṃ gantvā pāyāsaṃ yācitvā nisinnakāle tumhe brāhmaṇavaṇṇena paṭipāṭiyā🔽āgantvā yāceyyāthā”ti vatvā sayaṃ tāva brāhmaṇavaṇṇena taṃ upasaṅkamitvā “bho, kataro🔽bārāṇasigamanamaggo”ti pucchi. Atha naṃ macchariyakosiyo “kiṃ ummattakosi, bārāṇasimaggampi
analyzed: mama paṭhamam gantvā pāyāsam yācitvā nisinna kāle tumhe brāhmaṇa vaṇṇena paṭipāṭiyā  āgantvā yāceyyātha ati vatvā sayam tāva brāhmaṇa vaṇṇena tam upasaṅkamitvā bho kataraḥ  bārāṇasi gamana maggo ti pucchi atha nam macchariya kosiyaḥ kim ummattakaḥ si bārāṇasi maggam pi
translated: You wait here, and I will go first and ask him for milk-rice. When I am seated, you come one by one, disguised as Brahmins,🔽and ask him for milk-rice.” So Sakka went to Macchariyakosiya, disguised as a Brahmin, and asked him, “Sir, which is the road to Bārāṇasī?”

original: na jānāsi, kiṃ ito esi, etto yāhī”ti āha.
analyzed: na jānāsi kim itas esi ettas yāhi iti āha
translated: Macchariyakosiya replied, “You are mad, aren’t you? You don’t even know the road to Bārāṇasī. Where are you coming from? Where are you going?”

original: Sakko tassa vacanaṃ sutvā asuṇanto viya “kiṃ kathesī”ti taṃ upagacchateva. Sopi,🔽“are, badhira brāhmaṇa, kiṃ ito esi, purato yāhī”ti viravi. Atha naṃ sakko, “bho,
analyzed: sakko tassa vacanam sutvā a suṇantaḥ viya kim kathesi iti tam upagacchatā iva saḥ api  are badhira brāhmaṇa kim itas esi puratas yāhi iti atha nam sakkaḥ bho
translated: Sakka pretended not to hear and went up to him, saying, “What did you say?”🔽Macchariyakosiya shouted, “You deaf Brahmin! Where are you coming from? Where are you going?”

original: kasmā viravasi, dhūmo paññāyati, aggi paññāyati, pāyāso paccati, brāhmaṇānaṃ nimantanaṭṭhānena
analyzed: kasmai viravasi dhūmo paññāyati aggi paññāyati pāyāso paccati brāhmaṇānam nimantana ṭṭhānena
translated: Sakka said, “Sir, why do you shout? There is smoke, there is fire, there is milk-rice cooking. This is the place where the Brahmins are invited.

original: bhavitabbaṃ, ahampi brāhmaṇānaṃ bhojanakāle thokaṃ labhissāmi, kiṃ maṃ nicchubhasī”ti
analyzed: bhavitabbam aham pi brāhmaṇānam bhojana kāle thokam labhissāmi kim mama nicchubhasi iti
translated: “I shall get a little at the time of the Brahmans’ meal. Why do you try to frighten me?”

original: vatvā “natthettha brāhmaṇānaṃ nimantanaṃ, purato yāhī”ti vutte “tena hi kasmā kujjhasi,
analyzed: vatvā nattha itthā brāhmaṇānam nimantanam puratas yāhi iti vutte tena hi kasmā kujjhasi
translated: “There is no invitation to the Brahmans here. Go on in front.” “Then why do you get angry?

original: tava bhojanakāle thokaṃ labhissāmī”ti āha. Atha naṃ so “ahaṃ te ekasitthampi na dassāmi,
analyzed: tava bhojana kāle thokam labhissāmi iti āha atha nam saḥ aham te eka sittham pi na dassāmi
translated: I shall get a little at the time of your meal.” “I will not give you so much as a single grain of rice.

original: thokaṃ idaṃ mama yāpanamattameva, mayāpi cetaṃ yācitvāva laddhaṃ, tvaṃ aññato āhāraṃ
analyzed: thokam idam mama yāpanam attam eva mayā api ca itam yācitvā ava laddham tvam aññatas āhāram
translated: This is only enough to keep me alive. I got it by begging. You must seek your food elsewhere.”

original: pariyesāhī”ti vatvā bhariyaṃ yācitvā laddhabhāvaṃ sandhāyeva vatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: pariyesāhi iti vatvā bhariyam yācitvā laddha bhāvam sandhāya iva vatvā gātham āha
translated: So saying, he reminded his wife of the fact that he had obtained the food by begging, and he repeated the following Stanza,

original: “Neva kiṇāmi napi vikkiṇāmi, na cāpi me sannicayo ca atthi;🔽Sukiccharūpaṃ vatidaṃ parittaṃ, patthodano nālamayaṃ duvinna”nti.
analyzed: na iva kiṇāmi na api vikkiṇāmi na ca api me sannicayaḥ ca atthi 🔽su kiccha rūpam vatidam parittam patthodanaḥ nālam ayam
translated: I neither buy nor sell; I have no store of food;🔽This little food I have obtained by begging; I have no surplus to give to you.

original: Taṃ sutvā sakko “ahampi te madhurasaddena ekaṃ silokaṃ kathessāmi, taṃ suṇāhī”ti vatvā “na me tava silokena attho”ti tassa vārentasseva gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā sakkaḥ aham pi te madhura saddena ekam silokam kathessāmi tam suṇāhi iti vatvā na me tava silokena attho ti tassa vārentassa iva gāthā dvayam āha
translated: Having heard that, Sakka said: “I will also tell you a verse with a sweet sound, listen to it.” He said: “I do not need your verse.” Even while he was preventing him, he spoke two verses:

original: “Appamhā appakaṃ dajjā, anumajjhato majjhakaṃ;
analyzed: appamhe appakam dajjā anumajjhataḥ majjhakam
translated: “Having little, one should give little, having medium, one should give medium;

original: Bahumhā bahukaṃ dajjā, adānaṃ nūpapajjati.
analyzed: bahumhā bahukam dajjā a dānam nūpapajjati
translated: Having much, one should give much, not giving does not arise.

original: “Taṃ taṃ vadāmi kosiya, dehi dānāni bhuñja ca;
analyzed: tam tam vadāmi kosiya dehi dānāni bhuñja ca
translated: “This and that I say to you, Kosiya, give gifts and enjoy (them);

original: Ariyamaggaṃ samāruha, nekāsī labhate sukha”nti.
analyzed: ariya maggam samāruha na ekāsī labhate sukhanti
translated: Ascend the Noble Path, the one who is not greedy obtains happiness.”

original: Tattha anumajjhato majjhakanti appamattakampi majjhe chetvā dve koṭṭhāse karitvā
analyzed: tattha anumajjhataḥ majjhakanti appamattakam pi majjhe chetvā dve koṭṭhāse karitvā
translated: Herein, having medium, one should give medium: having even a little, having cut it in the middle, having made two parts,

original: ekaṃ koṭṭhāsaṃ datvā tato avasesato anumajjhatopi puna majjhe chetvā eko koṭṭhāso
analyzed: ekam koṭṭhāsam da tvā tatas avasesataḥ anumajjhataḥ api puna majjhe chetvā ekaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ
translated: having given one part, having taken the other part, having cut it in the middle again,

analyzed: dātabbaḥ yā iva adānam nūpapajjati iti appam vā bahum vā dinnam hotu adānam nāma na hoti
translated: one part should be given. Not giving does not arise: whether little or much is given, not giving does not arise,

original: tampi dānameva mahapphalameva.
analyzed: tam pi dānam eva mahapphalam eva
translated: that giving also is very fruitful.

original: So tassa vacanaṃ sutvā “manāpaṃ te, brāhmaṇa, kathitaṃ, pāyāse pakke thokaṃ labhissasi,
analyzed: saḥ tassa vacanam sutvā manāpam te brāhmaṇa kathitam pāyāse pakke thokam labhissasi
translated: When he heard his words, Sakka said, “You have spoken well, brahmin. When the milk-rice is cooked, you will get a little.

original: nisīdāhī”ti āha. Sakko ekamante nisīdi. Tasmiṃ nisinne cando teneva niyāmena upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: nisīdāhi iti āha sakkaḥ ekamante nisīdi tasmin nisinne cando tena iva niyāmena upasaṅkamitvā

original: tatheva kathaṃ pavattetvā tassa vārentasseva gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: tathā iva katham gāthā dvayam āha
translated: and after he had spoken in the same way, he recited two stanzas to him as he was trying to stop him:

original: “Moghañcassa hutaṃ hoti, moghañcāpi samīhitaṃ;
analyzed: mogham ca assa hutam hoti mogham ca api samīhitam
translated: “In vain is the sacrifice, in vain the wish,

original: Atithismiṃ yo nisinnasmiṃ, eko bhuñjati bhojanaṃ.
analyzed: atithismin yaḥ nisinnasmin ekaḥ bhuñjati bhojanam
translated: When one man eats the food while the guest sits there.

original: Taṃ taṃ vadāmi kosiya, dehi dānāni bhuñja ca;
analyzed: tam tam vadāmi kosiya dehi dānāni bhuñja ca
translated: I tell you this, Kosiya: give gifts and eat,

analyzed: ariya maggam samāruha na ekāsī labhate sukhanti
translated: And mount the noble path, and you will find happiness.”

analyzed: tattha samīhitan ti

analyzed: saḥ tassa vacanam sutvā kicchena kasirena tena hi nisīda thokam labhissasi iti āha

translated: he recited two stanzas to him as he was trying to stop him:

analyzed: saccañcassa hutam hoti saccañca api samīhitam

translated: while he who eats food, when a guest is seated,

original: “Taṃ taṃ vadāmi kosiya, dehi dānāni bhuñja ca;
analyzed: tam tam vadāmi kosiya dehi dānāni bhuñja ca
translated: “Therefore I say to you, Kosiya, give gifts and enjoy yourself,

original: Ariyamaggaṃ samāruha, nekāsī labhate sukha”nti.

translated: and mount the noble path, for the one who is not stingy finds happiness.”

translated: “A man offers a sacrifice for many, for Gayā,

translated: “Here his oblation is, here his desire is,

analyzed: atithismin yaḥ nisinnasmin na ekaḥ bhuñjati bhojanam
translated: while he who eats food, when a guest is seated,

original: “Taṃ taṃ vadāmi kosiya, dehi dānāni bhuñja ca;
analyzed: tam tam vadāmi kosiya dehi dānāni bhuñja ca
translated: “Therefore I say to you, Kosiya, give gifts and enjoy yourself,

original: Ariyamaggaṃ samāruha, nekāsī labhate sukha”nti.
analyzed: ariya maggam samāruha na ekāsī labhate sukhanti
translated: and mount the noble path, for the one who is not stingy finds happiness.”

original: Tāsaṃ attho – yo puriso “nāgayakkhādīnaṃ balikammaṃ karomī”ti samuddasoṇḍipokkharaṇīādīsu🔽yaṃ kiñci sarañca upagantvā juhati, tattha balikammaṃ karoti, tathā bahukāya nadiyā
analyzed: tāsam atthaḥ yaḥ purisaḥ nāga yakkha ādīnam bali kammam karomi iti samudda soṇḍi pokkharaṇī ādīsu  yam kiñci sarañcaḥ upagantvā juhati tattha bali kammam karoti tathā bahukāya nadiyā
translated: The meaning of these verses is this. If a man, thinking, “I will perform a sacrifice to the nagas, spirits, etc.,” goes to a lake, a pond, a pool, etc.,

translated: “He who is caught in the net, the long line with the hook,

translated: He who eats his food alone, while a guest is sitting near,

analyzed: ariya maggam samāruha na ekāsī labhate sukhanti

analyzed: macchariyakosiyaḥ tam sutvā dukkha vedanaḥ nitthunanto tena hi nisīda thokam labhissasi iti

analyzed: āha pañcasikhaḥ gantvā mātalissa santike nisīdi iti tesu pañcasu brāhmaṇesu nisinna mattesu eva

analyzed: kosiyaḥ tāni disvā tumhākam etesu pattesu dātabba pāyāsaḥ natthi khadira ādīnam pattāni

translated: covered their rice-gruel with their bowls. A drop of urine fell on the back of Kosiya’s hand. The brahmans🔽said,

analyzed: kuṇḍikāhi udakam gahetvā pāyāsam abbhukiritvā bhuñjamānāḥ viya ahesum kosiyaḥ mayham pi  udakam detha hattham dhovitvā bhuñjissāmi iti āha tava udakam āharitvā hattham  dhovāti mayā tumhākam pāyāsaḥ dinnaḥ mayham thokam udakam detha ati mayam piṇḍa paṭipiṇḍa kammaṃ
translated: They were eating the rice-porridge, sprinkling it with water from their water-pots. Kosiya said, “Give me some water, I will wash my hands and eat.” “Go and fetch some water yourself and wash your hands.” “I gave you rice-porridge, give me a little water.” “We are busy with our own work.

original: nāma na karomā”ti. “Tena hi imaṃ ukkhaliṃ oloketha, hatthaṃ dhovitvā āgamissāmī”ti
analyzed: nāma na karoma ati tena hi imam ukkhalim oloketha hattham dhovitvā āgamissāmi iti
translated: They took water in their water-pots and sprinkled it over the rice-gruel, and ate it as if they were sprinkling it over a field. Kosiya said, “Give me some water, too. I will wash my hands and eat.” “Go and get water and wash your hands.” “I gave you rice-gruel. Give me a little water.” “We do not do the work of a slave.” “Well, then, look at this cauldron. I will wash my hands and come.”

original: nadiṃ otari. Tasmiṃ khaṇe sunakho ukkhaliṃ passāvassa pūresi. So taṃ passāvaṃ karontaṃ
analyzed: nadim otari tasmin khaṇe su nakhaḥ ukkhalim passāvassa pūresi saḥ tam passāvam karontam
translated: He went down to the river. At that moment a dog came and urinated into the cauldron. He saw the dog urinating into it,

original: disvā mahantaṃ daṇḍamādāya taṃ tajjento āgacchi. So assājānīyamatto hutvā taṃ anubandhanto
analyzed: disvā mahantam daṇḍam ādāya tam tad jentaḥ āgacchi saḥ assājānīya mattaḥ hutvā tam anubandhantaḥ
translated: and taking a big stick, he drove it away. The dog ran after him as fast as a thoroughbred horse.

original: nānāvaṇṇo ahosi, kāḷopi hoti setopi suvaṇṇavaṇṇopi kabaropi uccopi nīcopi, evaṃ nānāvaṇṇo
analyzed: nānā vaṇṇaḥ kāḷaḥ api hoti setaḥ upi suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ pi kabaraḥ upi uccaḥ upi nīcaḥ pi evam nānā vaṇṇaḥ
translated: He became many-colored, black, white, golden-colored, and brown, tall and short, and blue. Thus he became many-colored

original: hutvā macchariyakosiyaṃ anubandhi. So maraṇabhayabhīto brāhmaṇe upasaṅkami. Tepi
analyzed: hutvā saḥ maraṇa bhaya bhītaḥ brāhmaṇe upasaṅkami te pi
translated: and followed the jealous Kosiya. He, in fear of death, went to the brahmins.

original: uppatitvā ākāse ṭhitā. So tesaṃ taṃ iddhiṃ disvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: uppatitvā ākāse ṭhitā saḥ tesam tam iddhim disvā gātham āha
translated: and stood in the air. When he saw their power of supernormal penetration, he spoke this verse:

original: “Uḷāravaṇṇā vata brāhmaṇā ime, ayañca vo sunakho kissa hetu;
analyzed: uḷāra vaṇṇāḥ vata brāhmaṇāḥ ime ayam ca vaḥ su nakhaḥ kissa hetu
translated: “These Brahmans are of wondrous hue, but why is this your dog?

original: Uccāvacaṃ vaṇṇanibhaṃ vikubbati, akkhātha no brāhmaṇā ke nu tumhe”ti.
analyzed: uccāvacam vaṇṇa nibham vikubbati akkhātha naḥ brāhmaṇā ke nu tumhā iti
translated: He changes his appearance, high and low. Tell me, O Brahmans, who are you?”

original: Taṃ sutvā sakko devarājā –
analyzed: tam sutvā sakkaḥ devarājā
translated: When Sakka heard this, he said:

original: “Cando ca sūriyo ca ubho idhāgatā, ayaṃ pana mātali devasārathi;
analyzed: cando ca sūriyo ca ubho idha āgatāḥ ayam pana mātali deva sārathi
translated: “The Moon and the Sun have come here, and this is Mātali, the charioteer of the gods.

original: Sakkohamasmi tidasānamindo; Eso ca kho pañcasikhoti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: sakkaḥ aham asmi tidasānam indo eso ca kho pañcasikho ti vuccati iti
translated: I am Sakka, the lord of the Thirty-three. And this one is called Pañcasikha.”

original: Gāthaṃ vatvā tassa yasaṃ vaṇṇento gāthamāha –
analyzed: gātham vatvā tassa yasam vaṇṇentaḥ gātham āha
translated: Having spoken this verse, he spoke another verse in praise of Yasa:

original: “Pāṇissarā mudiṅgā ca, murajālambarāni ca;
analyzed: pāṇissarā mudiṅgā ca murajā alambarāni ca
translated: “The Panissara, the Mudiṅga, the Muraja, the Alambara,

original: Suttamenaṃ pabodhenti, paṭibuddho ca nandatī”ti.
analyzed: suttam enam pabodhenti paṭibuddhaḥ ca nandati iti
translated: The Sutta, they awaken him, and when he wakes, he rejoices.”

original: So tassa vacanaṃ sutvā “sakka, evarūpaṃ dibbasampattiṃ kinti katvā labhasī”ti pucchi.
analyzed: so tassa vacanam sutvā sakkaḥ evarūpam dibba sampattim kinti katvā labhasi iti pucchi
translated: When Yasa heard this, he asked, “Sakka, how did you get such divine glory?”

original: Sakko “adānasīlā tāva pāpadhammā maccharino devalokaṃ na gacchanti, niraye nibbattantī”ti dassento –
analyzed: sakkaḥ a dāna sīlā tāva pāpa dhammāḥ mad śarinaḥ deva lokam na gacchanti niraye nibbattanti iti dassento
translated: Sakka, in order to show that those who are evil, miserly, and stingy do not go to the world of the gods but are reborn in hell, said:

original: “Ye kecime maccharino kadariyā, paribhāsakā samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ;
analyzed: ye kecid ime kadariyā samaṇa brāhmaṇānaṃ
translated: “Those who are niggardly, miserly, and who revile ascetics and brahmins,

original: Idheva nikkhippa sarīradehaṃ, kāyassa bhedā nirayaṃ vajantī”ti. –
analyzed: idha iva nikkhippa sarīra deham kāyassa bhedāḥ nirayam vajanti iti
translated: After casting off this body here, at the break-up of the body go to hell.”

original: Imaṃ gāthaṃ vatvā dhamme ṭhitānaṃ devalokapaṭilābhaṃ dassetuṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: imam gātham vatvā dhamme ṭhitānam deva loka paṭilābham dassetum gātham āha
translated: After saying this, in order to show the attainment of the deva world to those who are established in the Dhamma, he spoke the verse:

original: “Ye kecime suggatimāsamānā, dhamme ṭhitā saṃyame saṃvibhāge;
analyzed: ye keci ime suggatim āsamānāḥ dhamme ṭhitā saṃyame saṃvibhāge
translated: “Those who, desiring a good destination, are established in the Dhamma, in restraint and in sharing,

original: Idheva nikkhippa sarīradehaṃ, kāyassa bhedā sugatiṃ vajantī”ti.
analyzed: idha iva nikkhippa sarīra deham kāyassa bhedā sugatim vajanti iti
translated: After casting off this body here, at the break-up of the body go to a good destination.”

original: Tattha āsamānāti āsīsantā. Ye keci sugatiṃ āsīsanti, sabbe te saṃyamasaṅkhāte dasasīladhamme
analyzed: tattha āsamānā ati āsīsantā ye keci sugatim āsīsanti sabbe te saṃyama saṅkhāte dasa sīla dhamme
translated: Herein, desiring a good destination means desiring a good destination. Those who desire a good destination, all of them, established in the ten virtues called restraint

original: saṃvibhāgasaṅkhāte dānadhamme ca ṭhitā hutvā idha sarīrasaṅkhātaṃ dehaṃ nikkhipitvā
analyzed: saṃvibhāga saṅkhāte dāna dhamme ca ṭhitā hutvā idha sarīra saṅkhātam deham nikkhipitvā
translated: and in the virtue of giving called sharing, after casting off this body here called the body,

original: tassa kāyassa bhedā sugatiṃ vajantīti attho.
analyzed: tassa kāyassa bhedā sugatim vajanti iti attho
translated: at the break-up of that body go to a good destination. This is the meaning.

original: Evaṃ vatvā ca pana, “kosiya, na mayaṃ tava santike pāyāsatthāya āgatā, kāruññena pana taṃ anukampamānā āgatāmhā”ti tassa pakāsetuṃ āha –
analyzed: evam vatvā ca pana kosiya na mayam tava santike pāyāsa atthāya āgatā kāruññena pana tam anukampamānāḥ āgatāmha ati tassa pakāsetuṃ āha
translated: After saying this, “Kosiya, we have not come to you for the sake of alms, but out of compassion we have come to you with sympathy,” he spoke in order to make it clear to him:

original: “Tvaṃ nosi ñāti purimāsu jātisu, so maccharī rosako pāpadhammo;
analyzed: tvam na asi ñāti purimāsu jātisu saḥ mad śarī rosakaḥ pāpa dhammo
translated: “You are our kinsman in former births, you were miserly, angry, and evil-natured.

original: Taveva atthāya idhāgatamhā, mā pāpadhammo nirayaṃ gamitthā”ti.
analyzed: tava iva atthāya mā pāpa dhammo nirayam gamittha ati
translated: We have come here for your sake, lest the evil-natured one go to hell.”

original: Tattha soti so tvaṃ. Mā pāpadhammoti ayaṃ amhākaṃ ñāti pāpadhammo mā nirayaṃ agamāti etadatthaṃ āgatamhāti attho.
analyzed: tattha saḥ iti saḥ tvam mā pāpa dhammaḥ ti ayam amhākam ñāti pāpa dhammaḥ mā nirayam agama ati etad attham āgatamhā ati atthaḥ
translated: Herein, he: you. Lest the evil-natured one go to hell: the meaning is, we have come here for the sake of this kinsman of ours who is evil-natured, lest he go to hell.

original: Taṃ sutvā kosiyo “atthakāmā kira me, ete maṃ nirayā uddharitvā sagge patiṭṭhāpetukāmā”ti tuṭṭhacitto āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā kosiyaḥ attha kāmā kira me ete mam nirayāḥ uddharitvā sagge patiṭṭhāpetu kāmā iti tuṭṭha cittaḥ āha
translated: On hearing this, Kosiya thought: “They are desirous of my welfare, it seems, and they want to rescue me from hell and establish me in heaven,” and with a delighted mind he said:

original: “Addhā maṃ vo hitakāmā, yaṃ maṃ samanusāsatha;
analyzed: addhā mam vaḥ hita kāmāḥ yam mama samanusāsatha
translated: “Surely you are desirous of my welfare, since you advise me thus.

original: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi, sabbaṃ vuttaṃ hitesibhi.
analyzed: sā uham tathā karissāmi sabbam vuttam hita īsibhi
translated: I will do as you say, all that you, who are desirous of my welfare, have said.

original: “Esāhamajjeva uparamāmi, na cāhaṃ kiñci kareyya pāpaṃ;
analyzed: esā aham ajjā iva uparamāmi na ca aham kiñci kareyya pāpam
translated: “I will refrain from this very day, I will do no evil at all,

original: Na cāpi me kiñci adeyyamatthi, na cāpidatvā udakaṃ pivāmi.
analyzed: na ca api me kiñci adeyyam atthi na ca api datvā udakam pivāmi
translated: I will have nothing that should not be had, and I will not drink water unshared.

original: “Evañca me dadato sabbakālaṃ, bhogā ime vāsava khīyissanti;
analyzed: evam ca me dadataḥ sabbakālam bhogāḥ ime vāsava khīyissanti
translated: “And as I give thus all the time, these riches of mine, Vāsava, will be exhausted,

original: Tato ahaṃ pabbajissāmi sakka, hitvāna kāmāni yathodhikānī”ti.
analyzed: tatas aham pabbajissāmi sakka hitvāna kāmāni yathā udhikāni iti
translated: So I will go forth, Sakka, having abandoned sensual desires as much as is fitting.”

original: Tattha manti mama. Voti tumhe. Yaṃ manti yena maṃ samanusāsatha, tena me tumhe hitakāmā.
analyzed: tattha manti mama tumhe yam manti yena mama samanusāsatha tena me tumhe hita kāmā
translated: Yaṃ manti means by what you advise me.🔽Tathā karissāmi means I will do just as you say.

original: Tathāti yathā vadatha, tatheva karissāmi. Uparamāmīti maccharibhāvato uparamāmi.
analyzed: tathā iti yathā vadatha tathā iva karissāmi uparamāmi iti mad śari bhāvataḥ uparamāmi
translated: Uparamāmīti means I desist from miserliness.

original: Adeyyamatthīti ito paṭṭhāya ca mama ālopato upaḍḍhampi adeyyaṃ nāma natthi, na cāpidatvāti
analyzed: adeyyam atthi iti itas paṭṭhāya ca mama ālopataḥ upaḍḍham pi adeyyam nāma natthi na ca api datvā ati
translated: Adeyyam atthīti means from now on there is nothing that I will not give away, not even half a morsel.

original: udakapasatampi cāhaṃ labhitvā adatvā na pivissāmi. Khīyissantīti vikkhīyissanti.
analyzed: udaka pasatam pi ca aham labhitvā a datvā na pivissāmi khīyissanti iti vikkhīyissanti
translated: Na cāpidatvā means I will not drink water without giving it to others.

original: Yathodhikānīti vatthukāmakilesakāmavasena yathāṭhitakoṭṭhāsāniyeva.
analyzed: yathā udhikāni iti vatthu kāma kilesa kāma vasena
translated: Yathodhikānīti means just as they are, according to their respective positions, as objects of sense desire and as defilements of sense desire.

original: Sakko macchariyakosiyaṃ dametvā nibbisevanaṃ katvā dānaphalaṃ jānāpetvā dhammadesanāya
analyzed: sakkaḥ macchariya kosiyam dametvā nibbisevanam katvā dāna phalam jānāpetvā dhamma desanāya
translated: Sakka, having tamed the miserly king, having made him free from attachment, having made him understand the fruit of giving,

original: pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhāpetvā saddhiṃ tehi devanagarameva gato. Macchariyakosiyopi
analyzed: pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhāpetvā saddhim tehi deva nagaram eva gataḥ macchariya kosiyaḥ pi
translated: having established him in the five precepts through a discourse on the Dhamma, went to the city of the gods together with him. The miserly king,

original: nagaraṃ pavisitvā rājānaṃ anujānāpetvā “gahitagahitabhājanāni pūretvā gaṇhantū”ti
analyzed: nagaram pavisitvā rājānam anujānāpetvā gahita gahita bhājanāni pūretvā gaṇhantu uti
translated: having entered the city, having obtained the king’s permission, “Let them fill up the vessels that they have taken,”🔽and having filled them, gave them away to the poor.

original: yācakānaṃ dhanaṃ datvā tasmiṃ khīṇe nikkhamma himavantato dakkhiṇapasse gaṅgāya ceva
analyzed: yācakānam dhanam da tvā tasmin khīṇe nikkhamma himavantataḥ dakkhiṇa passe gaṅgāya ca iva
translated: Having given wealth to those who asked, when that was exhausted he went forth from the Himalayas to the south of the Ganges and

original: ekassa ca jātassarassa antare paṇṇasālaṃ katvā pabbajitvā vanamūlaphalāhāro tattha
analyzed: ekassa ca jāta ssarassa antare paṇṇa sālam katvā pabbajitvā vana mūla phala āhāraḥ tattha
translated: Having given away all his wealth to suppliants, he left his home and went to the Himalayas, where he built himself a leaf-hut on the southern side of the Himalayas, between the Ganges and the Jātaṃsarā River, and there went forth into the homeless state.

original: ciraṃ vihāsi, jaraṃ pāpuṇi. Tadā sakkassa āsā saddhā sirī hirīti catasso dhītaro
analyzed: ciram vihāsi jaram pāpuṇi tadā sakkassa āsā saddhā sirī hirīti catassaḥ dhītaraḥ
translated: There he lived for a long time, subsisting upon wild fruits and roots, and in course of time grew old. At that time Sakka had four daughters, āsā, saddhā, sirī, and hirī.

original: honti. Tā bahuṃ dibbagandhamālaṃ ādāya udakakīḷanatthāya anotattadahaṃ gantvā tattha
analyzed: honti tāḥ bahum dibba gandha mālam ādāya udaka kīḷana tthāya gantvā tattha
translated: Taking with them many celestial perfumes and garlands, they went to the Anotatta Lake to disport in the water.

original: kīḷitvā manosilātale nisīdiṃsu. Tasmiṃ khaṇe nārado nāma brāhmaṇatāpaso tāvatiṃsabhavanaṃ
analyzed: kīḷitvā manosilā tale nisīdiṃsu tasmin khaṇe nāradaḥ nāma brāhmaṇa tāpasaḥ
translated: Having sported in the water, they sat down upon the Golden Terrace. At that moment a certain seer named Nārada, who had attained the Supernatural Powers by the practice of austerities,

original: divāvihāratthāya gantvā nandanavanacittalatāvanesu divāvihāraṃ katvā pāricchattakapupphaṃ🔽chattaṃ viya chāyatthāya dhārayamāno manosilātalamatthakena attano vasanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: divāvihāra atthāya gantvā nandana vana cittalatā vanesu divāvihāram katvā pāricchattaka puppham  chattam viya chāyatthāya dhārayamāno manaḥ silā tala matthakena attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhānam
translated: went to the World of the Thirty-three to pass the day. Having passed the day in the Nandanavana and the Cittalatāvana, he took a pāricchattaka flower🔽and held it over his head as a sunshade to protect him from the sun. Then he went to his own dwelling-place, the Golden Cave,

original: kañcanaguhaṃ gacchati. Atha tā tassa hatthe taṃ pupphaṃ disvā yāciṃsu. Tamatthaṃ
analyzed: kañcana guham gacchati atha tā tassa hatthe tam puppham disvā yāciṃsu tam attham
translated: walking upon the Golden Terrace. When the four goddesses saw the flower in his hand, they asked him for it.

original: pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: To make this matter clear, the Teacher related the following

original: “Naguttame girivare gandhamādane, modanti tā devavarābhipālitā;
analyzed: naga uttame giri vare gandhamādane modanti tāḥ deva vara abhipālitā
translated: “On the most excellent mountain, the fragrant Gandhamadana, they rejoice, protected by the most excellent gods.

original: Athāgamā isivaro sabbalokagū, supupphitaṃ dumavarasākhamādiya.
analyzed: atha agamā isi varaḥ sabba loka gū su pupphitam duma vara sākham ādiya
translated: Then the lord of seers, the most excellent one in the world, came, holding a branch of a blossoming tree.

original: “Suciṃ sugandhaṃ tidasehi sakkataṃ, pupphuttamaṃ amaravarehi sevitaṃ;
analyzed: sucim sugandham tidasehi sakkatam pupphuttamam amara varehi sevitam
translated: “Pure, fragrant, honored by the three gods, the most excellent flower, served by the most excellent immortals.

original: Aladdha maccehiva dānavehi vā, aññatra devehi tadārahaṃ hidaṃ.
analyzed: aladdha maccehi iva dānavehi vā aññatra devehi hidam
translated: It is worthy of them, except for the gods, like the mortals or the demons.

original: “Tato catasso kanakattacūpamā, uṭṭhāya nāriyo pamadādhipā muniṃ;
analyzed: tatas catasso uṭṭhāya nāriyaḥ pamada adhipāḥ munim
translated: “Then four women, like golden palm trees, arose, the leaders in heedlessness, to the sage.

original: Āsā ca saddhā ca sirī tato hirī, iccabravuṃ nāradadeva brāhmaṇaṃ.
analyzed: āsā ca saddhā ca brāhmaṇam
translated: Hope, Faith, Glory, and then Shame, they spoke to the brahmin, the god Narada.

original: “Sace anuddiṭṭhaṃ tayā mahāmuni, pupphaṃ imaṃ pārichattassa bramhe;
analyzed: sace an uddiṭṭham tayā mahā muni puppham imam pārichattassa bramhe
translated: “If this flower, O great sage, is not intended by you, O brahmin, for the parasol tree,

original: Dadāhi no sabbā gati te ijjhatu, tuvampi no hohi yatheva vāsavo.
analyzed: dadāhi naḥ sabbā gati te ijjhatu tuvam pi naḥ hohi yathā iva vāsavaḥ
translated: Give it to us all, may your purpose be accomplished, and may you be like Vāsava to us.”

original: “Taṃ yācamānābhisamekkha nārado, iccabravī saṃkalahaṃ udīrayi;
analyzed: tam nāradaḥ saṃkalaham
translated: Narada, seeing them begging, spoke, expressing his disagreement:

original: Na mayhamatthatthi imehi koci naṃ, yāyeva vo seyyasi sā piḷandhathā”ti.
analyzed: na mayham atthatthi imehi koci nam vaḥ seyyasi sā piḷandhatha ati
translated: “I have no need for any of these, take her who is best among you.”

original: Tattha girivareti purimassa vevacanaṃ. Devavarābhipālitāti sakkena rakkhitā. Sabbalokagūti🔽devaloke ca manussaloke ca sabbattha gamanasamattho. Dumavarasākhamādiyāti sākhāya
analyzed: tattha giri vara iti purimassa vevacanam deva vara abhipālitā ati sakkena rakkhitā sabba loka gūti  deva loke ca manussa loke ca sabbattha gamana samatthaḥ duma vara sākham ādiyāti sākhāya
translated: Herein, ‘on the mountain’s crest’ is a synonym for ‘on the mountain’s top’. ‘Guarded by the gods’ means guarded by Sakka. ‘To all the worlds’

original: jātattā dumavarasākhanti laddhanāmaṃ pupphaṃ gahetvā. Sakkatanti katasakkāraṃ. Amaravarehīti
analyzed: jāta ttā laddha nāmam puppham gahetvā kata sakkāram amara varehi iti
translated: means able to go everywhere in the world of the gods and the world of men. ‘Taking a flower from the choicest tree’ means taking a flower called ‘choicest tree’s branch’ because it is born on a branch. ‘Honoured’ means honoured by Sakka. ‘On the choicest of the immortals’

original: sakkaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Aññatra devehīti ṭhapetvā deve ca iddhimante ca aññehi manussehi
analyzed: sakkam sandhāya vuttam aññatra devehi iti ṭhapetvā deve ca iddhimante ca aññehi manussehi
translated: means this is said referring to Sakka. ‘By none other than the gods’ means by no other men or spirits possessing supernormal power.

original: vā yakkhādīhi vā aladdhaṃ. Tadārahaṃ hidanti tesaṃyeva hi taṃ arahaṃ anucchavikaṃ.
analyzed: vā yakkha ādīhi vā a laddham tadā araham hidanti tesam yā iva hi tam araham an ucchavikam
translated: ‘It is worthy of them’ means it is worthy of them, it is suitable for them.

original: Kanakattacūpamāti kanakūpamā tacā. Uṭṭhāyāti ayyo mālāgandhavilepanādipaṭivirato
analyzed: kanaka ttaca upamā ati kanaka upamā tacā uṭṭhāya ati ayyaḥ mālā gandha vilepana ādi paṭivirataḥ
translated: ‘Like the bark of gold’ means like the bark of gold. ‘Rising up’ means ‘The venerable one, who has renounced garlands, scents, unguents, etc.,

original: pupphaṃ na piḷandhissati, ekasmiṃ padese chaḍḍessati, etha taṃ yācitvā pupphaṃ piḷandhissāmāti
analyzed: puppham na piḷandhissati ekasmin padese chaḍḍessati etha tam yācitvā puppham piḷandhissāma ati
translated: will not plait the flower, he will throw it away in one place, come, let us ask him and plait the flower’.

translated: how can I speak? “I have no use for these flowers by name,” he shows that he is abstaining from

translated: The meaning is: O blessed ones, this speech spoken by you is not fitting for me. For,
