translated: eat it, do not make a fuss. Having eaten it, it destroys twelve evil things: this ambrosia destroys twelve evil states. Hunger:🔽first of all it destroys the state of being hungry. Thirst:🔽secondly it destroys the thirst for drinking water. Discontent:

original: paṭhamaṃ tāva chātabhāvaṃ hanati, dutiyaṃ pānīyapipāsaṃ, tatiyaṃ ukkaṇṭhitaṃ, catutthaṃ
analyzed: paṭhamam tāva chāta bhāvam hanati dutiyam pānīya pipāsam tatiyam ukkaṇṭhitam catuttham
translated: thirdly it destroys discontent. Fatigue:🔽fourthly it destroys the fatigue of the body. Sloth:🔽fifthly it destroys the state of being slothful. Anger:

original: kāyadarathaṃ, pañcamaṃ kilantabhāvaṃ, chaṭṭhaṃ kodhaṃ, sattamaṃ upanāhaṃ, aṭṭhamaṃ
analyzed: pañcamam kilanta bhāvam chaṭṭham kodham sattamam upanāham aṭṭhamam
translated: sixthly it destroys anger. Resentment:🔽seventhly it destroys resentment.

original: vivādaṃ, navamaṃ pesuṇaṃ, dasamaṃ sītaṃ, ekādasamaṃ uṇhaṃ, dvādasamaṃ tandiṃ ālasiyabhāvaṃ,
analyzed: vivādam navamam pesuṇam dasamam sītam ekādasamam uṇham dvādasamam tandim ālasiya bhāvam
translated: the ninth, strife; the tenth, slander; the eleventh, cold; the twelfth, heat; the thirteenth, sloth and torpor;

original: idaṃ rasuttamaṃ uttamarasaṃ sudhābhojanaṃ ime dvādasa pāpadhamme hanati.
analyzed: idam uttama rasam sudhā bhojanam ime dvādasa pāpa dhamme
translated: this supreme taste, this supreme food, ambrosia, destroys these twelve bad states.

original: Taṃ sutvā kosiyo attano vatasamādānaṃ āvikaronto –
analyzed: tam sutvā kosiyaḥ attanaḥ vata samādānam āvikarontaḥ
translated: Having heard this, Kosiya, revealing his own vow, said:

original: “Na kappatī mātali mayha bhuñjituṃ, pubbe adatvā iti me vatuttamaṃ;
analyzed: na kappati mātali mayha bhuñjitum pubbe a datvā iti me
translated: “It is not proper for me to eat, O Mātali, without first giving, this is my supreme vow;

original: Na cāpi ekāsnamariyapūjitaṃ, asaṃvibhāgī ca sukhaṃ na vindatī”ti. –
analyzed: na ca api asaṃvibhāgī ca sukham na vindati iti
translated: And I will not eat alone, revered sir, without sharing, one who does not share does not find happiness.”

original: Gāthaṃ vatvā, “bhante, tumhehi parassa adatvā bhojane kaṃ dosaṃ disvā idaṃ vataṃ samādinna”nti mātalinā puṭṭho āha –
analyzed: gātham vatvā bhante tumhehi parassa a datvā bhojane kam dosam disvā idam vatam samādinnam ti mātalinā puṭṭhaḥ āha
translated: Having spoken this verse, when asked by Mātali, “Venerable sir, having seen what fault in eating without first giving to others, did you make this vow?” he said:

original: “Thīghātakā ye cime pāradārikā, mittadduno ye ca sapanti subbate;
analyzed: thī ghātakāḥ ye cime pāradārikāḥ mitta ddunaḥ ye ca sapanti subbate
translated: “Those who kill women, those who have intercourse with others’ wives, those who betray friends, and those who drink alcohol;

original: Sabbe ca te maccharipañcamādhamā, tasmā adatvā udakampi nāsniye.
analyzed: sabbe ca te mat śari pañcama adhamā tasmai a datvā udakampi
translated: All of them, these five contemptible miserly people, therefore I will not eat even water without first giving.

original: “Sohitthiyā vā purisassa vā pana, dassāmi dānaṃ vidusampavaṇṇitaṃ;
analyzed: sohitthiyā vā purisassa vā pana dassāmi dānam
translated: “To a dear friend or to a man, I will give a gift praised by the wise;

original: Saddhā vadaññū idha vītamaccharā, bhavanti hete sucisaccasammatā”ti.🔽Tattha pubbeti paṭhamaṃ adatvā, atha vā iti me pubbe vatuttamaṃ idaṃ pubbeva mayā
analyzed: saddhā vadaññū idha vītamaccharāḥ bhavanti ha ite suci sacca sammatā ati  tattha pubbā iti paṭhamam a datvā atha vā iti me pubbe idam pubbā iva mayā
translated: “Herein, the faithful, the generous, the free from stinginess, Are held to be pure in their truth.”

original: vataṃ samādinnanti dasseti. Na cāpi ekāsnamariyapūjitanti ekakassa asanaṃ na ariyehi
analyzed: vatam samādinnanti dasseti na ca api eka asnam ariya pūjitanti ekakassa asanam na ariyehi
translated: Herein, first: without first giving, or else: “This is my first vow, which I have undertaken thus,” he shows. And not even a single seat: not even a single seat is worshipped by Noble Ones,

original: buddhādīhi pūjitaṃ. Sukhanti dibbamānusikaṃ sukhaṃ na labhati. Thīghātakāti itthighātakā.
analyzed: buddha ādīhi pūjitam sukham ti dibba mānusikam sukham na labhati thī ghātakā ati itthi ghātakā
translated: by Buddhas, etc. He does not get happiness: he does not get heavenly or human happiness. It-thì-ghātakā: it-thì-ghātakas.

original: Ye cimeti ye ca ime. Sapantīti akkosanti. Subbateti dhammikasamaṇabrāhmaṇe. Maccharipañcamāti
analyzed: ye cima iti ye ca ime sapanti iti akkosanti subbata iti dhammika samaṇa brāhmaṇe macchari pañcamā ti
translated: Ye cime: these which. Sapanti: they abuse. Subbate: the righteous ascetics and brahmans. Macchari-pañcamā:

original: maccharī pañcamo etesanti maccharipañcamā. Adhamāti ime pañca adhamā nāma. Tasmāti
analyzed: pañcamaḥ mad śarī pañcamā adhamā ati ime pañca adhamāḥ nāma tasmāt iti
translated: they have stinginess as their fifth. Adhamā: these five are called bad. Therefore:

original: yasmā ahaṃ pañcamaadhamabhāvabhayena adatvā udakampi nāsniye na paribhuñjissāmīti
analyzed: yasmai aham pañcama adhama bhāva bhayena a datvā udakam pi na paribhuñjissāmi iti
translated: because I undertook this vow, thinking, “Out of fear of becoming one of the five bad kinds of persons, I will not eat, I will not use even water, without first giving,”

original: imaṃ vataṃ samādiyiṃ. Sohitthiyā vāti so ahaṃ itthiyā vā. Vidusampavaṇṇitanti vidūhi
analyzed: imam vatam samādiyim sohitthiyā vāti saḥ aham itthiyā vā
translated: So-hitthiyā vā: so I, with a woman or. Vidusampavaṇṇit: praised by the wise.

original: paṇḍitehi buddhādīhi vaṇṇitaṃ. Sucisaccasammatāti ete okappaniyasaddhāya samannāgatā
analyzed: paṇḍitehi buddha ādīhi vaṇṇitam ete okappaniya saddhāya samannāgatā
translated: and praised by the wise, by the Buddhas and so forth. “Pure and true” means that they are endowed with the faith that is worthy of respect.

original: vadaññū vītamaccharā purisā sucī ceva uttamasammatā ca hontīti attho.
analyzed: vadaññū vītamaccharā purisā sucī ca iva uttamasammatā ca honti iti attho
translated: The meaning is that these men are pure and are considered to be the best, being generous and free from stinginess.

original: Taṃ sutvā mātali dissamānakāyena aṭṭhāsi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe tā catasso devakaññāyo catuddisaṃ
analyzed: tam sutvā mātali dissamāna kāyena aṭṭhāsi tasmin khaṇe tā catasso deva kaññāyo catuddisam
translated: Having heard this, Mātali stood there with his body visible. At that moment, those four celestial maidens stood in the four directions,

original: aṭṭhaṃsu, sirī pācīnadisāya aṭṭhāsi, āsā dakkhiṇadisāya, saddhā pacchimadisāya, hirī
analyzed: sirī pācīna disāya āsā dakkhiṇa disāya saddhā pacchima disāya hirī
translated: Sīri stood in the eastern direction, āsā in the southern direction, saddhā in the western direction, and hirī

original: uttaradisāya. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: uttara disāya tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: in the northern direction. Explaining that matter, the Teacher said:

original: “Ato matā devavarena pesitā, kaññā catasso kanakattacūpamā;
analyzed: atas matā deva varena pesitā kaññā catasso
translated: “From there, sent by the god-king, four maidens, like golden palm-trees,

original: Āsā ca saddhā ca sirī tato hirī, taṃ assamaṃ āgamu yattha kosiyo.
analyzed: āsā ca saddhā ca sirī tatas hirī tam assamam āgamu yattha kosiyaḥ
translated: āsā, saddhā, sīri, and hirī, came to the hermitage where Kosiya was.

original: “Tā disvā sabbo paramappamodito, subhena vaṇṇena sikhārivaggino;
analyzed: tāḥ disvā sabbaḥ parama pamoditaḥ subhena vaṇṇena sikhāri vagginaḥ
translated: “Seeing them, all were filled with supreme joy, with their bodies shining with beauty like the crest-jewel,

original: Kaññā catasso caturo catuddisā, iccabravī mātalino ca sammukhā.
analyzed: kaññā catasso caturaḥ catuddisā iccabravī mātalino ca sammukhā
translated: the four maidens in the four directions. Thus spoke Mātali in their presence.

original: “Purimaṃ disaṃ kā tvaṃ pabhāsi devate, alaṅkatā tāravarāva osadhī;
analyzed: purimam disam kā tvam pabhāsi devate alaṅkatā osadhī
translated: “In the eastern direction, who are you, goddess, shining like a star, adorned with the best of stars, like a medicine?

original: Pucchāmi taṃ kañcanavelliviggahe, ācikkha me tvaṃ katamāsi devatā.
analyzed: pucchāmi tam kañcana velli viggahe ācikkha me tvam katamā asi devatā
translated: I ask you, O you who are like a golden palm-tree, tell me, which goddess are you?

original: “Sirāha devī manujehi pūjitā, apāpasattūpanisevinī sadā;
analyzed: sirā āha devī manujehi pūjitā a pāpa sattūpa nisevinī sadā
translated: “I am the goddess Sirī, worshipped by men, always attending on the virtuous,

original: Sudhāvivādena tavantimāgatā, taṃ maṃ sudhāya varapañña bhājaya.
analyzed: sudhā vivādena tava antimā āgatā tam mama sudhāya vara pañña bhājaya
translated: I have come from the farthest end of the ocean because of the dispute over the nectar, O you of excellent wisdom, share the nectar with me.”

original: “Yassāhamicchāmi sudhaṃ mahāmuni, so sabbakāmehi naro pamodati;
analyzed: yassa aham icchāmi sudham mahā muni so sabba kāmehi naraḥ pamodati
translated: “O great sage, I desire the nectar, that man rejoices in all his desires;

original: Sirīti maṃ jānahi jūhatuttama, taṃ maṃ sudhāya varapañña bhājayā”ti.
analyzed: sirīti mam jānahi jūhatuttama tam mama sudhāya vara pañña bhājayāti
translated: Know me as Sirī, O best of sacrificers, O you of excellent wisdom, share the nectar with me.”

original: Tattha atoti tato. Matāti anumatā, atha devavarena anumatā ceva pesitā cāti attho.🔽Sabbo paramappamoditoti anavaseso hutvā atipamodito. “Sāma”ntipi pāṭho, tā devatā🔽sāmaṃ disvāti attho. Caturoti caturā. Ayameva vā pāṭho, cāturiyena samannāgatāti
analyzed: tattha ato ti tatas matā ati anumatā atha deva varena anumatā ca iva pesitā ca ati  sabbo parama pamā udito ti anavasesaḥ hutvā atipamā uditaḥ tāḥ devatāḥ  sāmam disvā iti attho caturā iti caturā ayam eva vā cāturiyena samannāgatā iti
translated: Herein, from that: from there. I was allowed: I was agreed upon, or else the meaning is: I was agreed upon and sent by the lord of the gods.

original: attho. Tāravarāti tārakānaṃ varā. Kañcanavelliviggaheti kañcanarūpasadisasarīre.
analyzed: tāra varā ti tārakānam varā kañcana velli viggahā iti kañcana rūpa sadisa sarīre
translated: All were exceedingly delighted: without exception they were exceedingly delighted. The reading sāmaṃ is also found, the meaning is: seeing the goddess face to face. Four: fourfold. This is the reading, the meaning is: endowed with the fourfold. Best of stars: best of the stars. Like a golden palm-tree: having a body like the colour of gold.

original: Sirāhāti sirī ahaṃ. Tavantimāgatāti tava santikaṃ āgatā. Bhājayāti yathā maṃ sudhā
analyzed: sirā hā ati sirī aham tavantim āgatā ati tava santikam āgatā yathā mama sudhā
translated: I am the vein of glory. I have come to you: I have come to you. Share with me: as you would share with your own body.

original: bhajati, tathā karohi, sudhaṃ me dehīti attho. Jānahīti jāna. Jūhatuttamāti aggiṃ juhantānaṃ uttama.
analyzed: bhajati tathā karohi sudham me dehi iti atthaḥ jānahi iti jāna aggim juhantānam uttama
translated: I am the glory of the veins. I have come to you means I have come to your presence. Share means do as though I were sharing in the ambrosia; give me ambrosia, is the meaning. Know means know. Best of those who offer sacrifice means best of those who offer sacrifice to the fire.

original: Taṃ sutvā kosiyo āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā kosiyaḥ āha
translated: Having heard that, Kosiya said:

original: “Sippena vijjācaraṇena buddhiyā, narā upetā paguṇā sakammunā;
analyzed: sippena vijjā ācaraṇena buddhiyā narāḥ upetā paguṇā sa kammunā
translated: “Men endowed with skill, knowledge, conduct, and intelligence, and skilled in their own work,

original: Tayā vihīnā na labhanti kiñcanaṃ, tayidaṃ na sādhu yadidaṃ tayā kataṃ.
analyzed: tayā vihīnāḥ na labhanti kiñcanam tayā idam na sādhu yat idam tayā katam
translated: deprived of you, do not obtain anything; therefore this that you have done is not good.

original: “Passāmi posaṃ alasaṃ mahagghasaṃ, sudukkulīnampi arūpimaṃ naraṃ;
analyzed: passāmi posam alasam mahagghasam su dukkulīnam pi arūpimam naram
translated: “I see a supported one, lazy, of great expense, a man of bad family, and of no form;

original: Tayānugutto siri jātimāmapi, peseti dāsaṃ viya bhogavā sukhī.
analyzed: tayā anuguttaḥ peseti dāsam viya bhogavā sukhī
translated: followed by you, glory sends even one of good birth, as a slave, happy and wealthy.

original: “Taṃ taṃ asaccaṃ avibhajjaseviniṃ, jānāmi mūḷhaṃ vidurānupātiniṃ;
analyzed: tam tam asaccam a vibhajja sevinim jānāmi mūḍham vidura anupātinim
translated: “That is not true; you do not share; I know you are confused, and do not follow the wise;

original: Na tādisī arahati āsanūdakaṃ, kuto sudhā gaccha na mayha ruccasī”ti.
analyzed: na tādisī arahati āsanūdakam kutas sudhā gaccha na ruccasi iti
translated: one such as you is not worthy of a seat and water, how much less ambrosia? Go away, you are not pleasing to me.”

original: Tattha sippenāti hatthiassarathadhanusippādinā. Vijjācaraṇenāti vedattayasaṅkhātāya
analyzed: tattha sippena ati hatthi assa ratha dhanu sippa ādinā vijjā ācaraṇena ati veda ttaya saṅkhātāya
translated: Herein, by skill means by the skills of elephant riding, horse riding, charioteering, archery, and so on. By knowledge and conduct means by the three Vedas called Rg, Yajus, and Sama.

original: vijjāya ceva sīlena ca. Paguṇā sakammunāti attano purisakārena padhānaguṇasamannāgatā.
analyzed: vijjāya ca iva sīlena ca paguṇā ati attano purisakārena padhāna guṇa samannāgatā
translated: With their own work: endowed with the quality of striving by their own manliness.🔽They get nothing: they get nothing at all, not even a little, of fame or happiness.

original: Kiñcananti kiñci appamattakampi yasaṃ vā sukhaṃ vā na labhanti. Yadidanti yaṃ etaṃ
analyzed: kiñcananti kiñci appamattakam pi yasam vā sukham vā na labhanti yat idam iti yam etam
translated: This: this which you have done.

original: issariyatthāya sippāni uggaṇhitvā carantānaṃ tayā vekallaṃ kataṃ, taṃ te na sādhu.
analyzed: issariya tthāya sippāni uggaṇhitvā carantānam tayā vekallam katam tam te na sādhu
translated: It is not good for you: it is not good, not proper, not suitable, not fit for you.🔽It is not beautiful: it is ugly.

original: Arūpimanti virūpaṃ. Tayānuguttoti tayā anurakkhito. Jātimāmapīti jātisampannampi
analyzed: arūpimanti virūpam tayā anuguttaḥ ti tayā anurakkhitaḥ jātimām api iti jāti sampannam pi
translated: You are protected by him: you are protected by him.🔽Even though he is well-born: even though he is endowed with good birth.

original: sippavijjācaraṇabuddhikammehi sampannampi. Pesetīti pesanakārakaṃ karoti. Taṃ tanti
analyzed: sippa vijjā ācaraṇa buddhi kammehi sampannam pi peseti iti pesana kārakam karoti tam tanti
translated: He sends him away: he makes him a messenger.🔽That is why: that is the reason why.

original: tasmā taṃ. Asaccanti sabhāvasaṅkhāte sacce avattanatāya asaccaṃ uttamabhāvarahitaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā tam sabhāva saṅkhāte sacce avattanatāya asaccam uttama bhāva rahitam
translated: It is not true: it is not true in the sense of being real, it is devoid of the highest state.

original: Avibhajjasevininti avibhajitvā yuttāyuttaṃ ajānitvā sippādisampannepi itarepi sevamānaṃ.
analyzed: avibhajja sevinim ti a vibhajitvā yutta ayuttam a jānitvā sippa ādi sampanne pi itare pi sevamānam
translated: He associates indiscriminately: he associates without discrimination, without knowing who is suitable or unsuitable, associating with those endowed with skill and so on as well as others.

original: Vidurānupātininti paṇḍitānupātiniṃ paṇḍite pātetvā pothetvā viheṭhetvā caramānaṃ.
analyzed: vidura anupātinim ti paṇḍita anupātinim paṇḍite pātetvā pothetvā viheṭhetvā caramānam
translated: He follows the wise: he follows the wise, he goes about harming, tormenting, and persecuting the wise.

original: Kuto sudhāti tādisāya nigguṇāya kuto sudhābhojanaṃ, na me ruccasi, gaccha mā idha tiṭṭhāti.
analyzed: kutas sudhā ati tādisāya nigguṇāya kutas sudhā bhojanam na me ruccasi gaccha mā idha tiṭṭha ati
translated: How could there be nectar for one so vile? I do not like you; go away, do not stand here.”

original: Sā tena paṭikkhittā tatthevantaradhāyi. Tato so āsāya saddhiṃ sallapanto āha –
analyzed: sā tena paṭikkhittā tattha iva antaradhāyi tatas saḥ āsāya saddhim sallapantaḥ āha
translated: Rejected by him, she disappeared right there. Then he, speaking with her, said:

original: “Kā sukkadāṭhā paṭimukkakuṇḍalā, cittaṅgadā kambuvimaṭṭhadhārinī;
analyzed: kā sukka dāṭhā paṭimukka kuṇḍalā cittaṅgadā kambu vimaṭṭha dhārinī
translated: “Who are you, with yellow teeth and earrings, with a Cittaṅga-tree branch in your hand,

original: Osittavaṇṇaṃ paridayha sobhasi, kusaggirattaṃ apiḷayha mañjariṃ.
analyzed: ositta vaṇṇam paridayha sobhasi kusaggi rattam apiḷayha mañjarim
translated: wearing a garment dyed with turmeric, holding a mañjari-flower?

original: “Migīva bhantā saracāpadhārinā, virādhitā mandamiva udikkhasi;
analyzed: migī iva bhantā sara cāpa dhārinā virādhitā mandam iva udikkhasi
translated: “You look as if you were struck by a deer, O speaker, with a sharp-pointed horn,

original: Ko te dutīyo ida mandalocane, na bhāyasi ekikā kānane vane”ti.🔽Tattha cittaṅgadāti citrehi aṅgadehi samannāgatā. Kambuvimaṭṭhadhārinīti karaṇapariniṭṭhitena
analyzed: te manda locane na ekikā kānane vana iti  tattha cittaṅgadā ati citrehi aṅgadehi samannāgatā kambu vimaṭṭha dhārinī iti karaṇa pariniṭṭhitena
translated: who is your second, O you with round eyes? Are you not afraid, alone in the forest?”🔽There, Cittaṅga means endowed with variegated limbs. Kambuvimaṭṭhadhārinī means wearing ornaments made of gold that is polished by hand.

original: vimaṭṭhasuvaṇṇālaṅkāradhārinī. Osittavaṇṇanti avasittaudakadhāravaṇṇaṃ dibbadukūlaṃ.
analyzed: vimaṭṭha suvaṇṇa alaṅkāra dhārinī ositta vaṇṇanti avasitta udaka dhāra vaṇṇam dibba dukūlam
translated: Osittavaṇṇanti means a divine silk garment dyed with water.

original: Paridayhāti nivāsetvā ceva pārupitvā ca. Kusaggirattanti kusatiṇaggisikhāvaṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: nivāsetvā ca iva pārupitvā ca kusaggi rattanti kusa tiṇaggi sikhā vaṇṇam
translated: Paridayhāti means wearing and covering. Kusaggirattanti means the colour of a flame of kusagrass fire.

original: Apiḷayha mañjarinti sapallavaṃ asokakaṇṇikaṃ kaṇṇe piḷandhitvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Saracāpadhārināti
analyzed: a piḷayha mañjarin ti sa pallavam asoka kaṇṇikam kaṇṇe piḷandhitvā iti vuttam hoti sara cāpa dhārinā iti
translated: and, having done so, she placed a branch of the As oka tree with leaves and buds in her ear.🔽She was frightened by the noise of the lion’s roar.

original: luddena. Virādhitāti viraddhapahārā. Mandamivāti yathā sā migī bhītā vanantare ṭhatvā🔽taṃ mandaṃ mandaṃ oloketi, evaṃ olokesi.
analyzed: luddena virādhitā ati viraddha apahārā mandam iva ati yathā sā migī bhītā vanantare  tam mandam mandam evam
translated: She looked at him as if in fear, standing in the forest.

original: Tato āsā āha –
analyzed: tatas āsau āha
translated: Then she said:

original: “Na me dutīyo idha matthi kosiya, masakkasārappabhavamhi devatā;
analyzed: na me dutīyaḥ idha matthi kosiya masakkasāra ppabhavamhi devatā
translated: “I have no second here, O Kosiya, I am a goddess born in the abode of Sakka.

original: Āsā sudhāsāya tavantimāgatā, taṃ maṃ sudhāya varapañña bhājayā”ti.
analyzed: āsā sudhā sāya tavantim āgatā tam mama sudhāya vara pañña bhājayāti
translated: I have come to you, O wise one, for nectar; give me nectar.”

original: Tattha masakkasārappabhavāti tāvatiṃsabhavane sambhavā.
analyzed: tattha tāvatiṃsa bhavane sambhavā
translated: Therein, “born in the abode of Sakka” means born in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.

original: Taṃ sutvā kosiyo “tvaṃ kira yo te ruccati, tassa āsāphalanipphādanena āsaṃ desi, yo te na ruccati, tassa na desi, natthi tayā samā patthitatthavināsikā”ti dīpento āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā kosiyaḥ tvam kira yaḥ te ruccati tassa āsā phala nipphādanena āsam desi yaḥ te na ruccati tassa na desi natthi tayā samā patthitatthavināsikā ti dīpentaḥ āha
translated: Having heard that, Kosiya said, “You say that you give hope to whoever you like by fulfilling his desire for the fruit of his hope, and you do not give hope to whoever you do not like. There is no one who destroys the desired object like you,” and he said:

original: “Āsāya yanti vāṇijā dhanesino, nāvaṃ samāruyha parenti aṇṇave;
analyzed: āsāya yanti vāṇijāḥ dhanesinaḥ nāvam samāruyha parenti aṇṇave
translated: “Merchants go for wealth, hoping for profit, and they cross the ocean in ships.

original: Te tattha sīdanti athopi ekadā, jīnādhanā enti vinaṭṭhapābhatā.
analyzed: te tattha sīdanti ekadā enti
translated: They come back defeated, with their hopes destroyed.🔽“Farmers plough their fields in hope of a harvest,

original: “Āsāya khettāni kasanti kassakā, vapanti bījāni karontupāyaso;
analyzed: āsāya khettāni kasanti kassakāḥ vapanti bījāni karontu pāyasaḥ
translated: They sow their seed in hope of a crop.🔽If the rain does not fall in due season,

original: Ītīnipātena avuṭṭhitāya vā, na kiñci vindanti tato phalāgamaṃ.
analyzed: a vuṭṭhitāya vā na kiñci vindanti phala āgamam
translated: They get nothing, and no harvest comes.🔽“Servants work for their master’s sake,

original: “Athattakārāni karonti bhattusu, āsaṃ purakkhatvā narā sukhesino;
analyzed: athattakārāni karonti bhattusu āsam purakkhatvā narā sukhesinaḥ
translated: Putting their hopes in him, seeking happiness.🔽But if the master is too harsh, they leave him,

original: Te bhatturatthā atigāḷhitā puna, disā panassanti aladdha kiñcanaṃ.
analyzed: te bhattuḥ atthāḥ atigāḷhitāḥ puna disā panassanti kiñcanaṃ
translated: And go away with nothing, in all directions.🔽“Abandoning grain, wealth, and relatives,

original: “Hitvāna dhaññañca dhanañca ñātake, āsāya saggādhimanā sukhesino;
analyzed: hitvāna dhaññañca dhanañca ñātake āsāya sagga adhimanāḥ sukhesinaḥ
translated: Putting their hopes in heaven, seeking happiness,🔽They torment themselves with painful austerities for a long time,

original: Tapanti lūkhampi tapaṃ cirantaraṃ, kumaggamāruyha parenti duggatiṃ.
analyzed: tapanti lūkham pi tapam cirantaram ku maggam āruyha parenti duggatim
translated: And, taking a wrong path, go to a bad destination.🔽“These hopes are considered to be deceptive;

original: “Āsā visaṃvādikasammatā ime, āse sudhāsaṃ vinayassu attani;
analyzed: ime āse visaṃvādika sammatāḥ ime āse vinayassu
translated: Banish them from your mind, as if they were poison.🔽One like you is not worthy even of water and a seat,

original: Na tādisī arahati āsanūdakaṃ, kuto sudhā gaccha na mayha ruccasī”ti.
analyzed: na tādisī arahati āsanūdakam kutas sudhā gaccha na ruccasi iti
translated: Much less of poison. Go away, you are not pleasing to me.”

original: Tattha parentīti pakkhandanti. Jīnādhanāti jīnadhanā. Iti tava vasena eke sampajjanti
analyzed: tattha parenti iti pakkhandanti jīnādhanā ati jīna dhanā iti tava vasena eke sampajjanti
translated: Herein, they go away means they fall away. With their hopes destroyed means with their wealth destroyed. Thus some succeed by your means

original: eke vipajjanti, natthi tayā sadisā pāpadhammāti vadati. Karontupāyasoti taṃ taṃ kiccaṃ🔽upāyena karonti. Ītīnipātenāti visamavātamūsikasalabhasukapāṇakasetaṭṭhikarogādīnaṃ
analyzed: eke vipajjanti natthi tayā sadisā pāpa dhammā ati vadati karontu pāyasā iti tam tam kiccam  upāyena karonti visama vāta mūsika salabha suka pāṇaka seta ṭṭhika roga ādīnam
translated: He says: “Some are ruined. There is no one worse than you.” “They do their work by means of a device”: they do this or that task

original: sassupaddavānaṃ aññataranipātena vā. Tatoti tato sassato te kiñci phalaṃ na vindanti,
analyzed: sassu paddavānam aññatara nipātena vā tatoti tatas sassato te kiñci phalam na vindanti
translated: by means of a device. “By means of the fall of a disease”: by means of the fall of a disease such as wind, bile, phlegm, or a combination of the three, or a disease caused by demons, or by the fall of a mouse, a cricket, a lizard, a white ant, or a spider.

original: tesampi āsacchedanakammaṃ tvameva karosīti vadati. Athattakārānīti yuddhabhūmīsu
analyzed: tesam pi āsa chedana kammam tvam eva karosi iti vadati athattakārāni iti yuddha bhūmīsu
translated: “From that”: from that they do not get any fruit at all. He says: “You alone do the work of cutting off their hopes.” “The work of heroes”:

original: purisakāre. Āsaṃ purakkhatvāti issariyāsaṃ purato katvā. Bhatturatthāti sāmino atthāya.🔽Atigāḷitāti paccatthikehi atipīḷitā viluttasāpateyyā ddhastasenavāhanā hutvā. Panassantīti🔽palāyanti. Aladdha kiñcananti kiñci issariyaṃ alabhitvā. Iti etesampi issariyālābhaṃ
analyzed: purisakāre āsam purakkhatvā ati issariyāsam puratas katvā bhattuḥ attha ati sāminaḥ atthāya  atigāḷitā ati paccatthikehi atipīḷitā vilutta sāpateyyāḥ hutvā panassanti iti  palāyanti kiñci issariyam a labhitvā iti etesam pi issariya alābham
translated: the work of men in battlefields. “With hope placed foremost”: with the hope for lordship placed in front. “For the sake of their master”: for the sake of their lord.🔽“When they are too much pressed”: when they are too much oppressed by their enemies, when their property is lost, when they are without money, army, and vehicles. “They flee”:

original: tvameva karosīti vadati. Saggādhimanāti saggaṃ adhigantumanā. Lūkhanti nirojaṃ pañcatapādikaṃ
analyzed: tvam eva karosi iti vadati sagga adhimanāḥ saggam adhigantu manāḥ nirojam
translated: they run away. “Having not gained anything”: having not gained any lordship. He says: “You alone do the work of gaining lordship for them.” “Those who wish to go to heaven”: those who wish to go to heaven. “Rough”: rough, with five factors,

original: kāyakilamathaṃ. Cirantaranti cirakālaṃ. Āsā visaṃvādikasammatā imeti evaṃ ime sattā
analyzed: kāya kilamatham cirantaranti cira kālam āsā visaṃvādika sammatāḥ ime iti evam ime sattā
translated: and bodily fatigue. For a long time: for a long period. These beings are considered to be false hopes: thus these beings

original: saggāsāya duggatiṃ gacchanti, tasmā tvaṃ āsā nāma visaṃvādikasammatā visaṃvādikāti
analyzed: saggāsāya duggatim gacchanti tasmai tvam āsā nāma visaṃvādika sammatā visaṃvādikā ati
translated: go to a bad destination for the sake of heaven, therefore you, hope, are considered to be false, are known as

original: saṅkhaṃ gatā. Āseti taṃ ālapati.
analyzed: saṅkham gatā āsa iti tam ālapati
translated: false. Hope: she spoke to her.

original: Sāpi tena paṭikkhittā antaradhāyi. Tato saddhāya saddhiṃ sallapanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: sā api tena paṭikkhittā antaradhāyi tatas saddhāya saddhim sallapantaḥ gātham āha
translated: She too, having been refused, disappeared. Then, conversing with Faith, he spoke a verse:

original: “Daddallamānā yasasā yasassinī, jighaññanāmavhayanaṃ disaṃ pati;
analyzed: daddallamānā yasasā yasassinī jighañña nāma vhayanam disam pati
translated: “Shining, resplendent with fame, looking for food, facing the direction called ‘far’,

original: Pucchāmi taṃ kañcanavelliviggahe, ācikkha me tvaṃ katamāsi devate”ti.
analyzed: pucchāmi tam kañcana velli viggahe ācikkha me tvam katamā asi devatā iti
translated: I ask you, you who are like a golden creeper, tell me, what deity are you?”

original: Tattha daddallamānāti jalamānā. Jighaññanāmavhayananti aparāti ca pacchimāti ca evaṃ jighaññena lāmakena nāmena vuccamānaṃ disaṃ pati daddallamānā tiṭṭhasi.
analyzed: tattha daddallamānā ati jalamānā jighañña nāma vhayanam ti aparā ati ca pacchimā ati ca evam jighaññena lāmakena nāmena vuccamānam disam pati daddallamānā tiṭṭhasi
translated: There, shining: shining. Looking for food, facing the direction called ‘far’: you stand facing the direction called ‘far’, which is said to be ‘far’ because it is distant.

original: Tato sā gāthamāha –
analyzed: sā gātham āha
translated: Then she spoke a verse:

original: “Saddhāha devī manujehi pūjitā, apāpasattūpanisevinī sadā;
analyzed: saddhā āha devī manujehi pūjitā a pāpa sattu upanisevinī sadā
translated: “Faith, the queen, is worshipped by humans, always attending on those with good natures,

original: Sudhāvivādena tavanti māgatā, taṃ maṃ sudhāya varapañña bhājayā”ti.
analyzed: sudhā vivādena mā āgatā tam mama sudhāya vara pañña bhājayāti
translated: do you, O Sudhā, of excellent wisdom, give me the nectar.”

original: Tattha saddhāti yassa kassaci vacanapattiyāyanā sāvajjāpi hoti anavajjāpi. Pūjitāti🔽anavajjakoṭṭhāsavasena pūjitā. Apāpasattūpanisevinīti anavajjasaddhāya ca ekantapattiyāyanusabhāvāra
analyzed: tattha saddhā ati yassa kassaci vacana pattiyā āyanā sā avajjā api hoti anavajjā api pūjitā ati  anavajja koṭṭhāsa vasena pūjitā a pāpa sattu upanisevinī iti anavajja saddhāya ca
translated: Herein, “faith” is the going to, the paying of respect to, the revering of, the saluting of, the worshipping of, the honouring of, the revering as a treasure, the revering as a sublime state, the revering as a stainless state, the revering as a state beyond reproach, of whatever is said by anyone at all.🔽“Honoured” is the revering of the stainless state.

original: paresupi pattiyāyanavidahanasamatthāya devatāyetaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: paresu pi devatāya itam nāmam
translated: “The follower of the good being” is the deity that is able to burn up the going to and the revering of others by means of the stainless faith and the single-minded going to and revering of itself.🔽Then Kosiya said to her: “These beings, having faith in the word of anyone at all, do this and that, and what they do is mostly not to be done. All that is said to be done by you.”

original: Athaṃ naṃ kosiyo “ime sattā yassa kassaci vacanaṃ saddahitvā taṃ taṃ karontā kattabbato akattabbameva bahutaraṃ karonti, taṃ sabbaṃ tayā kāritaṃ nāma hotī”ti vatvā evamāha –
analyzed: ime sattāḥ yassa kassaci vacanam saddahitvā tam tam karontā kattabbataḥ a kattabbam eva bahutaram karonti tam sabbam tayā kāritam nāma hoti iti vatvā evam āha
translated: Having said this, he spoke thus:🔽“Giving, self-control, and also restraint,🔽they do at one time by means of faith;

original: “Dānaṃ damaṃ cāgamathopi saṃyamaṃ, ādāya saddhāya karonti hekadā;
analyzed: dānam damam saṃyamam ādāya saddhāya karonti hekadā
translated: Stealing, lying, slander, and also backbiting,

original: Theyyaṃ musā kūṭamathopi pesuṇaṃ, karonti heke puna viccutā tayā.
analyzed: theyyam musā pesuṇam karonti heke puna tayā
translated: they do at another time by means of you.🔽“A man who looks on his wives as equal,

original: “Bhariyāsu poso sadisīsu pekkhavā, sīlūpapannāsu patibbatāsupi;
analyzed: bhariyāsu posaḥ sadisīsu pekkhavā sīlu upapannāsu
translated: who is devoted to those endowed with virtue,

original: Vinetvāna chandaṃ kulitthirāsupi, karoti saddhaṃ puna kumbhadāsiyā.
analyzed: vinetvāna chandam karoti saddham puna
translated: And, having rejected the chance to give to a woman with a husband, he gives to a slave-girl with a pot.

original: “Tvameva saddhe paradārasevinī, pāpaṃ karosi kusalampi riñcasi;
analyzed: tvam eva saddhe para dāra sevinī pāpam karosi riñcasi
translated: You, who are faithful to another’s wife, are doing evil and neglecting what is good.

original: Na tādisī arahati āsanūdakaṃ, kuto sudhā gaccha na mayha ruccasī”ti.
analyzed: na tādisī arahati āsanūdakam kutas sudhā gaccha na ruccasi iti
translated: One like you is not worthy of a seat and water, much less of the ambrosia. Go away, you are not pleasing to me.

original: Tattha dānanti dasavatthukaṃ puññacetanaṃ. Damanti indriyadamanaṃ. Cāganti deyyadhammapariccāgaṃ.🔽Saṃyamanti sīlaṃ. Ādāya saddhāyāti “etāni dānādīni mahānisaṃsāni kattabbānī”ti vadataṃ
analyzed: tattha dānanti dasa vatthukam puñña cetanam damanti indriya damanam cāganti deyya dhamma pariccāgam  saṃyamanti sīlam ādāya saddhāya ati etāni dāna ādīni mahā nisaṃsāni kattabbāni iti vadatam
translated: Herein, giving is the meritorious volition in the ten instances of giving. Restraint is the restraining of the faculties. Sacrifice is the relinquishing of an offering.🔽Self-control is virtue. Having taken faith in what is said by others, some people do these things, giving and so on, thinking, “These things that are said to have great fruit are to be done.”

original: vacanaṃ saddhāya ādiyitvāpi karonti ekadā. Kūṭanti tulākūṭādikaṃ vā gāmakūṭādikaṃ🔽kammaṃ vā. Karonti heketi eke manussā evarūpesu nāma kālesu imesañca atthāya theyyādīni
analyzed: vacanam saddhāya ādiyitvā api karonti ekadā tulā kūṭa ādikam vā gāma kūṭa ādikam  kammam vā karonti heke iti eke manussāḥ evarūpesu nāma kālesu imesam ca atthāya theyya ādīni
translated: Deceit is cheating with weights and measures, etc., and cheating in buying and selling, etc.

original: kattabbānīti kesañci vacanaṃ saddahitvā etānipi karonti. Puna viccutā tayāti puna
analyzed: kattabbāni iti kesañci vacanam saddahitvā etāni pi karonti puna tayā ati puna
translated: Some people do these things, thinking, “In such and such a time these things are to be done, such as theft, etc.,” having taken faith in the words of others. Again, having gone forth …

original: tayā visuttā sāvajjadukkhavipākānetāni na kattabbānīti vadataṃ vacanaṃ apattiyāyitvāpi
analyzed: tayā visuttā sāvajja dukkha vipākāni etāni na kattabbāni iti vadatam vacanam
translated: But they do not act according to her words.

original: karonti. Iti tava vasena sāvajjampi anavajjampi kareyyāsi vadati.
analyzed: karonti iti tava vasena sāvajjampi anavajjampi kareyyāsi vadati
translated: “You are the one who should do what is blameful and what is blameless.”🔽“With those who are like you” : with those who are like you in clan, in virtue, etc.

original: Sadisīsūti jātigottasīlādīhi sadisīsu. Pekkhavāti pekkhā vuccati taṇhā, sataṇhoti
analyzed: sadisīsu iti jāti gotta sīla ādīhi sadisīsu pekkhavā ti pekkhā vuccati taṇhā sa taṇho ti
translated: “With those who look” : “looking” is craving. The meaning is “with those who have craving.”🔽“With those who desire” : with those who desire and are lustful.

original: attho. Chandanti chandarāgaṃ. Karoti saddhanti kumbhadāsiyāpi vacane saddhaṃ karoti,
analyzed: chandanti chanda rāgam karoti saddhanti kumbhadāsiyā api vacane saddham karoti
translated: “You are the one who should have faith” : “You are the one who should have faith in the words of the slave-girl, the potter’s wife,

original: tassā “ahaṃ tumhākaṃ idaṃ nāma upakāraṃ karissāmī”ti vadantiyā pattiyāyitvā kulitthiyopi🔽chaḍḍetvā tameva paṭisevati, asukā nāma tumhesu paṭibaddhacittāti kumbhadāsiyāpi
analyzed: tassāḥ aham tumhākam idam nāma upakāram karissāmi iti vadantiyā pattiyā ayitvā  chaḍḍetvā tam eva paṭisevati asukā nāma tumhesu paṭibaddha cittā ati kumbhadāsiyā api
translated: and, acting according to her words, should abandon your own wife and serve her instead.”🔽“You are the one who should have faith in the words of the slave-girl, the potter’s wife,🔽and, acting according to her words, should serve another’s wife.”🔽“You are the one who should have faith in the words of the slave-girl, the potter’s wife,🔽and, acting according to her words, should serve another’s wife.”🔽“You are the one who should have faith in the words of the slave-girl, the potter’s wife,🔽and, acting according to her words, should serve another’s wife.”🔽“You are the one who should have faith in the words of the slave-girl, the potter’s wife,

original: vacane saddhaṃ katvāva paradāraṃ sevati. Tvameva saddhe paradārasevinīti yasmā taṃ
analyzed: vacane saddham katvā ava para dāram sevati tvam eva saddhe para dāra sevinī iti yasmai tam
translated: and, acting according to her words, should serve another’s wife.”🔽“You are the one who should have faith in the words of the slave-girl, the potter’s wife,

original: taṃ pattiyāyitvā tava vasena paradāraṃ sevanti pāpaṃ karonti kusalaṃ jahanti, tasmā
analyzed: tam pattiyāyitvā tava vasena paradāram sevanti pāpam karonti kusalam jahanti tasmai
translated: and, acting according to her words, should serve another’s wife.”

original: tvameva paradārasevinī tvaṃ pāpāni karosi, kusalampi riñcasi, natthi tayā samā lokavināsikā
analyzed: tvam eva para dāra sevinī tvam pāpāni karosi kusalam pi riñcasi natthi tayā samā loka vināsikā
translated: You are a paramour of other men’s wives. You do evil deeds and neglect good deeds. There is no woman in the world more destructive than you.

original: pāpadhammā, gaccha na me ruccasīti.
analyzed: pāpa dhammā gaccha na me ruccasi iti
translated: You are a wicked woman. Go away. I do not like you.”

original: Sā tattheva antaradhāyi. Kosiyopi uttarato ṭhitāya hiriyā saddhiṃ sallapanto gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: sā tattha iva antaradhāyi kosiyaḥ api uttaratas ṭhitāya hiriyā saddhim sallapantaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: She disappeared right there. Kosiya, speaking to Hiri who was standing to the north, spoke two verses:

original: “Jighaññarattiṃ aruṇasmimūhate, yā dissati uttamarūpavaṇṇinī;
analyzed: jighaññarattim aruṇasmim ūhate yā dissati uttama rūpa vaṇṇinī
translated: “At night, when the sun is setting, a beautiful woman is seen,

original: Tathūpamā maṃ paṭibhāsi devate, ācikkha me tvaṃ katamāsi accharā.
analyzed: tathūpamā mam paṭibhāsi devate ācikkha me tvam katamā asi accharā
translated: Shining like a goddess. Tell me, which goddess are you?”

original: “Kāḷā nidāgheriva aggijāriva, anileritā lohitapattamālinī;
analyzed: kāḷā nidāgheḥ iva aggijāḥ iva anila īritā lohita patta mālinī
translated: “Like a black cloud, like a fire, like a red-leafed vine swaying in the wind,🔽Why do you stand there, looking like a slow-moving deer,

original: Kā tiṭṭhasi mandamigāvalokayaṃ, bhāsesamānāva giraṃ na muñcasī”ti.
analyzed: kā tiṭṭhasi manda miga avalokayam giram na muñcasi iti
translated: Speaking but not releasing your voice?”

original: Tattha jighaññarattinti pacchimarattiṃ, rattipariyosāneti attho. Ūhateti aruṇe uggate.
analyzed: tattha jighañña rattim ti pacchima rattim ratti pariyosāne iti attho ūhata iti aruṇe uggate
translated: Here, “at night, when the sun is setting” means at the end of the night. “Setting” means when the sun has risen.

original: Yāti yā puratthimā disā rattasuvaṇṇatāya uppamarūpadharā hutvā dissati. Kāḷā nidāgherivāti
analyzed: yā ati yā puratthimā disā ratta suvaṇṇa tāya uppama rūpa dharā hutvā dissati kāḷā nidāgheḥ iva ati
translated: “Which” means which woman is seen in the eastern direction, having the supreme form and color like morning gold. “Like a black cloud” means

original: nidāghasamaye kāḷavalli viya. Aggijārivāti aggijālā iva, sāpi nijjhāmakhettesu taruṇauṭṭhitakāḷavalli🔽viyāti attho. Lohitapattamālinīti lohitavaṇṇehi pattehi parivutā. Kā tiṭṭhasīti yathā
analyzed: nidāgha samaye kāḷavalli aggi jārivā ati aggi jālā iva sā api nijjhāma khettesu taruṇa oṭṭhita kāḷavalli  viyā ti atthaḥ lohita patta mālinī iti lohita vaṇṇehi pattehi parivutā kā tiṭṭhasi iti yathā
translated: like a black creeper in the hot season. Like a flame of fire: like a flame of fire, and like a young black creeper that has sprung up in a field of rice that has been burned by fire.🔽What do you stand for? As that young black creeper stands for,

original: sā taruṇakāḷavalli vāteritā vilāsamānā sobhamānā tiṭṭhati, evaṃ kā nāma tvaṃ tiṭṭhasi.
analyzed: sā taruṇa kāḷavalli vāta īritā vilāsamānā sobhamānā tiṭṭhati evam kā nāma tvam tiṭṭhasi
translated: shining and shining, so what do you stand for?

original: Bhāsesamānāvāti mayā saddhiṃ bhāsitukāmā viya hosi, na ca giraṃ muñcasi.
analyzed: mayā saddhim bhāsitu kāmā hosi na ca giram muñcasi
translated: As if you want to speak with me, but you don’t utter a word.

original: Tato sā gāthamāha –
analyzed: sā gātham āha
translated: Then she spoke this verse:

original: “Hirāha devī manujehi pūjitā, apāpasattūpanisevinī sadā;
analyzed: devī manujehi pūjitā a pāpa sattūpa nisevinī sadā
translated: “I am the goddess Hiri, worshipped by men, always attending on those of good character;

original: Sudhāvivādena tavantimāgatā, sāhaṃ na sakkomi sudhampi yācituṃ;
analyzed: sudhā vivādena sā aham na sakkomi yācitum
translated: I have come to you with the pretext of nectar, but I cannot ask for nectar;

original: Kopīnarūpā viya yācanitthiyā”ti.
analyzed: kopīna rūpāḥ
translated: I am like a beggar with a wrathful form.”

original: Tattha hirāhanti hirī ahaṃ. Sudhampīti sā ahaṃ sudhābhojanaṃ taṃ yācitumpi na sakkomi.
analyzed: tattha hirāhanti hirī aham sudham pi iti sā aham sudhā bhojanam tam yācitum pi na sakkomi
translated: Herein, I am the goddess Hiri: I am the goddess Hiri. I cannot ask for nectar: I cannot ask you for that nectar food.🔽Why? I am like a beggar with a wrathful form,

original: Kiṃkāraṇā? Kopīnarūpā viya yācanitthiyā, yasmā itthiyā yācanā nāma kopīnarūpā viya
analyzed: kiṃkāraṇā kopīna rūpā viya yācanitthiyā yasmai itthiyā yācanā nāma kopīna rūpā
translated: because for a woman to beg is like a wrathful form.

original: rahassaṅgavivaraṇasadisā hoti, nillajjā viya hotīti attho.
analyzed: rahassaṅga vivaraṇa sadisā hoti nillajjā viya hoti iti attho
translated: and it is as if she were shameless.

original: Taṃ sutvā tāpaso dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā tāpasaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: When the seer heard this, he spoke two stanzas:

original: “Dhammena ñāyena sugatte lacchasi, eso hi dhammo na hi yācanā sudhā.
analyzed: dhammena ñāyena sugatte lacchasi esaḥ hi dhammaḥ na hi yācanā sudhā
translated: “By right and by law you may get the ambrosia, for this is the law, not the begging of ambrosia.

original: Taṃ taṃ ayācantimahaṃ nimantaye, sudhāya yañcicchasi tampi dammi te.
analyzed: tam tam a yācantim aham nimantaye sudhāya yat cicchasi tam pi dammi te
translated: I invite you, not begging, to come to my hermitage. I will give you the ambrosia you desire.

original: “Sā tvaṃ mayā ajja sakamhi assame, nimantitā kañcanavelliviggahe;
analyzed: sā tvam mayā ajja sakamhi assame nimantitā kañcana velli viggahe
translated: “You are invited by me today to my hermitage, O you who are like a golden creeper.

original: Tuvañhi me sabbarasehi pūjiyā, taṃ pūjayitvāna sudhampi asniye”ti.🔽Tattha dhammenāti sabhāvena. Ñāyenāti kāraṇena. Na hi yācanā sudhāti na hi yācanāya🔽sudhā labbhati, teneva kāraṇena itarā tisso nalabhiṃsu. Taṃ tanti tasmā taṃ. Yañcicchasīti
analyzed: tuvan hi me sabba rasehi pūjiyā tam pūjayitvāna asniyā iti  tattha dhammena ati sabhāvena ñāyena ati kāraṇena na hi yācanā sudhā ati na hi yācanāya  sudhā labbhati tena iva kāraṇena itarā tissaḥ tam tasmai tam yat cicchasi iti
translated: You are to be worshipped by me with all kinds of flavors. Having worshipped you, I will eat the ambrosia.”

original: na kevalaṃ nimantemiyeva, yañca sudhaṃ icchasi, tampi dammi te. Kañcanavelliviggaheti
analyzed: na kevalam yat ca sudham icchasi tam pi dammi te
translated: Herein, by right means by nature. By law means by reason. Not the begging of ambrosia means ambrosia is not obtained by begging. For this reason the other three did not obtain it. I invite you means I invite you. I will give you the ambrosia you desire means I will give you not only an invitation but also the ambrosia you desire. O you who are like a golden creeper means

original: kañcanarāsisassirikasarīre. Pūjiyāti na kevalaṃ sudhāya, aññehipi sabbarasehi tvaṃ
analyzed: kañcana rāsi sassirika sarīre na kevalam sudhāya aññehi pi sabba rasehi tvam
translated: Honoured: not only with nectar, but also with all other kinds of food.

original: mayā pūjetabbayuttakāva. Asniyeti taṃ pūjetvā sace sudhāya avasesaṃ bhavissati, ahampi bhuñjissāmi.
analyzed: mayā tam pūjetvā sace sudhāya avasesam bhavissati aham pi bhuñjissāmi
translated: If there is any nectar left over after you have been honoured, I will eat it too.

original: Tato aparā abhisambuddhagāthā –
analyzed: tatas aparā abhisambuddha gāthā
translated: The following verses were uttered by the Buddha:🔽“She, approved by Kosiya, the radiant one,

original: “Sā kosiyenānumatā jutīmatā, addhā hiri rammaṃ pāvisi yassamaṃ;
analyzed: sā kosiyena anumatā jutīmatā addhā hiri rammam pāvisi yassamam
translated: surely entered the lovely Yasa’s presence.🔽The water-bearing fruit, worshipped by Noble Ones,

original: Udakavantaṃ phalamariyapūjitaṃ, apāpasattūpanisevitaṃ sadā.
analyzed: udakavantam phalam ariya pūjitam a pāpa sattu upanisevitam sadā
translated: always frequented by harmless creatures.

original: “Rukkhaggahānā bahukettha pupphitā, ambā piyālā panasā ca kiṃsukā;
analyzed: rukkhaggahānā bahukā ittha pupphitā ambā piyālā panasā ca kiṃsukā
translated: “Many flowering trees here, the mango, the rose-apple, the breadfruit, the ketaki,

original: Sobhañjanā loddamathopi paddhakā, kekā ca bhaṅgā tilakā supupphitā.
analyzed: sobhañjanā loddamathā upi paddhakā kekā ca bhaṅgā tilakā supupphitā
translated: the sobhāñjana, the lodhra, the asoka, the trumpet-flower tree, the ketaka, and the jasmine.

original: “Sālā karerī bahukettha jambuyo, assatthanigrodhamadhukavetasā;
analyzed: sālā karerī bahukā ittha assattha nigrodha madhuka vetasā
translated: “The sāl, the kareri, the rose-apple, the jambu, the assattha, the banyan, the madhūka, and the reed,

original: Uddālakā pāṭali sinduvārakā, manuññagandhā mucalindaketakā.
translated: the uddālaka, the trumpet-flower tree, the sinduvāra, the lovely-scented mucalinda, and the ketaka.

original: “Hareṇukā veḷukā keṇu tindukā, sāmākanīvāramathopi cīnakā;
analyzed: hareṇukā veḷukā keṇu tindukā cīnakā
translated: “The hareṇuka, the bamboo, the keṇu, the jujube, the wild grain, the nīvāra, and the rice of China,

original: Mocā kadalī bahukettha sāliyo, pavīhayo ābhūjino ca taṇḍulā.
analyzed: mocā kadalī bahukā ittha sāliyaḥ pavīhayaḥ ca taṇḍulā
translated: The lotus pond was full of fish, turtles, and otters.🔽“To the north of the pond,

original: “Tassevuttarapassena, jātā pokkharaṇī sivā;
analyzed: tassa iva uttara passena jātā pokkharaṇī sivā
translated: there was a lotus pond, cool,

original: Akakkasā apabbhārā, sādhu appaṭigandhikā.
analyzed: akakkasā a pabbhārā sādhu appaṭigandhikā
translated: with no crocodiles or whirlpools, and very fragrant.

original: “Tattha macchā sanniratā, khemino bahubhojanā;
analyzed: tattha macchā sanniratā kheminaḥ bahu bhojanā
translated: “There were many kinds of fish in the pond,🔽safe and well fed:

original: Siṅgū savaṅkā saṃkulā, satavaṅkā ca rohitā;
analyzed: siṅgū savaṅkā saṃkulā satavaṅkā ca rohitā
translated: singī, savaṅka, saṅkula, satavahā, and rohita;

original: Āḷigaggarakākiṇṇā, pāṭhīnā kākamacchakā.
analyzed: āḷigaggarakākiṇṇā pāṭhīnā kākamacchakā
translated: āḷi, agga, kakka, kiṇṇa, pāṭhīna, kāka, and macchaka.

original: “Tattha pakkhī sanniratā, khemino bahubhojanā;
analyzed: tattha pakkhī sanniratā kheminaḥ bahu bhojanā
translated: “There were many kinds of birds in the pond,🔽safe and well fed:

original: Haṃsā koñcā mayūrā ca, cakkavākā ca kukkuhā;
analyzed: haṃsā koñcā mayūrā ca cakkavākā ca kukkuhā
translated: geese, herons, peacocks, cuckoos, and pheasants;

original: Kuṇālakā bahū citrā, sikhaṇḍī jīvajīvakā.
translated: kuṇāla, bahu, citra, siṅgī, jīva, and jīvaka.

original: “Tattha pānāya māyanti, nānā migagaṇā bahū;
analyzed: tattha pānāya māyanti nānā miga gaṇāḥ bahū
translated: “Many kinds of animals came to drink from the pond:

analyzed: sīhā byagghā varāhā ca
translated: lions, tigers, boars, and chakora birds.

original: “Palāsādā gavajā ca, mahiṃsā rohitā rurū;
analyzed: palāsādā gavajā ca mahiṃsā rohitā rurū
translated: “There were deer: palāsa, gava, mahiṃsa, rohita, and ruru;

original: Eṇeyyā ca varāhā ca, gaṇino nīkasūkarā;
analyzed: eṇeyyā ca varāhā ca gaṇinaḥ nīka sūkarā
translated: eṇeyya, varāha, gaṇin, nīka, and sūkaria;

original: Kadalimigā bahukettha, biḷārā sasakaṇṇikā.
analyzed: kadalimigā bahukā ittha biḷārā sa sakaṇṇikā
translated: and many kinds of monkeys: kadalī, miga, bahu, biḷāra, and sasakaṇṇika.

original: “Chamāgirī pupphavicitrasanthatā, dijābhighuṭṭhā dijasaṅghasevitā”ti.
analyzed: chamā girī puppha vicitra santhatā dija abhighuṭṭhā dija saṅgha sevitā ati
translated: “The mountain was covered with flowers of various colors, frequented by flocks of birds and resounding with their calls.”

original: Tattha jutīmatāti ānubhāvasampannena. Pāvisi yassamanti pāvisi assamaṃ, ya-kāro byañjanasandhikaro.🔽Udakavantanti tesu tesu ṭhānesu udakasampannaṃ. Phalanti anekaphalasampannaṃ. Ariyapūjitanti
analyzed: tattha jutīmatā ati ānubhāva sampannena pāvisi yassamanti pāvisi assamam yakāraḥ byañjana sandhi karaḥ  tesu tesu ṭhānesu udaka sampannam phalanti aneka phala sampannam ariya pūjitanti
translated: Herein, resplendent means endowed with majesty. He entered the hermitage means he entered the hermitage. The syllable ya is a ligature.

original: nīvaraṇadosarahitehi jhānalābhīhi ariyehi pūjitaṃ pasatthaṃ. Rukkhaggahānāti pupphūpagaphalūpagarukkhagahanā.
analyzed: nīvaraṇa dosa rahitehi jhāna lābhīhi ariyehi pūjitam pasattham rukkhaggahānā ati pupphu upaga phalu upaga rukkhagahanā
translated: With water means endowed with water here and there. With fruit means endowed with many kinds of fruit. Honoured by the Noble Ones means honoured and esteemed by Noble Ones who have attained jhana and are free from the blemishes of the hindrances. With thickets of trees means with thickets of trees bearing flowers, fruits, and resin.

original: Sobhañjanāti siggurukkhā. Loddamathopi paddhakāti loddarukkhā ca padumarukkhā ca.
analyzed: sobhañjanā ati siggu rukkhā paddhakā ati lodda rukkhā ca paduma rukkhā ca
translated: With sigrus trees means with sigrus trees. With lodhras and with lotuses means with lodhra trees and with lotus trees.

original: Kekā ca bhaṅgāti evaṃnāmakā rukkhā eva. Karerīti karerirukkhā. Uddālakāti vātaghātakā.🔽Mucalindaketakāti mucalindā ca pañcavidhaketakā ca. Hareṇukāti aparaṇṇajāti. Veḷukāti
analyzed: kekā ca bhaṅgā ati evaṃnāmakā rukkhā eva karerī iti kareri rukkhā uddālakā ati vātaghātakā  mucalindaketakā ati mucalindā ca pañcavidhaketakā ca hareṇukā ati aparaṇṇajāti veḷukā ati
translated: With keka and with bhaṅga means with trees of those names. With kareri means with kareri trees. With uddaḷaka means with wind-resisting trees.

original: vaṃsabhedakā. Keṇūti araññamāsā. Tindukāti timbarurukkhā. Cīnakāti khuddakarājamāsā.
analyzed: vaṃsabhedakā keṇū ti araññamāsā tindukā ati timbarurukkhā cīnakā ati khuddakarājamāsā
translated: With mucalinda and with ketaka means with mucalinda trees and with five-petalled ketaka trees. With hareṇuka means with a kind of leaf-hut. With bamboo means with bamboo varieties. With keṇu means with forest beans. With tinduka means with timbaru trees. With china means with small royal beans.

original: Mocāti aṭṭhikakadaliyo. Sāliyoti nānappakārā jātassaraṃ upanissāya jātā sāliyo. Pavīhayoti
analyzed: mocā ati aṭṭhikakadaliyo sāliyo ti nānappakārā jātassaram upanissāya jātā sāliyo pavīhayo ti
translated: Mocas: the bones of the kadali plant. Sāli: various kinds of rice growing in the jungle. Pavīha:

original: nānappakārā vīhayo. Ābhūjinoti bhujapattā. Taṇḍulāti nikkuṇḍakathusāni sayaṃjātataṇḍulasīsāni.
analyzed: nānappakārāḥ vīhayaḥ bhuja pattā taṇḍulāti nikkuṇḍaka thusāni sayaṃjāta taṇḍula sīsāni
translated: various kinds of birds. Ābhūjin: the bhuja-leaf. Taṇḍula: rice without the husk, grown by itself.

original: Tassevāti, bhikkhave, tasseva assamassa uttaradisābhāge. Pokkharaṇīti pañcavidhapadumasañchannā
analyzed: tassa iva ati bhikkhave tassa iva assamassa uttara disā bhāge pokkharaṇī iti pañcavidha paduma sañchannā
translated: Tasseva: in the northern direction of that very hermitage. Pokkharaṇī: a lotus-pond covered with five kinds of lotuses,

original: jātassarapokkharaṇī. Akakkasāti macchasippikasevālādikakkasarahitā. Apabbhārāti acchinnataṭā
analyzed: jātassara pokkharaṇī a kakkasā ati maccha sippi kasevāla ādi kakkasa rahitā a pabbhārā ati a chinna taṭā
translated: grown in the jungle. Akakkas: free from the noise of fish, turtles, and alligators. Apabbhāra: with unbroken banks,

original: samatitthā. Appaṭigandhikāti apaṭikkūlagandhena udakena samannāgatā. Tatthāti tassā🔽pokkharaṇiyā. Kheminoti abhayā. “Siṅgū”tiādīni tesaṃ macchānaṃ nāmāni. Kuṇālakāti
analyzed: samatitthā appaṭigandhikā ati a paṭikkūla gandhena udakena samannāgatā tattha ati tassā  pokkharaṇiyā khemino ti abhayā siṅgu iti ādīni tesam macchānam nāmāni kuṇālakā ti
translated: with level banks. Appaṭigandhika: endowed with water that is not foul-smelling. Tattha: in that🔽pond. Khemin: safe. “Siṅgū” and so on are the names of those fish. Kuṇālakas:

original: kokilā. Citrāti citrapattā. Sikhaṇḍīti uṭṭhitasikhā morā, aññepi vā matthake jātasikhā
analyzed: kokilā citrā ati citra pattā sikhaṇḍī iti uṭṭhita sikhā morā aññe pi vā matthake jāta sikhā
translated: cuckoos. Citras: birds with colorful feathers. Sikhaṇḍis: peacocks with raised crests, or others with crests on their heads.

original: pakkhino. Pānāya māyantīti pānāya āyanti. Palāsādāti khaggā. Gavajāti gavayā. Gaṇinoti
analyzed: pakkhinaḥ pānāya mā āyanti iti pānāya āyanti palāsādāti khaggāḥ gavajāti gavayāḥ gaṇino ti
translated: “Birds” : birds. “Come to drink” : come to drink. “Palasa” : vultures. “Gavaja” : gavaya deer. “Ganina” :

original: gokaṇṇā. Kaṇṇikāti kaṇṇikamigā. Chamāgirīti bhūmisamapatthaṭā piṭṭhipāsāṇā. Pupphavicitrasanthatāti
analyzed: gokaṇṇā kaṇṇikā ati kaṇṇikamigā chamāgirī iti bhūmi sama patthaṭā piṭṭhi pāsāṇā puppha vicitra santhatā ati
translated: gokanna deer. “Kannika” : kannika deer. “Chamagiri” : flat rocks on the ground. “With a covering of various flowers” :

original: vicitrapupphasanthatā. Dijābhighuṭṭhāti madhurassarehi dijehi abhighuṭṭhā. Evarūpā
analyzed: vicitra puppha santhatā dija abhighuṭṭhā ati madhurassarehi dijehi abhighuṭṭhā evarūpā
translated: covered with various flowers. “Resounding with the cries of birds” : resounding with the sweet cries of birds. Such

original: tattha bhūmipabbatāti evaṃ bhagavā kosiyassa assamaṃ vaṇṇeti.
analyzed: tattha bhūmi pabbatā ti evam bhagavā kosiyassa assamam vaṇṇeti
translated: is the description of Kosiya’s hermitage by the Blessed One.

original: Idāni hirideviyā tattha pavisanādīni dassetuṃ āha –
analyzed: idāni hirideviyā tattha pavisana ādīni dassetuṃ āha
translated: Now, in order to show Hiri’s entry there, etc., he said:🔽“She, clothed in bark-cloth and blue silk,

original: “Sā suttacā nīladumābhilambitā, vijjū mahāmegharivānupajjatha;
analyzed: sā
translated: appeared like a flash of lightning in a great rain-cloud.🔽Her head was well-bound with kusagrass,

original: Tassā susambandhasiraṃ kusāmayaṃ, suciṃ sugandhaṃ ajinūpasevitaṃ;
analyzed: tassā su sambandha siram kusāmayam su cim su gandham ajina upasevitam
translated: clean, fragrant, and anointed with oil.🔽The koccha-bearer Hiri said to her:

original: Atricca kocchaṃ hirimetadabravi, nisīda kalyāṇi sukhayidamāsanaṃ.
analyzed: atrit ca hirim etat abravi nisīda kalyāṇi sukhayi dam āsanam
translated: “Sit down, good lady, on this comfortable seat.”🔽“Then, as she sat in the koccha, Kosiya,

original: “Tassā tadā kocchagatāya kosiyo, yadicchamānāya jaṭājinandharo;
analyzed: tassa tadā koccha gatāya kosiyaḥ yat icchamānāya jaṭā ajinandharaḥ
translated: the bearer of matted locks and bark-cloth, as she desired,

original: Navehi pattehi sayaṃ sahūdakaṃ, sudhābhihāsī turito mahāmuni.
analyzed: navehi pattehi sayam sahūdakam sudhā abhihāsī turitaḥ mahā muni
translated: With fresh leaves, water, and his own hands, the Great Sage quickly offered her the nectar.

original: “Sā taṃ paṭiggayha ubhohi pāṇibhi, iccabravi attamanā jaṭādharaṃ;
analyzed: sā tam paṭiggayha ubhohi pāṇibhiḥ atta manāḥ jaṭādharam
translated: “She accepted it with both hands, and, pleased, she said to the one with matted hair:

original: Handāhaṃ etarahi pūjitā tayā, gaccheyyaṃ brahme tidivaṃ jitāvinī.
analyzed: handa aham etarahi pūjitā tayā gaccheyyam brahme tidivam jitāvinī
translated: ‘Now that I’ve been worshipped by you, I’ll go to the Brahmā realm, victorious.’

original: “Sā kosiyenānumatā jutīmatā, udīritā vaṇṇamadena mattā;
analyzed: sā kosiyena anumatā jutīmatā udīritā vaṇṇa madena mattā
translated: “She, approved by the radiant one with the robe, was raised up, intoxicated with the pride of beauty.

original: Sakāse gantvāna sahassacakkhuno, ayaṃ sudhā vāsava dehi me jayaṃ.
analyzed: sakāse gantvāna sahassa cakkhunaḥ ayam sudhā vāsava dehi me jayam
translated: Having gone into the presence of the thousand-eyed one, she said, ‘Vāsava, give me victory, this is the nectar.’

original: “Tamena sakkopi tadā apūjayi, sahindadevā surakaññamuttamaṃ;
analyzed: tam ena sakkā upi tadā apūjayi sa hinda devā sura kaññam uttamam
translated: “Then Sakka worshipped her, the supreme celestial maiden with Indra and the gods.

original: Sā pañjalī devamanussapūjitā, navamhi kocchamhi yadā upāvisī”ti.🔽Tattha suttacāti succhavī. Nīladumābhilambitāti nīlesu dumesu abhilambitā hutvā,
analyzed: sā pañjalī deva manussa pūjitā navamhi kocchamhi yadā upāvisīti  tattha su tacā ati su chavī nīla duma abhilambitā ati nīlesu dumesu abhilambitā hutvā
translated: She, worshipped by gods and humans with palms together, when she sat down on the ninth seat.”🔽Here, “with leaves” means with good leaves. “Clinging to blue trees” means clinging to blue trees,

original: taṃ taṃ nīladumasākhaṃ parāmasantīti attho. Mahāmegharivāti tena nimantitā mahāmeghavijju
analyzed: tam tam nīla duma sākham parāmasanti iti tena nimantitā mahā megha vijju
translated: the meaning is that she was clinging to this and that branch of a blue tree. “Like a great cloud” means invited by that, a great cloud with lightning

original: viya tassa taṃ assamaṃ pāvisi. Tassāti tassā hiriyā. Susambandhasiranti suṭṭhu sambandhasīsaṃ.🔽Kusāmayanti usīrādimissakakusatiṇamayaṃ. Sugandhanti usīrena ceva aññena sugandhatiṇena
analyzed: viya tassa tam assamam pāvisi tassa ati tassā hiriyā su sambandha siranti suṭṭhu sambandha sīsam  kusāmayanti usīra ādi missaka kusa tiṇa mayam sugandhanti usīrena ca iva aññena sugandha tiṇena
translated: and entered his hermitage. ‘His’: his of that shame. ‘Well-joined head’: well-joined head-hairs.🔽‘Made of kusagrass’: made of kusagrass mixed with usīra and other fragrant grasses. ‘Fragrant’: fragrant because mixed with usīra and other fragrant grasses.

original: ca missakattā sugandhaṃ. Ajinūpasevitanti upariatthatena ajinacammena upasevitaṃ.
analyzed: ca missaka ttā sugandham ajina upasevitanti upari atthatena ajina cammena upasevitam
translated: ‘Used by the Ajina deer’: used by the Ajina deer as a scratching-post.

original: Atricca kocchanti evarūpaṃ kocchāsanaṃ paṇṇasāladvāre attharitvā. Sukhayidamāsananti
analyzed: evarūpam kocchāsanam paṇṇasāla dvāre attharitvā
translated: ‘Some spread out such a couch’: some spread out such a couch as this in the door of the leaf hut. ‘Sit down comfortably on this seat’:

original: sukhaṃ nisīda idamāsanaṃ.
analyzed: sukham nisīda idam āsanam
translated: ‘Sit down comfortably on this seat’.

original: tasmiṃ nigame aḍḍhamāsamattaṃ tena saddhiṃ anācāraṃ cari. Samma puṇṇamukha, itthiyo
analyzed: tasmin nigame aḍḍha māsa mattam tena saddhim anācāram cari samma puṇṇamukhaḥ itthiyaḥ
translated: she carried on an improper life with him in that town for a half-month. Samma Puṇṇamukhā, women

original: nāmetā dussīlā musāvādiniyoti idampi atītaṃ dassento mahāsatto “evañheta”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: nāma etāḥ dussīlāḥ musā vādiniyaḥ ti idam pi atītam dassentaḥ mahāsatto evañhi etat tiādim āha
translated: are not virtuous, they are liars. The Great Being said, “So it is,” in order to show this past event.

original: Tattha brahmadattassa mātaranti bārāṇasirajjaṃ kārentassa brahmadattakumārassa mātaraṃ. Tadā kira kuṇālo pañcālacaṇḍo ahosi, tasmā taṃ attanā ñātakāraṇaṃ dassento evamāha.🔽Etā cāti, samma puṇṇamukha, etāva pañca itthiyo pāpamakaṃsu, na aññāti saññaṃ mā
analyzed: tattha brahmadattassa mātaranti bārāṇasi rajjam kārentassa brahmadatta kumārassa mātaram tadā kira kuṇālaḥ pañcālacaṇḍaḥ ahosi tasmā tam attanā ñāta kāraṇam dassentaḥ evam āha  etā ca ati samma puṇṇamukhaḥ etāva pañca itthiyaḥ pāpam akaṃsu na aññā ati saññam mā
translated: Herein, Brahmadatta’s mother is the mother of Prince Brahmadatta who was reigning in Benares. It seems that at that time Kunala was fifty years old, and that is why he said this, showing his kinship with her.

original: kari, atha kho etā ca aññā ca bahū pāpakammakārikāti. Imasmiṃ ṭhāne ṭhatvā loke aticārinīnaṃ🔽vatthūni kathetabbāni. Jagatīti yathā jagatisaṅkhātā mahī samānarattā paṭighābhāvena🔽sabbesu samānarattā hutvā sā vasundharā itarītarāpatiṭṭhā uttamānañca adhamānañca
analyzed: atha kho etā ca aññā ca bahū pāpa kamma kārikā ati imasmim ṭhāne loke aticārinīnam  vatthūni kathetabbāni jagatī iti yathā jagati saṅkhātā mahī samāna rattā paṭigha abhāvena  sabbesu samāna rattā hutvā sā vasundharā uttamānañca adhamānañca
translated: And these: ‘My dear Punnamukha, these five women only did the wicked deed, do not think that it was anyone else; in fact, these and many others did the wicked deed.’ Standing in this place, he should tell the stories of those who have gone beyond the bounds of the world.

original: patiṭṭhā hoti, tathā itthiyopi kilesavasena sabbesampi uttamādhamānaṃ patiṭṭhā honti.
analyzed: patiṭṭhā hoti tathā itthiyaḥ api kilesa vasena sabbesam pi uttama adhamānam patiṭṭhāḥ honti
translated: The world: just as the earth, which is called the world, is the common resort of all, being the same in colour, because of the absence of any difference in colour, and just as that earth is the resort of the high and the low, being the support of this and that, so too, women are the common resort of all because of the defilements, being the same in colour as the high and the low, and they are the support of the high and the low, being the resort of this and that.

original: Itthiyo hi okāsaṃ labhamānā kenaci saddhiṃ pāpakaṃ karonti nāma. Sabbasahāti yathā
analyzed: itthiyaḥ hi okāsam labhamānā kenaci saddhim pāpakam karonti nāma yathā
translated: For women, when they get the chance, will do wicked things with anyone.🔽All-conquering: just as the earth conquers all, being the support of all, and as the earth is the all-conquering, being the support of this and that, so too, women conquer all, being the support of all, and they are the all-conquering, being the support of this and that.

original: ca sā sabbameva sahati na phandati na kuppati na calati, tathā itthiyo sabbepi purise
analyzed: ca sā sabbam eva sahati na phandati na kuppati na calati tathā itthiyaḥ sabbe pi purise
translated: She endures all, does not tremble, does not get angry, does not move. So women endure all men.

original: lokassādavasena sahanti. Sace tāsaṃ koci puriso citte patiṭṭhito hoti, tassa rakkhaṇatthaṃ
analyzed: sahanti sace tāsam koci puriso citte patiṭṭhitaḥ hoti tassa rakkhaṇa attham
translated: If any man is established in their hearts, then for the sake of protecting him

original: na phandanti na calanti na kolāhalaṃ karonti. Yathā ca sā na kuppati na calati, evaṃ
analyzed: na phandanti na calanti na kolāhalam karonti yathā ca sā na kuppati na calati evam
translated: they do not tremble, do not move, do not make a fuss. And just as she does not get angry, does not move,

original: itthiyopi methunadhammena na kuppanti na calanti, na sakkā tena pūretuṃ.🔽Vāḷamigoti duṭṭhamigo. Pañcāvudhoti mukhassa ceva catunnañca caraṇānaṃ vasenetaṃ
analyzed: itthiyaḥ api methuna dhammena na kuppanti na calanti na sakkā tena pūretum  vāḷamigo ti duṭṭhamigo mukhassa ca iva catunnam ca caraṇānam vasena itam
translated: so too women do not get angry, do not move, with sexual intercourse, and cannot be satisfied by it.🔽A wild beast: a vicious beast. Five weapons: this is said

original: vuttaṃ. Suruddhoti suluddho supharuso. Tathitthiyoti yathā hi sīhassa mukhañceva
analyzed: vuttam su ruddhaḥ ti su luddhaḥ su pharusaḥ tathitthiyaḥ ti yathā hi sīhassa mukham ca iva
translated: on the basis of the mouth and the four feet. Very fierce: very cruel. So too women: just as a lion has five weapons,

original: cattāro ca hatthapādāti pañcāvudhāni, tathā itthīnampi rūpasaddagandharasaphoṭṭhabbāni
analyzed: cattāro ca hattha pādāti pañca avudhāni tathā itthīnam pi rūpa sadda gandha rasa phoṭṭhabbāni
translated: namely, the mouth and the four paws, so too women have five weapons, namely, form, sound, odour, taste, and tactile objects.

original: pañcāvudhāni. Yathā so attano bhakkhaṃ gaṇhanto tehipi pañcahi gaṇhāti, tathā tāpi
analyzed: yathā saḥ attanaḥ bhakkham gaṇhantaḥ tehi pi pañcahi gaṇhāti tathā tā api
translated: Just as he seizes his prey with all five of them, so too they

original: kilesabhakkhaṃ gaṇhamānā rūpādīhi āvudhehi paharitvā gaṇhanti. Yathā so kakkhaḷo
analyzed: kilesa bhakkham gaṇhamānāḥ rūpa ādīhi āvudhehi paharitvā gaṇhanti yathā so kakkhaḷo
translated: They seize by striking with the weapons of visible forms, etc., and taking hold of the defilements as prey.🔽Just as he is hard,

original: pasayha khādati, evaṃ etāpi kakkhaḷā pasayha khādikā. Tathā hetā thirasīlepi purise
analyzed: pasayha khādati evam etā api kakkhaḷā pasayha khādikā tathā ha itā thira sīle pi purise
translated: so they are hard, since they are hard to fill. Just as he is a ravager,

original: attano balena pasayhakāraṃ katvā sīlavināsaṃ pāpenti. Yathā so parahiṃsane rato,
analyzed: attanaḥ balena pasayhakāram katvā sīla vināsam yathā saḥ para hiṃsane rataḥ
translated: so they are ravagers, since they are ravagers of virtue. Just as he is fond of harming others,🔽so they are fond of harming others, since they are fond of harming others through defilements.

original: evametāpi kilesavasena parahiṃsane ratā. Tāyoti tā evaṃ aguṇasammannāgatā na vissase naro.
analyzed: evam etā api kilesa vasena para hiṃsane ratā tā evam aguṇa sammannāgatāḥ na
translated: So a man should not trust these, which are thus disreputable.

original: Gamaniyoti gaṇikāyo. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – samma puṇṇamukha, yānetāni itthīnaṃ “vesiyo”tiādīni
analyzed: gamaniyaḥ ti gaṇikāyaḥ idam vuttam hoti samma puṇṇamukha itthīnam vesiyaḥ ti ādīni
translated: Gamaniyo: harlots. This is what is said: “These women are called ‘harlots,’ etc.,

original: nāmāni, na etāni tāsaṃ sabhāvanāmāni. Na hetā vesiyo nāma gamaniyo nāma bandhakiyo
analyzed: nāmāni na etāni tāsam sabhāvanāmāni na hetā vesiyaḥ nāma gamaniyaḥ nāma bandhakiyaḥ
translated: but these are not their real names. They are not really harlots, gamaniyo, or bandhakiyo;

original: nāma, sabhāvanāmato pana vadhikāyo nāma etāyo, yā etā vesiyo nāriyo gamaniyoti vuccanti.
analyzed: nāma sabhāva nāmato pana vadhikāyaḥ nāma etāyaḥ yāḥ etāḥ vesiyaḥ nāriyaḥ gamaniyaḥ ti vuccanti
translated: but their real name is vadhikāyo, ‘wives for sale,’ since these women called ‘harlots’ and ‘gamaniyo’🔽are wives for sale.

original: Vadhikāyoti sāmikaghātikāyo. Svāyamattho mahāhaṃsajātakena dīpetabbo. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: vadhi kāyaḥ ti sāmika ghāti kāyaḥ svāyam atthaḥ mahāhaṃsa jātakena dīpetabbo vuttam ha etam
translated: Vadhikāyo: wives for sale. This meaning should be illustrated by the story of the Great Goose. For this is said:

original: “Māyā cetā marīcī ca, sokā rogā cupaddavā;
analyzed: māyā cetā marīcī ca sokā rogā cupaddavā
translated: “Deception, mirage, and also sorrow, disease, and calamity,

original: Kharā ca bandhanā cetā, maccupāsā guhāsayā;
analyzed: kharā ca bandhanā cetā maccupāsā guhāsayā
translated: Harshness, and also bondage, and death, the cave-abider:

original: Tāsu yo vissase poso, so naresu narādhamo”ti. ;
analyzed: tāsu yaḥ vissase poso saḥ naresu nara adhamaḥ ti
translated: The man who trusts these is the worst of men.”

original: Veṇikatāti kataveṇiyo. Yathā hi moḷiṃ bandhitvā aṭaviyaṃ ṭhitacoro dhanaṃ vilumpati,🔽evametāpi kilesavasaṃ netvā dhanaṃ vilumpanti. Madirāva diddhāti visamissakā surā
analyzed: kata veṇiyaḥ yathā hi moḷim bandhitvā aṭaviyam ṭhita coraḥ dhanam vilumpati  evam etā api kilesa vasam netvā dhanam vilumpanti madirā ava visamissakā surā
translated: “Braided hair” : she who has braided hair. For just as a thief in the forest, having braided his hair, robs people of their wealth,

original: viya. Yathā sā vikāraṃ dasseti, evametāpi aññesu purisesu sārattā kiccākiccaṃ ajānantiyo
analyzed: viya yathā sā vikāram dasseti evam etā api aññesu purisesu sārattā kicca akiccam a jānantiyaḥ
translated: so do these, having brought one under the power of the defilements, rob one of one’s wealth. “Like a drunkard, full of hate” : like a mixture of wine. Just as that shows change, so do these, being attached to other men, not knowing what should and should not be done,

original: aññasmiṃ kattabbe aññameva karontiyo vikāraṃ dassenti. Vācāsanthutiyoti yathā vāṇijo
analyzed: aññasmin kattabbe aññam eva karontiyaḥ vikāram dassenti yathā vāṇijaḥ
translated: doing something else when something else should be done, show change. “Praise with words” : just as a merchant

original: attano bhaṇḍassa vaṇṇameva bhaṇati, evametāpi attano aguṇaṃ paṭicchādetvā guṇameva
analyzed: attanaḥ bhaṇḍassa vaṇṇam eva bhaṇati evam etā api attanaḥ aguṇam paṭicchādetvā guṇam eva
translated: praises the beauty of his own wares, so do these, concealing their own faults, reveal only their good qualities.

original: pakāsenti. Viparivattāyoti yathā issamigassa siṅgaṃ parivattitvā ṭhitaṃ, evaṃ lahucittatāya
analyzed: pakāsenti yathā issa migassa siṅgam parivattitvā ṭhitam evam lahu citta tāya
translated: “Turning back” : just as the horn of a wild ox stands turning back, so do these, because of their fickle minds,

original: viparivattāyova honti. Uragamivāti urago viya musāvāditāya dujivhā nāma. Sobbhamivāti
analyzed: viparivattāya uva honti uragam iva ati uragaḥ viya musā vāditāya dujivhā nāma sobbham iva ati
translated: They are like a snake, a pit of live coals, a cesspit, a razor, a piece of meat, a snake’s head, a dream, a borrowed ornament, a public road, a water lily, a flash of lightning, and a monkey.🔽They are like a snake because they are double-tongued in lying.

original: yathā padarapaṭicchanno gūthakūpo, evaṃ vatthālaṅkārapaṭicchannā hutvā vicaranti.🔽Yathā ca kacavarehi paṭicchanno āvāṭo akkanto pādadukkhaṃ janeti, evametāpi vissāsena
analyzed: yathā padara paṭicchannaḥ gūtha kūpaḥ evam vattha alaṅkāra paṭicchannāḥ hutvā vicaranti  yathā ca kaca varehi paṭicchannaḥ āvāṭaḥ akkantaḥ pāda dukkham janeti evam etā api vissāsena
translated: They are like a pit of live coals because they go about covered with the outer cloak of virtue and the inner cloak of shame.🔽And just as a cesspit covered with grass and sticks causes pain in the feet when trodden on, so these women cause pain in the feet of confidence when they are relied on.

original: upaseviyamānā. Pātālamivāti yathā mahāsamudde pātālaṃ duppūraṃ, evametāpi methunena🔽vijāyanena alaṅkārenāti tīhi duppūrā. Tenevāha – “tiṇṇaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ atitto mātugāmo”tiādi.🔽Rakkhasī viyāti yathā rakkhasī nāma maṃsagiddhatāya dhanena na sakkā tosetuṃ, bahumpi🔽dhanaṃ paṭikkhipitvā maṃsameva pattheti, evametāpi methunagiddhatāya bahunāpi dhanena
analyzed: upaseviyamānā pātālam iva ati yathā mahā samudde pātālam duppūram evam etā api methunena  vijāyanena alaṅkārena ati tīhi duppūrā tena iva āha tiṇṇam bhikkhave dhammānam atittaḥ mātugāmaḥ iti ādi  rakkhasī viyāti yathā rakkhasī nāma maṃsa giddha tāya dhanena na sakkā tosetum bahum pi  dhanam paṭikkhipitvā maṃsam eva pattheti evam etā api methuna giddha tāya bahunā api dhanena
translated: They are like a water lily because they are difficult to fill, like the ocean, with sexual intercourse.🔽With ornaments means with the ornaments of sexual intercourse.🔽They are like a demoness because a demoness cannot be satisfied with money because of her craving for flesh; she rejects much money and asks only for flesh. So too, these women cannot be satisfied with much money because of their craving for sexual intercourse; they do not reckon the money but ask only for sexual intercourse.

original: na tussanti, dhanaṃ agaṇetvā methunameva patthenti. Yamovāti yathā yamo ekantaharo
analyzed: na tussanti dhanam a gaṇetvā methunam eva patthenti yamaḥ uvāti yathā yamaḥ ekanta haraḥ
translated: They are like Yama because Yama is a single killer.

original: na kiñci pariharati, evametāpi jātisampannādīsu na kañci pariharanti, sabbaṃ kilesavasena🔽sīlādivināsaṃ pāpetvā dutiyacittavāre nirayaṃ upanenti. Sikhīrivāti yathā sikhī sucimpi🔽asucimpi sabbaṃ bhakkhayati, tathetāpi hīnuttame sabbe sevanti. Nadīupamāyampi eseva
analyzed: na kiñci pariharati evam etā api jāti sampanna ādīsu na kañci pariharanti sabbam kilesa vasena  sīla ādi vināsam pāpetvā dutiya cittavāre nirayam upanenti sikhīḥ iva ati yathā sikhī su cimpi  asucim pi sabbam bhakkhayati tathā itā api hi inuttame sabbe sevanti nadī upamāyam pi esā iva
translated: and he does not avoid anything, so too these do not avoid anyone among those endowed with the various kinds of beauty, but all according to the defilements

original: nayo. Yenakā maṃcarāti bhummatthe karaṇavacanaṃ, yattha etāsaṃ kāmo hoti, tattheva
analyzed: nayaḥ yenakāḥ maṃcarāti bhumma tthe karaṇa vacanam yattha etāsam kāmaḥ hoti tattha iva
translated: and lead them to hell in the second conscious moment after they have brought about the destruction of their virtue, etc. ‘Like fire’ : just as fire burns up everything, whether pure or impure, so too these frequent all kinds of beauty, high and low. The meaning of the simile of the river should be understood in the same way. ‘Where their desire is’ : the locative case is in the sense of place, that is, where their desire is there

original: dhāvanti. Nerūti himavati eko suvaṇṇapabbato, taṃ upagatā kākāpi suvaṇṇavaṇṇāva honti.
analyzed: dhāvanti nerū ti himavati eko suvaṇṇa pabbato tam upagatā kākā api suvaṇṇa vaṇṇāḥ ava honti
translated: they run to. ‘The Neru’: in the Himalayas there is a golden mountain called Neru. Crows that go there become the colour of gold.

original: Yathā so, evaṃ etāpi nibbisesakarā attānaṃ upagataṃ ekasadisaṃ katvā passanti.
analyzed: yathā so evam etā api nibbisesa karā attānam upagatam eka sadisam katvā passanti
translated: Just as that mountain, so too these make what they go to look like themselves.

original: Visarukkhoti ambasadiso kiṃpakkarukkho. So niccameva phalati, vaṇṇādisampanno ca
analyzed: visa rukkhaḥ ti amba sadiso kiṃpakka rukkho so niccam eva phalati vaṇṇa ādi sampanno ca
translated: ‘The tree with spreading branches’: a kiṃsuka tree is like an acacia tree. It always bears fruit, and it is possessed of colour, etc.,

original: hoti, tena naṃ nirāsaṅkā paribhuñjitvā maranti, evameva tāpi rūpādivasena niccaphalitā
analyzed: tena nam nirāsaṅkā paribhuñjitvā maranti evam eva tā api rūpa ādi vasena nicca phalitā
translated: and so they eat it without fear and die. So too these, always bearing fruit in the form of beauty, etc.,

original: ramaṇīyā viya khāyanti. Seviyamānā pana pamādaṃ uppādetvā apāyesu pātenti. Tena vuttaṃ –
analyzed: ramaṇīyāḥ viya khāyanti seviyamānāḥ pana pamādam uppādetvā apāyesu pātenti tena vuttam
translated: they seem delightful. But when they are resorted to, they produce heedlessness and so they lead to the states of deprivation. Hence it was said:

original: “Āyatiṃ dosaṃ naññāya, yo kāme paṭisevati;
analyzed: āyatim dosam na aññāya yaḥ kāme paṭisevati
translated: “He who resorts to sensual pleasures, not seeing danger in them for the future,

original: Vipākante hananti naṃ, kiṃpakkamiva bhakkhita”nti. ;
analyzed: vipākante hananti nam kiṃpakkam iva bhakkhitanti
translated: are destroyed by them when they break up, like the one who ate the poison.

original: Yathā vā visarukkho niccaphalito sadā anatthāvaho hoti, evametāpi sīlādivināsanavasena.🔽Yathā visarukkhassa mūlampi tacopi pattampi pupphampi phalampi visamevāti niccaphalo,
analyzed: yathā vā visa rukkhaḥ nicca phalitaḥ sadā anattha āvahaḥ hoti evam etā api sīla ādi vināsana vasena  yathā visa rukkhassa mūlam pi tacaḥ upi pattam pi puppham pi phalam visam eva ati nicca phalaḥ
translated: Or just as a poison tree, always bearing fruit, is always a source of harm, so too are these, by the destruction of virtue, etc.

original: tatheva tāsaṃ rūpampi…pe… phoṭṭhabbampi visamevāti visarukkho viya niccaphalitāyoti.🔽“Panuttaretthā”ti gāthābandhena tamatthaṃ pākaṭaṃ kātuṃ evamāha. Tattha ratanantakaritthiyoti
analyzed: tathā iva tāsam rūpam pipe phoṭṭhabbam pi visam eva ati visa rukkhaḥ viya nicca phalitāya ti  gāthā bandhena tam attham pākaṭam kātum evam āha tattha
translated: Just as the root, bark, leaves, flowers, and fruits of a poison tree are all poison, so too are the material form, etc., of these women all poison. Thus they are “always bearing fruit” like a poison tree.

original: sāmikehi dukkhasambhatānaṃ ratanānaṃ antarāyakarā itthiyo etāni paresaṃ datvā anācāraṃ caranti.
analyzed: sāmikehi dukkha sambhatānam ratanānam antarāya karāḥ itthiyaḥ etāni paresam da tvā anācāram caranti
translated: “But they are rejected here” : he said this in order to make the meaning clear by the method of the verse. Herein, women who are the makers of obstacles to the jewels that are difficult to obtain for their owners are these women who, having been given to others, behave improperly.

original: Ito paraṃ nānappakārena attano dhammakathāvilāsaṃ dassento āha –
analyzed: itas param nānā pakārena attanaḥ dhamma kathā vilāsam dassentaḥ āha
translated: From here on he says this in order to show his own skill in preaching the Dhamma in various ways.

original: “Cattārimāni, samma puṇṇamukha, yāni vatthūni kicce jāte anatthacarāni bhavanti,
analyzed: cattāri imāni samma puṇṇamukha yāni vatthūni kicce jāte anattha carāni bhavanti
translated: “There are four things, my dear Punna, which, when a man has done them, are the cause of his undoing.

original: tāni parakule na vāsetabbāni, goṇaṃ dhenuṃ yānaṃ bhariyā. Cattāri etāni paṇḍito dhanāni
analyzed: tāni para kule na vāsetabbāni goṇam dhenum yānam bhariyā cattāri etāni paṇḍitaḥ dhanāni
translated: They should not be done in another’s house: a bull, a cow, a vehicle, a wife. These four things

original: gharā na vippavāsaye. Bhavati ca panuttarettha vākyaṃ –
analyzed: na vippavāsaye bhavati ca vākyam
translated: the wise man does not take away from the house. And there is a verse about this:

original: ‘Goṇaṃ dhenuñca yānañca, bhariyaṃ ñātikule na vāsaye;🔽Bhañjanti rathaṃ ayānakā, ativāhena hananti puṅgavaṃ;
analyzed: goṇam dhenum ca yānam ca bhariyam ñāti kule na vāsaye  bhañjanti ratham ayānakāḥ ativāhena hananti puṅgavam
translated: ‘A bull, a cow, a vehicle, a wife should not be kept in another’s house.

original: Dohena hananti vacchakaṃ, bhariyā ñātikule padussatī”’ti.
analyzed: dohena hananti vacchakam bhariyā ñāti kule padussati iti
translated: They break the chariot, the driver kills the bull, the milk spoils the calf, the wife misbehaves in her relatives’ house.’

original: “Cha imāni, samma puṇṇamukha, yāni vatthūni kicce jāte anatthacarāni bhavanti –
analyzed: cha imāni samma puṇṇamukha yāni vatthūni kicce jāte anattha carāni bhavanti
translated: “There are six things, my dear Punna, which, when a man has done them, are the cause of his undoing:

original: ‘Aguṇaṃ dhanu ñātikule ca bhariyā, pāraṃ nāvā akkhabhaggañca yānaṃ;
