original: pucchi. Te itarāsaṃ itthīnaṃ santikā lañjaṃ gahetvā – “mahārāja, deviyā sabbasetassa
analyzed: pucchi te itarāsam itthīnam santikā lañjam gahetvā mahā rāja deviyā sabbasetassa
translated: like this?” They took bribes from the other queens and said, “Great king, the queen is pregnant.

original: hatthino khandhe nisinnabhāvo tumhākaṃ maraṇassa pubbanimittaṃ, hatthikhandhagatāya🔽pana candaparāmasanaṃ tumhākaṃ paccāmittarājānayanassa pubbanimitta”nti vatvā “idāni🔽kiṃ kātabba”nti vutte “deva imaṃ māretuṃ na sakkā, nāvāya pana naṃ ṭhapetvā nadiyaṃ🔽vissajjetuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti vadiṃsu. Rājā āhāravatthālaṅkārehi saddhiṃ rattibhāge naṃ
analyzed: hatthino khandhe nisinna bhāvaḥ tumhākam maraṇassa pubba nimittam hatthi khandha gatāya  pana canda parāmasanam tumhākam pacca amitta rāja ānayanassa pubba nimittan ti vatvā idāni  kim kātabban ti vutte deve imam māretum na sakkā nāvāya pana nam ṭhapetvā nadiyam  vissajjetum vaṭṭati iti vadiṃsu rājā āhāra vattha alaṅkārehi saddhim ratti bhāge naṃ
translated: “Your riding on the back of the elephant is a sign of your death. But your touching the moon🔽is a sign of your overthrowing your enemies.” “What shall we do now?” “Your Majesty, it is not possible to kill her. But it is proper to put her on a ship and to let her go down the river.”

original: nāvāya ṭhapetvā nadiyaṃ vissajjesi.
analyzed: nāvāya ṭhapetvā nadiyam vissajjesi
translated: The king, in the night, put her on a ship with food, clothing, and ornaments, and let her go down the river.

original: Sā nadiyā vuyhamānā heṭṭhānadiyā nāvāya udakaṃ kīḷantassa bāvarikarañño abhimukhaṭṭhānaṃ🔽pattā. Tassa senāpati nāvaṃ disvā “ayaṃ nāvā mayha”nti āha. Rājā “nāvāya bhaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: sā nadiyā vuyhamānā heṭṭhā nadiyā nāvāya udakam kīḷantassa bāvari karaññaḥ abhimukha ṭṭhānam  tassa senāpati nāvam disvā ayam nāvā mayhanti āha rājā nāvāya bhaṇḍam
translated: As she was being carried down the river, she came to the place where the king of the Bāvaras was playing in the water on a ship in the lower river.

original: mayha”nti vatvā āgatāya nāvāya taṃ disvā “kā nāma tvaṃ pisācīsadisā”ti pucchi. Sā
analyzed: vatvā āgatāya nāvāya tam disvā kā nāma tvam pisācīsadisā ati pucchi sā
translated: His general, seeing the ship, said, “This ship is mine.” The king said, “The goods in the ship are mine.” When the ship came, he saw her and asked, “What kind of a demoness are you?”

original: sitaṃ katvā bakassa rañño aggamahesibhāvaṃ kathetvā sabbaṃ taṃ pavattiṃ tassa kathesi.
analyzed: sitam katvā bakassa raññaḥ agga mahesi bhāvam kathetvā sabbam tam pavattim tassa kathesi
translated: and having made it white, he told the King’s chief queen all that had happened.

original: Sā pana pañcapāpīti sakalajambudīpe pākaṭā. Atha naṃ rājā hatthe gahetvā ukkhipi,
analyzed: sā pana pañcapāpī iti sakala jambudīpe pākaṭā atha nam rājā hatthe gahetvā ukkhipi
translated: But she was well known throughout the whole of Jambudīpa as the ‘Five-Sinful One’. Then the King took her by the hand and lifted her up,

original: saha gahaṇeneva phassarāgaratto aññāsu itthīsu itthisaññaṃ akatvā taṃ aggamahesiṭṭhāne🔽ṭhapesi. Sā tassa pāṇasamā ahosi. Bako taṃ pavattiṃ sutvā “nāhaṃ tassa aggamahesiṃ
analyzed: saha gahaṇena iva phassa rāga rattaḥ aññāsu itthīsu itthi saññam a katvā tam aggamahesiṭṭhāne  ṭhapesi sā tassa pāṇa samā ahosi bakaḥ tam pavattim sutvā na aham tassa agga mahesim
translated: and as soon as he had taken her by the hand, being full of passion, he made no sign of being a woman to any other woman, and he placed her in the position of chief queen.🔽She became as dear to him as his life. The Crane, having heard what had happened, said: “I will not give her to be his chief queen.”

original: kātuṃ dassāmī”ti senaṃ saṅkaḍḍhitvā tassa paṭititthe nivesanaṃ katvā paṇṇaṃ pesesi
analyzed: kātum dassāmi iti senam saṅkaḍḍhitvā tassa paṭititthe nivesanam katvā paṇṇam pesesi
translated: He gathered his army, built a fortress in front of him, and sent a message:

original: – “bhariyaṃ vā me detu yuddhaṃ vā”ti. So “yuddhaṃ dassāmi, na bhariya”nti vatvā yuddhasajjo
analyzed: bhariyam vā me detu yuddham vā ati saḥ yuddham dassāmi na bhariyanti vatvā yuddha sajjaḥ
translated: “Give me back my wife or fight.” He said: “I will give you a fight, not my wife,” and he was ready for battle.🔽The ministers of both (kings) said: “There is no business of death because of a woman,

original: ahosi. Ubhinnaṃ amaccā “mātugāmaṃ nissāya maraṇakiccaṃ natthi, purimasāmikattā esā
analyzed: ahosi ubhinnam amaccā mātugāmam nissāya maraṇa kiccam natthi purima sāmika ttā esā
translated: this one belongs to the Crane because she was his wife first,

original: bakassa pāpuṇāti, nāvāya laddhattā bāvarikassa, tasmā ekekassa gehe satta satta divasāni
analyzed: bakassa pāpuṇāti nāvāya laddhattā bāvarikassa tasmai ekekassa gehe satta satta divasāni
translated: and she belongs to the Bāvarika because she was obtained by ship, therefore let each of them have her for seven days in each house,🔽and let them live in peace.”

original: hotū”ti mantetvā dvepi rājāno saññāpesuṃ. Te ubhopi attamanā hutvā titthapaṭititthe
analyzed: hotu uti mantetvā dve api rājāno saññāpesum te ubho api attamanāḥ hutvā tittha paṭititthe
translated: and they both agreed. They were both delighted, and they built cities at the landing-places,

original: nagarāni māpetvā vasiṃsu. Sā dvinnampi tesaṃ aggamahesittaṃ kāresi. Dvepi tassā sammattā🔽ahesuṃ. Sā pana ekassa ghare sattāhaṃ vasitvā nāvāya itarassa gharaṃ gacchantī nāvaṃ
analyzed: nagarāni māpetvā vasiṃsu sā dvinnam pi tesam agga mahesittam kāresi dve pi tassā sammattā  ahesum sā pana ekassa ghare sattāham vasitvā nāvāya itarassa gharam gacchantī nāvam
translated: and lived there. She was the chief queen of both of them. Both of them were devoted to her.🔽But she would stay a week in one’s house, and then, after having the boat

original: pājetvā nentena ekena mahallakakhujjakevaṭṭena saddhiṃ nadīmajjhe pāpaṃ karoti. Tadā
analyzed: ekena mahallaka khujja kevaṭṭena saddhim nadī majjhe pāpam karoti tadā
translated: steadied, she would go to the other’s house in the boat, and on the way she would commit sin with a certain old fisherman who was rowing.

original: kuṇālo sakuṇarājā bako ahosi, tasmā idaṃ attanā diṭṭhakāraṇaṃ āharitvā dassento gāthamāha –
analyzed: kuṇālaḥ sakuṇa rājā bakaḥ ahosi tasmai idam attanā diṭṭha kāraṇam āharitvā dassentaḥ gātham āha
translated: At that time the king of the birds was a crane, and so, bringing forward this reason which he had seen, he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Bakassa ca bāvarikassa ca rañño, accantakāmānugatassa bhariyā;
analyzed: bakassa ca bāvarikassa ca raññaḥ accanta kāma anugatassa bhariyā
translated: The wife of the crane and the king of Bāvarī, who was devoted to her,

original: Avācarī paṭṭhavasānugassa, kaṃ vāpi itthī nāticare tadañña”nti.
analyzed: avācarī paṭṭhavasā anugassa kam vā api itthī na aticare
translated: And the king of Paṭṭhavasa, what woman would not be unchaste?

original: Tattha accantakāmānugatassāti accantaṃ kāmaṃ anugatassa. Avācarīti anācāraṃ cari.
analyzed: tattha accanta kāma anugatassa ati accantam kāmam anugatassa avācari iti anācāram cari
translated: Herein, devoted to her means devoted to her to the utmost. She was unchaste means she behaved unrighteously.

original: Paṭṭhavasānugassāti paṭṭhassa attano vasānugatassa, attano pesanakārassa santiketi
analyzed: paṭṭha vasā anugassa ati paṭṭhassa attanaḥ vasā anugatassa attanaḥ pesana kārassa santike iti
translated: ‘Who follows his own will’: who follows his own will, who is his own messenger, is near,

original: attho. Karaṇatthe vā sāmivacanaṃ, tena saddhiṃ pāpamakāsīti vuttaṃ hoti. Tadaññanti
analyzed: atthaḥ karaṇa tthe vā sāmi vacanam tena saddhim pāpam akāsi iti vuttam hoti tad aññam ti
translated: the meaning is. Or the word ‘his’ is in the instrumental case; so the meaning is, ‘he did evil with him’. ‘No other’:

original: kataraṃ taṃ aññaṃ purisaṃ nāticareyyāti attho.
analyzed: kataram tam aññam purisam na aticareyya ati attho
translated: what other man would she not go beyond? is the meaning.

original: Aparāpi atīte brahmadattassa bhariyā piṅgiyānī nāma aggamahesī sīhapañjaraṃ vivaritvā
analyzed: aparā api atīte brahmadattassa bhariyā piṅgiyānī nāma agga mahesī sīha pañjaram vivaritvā
translated: And there was another in the past: the chief queen of King Brahmadatta, named Piṅgiyāni, opened the lion-house

original: olokentī maṅgalaassagopakaṃ disvā rañño niddupagamanakāle vātapānena oruyha tena
analyzed: olokentī maṅgala assa gopakam disvā raññaḥ niddupa gamana kāle vāta pānena oruyha tena
translated: and looking out saw a lucky horse-keeper. At the time the king was not there, so she got down by the window,

original: saddhiṃ aticaritvā puna pāsādaṃ āruyha gandhehi sarīraṃ ubbaṭṭetvā raññā saddhiṃ🔽nipajji. Athekadivasaṃ rājā “kiṃ nu kho deviyā aḍḍharattasamaye niccaṃ sarīraṃ sītaṃ
analyzed: saddhim aticaritvā puna pāsādam āruyha gandhehi sarīram ubbaṭṭetvā raññā saddhim  nipajji atha eka divasam rājā kim nu kho deviyāḥ aḍḍha ratta samaye niccam sarīram sītam
translated: went beyond with him, and then got back into the palace. She anointed her body with perfumes and lay down with the king.

original: hoti, pariggaṇhissāmi na”nti ekadivasaṃ niddupagato viya hutvā taṃ uṭṭhāya gacchantiṃ
analyzed: hoti pariggaṇhissāmi eka divasam viya hutvā tam uṭṭhāya gacchantim
translated: Then one day the king thought, ‘Why is it that the queen’s body is always cool at midnight? I will find out.’ So one day he pretended to be asleep. As she was getting up to go,🔽he grabbed her.

original: anugantvā assabandhena saddhiṃ aticarantiṃ disvā nivattitvā sayanaṃ abhiruhi. Sāpi
analyzed: anugantvā assabandhena saddhim aticarantim disvā nivattitvā sayanam sā api
translated: and after following them, he saw the queen and the groom committing adultery. He turned back and got into bed. The queen

original: aticaritvā āgantvā cūḷasayanake nipajji. Punadivase rājā amaccagaṇamajjheyeva taṃ🔽pakkosāpetvā taṃ kiccaṃ āvikatvā “sabbāva itthiyo pāpadhammā”ti tassā vadhabandhachejjabhejjārahaṃ
analyzed: aticaritvā āgantvā cūḍasayanake puna divase rājā tam  pakkosāpetvā tam kiccam āvikatvā sabbāva itthiyo pāpa dhammā ati tassāḥ vadha bandha chejja bhejja araham
translated: came back after committing adultery and lay down on the lower bed. On the following day the king summoned her in the midst of the assembly of ministers

original: dosaṃ khamitvā ṭhānā cāvetvā aññaṃ aggamahesiṃ akāsi. Tadā kuṇālo rājā brahmadatto
analyzed: dosam khamitvā ṭhānā cāvetvā aññam agga mahesim akāsi tadā kuṇālaḥ rājā brahmadatto
translated: and, after making that matter known, he said: “All women are wicked.” He forgave her the fault of deserving to be killed, bound, cut, and hurt, and after removing her from her position, he made another chief queen. At that time Kuṇāla was King Brahmadatta.

original: ahosi, tena taṃ attanā diṭṭhaṃ āharitvā dassento gāthamāha –
analyzed: ahosi tena tam attanā diṭṭham āharitvā dassentaḥ gātham āha
translated: Recalling what he had seen, he spoke this verse:

original: “Piṅgiyānī sabbalokissarassa, rañño piyā brahmadattassa bhariyā;
analyzed: piṅgiyānī sabba lokissarassa raññaḥ piyā brahmadattassa bhariyā
translated: “Piṅgiyāṇī, the beloved wife of King Brahmadatta, the lord of all the world,

original: Avācarī paṭṭhavasānugassa, taṃ vāpi sā nājjhagā kāmakāminī”ti.
analyzed: avācarī paṭṭhavasa anugassa tam vā api sā na ajjhagā kāma kāminī iti
translated: committed adultery with the groom, his attendant. She did not go to him, being a woman who desired love.”

original: Tattha taṃ vāti sā evaṃ aticarantī taṃ vā assabandhaṃ taṃ vā aggamahesiṭṭhānanti ubhayampi nājjhagā, ubhato bhaṭṭhā ahosi. Kāmakāminīti kāme patthayamānā.
analyzed: tattha tam vā ati sā evam aticarantī tam vā assabandham tam vā aggamahesiṭṭhānam ti ubhayam pi na ajjhagāḥ ubhatas bhaṭṭhā ahosi kāma kāminī iti kāme patthayamānā
translated: Herein, she did not go to him means she did not go to him, the groom, or to the position of chief queen. She was dismissed from both. Being a woman who desired love means being a woman who sought love.

original: Evaṃ pāpadhammā itthiyoti atītavatthūhi itthīnaṃ dosaṃ kathetvā aparenapi pariyāyena tāsaṃ dosameva kathento āha –
analyzed: evam pāpa dhammā itthiyaḥ ti atīta vatthūhi itthīnam dosam kathetvā aparena api pariyāyena tāsam dosam eva kathentaḥ āha
translated: Thus, after telling the faults of women by way of past events, he spoke this verse in another way to tell their faults:

original: “Luddhānaṃ lahucittānaṃ, akataññūna dubbhinaṃ;
analyzed: luddhānam lahu cittānam dubbhinam
translated: “The greedy, the fickle-minded, the ungrateful, the wicked,

original: Nādevasatto puriso, thīnaṃ saddhātumarahati.
analyzed: na a deva sattaḥ purisaḥ thīnam saddhātum arahati
translated: The man who is not a god, does not deserve to trust women.

original: “Na tā pajānanti kataṃ na kiccaṃ, na mātaraṃ pitaraṃ bhātaraṃ vā;
analyzed: na tā pajānanti katam na kiccam na mātaram pitaram bhātaram vā
translated: “They do not know what is done or what should be done, nor mother, father, or brother;

original: Anariyā samatikkantadhammā, sasseva cittassa vasaṃ vajanti.
analyzed: an ariyāḥ samatikkanta dhammāḥ sassa iva cittassa vasam vajanti
translated: The unrighteous ones, having transgressed the Dhamma, go under the sway of their own minds.

original: “Cirānuvuṭṭhampi piyaṃ manāpaṃ, anukampakaṃ pāṇasamampi bhattuṃ;
analyzed: cira anuvuṭṭham pi piyam manāpam anukampakam pāṇa samam pi
translated: “Though he has been long-lived, dear, and agreeable, compassionate, and like a son to his father,

original: Āvāsu kiccesu ca naṃ jahanti, tasmāhamitthīnaṃ na vissasāmi.
analyzed: āvāsu kiccesu ca nam jahanti tasmā aham itthīnam na vissasāmi
translated: They abandon him in his old age and in his duties; therefore I do not trust women.

original: “Thīnañhi cittaṃ yathā vānarassa, kannappakannaṃ yathā rukkhachāyā;
analyzed: thīnam hi cittam yathā vānarassa kannappakannam yathā rukkha chāyā
translated: “For the mind of women is like that of a monkey, like the shade of a tree at midday;

original: Calācalaṃ hadayamitthiyānaṃ, cakkassa nemi viya parivattati.
analyzed: calācalam hadaya mitthiyānam cakkassa nemi viya parivattati
translated: The heart of women is fickle, it turns around like the rim of a wheel.

original: “Yadā tā passanti samekkhamānā, ādeyyarūpaṃ purisassa vittaṃ;
analyzed: yadā tā passanti samekkhamānāḥ ādeyya rūpam purisassa vittam
translated: “When they see a man’s wealth, which is fit to be taken,

original: Saṇhāhi vācāhi nayanti menaṃ, kambojakā jalajeneva assaṃ.
analyzed: saṇhāhi vācāhi nayanti mā enam kambojakāḥ jalajena iva assam
translated: They lead him on with soft words, like the Kambodians with a horse.

original: “Yadā na passanti samekkhamānā, ādeyyarūpaṃ purisassa vittaṃ;
analyzed: yadā na passanti samekkhamānāḥ ādeyya rūpam purisassa vittam
translated: When they see that a man’s wealth is not to be taken,

original: Samantato naṃ parivajjayanti, tiṇṇo nadīpāragatova kullaṃ.
analyzed: samantataḥ nam parivajjayanti tiṇṇaḥ nadī pāra gataḥ uva kullam
translated: they avoid him on all sides, like one who has crossed the river and left the raft behind.

original: “Silesūpamā sikhiriva sabbabhakkhā, tikkhamāyā nadīriva sīghasotā;
analyzed: silesu upamā sikhiḥ iva sabba bhakkhā tikkha māyā nadīḥ iva sīgha sotā
translated: Like virtue, like a peacock, like all-devouring fire, like a river with a steep current,

original: Sevanti hetā piyamappiyañca, nāvā yathā orakulaṃ parañca.
analyzed: sevanti hetā piyam appiyam ca nāvā yathā ora kulam parañca
translated: they associate with both the dear and the not-dear, like a boat with both banks.

original: “Na tā ekassa na dvinnaṃ, āpaṇova pasārito;
analyzed: na tāḥ ekassa na dvinnam āpaṇaḥ uva pasāritaḥ
translated: They are not for one or two, but are spread out like a market-place.

original: Yo tā mayhanti maññeyya, vātaṃ jālena bādhaye.
analyzed: yaḥ tā mayhanti maññeyya vātam jālena bādhaye
translated: He who would think, “They are mine,” would be like one who would catch the wind in a net.

original: “Yathā nadī ca pantho ca, pānāgāraṃ sabhā papā;
analyzed: yathā nadī ca panthaḥ ca pānāgāram sabhā papā
translated: As a river, a road, a drinking-hall, an assembly, a pit-fall,

original: Evaṃ lokitthiyo nāma, velā tāsaṃ na vijjati.
analyzed: evam lokitthiyaḥ nāma velā tāsam na vijjati
translated: so are women in the world; there is no limit to their wickedness.

original: “Ghatāsanasamā etā, kaṇhasappasirūpamā;
analyzed: etā kaṇha sappa sirūpamā
translated: They are like a pot of excrement, like a black snake,

original: Gāvo bahi tiṇasseva, omasanti varaṃ varaṃ.
analyzed: gāvaḥ bahi tiṇassa iva omasanti varam varam
translated: like a cow outside the village, they go after the best of the grass.

original: “Ghatāsanaṃ kuñjaraṃ kaṇhasappaṃ, muddhābhisittaṃ pamadā ca sabbā;
analyzed: ghatāsanam kuñjaram kaṇhasappam muddhābhisittam pamadā ca sabbā
translated: A pot of excrement, an elephant, a black snake, a crowned queen, and all intoxicated people,

original: Ete naro niccayato bhajetha, tesaṃ have dubbidu sabbabhāvo.
analyzed: ete naraḥ niccayataḥ bhajetha tesam have sabba bhāvaḥ
translated: these a man should never approach; for with them all is evil.

original: “Naccantavaṇṇā na bahūna kantā, na dakkhiṇā pamadā sevitabbā;
analyzed: na dakkhiṇā pamadā sevitabbā
translated: “Not one who is a dancer, not one who is loved by many, Not one who is a courtesan, not one who is a drunkard should be served.

original: Na parassa bhariyā na dhanassa hetu, etitthiyo pañca na sevitabbā”ti.🔽Tattha luddhānanti lubbhānaṃ. Kaṇaverajātake viya baddhacorepi sārajjanaṃ sandhāyetaṃ🔽vuttaṃ. Lahucittānanti muhuttameva parivattanacittānaṃ. Cūḷadhanuggahajātakena etaṃ
analyzed: na parassa bhariyā na dhanassa hetu etitthiyaḥ pañca na sevitabbā ati  tattha luddhānam ti lubbhānam kaṇavera jātake viya baddha core pi sārajjanam sandhāya itam  vuttam lahu cittānam ti muhuttam eva parivattana cittānam cūḷa dhanuggaha jātakena etam
translated: Not one who is another’s wife, not one who is for a price: These five kinds of women should not be served.”🔽Herein, those who are greedy are those who are lustful. This is said referring to the lustful state of the thieves who were bound in the Kaṇvera Jātaka.🔽Those whose minds are fickle are those whose minds change in a moment. This should be illustrated by the Cūḷadhanuggaha Jātaka.

original: dīpetabbaṃ. Akataññutā pana etāsaṃ ekakanipāte takkāriyajātakena dīpetabbā. Nādevasattoti
analyzed: dīpetabbam akataññu tā pana etāsam ekaka nipāte takkāriya jātakena dīpetabbā
translated: But ingratitude should be illustrated by the Takkiriyā Jātaka in the Minor Anthologies.

original: na adevasatto devena anāsatto ayakkhagahitako abhūtaviṭṭho puriso thīnaṃ sīlavantataṃ
analyzed: na a deva sattaḥ devena anāsattaḥ a yakkha gahitakaḥ a bhūta viṭṭhaḥ puriso thīnam
translated: Not one who is not a god: a man who is not a god, not a being, not a yakkha, not a demon, is not worthy of confidence in the virtue of women. But one who is a demon would be worthy of confidence.🔽What he has done: a favor done by himself.

original: saddhātuṃ nārahati, bhūtaviṭṭho pana saddaheyya. Katanti attano kataṃ upakāraṃ. Kiccanti
analyzed: saddhātum na arahati bhūta viṭṭhaḥ pana saddaheyya katanti attanaḥ katam upakāram
translated: What he has to do: a duty to be done by himself.

original: attanā kattabbaṃ kiccaṃ. Na mātaranti sabbepi ñātake chaḍḍetvā yasmiṃ paṭibaddhacittā
analyzed: attanā kattabbam kiccam na sabbe api ñātake chaḍḍetvā yasmin paṭibaddha cittā
translated: Not a mother: having abandoned all relatives, in whom there is a bound mind

original: honti, taññeva anubandhanato ete mātādayo na jānanti nāma mahāpanthakamātā viya.
analyzed: honti taññeva anubandhanataḥ ete mātā ādayaḥ na jānanti nāma mahā panthaka mātā viya
translated: They do not know, because they follow him, as in the case of the mother of the great sage Pantha.

original: Anariyāti nillajjā. Sassevāti sakassa. Āvāsūti āpadāsu. Kiccesūti tesu tesu karaṇīyesu.
analyzed: nillajjā sassevā ati sakassa āvāsu āpadāsu kiccesu iti tesu tesu karaṇīyesu
translated: “Unrighteous” : shameless. “To his own” : to his own. “In misfortune” : in calamities. “In undertakings” : in this and that undertaking.🔽“To be his confidant” : to be his confidant in what is done and what is not done.

original: Kannappakannanti otiṇṇotiṇṇaṃ. Yathā hi visame padese rukkhachāyā ninnampiorohati,
analyzed: kannappakannanti otiṇṇotiṇṇam yathā hi visame padese rukkha chāyā
translated: For just as the shade of a tree in an uneven place covers the low and reaches the high,

original: thalampi abhiruhati, tathā etāsampi cittaṃ na kañci uttamādhamaṃ vajjeti. Calācalanti
analyzed: thalam pi abhiruhati tathā etāsam pi cittam na uttama adhamam cala acalanti
translated: so their minds do not discriminate between high and low. “Unstable” :

original: ekasmiṃyeva apatiṭṭhitaṃ. Nemi viyāti sakaṭassa gacchato cakkanemi viya. Ādeyyarūpanti
analyzed: ekasmin yeva apatiṭṭhitam nemi viyāti sakaṭassa gacchataḥ cakka nemi viya ādeyya rūpanti
translated: uncertain. “Like a wheel” : like the wheel of a moving cart. “To be taken” :

original: gahetabbajātikaṃ. Vittanti dhanaṃ. Nayantīti attano vasaṃ nenti. Jalajenāti jalajātasevālena.
analyzed: gahetabba jātikam vittanti dhanam nayanti iti attanaḥ vasam nenti jalajena ati jala jāta sevālena
translated: to be grasped. “Wealth” : money. “Lead” : bring under their control. “By the water-born” : by the water-born creeper.

original: Kambojaraṭṭhavāsino kira yadā aṭavito asse gaṇhitukāmā honti, tadā ekasmiṃ ṭhāne
analyzed: kamboja raṭṭha vāsinaḥ kira yadā aṭavitaḥ asse gaṇhitu kāmāḥ honti tadā ekasmim ṭhāne
translated: It seems that the people of the Kamboja country, when they want to catch horses from the forest,

original: vatiṃ parikkhipitvā dvāraṃ yojetvā assānaṃ udakapānatitthe sevālaṃ madhunā makkhetvā
analyzed: vatim parikkhipitvā dvāram yojetvā assānam udaka pāna titthe sevālam madhunā makkhetvā
translated: first surround a place with a fence, make a gate, and smear honey on the grass at the water-drinking place of the horses.

original: sevālasambandhāni tīre tiṇāni ādiṃ katvā yāva parikkhepadvārā makkhenti, assā pānīyaṃ🔽pivitvā rasagiddhena madhunā makkhitāni tāni tiṇāni khādantā anukkamena taṃ ṭhānaṃ🔽pavisanti. Iti yathā te jalajena palobhetvā asse vasaṃ nenti, tathā etāpi dhanaṃ
analyzed: sevāla sambandhāni tīre tiṇāni ādim katvā yāva parikkhepa dvārā makkhenti assā pānīyam  pivitvā rasa giddhena madhunā makkhitāni tāni tiṇāni khādantā anukkamena tam ṭhānam  pavisanti iti yathā te jalajena palobhetvā asse vasam nenti tathā dhanam
translated: Beginning with the grass on the bank, they smear it with their mouths right up to the door of the enclosure. The horses drink the water,

original: disvā tassa gahaṇatthāya saṇhāhi vācāhipi purisaṃ vasaṃ nentīti attho. Kullanti taraṇatthāya gahitaṃ yaṃ kiñci.
analyzed: disvā tassa gahaṇa atthāya purisam vasam nenti iti tattho taraṇa atthāya gahitam yam kiñci
translated: and then, greedy for the taste of the honey, they eat the smeared grass. In this way they gradually enter the place. So just as the water-lilies entice the horses and make them live there, so too these women, seeing the wealth, entice the man with their sweet words in order to get it. The meaning is: they make him live with them. A raft is anything that is used for crossing.

original: Silesūpamāti purisānaṃ cittabandhanena silesasadisā. Tikkhamāyāti tikhiṇamāyā sīghamāyā.
analyzed: silesūpamā ati purisānam citta bandhanena silesa sadisā tikkha māyā ati tikhiṇa māyā sīgha māyā
translated: They are like a snare for men because they bind the minds of men. They are sharp and deceitful: they are quick in deceit.

original: Nadīrivāti yathā pabbateyyā nadī sīghasotā, evaṃ sīghamāyāti attho. Āpaṇovāti yathā
analyzed: nadīḥ iva ati yathā pabbateyyā nadī sīgha sotā evam sīgha māyā ati atthaḥ āpaṇā uvā iti yathā
translated: They are like a river: the meaning is that they are quick in deceit like a mountain river with a swift current. They are like a shop:

original: ca pasāritāpaṇo yesaṃ mūlaṃ atthi, tesaññeva upakāro, tatheva tāpi. Yo tāti yo puriso
analyzed: ca pasārita āpaṇaḥ yesam mūlam atthi tesam na eva upakāro tathā iva yaḥ tāti yo puriso
translated: and just as a shop that is open is of use only to those who have goods to sell, so too are they. The man who trusts them:

original: tā itthiyo. Bādhayeti so vātaṃ jālena bādheyya. Velā tāsaṃ na vijjatīti yathā etesaṃ
analyzed: tāḥ itthiyaḥ bādhaya iti saḥ vātam jālena bādheyya velā tāsam na vijjati iti yathā etesam
translated: Those women. The wind: he would obstruct the wind with a net. There is no chance: just as for these

original: nadīādīnaṃ “asukavelāyameva ettha gantabba”nti velā natthi, rattimpi divāpi icchiticchitakkhaṇe
analyzed: nadī ādīnam asuka velāyam eva ettha gantabbanti velā natthi rattim pi divā api icchiticchita khaṇe
translated: “Those women”: the women. “No time”: he would obstruct the wind with a net. “No time is known for them”: just as there is no time for these rivers, etc., “at such a time one should go there,” but they can be approached at any time, day or night, as one wishes;

original: upagantabbāneva, asukenevātipi mariyādā natthi, atthikena upagantabbāneva, tathā tāsampīti attho.
analyzed: upagantabbān eva asukena iva atipi mariyādā natthi atthikena upagantabbān eva tathā tāsam pi iti attho
translated: and there is no limit as to who can approach them, for anyone who wants to can approach them. The meaning is that it is the same with those women.

original: Ghatāsanasamā etāti yathā aggi indhanena na tappati, evametāpi kilesaratiyā. Kaṇhasappasirūpamāti🔽kodhanatāya upanāhitāya ghoravisatāya dujivhatāya mittadubbhitāyāti pañcahi kāraṇehi
analyzed: etā ati yathā aggi indhanena na tappati evam etā api kilesa ratiyā  kodhana tāya upanāhitāya ghora visa tāya dujivha tāya mitta dubbhitāya ati pañcahi kāraṇehi
translated: “Like a pot of water”: just as fire does not burn a pot of water, so these women do not burn with the lust of defilements. “Like a black snake”:

original: kaṇhasappasirasadisā. Tattha bahularāgatāya ghoravisatā, pisuṇatāya dujivhatā, aticāritāya
analyzed: kaṇha sappa sira sadisā tattha bahula rāga tāya ghora visa tā pisuṇa tāya dujivha tā aticāritāya
translated: because of their anger, their terrible poison, their forked tongues, and their treachery to friends, they are like the head of a black snake. Herein, their terrible poison is due to their great lust; their forked tongues, to their slander;

original: mittadubbhitā veditabbā. Gāvo bahi tiṇassevāti yathā gāvo khāditaṭṭhānaṃ chaḍḍetvā
analyzed: mitta dubbhitāḥ veditabbāḥ gāvaḥ bahi tiṇassa iva ati yathā gāvaḥ khādita ṭṭhānam chaḍḍetvā
translated: and their treachery to friends, to their adultery. This should be understood. “Like cows to grass outside”: just as cows, having abandoned the place where they have eaten,

original: bahi manāpamanāpassa tiṇassa varaṃ varaṃ omasanti khādanti, evametāpi niddhanaṃ chaḍḍetvā
analyzed: bahi manāpa manāpassa tiṇassa varam varam khādanti evam etā api niddhanam chaḍḍetvā
translated: They pick out the best of the grass, the pleasant and the unpleasant, and eat it. So too, these women, having cast off the dead,

original: aññaṃ sadhanameva bhajantīti attho. Muddhābhisittanti rājānaṃ. Pamadā ca sabbāti
analyzed: aññam sa dhanam eva bhajanti iti atthaḥ muddhābhisittanti rājānam pamadā ca sabbā ati
translated: go to another who has wealth. The meaning is: ‘They go to another who has wealth.’ The anointed: the king. And all women are heedless:

original: sabbā ca itthiyo. Eteti ete pañca jane. Niccayatoti niccasaññato, upaṭṭhitassati
analyzed: sabbā ca itthiyaḥ ete iti ete pañca jane niccayataḥ ti nicca saññataḥ upaṭṭhitassati
translated: all women. These five: these five people. As a rule: as a rule of thumb, with mindfulness established,

original: appamattova hutvāti attho. Dubbidūti dujjāno. Sabbabhāvoti ajjhāsayo. Cirapariciṇṇopi🔽hi aggi dahati, ciravissāsikopi kuñjaro ghāteti, ciraparicitopi sappo ḍaṃsati, ciravissāsikopi
analyzed: appamattaḥ iva hutvā ti atthaḥ dubbidu iti dujjāno sabba bhāvo ti ajjhāsayaḥ cira pariciṇṇaḥ api  hi aggi dahati cira vissāsikaḥ api kuñjaraḥ ghāteti cira paricitaḥ api sappaḥ ḍaṃsati cira vissāsikaḥ api
translated: being heedless. Hard to know: difficult to know. The whole nature: the inner nature. For even a fire that has been tended

original: rājā anatthakaro hoti, evaṃ cirāciṇṇāpi itthiyo vikāraṃ dassentīti.🔽Naccantavaṇṇāti abhirūpavatī. Na bahūna kantāti aḍḍhakāsigaṇikā viya bahūnaṃ piyā
analyzed: rājā anattha karaḥ hoti evam cirāciṇṇā api itthiyaḥ vikāram dassenti iti  abhirūpavatī na bahūnam piyā
translated: for a long time burns, even an elephant that has been trusted for a long time kills, even a snake that has been tended for a long time bites, even a king who has been trusted for a long time does harm, so too, even women who have been tended for a long time show their true nature.🔽Beautiful: beautiful in form. Not the beloved of many: not the beloved of many, like a courtesan who has a price.

original: manāpā. Na dakkhiṇāti naccagītakusalā. Tathārūpā hi bahupatthitā bahumittā honti,
analyzed: manāpā na dakkhiṇāti nacca gīta kusalā tathārūpāḥ hi bahu patthitāḥ bahu mittāḥ honti
translated: Not a dancer: not skilled in dancing and singing. For such a one is courted by many, has many friends,

original: tasmā na sevitabbā. Na dhanassa hetūti yā dhanahetuyeva bhajati, sā apariggahāpi
analyzed: tasmā na sevitabbā na dhanassa hetu uti yā dhana hetuyā iva bhajati sā a pariggahā api
translated: Therefore they should not be served. Not for the sake of wealth: she who associates with a man only for the sake of wealth, even though she be not a kept woman,

original: na sevitabbā. Sā hi dhanaṃ alabhamānā kujjhatīti.
analyzed: na sevitabbā sā hi dhanam a labhamānā kujjhati iti
translated: should not be served. For if she does not get wealth, she becomes angry.

original: Evaṃ vutte mahājano mahāsattassa “aho sukathita”nti sādhukāramadāsi. Sopi ettakehi🔽kāraṇehi itthīnaṃ aguṇaṃ kathetvā tuṇhī ahosi. Taṃ sutvā ānando gijjharājā, “samma
analyzed: evam vutte mahā janaḥ mahāsattassa aho su kathitanti sādhukāram adāsi saḥ api ettakehi  kāraṇehi itthīnam aguṇam kathetvā tuṇhī ahosi tam sutvā ānandaḥ gijjha rājā samma
translated: When this had been said, the multitude cried out with one voice, “Well said!” and applauded the Great Being. He, having thus set forth the faults of women for the space of three months,

original: kuṇāla, ahampi attano ñāṇabalena itthīnaṃ aguṇaṃ kathessāmī”ti vatvā aguṇakathaṃ
analyzed: kuṇāla aham pi attanaḥ ñāṇa balena itthīnam aguṇam kathessāmi iti vatvā aguṇa katham
translated: remained silent. When he had heard this, Ānanda the king of the geese said, “Very well, my friend Kuṇāla, I too will set forth the faults of women by the power of my own knowledge.” So saying, he began to set forth the faults of women.

original: ārabhi. Taṃ dassento satthā āha –
analyzed: ārabhi tam dassentaḥ satthā āha
translated: In order to show this, the Master said:

original: “Atha khalu, bho, ānando gijjharājā kuṇālassa ādimajjhakathāpariyosānaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: atha khalu bho ānandaḥ gijjha rājā kuṇālassa ādi majjha kathā pariyosānam viditvā tāyam velāyam imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: “Then, sirs, Ānanda the king of the geese, understanding that the beginning, the middle, and the end of Kuṇāla’s discourse were all good, on that occasion recited these verses:

original: “Puṇṇampi cemaṃ pathaviṃ dhanena, dajjitthiyā puriso sammatāya;
analyzed: puṇṇam pi ca imam pathavim dhanena purisaḥ sammatāya
translated: “Though a man give a gift of wealth to a woman, even to a wife who is dear,

original: Laddhā khaṇaṃ atimaññeyya tampi, tāsaṃ vasaṃ asatīnaṃ na gacche.
analyzed: laddhā khaṇam tam pi tāsam vasam asatīnam na gacche
translated: yet, having obtained a moment’s opportunity, she may despise him. Go not under the sway of such faithless ones.

original: “Uṭṭhāhakaṃ cepi alīnavuttiṃ, komārabhattāraṃ piyaṃ manāpaṃ;
analyzed: uṭṭhāhakam ce pi alīna vuttim komāra bhattāram piyam manāpam
translated: “Even if a man is a provider, of good conduct, a prince, dear and beloved,

original: Āvāsu kiccesu ca naṃ jahanti, tasmāhamitthīnaṃ na vissasāmi.
analyzed: āvāsu kiccesu ca nam jahanti tasmā aham itthīnam na vissasāmi
translated: They leave him behind in his work, that’s why I don’t trust women.

original: “Na vissase ‘icchati ma’nti poso, na vissase ‘rodati me sakāse’;
analyzed: na vissase icchati manti posaḥ na vissase rodati me sakāse
translated: “A man doesn’t trust that she loves him, she doesn’t trust that he cries in her presence;

original: Sevanti hetā piyamappiyañca, nāvā yathā orakūlaṃ parañca.
analyzed: sevanti hetā piyam appiyam ca nāvā yathā orakūlam parañca
translated: They associate with what is dear and what is not, like a boat in the water on both sides.

original: “Na vissase sākhapurāṇasanthataṃ, na vissase mittapurāṇacoraṃ;
analyzed: na vissase sākha purāṇa santhatam na vissase mitta purāṇa coram
translated: “I don’t trust an old tree with branches, I don’t trust an old friend who is a thief;

original: Na vissase rājānaṃ ‘sakhā mama’nti, na vissase itthi dasanna mātaraṃ.
analyzed: na vissase rājānam sakhā mamanti na vissase itthi dasan na mātaram
translated: I don’t trust a king with the words ‘he’s my friend,’ I don’t trust a woman with the words ‘she’s my mother.’

original: “Na vissase rāmakarāsu nārisu, accantasīlāsu asaññatāsu;
analyzed: na vissase rāma karāsu nārisu accanta sīlāsu asaññatāsu
translated: “I don’t trust women who are passionate, who are unrestrained though they have good virtue;

original: Accantapemānugatassa bhariyā, na vissase titthasamā hi nāriyo.
analyzed: bhariyāḥ na tittha samāḥ hi nāriyaḥ
translated: The wife of one who is completely devoted, I don’t trust her, for women are like river-banks.

original: “Haneyyuṃ chindeyyuṃ chedāpeyyumpi, kaṇṭhepi chetvā rudhiraṃ piveyyuṃ;
analyzed: haneyyum chindeyyum kaṇṭhe api chetvā rudhiram piveyyum
translated: “They would kill, cut, and have cut , they would cut the throat and drink blood;

original: Mā dīnakāmāsu asaññatāsu, bhāvaṃ kare gaṅgatitthūpamāsu.
analyzed: mā dīna kāmāsu asañña tāsu bhāvam kare gaṅga titthu upamāsu
translated: Don’t have a relationship with those who are unrestrained and have little desire, who are like river-banks.

original: “Musā tāsaṃ yathā saccaṃ, saccaṃ tāsaṃ yathā musā;
analyzed: musā tāsam yathā saccam saccam tāsam yathā musā
translated: “For them, lies are as true as truth,

original: Gāvo bahi tiṇasseva, omasanti varaṃ varaṃ.
analyzed: gāvaḥ bahi tiṇassa iva omasanti varam varam
translated: They praise the best of grass, the grass outside.

original: “Gatenetā palobhenti, pekkhitena mhitena ca;
analyzed: gatena itā palobhenti pekkhitena mhitena ca
translated: “They entice with going, with looking, with sitting,

original: Athopi dunnivatthena, mañjunā bhaṇitena ca.
analyzed: dunnivatthena mañjunā bhaṇitena ca
translated: And also with bad dress, with sweet speech.

original: “Coriyo kathinā hetā, vāḷā ca lapasakkharā;🔽Na tā kiñci na jānanti, yaṃ manussesu vañcanaṃ.
analyzed: coriyaḥ kathinā hetā vāḷā ca lapasakkharā  na tā kiñci na jānanti yam manussesu vañcanaṃ
translated: “They are thieves, they are the cause of the kasina, they are wild, they are slanderers,🔽They know nothing of deceiving people.

original: “Asā lokitthiyo nāma, velā tāsaṃ na vijjati;
analyzed: asā lokitthiyaḥ nāma velā tāsam na vijjati
translated: “There is no such thing as a faithful woman, there is no such thing as a woman who is not unfaithful,

original: Sārattā ca pagabbhā ca, sikhī sabbaghaso yathā.
analyzed: sārattā ca pagabbhā ca sikhī sabbaghasaḥ yathā
translated: They are greedy and shameless, like a peacock is all feathers.

original: “Natthitthīnaṃ piyo nāma, appiyopi na vijjati;
analyzed: natthi itthīnam piyaḥ nāma appiyaḥ api na vijjati
translated: “There is no such thing as a woman who is dear, there is no such thing as a woman who is not dear,

original: Sevanti hetā piyamappiyañca, nāvā yathā orakūlaṃ parañca.
analyzed: sevanti hetā piyam appiyam ca nāvā yathā orakūlam parañca
translated: They associate with the dear and the not dear, like a boat on the ocean goes back and forth.

original: “Natthitthīnaṃ piyo nāma, appiyopi na vijjati;
analyzed: natthi itthīnam piyaḥ nāma appiyaḥ api na vijjati
translated: “There is no such thing as a woman who is dear, there is no such thing as a woman who is not dear,

original: Dhanattā paṭivallanti, latāva dumanissitā.
analyzed: dhanattā paṭivallanti latā va duma nissitā
translated: They turn to the one who has wealth, like creepers clinging to a tree.

original: “Hatthibandhaṃ assabandhaṃ, gopurisañca maṇḍalaṃ;
analyzed: hatthi bandham assa bandham gopurisam ca maṇḍalam
translated: “They go to the elephant trainer, the horse trainer, the cowherd, the wrestler,

original: Chavaḍāhakaṃ pupphachaḍḍakaṃ, sadhanamanupatanti nāriyo.
analyzed: chava ḍāhakam puppha chaḍḍakam sa dhanam anupatanti nāriyaḥ
translated: The gravedigger, the flower-seller, the wealthy man, the woman goes to all.

original: “Kulaputtampi jahanti akiñcanaṃ, chavakasamasadisampi;
analyzed: kula puttam pi jahanti akiñcanam chavaka sama sadisam pi
translated: “They abandon the young man, the penniless one, the one who is like a bird,

original: Anugacchanti anupatanti, dhanahetu hi nāriyo”ti.
analyzed: anugacchanti anupatanti dhana hetu hi
translated: They follow, they pursue, for women are on account of wealth.

original: Tattha ādimajjhakathāpariyosānanti kathāya ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ. Laddhā khaṇanti
analyzed: tattha ādi majjha kathā pariyosānam ti kathāyaḥ ādi majjha pariyosānam laddhā
translated: Herein, the beginning, middle, and end of the talk: the beginning, middle, and end of the story. Having got the chance:

original: okāsaṃ labhitvā. Icchati manti maṃ esā icchatīti puriso itthiṃ na vissaseyya. Sākhapurāṇasanthatanti🔽hiyyo vā pare vā santhataṃ purāṇasākhāsanthataṃ na vissase, apapphoṭetvā apaccavekkhitvā
analyzed: okāsam labhitvā icchati manti mam esā icchati iti purisaḥ itthim na vissaseyya  hiyyas vā pare vā santhatam purāṇa sākhā santhatam na vissase a papphoṭetvā a paccavekkhitvā
translated: having got the opportunity. She wants me: a man should not trust a woman who says “She wants me.” A branch, old, and a bed:🔽he should not trust a bed made of old branches that have been cut yesterday or the day before. He should not use it without shaking it down and examining it,

original: na paribhuñjeyya. Tatra hi dīghajātiko vā pavisitvā tiṭṭheyye, paccāmitto vā satthaṃ🔽nikkhipeyya. Mittapurāṇacoranti panthadūhanaṭṭhāne ṭhitaṃ coraṃ “purāṇamitto me”ti
analyzed: na paribhuñjeyya tatra hi dīgha jātikaḥ vā pavisitvā tiṭṭheyye pacca amittaḥ vā sattham  nikkhipeyya mitta purāṇa coram ti panthadūhana ṭṭhāne ṭhitam coram purāṇa mittaḥ mā iti
translated: for a long-bodied animal might be in it, or an enemy might have put a weapon there. An old friend, a thief:

original: na vissaseyya. Corā hi ye sañjānanti teyeva mārenti. Sakhā mamanti so hi khippameva
analyzed: na vissaseyya corāḥ hi ye sañjānanti teyeva mārenti sakhā mamanti saḥ hi khippam eva
translated: he should not trust a thief who is standing in a place where cattle are driven along, thinking “He is an old friend of mine.” For thieves kill only those who recognize them. A friend:

analyzed: tittham viya sabba sādhāraṇā ti attho
translated: “Women are like a ford.” The meaning is: they are common to all.

analyzed: haneyyunti kuddhāḥ vā añña purisa sārattāḥ vā hutvā sabbam etam hanana ādim kareyyum mā

analyzed: dīna kāmāsu iti hīnajjhāsayāsu saṃkiliṭṭhaāsayāsu bhāvanti evarūpāsu sineham mā kare  gaṅga titthu upamāsu iti sabba sādhāraṇa ṭṭhena gaṅgā tittha sadisāsu musā ati musāvādaḥ tāsam
translated: “Do not love women who are poor in spirit”: do not love women who are of low disposition, who are of defiled disposition.🔽“Women who are like a river ford”: like a river ford in the sense of being common to all. “A lie”: a lie is like the truth to them.

original: niḷinikājātakaṃ, mañjunā bhaṇitena “tuvaṭaṃ kho, ayyaputta, āgaccheyyāsī”ti nandattherassa

original: vatthu kathetabbaṃ. Coriyoti sambhatassa dhanassa vināsanena coriyo. Kathināti thaddhahadayā.🔽Vāḷāti duṭṭhā appakeneva kujjhanasīlā. Lapasakkharāti niratthakalapanena sakkharā
analyzed: vatthu kathetabbam coriyaḥ ti sambhatassa dhanassa vināsanena coriyaḥ thaddha hadayā  vāḷā ati duṭṭhā appakena iva kujjhana sīlā lapasakkharā ti niratthaka lapanena sakkharā
translated: The Story of the Blue-Bearded One, and the story of the Elder Nandaka, who was told by a woman, “You may come, Master, if you will,” should be told in this place. Sweet-spoken is one who is sweet-spoken, like one who is sweet-spoken for the sake of gain. Unfaithful is one who is unfaithful, who is loose.

original: viya madhurā. Asāti asatiyo lāmakā. Sārattāti sabbadā sārattā. Pagabbhāti kāyapāgabbhiyādīhi
analyzed: viya madhurā asāti asatiyaḥ lāmakā sārattā ati sabbadā sārattā pagabbhā ati kāya pāgabbhiya ādīhi

Because women follow after wealth.”

translated: “Whatever rivers there are that flow to the ocean, the great ocean,

analyzed: mahantatāya na pūrati sambādha magge kaṇṭaka sākha sadisā yathā
translated: it is not fulfilled. ‘Like a thicket of thorns’ means like a thicket of thorns on a narrow path.

analyzed: hi sākhā laggitvā ākaḍḍhati evam etā api rūpa ādīhi kaḍḍhanti yathā sākhā hattha ādīsu
translated: For just as a thicket holds one back and pulls one this way and that, so these sensual pleasures pull one towards forms, etc. Just as

analyzed: vijjhitvā dukkham uppādeti evam etā api phuṭṭha mattā sarīra samphassena vijjhitvā mahā vināsam

translated: and ruin. ‘They go’ means they go to other men.

analyzed: ghosam uppādeyya sabba bhāvanti tvam eva iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ piyaḥ manāpaḥ iti vuccamānaḥ yaḥ  purisaḥ evam etat ti saddahantaḥ sabbam attanaḥ ajjhāsayam pamadāsu ossajeyya saḥ jāla ādīhi
translated: and make a noise. He would give up all his wealth, all his desires,

translated: They are hard to fill, like the great ocean with its water. They are hard to satisfy, like fire with fuel.🔽Knowing that they are sinking, one should not get close to them.

analyzed: ettha nipāta mattam itthiyaḥ catūsu apāyesu sīdanti iti viditvā āvaṭṭanī iti

analyzed: vikopanā ati nāsana tthena ca garaha tthena ca brahmacariyassa kopikā chandasā vāti  piya saṃvāsena vā dhanena vā ati dhana hetu vā saṃṭhānanti yathā jātavedaḥ attanaḥ ṭhānam

original: Evaṃ nāradena itthīnaṃ aguṇe pakāsite puna mahāsatto visesetvā tāsaṃ aguṇaṃ pakāseti. Taṃ dassetuṃ satthā āha –

translated: Thus, after the faults of women had been proclaimed by Nārada, the Great Being, distinguishing them, proclaimed their faults. In order to show this, the Teacher said:

original: “Atha khalu, bho, kuṇālo sakuṇo nāradassa devabrāhmaṇassa ādimajjhakathāpariyosānaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo ajjhabhāsi –
analyzed: atha khalu bho kuṇālaḥ sakuṇaḥ nāradassa deva brāhmaṇassa ādi majjha kathā pariyosānam viditvā imāḥ gāthāyaḥ ajjhabhāsi
translated: “Then, sirs, the bird Kuṇāla, having understood the beginning, middle, and end of the discourse of the divine brāhmaṇa Nārada, at that time spoke these verses:

original: “‘Sallape nisitakhaggapāṇinā, paṇḍito api pisācadosinā;
analyzed: sallape nisita khagga pāṇinā paṇḍitaḥ api pisāca dosinā
translated: ‘One may converse with one who holds a sharp sword in his hand, with a piśāca demon,

original: Uggatejamuragampi āside, eko ekāya pamadāya nālape.
analyzed: ekaḥ ekāya pamadāya na ālape
translated: But not alone with one woman, even if she is of exalted beauty.

original: “Lokacittamathanā hi nāriyo, naccagītabhaṇitamhitāvudhā;
analyzed: loka citta mathanāḥ hi nāriyaḥ
translated: “Women are the world’s mind-destroyers, their weapons are dancing, singing, and speech.

original: Bādhayanti anupaṭṭhitassatiṃ, dīpe rakkhasigaṇova vāṇije.
analyzed: bādhayanti an upaṭṭhita satim dīpe rakkhasi gaṇaḥ uva vāṇije
translated: They destroy the one who lacks mindfulness, like a horde of demons a merchant on the ocean.

original: “Natthi tāsaṃ vinayo na saṃvaro, majjamaṃsaniratā asaññatā;
analyzed: na atthi tāsam vinayaḥ na saṃvaraḥ majja maṃsa niratāḥ asañña tā
translated: “They have no discipline or restraint, they are unrestrained, attached to alcohol and meat.

original: Tā gilanti purisassa pābhataṃ, sāgareva makaraṃ timiṅgalo.
analyzed: tāḥ gilanti purisassa sāgarā iva makaram timiṅgalo
translated: They devour a man’s wealth, like a timiṅgala a whale in the ocean.

original: “Pañcakāmaguṇasātagocarā, uddhatā aniyatā asaññatā;
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇa sāta gocarā uddhatā aniyatā asañña tā
translated: “Attached to the five strands of sense pleasure, they are restless, fickle, and unrestrained.

original: Osaranti pamadā pamādinaṃ, loṇatoyavatiyaṃva āpakā.
analyzed: osaranti pamadā pamādinam āpakā
translated: The heedless are overcome by the heedless, like a boat in the ocean by a storm.

original: “Yaṃ naraṃ upalapenti nāriyo, chandasā vā ratiyā dhanena vā;
analyzed: yam naram upalapenti nāriyaḥ chandasā vā ratiyā dhanena vā
translated: “The women who get hold of a man, whether through passion, affection, or wealth,

original: Jātavedasadisampi tādisaṃ, rāgadosavadhiyo dahanti naṃ.
analyzed: jātavedas disam pi tādisam rāga dosava dhiyaḥ dahanti nam
translated: burn him up, even if he is like the fire of the end of the eon, with the flames of passion and hatred.

original: “Aḍḍhaṃ ñatvā purisaṃ mahaddhanaṃ, osaranti sadhanaṃ sahattanā;
analyzed: aḍḍham ñatvā purisam mahat dhanam osaranti sa dhanam sahattanā
translated: “Having seen a man who is rich and prosperous, they descend on the prosperous with their prosperity.

original: Rattacittamativeṭhayanti naṃ, sāla māluvalatāva kānane.
analyzed: ratta cittam ativeṭhayanti nam sāla kānane
translated: They seduce the one with a lustful mind, like a māluva creeper a sāl tree in the forest.

original: “Tā upenti vividhena chandasā, citrabimbamukhiyo alaṅkatā;
analyzed: tāḥ upenti vividhena chandasā citra bimba mukhiyaḥ alaṅkatā
translated: “They approach with various desires, their faces like colorful paintings, adorned.

original: Uhasanti pahasanti nāriyo, sambarova satamāyakovidā.
analyzed: uhasanti pahasanti nāriyaḥ
translated: The women laugh and smile, skilled in deception and deceit.

original: “Jātarūpamaṇimuttabhūsitā, sakkatā patikulesu nāriyo;
analyzed: jātarūpa maṇi mutta bhūsitā sakkatāḥ pati kulesu nāriyaḥ
translated: “Women, adorned with gold and jewels, honored in their husbands’ families,

original: Rakkhitā aticaranti sāmikaṃ, dānavaṃva hadayantarassitā.
analyzed: rakkhitāḥ aticaranti sāmikam dānavam va
translated: Protected, still stray from their husbands, as if they had no fear in their hearts.

original: “Tejavāpi hi naro vicakkhaṇo, sakkato bahujanassa pūjito;
analyzed: tejavā api hi naraḥ vicakkhaṇaḥ sakkataḥ bahu janassa pūjito
translated: “Even a man with splendor and discernment, honored and revered by the multitude,

original: Nārinaṃ vasagato na bhāsati, rāhunā upahatova candimā.
analyzed: nārinam vasagataḥ na bhāsati rāhunā upahata uva candimā
translated: Comes under the sway of women and does not speak, like the moon seized by Rāhu.

original: “Yaṃ kareyya kupito diso disaṃ, duṭṭhacitto vasamāgataṃ ariṃ;
analyzed: yam kareyya kupitaḥ disaḥ disam duṭṭha cittaḥ vasamāgatam arim
translated: “More than the harm a man in anger might do to a foe, a hostile mind under control,

original: Tena bhiyyo byasanaṃ nigacchati, nārinaṃ vasagato apekkhavā.
analyzed: tena bhiyyas byasanam nigacchati nārinam vasagataḥ apekkhavā
translated: A man who is heedful comes to ruin, under the sway of women.

original: “Kesalūnanakhachinnatajjitā, pādapāṇikasadaṇḍatāḷitā;
analyzed: kesa lūna nakha chinna tajjitā pāda pāṇi ka sa daṇḍa tāḷitā
translated: “Women, their hair, eyebrows, and nails plucked out, their feet, hands, and sides bruised,

original: Hīnamevupagatā hi nāriyo, tā ramanti kuṇapeva makkhikā.
analyzed: hīnam eva upagatāḥ hi nāriyaḥ tāḥ ramanti kuṇapā iva makkhikā
translated: Have gone to a lowly state, they delight in a corpse, like flies in filth.

original: “Tā kulesu visikhantaresu vā, rājadhāninigamesu vā puna;
analyzed: tā kulesu visikhantaresu vā rājadhāni nigamesu vā puna
translated: “In families that are scattered or in royal cities and towns,

original: Oḍḍitaṃ namucipāsavākaraṃ, cakkhumā parivajje sukhatthiko.
analyzed: oḍḍitam namuci pāsava ākaram cakkhumā parivajje sukhatthiko
translated: The wise one, seeking happiness, should avoid a woman, like a snake in the house.

original: “Ossajitva kusalaṃ tapoguṇaṃ, yo anariyacaritāni mācari;
analyzed: ossajitva kusalam tapaḥ guṇam yaḥ an ariya caritāni
translated: “Having abandoned the good qualities of austerity, he who does not follow the conduct of a noble one,

original: Devatāhi nirayaṃ nimissati, chedagāmimaṇiyaṃva vāṇijo.
analyzed: devatāhi nirayam nimissati cheda gāmi maṇiyam va vāṇijaḥ
translated: Will be sent to hell by the gods, like a merchant to a jewel mine that is exhausted.

original: “So idha garahito parattha ca, dummatī upahato sakammunā;
analyzed: saḥ idha garahitaḥ parattha ca dummatī upahataḥ sa kammunā
translated: “He is despised here and in the next world, the fool is ruined by his own deeds,

original: Gacchatī aniyato gaḷāgaḷaṃ, duṭṭhagadrabharathova uppathe.
analyzed: gacchatī aniyataḥ gaḷāgaḷam uppathe
translated: He goes to a bad rebirth, like a chariot on a bad road with a bad charioteer.

original: “So upeti nirayaṃ patāpanaṃ, sattisimbalivanañca āyasaṃ;
analyzed: saḥ upeti nirayam patāpanam āyasam
translated: “He goes to the hell of burning, to the forest of swords and the iron-beaked birds,

original: Āvasitvā tiracchānayoniyaṃ, petarājavisayaṃ na muñcati.
analyzed: āvasitvā peta rāja visayam na muñcati
translated: After living in the animal realm, he does not escape the realm of the hungry ghosts.

original: “Dibyakhiḍḍaratiyo ca nandane, cakkavatticaritañca mānuse;
analyzed: ca nandane cakkavatti caritam ca mānuse
translated: “The delights of the gods in Nandana, and the life of a universal monarch among humans,

original: Nāsayanti pamadā pamādinaṃ, duggatiñca paṭipādayanti naṃ.
analyzed: nāsayanti pamadā pamādinam duggatim ca paṭipādayanti naṃ
translated: Are destroyed by heedlessness for the heedless, and lead him to a bad rebirth.

original: “Dibyakhiḍḍaratiyo na dullabhā, cakkavatticaritañca mānuse;
analyzed: dibya khiḍḍa ratiyaḥ na dullabhā cakkavatti caritam ca mānuse
translated: “The delights of the gods in Nandana are not hard to get, and the life of a universal monarch among humans,

original: Soṇṇabyamhanilayā ca accharā, ye caranti pamadāhanatthikā.
analyzed: ca accharāḥ ye caranti
translated: The celestial nymphs who live in golden palaces, those who wander for the sake of heedless ones.

original: “Kāmadhātusamatikkamā gati, rūpadhātuyā bhāvo na dullabho;
analyzed: kāmadhātu samatikkamā gati rūpadhātuyā bhāvaḥ na dullabhaḥ
translated: “The state of overcoming the sense sphere, the existence in the form sphere is not hard to get,

original: Vītarāgavisayūpapatti yā, ye caranti pamadāhanatthikā.
analyzed: yāḥ ye caranti
translated: The rebirth in the realm of the passionless, those who wander for the sake of heedless ones.

original: “Sabbadukkhasamattikkamaṃ sivaṃ, accantamacalitaṃ asaṅkhataṃ;
analyzed: sivam accantam acalitam asaṅkhatam
translated: “The peaceful state of overcoming all suffering, the supreme, unshakable, unconditioned,

original: Nibbutehi sucihī na dullabhaṃ, ye caranti pamadāhanatthikā”’ti.
analyzed: nibbutehi na dullabham ye caranti
translated: It’s not hard for those who’ve crossed the flood, Who live for others, not for self.

original: Tattha sallapeti “sace mayā saddhiṃ sallapessasi, sīsaṃ te pātessāmī”ti vatvā khaggaṃ🔽ādāya ṭhitenāpi, “sallapitamatteyeva taṃ khāditvā jīvitavināsaṃ pāpessāmī”ti dosinā
analyzed: tattha sallapa iti sace mayā saddhim sallapessasi sīsam te pātessāmi iti vatvā khaggam  ādāya ṭhitena api tam khāditvā jīvita vināsam pāpessāmi iti dosinā
translated: “If you talk to me,” he said, “I’ll cut off your head.”🔽He talked to a ghost who was standing there with a sword, thinking, “As soon as he talks to me, I’ll eat him and destroy his life.”

original: hutvā ṭhitenāpi pisācena saddhiṃ sallape. “Upagataṃ ḍaṃsitvā nāsessāmī”ti ṭhitaṃ
analyzed: hutvā ṭhitena api pisācena saddhim sallape upagatam ḍaṃsitvā nāsessāmi iti ṭhitam
translated: He talked to a demon who was standing there, thinking, “As soon as he comes near, I’ll bite him and kill him.”

original: uggatejaṃ uragampi āside. Eko pana hutvā raho ekāya pamadāya na hi ālape. Lokacittamathanāti
analyzed: ekaḥ pana hutvā ekasmai pamadāya na hi ālape
translated: He talked to a snake that was standing there, thinking, “As soon as it comes out, I’ll kill it.” But he didn’t talk to a single woman in private.🔽“The agitators of the world’s mind”: they disturb the minds of the world.

original: lokassa cittaghātikā. Dīpe rakkhasigaṇoti yathā dīpe rakkhasigaṇo manussavesena vāṇije🔽upalāpetvā attano vase gate katvā khādati, evaṃ imāpi pañcahi kāmaguṇehi attano vase
analyzed: lokassa citta ghātikā dīpe rakkhasi gaṇaḥ ti yathā dīpe rakkhasi gaṇaḥ manussa vesena vāṇije  upalāpetvā attanaḥ vase gate katvā khādati evam imā api pañcahi kāmaguṇehi attanaḥ vase
translated: “The hordes of demons in the world”: just as a horde of demons in the world, after enticing merchants with the prospect of wealth,🔽kills them after bringing them under its control, so too do these five strands of sense pleasure bring beings to a great destruction after bringing them under their control. This is the meaning.🔽“The training”: good conduct.

original: katvā satte mahāvināsaṃ pāpentīti attho. Vinayoti ācāro. Saṃvaroti mariyādo. Purisassa
analyzed: katvā satte mahā vināsam pāpenti iti atthaḥ vinayo ti ācāro saṃvaro ti mariyādaḥ purisassa
translated: “Restraint”: the limit.

original: pābhatanti dukkhasambhataṃ dhanaṃ gilanti nāsenti.
analyzed: dukkha sambhatam dhanam gilanti nāsenti
translated: ‘They devour what is gained’: they devour the wealth that has been gained with difficulty.

original: Aniyatāti aniyatacittā. Loṇatoyavatiyanti loṇatoyavantaṃ samuddanti attho. Āpakāti
analyzed: aniyatā ati aniyata cittā loṇatoyavatiyanti loṇatoyavantam
translated: ‘Uncertain’: they are of uncertain mind. ‘With salt water’: the meaning is ‘with the ocean that has salt water’. ‘Rivers’:

original: āpagā, ayameva vā pāṭho. Yathā samuddaṃ nadiyo osaranti, evaṃ pamādinaṃ pamadāti
analyzed: āpagāḥ ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ yathā samuddam nadiyaḥ osaranti evam pamādinam pamadāti
translated: the reading is also ‘Āpagā’. Just as rivers flow into the ocean, so too the heedless flow into heedlessness.

original: attho. Chandasāti pemena. Ratiyāti pañcakāmaguṇaratiyā. Dhanena vāti dhanahetu vā.
analyzed: chandasā ati pemena ratiyā iti pañca kāmaguṇa ratiyā dhanena vā ati dhana hetu vā
translated: ‘By love’: by affection. ‘By delight’: by delight in the five strands of sense pleasure. ‘For wealth’s sake’: or ‘because of wealth’.

original: Jātavedasadisanti guṇasampattiyā aggimiva jalitampi. Rāgadosavadhiyoti kāmarāgadosehi🔽vadhikā. Rāgadosagatiyotipi pāṭho. Osarantīti dhanagahaṇatthāya madhuravacanena taṃ🔽bandhantiyo upagacchanti. Sadhananti sadhanā. Ayameva vā pāṭho, vatthālaṅkāratthāya
analyzed: guṇa sampattiyā aggim iva jalitam pi kāma rāga dosehi  vadhikāḥ madhura vacanena tam  bandhantiyaḥ upagacchanti sadhananti sadhanāḥ ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ vattha alaṅkāra tthāya
translated: ‘Like the fire’: though it burns with the excellence of its qualities, like a fire. ‘With greed and hate as its limit’:

original: kiñci attano dhanaṃ datvāpi osarantīti attho. Sahattanāti attabhāvena saddhiṃ attabhāvampi
analyzed: kiñci attanaḥ dhanam da tvā api osaranti iti attho sahattanā ati atta bhāvena saddhim atta bhāvam pi
translated: the reading is also ‘with greed and hate as its end’. ‘Flow’: they approach, binding him with sweet words in order to take his wealth. ‘With property’: the reading is also ‘with property’. The meaning is that they flow, giving him some of their own wealth even, for the sake of his property and ornaments. ‘With themselves’:🔽together with their own bodies.

original: tasseva pariccajantiyo viya honti. Ativeṭhayantīti dhanagahaṇatthāya ativiya veṭhenti pīḷenti.
analyzed: tassa iva pariccajantiyaḥ viya honti ativeṭhayanti iti dhana gahaṇa atthāya ativiya veṭhenti pīḷenti
translated: They are as if they were giving up that very thing. They torment: they torment and oppress him excessively in order to take his wealth.

original: Vividhena chandasāti nānāvidhena ākārena. Citrabimbamukhiyoti alaṅkāravasena citrasarīrā
analyzed: vividhena chandasā ati nānāvidhena ākārena alaṅkāra vasena citra sarīrā
translated: With various desires: with various kinds of wishes. With faces like painted masks: with bodies adorned with various ornaments,

original: citramukhiyo hutvā. Uhasantīti mahāhasitaṃ hasanti. Pahasantīti mandahasitaṃ hasanti.
analyzed: citra mukhiyaḥ hutvā uhasanti iti mahā hasitam hasanti pahasanti iti manda hasitam hasanti
translated: with faces like painted masks. They laugh: they laugh with loud laughter. They giggle: they laugh with gentle laughter.

original: Sambarovāti māyākārapuriso viya asurindo viya ca. Dānavaṃva hadayantarassitāti yathā
analyzed: māyākāra purisaḥ viya asurindaḥ viya ca yathā
translated: They deceive: they deceive like a magician or like the lord of the asuras. They are like a demoness in the heart’s core: just as

original: “kuto nu āgacchatha, bho, tayo janā”ti karaṇḍakajātake hadayantaranissitā antoudaragatāpi
analyzed: kutas nu āgacchatha bho karaṇḍaka jātake hadaya antara nissitā antar udara gatā api
translated: in the Karaṇḍa Jātaka the demoness in the heart’s core, in the belly,

original: dānavaṃ aticari, evaṃ aticaranti. Arakkhitā hetāti dīpeti. Na bhāsatīti na virocati
analyzed: dānavam aticari evam aticaranti a rakkhitā hetā ati dīpeti na bhāsati iti na virocati
translated: went beyond the demoness, so they go beyond. They are not protected: he shows that they are not protected. He does not shine: he does not shine

original: haritacalomasakassapakusarājāno viya. Tenāti tamhā amittena katā byasanā atirekataraṃ
analyzed: viya tena ati tamhā amittena katāḥ byasanāḥ atirekataram
translated: like the kings of the Harīta, Caloma, and Sakkapaka birds. By that: by that misfortune made by that enemy, a still greater

original: byasananti attho. Apekkhavāti sataṇho.
analyzed: byasanam ti atthaḥ apekkhavā ati sa taṇhaḥ
translated: misfortune, is the meaning. With expectation: with craving.

original: Kesalūnanakhachinnatajjitāti ākaḍḍhitvā lūnakesā nakhehi chinnagattā tajjitā pādādīhi
analyzed: kesa lūna nakha chinna tajjitā ati ākaḍḍhitvā lūna kesā nakhehi chinna gattā tajjitā pāda ādīhi
translated: Kesalunakhachinna-tajjitāti ākaḍḍhitvā lūnakesā nakhehi chinnagattā tajjitā pādādīhi

original: ca tāḷitāva hutvā. Yo kilesavasena etepi vippakāre karoti, tādisaṃ hīnameva upagatā
analyzed: ca hutvā yaḥ kilesa vasena ete api vippakāre karoti tādisam hīnam eva upagatā
translated: ca tāḷitāva hutvā. Yo kilesavasena etepi vippakāre karoti, tādisaṃ hīnameva upagatā

original: nāriyo ramanti, na ete vippakāre pariharanti, madhurasamācāre kiṃkāraṇā tā na ramanti.
analyzed: nāriyaḥ ramanti na ete vippakāre pariharanti madhura samācāre kiṃkāraṇā tāḥ na ramanti
translated: nāriyo ramanti, na ete vippakāre pariharanti, madhurasamācāre kiṃkāraṇā tā na ramanti.

original: Kuṇapeva makkhikāti yasmā jegucchahatthikuṇapādimhi makkhikā viya tā hīneyeva ramantīti
analyzed: kuṇapā iva makkhikā ati yasmai jeguccha hatthi kuṇapa ādimhi makkhikāḥ viya tāḥ ramanti iti
translated: Kuṇapeva makkhikāti yasmā jegucchahatthikuṇapādimhi makkhikā viya tā hīneyeva ramantīti

original: attho. Oḍḍitanti na etā itthiyo nāma, atha kho imesu ṭhānesu namucino kilesamārassa
analyzed: na etāḥ itthiyaḥ nāma atha kho imesu ṭhānesu namucinaḥ kilesa mārassa
translated: attho. Oḍḍitanti na etā itthiyo nāma, atha kho imesu ṭhānesu namucino kilesamārassa

original: migapakkhigahaṇatthaṃ luddakehi oḍḍitaṃ pāsañca vākarañcāti maññamāno paññācakkhumā
analyzed: miga pakkhi gahaṇa attham luddakehi oḍḍitam pāsam ca vākaram ca ati maññamānaḥ paññā cakkhumā
translated: migapakkhigahaṇatthaṃ luddakehi oḍḍitaṃ pāsañca vākarañcāti maññamāno paññācakkhumā

original: puriso dibbamānusikena sukhena atthiko parivajjeyya.
analyzed: purisaḥ dibba mānusikena sukhena atthikaḥ parivajjeyya
translated: puriso dibbamānusikena sukhena atthiko parivajjeyya.

original: Ossajitvāti devamanussesu mahāsampattidāyakaṃ tapoguṇaṃ chaḍḍetvā. Yoti yo puriso
analyzed: ossajitvā ati deva manussesu mahā sampatti dāyakam tapo guṇam chaḍḍetvā yaḥ ti yaḥ puriso
translated: Ossajitvāti devamanussesu mahāsampattidāyakaṃ tapoguṇaṃ chaḍḍetvā. Yoti yo puriso

original: anariyesu aparisuddhesu kāmaguṇesu kāmaraticaritāni ācarati. Devatāhi nirayaṃ nimissatīti
analyzed: anariyesu a parisuddhesu kāma guṇesu kāma rati caritāni ācarati devatāhi nirayam nimissati iti
translated: The gods will send him to hell.

original: so devalokena parivattitvā nirayaṃ gaṇhissati. Chedagāmimaṇiyaṃva vāṇijoti yathā
analyzed: saḥ deva lokena nirayam gaṇhissati cheda gāmi maṇiyam vā vāṇijaḥ iti yathā
translated: He will be turned away from the world of the gods and will be taken to hell. Like a merchant who takes a gem that breaks on impact.

original: bālavāṇijo satasahassagghabhaṇḍaṃ datvā chedagāmimaṇikaṃ gaṇhāti, tathārūpo ayaṃ🔽hotīti attho. Soti so itthīnaṃ vasaṃ gato. Aniyatoti ettakaṃ nāma kālaṃ apāyesu paccissatīti
analyzed: bāla vāṇijaḥ sata sahassa ggha bhaṇḍam da tvā cheda gāmi maṇikam gaṇhāti tathārūpaḥ ayam  hoti iti attho saḥ ti saḥ itthīnam vasam gataḥ aniyataḥ ti ettakam nāma kālam apāyesu paccissati iti
translated: As a foolish merchant, having given a hundred thousand for a gem, takes a gem that breaks on impact, so is this one.🔽The meaning is: he is like that. He, gone under the control of women.🔽Uncertain: uncertain as to how long he will be in the states of loss.

original: aniyato. Gaḷāgaḷanti devalokā vā manussalokā vā gaḷitvā apāyameva gacchatīti attho.
analyzed: aniyataḥ gaḷāgaḷanti deva lokāḥ vā manussa lokāḥ vā gaḷitvā apāyam eva gacchati iti attho
translated: He goes from one place to another: the meaning is, he goes to the states of loss, having fallen from the world of the gods or the human world.🔽How? Like a cart with a bad axle on a bad road.

original: [537] 5. Mahāsutasomajātakavaṇṇanā

analyzed: sutvā ajja mama gamanam bahu pakāram bhavissati mahā dhamma desanā pavattissati iti  ñatvā anopamāya buddha līlāya dhammasabham gantvā vara paññatta āsane nisīditvā

The Teacher related the following

analyzed: tam eva maggam paṭipajji atha sutasomaḥ maggam gantvā nagara dvāre sālāya phalake vissamatthāya  nisīdi brahmadatta kumāraḥ api gantvā tena saddhim eka phalake nisīdi atha nam sutasomaḥ

Where do you come from?” “From Benares.”

analyzed: tassa sabbam ācikkhi te ubho pi mayam khattiyāḥ eka ācariyassa iva santike sippu gahaṇa tthāya

analyzed: nipphattim pāpuṇi saḥ aññassa santikam a gantvā sahāyaḥ mā iti brahmadattassa kumārassa iva  santikam gantvā tassa piṭṭhi ācariyaḥ hutvā sippam sikkhāpesi itaresam pi anukkamena
translated: he soon became proficient. He did not go to anyone else, but went to Prince Brahmadatta, his friend,🔽and became his tutor, teaching him the craft. The others also, in due course,

analyzed: sippam niṭṭhitam te anuyogam da tvā ācariyam vanditvā sutasomam parivāretvā nikkhamiṃsu
translated: completed their training. They gave their teacher his fee, paid homage to him, and left, surrounding Sutasoma.

analyzed: atha ne sutasomaḥ maggantare ṭhatvā uyyojentaḥ tumhe attanaḥ attanaḥ pitūnam sippam
translated: Then Suta-soma, standing on the road, sent them away, saying: “You learn your father’s craft,🔽

original: “Kiṃ, ācariyā”ti? “Pakkhadivasesu uposathikā hutvā mā ghātaṃ kareyyāthā”ti. Te “sādhū”ti🔽sampaṭicchiṃsu. Te sabbepi attano🔽attano janapadaṃ gantvā pitūnaṃ sippaṃ dassetvā rajjesu patiṭṭhāya patiṭṭhitabhāvañceva🔽ovāde vattanabhāvañca jānāpetuṃ paṇṇākārena saddhiṃ paṇṇāni pahiṇiṃsu. Mahāsatto
analyzed: kim ācariyā ati pakkha divasesu uposathikāḥ hutvā mā ghātam kareyyātha ati te sādhu uti  bodhisattaḥ api aṅga vijjā pāṭhaka ttā anāgate bārāṇasiyam brahmadatta kumāram  nissāya mahā bhayam uppajjissati iti ñatvā te evam ovaditvā uyyojesi te sabbe api attanaḥ  attanaḥ janapadam gantvā pitūnam sippam dassetvā rajjesu patiṭṭhāya patiṭṭhita bhāvam ca iva  ovāde vattana bhāvañca jānā petum paṇṇa ākārena saddhim paṇṇāni pahiṇiṃsu mahāsatto
translated: “What is it, teacher?” “On the days of the full moon and the new moon, when you are observing the fast, do not kill living beings.” They agreed to do so, saying, “Very well.”

original: taṃ pavattiṃ sutvā “appamattāva hothā”ti paṇṇāni paṭipesesi.
analyzed: tam pavattim sutvā appamattāḥ ava hotha iti paṇṇāni paṭipesesi
translated: The Bodhisatta, knowing by his knowledge of the parts of the body that in the future a great calamity would befall the city of Benares through Prince Brahmadatta, gave them this advice and dismissed them. They all went to their own kingdoms, and after showing their fathers their skill in arms, they were established in their kingdoms. And when they were established, they sent messages to the king, telling him of their establishment and of their observance of his advice. The king, hearing of this, sent them messages in return, saying, “Be careful.”

original: Tesu bārāṇasirājā vinā maṃsena bhattaṃ na bhuñjati. Uposathadivasatthāyapissa maṃsaṃ
analyzed: tesu bārāṇasi rājā vinā maṃsena bhattam na bhuñjati uposatha divasa thāya api ssa maṃsam
translated: The king of Bārāṇasī would not eat his food without meat. So on the day of the fast he had meat set aside for him.

original: gahetvā ṭhapesi. Athekadivasaṃ evaṃ ṭhapitamaṃsaṃ bhattakārakassa pamādena rājagehe
analyzed: gahetvā ṭhapesi atha eka divasam evam ṭhapita maṃsam bhatta kārakassa pamādena rājagehe
translated: One day the meat that had been set aside was eaten by a dog of the king’s household through the negligence of the cook who was preparing the king’s food.

original: koleyyakasunakhā khādiṃsu. Bhattakārako taṃ maṃsaṃ aditvā kahāpaṇamuṭṭhiṃ ādāya carantopi
analyzed: koleyyaka sunakhā khādiṃsu bhatta kārako tam maṃsam aditvā kahāpaṇa muṭṭhim ādāya carantaḥ api
translated: The cook, not having any meat, took a handful of coins and went about trying to get some meat.

original: maṃsaṃ uppādetuṃ asakkonto “sace amaṃsakabhattaṃ upanāmessāmi, jīvitaṃ me natthi,
analyzed: maṃsam uppādetum a sakkontaḥ sace a maṃsaka bhattam upanāmessāmi jīvitam me natthi
translated: But he was unable to obtain any. He thought, “If I present the king with food that does not contain meat, I shall lose my life.

original: kiṃ nu kho karissāmī”ti cintetvā “attheso upāyo”ti vikāle āmakasusānaṃ gantvā muhuttamatassa🔽purisassa ūrumaṃsaṃ āharitvā supakkaṃ pacitvā bhattaṃ upanāmesi. Rañño maṃsakhaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: kim nu kho karissāmi iti cintetvā attha iso upāyaḥ ti vikāle āmaka susānam gantvā muhutta matassa  purisassa ūru maṃsam āharitvā su pakkam pacitvā bhattam upanāmesi raññaḥ maṃsa khaṇḍam
translated: What shall I do?” Then he thought, “There is a way out of this.” At an improper time he went to the charnel ground and brought away the thigh of a man who had recently died.

original: jivhagge ṭhapitamattameva satta rasaharaṇisahassāni phari, sakalasarīraṃ khobhetvā
analyzed: jivhagge ṭhapita mattam eva satta rasaharaṇi sahassāni sakala sarīram khobhetvā
translated: He cooked it well and presented it to the king. As soon as a piece of the meat was placed in the king’s mouth, it caused the seven hundred flavors to appear, and it thrilled his entire body.

original: aṭṭhāsi. Kiṃkāraṇā? Pubbe cassa sevanatāya. So kira atītānantare attabhāve yakkho
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi kiṃkāraṇā pubbe ca ssa sevana tāya so kira atīta anantare atta bhāve yakkho
translated: Why was this? Because in the past he had been accustomed to it. It seems that in a previous existence he had been a yakkha.

original: hutvā bahuṃ manussamaṃsaṃ khāditapubbo, tenassa taṃ piyaṃ ahosi. So “sacāhaṃ tuṇhīyeva🔽bhuñjissāmi, na me ayaṃ imaṃ maṃsaṃ kathessatī”ti cintetvā saha kheḷena bhūmiyaṃ
analyzed: hutvā bahum manussa maṃsam khādita pubbaḥ tena assa tam piyam ahosi saḥ sacā aham  bhuñjissāmi na me ayam imam maṃsam kathessati iti cintetvā saha kheḷena bhūmiyam
translated: and he had eaten much human flesh in the past. Therefore he liked it. He thought, “If I eat it silently, he will not tell me what it is.” So he spat it out on the ground with a loud noise.

original: pātesi. “Niddosaṃ, deva, khādāhī”ti vutte manusse paṭikkamāpetvā “ahametassa niddosabhāvaṃ🔽jānāmi, kiṃ nāmetaṃ maṃsa”nti pucchi. “Purimadivasesu paribhogamaṃsameva, devā”ti.
analyzed: pātesi niddosam deva khādāhi iti vutte manusse paṭikkamāpetvā aham etassa niddosa bhāvam  jānāmi kim nāma etam maṃsanti pucchi purima divasesu paribhoga maṃsam eva deva ati
translated: When the king said, “Eat it without fear,” he sent the men away and said, “I know whether it is without fear or not. What is this meat?”🔽“It is meat that was left over from yesterday, your majesty.”

original: “Nanu aññasmiṃ kāle ayaṃ raso natthī”ti? “Ajja supakkaṃ, devā”ti. “Nanu pubbepi evameva🔽pacasī”ti. Atha naṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ ñatvā “sabhāvaṃ kathehi, no ce kathesi, jīvitaṃ te🔽natthī”ti āha. So abhayaṃ yācitvā yathābhūtaṃ kathesi. Rājā “mā saddamakāsi, pakatiyā
analyzed: nanu aññasmim kāle ayam raso natthi iti ajja su pakkam deva ati nanu pubbe pi evam eva  pacasi iti atha nam tuṇhībhūtam ñatvā sabhāvam kathehi no ce kathesi jīvitam te  na atthi iti āha saḥ abhayam yācitvā yathābhūtam kathesi rājā mā saddam akāsi pakatiyā
translated: “Was there no flavor in it at other times?” “It was well cooked today, your majesty.”🔽“But did it not cook in the same way before?” Then, when he was silent, the king knew that he was guilty. He said, “Tell the truth. If you do not, you will lose your life.”

original: pacanakamaṃsaṃ tvaṃ khāditvā mayhaṃ manussamaṃsameva pacāhī”ti āha. “Nanu dukkaraṃ,
analyzed: pacanaka maṃsam tvam khāditvā mayham manussa maṃsam eva pacāhi iti āha nanu dukkaram
translated: He asked for immunity and told the truth. The king said, “Do not make a sound. You have eaten meat that was cooked in the ordinary way. Cook human flesh for me.”🔽“Is it not difficult to obtain?”

original: devā”ti? “Mā bhāyi, na dukkara”nti. “Nibaddhaṃ kuto labhissāmi, devā”ti? “Nanu bandhanāgāre
analyzed: devāti mā bhāyi na nibaddham kutas labhissāmi devāti nanu bandhanāgāre
translated: “How can I do that, your majesty?” “Don’t be afraid. It’s not difficult.” “But where can I get a regular supply, your majesty?” “In the prison.

original: bahū manussā”ti. So tato paṭṭhāya tathā akāsi.
analyzed: bahū manussā ati so tato paṭṭhāya tathā akāsi
translated: “How can I do that, your majesty?” “Don’t be afraid. It’s not difficult.” “But where can I get one, your majesty?” “Aren’t there many people in the prison?” From then on, that’s what he did.

original: Aparabhāge bandhanāgāre manussesu khīṇesu “idāni kiṃ karissāmi, devā”ti āha. “Antarāmagge
analyzed: aparabhāge bandhanāgāre manussesu khīṇesu idāni kim karissāmi deva ati āha antarāmagge
translated: Later, when there were no more people in the prison, he said, “What should I do now, your majesty?” “Throw a thousand-piece chest on the road

original: sahassabhaṇḍikaṃ khipitvā yo taṃ gaṇhāti, taṃ ‘coro’ti gahetvā mārehī”ti āha. So🔽tathā akāsi. Aparabhāge rājabhayena sahassabhaṇḍikaṃ olokentampi adisvā “idāni kiṃ
analyzed: sahassa bhaṇḍikam khipitvā yaḥ tam gaṇhāti tam coro ti gahetvā mārehi iti āha saḥ  tathā akāsi aparabhāge rāja bhayena sahassabhaṇḍikam olokentam pi a disvā idāni kim
translated: and have the one who picks it up arrested as a thief.” He did as he was told.

original: karissāmī”ti āha. “Yadā bherivelāya nagaraṃ ākulaṃ hoti, tadā tvaṃ pana ekasmiṃ gharasandhimhi
analyzed: karissāmi iti āha yadā bheri velāya nagaram ākulam hoti tadā tvam pana ekasmin ghara sandhimhi
translated: Later, when there was no one who even looked at the chest out of fear of the king, he said, “What should I do now, your majesty?” “When the city is crowded at the time of the Bheris,

analyzed: vā vīthiyam vā catukke vā ṭhatvā manusse māretvā maṃsam gaṇhāhi iti saḥ tatas paṭṭhāya

original: tathā katvā thūlamaṃsaṃ ādāya gacchati. Tesu tesu ṭhānesu kaḷevarāni dissanti. Mama
analyzed: tathā katvā thūla maṃsam ādāya gacchati tesu tesu ṭhānesu kaḷevarāni dissanti mama
translated: he did just that, and he went away carrying a large amount of flesh. Here and there, corpses were seen.

original: mātā na paññāyati, mama pitā na paññāyati, mama bhātā bhaginī ca na paññāyati, manussānaṃ🔽paridevanasaddo sūyati. Nāgarā bhītatasitā “ime manusse sīho nu kho khādati, byaggho
analyzed: mātā na paññāyati mama pitā na paññāyati mama bhātā bhaginī ca na paññāyati manussānaṃ  paridevana saddaḥ sūyati nāgarāḥ ime manusse sīhaḥ nu kho khādati byagghaḥ
translated: “I do not know my mother, I do not know my father, I do not know my brother or sister, I do not know any human being.

original: nu kho khādati, yakkho nu kho khādatī”ti olokentā pahāramukhaṃ disvā “eko manussakhādako🔽coro ime khādatī”ti maññanti. Mahājanā rājaṅgaṇe sannipatitvā upakkosiṃsu. Rājā “kiṃ,
analyzed: nu kho khādati yakkhaḥ nu kho khādati iti olokentā pahāra mukham disvā ekaḥ manussa khādako  coraḥ ime khādati iti maññanti mahājanāḥ rājaṅgaṇe sannipatitvā upakkosiṃsu rājā kim
translated: “The sound of people lamenting is heard. The citizens, frightened and terrified, are looking on, saying: ‘Are these people being eaten by a lion? Are they being eaten by a tiger? Are they being eaten by a demon?’ Seeing the face of the one who is striking, they think: ‘A human-eating thief is eating these people.’

original: tātā”ti pucchi. “Deva imasmiṃ nagare manussakhādako coro atthi, taṃ gaṇhāpethā”ti
analyzed: tāta ati pucchi deva imasmin nagare manussa khādakaḥ coraḥ atthi tam gaṇhāpetha ati
translated: A great crowd has gathered in the royal court and is complaining. The king asks: ‘What is it, gentlemen?’ They say: ‘Your Majesty, there is a human-eating thief in this city. Please apprehend him.’

original: āhaṃsu. “Ahaṃ kathaṃ taṃ jānissāmi, kiṃ ahaṃ nagaraṃ rakkhantopi carāmī”ti.🔽Mahājanā “rājā nagarena anatthiko, kāḷahatthisenāpatissa ācikkhissāmā”ti gantvā tassa
analyzed: āhaṃsu aham katham tam jānissāmi kim aham nagaram rakkhantaḥ api carāmi iti  mahājanāḥ rājā nagarena anatthikaḥ kāḷahatthi senāpatissa ācikkhissāma ati gantvā tassa
translated: He says: ‘How can I know that? Am I wandering about protecting the city?’

original: taṃ kathetvā “coraṃ pariyesituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti vadiṃsu. So “sādhu sattāhaṃ āgametha,
analyzed: tam kathetvā coram pariyesitum vaṭṭati iti vadiṃsu saḥ sādhu sattāham āgametha
translated: The great crowd says: ‘The king is not concerned with the city. We will inform the general of the black army.’ They go and tell him what happened, saying: ‘It is necessary to search for the thief.’ He says: ‘Very well, wait seven days.

original: pariyesitvā coraṃ dassāmī”ti mahājane uyyojetvā purise āṇāpesi, “tātā, nagare kira
analyzed: pariyesitvā coram dassāmi iti mahājane uyyojetvā purise āṇāpesi tāta nagare kira
translated: “After searching, I will show the thief,” and after sending away the great crowd, he ordered the men, “Gentlemen, it seems that in the city

analyzed: manussa khādakaḥ coraḥ atthi tumhe tesu tesu ṭhānesu nilīyitvā tam gaṇhatha ati te
translated: “I will search for the thief and show him to you.” He sent out a large crowd of people and ordered his men, “Men, it is said that a man-eating thief is in the city. You must hide here and there and seize him.”

original: “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā tato paṭṭhāya nagaraṃ pariggaṇhanti. Bhattakārakopi ekasmiṃ🔽gharasandhimhi sampaṭicchanno hutvā ekaṃ itthiṃ māretvā ghanaghanamaṃsaṃ ādāya pacchiyaṃ🔽pūretuṃ ārabhi. Atha naṃ te purisā gahetvā pothetvā pacchābāhaṃ bandhitvā “gahito🔽manussakhādako coro”ti mahāsaddaṃ kariṃsu. Mahājano taṃ parivāresi. Atha naṃ suṭṭhu🔽bandhitvā maṃsapacchiṃ gīvāya bandhitvā ādāya senāpatissa dassesuṃ. Senāpati taṃ
analyzed: sādhu iti sampaṭicchitvā tatas paṭṭhāya nagaram pariggaṇhanti bhatta kārakaḥ api ekasmin  ghara sandhimhi sampaṭicchannaḥ hutvā ekam itthim māretvā ghana ghana maṃsam ādāya  pūretum ārabhi atha nam te purisāḥ gahetvā pothetvā pacchābāham bandhitvā gahitaḥ  manussa khādako coro ti mahā saddam kariṃsu mahā janaḥ tam parivāresi atha nam suṭṭhu  bandhitvā maṃsa pacchim gīvāya bandhitvā ādāya senāpatissa dassesum senāpati tam
translated: They agreed, saying, “Very well,” and from then on they searched the city. The cook,

original: disvā “kiṃ nu kho esa imaṃ maṃsaṃ khādati, udāhu aññena maṃsena missetvā vikkiṇāti,
analyzed: disvā kim nu kho esaḥ imam maṃsam khādati udāhu aññena maṃsena missetvā vikkiṇāti
translated: concealed in a crack in the wall, killed a woman, took the fresh meat, and began to fill his basket. Then those men seized him, beat him, tied his hands behind his back, and made a great clamor, saying, “We have caught the man-eating thief!” A large crowd surrounded him. Then, having tied him up well, they tied the basket of meat around his neck, took him, and showed him to the general. When the general saw him, he thought, “Why does he eat this meat? Or does he mix it with other meat and sell it?

original: udāhu aññassa vacanena māretī”ti cintetvā tamatthaṃ pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: udāhu aññassa vacanena māreti iti cintetvā tam attham pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: or does one kill at the bidding of another?” Thinking thus, he asked the following question:

original: “Kasmā tuvaṃ rasaka edisāni, karosi kammāni sudāruṇāni;
analyzed: kasmā tuvam rasake edisāni karosi kammāni su dāruṇāni
translated: “Why, O Rasaka, do you commit such terrible deeds?

analyzed: hanāsi itthī purise ca mūḍhaḥ maṃsassa hetu dhanassa
translated: You kill women and men, O fool, for the sake of flesh and for the sake of money.”

original: Tattha rasakāti bhattakāraṇaṃ ālapati.
analyzed: tattha rasakāti bhatta kāraṇam ālapati
translated: Here, Rasaka is addressed because of his being a cook.

analyzed: itas param uttāna sambandhāni vacana paṭivacanāni pāḷi vasena iva veditabbāni
translated: The rest of the questions and answers should be understood according to the text of the sutta.

original: “Na attahetū na dhanassa kāraṇā, na puttadārassa sahāyañātinaṃ;
analyzed: na atta hetū na dhanassa kāraṇā na putta dārassa sahāya ñātinam
translated: “Not for my own sake, not for the sake of money, not for the sake of wife and children, friends and relatives,

analyzed: bhattā ca me bhagavā bhūmipālaḥ saḥ khādati maṃsam bhadantedisam

analyzed: sace tuvam bhattuḥ atthe payuttaḥ karosi kammāni su dāruṇāni
translated: “If you are employed by your master, and you commit such terrible deeds,

analyzed: tathā karissāmi aham bhadante yathā tuvam bhāsasi kāḷahatthi
translated: “I will do as you say, O good man, as you say, O black elephant.

analyzed: pātova antepuram pāpuṇitvā vakkhāmi te rājino sammukhe tanti

analyzed: musā bhaṇati iti vīmaṃsantaḥ evam āha tattha su dāruṇāni iti manussa ghāta kammāni sammukhe
translated: Herein, Blessed One is a term of respect. If you will is what he said in order to test him, thinking: “Is he telling the truth or is he lying through fear of death? ” Herein, very terrible is the deed of man-slaughter.🔽In front of is in front of the king.
