translated: So he consented and spoke the first stanza:

analyzed: āgacchissati idāni āgacchassati iti nisinnaḥ uva tam rattim vītināmetvā ajjapi rasakaḥ

translated: All the inhabitants of the city, extending for three leagues on every side, will go about keeping guard. If the guard is not well posted,

analyzed: migājinam uyyānam gantvā maṅgala pokkharaṇim otaritvā ṭhassāmi iti cintetvā tattha
translated: I will go to the Migadāya pleasure garden, enter the auspicious lotus-tank, and remain there.” So saying, he went there,

analyzed: rājā api bhutta pāta rāsaḥ alaṅkata hatthi kkhandha vara gataḥ caturaṅginiyā senāya

original: Atha naṃ porisādo āha –

translated: Then Porisāda said:

translated: “I do not believe that a man who has escaped from the jaws of death

translated: Will return to the hand of his enemy. You have not come near me, best of the Kora people.

original: “Mutto tuvaṃ porisādassa hatthā, gantvā sakaṃ mandiraṃ kāmakāmī;
analyzed: muttaḥ tuvam porisādassa hatthā gantvā sakam mandiram kāma kāmī
translated: “You are free from the hand of Porisāda. Go to your own house and enjoy yourself as you wish.

original: Madhuraṃ piyaṃ jīvitaṃ laddha rāja, kuto tuvaṃ ehisi me sakāsa”nti.
analyzed: madhuram piyam jīvitam rāja kutas tuvam ehisi me sakāsanti
translated: You have gained a sweet and pleasant life, O King. How will you come to me again?”

analyzed: tattha sukhīti sukha ppattaḥ hutvā maccu mukhā pamuttaḥ ti mādisassa corassa hatthato

analyzed: mutta tāya maraṇa mukhāḥ muttaḥ nāma hutvā amitta hattham punar āvajeyya āgaccheyya aham

translated: I would not believe your word. O best of the Kora people, you did not come to me. Released,

translated: Sutasoma, you were released from the hands of Porisāda. To your own

analyzed: kāma kāmī iti kāmam kāmayamānaḥ piyam jīvitam labhitvā me mama

original: santike kuto kena nāma kāraṇena ehisi.

translated: For what reason?”

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto sīho viya asambhito āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā mahā sattaḥ sīhaḥ viya asambhitaḥ āha
translated: Having heard that, the Great Being, fearless like a lion, said:

original: “Mataṃ vareyya parisuddhasīlo, na jīvitaṃ garahito pāpadhammo;
analyzed: matam vareyya parisuddha sīlaḥ na jīvitam garahito pāpa dhammo
translated: “One of pure virtue would prefer death, not a life of blame and evil deeds.

translated: “Even if the wind were to blow away the mountain, and the moon and sun were to fall,

analyzed: na tu eva aham rāja musā
translated: But I, O King, would never tell a lie.”

original: Tattha mataṃ vareyyāti porisāda yo naro parisuddhasīlo jīvitahetu aṇumattampi pāpaṃ🔽na karoti, sīlasampanno hutvā vareyya taṃ maraṇaṃ iccheyya, garahito pāpadhammo taṃ
analyzed: tattha matam porisāda yaḥ naraḥ parisuddha sīlaḥ jīvita hetu aṇumattam pi pāpam  na karoti sīla sampannaḥ hutvā vareyya tam maraṇam iccheyya gara hito pāpa dhammo tam
translated: Herein, the best of deaths is this: a man of pure virtue, who for the sake of life🔽Would not commit the slightest evil,

analyzed: tam naram evarūpam duggatīhi tam alikam na tāyate sace ipi vātaḥ girim āvaheyya ati samma  porisāda tayā saddhim eka ācariya kule sikkhitaḥ evarūpaḥ sahāyakaḥ hutvā aham jīvita hetu
translated: That man such as this is not protected from the states of loss by that lie. “Even if the wind should carry off the mountain,”

analyzed: musā na kathemi kim na saddahasi sace puratthima ādi bhedaḥ vātaḥ uṭṭhāya mahantam girim
translated: O Porisada, I, who have been trained in the same teacher’s discipline as you, and who have become a friend such as this, would not tell a lie for the sake of life. Why do you not believe me? “Even if the wind should arise from the east, west, north, or south,”

original: tūlapicuṃ viya ākāse āvaheyya, cando ca sūriyo ca attano attano vimānena saddhiṃ
analyzed: tūla picum viya ākāse āvaheyya cando ca sūriyo ca attanaḥ attanaḥ vimānena saddhim
translated: and could make a tuft of cotton fly through the air, and could make the moon and sun

analyzed: chamā pathaviyam pateyyum sabbā api najjo pati sotam vajeyyum bho porisāda evarūpam

analyzed: janehi vuttam na tu eva tam saddahitabbam  evam vutte pi saḥ na atha bodhisattaḥ ayam mayham na saddahati sapathena api

analyzed: nam saddahāpessāmi iti cintetvā samma porisāda khandhato tāva mama otārehi sa patham

translated: The meaning is: “If you wish, O Porisāda, I will swear by the sword and the spear that I will not be reborn in a khattiya family which is protected by such weapons as these.

analyzed: aññam vā yam icchasi tam sapatham pi te samma aham karomi yathā aham tayā pamuttaḥ

translated: “Then go, great king, if you do not come, the sacrifice will not be performed, the gods will not accept it without you, do not cause an obstacle to my sacrifice.” Thus he sent the Great Being away.

analyzed: saḥ rāhu mukhā mutta candaḥ viya nāga balaḥ thāma sampanno khippam eva nagaram sampāpuṇi

analyzed: senāpissa sutasomaḥ rājā paṇḍitaḥ madhura dhamma kathiko ekam dve kathā kathetum labhanto  porisādam dametvā sīha mukhāḥ mutta matta vāraṇaḥ viya āgamissati ime rājānam porisādassa
translated: His army thought: “King Su­tasoma is wise, a preacher of the sweet Dhamma, if he gets to speak one or two words🔽he will tame Porisāda and return like a mad elephant released from a lion’s mouth, the people will blame us, saying: ‘They have given the king to Porisāda

analyzed: da tvā āgatā ati mahā janaḥ garahissati iti cintetvā bahi nagareya iva khandhāvāram katvā

analyzed: paṭisanthāram katvā porisādena mayham dukkaram katam tathārūpaḥ
translated: “Porisāda has done what is difficult for my parents, for me,

analyzed: nāma caṇḍaḥ sāhasikaḥ porisādaḥ mama dhamma katham sutvā mam vissajjesi iti vutte rājānam
translated: “The king is a fierce and violent man, but he has released me after hearing my discourse on the Law.” When the king heard this, he had the Brahman

analyzed: alaṅkaritvā hatthi khandham āropetvā parivāretvā nagaram pāvisi tam disvā sabbe nāgarā tussiṃsu
translated: adorned with ornaments, mounted him on the back of an elephant, and entered the city with him surrounded by an escort. When the people saw him, they were delighted.

original: Sopi dhammagarutāya dhammasoṇḍatāya mātāpitaro adisvāva “pacchāpi ne passissāmī”ti🔽rājanivesanaṃ pavisitvā rājāsane nisīditvā brāhmaṇaṃ pakkosāpetvā massukammādīnissa
analyzed: saḥ api dhamma garu tāya dhamma soṇḍa tāya mātā pitaro a disvā ava pacchā api ne passissāmi iti  rāja nivesanam pavisitvā rāja āsane nisīditvā brāhmaṇam pakkosāpetvā massu kamma ādīni issa
translated: The king, out of respect for the Law, and because he was a lover of the Law, without even asking about his parents, said to himself, “I will see them later,”🔽and entered the palace. He sat down on the royal throne, sent for the Brahman, and ordered him to have his hair and beard cut,

original: āṇāpetvā taṃ kappitakesamassuṃ nhātānulittaṃ vatthālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ katvā ānetvā
analyzed: āṇāpetvā tam kappita kesa massum nhāta anulittam vattha alaṅkāra paṭimaṇḍitam katvā ānetvā

analyzed: pūjam katvā sayam nīce āsane nisīditvā tumhehi mayham gāthāḥ suṇoma

translated: and asked him to teach them to him. Expounding this matter, the Master pronounced the following Stanza,

translated: Herein, he said this means he said this.

original: Atha brāhmaṇo bodhisattena yācitakāle gandhehi hatthe ubbaṭṭetvā pasibbakā manoramaṃ
analyzed: atha brāhmaṇaḥ bodhisattena yācita kāle gandhehi hatthe ubbaṭṭetvā pasibbakāḥ manoramam
translated: Then, when the Brahman was asked by the Bodhisatta, he washed his hands with perfumes, and taking out a beautiful book bound in plaited cane,

original: potthakaṃ nīharitvā ubhohi hatthehi gahetvā “tena hi, mahārāja, kassapadasabalena
analyzed: potthakam nīharitvā ubhohi hatthehi gahetvā tena hi mahā rāja kassapadasabalena
translated: he held it in both hands and said, “Well then, great king, listen to the four Stanzas of a hundred blessings, which were taught by Kassapa of the Ten Powers,

original: desitā rāgamadādinimmadanā amatamahānibbānasampāpikā catasso satārahā gāthāyo suṇohī”ti
analyzed: desitāḥ rāga mada ādi nimmadanāḥ amata mahā nibbāna sampāpikā catasso sata arahāḥ gāthāyaḥ suṇohi iti
translated: which are a medicine for the destruction of lust, hatred, and folly, and which lead to the attainment of the great Nibbāna.”

original: vatvā potthakaṃ olokento āha –
analyzed: vatvā potthakam olokentaḥ āha
translated: And looking at the book, he said,

original: “Sakideva sutasoma, sabbhi hoti samāgamo;
analyzed: sakideva suta soma sabbhi hoti samāgamaḥ
translated: “Once, Sutasoma, all are gathered together,

original: Sā naṃ saṅgati pāleti, nāsabbhi bahu saṅgamo.
analyzed: sā nam saṅgati pāleti bahu
translated: But that gathering leads to his destruction, not to much gathering with the good.

original: “Sabbhireva samāsetha, sabbhi kubbetha santhavaṃ;
analyzed: sabbhiḥ eva samāsetha sabbhi kubbetha santhavam
translated: “One should associate only with the good, one should cultivate friendship with the good;

original: Sataṃ saddhammamaññāya, seyyo hoti na pāpiyo.
analyzed: satam saddhammam aññāya seyyaḥ hoti na pāpiyaḥ
translated: Having learned the good Dhamma, one becomes better, not worse.

original: “Jīranti ve rājarathā sucittā, atho sarīrampi jaraṃ upeti;
analyzed: jīranti ve rāja rathā su cittāḥ atho sarīram pi jaram upeti
translated: “Fine royal chariots wear out, and so does the body,🔽But the Dhamma of the good does not wear out.

original: Satañca dhammo na jaraṃ upeti, santo have sabbhi pavedayanti.
analyzed: satañca dhammaḥ na jaram upeti santaḥ have sabbhi pavedayanti
translated: The good proclaim it everywhere.

original: “Nabhañca dūre pathavī ca dūre, pāraṃ samuddassa tadāhu dūre;
analyzed: nabhan ca dūre pathavī ca dūre pāram samuddassa tat āhu dūre
translated: “The sky is far from the earth, and far as well the ocean’s shore,

original: Tato have dūrataraṃ vadanti, satañca dhammo asatañca rājā”ti.🔽Tattha sakidevāti ekavārameva. Sabbhīti sappurisehi. Sā nanti sā sabbhi sappurisehi
analyzed: tatas have dūrataram vadanti satam ca dhammaḥ a satam ca rājā ati  tattha eka vāram eva sabbhi iti sappurisehi sā nanti sā sabbhi sappurisehi
translated: But they say that is even farther: the Dhamma of the good from the bad, O King.”

original: saṅgati samāgamo ekavāraṃ pavattopi taṃ puggalaṃ pāleti rakkhati. Nāsabbhīti asappurisehi
analyzed: saṅgati samāgamaḥ eka vāram pavattaḥ api tam puggalam pāleti rakkhati asappurisehi
translated: Herein, once only means once, just once. The good means the noble ones. That means that that association, that coming together, that intercourse, even if it occurs just once, protects, guards, that person. Not the bad means that with the bad,

original: pana bahu sucirampi kato saṅgamo ekaṭṭhāne nivāso na pāleti, na thāvaro hotīti attho.
analyzed: pana bahu su ciram pi kato saṅgamaḥ eka ṭṭhāne nivāso na pāleti na thāvaraḥ hoti iti attho
translated: however much association, intercourse, living together, is made, it does not protect, it is not lasting, is the meaning.

original: Samāsethāti saddhiṃ nisīdeyya, sabbepi iriyāpathe paṇḍiteheva saddhiṃ pavatteyyāti
analyzed: samāsetha ati saddhim nisīdeyya sabbe pi iriyāpathe paṇḍitehi iva saddhim pavatteyya ati
translated: Sit down together means sit down together with them. In all postures one should conduct oneself only with the wise.

original: attho. Santhavanti mittasanthavaṃ. Sataṃ saddhammanti paṇḍitānaṃ buddhādīnaṃ sattatiṃsabodhipakkhiyadhammasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: attho santhavanti mitta santhavam satam saddhammanti paṇḍitānam buddha ādīnam sattatiṃsa bodhi pakkhiya dhamma saṅkhātam
translated: Attha. Santhavaṃ means friendship. Sataṃ saddhamman means the true Dhamma, which is the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, etc., of the wise, the Buddhas, etc.

original: saddhammaṃ. Seyyoti etaṃ dhammaṃ ñatvā vaḍḍhiyeva hoti, hāni nāma natthīti attho.
analyzed: saddhammam seyyo ti etam dhammam ñatvā vaḍḍhiyā iva hoti hāni nāma natthi iti attho
translated: Seyyo means “it is better,” i.e., having known this Dhamma, there is only increase, there is no decrease.

original: Rājarathāti rājūnaṃ ārohanīyarathā. Sucittāti suparikammakatā. Sabbhi pavedayantīti
analyzed: rāja rathā ati ārohanīya rathā su cittā ati su parikammakatā sabbhi pavedayanti iti
translated: Rājarath means the chariots which the kings ride in. Sucitta means well-made. Sabbhi pavedayantīti

original: buddhādayo santo “sabbhī”ti saṅkhaṃ gataṃ sobhanaṃ uttamaṃ nibbānaṃ pavedenti thomenti,
analyzed: buddha ādayaḥ santaḥ sabbhi iti saṅkham gatam sobhanam uttamam nibbānam pavedenti thomenti
translated: the Buddhas, etc., proclaim, make known, the beautiful, excellent Nibbāna, which is called “all,”

original: so nibbānasaṅkhāto sataṃ dhammo jaraṃ na upeti na jīrati. Nabhanti ākāso. Dūreti
analyzed: saḥ nibbāna saṅkhātaḥ satam dhammaḥ jaram na upeti na jīrati nabhanti ākāsaḥ dūrā iti
translated: that true Dhamma called Nibbāna does not come to old age, it does not grow old. Nabhanti means the sky. Dūreti

original: pathavī hi sappatiṭṭhā sagahaṇā, ākāso nirālambo appatiṭṭho, iti ubho ete ekābaddhāpi
analyzed: pathavī hi sa patiṭṭhā sa gahaṇā ākāsaḥ nirālambaḥ appatiṭṭhaḥ iti ubho ete eka ābaddhā api
translated: the earth is firm, with its mountains, the sky is unsupported, without a base; thus, although both are connected,

original: visaṃyogaṭṭhena anupalittaṭṭhena ca dūre nāma honti. Pāranti orimatīrato paratīraṃ. Tadāhūti taṃ āhu.
analyzed: visaṃyoga ṭṭhena anupalitta ṭṭhena ca dūre nāma honti para tīram tam āhu
translated: they are called “far” in the sense of separation and in the sense of being unattached. Pā means the further shore from this shore. Tadāhū means they say that.

original: Iti brāhmaṇo catasso satārahā gāthā kassapadasabalena desitaniyāmena desetvā tuṇhī
analyzed: iti brāhmaṇaḥ gāthā kassapadasa balena desita niyāmena desetvā tuṇhī
translated: Thus the brāhmaṇa, having recited the four hundred verses, which were taught by the power of the Buddha, remained silent.

original: ahosi. Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto “sapphalaṃ vata me āgamana”nti tuṭṭhacitto hutvā “imā
analyzed: ahosi tam sutvā mahāsatto sapphalam vata me āgamanan ti tuṭṭha cittaḥ hutvā imā
translated: Having heard them, the Great Being thought: “Indeed, my coming has been fruitful.”

original: gāthā neva sāvakabhāsitā, na isibhāsitā, na kenaci bhāsitā, sabbaññunāva bhāsitā,
analyzed: gāthā na iva sāvaka bhāsitā na isi bhāsitā na kenacid bhāsitā sabbaññunā ava bhāsitā
translated: He thought: “These verses were not spoken by a disciple, nor by a sage, nor by anyone else, but were spoken by the Omniscient One.

original: kiṃ nu kho agghantī”ti cintetvā “imāsaṃ sakalampi cakkavāḷaṃ yāva brahmalokā sattaratanapuṇṇaṃ
analyzed: kim nu kho cintetvā imāsam sakalam pi cakkavāḷam yāva brahma lokāḥ satta ratana puṇṇam
translated: What is their value?” He thought: “Even if one were to give the whole world, from the Brahma world down, filled with the seven treasures,

original: katvā dadamānopi neva anucchavikaṃ kātuṃ sakkoti, ahaṃ kho panassa tiyojanasate kururaṭṭhe
analyzed: katvā dadamānaḥ api na iva anucchavikam kātum sakkoti aham kho pana sa ti yojana sate kuru raṭṭhe
translated: it would not be enough to do them justice. But I am able to give him the kingdom in the city of Indapatta, in the Kuru country, three hundred leagues from here,

original: sattayojanike indapatthanagare rajjaṃ dātuṃ pahomi, atthi nu khvassa rajjaṃ kāretuṃ
analyzed: satta yojanike indapattha nagare rajjam dātum pahomi atthi nu khvassa rajjam kāretum
translated: and extending for seven leagues. Is he worthy to rule a kingdom?

original: bhāgya”nti aṅgavijjānubhāvena olokento nāddasa. Tato senāpatiṭṭhānādīni olokento
analyzed: aṅga vid jānubhāvena olokentaḥ na addasa tato senāpati ṭṭhāna ādīni olokentaḥ
translated: ” He looked with the power of his knowledge of the parts of existence, but saw nothing. Then he looked at the position of a general, and so on,

original: ekagāmabhojakamattassapi bhāgyaṃ adisvā dhanalābhassa olokento koṭidhanato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: eka gāma bhojaka mattassa api bhāgyam a disvā dhana lābhassa olokento koṭi dhanato paṭṭhāya
translated: but saw that he was not worthy even of the position of a lord of a single village. Then he looked at the possibility of his obtaining wealth, and saw that he was not worthy of a koṭi of treasure,

original: oloketvā catunnaṃyeva kahāpaṇasahassānaṃ bhāgyaṃ disvā “ettakena naṃ pūjessāmī”ti
analyzed: oloketvā catunnam yeva kahāpaṇa sahassānam bhāgyam disvā ettakena nam pūjessāmi iti
translated: and seeing that they were worth only four thousand kahāpaṇas, he said, “I will honor him with that much.”

original: catasso sahassatthavikā dāpetvā, “ācariya, tumhe aññesaṃ khattiyānaṃ imā gāthā desetvā
analyzed: catassaḥ sahassa tthavikāḥ dāpetvā ācariya tumhe aññesam khattiyānam imāḥ gāthāḥ desetvā
translated: and having had four thousand kahāpaṇas given to him, asked, “Teacher, having taught these verses to other nobles,

original: kittakaṃ dhanaṃ labhathā”ti pucchati. “Ekekāya gāthāya sataṃ sataṃ, mahārāja, teneva🔽tā satārahā nāma jātā”ti. Atha naṃ mahāsatto, “ācariya, tvaṃ attanā gahetvā vikkeyyabhaṇḍassa
analyzed: kittakam dhanam labhatha iti pucchati ekekāya gāthāya satam satam mahā rāja tena iva  tā satārahā nāma jātā ati atha nam mahāsattaḥ ācariya tvam attanā gahetvā vikkeyya bhaṇḍassa
translated: how much wealth did you receive?” “One hundred kahāpaṇas for each verse, great king. Therefore,🔽they are called the ‘hundred-kahāpaṇa verses.’” Then the Great Being said, “Teacher, you do not even know the value of the goods you have brought to sell.

original: agghampi na jānāsi, ito paṭṭhāya ekekā gāthā sahassārahā nāma hontū”ti vatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: na jānāsi itas paṭṭhāya ekekā gāthā sahassārahāḥ nāma hontu iti vatvā gātham āha
translated: From now on, let each verse be worth a thousand kahāpaṇas,” and spoke this verse:

original: “Sahassiyā imā gāthā, nahimā gāthā satārahā;
analyzed: sahassiyāḥ imāḥ gāthāḥ nahimā gāthā sa tārahā
translated: “These verses are worth a thousand, not worth a hundred;

original: Cattāri tvaṃ sahassāni, khippaṃ gaṇhāhi brāhmaṇā”ti.
analyzed: cattāri tvam sahassāni khippam gaṇhāhi brāhmaṇa ati
translated: take quickly, brahmin, your four thousand.”

original: Tassattho – brāhmaṇa, imā gāthā sahassiyā sahassārahā, imā gāthā satārahā na hi hontu, brāhmaṇa, tvaṃ cattāri sahassāni khippaṃ gaṇhāti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ brāhmaṇa imāḥ gāthāḥ sahassiyā sahassārahā imāḥ gāthāḥ sata arahā na hi hontu brāhmaṇa tvam cattāri sahassāni khippam gaṇhāti
translated: The meaning is: Brahmin, these verses are worth a thousand, not worth a hundred. Brahmin, take quickly your four thousand.

original: Athassa ekaṃ sukhayānakaṃ datvā “brāhmaṇaṃ sotthinā gehaṃ sampāpethā”ti purise āṇāpetvā
analyzed: athassa ekam sukha yānakam da tvā brāhmaṇam sotthinā geham sampāpetha ati purise āṇāpetvā
translated: Then he gave him a good carriage, and ordered some men to take the Brahman safely home.

original: taṃ uyyojesi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe “sutasomaraññā satārahā gāthā sahassārahā katvā pūjitā
analyzed: tam uyyojesi tasmin khaṇe sutasomaraññā sa tārahā gāthā sahassārahā katvā pūjitā
translated: At that moment there arose a great shout of applause, “Well done! Well done!” and the people cried, “The king has honored the hundred verses of King Sutasoma with a thousand pieces of money.

original: sādhu sādhū”ti mahāsādhukārasaddo ahosi. Tassa mātāpitaro taṃ saddaṃ sutvā “kiṃ saddo
analyzed: sādhu sādhu uti mahā sādhukāra saddo ahosi tassa mātā pitaro tam saddam sutvā kim saddo
translated: Well done! Well done!” His parents heard the shout, and asked, “What is the matter?

original: nāmesā”ti pucchitvā yathābhūtaṃ sutvā attano dhanalobhatāya mahāsattassa kujjhiṃsu.
analyzed: nāma isā iti pucchitvā yathābhūtam sutvā dhana lobha tāya mahāsattassa kujjhiṃsu
translated: What is the meaning of this shout of applause?” When they learned the truth, they were angry with the Great Being because of their greed for his wealth.

original: Sopi brāhmaṇaṃ uyyojetvā tesaṃ santikaṃ gantvā vanditvā aṭṭhāsi. Athassa pitā “kathaṃ,
analyzed: saḥ api brāhmaṇam uyyojetvā tesam santikam gantvā vanditvā aṭṭhāsi athassa pitā katham
translated: The Great Being, after sending the Brahman on his way, went to his parents, and after paying obeisance to them, stood before them. His father said, “How is this?

original: tāta, evarūpassa sāhasikassa corassa hatthato muttosī”ti paṭisanthāramattampi akatvā🔽attano dhanalobhatāya “saccaṃ kira, tāta, tayā catasso gāthā sutvā cattāri sahassāni
analyzed: tāta evarūpassa sāhasikassa corassa hatthataḥ muttaḥ asi iti paṭisanthāra mattam pi a katvā  attanaḥ dhana lobha tāya saccam kira tāta tayā catassaḥ gāthāḥ sutvā cattāri sahassāni
translated: How did you escape from the hands of such a bold robber?” Without even offering him a welcome,

original: dinnānī”ti pucchitvā “sacca”nti vutte gāthamāha –
analyzed: dinnāni iti pucchitvā saccanti vutte gātham āha
translated: out of greed for his wealth, he asked, “Is it true, my dear, that you gave four thousand pieces of money for four verses?” “It is true.” When he heard this, he spoke the first stanza:—

original: “Āsītiyā nāvutiyā ca gāthā, satārahā cāpi bhaveyya gāthā;
analyzed: āsītiyā nāvutiyā ca gāthā sa tārahā ca api bhaveyya gāthā
translated: “Eighty, ninety, and a hundred verses, and a verse of a thousand syllables,

original: Paccattameva sutasoma jānahi, sahassiyā nāma kā atthi gāthā”ti.
analyzed: paccattam eva sutasoma jānahi sahassiyā nāma kā atthi gāthā ati
translated: Know for thyself, Sutasoma, what a verse of a thousand syllables is.”

original: Tassattho – gāthā nāma, tāta, āsītiyā ca nāvutiyā ca satārahā cāpi bhaveyya, paccattameva attanāva jānāhi, sahassārahā nāma gāthā kā kassa santike atthīti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ gāthā nāma tāta āsītiyā ca nāvutiyā ca satārahā ca api bhaveyya paccattam eva jānāhi sahassārahā nāma gāthā kā kassa santike atthi iti
translated: The meaning is this: “A verse, my dear, may be of eighty, or of ninety, or of a hundred syllables; know for thyself what a verse of a thousand syllables is.”

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto “nāhaṃ, tāta, dhanena vuddhiṃ icchāmi, sutena pana icchāmī”ti saññāpento āha –
analyzed: atha nam mahāsattaḥ na aham tāta dhanena vuddhim icchāmi sutena pana icchāmi iti saññāpentaḥ āha
translated: Then the Great Being, in order to make him understand that he did not desire prosperity through wealth, but through learning, said:

original: “Icchāmi vohaṃ sutavuddhimattano, santoti maṃ sappurisā bhajeyyuṃ;
analyzed: icchāmi vo ham suta vuddhimattano santo ti mamam sappurisāḥ bhajeyyum
translated: “I desire to be prosperous through learning, and let good men call me ‘the peaceful one.’

original: Ahaṃ savantīhi mahodadhīva, na hi tāta tappāmi subhāsitena.
analyzed: aham mahā udadhi iva na hi tāta tappāmi su bhāsitena
translated: I am like the great ocean, which is never satiated with the rivers that flow into it. I am never satiated with good sayings.

original: “Aggi yathā tiṇakaṭṭhaṃ dahanto, na kappatī sāgarova nadībhi;
analyzed: aggi yathā tiṇa kaṭṭham dahantaḥ na sāgaraḥ uva nadībhi
translated: “As a fire burns wood, and is not satiated, as the ocean is not satiated with the rivers that flow into it,

original: Evampi te paṇḍitā rājaseṭṭha, sutvā na tappanti subhāsitena.
analyzed: evam pi te paṇḍitāḥ rāja seṭṭha sutvā na tappanti su bhāsitena
translated: So the wise, O best of kings, are never satiated with hearing good sayings.

original: “Sakassa dāsassa yadā suṇomi, gāthaṃ ahaṃ atthavatiṃ janinda;
analyzed: sakassa dāsassa yadā suṇomi gātham aham atthavatim janinda
translated: “When I hear a verse of a wise man, O king, which is full of meaning,

original: Tameva sakkacca nisāmayāmi, na hi tāta dhammesu mamatthi tittī”ti.🔽Tattha voti nipātamattaṃ. “Santo”ti ete ca maṃ bhajeyyuṃ iti icchāmi. Savantīhīti🔽nadīhi. Sakassāti tiṭṭhatu, nanda, brāhmaṇo, yadā ahaṃ attano dāsassapi santike suṇomi,
analyzed: tam eva sakkacca nisāmayāmi na hi tāta dhammesu mamatthi tittīti  tattha vā iti nipāta mattam santoti ete ca mam bhajeyyum iti icchāmi savantīhi iti  nadīhi sakassa ati tiṭṭhatu nanda brāhmaṇaḥ yadā aham attanaḥ dāsassa api santike suṇomi
translated: I will listen to them with all my heart, for, dear Father, I am never satiated with the Law.”

original: tāta, dhammesu mama titti na hi atthīti.
analyzed: tāta dhammesu mama titti na hi atthi iti
translated: Here the word “vo” is merely a particle. “I wish that they would attend on me” means that I wish that they would serve me. “With rivers” means with rivers. “Let be, Nanda, the Brahman” means that I will listen to the Law even in the presence of my own slave. “For, dear Father, I am never satiated with the Law” means that I am never satiated with the Law.

original: Evañca pana vatvā “mā maṃ, tāta, dhanahetu paribhāsasi, ahaṃ dhammaṃ sutvā āgamissāmī”ti
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā mā mama tāta dhana hetu paribhāsasi aham dhammam sutvā āgamissāmi iti
translated: Having said this, “Do not, dear Father, revile me on account of wealth. I will return after hearing the Law,”

original: sapathaṃ katvā āgato, idānāhaṃ porisādassa santikaṃ gamissāmi, idaṃ te rajjaṃ gaṇhathā”ti
analyzed: sapatham katvā āgataḥ idānā aham porisādassa santikam gamissāmi idam te rajjam gaṇhatha ati
translated: and having taken an oath, he came. Now I will go into the presence of Porisāda. Take this kingdom.”

original: rajjaṃ niyyādento gāthamāha –
analyzed: rajjam niyyādentaḥ gātham āha
translated: And as he was giving up the kingdom, he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Idaṃ te raṭṭhaṃ sadhanaṃ sayoggaṃ, sakāyuraṃ sabbakāmūpapannaṃ;
analyzed: idam te raṭṭham sa dhanam sa yoggam sa kāyuram sabba kāma upapannam
translated: “This kingdom is yours, with its wealth and its army, with its chariots and its elephants, with all its desires fulfilled.

original: Kiṃ kāmahetu paribhāsasi maṃ, gacchāmahaṃ porisādassa ñatte”ti.
analyzed: kim kāma hetu paribhāsasi mam gacchāmaham porisādassa ñattā iti
translated: Why do you revile me on account of desire? I will go into the presence of Porisāda.”

original: Tattha ñatteti santike.
analyzed: tattha ñattā iti santike
translated: Here “into the presence” means into the vicinity.

original: Tasmiṃ samaye piturañño hadayaṃ uṇhaṃ ahosi. So, “tāta sutasoma, kiṃ nāmetaṃ kathesi, mayaṃ caturaṅginiyā senāya coraṃ gahessāmā”ti vatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tasmin samaye pituḥ aññaḥ hadayam uṇham ahosi saḥ tāta sutasoma kim nāma etam kathesi mayam caturaṅginiyā senāya coram gahessāma iti vatvā gātham āha
translated: At that moment the king’s heart grew hot. He said, “Dear Sutasoma, what is this you say? We will take the thief with a four-fold army.” And he spoke this verse:

original: “Attānurakkhāya bhavanti hete, hatthārohā rathikā pattikā ca;
analyzed: attā anurakkhāya bhavanti ha ete hattha ārohā rathikā pattikā ca
translated: “These are for their own protection, the elephant-riders, the charioteers, the infantry,

original: Assārohā ye ca dhanuggahāse, senaṃ payuñjāma hanāma sattu”nti.
analyzed: assa ārohāḥ ye ca dhanuggahāse senam payuñjāma hanāma sattunti
translated: The cavalry, and the archers. We will send forth the army and kill the foe.”

original: Tattha hanāmāti sace evaṃ payojitā senā taṃ gahetuṃ na sakkonti, atha naṃ sakalaraṭṭhavāsino gahetvā gantvā hanāma sattuṃ, mārema taṃ amhākaṃ paccāmittanti attho.
analyzed: tattha hanāma ati sace evam payojitā senā tam gahetum na sakkonti atha nam sakala raṭṭha vāsinaḥ gahetvā gantvā hanāma sattum mārema tam amhākam pacca amittam ti attho
translated: Herein, kill means if the army sent forth is unable to take him, then we will take him and go, and kill the foe, we will destroy him, he is our enemy, is the meaning.

original: Atha naṃ mātāpitaro assupuṇṇamukhā rodamānā vilapantā, “tāta, mā gaccha, gantuṃ na🔽labbhā”ti yāciṃsu. Soḷasasahassā nāṭakitthiyopi sesaparijanopi “amhe anāthe katvā
analyzed: atha nam mātā pitaraḥ assu puṇṇa mukhāḥ rodamānāḥ vilapantā tāta mā gaccha gantum na  labbhāti yāciṃsu soḷasa sahassā nāṭaka itthiyaḥ pi sesa parijanaḥ pi amhe anāthe katvā
translated: Then his parents, their faces full of tears, weeping and lamenting, begged him, “Dear, do not go, it is not allowed to go.”🔽The sixteen thousand dancing-girls and the rest of the retinue wailed, “Where are you going, your majesty, leaving us helpless?”

original: kuhiṃ gacchasi, devā”ti parideviṃsu. Sakalanagare koci sakabhāvena saṇṭhātuṃ asakkonto
analyzed: kuhim gacchasi deva iti parideviṃsu sakala nagare koci saka bhāvena saṇṭhātum a sakkonto
translated: No one in the whole city was able to remain in his own place.

original: “sutasomo porisādassa kira paṭiññaṃ datvā āgato, idāni catasso satārahā gāthā sutvā
analyzed: sutasomaḥ porisādassa kira paṭiññam da tvā āgataḥ idāni catassaḥ satārahāḥ gāthāḥ sutvā
translated: “Sutasoma, it seems, has given his word to Pāyāsi and has gone away. Now, after hearing four hundred stanzas,

original: dhammakathikassa sakkāraṃ katvā mātāpitaro vanditvā punapi kira corassa santikaṃ
analyzed: dhamma kathikassa sakkāram katvā mātā pitaraḥ vanditvā puna api kira corassa santikam
translated: he will make a gift to the preacher of the Dhamma, pay homage to his parents, and then go back to the robber again.”

original: gamissatī”ti sakalanagaraṃ ekakolāhalaṃ ahosi. Sopi mātāpitūnaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: gamissati iti sakala nagaram eka kolāhalam ahosi saḥ api mātā pitūnam vacanam sutvā gātham āha
translated: So the whole city was in an uproar. Sutasoma, after hearing the words of his parents, spoke this verse:

original: “Sudukkaraṃ porisādo akāsi, jīvaṃ gahetvāna avassajī maṃ;
analyzed: su dukkaram porisādaḥ akāsi jīvam gahetvāna avassajī mam
translated: “Pāyāsi has done a very difficult thing; he has taken my life and let me go.

original: Taṃ tādisaṃ pubbakiccaṃ saranto, dubbhe ahaṃ tassa kathaṃ janindā”ti.
analyzed: tam tādisam pubba kiccam sarantaḥ aham tassa katham
translated: Remembering such a former kindness, how can I, O lord of men, do him harm?”

original: Tattha jīvaṃ gahetvānāti jīvaggāhaṃ gahetvā. Taṃ tādisanti taṃ tena kataṃ tathārūpaṃ. Pubbakiccanti purimaṃ upakāraṃ. Janindāti pitaraṃ ālapati.
analyzed: tattha jīvam gahetvāna ati jīva ggāham gahetvā tam tādisanti tam tena katam tathārūpam pubba kiccanti purimam upakāram pitaram ālapati
translated: Herein, he has taken my life means he has taken my life as a hostage. Such a one means such a one as he has done. Former kindness means a former service. O lord of men means he addresses his father.

original: So mātāpitaro assāsetvā, “amma tātā, tumhe mayhaṃ mā cintayittha, katakalyāṇo ahaṃ,
analyzed: saḥ mātā pitaraḥ assāsetvā amma tātā tumhe mayham mā cintayittha kata kalyāṇaḥ aham
translated: He comforted his parents thus: “Mother, Father, do not worry about me. I have done what was good.

original: mama chakāmassaggissariyaṃ na dullabha”nti mātāpitaro vanditvā āpucchitvā sesajanaṃ
analyzed: mama na dullabhanti mātā pitaraḥ vanditvā āpucchitvā sesa janam
translated: The sovereignty of the six psychic powers is not difficult for me to obtain.” After paying homage to his parents and taking leave of them, he said to the rest of the people,

original: anusāsitvā pakkāmi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: anusāsitvā pakkāmi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: and after giving them his advice, he departed. Expounding this matter, the Teacher said:

original: “Vanditvā so pitaraṃ mātarañca, anusāsitvā negamañca balañca;
analyzed: vanditvā saḥ pitaram mātarañca anusāsitvā negamañca balañca
translated: “Having paid homage to his father and his mother, and having given advice to the city and the army,

original: Saccavādī saccānurakkhamāno, agamāsi so yattha porisādo”ti.
analyzed: sacca vādī sacca anurakkhamāno agamāsi saḥ yattha porisādaḥ ti
translated: the speaker of truth, keeping his word, went to the place where Porisāda was.”

original: Tattha saccānurakkhamānoti saccaṃ anurakkhamāno. Agamāsīti taṃ rattiṃ nivesaneyeva
analyzed: tattha sacca anurakkhamānaḥ ti saccam anurakkhamānaḥ agamāsi iti tam rattim
translated: Herein, keeping his word means keeping his promise. He went means that he spent the night in the house of the king of Kāsi and

original: vasitvā punadivase aruṇuggamanavelāya mātāpitaro vanditvā āpucchitvā sesajanaṃ anusāsitvā
analyzed: vasitvā puna divase aruṇuggamana velāya mātā pitaraḥ vanditvā āpucchitvā sesa janam anusāsitvā
translated: after paying homage to his parents and taking leave of them, and after giving advice to the rest of the people,

original: assumukhena nānappakāraṃ paridevantena itthāgārādinā mahājanena anugato nagarā nikkhamma🔽taṃ janaṃ nivattetuṃ asakkonto mahāmagge daṇḍakena tiriyaṃ lekhaṃ kaḍḍhitvā “sace
analyzed: assumukhena nānappakāram paridevantena itthāgāra ādinā mahājanena anugataḥ nagarā nikkhamma  tam janam nivattetum a sakkontaḥ mahā magge daṇḍakena tiriyam lekham kaḍḍhitvā sace
translated: he went out of the city with his face turned away from the city, followed by a great crowd of people, including the women of the harem, who wept and lamented in various ways.

original: mayi sineho atthi, imaṃ mā atikkamiṃsū”ti āha. Mahājano sīlavato tejavantassa āṇaṃ
analyzed: mayi sinehaḥ atthi imam mā atikkamiṃsu iti āha mahā janaḥ sīlavataḥ tejavantassa āṇam
translated: Unable to turn back that crowd, he drew a line across the road with his staff, saying, “If you have any love for me, do not cross this line.”

original: atikkamituṃ asakkonto mahāsaddena paridevamāno taṃ sīhavijambhitena gacchantaṃ oloketvā
analyzed: atikkamitum a sakkontaḥ mahā saddena paridevamānaḥ tam sīhavijambhitena gacchantam oloketvā
translated: Unable to pass beyond the command of the virtuous and powerful one, the great crowd, weeping and lamenting with a great noise,🔽looked on as he went away like a lion yawning.

original: tasmiṃ dassanūpacāraṃ atikkante ekaravaṃ ravanto nagaraṃ pāvisi. Sopi āgatamaggeneva
analyzed: tasmin dassana upacāram atikkante eka ravam ravantaḥ nagaram pāvisi saḥ api āgata maggena iva
translated: and when he had passed the range of vision, he entered the city, crying out with a single voice.

original: tassa santikaṃ gato. Tena vuttaṃ “agamāsi so yattha porisādo”ti.
analyzed: tassa santikam gato tena vuttam agamāsi saḥ yattha porisādaḥ ti
translated: and as soon as he had passed the boundary of the town, he entered the town, crying out with a loud voice. He went straight to the presence of Porisāda. Therefore it is said: “He went to the place where Porisāda was.”

original: Tato porisādo cintesi – “sace mama sahāyo sutasomo āgantukāmo, āgacchatu, anāgantukāmo,🔽anāgacchatu, rukkhadevatā yaṃ mayhaṃ icchati, taṃ karotu, ime rājāno māretvā pañcamadhuramaṃsena
analyzed: tatas porisādaḥ cintesi sace mama sahāyaḥ sutasomaḥ āgantu kāmaḥ āgacchatu an āgantu kāmaḥ  rukkha devatā yam mayham icchati tam karotu ime rājānaḥ mā āretvā pañcamadhuram aṃsena
translated: Then Porisāda thought: “If my friend Sutasoma wishes to come, let him come; if he does not wish to come, let him not come.

original: balikammaṃ karissāmī”ti citakaṃ katvā aggiṃ jāletvā “aṅgārarāsi tāva hotū”ti tassa
analyzed: bali kammam karissāmi iti citakam katvā aggim jāletvā aṅgāra rāsi tāva hotu uti tassa
translated: The tree-spirit may do what she wishes. I will kill these kings and make a sacrifice with the five kinds of flesh.” Having thus reflected, he built a pyre, set fire to it, and said: “Let the pile of embers be ready.”

original: sūle tacchantassa nisinnakāle sutasomo āgato. Atha naṃ porisādo disvā tuṭṭhacitto,
analyzed: sūle tacchantassa nisinna kāle sutasomaḥ āgataḥ atha nam porisādaḥ disvā tuṭṭha citto
translated: While he was sitting there, having his body pierced with spikes, Sutasoma came. Then Porisāda, seeing him, was delighted,

original: “samma, gantvā kattabbakiccaṃ te kata”nti pucchi. Mahāsatto, “āma mahārāja, kassapadasabalena
analyzed: samma gantvā kattabba kiccam te katanti pucchi mahāsattaḥ āma mahā rāja kassapadasabalena
translated: and asked: “Friend, have you done what you had to do?” The Great Being replied: “Yes, great king, by the power of the advice of Kassapa, the Buddha,

original: desitā gāthā me sutā, dhammakathikassa ca sakkāro kato, tasmā gantvā kattabbakiccaṃ
analyzed: desitā gāthā me sutā dhamma kathikassa ca sakkāro kato tasmā gantvā kattabba kiccam
translated: I have heard the stanzas which he taught, and have honoured the preacher of the Law. Therefore I have done what I had to do.

original: kataṃ nāma hotī”ti dassetuṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: katam nāma hoti iti dassetum gātham āha
translated: and to show what was done, he spoke this verse:

original: “Kato mayā saṅgaro brāhmaṇena, raṭṭhe sake issariye ṭhitena;
analyzed: kataḥ mayā saṅgaraḥ brāhmaṇena raṭṭhe sake issariye ṭhitena
translated: “A battle was fought by me, a brahmin, standing in my own kingdom, in my own authority;

original: Taṃ saṅgaraṃ brāhmaṇasappadāya, saccānurakkhī punarāgatosmi;
analyzed: tam saṅgaram brāhmaṇa sappadāya sacca anurakkhī punar āgataḥ asmi
translated: That battle, O brahmin, I have fought, I, the protector of truth, have come back again;

original: Yajassu yaññaṃ khāda maṃ porisādā”ti.
analyzed: yajassu yaññam khāda mam porisāda ati
translated: Perform the sacrifice, eat me, O Porisāda.”

original: Tattha yajassūti maṃ māretvā devatāya vā yaññaṃ yajassu, maṃsaṃ vā me khādāhīti attho.
analyzed: tattha yajassu iti mam mā āretvā devatāya vā yaññam yajassu maṃsam vā me khādāhi iti attho
translated: Herein, perform the sacrifice means either kill me and perform the sacrifice to the deity, or eat my flesh.

original: Taṃ sutvā porisādo “ayaṃ rājā na bhāyati, vigatamaraṇabhayo hutvā katheti, kissa
analyzed: tam sutvā porisādaḥ ayam rājā na bhāyati vigata maraṇa bhayaḥ hutvā kathā iti kissa
translated: On hearing this, Porisāda thought: “This king is not afraid, he speaks without fear of death, why

original: nu kho esa ānubhāvo”ti cintetvā “aññaṃ natthi, ayaṃ ‘kassapadasabalena desitā gāthā
analyzed: nu kho esaḥ ānubhāvaḥ ti cintetvā aññam na atthi ayam kassapadasa balena desitā gāthā
translated: is this so? There is nothing else, he says that he heard a verse taught by Kassapa the Great,

original: me sutā’ti vadati, tāsaṃ etena āsubhāvena bhavitabbaṃ, ahampi taṃ kathāpetvā tā gāthāyo
analyzed: me sutā ati vadati tāsam etena āsu bhāvena bhavitabbam aham pi tam kathāpetvā tāḥ gāthāyaḥ
translated: it must be that by its power this has come to be, I too will have it recited and will learn those verses,

original: sossāmi, evaṃ ahampi nibbhayo bhavissāmī”ti sanniṭṭhānaṃ katvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: sossāmi evam aham pi nibbhayaḥ bhavissāmi iti sanniṭṭhānam katvā gātham āha
translated: and so I too will be fearless.” Having made up his mind, he spoke this verse:

original: “Na hāyate khāditaṃ mayhaṃ pacchā, citakā ayaṃ tāva sadhūmikāva;
analyzed: na hāyate khāditam pacchā ayam
translated: “What is eaten by me is not lost afterwards, this funeral pyre is still smoking;

original: Niddhūmake pacitaṃ sādhupakkaṃ, suṇomi gāthāyo satārahāyo”ti.🔽Tattha khāditanti khādanaṃ. Taṃ khādanaṃ mayhaṃ pacchā vā pure vā na parihāyati,🔽pacchāpi hi tvaṃ mayā khāditabbova. Niddhūmake pacitanti niddhūme nijjhāle aggimhi🔽pakkamaṃsaṃ sādhupakkaṃ nāma hoti.🔽Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto “ayaṃ porisādo pāpadhammo, imaṃ thokaṃ niggahetvā lajjāpetvā kathessāmī”ti cintetvā āha –
analyzed: niddhūmake pacitam sādhu pakkam suṇomi  tattha khāditanti khādanam tam khādanam mayham pacchā vā pure vā na parihāyati  pacchā api hi tvam mayā khāditabbaḥ uva niddhūmake niddhūme nijjhāle aggimhi  pakka maṃsam sādhupakkam nāma hoti  tam sutvā mahāsattaḥ ayam porisādaḥ pāpa dhammaḥ imam thokam niggahetvā lajjāpetvā kathessāmi iti cintetvā āha
translated: Well-cooked, in a smokeless fire, I hear the verses worth a hundred.”

original: “Adhammiko tvaṃ porisādakāsi, raṭṭhā ca bhaṭṭho udarassa hetu;🔽Dhammañcimā abhivadanti gāthā, dhammo ca adhammo ca kuhiṃ sameti.🔽“Adhammikassa luddassa, niccaṃ lohitapāṇino;🔽Natthi saccaṃ kuto dhammo, kiṃ sutena karissasī”ti.🔽Tattha dhammañcimāti imā ca gāthā navalokuttaradhammaṃ abhivadanti. Kuhiṃ sametīti
analyzed: adhammikaḥ tvam porisādakā asi raṭṭhā ca bhaṭṭhaḥ udarassa hetu 🔽dhammañcimāḥ abhivadanti gāthāḥ dhammo ca adhammaḥ ca kuhim sameti 🔽adhammikassa luddassa niccam lohita pāṇinaḥ 🔽natthi saccam kutas dhammaḥ kim sutena karissasi iti 🔽tattha imāḥ ca gāthāḥ nava lokuttara dhammam abhivadanti kuhim sameti iti
translated: Herein, he said “I have eaten,” meaning that he had eaten his food. He said “I have eaten” because he had eaten his food, either before or after the other. “In a smokeless fire” means in a smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokeless, smokel

original: kattha samāgacchati. Dhammo hi sugatiṃ pāpeti nibbānaṃ vā, adhammo duggatiṃ. Kuto
analyzed: kattha samāgacchati dhammaḥ hi sugatim pāpeti nibbānam vā adhammaḥ duggatim kutas
translated: Where does it come from? For the Dhamma leads to a good bourn, to Nibbāna, while the Dhamma leads to a bad bourn.

original: dhammoti vacīsaccamattampi natthi, kuto dhammo. Kiṃ sutenāti tvaṃ etena sutena kiṃ
analyzed: dhammo ti vacī sacca mattam pi natthi kutas dhammo kim sutena ati tvam etena sutena kim
translated: Where does the Dhamma come from? You have not even the truth of speech, much less the Dhamma.

original: karissasi, mattikābhājanaṃ viya hi sīhavasāya abhājanaṃ tvaṃ dhammassa.
analyzed: karissasi mattikā bhājanam viya hi sīha vasāya a bhājanam tvam dhammassa
translated: What will you do with your learning? For you are a vessel for the Dhamma, like a pot of clay.

original: So evaṃ kathitepi neva kujjhi. Kasmā? Mahāsattassa mettābhāvanāya mahattena. Atha naṃ “kiṃ pana samma sutasoma ahameva adhammiko”ti vatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ evam kathite pi na iva kujjhi kasmā mahāsattassa mettā bhāvanāya mahattena atha nam kim pana samma sutasoma aham eva adhammikaḥ iti vatvā gātham āha
translated: But even when he was thus addressed, he did not get angry. Why? Because of the greatness of the Great Being’s development of loving-kindness. Then, saying, “But, my good Sutasoma, am I the only one who is not in accordance with the Dhamma? ” he spoke this verse:

original: “Yo maṃsahetu migavaṃ careyya, yo vā hane purisamattahetu;
analyzed: yaḥ maṃsa hetu migavam careyya yaḥ vā hane purisa matta hetu
translated: “He who would hunt the deer for meat, or kill a man for the sake of a mere trifle,

original: Ubhopi te pecca samā bhavanti, kasmā no adhammikaṃ brūsi maṃ tva”nti.
analyzed: ubhaḥ api te pecca samāḥ bhavanti kasmai naḥ adhammikam brūsi mam
translated: Both of them are equal in the end: why do you call me not in accordance with the Dhamma? ”

original: Tattha kasmā noti ye jambudīpatale rājāno alaṅkatapaṭiyattā mahābalaparivārā rathavaragatā
analyzed: tattha kasmai ye jambudīpa tale rājānaḥ alaṅkata paṭiyattāḥ mahā bala parivārāḥ ratha vara gatā
translated: Here, why do you? — those kings who, on the mainland of India, go hunting the deer, mounted on their fine chariots, surrounded by their great armies,

original: migavaṃ carantā tikhiṇehi sarehi mige vijjhitvā mārenti, te avatvā kasmā tvaṃ maññeva
analyzed: migavam carantā tikhiṇehi sarehi mige vijjhitvā mārenti te a vatvā kasmā tvam maññā iva
translated: and kill the deer with their sharp arrows, — leaving them out, why do you call me alone

original: adhammikanti vadati. Yadi te niddosā, ahampi niddoso evāti dīpeti.
analyzed: adhammikanti vadati yadi te niddosāḥ aham pi niddosaḥ eva ati dīpeti
translated: “You are unjust.” He means to say: “If they are innocent, I am innocent too.”

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto tassa laddhiṃ bhindanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsatto tassa laddhim bhindantaḥ gātham āha
translated: Having heard this, the Great Being, in order to break his opponent’s position, spoke this verse:

original: “Pañca pañca na khā bhakkhā, khattiyena pajānatā;
analyzed: pañca pañca na khā bhakkhā khattiyena pajānatā
translated: “Five times five are not to be eaten, by a king who knows the law.

original: Abhakkhaṃ rāja bhakkhesi, tasmā adhammiko tuva”nti.
analyzed: a bhakkham rāja bhakkhesi tasmai adhammikaḥ tuvanti
translated: You eat what should not be eaten, therefore you are unjust.”

original: Tassattho – samma porisāda, khattiyena nāma khattiyadhammaṃ jānantena pañca pañca
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ samma porisāda khattiyena nāma khattiya dhammam jānantena pañca pañca
translated: The meaning is this: “Good Pāyāsi, by a king who knows the law of the Kshatriyas, five times five

original: hatthiādayo daseva sattā maṃsavasena na khā bhakkhā na kho khāditabbayuttakā. “Na🔽kho”tveva vā pāṭho. Aparo nayo khattiyena khattiyadhammaṃ jānantena pañcanakhesu
analyzed: hatthi ādayaḥ dasa iva sattāḥ maṃsa vasena na khā bhakkhāḥ na kho khāditabba yuttakāḥ na  khotvā iva vā pāṭhaḥ aparaḥ nayaḥ khattiyena khattiya dhammam jānantena pañcanakhesu
translated: animals, namely, the elephant, etc., are not to be eaten, are not to be eaten as food. “Not to be eaten” is the reading.

original: sattesu sasako, sallako, godhā, kapi kummoti ime pañceva sattā bhakkhitabbayuttakā,
analyzed: sattesu sasakaḥ sallakaḥ godhā kapi kummaḥ ti ime pañca iva sattāḥ bhakkhitabba yuttakā
translated: Another interpretation: by a king who knows the law of the Kshatriyas, five animals among the five-toed animals, namely, the hare, the porcupine, the tortoise, the monkey, and the alligator, are to be eaten,

original: na aññe, tvaṃ pana abhakkhaṃ manussamaṃsaṃ bhakkhesi, tena adhammikoti.
analyzed: na aññe tvam pana a bhakkham manussa maṃsam bhakkhesi tena adhammikaḥ ti
translated: not the others. But you eat the human flesh which should not be eaten, therefore you are unjust.”

original: Iti so niggahaṃ patvā aññaṃ nissaraṇaṃ adisvā attano pāpaṃ paṭicchādento gāthamāha –
analyzed: iti saḥ niggaham patvā aññam nissaraṇam a disvā attanaḥ pāpam paṭicchādentaḥ gātham āha
translated: So, being thus caught, and seeing no other way of escape, he tried to conceal his own wickedness by saying,

original: “Mutto tuvaṃ porisādassa hatthā, gantvā sakaṃ mandiraṃ kāmakāmī;
analyzed: muttaḥ tuvam porisādassa hatthā gantvā sakam mandiram kāma kāmī
translated: “You are free from the hands of Porisāda, and you have gone to your own home, and you are doing as you like.

original: Amittahatthaṃ punarāgatosi, na khattadhamme kusalosi rājā”ti.🔽Tattha na khattadhammeti tvaṃ khattiyadhammasaṅkhāte nītisatthe na kusalosi, attano🔽atthānatthaṃ na jānāsi, akāraṇeneva te loke paṇḍitoti kitti patthaṭā, ahaṃ pana te
analyzed: amitta hattham punar āgataḥ asi na khatta dhamme kusalaḥ asi rājā ati  tattha na khatta dhamma iti tvam khattiya dhamma saṅkhāte nīti satthe na kusalaḥ asi attanaḥ  attha anattham na jānāsi akāraṇena iva te loke paṇḍita uti kitti patthaṭā aham pana te
translated: But you have come back into the hands of your enemy. The king is not skilled in the duties of a Khattiya.”

original: paṇḍitabhāvaṃ na passāmi na jānāmi, atibālosīhi vadati.
analyzed: paṇḍita bhāvam na passāmi na jānāmi vadati
translated: Here he says, “Not skilled in the duties of a Khattiya,” meaning, “You are not skilled in the science of government called the duties of a Khattiya. You do not know what is for your good and what is not. For no reason at all you have acquired the reputation of being wise in the world. But I do not see your wisdom, I do not know it. You are exceedingly foolish.”

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto, “samma, khattiyadhamme kusalena nāma mādiseneva bhavitabbaṃ. Ahañhi taṃ jānāmi, na pana tadatthāya paṭipajjāmī”ti vatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam mahāsattaḥ samma khattiya dhamme kusalena nāma mādisena iva bhavitabbam aham hi tam jānāmi na pana tad atthāya paṭipajjāmi iti vatvā gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Being said, “Friend, it is only one like me who is skilled in the duties of a Khattiya. I know you, but I do not act accordingly.” So saying, he spoke the second stanza,

original: “Ye khattadhamme kusalā bhavanti, pāyena te nerayikā bhavanti;
analyzed: ye khatta dhamme kusalāḥ bhavanti pāyena te nerayikāḥ bhavanti
translated: “Those who are skilled in the duties of a Khattiya, in the end become the denizens of hell.

original: Tasmā ahaṃ khattadhammaṃ pahāya, saccānurakkhī punarāgatosmi;
analyzed: tasmai aham khatta dhammam pahāya sacca anurakkhī punar āgataḥ asmi
translated: So I have left behind the doctrine of the stick, And, guarding the truth, I have come back again.

original: Yajassu yaññaṃ khāda maṃ porisādā”ti.
analyzed: yajassu yaññam khāda mam porisāda ati
translated: Perform the sacrifice, Pāyāsi, and eat me.”

original: Tattha kusalāti tadatthāya paṭipajjanakusalā. Pāyenāti yebhuyyena nerayikā. Ye pana tattha na nibbattanti, te sesāpāyesu nibbattanti.
analyzed: tattha kusalā ati tad atthāya paṭipajjana kusalā pāyena ati yebhuyyena nerayikā ye pana tattha na nibbattanti te sesa apāyesu nibbattanti
translated: Herein, skilled is skilled in undertaking it for that purpose. To the lower realms means for the most part to the hells. But those who are not reborn there are reborn in the other kinds of lower realms.

original: Porisādo āha –
analyzed: āha
translated: Pāyāsi said:

original: “Pāsādavāsā pathavīgavāssā, kāmitthiyo kāsikacandanañca;
analyzed: pāsāda vāsā pathavīga vāssā kāmitthiyaḥ kāsika candanañca
translated: “The dwelling in palaces, the dwelling on earth, the dwelling in cattle, the dwelling in horses,🔽The women, the Kāsi fabrics, and the red sandalwood—

original: Sabbaṃ tahiṃ labhasi sāmitāya, saccena kiṃ passasi ānisaṃsa”nti.🔽Tattha pāsādavāsāti, samma sutasoma, tava tiṇṇaṃ utūnaṃ anucchavikā dibbavimānakappā
analyzed: sabbam tahim labhasi sāmitāya saccena kim passasi ānisaṃsanti  tattha pāsādavāsāti samma sutasoma tava tiṇṇam utūnam anucchavikā dibba vimāna kappā
translated: You get all that by the truth, But what advantage do you see in truth?”🔽Herein, dwelling in palaces is the three kinds of dwelling in palaces that are suitable to the three seasons and are like divine palaces,

original: tayo nivāsapāsādā. Pathavīgavāssāti pathavī ca gāvo ca assā ca bahū. Kāmitthiyoti
analyzed: tayaḥ nivāsa pāsādā pathavīgavāssā ati pathavī ca gāvo ca assā ca bahū kāmitthiyā ti
translated: Dwelling on earth is the earth, cattle, and horses that are numerous. The women are women who are objects of sensual pleasure.

original: kāmavatthubhūtā itthiyo. Kāsikacandanañcāti kāsikavatthañca lohitacandanañca. Sabbaṃ
analyzed: kāma vatthu bhūtāḥ itthiyaḥ kāsika candanam ca ati kāsika vatthañca lohita candanam ca sabbam
translated: The Kāsi fabrics are Kāsi cloth, and the red sandalwood is red sandalwood. All that

original: tahinti etañca aññañca upabhogaparibhogaṃ sabbaṃ tvaṃ tahiṃ attano nagare sāmitāya
analyzed: tahinti etam ca aññam ca upabhoga paribhogam sabbam tvam tahin nagare
translated: All this and more besides, you have in your own city,

original: labhasi, sāmī hutvā yathā icchasi, tathā paribhuñjituṃ labhati, so tvaṃ sabbametaṃ
analyzed: labhasi sāmī hutvā yathā icchasi tathā paribhuñjitum labhati saḥ tvam sabbam etam
translated: you are the master of it, you can enjoy it as you wish, you can use it as you like. But you,

original: pahāya saccānurakkhī idhāgacchanto saccena kiṃ ānisaṃsaṃ passasīti.
analyzed: pahāya sacca anurakkhī idha āgacchanto saccena kim ānisaṃsam passasi iti
translated: having renounced all this, and coming here to keep the truth, what advantage do you see in the truth?”

original: Bodhisatto āha –
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ āha
translated: The Bodhisatta replied:

original: “Ye kecime atthi rasā pathabyā, saccaṃ tesaṃ sādutaraṃ rasānaṃ;
analyzed: ye keci ime atthi rasā pathabyā saccam tesam sādutaram
translated: “Whatever tastes there are in the world, the truth is the sweetest of all tastes;

original: Sacce ṭhitā samaṇabrāhmaṇā ca, taranti jātimaraṇassa pāra”nti.
analyzed: sacce ṭhitā samaṇa brāhmaṇā ca taranti jāti maraṇassa pāranti
translated: The ascetics and brāhmans who stand in the truth, they cross over the far shore of birth and death.”

original: Tattha sādutaranti yasmā sabbepi rasā sattānaṃ saccakāleyeva paṇītā madhurā honti,🔽tasmā saccaṃ tesaṃ sādutaraṃ rasānaṃ, yasmā vā viratisaccavacīsacce ṭhitā jātimaraṇasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: tattha sādutaranti yasmā sabbe api rasā sattānam paṇītāḥ madhurāḥ honti  tasmā saccam tesam sādutaram yasmā vā virati sacca vacī sacce ṭhitā jāti maraṇa saṅkhātassa
translated: Herein, the sweetest means that all tastes are good and sweet to living beings only when the truth is present.

original: tebhūmakavaṭṭassa pāraṃ amatamahānibbānaṃ taranti pāpuṇanti, tasmāpi taṃ sādutaranti.
analyzed: tebhūmakavaṭṭassa pāram amatamahānibbānam taranti pāpuṇanti tasmā api tam sādutaranti
translated: Or alternatively, because those who stand in the truth of abstinence and the truth of right speech cross over the far shore of the triple-barrelled round of birth and death, and reach the great Nibbāna, which is the deathless, therefore it is the sweetest.

original: Evamassa mahāsatto sacce ānisaṃsaṃ kathesi. Tato porisādo vikasitapadumapuṇṇacandasassirikamevassa
analyzed: evam assa mahāsatto sacce ānisaṃsam kathesi tatas porisādaḥ
translated: Thus did the Great Being expound the advantages of truthfulness. Then Porisāda, with a face like a full-blown lotus,🔽

original: mukhaṃ oloketvā “ayaṃ sutasomo aṅgāracitakaṃ mañca sūlaṃ tacchantaṃ passati, cittutrāsamattampissa
analyzed: mukham oloketvā ayam suta somaḥ aṅgāra citakam mañca sūlam tad chantam passati cittu trāsa mattampissa
translated: Thus did the Great Being expound the benefits of truth. Then Porisāda, looking at his face, which was radiant as the full moon in the autumn season, thought to himself, “Sutasoma sees the charcoal pit and the stake, and yet he is not afraid.

original: natthi, kiṃ nu kho esa satārahagāthānaṃ ānubhāvo, udāhu saccassa, aññasseva vā kassacī”ti
analyzed: natthi kim nu kho esa satāraha gāthānam ānubhāvaḥ udāhu saccassa aññassa iva vā kassaci iti
translated: Is it the power of the verses of the Seven Buddhas, or is it the power of truth, or is it the power of some one else?”

original: cintetvā “pucchissāmi tāva na”nti pucchanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: cintetvā pucchissāmi tāva pucchantaḥ gātham āha
translated: And he said to himself, “I will ask him.” So he asked the following question:

original: “Mutto tuvaṃ porisādassa hatthā, gantvā sakaṃ mandiraṃ kāmakāmī;
analyzed: muttaḥ tuvam porisādassa hatthā gantvā sakam mandiram kāma kāmī
translated: “You have escaped from the hands of Porisāda, and you have gone to your own home and have had your will of pleasures.

original: Amittahatthaṃ punarāgatosi, na hi nūna te maraṇabhayaṃ janinda;
analyzed: amitta hattham punar āgataḥ asi na hi nūna te maraṇa bhayam janinda
translated: But now you have come again into the hands of an enemy. Surely, O King, you have no fear of death.

original: Alīnacitto asi saccavādī”ti.
analyzed: a līna cittaḥ asi sacca vādī iti
translated: You are of resolute mind and you speak the truth.”

original: Mahāsattopissa ācikkhanto āha –
analyzed: mahāsatto pi issa ācikkhantaḥ āha
translated: And the Great Being, in reply, said:

original: “Katā me kalyāṇā anekarūpā, yaññā yiṭṭhā ye vipulā pasatthā;
analyzed: katāḥ me kalyāṇāḥ aneka rūpāḥ yaññāḥ yiṭṭhāḥ ye vipulā pasatthā
translated: “Many and various sacrifices have I offered, and they have been well performed and have been highly spoken of.

original: Visodhito paralokassa maggo, dhamme ṭhito ko maraṇassa bhāye.
analyzed: visodhitaḥ para lokassa maggaḥ dhamme ṭhitaḥ kaḥ maraṇassa bhāye
translated: The way to the other world has been cleared for me. How should one who is established in righteousness fear death?

original: “Katā me kalyāṇā anekarūpā, yaññā yiṭṭhā ye vipulā pasatthā;
analyzed: katāḥ me kalyāṇāḥ aneka rūpāḥ yaññāḥ yiṭṭhāḥ ye vipulā pasatthā
translated: I have given many kinds of great offerings.🔽I will go to the next world without regret.

original: Anānutappaṃ paralokaṃ gamissaṃ, yajassu yaññaṃ ada maṃ porisāda.
analyzed: anānutappam para lokam gamissam yajassu yaññam ada mam porisāda
translated: Make an offering, Porisāda, but do not give me away.”🔽“My father and mother have looked after me,

original: “Pitā ca mātā ca upaṭṭhitā me, dhammena me issariyaṃ pasatthaṃ;
analyzed: pitā ca mātā ca upaṭṭhitā me dhammena me issariyam pasattham
translated: my rule is approved by the Dhamma.🔽The path to the next world has been purified.

original: Visodhito paralokassa maggo, dhamme ṭhito ko maraṇassa bhāye.
analyzed: visodhitaḥ para lokassa maggaḥ dhamme ṭhitaḥ kaḥ maraṇassa bhāye
translated: Who, established in the Dhamma, should fear death?”🔽“My father and mother have looked after me,

original: “Pitā ca mātā ca upaṭṭhitā me, dhammena me issariyaṃ pasatthaṃ;
analyzed: pitā ca mātā ca upaṭṭhitā me dhammena me issariyam pasattham
translated: my rule is approved by the Dhamma.🔽I will go to the next world without regret.

original: Anānutappaṃ paralokaṃ gamissaṃ, yajassu yaññaṃ ada maṃ porisāda.
analyzed: anānutappam para lokam gamissam yajassu yaññam ada mam porisāda
translated: Make an offering, Porisāda, but do not give me away.”🔽“I have done what should be done for relatives and friends,

original: “Ñātīsu mittesu katā me kārā, dhammena me issariyaṃ pasatthaṃ;
analyzed: ñātīsu mittesu katā me kārā dhammena me issariyam pasattham
translated: my rule is approved by the Dhamma.🔽The path to the next world has been purified.

original: Visodhito paralokassa maggo, dhamme ṭhito ko maraṇassa bhāye.
analyzed: visodhitaḥ para lokassa maggaḥ dhamme ṭhitaḥ kaḥ maraṇassa bhāye
translated: Who, established in the Dhamma, should fear death?”🔽“I have done what should be done for relatives and friends,

original: “Ñātīsu mittesu katā me kārā, dhammena me issariyaṃ pasatthaṃ;
analyzed: ñātīsu mittesu katā me kārā dhammena me issariyam pasattham
translated: my rule is approved by the Dhamma.🔽I will go to the next world without regret.

original: Anānutappaṃ paralokaṃ gamissaṃ, yajassu yaññaṃ ada maṃ porisāda.
analyzed: anānutappam para lokam gamissam yajassu yaññam ada mam porisāda
translated: Make an offering, Porisāda, but do not give me away.”🔽“I have given gifts to many people,

original: “Dinnaṃ me dānaṃ bahudhā bahūnaṃ, santappitā samaṇabrāhmaṇā ca;
analyzed: dinnam me dānam bahudhā bahūnam santappitā samaṇa brāhmaṇā ca
translated: I have satisfied monastics and brahmins,

original: Visodhito paralokassa maggo, dhamme ṭhito ko maraṇassa bhāye.
analyzed: visodhitaḥ para lokassa maggaḥ dhamme ṭhitaḥ kaḥ maraṇassa bhāye
translated: The path to the world beyond is purified, So why should one like me fear death?

original: “Dinnaṃ me dānaṃ bahudhā bahūnaṃ, santappitā samaṇabrāhmaṇā ca;
analyzed: dinnam me dānam bahudhā bahūnam santappitā samaṇa brāhmaṇā ca
translated: “I have given gifts in many ways to many, I have satisfied ascetics and brahmans,

original: Anānutappaṃ paralokaṃ gamissaṃ, yajassu yaññaṃ ada maṃ porisādā”ti.🔽Tattha kalyāṇāti kalyāṇakammā. Anekarūpāti dānādivasena anekavidhā. Yaññāti dasavidhadānavatthupariccāgavasena
analyzed: anānutappam para lokam gamissam yajassu yaññam ada mam porisāda ati  tattha kalyāṇā ati kalyāṇa kammā aneka rūpā ati dāna ādi vasena anekavidhā yaññā iti dasavidha dāna vatthu pariccāga vasena
translated: I will go to the world beyond without regret, So perform the sacrifice, O Porisāda, and give me to him.”

original: ativipulā paṇḍitehi pasatthā yaññāpi yiṭṭhā pavattitā. Dhamme ṭhitoti evaṃ dhamme
analyzed: ati vipulā paṇḍitehi pasatthā yaññā api yiṭṭhā pavattitā dhamme ṭhito ti evam dhamme
translated: Herein, “virtuous” means having good deeds. “Many-formed” means of many kinds, such as giving. “Sacrifices” means sacrifices that are very extensive and approved by the wise, performed by the giving up of the ten objects of giving.

original: patiṭṭhito mādiso ko nāma maraṇassa bhāyeyya. Anānutappanti anānutappamāno. Dhammena
analyzed: patiṭṭhitaḥ mādisaḥ kaḥ nāma maraṇassa bhāyeyya an ānutappanti an ānutappamānaḥ dhammena
translated: “One like me” means one who is established in the Dhamma in this way. “Why should he fear death?” means why should he be afraid of death? “Without regret” means without regret.

original: me issariyaṃ pasatthanti dasavidhaṃ rājadhammaṃ akopetvā dhammeneva mayā rajjaṃ pasāsitaṃ.
analyzed: me issariyam pasatthanti dasavidham rāja dhammam a kopetvā dhammena iva mayā rajjam pasāsitam
translated: “My sovereignty” means my sovereignty over the ten royal duties.

original: Kārāti ñātīsu ñātikiccāni, mittesu ca mittakiccāni. Dānanti savatthukacetanā. Bahudhāti
analyzed: kārāti ñātīsu ñāti kiccāni mittesu ca mitta kiccāni dānanti savatthuka cetanā bahudhā ati
translated: “Kindness” means the duties to kinsmen among kinsmen and the duties to friends among friends. “Giving” means volition together with its material basis. “To many” means

original: bahūhi ākārehi. Bahūnanti na pañcannaṃ, na dasannaṃ, satassapi sahassassapi satasahassassapi
analyzed: bahūhi ākārehi na pañcannam na dasannam satassa api sahassassa api sata sahassassa api
translated: In many ways. In many ways means not five, not ten, not a hundred, not a thousand, not a hundred thousand,

original: dinnameva. Santappitāti gahitagahitabhājanāni pūretvā suṭṭhu tappitā.
analyzed: dinnam eva santappitā ati gahita gahita bhājanāni pūretvā suṭṭhu tappitā
translated: but a great many. Satisfied means having filled the vessels that were taken, they were well satisfied.

original: Taṃ sutvā porisādo “ayaṃ sutasomamahārājā sappuriso ñāṇasampanno madhuradhammakathiko,
analyzed: tam sutvā porisādaḥ ayam sutasoma mahā rājā sappurisaḥ ñāṇa sampannaḥ madhura dhamma kathiko
translated: Having heard that, Porisada thought, “This King Sutasoma is a good man, endowed with knowledge, a speaker of sweet dhamma,

original: sacāhaṃ etaṃ khādeyyaṃ, muddhā me sattadhā phaleyya, pathavī vā pana me vivaraṃ dadeyyā”ti
analyzed: sacā aham etam khādeyyam muddhā me sattadhā phaleyya pathavī vā pana me vivaram dadeyya ati
translated: if I were to eat him, my head would split into seven pieces, or the earth would open up and receive me.”

original: bhītatasito hutvā, “samma, na tvaṃ mayā khāditabbarūpo”ti vatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: hutvā samma na tvam mayā khāditabba rūpā iti vatvā gātham āha
translated: Being frightened and terrified, saying, “Friend, you are not fit to be eaten by me,” he spoke this verse:

original: “Visaṃ pajānaṃ puriso adeyya, āsīvisaṃ jalitamuggatejaṃ;
analyzed: visam pajānam purisaḥ adeyyaḥ āsīvisam jalita mugga tejam
translated: “A man knowing poison would not give, a poisonous snake with blazing fiery mouth;

original: Muddhāpi tassa viphaleyya sattadhā, yo tādisaṃ saccavādiṃ adeyyā”ti.
analyzed: muddhā api tassa viphaleyya sattadhā yaḥ tādisam sacca vādim a deyya ati
translated: His head would split into seven pieces, he who would give such a truthful speaker.”

original: Tattha visanti tattheva māraṇasamatthaṃ halāhalavisaṃ. Jalitanti attano visatejena jalitaṃ teneva uggatejaṃ aggikkhandhaṃ viya carantaṃ āsīvisaṃ vā pana so gīvāya gaṇheyya.
analyzed: tattha visanti tattha iva māraṇa samattham halāhala visam jalitanti attanaḥ visa tejena jalitam tena iva ugga tejam aggi kkhandham viya carantam āsīvisam vā pana saḥ gīvāya gaṇheyya
translated: The poison of the halāhala snake enters the body and kills the person. The snake is burning with the heat of its own poison, and it moves about as if it were a mass of fire. Or else, the snake may seize the person by the neck.

original: Iti so mahāsattaṃ “halāhalavisasadiso tvaṃ, ko taṃ khādissatī”ti vatvā gāthā sotukāmo
analyzed: iti saḥ mahāsattam halāhala visa sadisaḥ tvam kaḥ tam khādissati iti vatvā gāthā sotu kāmo
translated: The great being said to the snake, “You are like the halāhala poison. Who will eat you?” Then he desired to hear the verses.

original: taṃ yācitvā tena dhammagāravajananatthaṃ “evarūpānaṃ anavajjagāthānaṃ tvaṃ abhājana”nti
analyzed: tam yācitvā tena dhamma gārava janana attham evarūpānam anavajja gāthānam tvam
translated: He asked the snake for the verses. The snake refused, saying, “You are not a fit vessel for such faultless verses.”

original: paṭikkhittopi “sakalajambudīpe iminā sadiso paṇḍito natthi, ayaṃ mama hatthā muccitvā
analyzed: paṭikkhittaḥ api sakala jambudīpe iminā sadisaḥ paṇḍitaḥ natthi ayam mama hatthāḥ muccitvā
translated: But the king persisted, saying, “There is no one in all India so wise as I. If I let this snake go,

original: gantvā tā gāthā sutvā dhammakathikassa sakkāraṃ katvā nalāṭena maccuṃ ādāya punāgato,
analyzed: gantvā tāḥ gāthāḥ sutvā dhamma kathikassa sakkāram katvā nalāṭena maccum ādāya puna āgataḥ
translated: it will go and hear the verses, and then it will return and carry Death off on its brow.

original: ativiya sādhurūpā gāthā bhavissantī”ti suṭṭhutaraṃ sañjātadhammassavanādaro hutvā
analyzed: sādhu rūpāḥ gāthāḥ bhavissanti iti suṭṭhutaram sañjāta dhamma ssavana ādaraḥ hutvā
translated: The verses will be very beautiful.” The king’s desire to hear the Law became all the keener.

original: taṃ yācanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam yācantaḥ gātham āha
translated: He asked the snake for the verses, and the snake replied with the following verse:

original: “Sutvā dhammaṃ vijānanti, narā kalyāṇapāpakaṃ;
analyzed: sutvā dhammam vijānanti narā kalyāṇa pāpakam
translated: “Men know the Law when they have heard it, what is good and what is evil.

original: Api gāthā suṇitvāna, dhamme me ramate mano”ti.
analyzed: api gāthā suṇitvāna dhamme me ramate
translated: But hearing the verses, my mind delights in the Law.”

original: Tassattho – “samma sutasoma, narā nāma dhammaṃ sutvā kalyāṇampi pāpakampi jānanti, appeva nāma tā gāthā sutvā mamapi kusalakammapathadhamme mano rameyyā”ti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ samma sutasoma narāḥ nāma dhammam sutvā kalyāṇam pi pāpakam pi jānanti appa eva nāma tāḥ gāthāḥ sutvā mama api kusala kammapatha dhamme manaḥ rameyya ati
translated: The meaning is this: “Well, Sutasoma, men, when they hear the Law, know what is good and what is bad; perhaps, hearing these verses, your mind will delight in the Law of the good way of action.”

original: Atha mahāsatto “sotukāmo dāni porisādo, kathessāmī”ti cintetvā “tena hi, samma, sādhukaṃ
analyzed: atha mahāsattaḥ sotu kāmaḥ dāni porisādaḥ kathessāmi iti cintetvā tena hi samma sādhukam
translated: Then the Great Being thought, “Now Porisāda is desirous to hear; I will preach.” And he said, “Well then, Sutasoma, listen carefully

original: suṇāhī”ti taṃ ohitasotaṃ katvā nandabrāhmaṇena kathitaniyāmeneva gāthānaṃ thutiṃ
analyzed: suṇāhi iti tam ohita sotam katvā nanda brāhmaṇena kathita niyāmena iva gāthānam thutim
translated: and give your mind to it.” And he made him attentive, and in the very same way as the brāhman Nanda had done, he praised the verses,

original: katvā chasu kāmāvacaradevesu ekakolāhalaṃ katvā devatāsu sādhukāraṃ dadamānāsu porisādassa dhammaṃ kathesi –
analyzed: katvā chasu kāmāvacara devesu eka kolāhalam katvā devatāsu sādhukāram dadamānāsu porisādassa dhammam kathesi
translated: and he preached the Law to Porisāda, while the gods in the six heavens of the sensual sphere made a great uproar and gave him the applause of “Bravo!”

original: “Sakideva mahārāja, sabbhi hoti samāgamo;
analyzed: sakideva mahā rāja sabbhi hoti samāgamaḥ
translated: “Once, O great king, all are assembled together;

original: Sā naṃ saṅgati pāleti, nāsabbhi bahu saṅgamo.
analyzed: sā nam saṅgati pāleti bahu
translated: That assembly leads him to the good, not the assembly of the bad.

original: “Sabbhireva samāsetha, sabbhi kubbetha santhavaṃ;
analyzed: sabbhiḥ eva samāsetha sabbhi kubbetha santhavam
translated: “With all one should be united, with all one should hold intercourse;

original: Sataṃ sandhammamaññāya, seyyo hoti na pāpiyo.
analyzed: satam sandhammam aññāya seyyaḥ hoti na pāpiyaḥ
translated: Having known the good of intercourse, one becomes better, not worse.

original: “Jīranti ve rājarathā sucittā, atho sarīrampi jaraṃ upeti;
analyzed: jīranti ve rāja rathā su cittāḥ atho sarīram pi jaram upeti
translated: “The king’s chariots, though well-made, grow old; and so the body, too, is subject to decay.

original: Satañca dhammo na jaraṃ upeti, santo have sabbhi pavedayanti.
analyzed: satañca dhammaḥ na jaram upeti santaḥ have sabbhi pavedayanti
translated: But the Dhamma of the good does not grow old; the good proclaim it to all.

original: “Nabhañca dūre pathavī ca dūre, pāraṃ samuddassa tadāhu dūre;
analyzed: nabhan ca dūre pathavī ca dūre pāram samuddassa tat āhu dūre
translated: “The sky is far from earth, the ocean far from shore, far is the other world, they say, from this;

original: Tato have dūrataraṃ vadanti, satañca dhammo asatañca rājā”ti.🔽Tassa tena sukathitattā ceva attano paṇḍitabhāvena ca tā gāthā sabbaññubuddhakathitā🔽viyāti cintentassa sakalasarīraṃ pañcavaṇṇāya pītiyā paripūri, bodhisatte muducittaṃ
analyzed: tatas have dūrataram vadanti satam ca dhammaḥ a satam ca rājā ati  tassa tena su kathita ttā ca iva attano paṇḍita bhāvena ca tāḥ gāthāḥ sabbaññu buddha kathitā  viyā ti cintentassa sakala sarīram pañca vaṇṇāya pītiyā paripūri bodhisatte mudu cittam
translated: But far beyond all these, they say, is the Dhamma of the good from that of the bad, O King.”🔽Because of the well-spoken nature of these verses and because of his own wisdom, the Bodhisatta thought that they must have been spoken by a Buddha who knows all things.

original: ahosi, setacchattadāyakaṃ pitaraṃ viya naṃ amaññi. So “ahaṃ sutasomassa dātabbaṃ
analyzed: ahosi seta chatta dāyakam pitaram viya nam amaññi saḥ aham sutasomassa dātabbam
translated: The whole of his body was filled with the five-colored joy, and he became very favorably disposed towards the Bodhisatta, thinking of him as his father, the giver of the white parasol.

original: kiñci hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ na passāmi, ekekāya panassa gāthāya ekekaṃ varaṃ dassāmī”ti
analyzed: kiñci hirañña suvaṇṇam na passāmi ekekāya panassa gāthāya ekekam varam dassāmi iti
translated: He thought, “I do not see any gold or silver to give to Sutasoma, but I will give him a boon for each verse he recites.”

original: cintetvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: cintetvā gātham āha
translated: So he spoke this verse:

original: “Gāthā imā atthavatī subyañjanā, subhāsitā tuyha janinda sutvā;
analyzed: gāthā imā atthavatī su byañjanā su bhāsitā tuyha janinda sutvā
translated: “These verses are meaningful and well-spoken, well-recited, O King.

original: Ānandi vitto sumano patīto, cattāri te samma vare dadāmī”ti.
analyzed: ānandi vitto sumano patīto cattāri te samma vare dadāmi iti
translated: He rejoiced, was glad, elated, and delighted, and he said to me, “I will give you four boons.”

original: Tattha ānandīti ānandajāto. Sesāni tasseva vevacanāni. Cattāropi hete tuṭṭhākārā eva.
analyzed: tattha ānandī iti ānanda jātaḥ sesāni tassa iva vevacanāni cattāro api ha ete tuṭṭhākārāḥ eva
translated: Herein, he rejoiced means he was born of joy. The rest are synonyms for that. All four are expressions for being satisfied.

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto “kiṃ nāma tvaṃ varaṃ dassasī”ti apasādento gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam mahāsatto kim nāma tvam varam dassasi iti apasādentaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Being, in order to discourage him, spoke this verse:

original: “Yo nattano maraṇaṃ bujjhasi tuvaṃ, hitāhitaṃ vinipātañca saggaṃ;
analyzed: yaḥ nattanaḥ maraṇam bujjhasi tuvam hita ahitam vinipātam ca saggam
translated: “You who do not understand your own death, what is good and what is not good, what is downfall and what is heaven,

original: Giddho rase duccarite niviṭṭho, kiṃ tvaṃ varaṃ dassasi pāpadhamma.
analyzed: giddhaḥ rase duccarite niviṭṭhaḥ kim tvam varam dassasi pāpa dhamma
translated: You who are greedy for sensual pleasures and are addicted to evil deeds, what boon will you give, you of evil nature?

original: “Ahañca taṃ ‘dehi vara’nti vajjaṃ, tvaṃ cāpi datvā na avākareyya;
analyzed: aham ca tam dehi varanti vajjam tvam ca api da tvā na avākareyya
translated: “I would say to you, ‘Give me a boon,’ and you would say, ‘I will give,’ but you would not give it.

original: Sandiṭṭhikaṃ kalahamimaṃ vivādaṃ, ko paṇḍito jānamupabbajeyyā”ti.
analyzed: sandiṭṭhikam kalaham imam vivādam kaḥ paṇḍitaḥ jānam upabbajeyya ati
translated: This is a quarrel and a dispute that can be seen in this very life. What wise man would enter the homeless life?”

original: Tattha yoti yo tvaṃ “maraṇadhammohamasmī”ti attanopi maraṇaṃ na bujjhasi na jānāsi,
analyzed: tattha yaḥ iti tvam maraṇa dhammo ham asmi iti maraṇam na bujjhasi na jānāsi
translated: Herein, you who means you who do not understand, do not know, even your own death, thinking, “I am subject to death.”

original: pāpakammameva karosi. Hitāhitanti “idaṃ me kammaṃ hitaṃ, idaṃ ahitaṃ, idaṃ vinipātaṃ
analyzed: pāpa kammam eva karosi hita ahitam ti idam me kammam hitam idam ahitam idam vinipātam
translated: You do only evil deeds. What is good and what is not good means this deed is good for me, this is not good. What is downfall and what is heaven means this is downfall, this is heaven.

original: nessati, idaṃ sagga”nti na jānāsi. Raseti manussamaṃsarase. Vajjanti vadeyyaṃ. Na
analyzed: na issati idam sagganti na jānāsi rasa iti manussa maṃsa rase vajjanti vadeyyam na
translated: you do not know what is the better, what the worse. Taste means the taste of human flesh. I would say:

original: avākareyyāti vācāya datvā “dehi me vara”nti vuccamāno na avākareyyāsi na dadeyyāsi.
analyzed: avākareyya iti vācāya da tvā dehi me varanti vuccamānaḥ na avākareyyāsi na dadeyyāsi
translated: Do not give means: having given by speech, if you are told: “Give me the boon,” you should not give, you should not grant.

original: Upabbajeyyāti ko imaṃ kalahaṃ paṇḍito upagaccheyya.
analyzed: upabbajeyya ati kaḥ imam kalaham paṇḍitaḥ upagaccheyya
translated: Would go forth means: what wise man would go forth to this quarrel?

original: Tato porisādo “nāyaṃ mayhaṃ saddahati, saddahāpessāmi na”nti gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas porisādaḥ na ayam mayham saddahati saddahāpessāmi na nti gātham āha
translated: Then Porisāda, thinking: “He does not believe me, I will make him believe,” spoke this verse:

original: “Na taṃ varaṃ arahati jantu dātuṃ, yaṃ vāpi datvā na avākareyya;
analyzed: na tam varam arahati jantu dātum yam vā api da tvā na avākareyya
translated: “That boon a man should not give, which, having given, he should not grant;

original: Varassu samma avikampamāno, pāṇaṃ cajitvānapi dassamevā”ti.
analyzed: samma a vikampamānaḥ pāṇam dassam eva ati
translated: Choose, my friend, without trembling, even if it be the giving up of life.”

original: Tattha avikampamānoti anolīyamāno.
analyzed: tattha a vikampamānaḥ ti an olīyamānaḥ
translated: Herein, without trembling means: without wavering.

original: Atha mahāsatto “ayaṃ ativiya sūro hutvā katheti, karissati me vacanaṃ, varaṃ gaṇhissāmi,
analyzed: atha mahāsattaḥ ayam sūraḥ hutvā kathā iti karissati me vacanam varam gaṇhissāmi
translated: Then the Great Being thought: “This one speaks as if he were very brave, he will do my bidding, I will choose a boon,

original: sace pana “manussamaṃsaṃ na khāditabba’nti paṭhamameva varaṃ vārayissaṃ, ativiya
analyzed: sace pana manussa maṃsam na khāditabbanti paṭhamam eva varam vārayissam ativiya
translated: but if I choose the first boon, saying: ‘Human flesh should not be eaten,’ he will be very angry,

original: kilamissati, paṭhamaṃ aññe tayo vare gahetvā pacchā etaṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti cintetvā āha –
analyzed: kilamissati paṭhamam aññe tayo vare gahetvā pacchā etam gaṇhissāmi iti cintetvā āha
translated: “He will get tired of it. First I will take the other three boons and then I will take this one.” So he said:

original: “Ariyassa ariyena sameti sakhyaṃ, paññassa paññāṇavatā sameti;
analyzed: ariyassa ariyena sameti sakhyam paññassa paññāṇavatā sameti
translated: “The noble with the noble makes friendship, the wise with the wise;

original: Passeyya taṃ vassasataṃ arogaṃ, etaṃ varānaṃ paṭhamaṃ varāmī”ti.
analyzed: passeyya tam vassa satam arogam etam varānam paṭhamam varāmi iti
translated: May I see you a hundred years in health: this boon I first request.”

original: Tattha ariyassāti ācāraariyassa. Sakhyanti sakhidhammo mittadhammo. Paññāṇavatāti
analyzed: tattha ariyassa ati ācāra ariyassa sakhyanti sakhi dhammo mitta dhammo paññāṇavatā ati
translated: Herein, the noble is the noble in conduct. Friendship is the state of a friend, the state of a companion. The wise with the wise:

original: ñāṇasampannena. Sametīti gaṅgodakaṃ viya yamunodakena saṃsandati. Dhātuso hi sattā🔽saṃsandanti. Passeyya tanti sutasomo porisādassa ciraṃ jīvitaṃ icchanto viya paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa sampannena sameti iti gaṅgā udakam viya yamunā udakena saṃsandati dhātusaḥ hi sattā  saṃsandanti passeyya tanti sutasomo porisādassa ciram jīvitam icchantaḥ viya paṭhamam
translated: with one possessing knowledge. Makes friendship: they are mixed up together like the water of the Ganges and the water of the Jumna. For beings are mixed up together

original: attano jīvitavaraṃ yācati. Paṇḍitassa hi “mama jīvitaṃ dehī”ti vattuṃ ayuttaṃ, apica
analyzed: attanaḥ jīvita varam yācati paṇḍitassa hi mama jīvitam dehi iti vattum ayuttam apica
translated: by affinity. May I see you: like Suta Soma, who wanted to see Porisāda live long, he first asks for the boon of his own life. For it is not proper for a wise man to say, “Give me your life.” Besides,

original: so ‘mayhameva esa ārogyaṃ icchatī’ti cintetvā tussissatīti evamāha.
analyzed: saḥ mayham eva esaḥ ārogyam icchati iti cintetvā tussissati iti evam āha
translated: he thought, “He wants my health,” and so he said this.

original: Sopi taṃ sutvāva “ayaṃ issariyā dhaṃsetvā idāni maṃsaṃ khāditukāmassa evaṃ mahāanatthakarassa
analyzed: saḥ api tam sutvā ava ayam issariyā dhaṃsetvā idāni maṃsam khāditu kāmassa evam mahā anattha karassa
translated: He, too, was delighted to hear this, and thought: “This man, who is a great robber, who has done me such great harm, who is now desirous of destroying my sovereignty and of eating my flesh,

original: mahācorassa mayhameva jīvitaṃ icchati, aho mama hitakāmo”ti tuṭṭhamānaso vañcetvā
analyzed: mahā corassa jīvitam icchati aho mama hita kāmo ti tuṭṭha mānasaḥ vañcetvā
translated: wants my life for himself. Ah! he is my benefactor.” So he deceived him,

original: varassa gahitabhāvaṃ ajānitvā taṃ varaṃ dadamāno gāthamāha –
analyzed: varassa gahita bhāvam a jānitvā tam varam dadamānaḥ gātham āha
translated: and not knowing that he had already accepted the boon, he gave him the boon, and spoke the first stanza:
