original: “Ariyassa ariyena sameti sakhyaṃ, paññassa paññāṇavatā sameti;
analyzed: ariyassa ariyena sameti sakhyam paññassa paññāṇavatā sameti
translated: “The noble and the noble meet, the wise and the wise;

original: Passāsi maṃ vassasataṃ arogaṃ, etaṃ varānaṃ paṭhamaṃ dadāmī”ti.
analyzed: passāsi mam vassa satam arogam etam varānam paṭhamam dadāmi iti
translated: Behold me, hale and hearty, a hundred years. This is the first boon I grant.”

original: Tattha varānanti catunnaṃ varānaṃ paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: tattha varānam ti catunnam varānam paṭhamam
translated: Here “boons” means the first of the four boons.

original: Tato bodhisatto āha –
analyzed: tatas bodhisattaḥ āha
translated: Then the Bodhisatta said:

original: “Ye khattiyāse idha bhūmipālā, muddhābhisittā katanāmadheyyā;
analyzed: ye khattiyāse idha bhūmipālāḥ kata nāmadheyyā
translated: “The nobles here who rule the land, anointed, bearing their own name,

original: Na tādise bhūmipatī adesi, etaṃ varānaṃ dutiyaṃ varāmī”ti.
analyzed: na tādise bhūmipatī adesi etam varānam dutiyam varāmi iti
translated: To such as these the king shall not give up his subjects. This is the second boon I grant.”

original: Tattha katanāmadheyyāti muddhani abhisittattāva “muddhābhisittā”ti katanāmadheyyā. Na tādiseti tādise khattiye na adesi mā khādi.
analyzed: tattha kata nāmadheyyā ati muddhani muddhābhisittā ati kata nāmadheyyā na tādisā iti tādise khattiye na adesi mā khādi
translated: Here “bearing their own name” means that they are called “anointed” because they are anointed on the head. “To such as these the king shall not give up his subjects” means that he shall not give them up to be eaten by such nobles.

original: Iti so dutiyaṃ varaṃ gaṇhanto parosatānaṃ khattiyānaṃ jīvitavaraṃ gaṇhi. Porisādopissa dadamāno āha –
analyzed: iti saḥ dutiyam varam gaṇhantaḥ parosatānam khattiyānam jīvita varam gaṇhi porisādopissa dadamānaḥ āha
translated: Thus, in asking for a second boon, he asked for the lives of the two hundred and odd Khattiyas. Porisada, in granting the boon, said:

original: “Ye khattiyāse idha bhūmipālā, muddhābhisittā katanāmadheyyā;
analyzed: ye khattiyāse idha bhūmipālāḥ kata nāmadheyyā
translated: “Those Khattiyas who are here, the rulers of the earth, anointed, with names made known,

original: Na tādise bhūmipatī ademi, etaṃ varānaṃ dutiyaṃ dadāmī”ti.
analyzed: na tādise bhūmipatī a demi etam varānam dutiyam dadāmi iti
translated: I do not give them up, the rulers of the earth; this is the second boon I grant.”

original: Kiṃ pana te tesaṃ saddaṃ suṇanti, na suṇantīti? Na sabbaṃ suṇanti. Porisādena hi🔽rukkhassa dhūmajālaupaddavabhayena paṭikkamitvā aggi kato, aggino ca rukkhassa ca
analyzed: kim pana te tesam saddam suṇanti na suṇanti iti na sabbam suṇanti porisādena hi  rukkhassa dhūma jāla opaddava bhayena paṭikkamitvā aggi kataḥ aggino ca rukkhassa ca
translated: But did they all hear what was said? No, not all of them heard it. For Porisada,

original: antare nisīditvā mahāsatto tena saddhiṃ kathesi, tasmā sabbaṃ asutvā upaḍḍhupaḍḍhaṃ
analyzed: antare nisīditvā mahāsatto tena saddhim kathesi tasmai sabbam a sutvā upaḍḍhupaḍḍham
translated: fearing that the smoke from the fire would be a danger to the tree, had gone away, and had made the fire; and he sat down between the fire and the tree and talked with the Great Being. Therefore, not hearing all, they heard

original: suṇiṃsu. Te “idāni sutasomo porisādaṃ damessati, mā bhāyathā”ti aññamaññaṃ samassāsesuṃ.
analyzed: te idāni suta somaḥ porisādam damessati mā bhāyatha ati aññam aññam samassāsesuṃ
translated: half and half. They comforted one another, saying: “Now Sutasoma will tame Porisada; do not fear.”

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe mahāsatto imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe mahāsattaḥ imam gātham āha
translated: At that moment the Great Being spoke this verse:

original: “Parosataṃ khattiyā te gahītā, talāvutā assumukhā rudantā;
analyzed: parosatam khattiyā te gahītā talāvutā assu mukhā rudantā
translated: “Two hundred and odd Khattiyas are taken, bound, with tearful faces, weeping;

original: Sake te raṭṭhe paṭipādayāhi, etaṃ varānaṃ tatiyaṃ varāmī”ti.
analyzed: sake te raṭṭhe paṭipādayāhi etam varānam tatiyam varāmi iti
translated: “In your own realm, O King, set them free. This is the boon I choose.”

original: Tattha parosatanti atirekasataṃ. Te gahītāti tayā gahitā. Talāvutāti hatthatalesu āvutā.
analyzed: tattha atireka satam te gahītā ati tayā gahitā talāvutā ati hattha talesu āvutā
translated: Herein, more than a hundred means more than a hundred. Taken by you means taken by you. On the palms of your hands means on the palms of your hands.

original: Iti mahāsatto tatiyaṃ varaṃ gaṇhanto tesaṃ khattiyānaṃ sakaraṭṭhaniyyātanavaraṃ gaṇhi.
analyzed: iti mahāsatto tatiyam varam gaṇhanto tesam khattiyānam sakaraṭṭha niyyātana varam gaṇhi
translated: Thus the Great Being, in choosing the third boon, chose the boon of the nobles’ banishment from his own realm.

original: Kiṃkāraṇā? So akhādantopi verabhayena sabbe te dāse katvā araññeyeva vāseyya, māretvā🔽vā chaḍḍeyya, paccantaṃ netvā vā vikkiṇeyya, tasmā tesaṃ sakaraṭṭhaniyyātanavaraṃ
analyzed: kiṃkāraṇā saḥ a khādantaḥ api vera bhayena sabbe te dāse katvā a raññeya iva vāseyya māretvā  vā chaḍḍeyya paccantam netvā vā vikkiṇeyya tasmā tesam sa karaṭṭha niyyātana varam
translated: Why? If he did not eat them, he would make them all slaves and keep them in the forest, or he would kill them and

original: gaṇhi. Itaropissa dadamāno imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: imam gātham āha
translated: throw them away, or he would take them to the frontier districts and sell them. Therefore he chose the boon of their banishment from his own realm. The other, in giving the boon, spoke this verse:🔽“More than a hundred nobles have been taken by you,

original: “Parosataṃ khattiyā me gahītā, talāvutā assumukhā rudantā;
analyzed: parosatam khattiyā me gahītā talāvutā assu mukhā rudantā
translated: With tears on their faces and weeping,

original: Sake te raṭṭhe paṭipādayāmi, etaṃ varānaṃ tatiyaṃ dadāmī”ti.
analyzed: sake te raṭṭhe paṭipādayāmi etam tatiyam dadāmi iti
translated: In your own realm, O King, set them free. This is the boon I choose.”

original: Catutthaṃ pana varaṃ gaṇhanto bodhisatto imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: catuttham pana varam gaṇhantaḥ bodhisatto imam gātham āha
translated: But in choosing the fourth boon the Bodhisatta spoke this verse:🔽“Your realm is rent, O King, and in fear and terror

original: “Chiddaṃ te raṭṭhaṃ byathitā bhayā hi, puthū narā leṇamanuppaviṭṭhā;
analyzed: chiddam te raṭṭham byathitāḥ bhayā hi puthū narāḥ leṇam anuppaviṭṭhā
translated: Many people have gone to the forest for shelter.

original: Manussamaṃsaṃ viramehi rāja, etaṃ varānaṃ catutthaṃ varāmī”ti.
analyzed: manuḥ sa maṃsam viramehi rāja etam varānam catuttham varāmi iti
translated: “Turn away from human flesh, O King, this is the fourth boon I ask.”

original: Tattha chiddanti na ghanavāsaṃ tattha tattha gāmādīnaṃ uṭṭhitattā savivaraṃ. Byathitā
analyzed: na ghana vāsam tattha tattha gāma ādīnam uṭṭhita ttā sa vivaram byathitā
translated: Herein, cleft means not solid, not compact, with holes here and there, because it is made up of villages, etc., that have arisen there.

original: bhayāhīti “porisādo idāni āgamissatī”ti tava bhayena kampitā. Leṇamanuppaviṭṭhāti
analyzed: bhayāhi iti porisādaḥ idāni āgamissati iti tava bhayena kampitā leṇam anuppaviṭṭhā ati
translated: Terrified means trembling through fear of you, thinking “Porisāda will come now.”🔽They have gone to their lairs means they have gone to their hiding-places in the grass thickets, etc., after taking their children by the hand.

original: dārake hatthesu gahetvā tiṇagahanādinilīyanaṭṭhānaṃ paviṭṭhā. Manussamaṃsanti duggandhaṃ
analyzed: dārake hatthesu gahetvā tiṇa gahana ādi nilīyana ṭhānam paviṭṭhāḥ manussa maṃsanti duggandham
translated: Human flesh means human flesh that is stinking, disgusting, repulsive.

original: jegucchaṃ paṭikkūlaṃ manussamaṃsaṃ pajaha. Nissakkatthe vā upayogaṃ, manussamaṃsato viramāhīti attho.
analyzed: jeguccham paṭikkūlam manussa maṃsam pajaha nissakka tthe vā upayogam manussa maṃsataḥ viramāhi iti atthaḥ
translated: Give up human flesh. Or the meaning can be taken as “Turn away from the use of human flesh for the purpose of eating it.”

original: Evaṃ vutte porisādo pāṇiṃ paharitvā hasanto “samma sutasoma kiṃ nāmetaṃ kathesi, kathāhaṃ tumhākaṃ etaṃ varaṃ dassāmi, sace gaṇhitukāmo, aññaṃ gaṇhāhī”ti vatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam vutte porisādaḥ pāṇim paharitvā hasantaḥ samma sutasoma kim nāma etam kathesi kathā aham tumhākam etam varam dassāmi sace gaṇhitu kāmaḥ aññam gaṇhāhi iti vatvā gātham āha
translated: When this was said, Porisāda struck his hand against his thigh and laughed, saying, “What is this you are saying, my dear Sutasoma? How can I give you this boon? If you want to take it, take another.” And he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Addhā hi so bhakkho mama manāpo, etassa hetumhi vanaṃ paviṭṭho;
analyzed: addhā hi so bhakkhaḥ mama manāpaḥ etassa hetumhi vanam paviṭṭhaḥ
translated: “Surely this food is to my liking, For this I entered on the wood;

original: Sohaṃ kathaṃ etto upārameyyaṃ, aññaṃ varānaṃ catutthaṃ varassū”ti.
analyzed: sā uham katham ettas upārameyyam aññam varānam catuttham varassu ti
translated: How can I get out of this? I ask for a fourth boon, a better one.”

original: Tattha vananti rajjaṃ pahāya imaṃ vanaṃ paviṭṭho.
analyzed: tattha vananti rajjam pahāya imam vanam paviṭṭhaḥ
translated: Herein, he “entered the forest” after renouncing his kingdom.

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto “tvaṃ ‘manussamaṃsassa piyatarattā tato viramituṃ na sakkomī”ti vadasi. Yo hi piyaṃ nissāya pāpaṃ karoti, ayaṃ bālo”ti vatvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam mahāsatto tvam manussa maṃsassa piyatarattā tatas viramitum na sakkomi iti vadasi yaḥ hi piyam nissāya pāpam karoti ayam bālaḥ iti vatvā gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Being said, “You say that you cannot refrain from eating human flesh because you love it so much. But a fool is he who, in the pursuit of what he loves, does evil. ” So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,

original: “Na ve ‘piyaṃ me’ti janinda tādiso, attaṃ niraṃkacca piyāni sevati;
analyzed: na ve piyam mā iti janinda tādisaḥ attam niraṃkacca piyāni sevati
translated: “A king should not, for the sake of what he loves, abandon his own self. He who abandons his self for the sake of what he loves,

original: Attāva seyyo paramā ca seyyo, labbhā piyā ocitatthena pacchā”ti.
analyzed: attā ava seyyo paramā ca seyyo labbhā piyā ocitatthena pacchā ati
translated: His self is better than what he loves. After a time he may get what he loves, but his self is better than what he loves.

original: Tattha tādisoti janinda tādiso yuvā abhirūpo mahāyaso “idaṃ nāma me piya”nti piyavatthulobhena
analyzed: tattha tādisaḥ iti janinda tādisaḥ yuvā abhirūpaḥ mahāyasaḥ idam nāma me piyanti piya vatthu lobhena
translated: Herein, tādiso means “such a one,” a young man, handsome, famous. “I love this,” he says, and out of greed for what he loves,

original: tattha attānaṃ niraṃkatvā sabbasugatīhi ceva sukhavisesehi ca cavitvā niraye pātetvā
analyzed: tattha attānam sabba su gatīhi ca iva sukha visesehi ca cavitvā niraye pātetvā
translated: he abandons his self, and for the sake of what he loves, he gives up all the pleasures of heaven and the special pleasures of the gods, and he is reborn in hell.

original: na ve piyāni sevati. Paramā ca seyyoti purisassa hi paramā piyavatthumhā attāva varataro.
analyzed: na ve piyāni sevati paramā ca seyyā uti purisassa hi paramā piya vatthumhā attā ava varataraḥ
translated: He does not, for the sake of what he loves, abandon his self. His self is better than what he loves.

original: Kiṃkāraṇā? Labbhā piyāti, piyā nāma visayavasena ceva puññena ca ocitatthena vaḍḍhitatthena
analyzed: kiṃkāraṇā labbhā piyā ati piyā nāma visaya vasena ca iva puññena ca ocitatthena vaḍḍhitatthena
translated: Why? Because it is possible to get what is dear. What is dear is the object of merit, the meaning of “accomplished,” the meaning of “increased,”

original: diṭṭhadhamme ceva parattha ca devamanussasampattiṃ patvā sakkā laddhuṃ.
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamme ca iva parattha ca deva manussa sampattim patvā sakkā laddhum
translated: and after attaining the human and divine good in this very life and in the next, it is possible to get it.

original: Evaṃ vutte porisādo bhayappatto hutvā “ahaṃ sutasomena gahitaṃ varaṃ vissajjāpetumpi manussamaṃsato viramitumpi na sakkomi, kiṃ nu kho karissāmī”ti assupuṇṇehi nettehi gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam vutte porisādaḥ bhaya pattaḥ hutvā aham sutasomena gahitam varam vissajjāpetum pi manussa maṃsataḥ viramitum pi na sakkomi kim nu kho karissāmi iti assu puṇṇehi nettehi gātham āha
translated: When this was said, Porisāda, being frightened, thought, “I am not able to release the boon taken by Sutasoma nor to abstain from human flesh. What shall I do?” With eyes full of tears he spoke this verse:

original: “Piyaṃ me mānusaṃ maṃsaṃ, sutasoma vijānahi;
analyzed: piyam me mānusam maṃsam suta soma vijānahi
translated: “I love human flesh, Sutasoma, know;

original: Namhi sakkā nivāretuṃ, aññaṃ varaṃ samma varassū”ti.
analyzed: namhi sakkā nivāretum aññam varam samma varassu ti
translated: I am not able to be restrained, choose another boon, good sir.”

original: Tattha vijānahīti tvampi jānāhi.
analyzed: tattha vijānahi iti tvam pi jānāhi
translated: Herein, know means you also know.

original: Tato bodhisatto āha –
analyzed: tatas bodhisattaḥ āha
translated: Then the Bodhisatta said:

original: “Yo ve ‘piyaṃ me’ti piyānurakkhī, attaṃ niraṃkacca piyāni sevati;
analyzed: yaḥ ve piyam mā iti piya anurakkhī attam piyāni sevati
translated: “He who, saying ‘I love,’ loves in return, and serves the dear ones, not caring for himself,

original: Soṇḍova pitvā visamissapānaṃ, teneva so hoti dukkhī parattha.
analyzed: soṇḍā uva pitvā tena iva saḥ hoti dukkhī parattha
translated: Like a pig that has drunk water mixed with poison, he is miserable thereby in the next world.

original: “Yo cīdha saṅkhāya piyāni hitvā, kicchenapi sevati ariyadhamme;
analyzed: yaḥ ci idha saṅkhāya piyāni hitvā kicchena api sevati ariya dhamme
translated: “But he who, having considered, abandons the dear ones, and serves the noble Dhamma, though it be with difficulty,

original: Dukkhitova pitvāna yathosadhāni, teneva so hoti sukhī paratthā”ti.
analyzed: dukkhitaḥ uva pitvāna yathā usadhāni tena iva saḥ hoti sukhī parattha ati
translated: Having drunk the poison, he is miserable, but by the medicine he is happy in the future.”

original: Tattha yo veti, samma porisāda, yo puriso “idaṃ me piya”nti pāpakiriyāya attānaṃ
analyzed: tattha yaḥ veti samma porisāda yaḥ purisaḥ idam me piyanti pāpa kiriyāya attānam
translated: Herein, he who, “This is dear to me,” and, for the sake of his dear things,

original: niraṃkatvā piyāni vatthūni sevati, so surāpemena visamissaṃ suraṃ pitvā soṇḍo viya
analyzed: piyāni vatthūni sevati saḥ surā pemena visamissam suram pitvā soṇḍaḥ viya
translated: neglects himself, and resorts to evil deeds, he, like a drunkard who has drunk liquor mixed with poison,

original: tena pāpakammena parattha nirayādīsu dukkhī hoti. Saṅkhāyāti jānitvā tuletvā. Piyāni
analyzed: tena pāpa kammena parattha niraya ādīsu dukkhī hoti saṅkhāya ati jānitvā tuletvā piyāni
translated: by that evil deed is miserable in the future in the hells, etc. Having understood, having weighed, having considered,🔽having abandoned the dear things,

original: hitvāti adhammapaṭisaṃyuttāni piyāni chaḍḍetvā.
analyzed: hitvā ati adhamma paṭisaṃyuttāni piyāni chaḍḍetvā
translated: which are connected with unrighteousness,

original: Evaṃ vutte porisādo kalūnaṃ paridevanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam vutte porisādaḥ kalūnam paridevantaḥ gātham āha
translated: When this was said, Pāyāsi, lamenting, spoke this verse:

original: “Ohāyahaṃ pitaraṃ mātarañca, manāpiye kāmaguṇe ca pañca;
analyzed: pitaram mātaram ca kāma guṇe ca pañca
translated: “Having abandoned father and mother, and the five dear qualities of sensual pleasure,

original: Etassa hetumhi vanaṃ paviṭṭho, taṃ te varaṃ kinti mahaṃ dadāmī”ti.
analyzed: etassa hetumhi vanam paviṭṭho tam te varam kinti maham dadāmi iti
translated: I have entered the forest for the sake of this; what great boon shall I give you?”

original: Tattha etassāti manussamaṃsassa. Kinti mahanti kinti katvā ahaṃ taṃ varaṃ demi.
analyzed: tattha etassa ati manussa maṃsassa kinti mahanti kinti katvā aham tam varam demi
translated: Herein, this means human flesh. What great boon means what shall I give you for it?

original: Tato mahāsatto imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas mahāsattaḥ imam gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Being spoke this verse:

original: “Na paṇḍitā diguṇamāhu vākyaṃ, saccappaṭiññāva bhavanti santo;
analyzed: na paṇḍitāḥ diguṇam āhu vākyam bhavanti santaḥ
translated: “The wise do not speak twice, they say, when they have given their word;

original: ‘Varassu samma’ iti maṃ avoca, iccabravī tvaṃ na hi te sametī”ti.
analyzed: samme iti mam avocaḥ id ca bravīḥ tvam na hi te sameti iti
translated: ‘Choose, good sir,’ you said to me, but now you do not keep your word.”

original: Tattha diguṇanti, samma porisāda, paṇḍitā nāma ekaṃ vatvā puna taṃ visaṃvādentā dutiyaṃ🔽vacanaṃ na kathenti. Iti maṃ avocāti, “samma sutasoma varassu vara”nti evaṃ maṃ abhāsasi.
analyzed: tattha samma porisāda paṇḍitāḥ nāma ekam vatvā puna tam visaṃvādentā dutiyam  vacanam na kathenti iti mam avoca ati samma suta soma evam mama abhāsasi
translated: Herein, twice, good sir, means, good sir Porisada, the wise do not speak once and then, by deceiving, speak a second time.🔽So you said to me is what you said to me, namely, “Good sir Sutasoma, choose a boon.”

original: Iccabravīti tasmā yaṃ tvaṃ iti abravi, taṃ te idāni na sameti.
analyzed: tasmai yam tvam iti abravi tam te idāni na sameti
translated: But now you do not keep your word means therefore what you said to me does not now agree with what you are doing.

original: So puna rodanto eva gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ punar rodantaḥ eva gātham āha
translated: Then he wept and spoke this third stanza:🔽“The gain of demerit, the infamy, the lack of fame,

original: “Apuññalābhaṃ ayasaṃ akittiṃ, pāpaṃ bahuṃ duccaritaṃ kilesaṃ;
analyzed: apuñña lābham ayasam akittim pāpam bahum duccaritam kilesam
translated: The many sins, the evil conduct, the defilement,🔽That have come about through human flesh—what boon, I ask,

original: Manussamaṃsassa kate upāgā, taṃ te varaṃ kinti mahaṃ dadeyya”nti.
analyzed: manussa maṃsassa kate upāgā tam te varam kinti maham dadeyyanti
translated: Can I give you now?”

original: Tattha pāpanti kammapathaṃ appattaṃ. Duccaritanti kammapathappattaṃ. Kilesanti dukkhaṃ.
analyzed: tattha pāpanti kammapatham appattam duccaritanti kammapatha ppattam kilesanti dukkham
translated: Herein, sin means what has not yet become a course of action. Evil conduct means what has become a course of action. Defilement means suffering.

original: Manussamaṃsassa kateti manussamaṃsassa hetu. Upāgāti upagatomhi. Taṃ teti taṃ tuyhaṃ
analyzed: manussa maṃsassa katā iti manussa maṃsassa hetu upāgāti upagataḥ amhi tam te iti tam tuyham
translated: ‘For human flesh’ means ‘for the sake of human flesh.’ ‘I have come’ means ‘I have approached.’ ‘That of yours’ means ‘that which is yours.’

original: kathāhaṃ varaṃ demi, mā maṃ vārayi, anukampaṃ kāruññaṃ mayi karohi, aññaṃ varaṃ gaṇhāhīti āha.
analyzed: kathā aham varam demi mā mama vārayi anukampam kāruññam mayi karohi aññam varam gaṇhāhi iti āha
translated: “For the sake of human flesh” means “for the sake of human flesh.” “I have come” means “I have come to you.” “That” means “that which you have said.” “I will give you a boon” means “I will give you a boon.” “Do not hinder me” means “do not hinder me.” “Have compassion” means “have compassion on me.” “Take another boon” means “take another boon.”

original: Atha mahāsatto āha –
analyzed: atha mahāsattaḥ āha
translated: Then the Great Being said:

original: “Na taṃ varaṃ arahati jantu dātuṃ, yaṃ vāpi datvā na avākareyya;
analyzed: na tam varam arahati jantu dātum yam vā api da tvā na avākareyya
translated: “That boon a man does not deserve to give, which, having given, he would not be glad;

original: Varassu samma avikampamāno, pāṇaṃ cajitvānapi dassamevā”ti.
analyzed: samma a vikampamānaḥ pāṇam dassam eva ati
translated: Choose, good sir, without hesitation, even if it be the giving up of life.”

original: Evaṃ tena paṭhamaṃ vuttagāthaṃ āharitvā dassetvā varadāne ussāhento gāthā āha –
analyzed: evam tena paṭhamam vutta gātham āharitvā dassetvā vara dāne ussāhentaḥ gāthāḥ āha
translated: Having recited this verse first spoken by him, and having shown it, he spoke this verse, encouraging him to give a boon:

original: “Pāṇaṃ cajanti santo nāpi dhammaṃ, saccappaṭiññāva bhavanti santo;
analyzed: pāṇam cajanti santaḥ na api dhammam sacca ppaṭiññāḥ ava bhavanti santaḥ
translated: “The good do not give up life for the sake of the Dhamma, the good are true to their word;

original: Datvā varaṃ khippamavākarohi, etena sampajja surājaseṭṭha.
analyzed: da tvā varam khippam avākarohi etena sampajja su rāja seṭṭha
translated: Having given the boon, quickly be true to your word, by this, best of good kings, be successful.

original: “Caje dhanaṃ aṅgavarassa hetu, aṅgaṃ caje jīvitaṃ rakkhamāno;
analyzed: caje dhanam aṅga varassa hetu aṅgam caje jīvitam rakkhamānaḥ
translated: “For the sake of a limb of the body, one gives up wealth, for the sake of a limb of the body, one protects life;

original: Aṅgaṃ dhanaṃ jīvitañcāpi sabbaṃ, caje naro dhammamanussaranto”ti.
analyzed: aṅgam dhanam jīvitam ca api sabbam caje naraḥ dhammam anussarantaḥ ti
translated: For the sake of a limb of the body, for the sake of wealth, for the sake of life, for the sake of all, a man, following the Dhamma, gives up.”

original: Tattha pāṇanti jīvitaṃ. Santo nāma api jīvitaṃ cajanti, na dhammaṃ. Khippamavākarohīti
analyzed: tattha pāṇanti jīvitam santaḥ nāma api jīvitam cajanti na dhammam khippam avākarohi iti
translated: Herein, ‘life’ means life. Even the good abandon life, but not the Dhamma. ‘Quickly get on board’ means

original: idha khippaṃ mayhaṃ dehīti attho. Etenāti etena dhammena ceva saccena ca sampajja
analyzed: idha khippam mayham dehi iti attho etena ati etena dhammena ca iva saccena ca sampajja
translated: ‘give it to me quickly here.’ ‘By this’ means by this Dhamma and by this Truth,

original: sampanno upapanno hohi. Surājaseṭṭhāti taṃ paggaṇhanto ālapati. Caje dhananti, samma🔽porisāda, paṇḍito puriso hatthapādādimhi aṅge chijjamāne tassa rakkhaṇatthāya bahumpi
analyzed: sampannaḥ upapannaḥ hohi su rāja seṭṭha ati tam paggaṇhantaḥ ālapati caje dhananti samma  porisāda paṇḍito puriso hattha pāda ādimhi aṅge chijjamāne tassa rakkhaṇa tthāya bahumpi
translated: you have been born, you have been produced. ‘Best of the gods’ is an address. ‘Give up wealth’ means, ‘Good Porisāda,

original: dhanaṃ cajeyya. Dhammamanussarantoti aṅgadhanajīvitāni pariccajantopi “sataṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: dhanam cajeyya dhammam anussarantaḥ ti aṅga dhana jīvitāni pariccajantaḥ api satam dhammaṃ
translated: a wise man, when a limb such as a hand or foot is being cut off, would give up much wealth to protect it. ‘Remembering the Dhamma’ means, ‘even though I am giving up limbs, wealth and life,

original: na vītikkamissāmī”ti evaṃ dhammaṃ anussaranto.
analyzed: na vītikkamissāmi iti evam dhammaṃ anussarantaḥ
translated: I will not transgress the Dhamma.’

original: Evaṃ mahāsatto imehi kāraṇehi taṃ sacce patiṭṭhāpetvā idāni attano gurubhāvaṃ dassetuṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam mahāsattaḥ imehi kāraṇehi tam sacce patiṭṭhāpetvā idāni attanaḥ guru bhāvam dassetum gātham āha
translated: Thus the Great Being, having established him in truth by these reasons, now spoke this verse in order to show his own greatness:

original: “Yasmā hi dhammaṃ puriso vijaññā, ye cassa kaṅkhaṃ vinayanti santo;
analyzed: yasmā hi dhammam purisaḥ vijaññā ye ca assa kaṅkham vinayanti santaḥ
translated: ‘For when a man knows the Dhamma, and the good remove his doubts,

original: Taṃ hissa dīpañca parāyaṇañca, na tena mittiṃ jirayetha pañño”ti.
analyzed: tam hissa dīpam ca parāyaṇam ca na tena mittim jirayetha
translated: And with that friend the wise man should not break.

original: Tattha yasmāti yamhā purisā. Dhammanti kusalākusalajotakaṃ kāraṇaṃ. Vijaññāti vijāneyya.
analyzed: tattha yasmā iti yamhā purisāḥ dhammanti kusala akusala jotakam kāraṇam vijaññāti vijāneyya
translated: Herein, as to the “man”: as to the person. As to “the way”: as to the cause that shows what is profitable and unprofitable. “Should know”: should know.

original: Taṃ hissāti taṃ ācariyakulaṃ etassa puggalassa patiṭṭhānaṭṭhena dīpaṃ, uppanne bhaye
analyzed: tam hissa ati tam ācariya kulam etassa puggalassa patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena dīpam uppanne bhaye
translated: “For that”: for that teacher’s family is an island in the sense of a footing for this person,

original: gantabbaṭṭhānaṭṭhena parāyaṇañca. Na tena mittinti tena ācariyapuggalena saha so
analyzed: gantabba ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena parāyaṇam ca na tena tena ācariya puggalena saha saḥ
translated: and a refuge in the sense of a place to go to when fear arises. “And with that friend”: with that teacher as friend,

original: paṇḍito kenacipi kāraṇena mittiṃ na jīrayetha na vināseyya.
analyzed: paṇḍito kenacid pi kāraṇena mittim na jīrayetha na vināseyya
translated: the wise man should not break, should not destroy, any friendship for any reason.

original: Evañca pana vatvā, “samma porisāda, guṇavantassa ācariyassa vacanaṃ nāma bhindituṃ
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā samma porisāda guṇavantassa ācariyassa vacanam nāma bhinditum
translated: After saying this, he went on: “Good Prince, it is not right to break the word of a teacher who has good qualities.

original: na vaṭṭati, ahañca taruṇakālepi tava piṭṭhiācariyo hutvā bahuṃ sikkhaṃ sikkhāpesiṃ,
analyzed: na vaṭṭati aham ca taruṇa kāle pi tava piṭṭhi ācariyaḥ hutvā bahum sikkham sikkhāpesim
translated: And I was your teacher when you were a boy and I taught you much lore,

original: idānipi buddhalīlāya satārahā gāthā te kathesiṃ, tena me vacanaṃ kātuṃ arahasī”ti
analyzed: buddha līlāya gāthā te kathesim tena me vacanam kātum arahasi iti
translated: and now I have told you ten verses in the manner of the Enlightened One. So it is right for you to carry out my word.”

original: āha. Taṃ sutvā porisādo “ayaṃ sutasomo mayhaṃ ācariyo ceva paṇḍito ca, varo cassa🔽mayā dinno, kiṃ sakkā kātuṃ, ekasmiṃ attabhāve maraṇaṃ nāma dhuvaṃ, manussamaṃsaṃ🔽na khādissāmi, dassāmissa vara”nti assudhārāhi pavattamānāhi uṭṭhāya sutasomanarindassa
analyzed: āha tam sutvā porisādaḥ ayam sutasomaḥ mayham ācariyo ca iva paṇḍito ca varo cassa  mayā dinnaḥ kim sakkā kātum ekasmin atta bhāve maraṇam nāma dhuvam manussa maṃsam  na khādissāmi dassāmissa varanti assu dhārāhi pavattamānāhi uṭṭhāya sutasoma narindassa

translated: The Birth Stories are ended.

original: Sumukho pana haṃsavaro ca mahā, sudhabhojaniko ca paro pavaro;
analyzed: sumukhaḥ pana haṃsa varaḥ ca mahā sudha bhojanikaḥ ca paraḥ pavaraḥ
translated: The Sumukha, the great swan, the excellent, the excellent food-eater,

original: Sakuṇāladijādhipativhayano, sutasomavaruttamasavhayanoti.
analyzed: suta soma varuttama sa vhayanaḥ ti
translated: The bird-king, the lord of the birds, the Sutasoma, the best, the excellent.

original: Asītinipātavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: asīti nipāta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the eighty-ninth chapter is finished.

original: Pañcamo bhāgo niṭṭhito.
analyzed: pañcamaḥ bhāgaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The fifth section is finished.
